subject: Con Law
cloze: Incitement of imminent unlawful activity, {{c1::fighting words}}, and {{c2::true threats}} are categories of speech that may be punished and restricted. 1. Incitement of imminent unlawful activity 1.1 Test: The government may punish speech as incitement if: 1.1.1 There is a {{c3::substantial likelihood}} the speech will bring about {{c4::imminent illegal activity}}; and 1.1.2 The speech is {{c5::aimed at causing imminent illegality}}. 1.2 This test, often referred to as the {{c6::modern incitement standard (Brandenburg test)}}, is difficult to satisfy; any law aimed at restricting incitement must be {{c7::narrowly tailored}}. 2. Fighting words 2.1 The government may punish speech as fighting words if it is {{c8::likely to cause an immediate violent response}} against the speaker. 2.2 However, fighting words statutes tend to be {{c9::overbroad}}, {{c10::vague}}, or deemed {{c11::content-based}} and thus often fail under {{c12::strict scrutiny}}. 3. True threats 3.1 True threats are {{c13::not protected speech}}. 3.2 A true threat is a threat communicated with the {{c14::intent to intimidate the recipient}}; the speaker must actually intend to {{c15::instill fear in the recipient}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, several core discovery devices are available: 1. {{c1::Interrogatories (FRCP 33)}}: Written questions served on an opposing party to obtain basic factual information (e.g., identities of documents and witnesses), with {{c2::30 days}} to respond. 2. {{c3::Requests for production (FRCP 34)}}: Written requests for a party to make documents, ESI, or tangible things in its control available for inspection or copying, usually with {{c4::30 days}} to respond; {{c5::non-parties must be compelled by subpoena}}. 3. {{c6::Requests for admission (FRCP 36)}}: Written requests that a party admit facts, application of law to fact, or document genuineness. {{c7::Admissions are conclusively established and need not be litigated at trial}}, and the responding party must {{c8::admit, deny, or state lack of knowledge after reasonable inquiry within 30 days}}. 4. {{c9::Physical or mental examinations (FRCP 35)}}: Available only {{c10::by court order}} when a person's condition is {{c11::in controversy}} and {{c12::good cause}} is shown; if ordered, {{c13::doctor–patient confidentiality for that condition is effectively waived for the litigation}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 1. General Rule (First Restatement – Vested Rights): 1.1 Under the {{c1::First Restatement's Vested Rights Approach}}, the court applies the law of the state where the {{c2::act occurred}} or where the {{c3::relationship that gave rise to the lawsuit developed}}. 1.2 Rights most often vest in the state where the {{c4::last act or event occurred}} that gave rise to the rights being asserted in the lawsuit. 1.3 Conceptual focus: - The approach is {{c5::territorial}}: it looks for the geographic location where a legal right came into existence. - Once the {{c6::vesting state}} is identified, its law governs the {{c7::substantive issues}} related to that right.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: Recognition of divorce-related judgments involves: 1. General rule for interstate recognition of divorce decrees: - Courts must give {{c1::full faith and credit}} to a divorce decree from another state if (a) the decree is {{c2::valid where rendered}} and (b) the rendering state had {{c3::proper jurisdiction}}, which is ordinarily satisfied when at least {{c4::one spouse is domiciled}} there. 2. Jurisdictional nuances: {{c5::ex parte}} vs. {{c6::consent}} divorces: - Ex parte divorces (only one spouse domiciled/appearing): the enforcing court may {{c7::reexamine domicile}} though domicile is {{c8::presumed bona fide}}. - Consent divorces (both spouses appear): if at least {{c9::one spouse is domiciled in the forum}}, the court has jurisdiction and other states must generally give full faith and credit. 3. Child custody determinations: - Custody jurisdiction is generally based on the child’s {{c10::home state}}, whose decree receives {{c11::full faith and credit}} and retains {{c12::continuing jurisdiction}} unless it loses a {{c13::significant connection}} with the child or the parties.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Under {{c1::modern rape statutes}}: 1. The offense is often called {{c2::sexual assault}} or {{c3::sexual battery}} rather than "rape"; 2. The {{c4::slightest penetration}} is sufficient to complete the crime; and 3. {{c5::Marital status}} is {{c6::insignificant}}, and most states have {{c7::abolished marital status as an element}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Defenses to {{c1::contract formation or enforcement}} allow a court to refuse to enforce an otherwise valid agreement, making it {{c2::void or voidable}} by a party. The main categories are: {{c3::incapacity}}, {{c4::Statute of Frauds}}, {{c5::illegality}}, {{c6::misrepresentation/fraud}}, {{c7::duress}}, {{c8::unconscionability}}, {{c9::misunderstanding}}, and {{c10::mistake}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Appeal of certification 1.1 A certification decision can be appealed via {{c1::interlocutory appeal}} before final judgment on the merits. 2. Effect of judgment 2.1 A class judgment is {{c2::binding}} as to all {{c3::absent class members}}, unless they {{c4::opt out}}, if applicable.

subject: Evidence
cloze: For {{c1::scientific}} expert testimony, courts apply {{c2::Daubert}}-style reliability factors in addition to the usual expert foundations. Key (nonexclusive) factors include: - {{c3::Testability}} – Whether the theory or technique {{c4::has been tested and is capable of being tested}}. - {{c5::Peer review and publication}} – Whether it has been {{c6::subject to peer review and publication}}. - {{c7::Error rate}} – The {{c8::known or potential error rate}} and whether it is acceptably low. - {{c9::General acceptance}} – Whether the theory or technique is {{c10::reasonably or generally accepted in the relevant scientific community}}. These factors help the judge, acting as a {{c11::gatekeeper}}, decide if the scientific principles and methods underlying the opinion are {{c12::sufficiently reliable}} for the jury to hear.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Under the {{c1::doctrine of waste}}, a {{c2::life tenant (LT)}} cannot commit acts that constitute an {{c3::unreasonable use of the land}} and/or injure the interests of a {{c4::future interest holder}}; doing so constitutes {{c5::waste}}. There are three main types of waste: - {{c6::Affirmative (voluntary) waste}} – acts of commission that overuse or exploit the property or its natural resources. - {{c7::Permissive waste}} – harm to the property due to the LT's neglect or failure to maintain, repair, or pay carrying charges. - {{c8::Ameliorative waste}} – LT acts that materially change the property but economically benefit the land.

subject: Torts
cloze: General definition and nature of nuisance: 1. {{c1::Nuisance}} is an {{c2::intentional invasion}} of either {{c3::public or private property rights}} that {{c4::substantially and unreasonably interferes}} with the peaceful and quiet enjoyment of those rights. 2. Nuisance is a {{c5::harm, not a standalone tort}}: • It describes a {{c6::type of harm caused by underlying tortious conduct}}, focusing on {{c7::interference with use and enjoyment of property}}, often via {{c8::nontrespassory invasions}} like noise, odors, or smoke.

subject: Real Property
cloze: An {{c1::easement}} is a {{c2::non-possessory property interest}} that confers a {{c3::right to use another's land}}. The burdened land is the {{c4::servient estate}}, and the benefited land—if any—is the {{c5::dominant estate}}. Easements can be {{c6::appurtenant}} or {{c7::in gross}}, and may be {{c8::affirmative}} or {{c9::negative}}. They may be created by {{c10::express grant or reservation}}, {{c11::implication}}, {{c12::necessity}}, or {{c13::prescription}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 3. Scheduling conference 3.1 A scheduling conference is a conference at or after which the judge issues a {{c1::scheduling order}}. 3.2 The scheduling order sets deadlines for {{c2::filing pleadings}}, {{c3::joinder}}, {{c4::amendments}}, and {{c5::discovery deadlines}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: When defamation involves a {{c1::public official}}, a {{c2::public figure}}, or a {{c3::matter of public concern}}, the First Amendment adds requirements. 1. {{c4::Falsity}}: - The plaintiff must prove the statement was {{c5::false}}. 2. Fault standards: 2.1 {{c6::Public officials or public figures}}: - Must prove {{c7::actual malice}}: - {{c8::Knowledge}} that the statement was false; OR - {{c9::Reckless disregard}} as to its truth or falsity. 2.2 {{c10::Private figures}}: - Must prove at least {{c11::negligence}} regarding the truth or falsity of the statement.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: {{c1::Malice crimes}} require a {{c2::reckless disregard of, or undertaking an obvious risk from which a harmful result is expected}}. Major common law malice crimes: - {{c3::Common law murder}} ({{c4::malice aforethought}}). - {{c5::Arson}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. General note on grounds: • Grounds for annulment are typically considered {{c1::voidable}} unless otherwise specified, and their classification {{c2::varies by state}}. 2. Grounds that typically render a marriage {{c3::void}}: • {{c4::Bigamy or polygamy}}: Marriage when one party is already married. • {{c5::Consanguinity}}: Marriage between {{c6::close blood relatives}}. 3. Other common grounds for annulment (usually {{c7::voidable}}): • {{c8::Non-age}}: One spouse was under the {{c9::statutory age}} at the time of marriage. • {{c10::Incurable physical impotence}}: Inability to have {{c11::normal sexual relations}} existing at the time of marriage. • {{c12::Incapacity to consent}} to marriage, including: – {{c13::Mental incompetence}} (did not understand the nature of marriage). – {{c14::Intoxication or incapacitation due to drugs or alcohol}} at the time of marriage. – {{c15::Fraud}} going to an essential aspect of the marriage. – {{c16::Duress or coercion}} that overbore the party’s free will to marry.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 2. {{c1::Exceptions}}: suits against state governments allowed in federal court 2.1 {{c2::Waiver or consent}} – a state may {{c3::explicitly and unequivocally waive}} sovereign immunity or consent to be sued. 2.2 {{c4::Valid Section 5 abrogation}} – Congress may authorize private suits against states when it: • {{c5::clearly expresses}} an intent to abrogate immunity; and • Acts under a {{c6::valid exercise of Section 5}} power (congruent and proportional enforcement of the 14th Amendment). 2.3 {{c7::Federal government suits}} – the {{c8::United States}} may sue a state in federal court; 11th Amendment immunity does not apply. 2.4 {{c9::Bankruptcy proceedings}} – certain {{c10::federal bankruptcy}} proceedings involving states are not barred by the 11th Amendment.

subject: Corporations
cloze: {{c1::Promoter liability}} for pre-incorporation agreements: 0.1 A {{c2::promoter}} is {{c3::personally liable}} for knowingly acting on behalf of a {{c4::corporation (C) before incorporation}}, and remains liable after C comes into existence, unless: 0.1.1 There is a subsequent {{c5::novation}} releasing the promoter from liability. 0.1.2 The {{c6::third party agrees to look only to the corporation for performance}}. 0.1.3 The promoter had {{c7::no actual knowledge that the corporation's charter has not yet been issued}}. {{c8::Fiduciary duty}}: a promoter can be liable to C for violating fiduciary duties. {{c9::Compensation}}: a promoter may seek compensation or reimbursement for related expenses, but {{c10::cannot compel the corporation to pay}} because the acts were not undertaken at C's direction.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Spousal testimonial privilege}}. 1.1. Applies in {{c2::criminal cases only}}. 1.2. A person whose spouse is a {{c3::defendant in a criminal case}} cannot be called as a witness by the {{c4::prosecution}} or compelled to {{c5::testify against the spouse}} in the criminal proceeding. 1.3. Only the {{c6::witness-spouse}} may invoke the privilege (the defendant cannot prevent a willing spouse from testifying). 1.4. The privilege can only be invoked {{c7::during a valid marriage}}. 2. {{c8::Marital communications privilege}}. 2.1. Applies in both {{c9::civil and criminal}} cases. 2.2. {{c10::Confidential communications}} made between spouses during marriage are privileged in any later proceeding. 2.3. The privilege applies even if the spouses {{c11::divorce after the confidential communication}} was made. 2.4. {{c12::Either spouse}} may invoke the privilege. 2.5. A spouse can lose the privilege as to his own use if he {{c13::breaks confidentiality}} by relaying a marital communication to a third party, but the other spouse still retains the privilege. 3. Exceptions where marital communications privilege does not apply. 3.1. {{c14::Suits between spouses}}. 3.2. Suits in which one spouse is charged with a {{c15::crime or tort against the couple’s children}}. 3.3. Suits in which spouses are {{c16::co-defendants}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach}}, a court applies the law of the state with the {{c2::most significant relationship}} to the specific issue. Courts first consider {{c3::general choice-of-law factors}}—such as the {{c4::relevant policies of the forum and other interested jurisdictions}}, the {{c5::policies of the substantive field}}, the {{c6::ease of applying a candidate law}}, and whether applying a given law promotes {{c7::certainty, uniformity, and predictability}}. They then refine the analysis with {{c8::subject-specific contacts}} for different substantive areas, including {{c9::torts, contracts, property, and corporations}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: In most states, the {{c1::settlor}} of a private trust can {{c2::modify or revoke}} the trust unless the trust terms {{c3::expressly prohibit modification or revocation}} (i.e., make the trust irrevocable or unmodifiable).

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Trespass to land}} is a {{c2::physical entry}} of P's {{c3::real property}} by D {{c4::without consent}}. 2. Elements: 2.1 {{c5::Physical entry}} of P's real property by D. 2.1.1 D {{c6::enters P's property or propels an object onto it}}. 2.1.2 Examples: D walks on P's property, throws a ball onto P's property, or chases someone onto P's property. 2.1.3 P need only have {{c7::lawful possession}} of the property; {{c8::ownership is not required}}. 2.1.4 There must be a {{c9::physical invasion}}; invasions by {{c10::light, sound, or smell}} are not trespass. 2.1.5 P's real property includes the {{c11::surface}}, {{c12::immediate airspace}}, and {{c13::subterranean space}} to a reasonable distance. 2.2 {{c14::Intent}}. 2.2.1 {{c15::Intent to enter the land will suffice}}, even if D acts under a reasonable mistake. 2.2.2 D does not need to {{c16::know the land belongs to another}}. 2.3 {{c17::Causation}}. 3. Note: {{c18::Actual damages are not required}}; compare to {{c19::trespass to chattel}} and {{c20::conversion}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Subjacent support}} – definition 1.1 Subjacent support concerns {{c2::underground (subjacent) structures}} that must support the {{c3::surface estate}}. 1.2 Typical subjacent structures include {{c4::parking garages}}, {{c5::tunnels}}, {{c6::mines}}, and similar underground works. 1.3 The duty is to support the {{c7::surface land}} and the structures that existed when the {{c8::subjacent estate}} was created or severed. 2. Liability for failure of subjacent support 2.1 {{c9::Strict liability}}: Subjacent owners are strictly liable if their failure to provide adequate support causes subsidence or damage to the surface land or to {{c10::pre-existing surface structures}}. 2.2 {{c11::Negligence}}: For damage to buildings or structures constructed on the surface {{c12::after}} the subjacent estate was created, the subjacent owner is liable only if {{c13::negligent}}. 2.3 The key distinction is between {{c14::pre-existing}} surface structures, which are protected by strict liability, and {{c15::subsequently constructed}} buildings, which generally require proof of negligence.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Evidence of a person's character is generally inadmissible to prove that they acted in conformity with that character on a given occasion. 1. {{c1::Exceptions}}: character evidence in civil cases is admissible when: 1.1 {{c2::Character is at issue}}: Character is an essential element of a claim or defense (e.g., defamation). In such cases, character can be proved through {{c3::opinion, reputation, or specific instances of conduct}}. 1.2 {{c4::Prior acts of sexual assault or child molestation}} in cases based on similar claims: In civil cases arising from sexual assault or child molestation, the defendant's prior acts of sexual assault or molestation are admissible to prove the defendant's conduct in the present case. This rule also applies in criminal cases. The plaintiff must {{c5::disclose the intent to offer such evidence at least 15 days before trial}}. 1.3 {{c6::Impeachment versus character}}: Distinguish whether evidence of a person's character is being used as {{c7::substantive character evidence}} or for {{c8::impeachment}}. Substantive character evidence is subject to {{c9::greater admissibility restrictions}} than impeachment evidence.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. General definition of {{c1::attempt}}: - Attempt is an act, done with the {{c2::specific intent}} to commit a crime, that constitutes an {{c3::overt or substantial step}} toward committing the crime but {{c4::falls short of completion}}. - An {{c5::incomplete act that would be a crime if completed}} can constitute attempt. 2. Overt act / substantial step requirement: - The defendant must commit an act beyond {{c6::mere preparation}} and take a {{c7::substantial step}} toward committing the target crime. - Under the common law {{c8::"dangerous proximity"}} standard, attempt requires an act that is {{c9::dangerously close to success}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 {{c1::Equitable servitudes}} are {{c2::covenants enforced in equity against successors}} through {{c3::injunctive relief}} (i.e., an injunction is the remedy). 1.2 An equitable servitude is a covenant that will be enforced against {{c4::successors of the burdened land}} who have {{c5::notice}} of the covenant. 1.3 {{c6::Privity is not required}} to bind successors. 2. Creation (requirements): 2.1 {{c7::Writing}}: There must generally be a written promise. 2.1.1 Exception: {{c8::Reciprocal negative servitudes}} may be {{c9::implied from a common scheme for development}} of a residential subdivision. 2.2 {{c10::Intent}}: The original parties must intend to bind successors. 2.3 {{c11::Touches and concerns the land}}: The servitude must affect the parties' legal relations as landowners. 2.4 {{c12::Notice}}: Successors of the burdened land must have notice; notice is {{c13::not required for the benefit to run}}. 2.5 Defenses to enforcement: A court will not enforce an equitable servitude if any of the following conditions exist: 2.5.1 {{c14::Pervasive changes in the neighborhood}}. 2.5.2 {{c15::Estoppel}}. 2.5.3 {{c16::Acquiescence}}. 2.5.4 {{c17::Unclean hands}}. 2.5.5 {{c18::Laches}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::fee simple determinable}} is a fee simple estate that {{c2::automatically terminates and reverts back to the grantor}} upon the happening of a given event or condition. For example: "to A {{c3::so long as}} A practices law"—if A stops practicing law, the property automatically reverts back to the grantor. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 {{c4::Automatic forfeiture}}: Upon occurrence of the given event or condition, the grantee automatically forfeits the estate. 2.2 {{c5::Potentially infinite}}: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur. 2.3 {{c6::Transferable}}: The fee estate is {{c7::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}, subject to the condition. 3. {{c8::Creation and future interest}}: A fee simple determinable requires {{c9::clear durational language}}; words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient. The accompanying future interest is a {{c10::possibility of reverter}}, which is {{c11::retained by the grantor}} and becomes possessory automatically if the event or condition occurs.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Abnormally Dangerous Conditions or Activities}} 1. General rule 1.1. Abnormally dangerous or ultrahazardous activities or conditions give rise to {{c2::strict liability}} for any resulting injuries. 2. Requirements (an abnormally dangerous activity or condition exists if): 2.1. {{c3::Severe risk}}: The condition or activity imposes a severe risk of harm to persons or property. 2.2. {{c4::Cannot be made safe}}: It cannot be made reasonably safe and cannot be performed without a serious risk of harm, {{c5::even with due care}}. 2.3. {{c6::Uncommon}}: The condition or activity is uncommon in the community. 2.3.1. Note: This often arises with {{c7::explosive, toxic, and/or biohazardous materials}}. 3. Injury must result from the abnormally dangerous aspect 3.1. The plaintiff’s injury must result from the {{c8::abnormally dangerous activity or condition itself}}. 3.2. Watch for fact patterns where abnormally dangerous conditions exist but do not cause the plaintiff’s injury. 3.3. Example: A truck carrying toxic waste in sealed containers falls and crashes into the plaintiff’s car but the containers do not spill. 3.3.1. {{c9::No strict liability because the abnormally dangerous nature of the containers did not cause the plaintiff’s injury}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Testimonial hearsay and the Confrontation Clause: 1.1 The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} restricts the admission of prior {{c2::testimonial statements}} by witnesses who do not testify at trial. 2. Unavailable declarant and prior opportunity to cross-examine: 2.1 Prior testimonial statements of an {{c3::unavailable}} witness are admissible against the defendant only if: 2.1.1 The witness is unavailable; and 2.1.2 The defendant had a prior opportunity to {{c4::cross-examine}} the declarant when the statement was made (e.g., at a prior hearing or deposition). 3. Relationship to hearsay law: 3.1 Even if a statement fits a {{c5::hearsay exception}}, it cannot be admitted against a criminal defendant if it is {{c6::testimonial}}, the declarant is {{c7::unavailable}}, and the defendant lacked a prior opportunity to {{c8::cross-examine}}. 3.2 The Confrontation Clause is an independent {{c9::constitutional}} limit on {{c10::testimonial hearsay}} in criminal cases.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Bruton rule – basic principle: 1.1 In a {{c1::joint jury trial}}, a {{c2::co-defendant’s confession}} that directly implicates the defendant is {{c3::inadmissible against the defendant}}, because the defendant cannot effectively confront and cross-examine the confessing co-defendant regarding that statement. 1.2 The same confession may be considered in a {{c4::bench trial}}, because the judge is presumed able to consider it only for the proper party. 2. Exceptions: when a co-defendant’s confession may be admitted: 2.1 The confessing co-defendant {{c5::testifies at trial}} and is subject to {{c6::cross-examination}}. 2.2 The defendants are {{c7::tried separately}} ({{c8::severance of trials}}). 2.3 The confession is properly {{c9::redacted}} so that all portions referring to the co-defendant are eliminated and it does not obviously point to the other defendant. 2.4 The co-defendant’s confession is used only to {{c10::rebut the defendant’s claim}} that the defendant’s {{c11::own confession was obtained coercively}}, and is not used as direct evidence of the defendant’s guilt.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Dissolution}} – overview 1.1 Definition and effect: Dissolution {{c2::terminates the corporation’s legal existence}}, but the corporation continues solely to {{c3::wind up and liquidate its affairs}} and may not carry on {{c4::new or regular business}}. 1.2 Types of dissolution: - {{c5::Voluntary}} dissolution: A {{c6::fundamental change}} requiring {{c7::board and shareholder approval}}. - {{c8::Administrative}} dissolution: Initiated by the {{c9::state}} (e.g., failure to file reports or pay fees) and typically {{c10::curable}}. - {{c11::Judicial}} dissolution: Initiated by the {{c12::attorney general}} (for {{c13::abuse of authority, fraud, or illegality}}) or by {{c14::shareholders}} (for {{c15::deadlock, abandonment, or waste/misuse of assets}}). 2. {{c16::Disposition of property}} – overview 2.1 A sale, lease, or other disposition of {{c17::all or substantially all}} corporate property {{c18::outside the ordinary course of business}} is treated as a {{c19::fundamental change}}. 2.2 It requires approval by both the {{c20::board}} and {{c21::shareholders}}, and "all or substantially all" means the corporation is left without {{c22::significant continuing business activities}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 A defendant may enter a plea bargain, but doing so waives his {{c2::Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial}}. 1.2 For a valid plea bargain, the judge must: 1.2.1 Determine that the plea is {{c3::voluntary and intelligently made}}, and 1.2.2 Ensure that the defendant understands: 1.2.2.1 The {{c4::nature of the charge and its critical elements}}. 1.2.2.2 The {{c5::maximum authorized penalty}} and any {{c6::mandatory sentence}}. 1.2.2.3 That the defendant has a right to {{c7::plead not guilty}}, and 1.2.2.4 That the defendant is {{c8::waiving his right to a jury trial}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Express and implied conditions: 1.1 Conditions can be {{c1::express}} (stated in the contract) or {{c2::implied}} (supplied by law or inferred from the agreement and conduct). 2. Condition precedent: 2.1 A {{c3::condition precedent}} must occur {{c4::before performance is due}}. 2.2 Non-occurrence of a condition precedent {{c5::excuses the other party's performance}}. 2.3 Example: A agrees to buy B's car {{c6::if B gets new tires}}; getting new tires is a {{c7::condition precedent}} to A's duty. 3. Condition subsequent: 3.1 A {{c8::condition subsequent}} occurs {{c9::after performance has begun}} and, when it occurs, {{c10::excuses the duty to continue performing}}. 3.2 The duty exists {{c11::unless and until}} the condition subsequent occurs, at which point it is {{c12::discharged}}. 4. Practical effect: 4.1 Both types tie duties to events, but differ in {{c13::timing}}—{{c14::before performance is due}} (precedent) versus {{c15::after performance has begun}} (subsequent).

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Definition and formation 1.1 Executive agreements are agreements between the {{c1::President}} and {{c2::foreign heads of state}}. 1.2 They require {{c3::no congressional approval}}. 2. Scope of executive agreements 2.1 Executive agreements can be used for {{c4::any purpose}} for which the U.S. might make an international agreement, if otherwise constitutional. 3. Executive agreements in conflict with other law 3.1 Conflict with state law 3.1.1 A valid executive agreement {{c5::prevails over conflicting state law}}. 3.2 Conflict with federal statutes 3.2.1 Executive agreements {{c6::do not prevail over federal statutes}}; statutes control. 3.3 Conflict with the Constitution 3.3.1 Executive agreements {{c7::do not prevail over the Constitution}} and cannot authorize unconstitutional conduct.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: A {{c1::detention}} is a {{c2::governmental seizure}} of a person that is {{c3::less than a full custodial arrest}}. 1. Common governmental detentions: 1.1 {{c4::Stop and frisk}} (a "stop"): 1.1.1 Requires {{c5::reasonable suspicion}}. 1.2 {{c6::Automobile stop}}: 1.2.1 Requires {{c7::reasonable suspicion}}. 1.3 {{c8::Stationhouse detention}}: 1.3.1 {{c9::Probable cause}} is required to compel a person to enter a government location for fingerprinting, questioning, or similar purposes. 1.4 {{c10::Detention to obtain a search warrant}}: 1.4.1 Requires {{c11::probable cause}}. 1.4.2 If police have probable cause to believe a suspect has contraband hidden in her home, they may {{c12::prevent her from entering her home for a reasonable time}} while they obtain a search warrant. 1.4.3 The purpose must be to {{c13::prevent destruction of evidence}}. 1.5 {{c14::Detention of occupants of premises}}: 1.5.1 If police have a valid warrant to search premises, they may {{c15::detain occupants for the duration of the proper search}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: Easements may be expressly created by {{c1::grant}} or {{c2::reservation}}. 2. {{c3::Grant}}: An express grant of the easement is created by an {{c4::instrument (e.g., a written agreement)}} in which the {{c5::servient estate owner}} gives an easement to the {{c6::owner of the dominant estate}}. 3. {{c7::Reservation}}: A grantor conveys title to land but {{c8::reserves the right to continue using the land for a designated purpose}}. The grantor may only reserve an easement {{c9::for himself}}; a reservation that purports to benefit a {{c10::third party is void}}. For example: O conveys property to A, reserving an easement allowing access to a path across the property. 4. Requirements: Express easements must be: 4.1 {{c11::In writing}} (otherwise they violate the {{c12::Statute of Frauds}}); and 4.2 {{c13::Signed by the servient estate holder}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Revocation {{c1::terminates an offer}} and the offeree's {{c2::power of acceptance}}. It generally requires a {{c3::clear indication}} by the offeror of an unwillingness or inability to contract that is {{c4::communicated to the offeree}} and is effective only upon {{c5::receipt}}. Once an offer is {{c6::accepted}}, it can no longer be revoked. Some offers are {{c7::irrevocable}}, including those in {{c8::unilateral contracts once performance begins}}, {{c9::option contracts with consideration}}, {{c10::UCC firm offers}}, and offers on which the offeree has {{c11::reasonably and detrimentally relied}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: {{c1::Intestate succession}} involves the {{c2::distribution of a decedent's assets that are not disposed of by will}}. 1. When intestate succession issues arise: 1.1. The decedent {{c3::dies without a will}}. 1.2. The decedent's will does not dispose of all of her property (for example, a {{c4::gift in the will fails}} or the will lacks a {{c5::residuary clause}}). 1.3. The decedent's will is {{c6::denied probate}} (for example, the will is {{c7::successfully contested}} or {{c8::improperly executed}}). 2. Varying statutory schemes: 2.1. States have {{c9::varying rules}} for how a decedent's assets are distributed through intestate succession (i.e., who is entitled to the assets and in what amounts). 2.2. Because of this variation, exam questions involving intestate distribution often provide the text of a {{c10::hypothetical statute}} governing asset distribution. 3. Terminology: 3.1. {{c11::Heir}} vs. {{c12::beneficiary}}: An heir is one who takes by intestate succession; a beneficiary is one named in a will or trust. 3.2. {{c13::Issue}} and {{c14::descendants}}: These terms are often used interchangeably to describe heirs or lineal descendants of the decedent. 3.3. {{c15::Devise}} and {{c16::bequest}}: These terms are used interchangeably to refer to property disposed of via a will. 3.4. {{c17::Probate estate}}: Roughly refers to property the decedent owned upon death that passes through probate.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: At {{c1::common law}}, {{c2::burglary}} is defined as a {{c3::trespassory breaking and entering}} of the {{c4::dwelling house}} of {{c5::another}} {{c6::at nighttime}} with {{c7::intent to commit a felony therein}}. Required elements: 1. {{c3::Trespassory breaking}}. 2. {{c8::Entering}}. 3. Of the {{c4::dwelling house}}. 4. Of {{c5::another}}. 5. {{c6::At nighttime}}. 6. With {{c7::intent to commit a felony therein}}. Timing of intent: - The defendant must intend to commit a felony {{c9::at the time of the breaking and entering}}. - The {{c10::felony need not be completed}}. - Intent formed only {{c11::after entering is insufficient}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Felony-murder liability is generally limited to {{c1::inherently dangerous felonies}} and {{c2::statutorily enumerated felonies}}. Common underlying felonies include {{c3::burglary}}, {{c4::arson}}, {{c5::rape}}, {{c6::robbery}}, and {{c7::kidnapping}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::5th Amendment Takings Clause}} prohibits the government from taking {{c2::private property}} for {{c3::public use}} without providing {{c4::just compensation}}. Courts ask three main questions: (1) {{c5::Has there been a taking (possessory or regulatory)?}} (2) {{c6::Is the taking for public use (broadly defined)?}} (3) {{c7::Has just compensation (owner’s loss, usually FMV) been paid?}}

subject: Contracts
cloze: Duress involves wrongful pressure that overcomes a party’s free will. 1. Definition: 1.1 Duress is a {{c1::wrongful act or threat}} that overcomes a party's {{c2::free will}}. 2. {{c3::Physical duress}}: 2.1 Physical threats or violence used to obtain assent. 2.2 A contract induced by physical duress is {{c4::void}}. 3. {{c5::Non-physical duress}} (economic or other improper threats): 3.1 Non-physical wrongful acts or threats (e.g., economic duress) that overcome the party’s free will. 3.2 A contract induced by non-physical duress is {{c6::voidable}} by the {{c7::coerced or threatened party}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Only the {{c1::defendant}} can open the door by introducing evidence of the {{c2::victim's character}} to prove {{c3::conduct in conformity}} with that character. Once the defendant offers evidence of the victim's character, the {{c4::prosecution}} may rebut. 1. {{c5::Homicide cases}} 1.1 If the defendant raises {{c6::self-defense}}, the defendant may offer evidence of the victim's character for {{c7::violence}} to show that the victim was the {{c8::first aggressor}}. 1.2 The prosecution may then rebut by offering evidence of the victim's character for {{c9::peacefulness}} to rebut the defendant's claim of self-defense. 2. Methods of proving the victim's character 2.1 {{c10::Direct examination}}: {{c11::reputation}} and {{c12::opinion}} evidence are admissible; evidence of {{c13::specific instances of conduct}} is inadmissible. 2.2 {{c14::Cross-examination}}: reputation, opinion, and specific instances of conduct are admissible.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: In a probate proceeding, a {{c1::personal representative}} is appointed to carry out administration of the decedent's estate. 1. {{c2::Executor}} 1.1 An executor is one {{c3::named in the decedent's will}} to be the personal representative. 1.2 If no executor is named in a will, or the decedent dies intestate, the {{c4::court appoints a personal representative}} (usually a surviving spouse or heir of the decedent). 1.3 Capacity: Any person with the {{c5::capacity to contract}} can be a personal representative (i.e., must be {{c6::mentally competent}} and {{c7::not a minor}}). 2. {{c8::Responsibilities}} 2.1 Generally, a representative or executor handles {{c9::all matters associated with winding up the decedent's estate}}. 2.2 Examples include: {{c10::filing paperwork}}, {{c11::paying creditors}}, {{c12::notifying beneficiaries and devisees}}, and {{c13::managing property distributions}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Venue determines the proper {{c1::judicial district}} in which the plaintiff may bring suit in federal court. 1. Determining proper venue For most actions, venue is proper in: 1.1. Any district where any {{c2::defendant resides}}, if {{c3::all defendants reside in the same state}} in which the district is located. 1.2. Any district in which a {{c4::substantial part of the claim arose}} or in which a {{c5::substantial part of the property}} that is the subject of the action is situated. 1.3. Fallback: If no district satisfies 1.1 or 1.2, venue is proper in any district in which any defendant is subject to {{c6::personal jurisdiction}} with respect to the action. 2. Residency for venue purposes 2.1. People: A natural person resides where they are {{c7::domiciled}}. 2.2. Corporations: A corporation resides in any {{c8::state where it is subject to personal jurisdiction}}. In a state with more than one district, the corporation resides in any district where its {{c9::contacts would be sufficient for personal jurisdiction}} if that district were a separate state. 2.3. Non-corporate businesses: A non-corporate business entity is a resident of {{c10::all districts in which it was subject to personal jurisdiction}} when the action commenced (a broader standard than {{c11::principal place of business}}). 2.4. Unincorporated associations: Residency is determined by the {{c12::location of the association itself}}, not by the {{c13::individual members}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 1. Basic Rule: 1.1 Under the {{c1::Full Faith and Credit Clause}} of the {{c2::U.S. Constitution}}, a state court judgment that is {{c3::valid, final, and on the merits}} must be {{c4::recognized and enforced}} in other states. 1.2 A court in one state may not {{c5::retry an issue that was properly decided}} in another state court proceeding. 1.3 If an issue is barred from re-litigation by virtue of {{c1::full faith and credit}}, no further {{c6::choice-of-law}} analysis is necessary as to that issue or judgment. 2. Scope and Application: 2.1 Although the Full Faith and Credit Clause formally applies only to {{c7::state courts}}, {{c8::federal courts}} follow the same basic framework under {{c9::28 U.S.C. §§ 1738 and 1963}} when issuing or recognizing judgments. 2.2 Courts must give full faith and credit to prior proceedings of U.S. states and territories unless a valid {{c10::defense to recognition or enforcement}} applies (e.g., {{c11::lack of jurisdiction, not on the merits, or no final judgment}}).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. Voluntary manslaughter (imperfect self-defense theory): 1.1 Voluntary manslaughter is a {{c1::killing that would otherwise be murder}} but is mitigated when it occurs under {{c2::imperfect self-defense}}, in jurisdictions that recognize the doctrine. 2. Imperfect self-defense – when it applies: 2.1 If the defendant commits a killing while acting in self-defense, his criminal liability can be reduced to voluntary manslaughter if either: 2.1.1 The defendant {{c3::initiated the altercation}} that required self-defense, or 2.1.2 The defendant {{c4::unreasonably believed that the use of deadly force was necessary}}. 3. Jurisdictional limits: 3.1 Imperfect self-defense is {{c5::not recognized in all jurisdictions}}; where it is not recognized, these circumstances may leave the defendant fully liable for murder. 4. Effect of imperfect self-defense: 4.1 Imperfect self-defense {{c6::does not completely justify}} the killing. 4.2 Where recognized and its conditions are met, it {{c7::mitigates what would otherwise be murder to voluntary manslaughter}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule for intentional torts: 1.1. {{c1::Intentional torts}} are usually {{c2::outside the scope of employment}} and do not trigger respondeat superior. 2. Exceptions – when intentional torts are within the scope: 2.1. {{c3::Job requires use of force}} (e.g., bouncer or security guard using force while doing the job). 2.2. {{c4::Job entails creating friction}} (e.g., bail bondsman whose confrontational role leads to intentional torts). 2.3. Intentional tort is done to {{c5::further the employer’s goals}} (e.g., employee physically breaking up a fight in a store to protect business interests).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::License}}: A license is a {{c2::right to use another person's (the licensor's) land, which is revocable at the licensor's will}}. 1.1 Examples: Oral permission for a neighbor to use the licensor's pool, {{c3::theater tickets}} (grant a license to ticket holders), and the right to use a parking lot. 1.2 Not an interest in land: A license is a {{c4::privilege, not an interest in land}} (distinguish from an {{c5::affirmative easement}}). 1.3 Revocable: The licensor may revoke the privilege at any time, unless {{c6::estoppel}} applies. 1.4 Inalienable: A license may not be {{c7::assigned or transferred}}; any attempt to do so revokes the license. 1.5 No {{c8::Statute of Frauds}} requirement: A license may be oral or written. A license can result from an easement that is invalid under the Statute of Frauds. 1.5.1 Example: An oral grant of a {{c9::permanent easement}} between neighbors may result in a license because the Statute of Frauds is not satisfied. 2. {{c10::Profit}}: A profit is a {{c11::non-possessory property interest}} that entitles its holder to {{c12::enter a servient estate to remove resources}}. 2.1 Examples: {{c13::Minerals, timber, soil, fish}}. 2.2 Rules: All rules governing {{c14::easements}} apply to profits, including rules on {{c15::creation, transferability, and termination}}. 2.3 Extinguishment: A profit may be extinguished through {{c16::misuse or overuse}} of resources on the servient estate.

subject: Torts
cloze: Elements 5 & 6: {{c1::Who can sue}} and {{c2::recoverable damages}}. 1. Who can sue: 1.1 Any {{c3::foreseeable user or bystander}}. 1.2 Examples of foreseeable plaintiffs: 1.2.1 {{c4::Buyers}}. 1.2.2 Their {{c5::guests}}. 1.2.3 {{c6::Employees}}. 1.2.4 {{c7::Family members}}. 2. Recoverable damages: 2.1 P can recover for: 2.1.1 {{c8::Physical injury}} (personal injury). 2.1.2 {{c9::Property damage}}. 2.2 P cannot recover for solely {{c10::economic losses}} in strict products liability.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Negligence theory}} for products liability: 1. General rule: P may establish liability for a product defect under a negligence theory (note: a product defect is almost always easier to establish under a {{c2::strict liability}} theory). 2. Elements: 2.1 {{c3::Duty of care}}: Each {{c4::commercial supplier in the stream of commerce}} owes a duty to all {{c5::foreseeable product users and bystanders}}. 2.2 {{c6::Breach of duty}}: D's negligence leads to the supplying of a {{c7::defective product}}; retailers and wholesalers satisfy due care by a {{c8::cursory inspection}} of the product, which makes it difficult to hold them negligent for product defects. 2.3 {{c9::Causation}}: P must show {{c10::actual and proximate cause}}. Note: an intermediary's negligent failure to discover a defect does not absolve the {{c11::upstream commercial supplier}} of liability. 2.4 {{c12::Damages}}: P must show {{c13::physical injury or property damage}}; {{c14::economic loss alone is not recoverable}}. 2.5 {{c15::Defenses}}: all standard negligence defenses are available.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 4. {{c1::Reformation for a mistake under the UPC}} 4.1 Under the {{c2::UPC}}, a court may {{c3::reform the terms of a will}} to conform to the {{c4::testator's intent}}. 4.2 This requires {{c5::clear and convincing evidence}} that a {{c6::mistake of law or fact}} affected the {{c7::will’s terms and the testator's intent}}. 4.3 Both {{c8::latent}} and {{c9::patent ambiguities}} may be resolved with {{c10::extrinsic evidence}} to carry out the testator’s actual intent.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Courts use {{c1::three tests}} to analyze the constitutionality of government acts under {{c2::substantive due process}} and {{c3::equal protection}}. 1. {{c4::Rational basis}}: a law will be upheld if it is {{c5::rationally related}} to a {{c6::legitimate government purpose}}. 1.1 Any {{c7::conceivable}} legitimate purpose suffices, regardless of the actual purpose of the law. 1.2 A law will almost always be upheld under rational basis review unless it is completely {{c8::irrational or arbitrary}}. 1.3 Burden of proof: the {{c9::challenger}} bears the burden of proof. 2. {{c10::Intermediate scrutiny}}: a law will be upheld if it is {{c11::substantially related}} to an {{c12::important government purpose}}. 2.1 The government’s goal must be {{c13::important}}. 2.2 Courts look at the {{c14::actual reason}} the law was enacted. 2.3 Burden of proof: the {{c15::government}} bears the burden of proof. 3. {{c16::Strict scrutiny}}: a law will be upheld if it is {{c17::necessary}} to achieve a {{c18::compelling government interest}}. 3.1 The government must show there are {{c19::no less restrictive or burdensome means}} of achieving its goal. 3.2 Courts look at the {{c20::actual reason}} the law was enacted. 3.3 Burden of proof: the {{c21::government}} bears the burden of proof.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Double Jeopardy protects a defendant from being prosecuted more than once for the {{c1::same offense}} after {{c2::jeopardy has attached}}. Whether two prosecutions involve the "same offense" is determined under the {{c3::same-elements (Blockburger) test}}, which asks whether each offense requires proof of an {{c4::element the other does not}}. {{c5::Lesser-included offenses}} merge into greater offenses once jeopardy attaches for the greater. Limited {{c6::exceptions}} allow later prosecution for a {{c7::greater offense}} when the greater was not complete or when {{c8::new evidence}} arises (e.g., {{c9::homicide}} after the victim later dies from an earlier {{c10::battery}}). Jeopardy attaches at the start of trial proceedings: when the jury is {{c11::impaneled and sworn}} in a jury trial, when the {{c12::first witness is sworn}} in a bench trial, and when the court {{c13::accepts a guilty plea}}; it does {{c14::not}} attach merely from the {{c15::filing of charges}} or {{c16::grand jury proceedings}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: Both parents have an {{c1::absolute duty to support their children}}. 1. Guidelines and formulas: 1.1 Each state has {{c2::guidelines}} to determine the proper amount of child support owed. 1.2 Guidelines are usually based on a {{c3::formula}} that considers the {{c4::number of children}}, their {{c5::ages}}, {{c6::healthcare needs}}, any {{c7::special needs}}, and parents' {{c8::incomes}}. 1.3 {{c9::Time share}} (how much time the children live with each parent) is also a factor. 2. Duration: Child support obligations generally last until the child {{c10::reaches the age of majority}} or is otherwise {{c11::emancipated}}. 3. Independent from visitation rights: {{c12::Custodial parents cannot deny visitation rights based on a parent's failure to make child support payments}}. 4. Jurisdiction: 4.1 {{c13::Full faith and credit}} is given to child support orders issued in other states as long as the issuing court had proper jurisdiction and the parties had reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard. 4.2 The issuing court has {{c14::continuing exclusive jurisdiction}} to modify the order if the child or one of the parties resides in-state, unless the parties have moved out of state but {{c15::consent to the issuing court's ongoing jurisdiction}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Industry {{c1::custom or usage}} can be used as {{c2::evidence}} of the {{c3::standard of care}} in negligence. However, failure to adhere to custom does not automatically establish a {{c4::breach of duty}}, and compliance with custom does not automatically establish a {{c5::lack of negligence}}. Custom is relevant but {{c6::not dispositive}}; the trier of fact ultimately decides what is reasonable.

subject: Contracts
cloze: If goods are {{c1::destroyed before risk of loss passes}} to the buyer and {{c2::no party is at fault}}, the contract is {{c3::avoided}}—neither party has a duty to perform. If the buyer {{c4::rightfully rejects defective goods}} or {{c5::revokes acceptance}}, {{c6::risk of loss does not pass to the buyer}}. Instead, risk of loss {{c7::remains with the seller}} until the defects are {{c8::cured}} or the buyer {{c9::accepts}} the goods.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::trespasser}} may acquire title to another’s property without compensation by possessing the property for a specified period, in a manner conflicting with the true owner’s rights. 2. Requirements: The trespasser’s possession of the land must be: 2.1 {{c2::Continuous for the statutory period}}: Possession must be similar to an ordinary owner’s use of the property. Daily possession is not required if an ordinary user would not use the property daily (for example, a winter cabin). 2.2 {{c3::Open and notorious}}: The trespasser’s possession must be conspicuous such that the true owner would know of the trespass if he inspected his property regularly. The owner need not actually know of the trespasser’s use. 2.3 {{c4::Actual and exclusive}}: The trespasser must possess a reasonable portion of the property to the exclusion of the owner and the public. 2.4 {{c5::Hostile}}: Possession must be without the owner’s permission. There is no knowledge or intent requirement (the trespasser need not intend to adversely possess). 2.4.1 {{c6::Leasehold}}: If a tenant stays in possession after a lease has expired, he is presumed to have permission (a {{c7::tenancy at sufferance}}), rather than beginning a period of adverse possession.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the old framework, abortion was treated as a {{c1::substantive due process}} right included in the {{c2::right to privacy}}. The analysis turned on {{c3::fetal viability}}. 1. Viability is when a fetus can {{c4::survive outside the womb}}. 2. The law distinguished {{c5::pre-viability}} from {{c6::post-viability}} abortions: before viability the state’s power was more limited, and after viability the state had greater power to {{c7::prohibit abortion (subject to a health exception)}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: A {{c1::divorce decree}} {{c2::terminates the marriage relationship}}. Historically, divorce was {{c3::fault-based}}, requiring proof that one spouse was {{c4::at fault}}. Some states still recognize {{c5::fault grounds}}, but every state now offers {{c6::no-fault divorce}}. Common no-fault grounds include: - {{c7::Irretrievably broken}} marriage (a.k.a. {{c8::irreconcilable differences}}), often the {{c9::primary or exclusive}} ground in some states. - {{c10::Living separate and apart}} for a prescribed period, usually {{c11::six months to one year}}. - {{c12::Incompatibility}} between the spouses.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A person cannot take as an heir or beneficiary unless she {{c1::survives the decedent}}. Issues arise where a decedent and heir or beneficiary die at or about the same time. 1. {{c2::Simultaneous death rules}} 1.1. {{c3::Uniform Simultaneous Death Act (USDA)}} 1.1.1. Property passes as though the beneficiary or heir {{c4::died before the decedent}}, unless there is sufficient evidence that the decedent died first. 1.1.2. The USDA applies to distributions of property by any means, including by {{c5::will, joint tenancy, intestate succession, life insurance}}, and similar transfers. 1.2. {{c6::120-hour rule}} 1.2.1. A beneficiary or heir is treated as having survived the decedent only if there is clear evidence that she survived the decedent by at least {{c7::120 hours (five days)}}. 2. Death caused by beneficiary or heir ({{c8::Slayer Rule}}) 2.1. A person who {{c9::wrongfully causes the death of a decedent}} forfeits any interest in the decedent's estate. 2.2. In such a case, property passes as though the {{c10::killer predeceased the victim}}.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: 1. Definition of {{c1::partnership property}} • Partnership property consists of {{c2::capital contributed}} by each partner and all property {{c3::owned by the partnership}}. • All other property is {{c4::individual property}} of the partners. 2. Property {{c5::deemed}} to be partnership property • Anything {{c6::titled in the partnership name}}. • Anything titled in the name of one or more partners in their capacity as {{c7::partnership members}}. 3. Property {{c8::presumed}} to be partnership property • Property {{c9::purchased with partnership funds}} is presumed to be partnership property, regardless of who has title. 4. Other factors courts consider (when title/funds are unclear) • {{c10::Use of the property by the partnership}}. • {{c11::Entry of the property in partnership books}}. • {{c12::Improvement and maintenance}} of the property with {{c13::partnership funds}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A plaintiff may {{c1::voluntarily dismiss}} her case, either with or without {{c2::leave of court}}. Dismissal will be {{c3::without prejudice}} (the plaintiff can bring the claims again), unless an exception applies. 1. {{c4::Dismissal without leave of court}}: 1.1 This is allowed {{c5::before the defendant serves an answer or a motion for summary judgment}}. 1.2 The plaintiff voluntarily dismisses by filing a {{c6::written notice of dismissal}} or a {{c7::stipulation signed by all parties who have appeared}}. 1.3 Dismissal is without prejudice, provided this is the {{c8::first time that the plaintiff has dismissed her case}}. 1.4 Otherwise, it is {{c9::with prejudice}}. 2. {{c10::Dismissal with leave of court}}: 2.1 This is required if there has been an {{c11::answer, a motion, or a prior dismissal}}. 2.2 The court has {{c12::discretion}} to grant dismissal on such {{c13::terms and conditions as it deems proper}}. 2.3 Dismissal is without prejudice unless the {{c14::court states otherwise}}. 2.4 {{c15::Pending counterclaim}}: if the defendant has filed a counterclaim, the plaintiff cannot voluntarily dismiss without the {{c16::defendant's consent}}.

subject: Agency
cloze: Step 2: {{c1::Apparent authority}} 1. If the agent lacked actual authority, ask: Did the agent have {{c2::apparent authority}}? - Apparent authority arises when the {{c3::principal’s manifestations to the third party}} cause the third party {{c4::reasonably to believe}} the agent is authorized. 2. Effect of apparent authority on the principal: - Apparent authority will {{c5::bind the principal}} to the contract the agent makes with the third party. 3. Effect of apparent authority on the agent: - The agent may be {{c6::liable to the principal}} for acting {{c7::beyond the scope of her actual authority}}, even though the principal is bound to the third party. Step 3: {{c8::Ratification}} 1. If there is no actual or apparent authority, ask: Did the principal {{c9::ratify}} the agent’s unauthorized act? - Ratification occurs when the principal, with {{c10::knowledge of all material facts}}, {{c11::affirms or accepts the benefits}} of the agent’s unauthorized transaction. 2. Effect of ratification: - Ratification can {{c12::bind the principal}} to the agent’s previously unauthorized conduct as if it had been {{c13::authorized from the outset}}. - The principal may still have {{c14::claims against the agent}} for acting without prior authority, depending on their relationship and the circumstances.

subject: Family Law
cloze: Some states recognize traditional {{c1::defenses to divorce}} such as: - {{c2::Collusion}}: spouses agree to fabricate grounds or suppress valid defenses. - {{c3::Condonation}}: the innocent spouse {{c4::forgives}} known misconduct, often by {{c5::resuming cohabitation}}. - {{c6::Recrimination}}: the complaining spouse is also guilty of {{c7::marital misconduct}} ("unclean hands"). In modern practice, however, these defenses are {{c8::less significant}} because courts generally will not {{c9::force a marriage to continue}} if one party seeks dissolution.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A case must be {{c1::justiciable}} to be heard in federal court. This means there must be an actual {{c2::case or controversy}}. To determine whether a case or controversy exists, the case must satisfy requirements for: 1. {{c3::Standing}}; 2. {{c4::Ripeness}}; 3. {{c5::Mootness}}; and 4. The {{c6::political question doctrine}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: {{c1::Misunderstanding}} arises when a {{c2::term is ambiguous}} and the parties attach different meanings. 1. {{c3::Neither party aware of ambiguity}}: - {{c4::No contract is formed}} unless both parties actually intended the same meaning. 2. {{c5::One party aware of ambiguity}}: - {{c6::A contract is formed}}. - The contract is enforced according to the intention of the {{c7::unaware party}}. - If A knows B misunderstands but A remains silent, the contract is enforced according to {{c8::B's understanding}}. 3. {{c9::Both parties aware of ambiguity}}: - {{c10::No contract is formed}} unless both parties actually intended the same meaning.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Donors}}: 1.1. One who produces {{c2::sperm or an egg}} used for reproduction generally does {{c3::not have parental rights}} in a conceived child. 1.2. The {{c4::mother's husband}} is generally presumed to be the {{c5::father}} of a child born from {{c6::artificial insemination}}. 1.3. Most states {{c7::extinguish parental rights}} of sperm or egg donors. 1.4. Exception: Donors may have parental rights if {{c8::agreed to in writing}} by the donor and intended parents. 2. {{c9::Surrogacy}}: 2.1. Surrogacy occurs where a woman agrees to bear a child conceived through {{c10::assisted reproduction}} (using the intended parents' eggs or sperm or both) for the {{c11::intended parents}}. 2.2. Agreement: The {{c12::surrogate}}, the surrogate's {{c13::husband}} (if she is married), and the {{c11::intended parents}} enter into a {{c14::written agreement}} in which the surrogate {{c15::relinquishes her rights and duties as a parent}}. 2.3. Most states allow surrogacy in some form and treat the agreement as a {{c16::contract}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under the federal rules, material is within the scope of discovery if it is {{c1::non-privileged}}, {{c2::relevant}} to a party’s claim or defense, and {{c3::proportional to the needs of the case}}. Proportionality is assessed by considering factors such as {{c4::amount in controversy}}, {{c5::importance of the issues}}, {{c6::parties’ resources}}, {{c7::importance of the discovery to resolving the issues}}, {{c8::parties’ relative access to the information}}, and whether {{c9::the burden or expense of the discovery outweighs its likely benefit}}. {{c10::Privileged material is generally undiscoverable}}, though {{c11::work product}} may be discoverable on a showing of {{c12::substantial need and lack of other means}}, and {{c13::privilege objections must be stated with particularity}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. A {{c1::defendant}} can establish {{c2::personal jurisdiction}} by {{c3::express or implied consent}}. 1.1. The most common form of consent is a {{c4::forum-selection clause}}. 1.2. Courts will enforce forum-selection clauses unless the selected forum is {{c5::remote and alien to the parties or the transaction}}. 1.3. Ensure that the defendant is a {{c6::party to the contract}} containing the clause and that the dispute {{c7::falls within the scope of the clause}}. 2. A defendant can also consent to personal jurisdiction by {{c8::waiving the objection}}. 2.1. The defendant must raise the personal-jurisdiction objection in its {{c9::first appearance (answer or Rule 12 motion)}}. 2.2. The defendant must {{c10::litigate the objection promptly}} or it may be deemed {{c11::waived}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Issue preclusion ({{c1::collateral estoppel}}) prevents relitigation of particular {{c2::issues of fact or law}} that have been {{c3::actually litigated}} and previously {{c4::determined}}. It is {{c5::narrower than claim preclusion}}; it does not necessarily preclude the whole claim, just the same issue. The issue must have been actually litigated, unlike claim preclusion, which only requires an {{c6::opportunity to litigate}}. 1. Requirements: 1.1 {{c7::Final judgment on the merits}}: the first case ended with a valid, final judgment on the merits. 1.2 {{c8::Same issue}}: the same issue was actually litigated and determined in the first case. 1.3 Issue was {{c9::essential to the judgment}}: the judgment would have been different in the first case absent litigation of this issue. It must be clear how the issue was decided by the original trier of fact. 1.4 Asserted against {{c10::actual party to previous case}}: the party against whom issue preclusion is asserted was a party (or in privity with a party) in the prior case. 2. Who may assert issue preclusion: 2.1 {{c11::Mutuality}} (traditional view): only parties to prior litigation can assert issue preclusion. 2.2 {{c12::Non-mutuality}} (modern view): in many jurisdictions, issue preclusion may be asserted by those who were not parties in the prior litigation, subject to fairness limits (e.g., offensive vs. defensive use).

subject: Con Law
cloze: A government law or regulation may be {{c1::invalid}} if it interferes with a group's {{c2::expressive activities}}. This usually involves groups formed for {{c3::expressive, non-intimate purposes}} (e.g., {{c4::NAACP}}, {{c5::KKK}}). Example: The {{c5::KKK}} is not required to accept {{c6::non-white members}} when that exclusion is integral to its {{c7::organizational message}}. Forcing inclusion that would significantly alter or burden an expressive group's message can violate {{c8::freedom of association}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: {{c1::Felony murder}} is a killing that occurs during the {{c2::attempt or commission}} of certain felonies. The intent required for felony murder is simply the {{c3::intent necessary to commit the underlying felony}}; no separate {{c4::intent to kill}} is required.

subject: Agency
cloze: An agency relationship can end by {{c1::act or agreement of the parties}} or by {{c2::operation of law}}. 1. Termination by parties (agency can be terminated by the parties where): 1.1 {{c3::Party desire}}: either party manifests to the other the desire to terminate the agency relationship (termination is effective when {{c4::notice is received}}); 1.2 {{c5::Expiration}}: the express terms of the agency expire; and 1.3 {{c6::Purpose fulfilled}}: the purpose of the agency relationship has been fulfilled. 2. Termination by operation of law (can occur where): 2.1 The agent or principal {{c7::dies}}; 2.2 The agent or principal {{c8::loses capacity}}; and/or 2.3 The agent {{c9::materially breaches a fiduciary duty}} owed to the principal.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Classifications based on {{c1::alienage (citizenship status)}} are generally subject to {{c2::strict scrutiny}}. However, {{c3::rational basis}} review applies if the classification is: 1. Related to {{c4::self-government and the democratic process}}: 1.1 This often arises where job applicants are denied {{c5::government employment}} based on their citizenship status. 1.2 Areas where alienage classifications have been upheld under rational basis review include: 1.2.1 {{c6::Voting}}; 1.2.2 {{c7::Serving on a jury}}; 1.2.3 {{c8::Working as a police officer}}; 1.2.4 {{c9::Working as a teacher}}; and 1.2.5 {{c10::Working as a probation officer}}. 2. A {{c11::congressional law regulating immigration}}: 2.1 Congress has {{c12::plenary power}} to regulate immigration. 2.2 {{c13::Undocumented (unlawful) aliens}} are not considered a {{c14::suspect classification}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Common-law murder is the {{c1::unlawful killing of another human being with malice aforethought}}, and the defendant must {{c2::actually and proximately cause}} the victim’s death. Malice aforethought can be satisfied by four mental states: {{c3::intent to kill}}, {{c4::intent to inflict great bodily injury}}, {{c5::depraved-heart recklessness}}, or {{c6::felony murder}} (a killing during an {{c7::inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony}}). For felony murder, the only intent required is the {{c8::intent to commit the underlying felony}}. Any act by the defendant that {{c9::hastens the victim’s death}} is treated as a cause, even if death was already inevitable.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A non-party {{c1::absentee}} may intervene in a pending suit {{c2::as of right}}. Intervention as of right must be allowed if either of the following is satisfied: 1. {{c3::Interest + harm + inadequate representation}}: • The absentee has an {{c4::interest in the subject matter}} of the action; • The absentee’s interest will be {{c5::harmed (practically impaired or impeded)}} if not joined; and • No existing party will {{c6::adequately represent}} that interest. 2. {{c7::Unconditional statutory right}}: • The absentee has an {{c8::unconditional statutory right to intervene}}. If one of these bases exists and the motion is {{c9::timely}}, the court {{c10::must permit}} intervention.

subject: Evidence
cloze: A court may exclude logically relevant evidence if its {{c1::probative value}} is {{c2::substantially outweighed}} by the danger of {{c3::unfair prejudice, confusion of issues, misleading the jury, undue delay, or waste of time}}. 1. Exclusion of relevant evidence often arises with evidence that is: 1.1 {{c4::Emotionally disturbing}}. 1.2 {{c5::Repetitive or confusing}}. 1.3 {{c6::Admissible for one purpose but inadmissible for another}} (and excluded to avoid the risk of the jury using the evidence for the improper purpose). Note: {{c7::Unfair surprise is not a valid ground}} for excluding relevant evidence. 2. Balancing test 2.1 To exclude relevant evidence, its probative value must be substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice. 2.2 Memorize this standard; wrong MBE answer choices may use similar, but incorrect, language. 3. Exception 3.1 {{c8::Impeachment evidence based on convictions for crimes involving false statements}} is not subject to discretionary exclusion. 4. Evidentiary hearings 4.1 The court may conduct a hearing on the admissibility of evidence or other {{c9::preliminary questions (e.g., witness qualification)}}. 4.2 The court must conduct such a hearing {{c10::outside the presence of the jury}} when required by rule or to avoid unfair prejudice.

subject: Evidence
cloze: A witness can be impeached by {{c1::contradiction}} and by {{c2::prior inconsistent statements (PIS)}}. - {{c1::Contradiction}} uses any evidence showing the witness has made contradictory statements on {{c3::material issues}}. - {{c2::PIS}} may be proved by {{c4::cross-examination}} or {{c5::extrinsic evidence}}, subject to {{c6::collateral-matter limits}} and a {{c7::foundation}} opportunity for the witness to {{c8::explain or deny}} (except for a {{c9::hearsay declarant}}). - If the PIS is {{c10::hearsay}}, it is admissible only for {{c11::impeachment}}; if it is {{c12::nonhearsay}} or within a hearsay {{c13::exemption or exception}}, it is admissible {{c14::for any purpose}}, including to prove the truth of the matter asserted.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: {{c1::Strict liability crimes}} do {{c2::not require proof of any mens rea}} as to one or more elements of the offense; the prosecution need only prove the {{c3::voluntary act and any required attendant circumstances}}. Common strict liability offenses: - {{c4::Statutory rape}}. - {{c5::Regulatory crimes}}. - {{c6::Administrative crimes}}. - {{c7::Morality crimes}} (e.g., {{c8::bigamy, polygamy}}).

subject: Partnerships
cloze: To prove a partnership exists, courts look first to the parties’ {{c1::intent}} to carry on a business as {{c2::co-owners}}; a partnership can be formed even if they did not intend to be in a “partnership.” Primary factor – {{c3::Profit-sharing}} presumption: • A person who receives a share of a business’s profits is {{c4::presumed to be a partner}}. • Exceptions: There is {{c5::no presumption}} when profits are received as payment of a {{c6::debt}}, {{c7::rent}}, {{c8::wages}}, or {{c9::services rendered}} (i.e., as a business expense rather than a profit distribution). Lesser, non-presumptive factors: • {{c10::Sharing of control/management}} of the business; • {{c11::Capital investment or contributions}}; and • {{c12::Joint ownership of property}} used in the business.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Consent}}: 1. General rule: Consent is a {{c2::defense to all intentional torts}}—if P consents to D's otherwise tortious conduct, D is not liable for that act. 1.1 {{c3::Capacity required}}: P must be capable of consenting. 1.2 Examples: {{c4::Drunks, mentally impaired persons, and young children}} are generally incapable of consenting to tortious conduct. 2. {{c5::Express consent}}: P gives D {{c6::verbal or written consent}}; this is nullified by {{c7::duress, fraud, or certain mistakes}}. 3. {{c8::Implied consent}}: D can reasonably infer P's consent based on {{c9::custom}} or P's {{c10::observable conduct}}. 3.1 Implied consent often arises if P {{c11::participates in an activity}} or {{c12::goes to a place where torts are common}}. 3.2 Example: If P plays tackle football, P has given implied consent to {{c13::certain forms of battery}}. 3.3 Consent is usually implied for {{c14::ordinary contacts of daily life}} (e.g., brushing against someone on a crowded sidewalk or public transportation). 3.4 Facts must indicate that, based on P's {{c15::objective conduct}}, D was {{c16::reasonable in interpreting P's consent}}. 4. {{c17::Scope of consent}}: D can be held liable for conduct that {{c18::exceeds the scope}} of P's valid consent (express or implied).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::bona fide purchaser (BFP)}} is one who {{c2::purchases property for value}} (i.e., gives pecuniary consideration) {{c3::without notice of a prior conveyance}}. Whether a buyer is a BFP is important in the context of {{c4::recording statutes}}. 2. Purchasers: 2.1 Include {{c5::mortgagees for value}}. 2.2 Do not include {{c6::donees, heirs, or devisees}}. 2.3 Donees, heirs, and devisees are not protected by the recording statutes unless the {{c7::Shelter Rule}} applies. 3. {{c8::Notice}}: a buyer has notice of a prior conveyance by any of the following: 3.1 {{c9::Actual notice}}: {{c10::actual knowledge}} from any source. 3.2 {{c11::Inquiry notice}}: what a {{c12::reasonable inspection}} of the land or further investigation of facts would reveal, regardless of whether the buyer actually inspects. 3.3 {{c13::Record notice}}: knowledge that would be obtained from a {{c14::routine title search}}, such as a previous conveyance properly recorded in the {{c15::chain of title}} (not a {{c16::wild deed}}).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::successor in interest to the burdened estate}} will be bound by a covenant if the following requirements are satisfied. 1.1 {{c2::Writing}}: The original covenant was in writing. 1.2 {{c3::Intent}}: The original parties intended to bind successors in interest; look to the language of the covenant. Courts are liberal in construing the requisite intent. 1.3 {{c4::Touches and concerns the land}}: The covenant must affect the parties' {{c5::legal relations as landowners}} (a very low standard). {{c6::Homeowner association fees}} satisfy this requirement. 1.4 {{c7::Horizontal and vertical privity}}: Both must exist between the interested parties. 1.4.1 {{c8::Horizontal privity}}: The relationship between the original covenanting parties (for example, {{c9::grantor/grantee, landlord/tenant, fee ownership/easement right in the same land, mortgagor/mortgagee}}). 1.4.2 {{c10::Vertical privity}}: The relationship between the covenanting parties and their successors in interest (for example, {{c11::contract, devise, or descent}}). 1.5 {{c12::Notice}}: The successor in interest had notice of the covenant when she took her interest.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A prior restraint is a {{c1::court order or other governmental ban on speech or publication before it occurs}} and is {{c2::presumptively invalid}}. It is subject to {{c3::strict scrutiny}}, so it is very difficult to uphold. To be valid, a prior restraint must further a {{c4::significant governmental interest}} (such as a concrete, non-theoretical {{c5::national security}} or other special societal harm) and include {{c6::strong procedural safeguards}}—the restraint must be {{c7::narrow, reasonable, and definite}} and provide {{c8::prompt, final judicial review}}. Prior restraints commonly appear as {{c9::injunctions preventing speech}} (including those aimed at preserving a fair trial) and as {{c10::licensing or permit schemes}} that condition speech on prior approval; these are valid only in {{c11::narrow, carefully reviewed circumstances}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Non-deadly self-defense is justified when: 1. {{c1::No fault}}: The defendant is not at fault in starting the confrontation (i.e., not the {{c2::initial aggressor}}). 2. {{c3::Reasonable belief}} of necessity against {{c4::imminent unlawful force}}: The defendant reasonably believes that non-deadly force is necessary to protect himself from imminent unlawful force. 3. {{c5::No duty to retreat}}: There is generally no duty to retreat before using non-deadly force. 4. {{c6::Proportionate force}}: The amount of force used must be proportionate to the threat and to the nature of the provoking offense.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Constitutional basis 1.1 Article II gives the {{c1::President}} authority to {{c2::make treaties}} and appoint ambassadors. 2. Definition and formation of treaties 2.1 Definition 2.1.1 Treaties are formal agreements between the {{c3::United States and foreign countries}} negotiated by the President. 2.2 Effectiveness 2.2.1 A treaty becomes effective as U.S. law only upon ratification by {{c4::two-thirds of the Senate}}. 3. Treaties in conflict with other law 3.1 Conflict with state law 3.1.1 A valid treaty {{c5::prevails over conflicting state law}}. 3.2 Conflict with federal statute 3.2.1 Between a treaty and a federal statute, the {{c6::most recent in time prevails}}. 3.3 Conflict with the Constitution 3.3.1 The {{c7::Constitution}} always prevails over a conflicting treaty.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, if the decedent is survived only by a {{c2::spouse}} and has {{c3::no descendants or parents}}, the surviving spouse takes {{c4::the entire intestate estate}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 2. Application by Substantive Area – Property and Corporations: 2.3 {{c1::Property}} (situs rule): - The court applies the law of the state where the {{c2::property is located}} (the {{c3::situs}}). 2.4 {{c4::Tangible personal property}}: - The court applies the law of the state where the tangible personal property was located at the time of the {{c5::relevant transaction}}. - Rationale: The right in the chattel is treated as vesting at the {{c6::situs of the chattel}} when the right was {{c7::created or transferred}}. 2.5 {{c8::Corporations}} (internal affairs): - When the issue involves {{c9::internal corporate affairs}} (e.g., shareholder disputes, director duties), the court applies the law of the state where the {{c10::corporation is incorporated}}. - This reflects the idea that corporate internal rights and obligations {{c11::vest}} under the law of the {{c12::incorporating state}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Directors and officers owe a {{c1::duty of loyalty}} to the corporation, which prohibits them from {{c2::profiting at the corporation’s expense}}. This duty commonly arises with {{c3::conflicts of interest}}, {{c4::safe-harbor rules for conflicted transactions}}, and {{c5::the corporate opportunity doctrine}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Infancy as a defense to criminal liability: 1. Children {{c1::under 7 years old}}: - {{c2::No criminal liability}} (conclusive presumption of incapacity). 2. Children ages {{c3::7–14 years}}: - {{c4::Rebuttable presumption}} against criminal liability, - The prosecution may rebut by showing the child {{c5::understood the wrongfulness}} of his conduct and had sufficient {{c6::capacity to form the required mens rea}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Definition of a condition: 1.1 A {{c1::condition}} is an agreed-upon {{c2::limitation on performance}} in a contract. 1.2 Performance is {{c3::contingent on the occurrence of some event}}; the conditioned duty {{c4::does not arise or is discharged}} unless and until the event occurs. 1.3 Conditions are often indicated by words such as {{c5::"if," "provided that," "on condition that"}}. 1.4 Example: A agrees to buy B's car {{c6::if B gets new tires}}; B getting new tires is a {{c7::condition}} of A's performance. 2. Condition vs. promise: 2.1 Failure of a {{c8::promise}} leads to a {{c9::breach}} and {{c10::liability for damages}}. 2.2 Failure of a {{c11::condition}} {{c12::relieves the party's performance obligation}}—the duty {{c13::never arises or is discharged}}. 2.3 Characterizing a term as a {{c14::condition}} versus a {{c15::promise}} changes whether {{c16::nonoccurrence}} results in {{c17::breach with damages}} or merely {{c18::excuse of performance}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 2. {{c1::Voir dire}} (jury selection) 2.1 Jury selection process - During voir dire, each party may seek to remove prospective jurors either {{c2::for cause}} or through {{c3::peremptory challenges}}. 2.2 {{c4::For-cause}} strikes - Basis: Used to remove a potential juror for legally sufficient cause, such as {{c5::bias}}, {{c6::prejudice}}, or a close {{c7::relationship}} to a party or witness. - Number: Each side has an {{c8::unlimited}} number of for-cause challenges, but each must be supported by an adequate reason recognized by the court. 2.3 {{c9::Peremptory}} challenges - Number: Each side generally has {{c10::3}} peremptory challenges in federal civil cases. - Basis: May be used for any reason, but the reason must be {{c11::race-neutral}} and {{c12::gender-neutral}}; peremptory challenges cannot be used to intentionally discriminate on the basis of race or gender.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Tacking and Concurrent Owners: 1. {{c1::Tacking}}: Adverse possessors can tack together successive periods of adverse possession to satisfy the statutory period, even if successive possession was by different adverse possessors. 1.1 Must be {{c2::successive}}: There cannot be gaps between periods of adverse possession. 1.2 {{c3::Privity}}: Tacking requires privity between successive adverse holders, satisfied if the subsequent possessor takes by {{c4::descent}}, {{c5::devise}}, or by {{c6::deed purporting to convey title}}. Tacking is not permitted if one adverse claimant {{c7::ousts}} the preceding claimant. 2. {{c8::Concurrent owners}}: Co-tenants may not adversely possess each other’s interests unless {{c9::ouster}} has occurred. To adversely possess a co-tenant’s interest, the co-tenant must be excluded from the land for the statutory period, and the statutory period begins once exclusion (ouster) begins.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Defenses to {{c1::attempt}}: 1. {{c2::Legal impossibility}}: - Legal impossibility {{c3::is a defense}} to attempt. - It applies when, even if the defendant did everything he intended, his conduct {{c4::would not be a crime}}. 2. {{c5::Factual impossibility}}: - Factual impossibility {{c6::is not a defense}} to attempt. - It applies when {{c7::external or factual circumstances}} (e.g., an {{c8::empty pocket}} for a pickpocket) prevent completion. 3. {{c9::Abandonment}}: - At {{c10::common law}}, abandonment {{c11::is not a defense}} to attempt. - Under the {{c12::majority rule}}, attempt liability arises once the defendant commits an {{c13::overt act concurrently with the specific intent}} to commit the crime; he is liable for attempt {{c14::before he can abandon}} the crime.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::Establishment Clause}} prohibits government acts that {{c2::establish or sponsor religion}} or {{c3::give preference to one religion over another}}.
