Under the traditional {{c4::Lemon test}}, a government act concerning religion is valid only if all three prongs are met: 1) {{c5::Secular purpose}} – the act has a secular (nonreligious) purpose; 2) {{c6::Primary effect neutral}} – its primary effect neither {{c7::advances nor inhibits religion}}; 3) {{c8::No excessive entanglement}} – it does not create {{c9::excessive government entanglement with religion}}. Failure of any prong means the action {{c10::violates the Establishment Clause}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In federal class actions, {{c1::absent class members}} are not each required to satisfy {{c2::minimum contacts}} with the forum state. Instead, their due process rights are protected through procedural safeguards: - {{c3::Reasonable and adequate notice}} must be provided to class members. - Class members must be given an {{c4::opportunity to opt out}} where the applicable rule (e.g., Rule 23(b)(3)) requires it. - The {{c5::named class representatives}} must {{c6::adequately represent}} the interests of the absent class members. If these protections are in place, the {{c7::personal jurisdiction due process}} requirements for absent class members are satisfied without individualized minimum contacts.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Invoking the Fifth Amendment Right to Counsel (Miranda) 1. An accused may terminate custodial interrogation by invoking the {{c1::Fifth Amendment right to counsel}}. 2. Once the accused {{c2::unambiguously requests counsel}}, police must cease all questioning on {{c3::any topic}}. 3. This {{c4::Fifth Amendment right to counsel}} is different from the {{c5::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}}, which is {{c6::offense-specific}} and attaches only once {{c7::formal charges are filed}}. 4. If the accused {{c8::initiates communication}} after invoking counsel, interrogation may resume, but only with a {{c9::valid Miranda waiver}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Governing law for real property 1.1. Real property is subject to the law of the jurisdiction where it is situated (the {{c1::situs}}). 1.2. For example: A dispute over property in California is generally governed by {{c2::California law}}. 1.3. This rule applies to the {{c3::disposition of real property}}, whether by {{c4::descent}}, {{c5::deed}}, or other method. 2. Contracts related to real property 2.1. Contracts related to real property are generally governed by the law of the {{c6::place where the property is situated}}. 2.2. However, traditional {{c7::conflict-of-law rules}} may apply if the property is {{c8::merely incidental to a contract}} and the contract is of a {{c9::personal nature}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: The board of directors is ultimately responsible for {{c1::corporate management}}, but it usually does not handle {{c2::day-to-day operations}} itself. 1. {{c3::Delegation to officers}} - The board sets {{c4::overall policy and strategy}}. - It delegates daily management to {{c5::corporate officers and executives}} (e.g., CEO, CFO), who act as {{c6::agents of the corporation}} within granted authority. 2. {{c7::Board committees}} - The board may create {{c8::committees}} composed of one or more {{c9::directors}}. - Committees may be empowered to {{c10::oversee specific aspects of corporate affairs}} (e.g., audit or compensation). 3. {{c11::Limits on committee authority}} - Committees cannot make certain {{c12::major corporate decisions}} reserved to the full board. - Typically, committees may not {{c13::declare dividends}}, {{c14::amend the articles}}, {{c15::adopt or amend bylaws}}, or {{c16::approve fundamental changes}} requiring full board or shareholder approval.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, when the decedent is survived by {{c2::issue not related to the surviving spouse}} (non-spousal kids), the surviving spouse takes {{c3::$150,000}} and {{c4::one-half}} of the {{c5::remaining property}}, with the other {{c6::half of the remainder}} going to the {{c7::decedent’s non-spousal descendants}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Every land sale contract contains two key {{c1::implied promises}} and associated remedies if they are breached before closing: 1. An implied promise of {{c2::marketable title}}—that the seller will deliver title at closing that is {{c3::free from a reasonable risk of litigation}}. 2. An implied promise regarding {{c4::condition and disclosures}}—that the seller will not make {{c5::material misstatements}} and will {{c6::disclose known latent material defects}} (plus an {{c7::implied warranty of quality}} for new construction). If these promises are breached and not cured before closing, the buyer may seek {{c8::contract and equitable remedies}}. If the buyer does not act before closing, the land sale contract {{c9::merges into the deed}}, generally limiting the seller’s liability to {{c10::deed covenants}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Legislative veto}} 1.1 A legislative veto is an attempt by Congress to {{c2::overturn or block agency action}} taken under delegated authority by passing a {{c3::one‑house or two‑house resolution}} without following the full lawmaking process. 1.2 Legislative vetoes are {{c4::unconstitutional}} because Congress must comply with {{c5::bicameralism and presentment}} to change legal rights or obligations. To override agency action, Congress must enact a {{c6::superseding law passed by both houses and presented to the President}}. 2. {{c7::Presidential line‑item veto}} 2.1 A line‑item veto is the supposed power of the President to {{c8::approve a bill but cancel specific provisions}} (e.g., spending items) after enactment. 2.2 The line‑item veto is {{c9::unconstitutional}}. The President cannot {{c10::veto only part of a bill}}; doing so would be an impermissible {{c11::delegation of legislative power to the President}} because it lets the President {{c12::unilaterally amend or repeal parts of statutes}}. Under the Presentment Clause, the President must {{c13::sign or veto a bill in its entirety}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The Supreme Court’s jurisdiction and review powers break down into four key areas: 1. {{c1::Original jurisdiction}} (suits between states; foreign ambassadors and ministers; cannot be expanded by Congress). 2. {{c2::Methods of review}} (primarily discretionary {{c3::certiorari}}, with limited {{c4::mandatory}} appeals from {{c5::three-judge district court panels}} on {{c6::injunctive relief}}). 3. {{c7::Final judgment}} and {{c8::limits on appellate jurisdiction}} (review of {{c9::final judgments}} only; Congress may {{c10::limit}} but not expand jurisdiction within Article III). 4. {{c11::Adequate and independent state grounds}} (no review if the state law ground is {{c12::independent}} of federal law and {{c13::adequate}} to support the judgment).

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Security interests}} are created by contract (a {{c2::security agreement}}), and security agreements are typically: 1.1 In {{c3::writing}}. 1.2 {{c4::Signed or otherwise authenticated by the debtor}}. 1.3 Inclusive of a {{c5::description of the collateral}}. 1.4 Once a security interest {{c6::attaches}}, the obligation is secured, meaning the creditor has a right to take the collateral if the debtor {{c7::defaults}} (i.e., fails to pay). 2. Requirements for {{c8::attachment}} (three requirements for a security interest to attach): 2.1 {{c9::Valid security agreement}}: 2.1.1 An agreement memorializing the security interest. 2.1.2 It may be evidenced by either: 2.1.2.1 An {{c10::authenticated security agreement}}, or 2.1.2.2 The creditor's {{c11::possession or control of the collateral}}. 2.1.3 {{c12::Authenticated security agreement}}: a record authenticated by the debtor that describes the collateral. 2.1.4 Signing, initialing, or similar acts are adequate proof of {{c13::authentication}}. 2.1.5 The agreement must {{c14::reasonably identify the collateral}}. 2.2 {{c15::Value}}: 2.2.1 The secured party (i.e., creditor) must give value to create a security interest. 2.2.2 For example, the creditor loans the debtor money or delivers equipment in exchange for the security interest. 2.2.3 Almost any {{c16::consideration}} is sufficient. 2.3 {{c17::Rights in collateral}}: 2.3.1 The debtor must have rights in the property offered as collateral. 2.3.2 {{c18::Ownership or a sufficient possessory interest}} is usually enough.

subject: Real Property
cloze: An {{c1::easement}} is a {{c2::non-possessory property interest}} that confers a {{c3::right to use another's land}}. The {{c4::servient estate}} is the {{c5::burdened land}}. The {{c6::dominant estate}} is the {{c7::benefited land}}, and it is not present in every easement (e.g., easements in gross).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Voluntary manslaughter is a {{c1::killing that would otherwise be murder}} but is mitigated when it results from either {{c2::adequate provocation (a heat of passion killing)}} or {{c3::imperfect self-defense}} (in jurisdictions that recognize it). Adequate provocation mitigates murder when strong provocation causes loss of self-control without sufficient cooling-off, and imperfect self-defense mitigates when the defendant kills while purporting to act in self-defense but either started the confrontation or unreasonably believed deadly force was necessary.

subject: Evidence
cloze: An otherwise admissible {{c1::out-of-court statement}} offered against the {{c2::defendant in a criminal case}} may be excluded under the {{c3::Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause}}. 1. An out-of-court statement offered against the defendant will be excluded if: 1.1 The {{c4::declarant is currently unavailable}}. 1.2 The defendant had {{c5::no prior opportunity to cross-examine}} the declarant about the statement. 1.3 The statement is {{c6::testimonial}}. 1.4 Exception: an out-of-court statement will not be excluded if the declarant is unavailable as a result of the defendant's own wrongdoing ({{c7::forfeiture by wrongdoing}}). 2. {{c8::Testimonial}} statements include: 2.1 Prior statements made during {{c9::court proceedings}}. 2.2 Statements made in furtherance of a {{c10::police investigation}} (for example, a statement aimed at producing evidence potentially relevant to a later prosecution). 2.3 {{c11::Business records}} are not generally considered testimonial. 2.4 Exception: statements made to police during an {{c12::ongoing emergency}} are {{c13::non-testimonial}} and can be admitted without violating the Confrontation Clause.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Personal jurisdiction}} involves the court's ability to exercise authority over parties or their property. 1.1. The core concept is {{c2::fairness}}—i.e., is it fair for this court to exercise jurisdiction over this defendant? 1.2. The court must balance the {{c3::state's interest in protecting its citizens}} with {{c4::due process rights protecting against unfair exercise of jurisdiction}}. 1.3. Perform this analysis for {{c5::each defendant separately}}. 1.4. {{c6::Statutory and constitutional constraints}} can limit the court's jurisdiction. 2. Personal-jurisdiction analysis: jurisdiction must be both {{c7::statutorily authorized}} and {{c8::constitutional}}. 2.1. Statutory: an applicable state law must authorize jurisdiction. Usually a {{c9::long-arm statute}} will apply. 2.2. Constitutional: jurisdiction must satisfy {{c10::due process}}. 2.2.1. {{c11::Minimum contacts}}: parties must have minimum contacts with the forum state. 2.2.2. {{c12::Adequate notice}}: parties must receive adequate notice of the action and an {{c13::opportunity to be heard}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. General Rule 1.1. A {{c1::rejection by the offeree}} {{c2::terminates the offer}} and the offeree's {{c3::power of acceptance}}. 2. Express Rejection 2.1. Express rejection occurs when the offeree {{c4::clearly communicates that they do not accept}} the offer. 2.2. Express rejection is {{c5::effective when received}} by the offeror. 2.3. Once an offer is rejected, the offeree can no longer accept it unless the offeror {{c6::renews or re-extends the offer}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Scope of {{c1::psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege}}. 1.1. Protects material conveyed by the {{c2::patient (client)}} to a psychotherapist or social worker. 1.2. Applies in {{c3::all civil or criminal cases}}. 2. Requirements. 2.1. The client {{c4::intends the communication to be confidential}}. 2.2. The communication is made to {{c5::facilitate therapy or social work}}. 3. Relation to attorney–client privilege. 3.1. In most ways, this privilege operates similarly to the {{c6::attorney–client privilege}}, protecting confidential communications made for the purpose of obtaining professional help or advice in the therapeutic context.

subject: Agency
cloze: A person is generally not liable for the acts of another unless that other person has been made the person's {{c1::representative}} and given the {{c2::power to bind}} them. In agency law, a principal can be bound to a contract made by another only when that person is acting as the principal’s {{c3::agent}} with power to bind the principal. This power to bind can arise through three main bases: 1. {{c4::Actual authority}}. 2. {{c5::Apparent authority}}. 3. {{c6::Ratification}}. To analyze whether a principal is bound by an agent’s contract with a third party, apply a structured sequence: 1. Ask whether the agent had {{c7::actual authority}}. 2. If not, ask whether there was {{c8::apparent authority}}. 3. If neither exists, ask whether the principal nonetheless became bound through {{c9::ratification}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Court approval of settlement 1.1 The court must {{c1::approve any settlement}} reached between class representatives and the opposing party. 2. Standard for approval 2.1 A class settlement must be {{c2::fair, reasonable, and adequate}}. 3. Procedure and input from absent class members 3.1 In deciding whether to approve or reject the settlement, the court will seek {{c3::feedback}} (e.g., {{c4::notice}} and {{c5::objections}}) from absent class members.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. Directors and officers owe the corporation a {{c1::fiduciary duty of care}}. In determining whether that duty was breached, courts apply the {{c2::Business Judgment Rule}}. A director or officer act that fails to pass scrutiny under the Business Judgment Rule will be deemed a {{c3::breach of the duty of care}}. 2. {{c4::Business Judgment Rule}}: courts will not second-guess a poor or erroneous decision made by a director or officer if the decision was made: 2.1 in {{c5::good faith}}; 2.2 with the care that an {{c6::ordinarily prudent person in a like position would exercise under similar circumstances}}; and 2.3 in a manner the director or officer {{c7::reasonably believed to be in the best interests of the corporation}}. 3. Liability for breach of duty of care: if a director or officer breaches the duty of care, they can be held {{c8::personally liable for damages}}. 3.1 Limiting liability: the {{c9::articles of incorporation}} can limit directors' and officers' personal liability for {{c10::monetary damages for breaches of the duty of care}}. 3.2 Exceptions: the articles cannot limit director or officer liability for: 3.2.1 {{c11::Intentional violations of law}}. 3.2.2 {{c12::Unlawful corporate distributions}}. 3.2.3 {{c13::Receiving unentitled financial benefits}}. 3.2.4 {{c14::Intentionally inflicted harm on the corporation or its shareholders}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the old framework, abortion was treated as a {{c1::substantive due process}} {{c2::privacy}} right. The core analysis turned on {{c3::fetal viability}}: {{c4::before viability}} the state could not {{c5::ban abortion}} and could regulate only if there was no {{c6::undue burden}}; {{c7::after viability}} the state could {{c8::prohibit abortion}} but had to allow abortions when {{c9::medically necessary to protect the mother's health}}. Additional rules governed {{c10::minors (judicial bypass)}} and the lack of any {{c11::constitutional duty to fund or provide abortions}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Congress’s power to regulate {{c1::intrastate commerce}} depends on whether the activity is {{c2::economic}} or {{c3::non‑economic}}. 1. {{c4::Intrastate economic activity}}: Congress may regulate if there is a {{c5::rational basis}} to conclude that the activity, in the {{c6::aggregate}}, {{c7::substantially affects interstate commerce}}. 2. {{c8::Intrastate non‑economic activity}}: Congress may regulate only if the activity itself has a {{c9::direct, substantial economic effect}} on interstate commerce—a {{c10::tougher burden}} than for economic activity.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A {{c1::default judgment}} against a defendant may be entered when the defendant {{c2::fails to plead or otherwise defend}} a properly served complaint. 1. {{c3::Procedure}}: 1.1 The plaintiff files a {{c4::motion for default judgment}} against the defendant. 1.2 The {{c5::clerk enters default on the docket}} if the plaintiff shows that the defendant failed to respond within {{c6::21 days}} of being served ({{c7::60 days}} if service was waived). 1.3 Entry of default does not automatically entitle the plaintiff to {{c8::recovery}}. 1.4 The {{c9::clerk or the judge}} must then enter a {{c10::judgment of default}}. 2. {{c11::Default judgment by court clerk}}: The clerk may enter default judgment if: 2.1 The defendant has {{c12::not responded at all}}. 2.2 The claim is for {{c13::money damages}}. 2.3 The plaintiff provides an {{c14::affidavit of the sum owed}}. 2.4 The defendant is not a {{c15::minor or incompetent}}. 3. {{c16::Default judgment by court}}: If the elements above for clerk entry are not met, the court may still enter a default judgment and may hold a {{c17::hearing on damages}}. If the defendant has appeared at some point in response to the plaintiff's complaint, the defendant must get {{c18::7 days' notice}} of a hearing on the default motion. 4. {{c19::Recovery}}: Recovery on default is limited to the {{c20::amount demanded in the complaint}}. 5. {{c21::Setting aside default judgment}}: The court may set aside a default judgment for {{c22::good cause shown within one year}}, usually satisfied if the defendant can show {{c23::excusable neglect, mistake, or fraud}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Best Evidence Rule}} (general rule). 1.1. If evidence is offered to {{c2::prove the contents of a writing}}, an {{c3::original document}} must be used unless it is unavailable. 1.2. A "{{c4::writing}}" includes any {{c5::tangible collection of data}} (e.g., videos, documents, photos, books, e-mails, text messages, computer drives, x-rays). 2. Applicability. 2.1. The rule applies only if the evidence is offered to {{c6::prove the contents}} of the writing (e.g., a witness’s knowledge is obtained from a writing, or the case turns on the contents of a legal instrument). 3. Evidence sufficient to prove a writing’s contents. 3.1. {{c7::Originals}}. 3.2. {{c8::Duplicates}}: must be a {{c9::machine or carbon copy}} and are admissible unless there is a {{c10::genuine question as to the authenticity of the original}} itself. 3.3. {{c11::Testimony regarding contents}}: admissible if the original is {{c12::lost or destroyed}}, unless it was lost or destroyed {{c13::in bad faith by the proponent}} of the testimony. 3.4. {{c14::Voluminous documents exception}}: a voluminous series of documents may be {{c15::summarized in court}}; the originals relied upon must be {{c16::available for inspection}}. 4. {{c17::Completeness doctrine}}. 4.1. If a party introduces part of a writing or recorded statement into evidence, an adverse party may introduce any other part—or any other writing or recorded statement—that {{c18::in fairness should be considered at the same time}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: As a general rule, {{c1::government-owned land}} {{c2::cannot be acquired}} by adverse possession. Public property held by the {{c3::federal}}, {{c4::state}}, or often {{c5::local}} government is generally {{c6::immune}} from adverse possession unless a statute clearly provides otherwise.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Required responses to allegations 1.1 For each allegation, the defendant must respond in the answer. 2. Available types of responses 2.1 {{c1::Admit}} the allegation. 2.2 {{c2::Deny}} the allegation. 2.2.1 Failure to deny an allegation (other than as to {{c3::damages}}) can operate as an {{c4::admission}}. 2.3 State {{c5::lack of sufficient information}} to admit or deny the allegation. 3. Practical effect 3.1 Allegations not denied are generally {{c6::treated as admitted}}, except those relating solely to {{c7::damages}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general: Most contracts are governed by either {{c1::common law}} or the {{c2::UCC}}. 1.1. {{c3::Common law}}: 1.1.1. Applies to most contracts, except {{c4::sales of goods}}. 1.1.2. Any contract not involving the sale of goods should be treated under common law contract principles. 1.1.3. Generally applies to contracts for {{c5::real estate}} or {{c6::services}}. 2. {{c7::UCC Article 2}}: 2.1. Governs the {{c8::sale of goods}}. 2.2. If both parties to a contract are {{c9::merchants}}, the UCC has additional special rules (e.g., acceptance with additional terms). 3. {{c10::Mixed contracts}}: 3.1. For contracts involving both goods and services, the {{c11::predominant purpose}} of the contract dictates the applicable law. 3.2. Exception: if contract terms {{c12::divide payment between the goods and the services}}, apply the UCC to the {{c13::sale-of-goods portion}} of the contract and common law to the {{c14::remainder}}. 4. Duty of {{c15::good faith}}: 4.1. In both UCC and common law contracts, an obligation of good faith is imposed on the {{c16::performance and enforcement}} of a contract.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: If a prior conveyance or interest is not recorded, a subsequent purchaser or mortgagee may be protected under a {{c1::recording statute}}. The level of protection depends on the type of recording statute. 1.1 {{c2::Notice statutes}} 1.1.1 A subsequent {{c3::bona fide purchaser (BFP)}} always prevails. 1.1.2 Whether or not she records first, a subsequent BFP always prevails over a prior grantee who {{c4::fails to record}}. 1.1.3 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any subsequent purchaser for value {{c5::without notice}} thereof, unless it is recorded." 2. {{c6::Race-notice statutes}} 2.1 The first subsequent {{c7::BFP to record}} prevails. 2.2 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any subsequent purchaser for value, without notice thereof, {{c8::whose conveyance is first recorded}}." 3. {{c9::Race statutes}} 3.1 The first grantee to {{c10::record}} prevails, regardless of whether the buyer is a BFP. 3.2 For example, a {{c11::non-BFP purchaser who records first}} prevails over a later BFP. 3.3 Typical statutory language: "No conveyance or mortgage of an interest in land shall be valid against any other conveyance whose recording is {{c12::first in time}}."

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under the {{c1::cy pres}} doctrine, a {{c2::charitable trust’s property}} can be applied to {{c3::different charitable purposes}} when the original purpose becomes {{c4::impossible, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful}}. - The court modifies the trust to carry out a purpose that is {{c5::as near as possible}} to the settlor’s original charitable intent.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 3. {{c1::Non-jury (bench) trial}} 3.1 Election of bench trial or documentary trial - Parties can elect to have the case decided on {{c2::documentary evidence alone}} or to proceed with a {{c3::non-jury (bench) trial}} where the {{c4::judge}} is the fact-finder. 3.2 Judge’s duties in a bench trial - In a bench trial, the judge must: - Make {{c5::findings of fact}}; and - State separate {{c6::conclusions of law}}. - These findings and conclusions are typically set out in a written opinion or on the record and provide the basis for {{c7::appellate review}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under the {{c1::Final Judgment Rule}}, an appeal may be taken only from a {{c2::final judgment}}. A final judgment is an {{c3::ultimate decision on the merits of the entire case}}. If there is no final judgment (and no exception applies), the {{c4::appellate court lacks jurisdiction}}. For timing, a {{c5::notice of appeal}} must be filed in the {{c6::trial court}} within {{c7::30 days}} of entry of the final judgment.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Merger in criminal law limits {{c1::multiple convictions}} when one offense is essentially part of another. 1. General rule - Under the {{c2::merger doctrine}}, two or more offenses may merge, prohibiting the defendant from being convicted of both offenses. - Merger concerns the relationship between either: - An {{c3::inchoate offense}} and its completed {{c4::substantive offense}}, or - A greater offense and its {{c5::lesser included offense}}. 2. Two main contexts - {{c6::Inchoate offenses}}: solicitation and attempt may merge into the completed target offense; conspiracy does not merge. - {{c7::Lesser included offenses}}: a defendant cannot be convicted of both a greater offense and its lesser included offense, but crimes with different victims do not merge.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Nature of the {{c1::physician–patient privilege}}. 1.1. Prevents disclosure of information {{c2::confidentially conveyed by a patient to a physician}}. 1.2. It is a {{c3::statutory privilege}}, not recognized in the {{c4::Federal Rules of Evidence}}, but recognized and applied in most federal courts on the basis of {{c5::state law}}. 2. Requirements for privileged physician–patient communications. 2.1. The communication is made for purposes of obtaining {{c6::diagnosis or treatment}}. 2.2. The communication is {{c7::pertinent to diagnosis or treatment}}. 2.3. The communication is {{c8::intended by the patient to be confidential}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: Defenses to Full Faith and Credit (when a court is NOT required to enforce another state's judgment): 1. {{c1::Lack of Jurisdiction}} 1.1 The rendering court lacked proper {{c2::jurisdiction over the parties and/or subject matter}}; and 1.2 The party challenging the prior judgment did not {{c3::fully and fairly litigate the jurisdiction issue in the prior court}}. 2. {{c4::Judgment Not on the Merits}} 2.1 The prior judgment was not {{c5::on the merits}} (it did not resolve the {{c6::substance of the plaintiff's claim}}). 2.2 Example: A prior action {{c7::dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction}} is not on the merits. 3. {{c8::No Final Judgment}} 3.1 The prior court’s judgment was not {{c9::final}}. 3.2 A judgment is final when {{c10::no further action by the court is necessary to resolve the litigation}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Consignments}} are transactions where an owner of goods (the {{c2::consignor}}) such as a manufacturer or wholesaler delivers goods to a merchant (the {{c3::consignee}}) for the purpose of sale. 2. Consignment as a {{c4::security interest}}: 2.1 A consignment can be treated as a security interest if the {{c5::inventory the consignee is selling on consignment is difficult to distinguish from inventory the consignee actually owns}}. 2.2 When a consignee or merchant owns inventory that could be mistaken by a creditor of the consignee for similar inventory that is on consignment (i.e., owned by the consignor), the consignment is considered a security interest and the consignor must comply with {{c6::Article 9}} to give notice to the consignee's creditors. 3. Requirements for Article 9 protection (the consignor must comply with Article 9 to protect her interest in consigned goods against the consignee's creditors if all of the following are met): 3.1 The consigned goods are worth {{c7::$1,000 or more}}. 3.2 The consignor did not use the goods for {{c8::personal, family, or household purposes}} (for example, consigned used clothes from a consumer are not covered by Article 9). 3.3 The consignee or merchant: 3.3.1 {{c9::Deals in goods of that kind under a name other than the name of the person making delivery}}. 3.3.2 {{c10::Is not an auctioneer}}. 3.3.3 {{c11::Is not generally known by its creditors to be substantially engaged in selling goods of others}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::defeasible fee}} is a {{c2::fee simple}} that may {{c3::terminate upon the occurrence of a specified event}}. Creating one requires {{c4::clear forfeiture language}} (mere {{c5::desire, hope, or aspiration}} is insufficient). The main types are {{c6::fee simple determinable}} (with a {{c7::possibility of reverter}}), {{c8::fee simple subject to condition subsequent}} (with a {{c9::right of reentry/power of termination}}), and {{c10::fee simple subject to an executory interest}} (with a {{c11::shifting executory interest}} in a third party).

subject: Agency
cloze: An agency relationship is created when all three of the following are present: 1. {{c1::Consent}} – the parties expressly or impliedly agree to enter an agency relationship. 2. {{c2::Control}} – the agent is subject to the principal's control, meaning the principal has the right to direct or supervise the agent’s work. 3. {{c3::Acting on behalf}} – the agent is acting on behalf of the principal, generally acting primarily for the principal’s benefit. Mnemonic: {{c4::CCA}} – Consent, Control, Acting on behalf.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Discretionary and support trusts restrict a beneficiary's access to trust property by the terms of the trust. 1. {{c1::Creditor issues generally}} 1.1 Because beneficiaries have {{c2::limited access}} to trust property, their creditors are also {{c3::limited in accessing}} the beneficiary's trust interest. 2. {{c4::Discretionary trusts}} 2.1 In a discretionary trust, the trustee has {{c5::absolute power and discretion}} to make decisions regarding distribution of trust property to beneficiaries. 2.2 Beneficiaries have {{c6::no right to income}} until the trustee exercises discretion to distribute property or income. 2.3 Beneficiary's creditors: Creditors {{c7::cannot reach the trust}} because the beneficiary cannot compel payment from the trust. However, if creditors {{c8::serve the trustee with process}}, the trustee must first {{c9::satisfy the creditor's claims}} before distributing funds to the beneficiary. 3. {{c10::Support trusts}} 3.1 A support trust directs the trustee to pay beneficiaries from the trust as much as is necessary for the beneficiary's {{c11::support}}. 3.2 Beneficiary's creditors: Creditors generally have the {{c12::same rights as for a discretionary trust}}. 4. {{c13::Spendthrift trusts}} 4.1 A spendthrift trust {{c14::prohibits beneficiaries from transferring}} their interests in the trust, either voluntarily or involuntarily. 4.2 Spendthrift clauses are usually included to {{c15::protect the beneficiary from their own carelessness}}. 4.3 Beneficiary's creditors: Creditors {{c16::cannot reach the beneficiary's interest}} in the trust, but {{c17::distributions actually made}} to the beneficiary are reachable. 5. {{c18::Exceptions for certain creditors}} 5.1 The following creditors can reach trust property despite a spendthrift or similar restriction: 5.1.1 {{c19::Spousal or child support}} claimants; 5.1.2 Those providing {{c20::basic necessities}} to the beneficiary; and 5.1.3 Holders of {{c21::federal or state tax liens}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Definition of Accessions}} 1.1 Accessions are {{c2::collateral that does not lose its identity when physically united with other goods}}. 1.2 The item remains {{c3::separately identifiable}} even though it is attached to a larger whole. 1.3 Example: A {{c4::hard drive}} used as collateral does not lose its identity when installed in a {{c5::laptop}}. 2. {{c6::Continuation of Security Interest in Accessions}} 2.1 A security interest can be created in collateral even if it will later become {{c7::physically united with other goods}}. 2.2 When collateral becomes an accession, the existing {{c8::security interest continues}} in the accession. 2.3 The secured party’s interest {{c9::follows the item into the larger product}} and remains attached to that {{c10::identifiable component}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Parental notice or consent laws for minors do not create an undue burden under the old framework if the law includes an {{c1::alternative judicial bypass procedure}}. Judicial bypass procedure: 1. The minor may {{c2::go before a judge}} instead of obtaining parental consent. 2. The judge can authorize the abortion by finding either: 2.1 That abortion is in the minor’s {{c3::best interests}}, or 2.2 That the minor is {{c4::mature enough to decide for herself}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Federal recognition of testimonial privileges}}: {{c2::1.1 There are no FRE privilege rules}} written into the Federal Rules of Evidence. {{c3::1.2 Federal courts have created and adopted privilege rules as matters of common law}}. {{c4::1.3 State privilege rules}} (which often vary) apply in federal cases based on {{c5::diversity jurisdiction}}. 2. Testimonial privileges recognized on the MBE: {{c6::2.1 Attorney-client}}. {{c7::2.2 Clergy-penitent}}. {{c8::2.3 Spousal (spousal testimonial privilege)}}. {{c9::2.4 Marital communications}}. {{c10::2.5 Psychotherapist or social worker–patient}}. {{c11::2.6 Governmental}}. 3. Privilege against self-incrimination ({{c12::Fifth Amendment}}): 3.1 Under the Fifth Amendment, a witness cannot be compelled to provide self-incriminating testimony in either civil or criminal cases. 3.2 The witness may invoke the privilege if there is a {{c13::reasonable possibility of self-incrimination}}. 3.3 {{c14::Civil cases}}: the jury may draw an {{c15::adverse inference}} from a witness's assertion of the Fifth Amendment privilege. 3.4 {{c16::Criminal cases}}: the defendant cannot be {{c17::punished}} for invoking the privilege. 4. Exam tip: {{c18::4.1 These privileges are not codified in the FRE}}; the MBE usually assumes their existence, but an answer choice indicating any of these privileges as an evidentiary rule of the FRE will be incorrect.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Expectation damages}}: 1.1 {{c2::Standard measure}} of money damages. 1.2 Puts the party in the economic position they would be in if the contract had been {{c3::performed}} (i.e., if the breach never occurred). 1.3 When in doubt, select the remedy that most closely gives the damaged party what they would have received {{c4::absent the breach}}. 2. {{c5::Reliance damages}}: 2.1 {{c6::Alternative measure}} used when expectation damages are {{c7::too speculative}}. 2.2 Designed to compensate the plaintiff based on the {{c8::value of their performance}} and put them in the position they would have been in had the contract {{c9::never been formed}}. 3. {{c10::Consequential damages}}: 3.1 {{c11::Foreseeable losses indirectly resulting}} from a breach (e.g., lost profits); recoverable if: 3.1.1 The damages are a {{c12::foreseeable result}} of the breach. 3.1.2 When the contract was formed, the defendant had {{c13::reason to know}} the plaintiff would suffer {{c14::special, unpreventable, or unexpected damages}} in the event of a breach. 3.2 Under the {{c15::UCC}}, only {{c16::buyers}} can recover consequential damages. 4. {{c17::Incidental damages}}: 4.1 {{c18::Commercially reasonable expenses}} incurred by the non-breaching party in UCC contracts (e.g., costs of inspecting, returning, storing, or reselling goods). 5. {{c19::Duty to mitigate}}: 5.1 The plaintiff cannot recover {{c20::reasonably avoidable damages}}, but may recover the {{c21::costs of reasonably avoiding further damages}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Owners and occupiers of land owe different duties of care depending on the type of trespasser: 1. {{c1::Unknown or undiscovered trespassers}}: {{c2::No duty of care}} is owed. 2. {{c3::Anticipated trespassers}} (where the owner has reason to believe trespassers will be on the land): The owner must use {{c4::reasonable care in activities}} and address certain {{c5::dangerous conditions}}. 3. {{c6::Child trespassers}} under the {{c7::attractive nuisance doctrine}} may trigger an elevated duty when specific elements are met.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In {{c1::diversity}} cases, an intervenor generally must establish {{c2::independent subject-matter jurisdiction}}. 1. {{c3::Independent SMJ}}: • In diversity-only cases, an intervenor must independently satisfy {{c4::complete diversity}} and the {{c5::amount-in-controversy}} requirement (unless another jurisdictional basis, like federal question, applies). 2. {{c6::No supplemental jurisdiction for diversity intervention}}: • {{c7::Supplemental jurisdiction does not extend}} to claims by or against intervenors if doing so would {{c8::destroy diversity}} or otherwise circumvent statutory diversity requirements. Therefore, in a purely diversity case, an absentee cannot rely solely on {{c9::supplemental jurisdiction}} to intervene; the intervenor’s claim must {{c10::qualify independently}} for federal jurisdiction.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. General rule: Once a court categorizes property as separate or marital, it {{c1::equitably distributes}} marital property between both spouses. Courts have significant {{c2::discretion}} in determining equitable distribution. 2. Factors: Courts look at all relevant factors concerning how marital property was accumulated and each party's needs going forward, including: 2.1 {{c3::Income, educational or vocational skills, and employability}} of each party. 2.2 {{c4::Duration of the marriage}}. 2.3 {{c5::Standard of living}} during the marriage. 2.4 {{c6::Assets, debts, and liabilities}} of the parties. 2.5 {{c7::Obligations for support arising out of a prior marriage}}. 2.6 {{c8::Contributions}} made by each spouse toward accumulation of marital property, including contributions to the home and household. 2.7 {{c9::Needs of the parties}}. 2.8 {{c10::Provisions for custody of minor children}}. 2.9 Whether distribution is {{c11::in lieu of alimony or spousal support}}. 2.10 {{c12::Health of the parties}}. 3. Fault as a factor: {{c13::Marital fault of either spouse (e.g., infidelity) is not a relevant factor in most jurisdictions}}. Note: If a question asks you to divide property, be sure to utilize the facts of the question in discussing relevant factors.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: Child Custody Jurisdiction and Recognition: 1. Governing Law: 1.1 Child custody determinations are governed by {{c1::reciprocal statutes}} adopted by all states (e.g., {{c2::UCCJEA}}). 2. Initial Jurisdiction – {{c3::Home State Rule}}: 2.1 A court has jurisdiction to make an initial custody determination if it is the child’s {{c4::home state}}. 2.2 When a court properly exercises home-state jurisdiction and issues a custody order, all other states must give that determination {{c5::full faith and credit}}. 3. Continuing Jurisdiction and Modification: 3.1 The court that made the original custody decree {{c6::retains exclusive, continuing jurisdiction}}. 3.2 No other state may {{c7::modify}} that custody determination unless the original court has {{c8::no significant connection}} with the child or the parties (or otherwise loses or relinquishes jurisdiction under the statute). 4. Effect: 4.1 These rules prevent {{c9::competing custody orders}} and promote {{c10::stability}} in the child’s custody arrangements.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: M'Naghten Test (Cognitive Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant {{c1::does not know right from wrong}}. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 Due to a {{c2::mental disease or defect}}, at the time of the offense the defendant lacked the ability to know the {{c3::wrongfulness}} of his conduct or understand the {{c4::nature and quality}} of his act. 2.2 This test focuses on the defendant’s {{c5::cognitive capacity}} (ability to understand what he is doing and that it is wrong).

subject: Agency
cloze: Agency is a legal relationship between a {{c1::principal}} and an {{c2::agent}}, in which the agent acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control. Agency creation turns on {{c3::consent}}, {{c4::control}}, and {{c5::acting on behalf}}, and agency can arise by {{c6::agreement}}, {{c7::apparent authority}}, or {{c8::ratification}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Federal law governs {{c1::transfer of venue}} in civil cases. A case may be transferred from one federal district to another federal district either to a district {{c2::where the case could have been filed originally}} or to a district {{c3::to which all parties consent}}. Any party may move for transfer, but the court may refuse if the original venue is {{c4::proper}}. When venue in the original district is proper, the court may order transfer in its {{c5::discretion}} based on the {{c6::interest of justice}} and the {{c7::convenience of parties and witnesses}}. In applying this standard, the court considers both {{c8::public factors}} (such as what law applies, which community should bear jury service, and systemic interests) and {{c9::private factors}} (including convenience of the parties and witnesses and the location of evidence and witnesses).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A {{c1::cross-claim}} is an offensive claim asserted by a {{c2::co-party}}. For example, if the plaintiff sues D1 and D2, D1 may assert a cross-claim against D2. 1. Requirements: {{c3::Same transaction or occurrence}}. 1.1 A cross-claim must arise from the {{c4::same transaction or occurrence}} as the underlying action. 1.2 A cross-claim is {{c5::never compulsory}}, even if it arises from the same transaction or occurrence, unlike a {{c6::compulsory counterclaim}}. 2. Jurisdiction: Must have an {{c7::independent basis for subject-matter jurisdiction}}. 2.1 Cross-claims will almost always satisfy {{c8::supplemental jurisdiction}} requirements because they must arise from the same transaction or occurrence.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Persons who lack capacity to contract include: 1. {{c1::Infants (minors)}} – generally under the age of majority and lacking contractual capacity. 2. {{c2::Mentally incompetent persons}} – those who cannot understand the {{c3::nature and consequences}} of the transaction. 3. {{c4::Intoxicated persons}} – but only where the intoxication prevents understanding of the {{c5::nature and consequences}} of the transaction and the {{c6::other party has reason to know}} of the intoxication. Contracts with these persons are generally {{c7::voidable}} at the option of the person lacking capacity or their representative.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Performance and the Statute of Frauds: 1. {{c1::Service contracts}}: • Only {{c2::full performance}} by one party satisfies the SoF. • {{c3::Part performance}} alone does not satisfy the SoF for the remaining unperformed portion. 2. {{c4::Sale of goods contracts (UCC)}}: 2.1 {{c5::Delivery and acceptance}}: • {{c6::Delivery and acceptance of goods}} by the buyer satisfies the SoF for the goods that have been delivered and accepted. 2.2 {{c7::Custom-made (specially manufactured) goods}}: • The SoF is satisfied once the seller makes a {{c8::substantial beginning toward performance}} (e.g., beginning manufacture or making commitments for their procurement).

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Dissenters’ (appraisal) rights}} – basic concept: - Dissenting shareholders can {{c2::challenge the merger transaction or demand payment for their shares at fair market value}} instead of going along with the merger. 2. When appraisal rights arise (in general): - Appraisal rights are typically triggered when a shareholder {{c3::is entitled to vote on a merger or other fundamental transaction}} and {{c4::opposes the transaction}} (exact triggers depend on statute). 3. {{c5::Mutual notice and procedure requirements}}: 3.1 Corporation’s notice obligations: - Before a vote is taken on the merger, the corporation must give shareholders: • {{c6::Notice of the meeting}} at which the merger will be voted on; and • {{c7::Notice of their appraisal rights}} and how to exercise them. 3.2 Shareholders’ obligations to perfect rights: - Shareholders must follow statutory procedures to perfect appraisal rights, generally including: • Giving {{c8::timely notice of intent to dissent}}; • {{c9::Not voting in favor of the merger}}; and • Complying with {{c10::additional statutory steps}} (e.g., submitting share certificates or written demands). 4. {{c11::Valuation and payment}}: 4.1 Corporation’s obligation to pay: - If the merger is approved, the corporation must pay dissenting shareholders the {{c12::fair market value (FMV)}} for their shares, as determined under the applicable statute. 4.2 Disputes and judicial determination: - If the parties cannot agree on FMV, a {{c13::court or statutory appraiser}} will determine the {{c14::fair value}} to be paid. 4.3 Nature of the remedy: - Appraisal is typically the shareholder’s {{c15::exclusive remedy for challenging the price of a merger}}, absent {{c16::fraud, illegality, or other serious wrongdoing}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Even if {{c1::minimum contacts}} are satisfied, due process also requires that the exercise of {{c2::personal jurisdiction}} be {{c3::fair}} and not offend {{c4::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}}. Courts assess fairness under three main factors: {{c5::(1) relatedness of contacts and claim, (2) convenience, and (3) the forum state's interest}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. There is {{c1::no reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP)}} in inherently public or exposed things, so the {{c2::Fourth Amendment}} does not apply to their observation or seizure. 2. Examples where there is no REOP: 2.1. {{c3::Handwriting}}. 2.2. {{c4::Voice}}. 2.3. {{c5::Physical location or movements}} in public. 2.4. {{c6::Odors}} emanating from a person or property. 2.5. {{c7::Public records}}. 2.6. Items {{c8::viewable from a public space}} (plain view from a lawful vantage point). 2.7. {{c9::Bank account records}} held by the bank. 2.8. The {{c10::smell of luggage}}. 3. Areas outside the home’s {{c11::curtilage}} are not protected by the Fourth Amendment, including: 3.1. {{c12::Open fields}} and other areas beyond the curtilage. 3.2. {{c13::Garbage or trash placed outside the curtilage}} (e.g., on the street for collection).

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In General 1.1. A {{c1::rejection by the offeree terminates the offer and the offeree's power of acceptance}}. 1.2. Main methods of rejection: - {{c2::Express rejection}}. - {{c3::Counteroffer}}. - {{c4::Conditional acceptance}}. - {{c5::Acceptance with additional terms (common law vs. UCC)}}. 2. Overview of Methods 2.1. Express rejection is {{c6::effective when received}} by the offeror. 2.2. A counteroffer or conditional acceptance normally {{c7::terminates the original offer and becomes a new offer}}; mere {{c8::bargaining or requests for information}} do not. 2.3. Under {{c9::common law}}, acceptance must mirror the offer ({{c10::mirror-image rule}}), so additional or different terms are a {{c11::rejection and counteroffer}}. 2.4. Under the {{c12::UCC}}, the effect of additional terms depends on whether the parties are {{c13::merchants}} and on specific exceptions.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Citizen use of force to effectuate arrest: 1. {{c1::Non-deadly force}} (NDF) 1.1 A private citizen may use NDF to arrest only if: 1.1.1 {{c2::A crime was actually committed}}; and 1.1.2 The citizen has a {{c3::reasonable belief}} that {{c4::the person to be arrested committed that crime}}. 2. {{c5::Deadly force}} (DF) 2.1 A private citizen may use DF to: 2.1.1 {{c6::Prevent the escape of a person who actually committed a felony}}; and 2.1.2 Only when the fleeing felon {{c7::threatens human life}}. Key idea: Citizen’s arrest requires an {{c8::actual crime}} and allows DF only against a {{c9::life‑threatening felon trying to escape}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Permissive waste is {{c1::harm to the property due to the life tenant's (LT's) neglect or failure to act}}. The LT's duties to avoid permissive waste include: - Duty to {{c2::repair and maintain}} the property in a reasonable state of repair, limited to the {{c3::income or profits derived from the land, or its reasonable rental value}}. - Duty to pay ordinary {{c4::carrying charges}}, including {{c5::property taxes}}, {{c6::interest on encumbrances}}, and other similar ongoing charges necessary to preserve the property. If {{c7::future interest holders}} assume the LT's obligations (e.g., pay taxes or necessary repairs), they are entitled to {{c8::reimbursement}} from the LT to the extent of the LT's duty.

subject: Family Law
cloze: A {{c1::divorce decree}} {{c2::terminates the marriage relationship}}. Historically, divorce was {{c3::fault-based}}, but now every state offers some form of {{c4::no-fault divorce}}, typically on grounds such as {{c5::irretrievable breakdown}}, {{c6::living separate and apart for a specified period}}, or {{c7::incompatibility}}. Some {{c8::defenses to divorce}} exist, but courts generally will not {{c9::force a marriage to continue}} if one spouse seeks dissolution. In contrast, {{c10::legal separation}} is a judicially recognized parting that {{c11::does not terminate the marriage}} or permit {{c12::remarriage}}, but allows adjudication of {{c13::property, support, and custody}} and in some states may later be {{c14::converted into an absolute divorce}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Neutral and detached magistrate}}: - A valid search warrant must be issued by a magistrate who is not aligned with law enforcement and who can make an {{c2::independent probable cause}} determination. 2. {{c3::Good-faith exception}} to the {{c4::exclusionary rule}}: - Even if a warrant is later found invalid, evidence is generally not excluded if police acted in {{c5::objective good-faith reliance}} on the warrant. 3. Exceptions to good-faith reliance (when the exception does NOT apply): Officers cannot rely on the good-faith exception if: (1) The affidavit {{c6::completely lacks probable cause}}—no reasonable officer would have relied on it. (2) The warrant is {{c7::defective on its face}} (e.g., fails to particularize place or items). (3) The police or government officials {{c8::lied to or misled the magistrate}}. (4) The magistrate has {{c9::wholly abandoned the judicial role}} and is not truly neutral and detached.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Federal courts have {{c1::subject-matter jurisdiction}} over properly pleaded claims {{c2::arising under federal law}} ({{c3::28 U.S.C. § 1331}}). No {{c4::diversity}} or {{c5::amount-in-controversy}} requirements apply. 1. Requirements 1.1. The claim must show a right or interest founded substantially on {{c6::federal law}}. 1.2. The {{c7::federal question}} must appear on the face of the {{c8::well-pleaded complaint}}. 1.3. Federal question jurisdiction cannot be based on {{c9::extraneous allegations}} or {{c10::potential defenses}}. 2. Analysis 2.1. Ask whether the plaintiff is {{c11::enforcing a right that arises under federal law}} (e.g., federal statute, regulation, or the Constitution). If not, no federal question jurisdiction exists. 2.2. Beware of fact patterns where the complaint mentions a federal law or issue, but the plaintiff is not actually enforcing a {{c12::federal right}}. 3. Exclusive federal jurisdiction 3.1. Federal courts have {{c13::exclusive jurisdiction}} over certain types of claims, which must be heard in federal court. 3.2. Otherwise, federal claims can generally be heard in {{c14::state court}}, which are courts of {{c15::general jurisdiction}}. 4. Common areas of exclusive federal jurisdiction 4.1. {{c16::Bankruptcy}}. 4.2. {{c17::Patent, copyright, and trademark}}. 4.3. {{c18::Federal antitrust}} claims. 4.4. {{c19::Postal matters}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Out-of-court statements are not {{c1::hearsay}} if offered to prove anything other than the {{c2::truth of the matter they assert}}. 1. Common non-hearsay out-of-court statements 1.1 {{c3::Statements of independent legal significance}} 1.1.1 The statement contains {{c4::legally operative words}} (e.g., words of offer, acceptance, defamation, or threats). 1.1.2 The statement is not hearsay because it is offered to show that the statement was {{c5::made}}, not whether it was {{c6::true}}. 1.1.3 For example: in a contract dispute, a witness testifies that B told A, "{{c7::I accept your offer}}." 1.2 Statements offered to show their {{c8::effect on the listener or reader}} 1.2.1 For example: in a negligence claim, a statement warning P of the injury-causing condition is admissible to show {{c9::notice}} to P. 1.3 Statements offered to show speaker's {{c10::knowledge}} 1.3.1 For example: D, charged with conspiracy, claims he did not know about the crime; a statement indicating D was told specifics of the crime is admissible to show he {{c11::knew it was planned}}. 1.4 Statements offered to show {{c12::state of mind}} 1.4.1 Statements offered as {{c13::circumstantial evidence}} of the declarant's state of mind are not hearsay. 1.4.2 For example: a statement by D, before running into traffic and causing an accident, that he is invisible may be used to show {{c14::insanity}}. 1.4.3 Compare with the {{c15::state of mind hearsay exception}}, which allows hearsay statements that {{c16::directly}} (not circumstantially) reflect the declarant's state of mind.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: The {{c1::Eighth Amendment}} prohibits {{c2::cruel and unusual punishment}}, including punishments that are {{c3::grossly disproportionate to the offense}}. The {{c4::death penalty}} is not per se unconstitutional, but its use is strictly limited by {{c5::procedural safeguards}} and {{c6::categorical exclusions}} (e.g., certain classes of defendants and certain offenses, such as non-homicide crimes by juveniles, for which life without parole is impermissible).

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Signed writing}}: • A {{c2::writing}} containing the {{c3::signature of the party to be charged}} (the party asserting the SoF defense) that reasonably identifies the subject matter and shows a contract was made. 2. {{c4::UCC merchant confirmation}} (no defendant signature needed if): • {{c5::Both parties are merchants}}; and • The party asserting the SoF defense received a {{c6::signed writing memorializing the agreement and its essential terms}}; and • That party {{c7::failed to object in writing within 10 days}} of receipt. If these elements are met, the {{c8::confirmation memo satisfies the Statute of Frauds}} against the non-signing merchant.

subject: Contracts
cloze: {{c1::Unilateral mistake}} occurs when only {{c2::one party}} is mistaken about a fact of the agreement, often due to a {{c3::computational or clerical error}}. General rule: - Unilateral mistake will {{c4::not prevent contract formation}}. Exception – the mistaken party may {{c5::void the contract}} if: - The mistake is {{c6::material}}; and either - The {{c7::non-mistaken party}} {{c8::knew or should have known}} of the mistake; or - The mistake makes the contract {{c9::unconscionable}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Establishment Clause}}, government powers generally may not be {{c2::delegated to or shared with religious institutions}}. Government aid to religious institutions is generally {{c3::permissible}} if it is used for a {{c4::secular purpose}} and does not have a {{c5::primary effect of advancing religion}}. {{c6::Sponsored prayer}}—whether {{c7::mandatory or voluntary}}—in {{c8::public schools}} is generally {{c9::invalid}} under the Establishment Clause, including at events like graduations and football games.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Judicial notice}} (general rule). 1.1. A court may {{c2::recognize a fact as true without formal presentation of evidence}}, either on its own or upon formal request of a party. 2. Judicially-noticeable facts. 2.1. {{c3::Manifest facts}}: those capable of verification by a source that is {{c4::not subject to reasonable dispute}}. 2.2. {{c5::Notorious facts}}: those {{c6::generally known within the jurisdiction}}. 3. Judicial notice of laws. 3.1. The court {{c7::must}} take judicial notice of {{c8::federal and state laws and regulations}}. 3.2. As to all other laws, the court has {{c9::discretion}} to take judicial notice (for example, {{c10::municipal ordinances or foreign laws}}). 4. Effect of judicially-noticed facts or laws. 4.1. {{c11::Civil cases}}: the jury {{c12::must accept}} judicially-noticed facts as {{c13::conclusive}}. 4.2. {{c14::Criminal cases}}: the jury {{c15::may accept}} judicially-noticed facts as conclusive, but is {{c16::not required}} to do so. 5. Judicial testimony. 5.1. A {{c17::presiding judge}} may not testify as a {{c18::witness at trial}} (no party may call the trial judge to testify).

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Intangible and quasi‑tangible property under Article 9 consists largely of {{c1::rights to payment}} or other {{c2::non‑physical personal property}} interests. Common categories include: 1. {{c3::Instruments}}: - Writings that evidence a right to be {{c4::paid money}}. - Examples: {{c5::promissory notes, checks}}. 2. {{c6::Documents}}: - Writings that evidence a right to {{c7::receive goods}}. - Examples: {{c8::bills of lading, warehouse receipts}}. 3. {{c9::Chattel paper}}: - A record evidencing BOTH: (1) a {{c10::monetary obligation}}, and (2) a {{c11::security interest in specific goods}} or a {{c12::lease of specific goods}}. - Example: {{c13::a retail installment sales contract including a promissory note and a security interest in the goods sold}}. 4. {{c14::Accounts}}: - A right to payment not evidenced by an instrument or chattel paper (i.e., {{c15::accounts receivable}}). - Example: {{c16::money owed to a dentist after treating a patient}}. - Excludes: {{c17::deposit accounts, investment property, and commercial tort claims}}. 5. {{c18::Deposit accounts}}: - {{c19::Bank accounts}}, generally non‑consumer when treated as original collateral under Article 9. 6. {{c20::General intangibles}}: - Residual category for {{c21::personal property not fitting another classification}}. - Examples: {{c22::patent rights, copyrights, trademarks, software, goodwill}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Shareholders may bring suit against the corporation either {{c1::directly}} or through a {{c2::derivative action}} to enforce the corporation's rights. 1. {{c3::Direct suit}}: a direct suit is brought where the corporation, an officer, or a director caused harm to, or breached a duty owed to, a {{c4::particular shareholder or a class of shareholders}}. The recovery is for the benefit of the {{c5::shareholder or shareholder class}}. Note: if the duty breached is owed to the {{c6::corporation}}, as opposed to an individual shareholder, the proper avenue is a {{c7::derivative suit}}. 2. {{c8::Derivative suit}}: in a derivative suit, a shareholder sues to {{c9::enforce the corporation's rights}} when the corporation has a cause of action but fails to pursue it (i.e., the suit is brought by a shareholder, on behalf of the corporation, usually against officers or directors). This often arises where a director or officer {{c10::breaches a duty owed to the corporation}} and the corporation has not taken action. 2.1 {{c11::Standing}}: the shareholder bringing suit must have been a shareholder at the time of the alleged wrong (and often must continue to be a shareholder throughout the litigation). 2.2 {{c12::Recovery}}: any recovery goes to the {{c13::corporation}}, but shareholders may recoup reasonable {{c14::legal expenses}}. 2.3 {{c15::Written demand}} required: the shareholder must make a written demand on the corporation and {{c16::wait 90 days}} before filing suit, unless: 2.3.1 the corporation has already {{c17::rejected}} the shareholder's demand; or 2.3.2 {{c18::irreparable injury}} to the corporation will result by waiting the full 90 days.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Counterclaims in the answer 1.1 The defendant's claims against the plaintiff may be asserted in the answer as {{c1::counterclaims}}. 2. Types of counterclaims 2.1 {{c2::Compulsory}} counterclaims 2.1.1 Arise out of the {{c3::same transaction or occurrence}} as the plaintiff's claim. 2.1.2 Must generally be {{c4::brought in the same action}} or are {{c5::barred}}. 2.2 {{c6::Permissive}} counterclaims 2.2.1 Do {{c7::not}} arise out of the same transaction or occurrence. 2.2.2 May be brought in the {{c8::same action}} or {{c9::separately}} in another lawsuit. 3. Procedural point 3.1 Both types may be asserted in the answer, subject to {{c10::jurisdictional}} and other procedural requirements.

subject: Torts
cloze: Protective defenses to intentional torts—{{c1::self-defense}}, {{c2::defense of others}}, and {{c3::defense of property}}—share common requirements: 1. {{c4::Reasonable belief}} that a tort is being committed or is about to be committed. 2. {{c5::Proper timing}}: the threat must be {{c6::in progress or imminent}}. 3. {{c7::Reasonable, proportionate force}}. - {{c8::Deadly force}} is allowed only if D reasonably believes a {{c9::life is in danger}} and is {{c10::never permitted to protect property alone}}. Self-defense governs threats to oneself (with retreat and initial-aggressor rules), defense of others applies when aiding someone who would have self-defense, and defense of property allows only reasonable, non-deadly force and is limited by privileges and mistake rules.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 A security interest in {{c1::proceeds}} from original collateral is perfected {{c2::automatically for 20 days}} from the debtor’s receipt of the proceeds, but may become {{c3::unperfected on the 21st day}}. 1.2 This arises where the debtor {{c4::sells or otherwise disposes of property that was used as collateral}}. 1.3 Article 9 gives the creditor an automatic security interest in {{c5::identifiable proceeds}} from the sale or disposition of collateral. 2. {{c6::Identifiable proceeds}}: 2.1 A security interest in proceeds from collateral is automatically perfected for {{c7::20 days}} from the debtor’s receipt of the proceeds. 2.2 Example: A TV store takes a loan and puts its TV inventory up as collateral. The store can continue selling TVs, but the creditor has an automatically perfected SI in the store’s identifiable TV proceeds for 20 days after the proceeds are received. 3. {{c8::Continuing perfection beyond 20 days}}: 3.1 A perfected security interest in proceeds becomes unperfected on the 21st day after the security interest attaches to the proceeds unless: 3.1.1 A filed {{c9::financing statement}} covers the {{c10::original collateral}}; 3.1.2 The proceeds are collateral in which a security interest may be perfected by {{c11::filing in the same office}} where the financing statement for the original collateral has been filed; and 3.1.3 The proceeds are {{c12::not acquired with cash proceeds}} (i.e., they are non-cash proceeds that remain traceable from the original collateral and filing office).

subject: Contracts
cloze: An offer is an {{c1::objective manifestation}} of a {{c2::present intent to contract}} such that a {{c3::reasonable offeree}} would believe the communication {{c4::invites acceptance}}. The core elements are: - {{c5::Promise, undertaking, or commitment}} by the offeror; - {{c6::Definite and certain terms}} sufficient for a court to {{c7::enforce the contract}} (typically including {{c8::quantity, time for performance, price, subject matter, and parties}}); and - {{c9::Communication}} of the offer to an {{c10::identified offeree}} who {{c11::knows of the offer}} and has the {{c12::power to accept}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: If there is a taking for public use, the government must pay {{c1::just compensation}}. 1. Measure: - Just compensation is measured in terms of {{c2::loss to the owner}}, not the government’s gain. - It is usually the {{c3::fair market value}} of the property at the {{c4::time of the taking}}. 2. Scope: - The amount of compensation corresponds to the {{c5::property interest taken}} (e.g., fee simple, easement, or temporary occupation).

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Witness {{c1::competency}}. 1.1 Testifying witnesses must be competent, meaning they must satisfy requirements of {{c2::basic reliability}}. 1.2 Witnesses are generally {{c3::presumed to be competent}}. 1.3 Competency qualifications: to be competent, the witness (W) must have: 1.3.1 {{c4::Personal knowledge}}: W's testimony must be based on W's own perceptions (e.g., what W saw or heard). 1.3.2 {{c5::Memory}}: W must have the ability to remember (e.g., must not have amnesia that prevents recall of the events). 1.3.3 {{c6::Communication}}: W must be able to relay W's perceptions, either directly or through an interpreter. 1.3.4 {{c7::Sincerity}}: W must take an {{c8::oath or affirmation}} to tell the truth. 1.4 Diminution of any of the above capacities usually goes only to the {{c9::weight}} of the testimony (i.e., makes W less persuasive), not its {{c10::admissibility}}. 2. {{c11::Excluding witnesses}} ({{c12::sequestration}}). 2.1 Upon a party's request, the court must order witnesses excluded from the courtroom so they cannot hear other witnesses' testimony. 2.2 This rule does not apply to {{c13::parties}} or certain {{c14::party representatives}} (e.g., where a party is a non-person entity and appears through a designated representative).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::successor in interest to the benefiting estate}} may enforce the covenant if the following requirements are satisfied. 2. Requirements: 2.1 {{c2::Writing}}: The original covenant was in writing. 2.2 {{c3::Intent}}: The original parties intended the {{c4::benefit}} to run with the land; look to the language of the covenant. Courts are liberal in construing the requisite intent. 2.3 {{c5::Touches and concerns the land}}: The covenant must affect the parties' {{c6::legal relations as landowners}} (a very low standard). 2.4 {{c7::Vertical privity}}: Successors in interest are in vertical privity with the original covenanting parties (for example, through {{c8::contract, devise, or descent}}). Vertical privity can be {{c9::relaxed}} (not full) for the burden to run. {{c10::Horizontal privity is not required}} in a majority of states.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 The government has a duty to disclose {{c2::material exculpatory evidence}} to the defendant. 1.2 Failure to disclose violates {{c3::due process}}, whether intentional or not, and is grounds for {{c4::reversing a conviction}} if the standard for materiality is met. 2. {{c5::Establishing a violation}} 2.1 The defendant must show that the undisclosed evidence {{c6::impeaches or is exculpatory}}. 2.2 The evidence is {{c7::favorable to the defendant}}. 2.3 {{c8::Prejudice}} has resulted: prejudice will be found if there is a {{c9::reasonable probability}} that the result of the case would have been different if the undisclosed evidence had been presented at trial. 3. {{c10::Applicability of duty to disclose}} 3.1 The duty applies to evidence relevant to the prosecution's {{c11::case in chief}} and to evidence held by {{c12::police and other investigators}} acting on the government's behalf. 3.2 The duty does not apply to {{c13::post-conviction proceedings}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Definition of {{c1::modification}} (common law) 1.1 A modification occurs when the parties make a {{c2::subsequent change}} to the terms of an existing {{c3::contract}}. 1.2 The parties agree to discharge the {{c4::original contract terms}} in favor of the new terms, but a modification does not discharge the {{c5::entire original contract}} unless expressly agreed. 2. Requirements for modification at {{c6::common law}} 2.1 {{c7::Mutual assent}}: There must be mutual assent of the parties to the modification. 2.2 {{c8::Consideration}}: Generally required, usually found because the parties have limited their rights under the original contract by the modification. 2.3 {{c9::Modern trend}} exception: A modification may be enforced without new consideration if it is {{c10::fair}} and is due to {{c11::circumstances unanticipated when the contract was made}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1. Under {{c1::strict liability}}, the defendant has an {{c2::absolute duty to make certain activities safe}}. 1.2. Strict liability allows the plaintiff to establish the defendant’s liability for injuries {{c3::without proving that the defendant acted negligently}}. 2. Scope of strict liability 2.1. Strict liability is limited to cases involving: 2.1.1. {{c4::Ultrahazardous and/or abnormally dangerous conditions or activities}}. 2.1.2. {{c5::Animal conduct}}. 2.1.3. {{c6::Products liability}}. 3. Prima facie case for strict liability 3.1. The nature of the defendant’s activity {{c7::imposes an absolute duty to make it safe}}. 3.2. Causation: 3.2.1. {{c8::Actual and proximate cause}} must be established. 3.2.2. The {{c9::dangerous aspect of the defendant’s activity}} must have caused the plaintiff’s injury. 3.2.3. The defendant is generally liable only to {{c10::foreseeable plaintiffs}}. 3.3. The plaintiff must suffer {{c11::damages to person or property}}. 4. No due care defense 4.1. {{c12::No amount of due care will relieve the defendant of liability under strict liability}}. 5. Defenses 5.1. {{c13::Assumption of risk}}. 5.2. {{c14::Comparative negligence}} (in some jurisdictions).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. Inchoate offenses covered by merger - Merger only applies to {{c1::solicitation}} and {{c2::attempt}}. 2. Effect of merger for inchoate crimes - A defendant cannot be convicted of both solicitation or attempt and the {{c3::completed target offense}}. - Example: The defendant completes a burglary after attempting it. The defendant cannot be convicted of both {{c4::attempt}} and {{c5::burglary}}. 3. Conspiracy as an exception - Merger does {{c6::not}} apply to {{c7::conspiracy}}. - The defendant can be convicted of both {{c8::conspiracy to commit a given crime}} and the {{c9::completed crime itself}}. - Rationale: conspiracy punishes the {{c10::agreement and group danger}}, which is distinct from the substantive offense.

subject: Torts
cloze: Certain actors in negligence are subject to {{c1::specialized standards of care}} beyond the ordinary reasonably prudent person standard. Key categories include: {{c2::children}}, {{c3::common carriers and innkeepers}}, {{c4::custom or usage in an industry}}, and {{c5::professionals}}. Other specialized standards—such as {{c6::statutory standards of care}} and duties of {{c7::owners and occupiers of land}}—are covered separately.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Federal courts have {{c1::subject-matter jurisdiction}} over controversies between {{c2::citizens of different states}}, even where claims do not involve {{c3::federal law}}. 2. Diversity jurisdiction is conferred by the {{c4::Constitution}} and by statute ({{c5::28 U.S.C. § 1332}}). 3. Requirements for diversity jurisdiction: 3.1. {{c6::Complete diversity of citizenship}}. 3.1.1. Every plaintiff must be of diverse citizenship from every defendant (i.e., there is no diversity if any {{c7::plaintiff}} is a citizen of the same state as any {{c8::defendant}}). 3.1.2. Complete diversity does not require that all parties be citizens of different states; it only requires that no P and no D share the same state citizenship (e.g., two Ps can be from Utah, as long as no D is from Utah). 3.1.3. Diversity is examined at the {{c9::time of filing}}; diversity need not exist when the claim arose. 3.1.4. Diversity can exist between a citizen of a U.S. state and a {{c10::foreign country}} (often referred to as {{c11::alienage jurisdiction}}). 3.2. {{c12::Amount in controversy}} must {{c13::exceed $75,000}}. 3.2.1. The plaintiff must make a {{c14::good-faith allegation}} that her claim exceeds $75,000. 4. Exceptions to diversity jurisdiction: 4.1. Federal courts will not hear actions involving {{c15::divorce}}, {{c16::alimony}}, {{c17::child custody}}, or {{c18::probate}}, even if diversity requirements are otherwise satisfied.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Restrictions on transfer: • Lease provisions restricting assignment or sublease are generally {{c1::enforceable}}. • Such provisions are {{c2::construed against the landlord}}, so ambiguities favor the tenant’s ability to transfer. Construction: • Clauses are read {{c3::narrowly}}; a restriction on “assignments” does not automatically bar subleases unless {{c4::clearly stated}}. Waiver: • Once the landlord gives a tenant permission to assign or sublet despite a restriction, that restriction is generally treated as {{c5::waived}} going forward for that tenant, unless the lease {{c6::clearly provides otherwise}}. • The landlord may preserve the restriction by {{c7::expressly stating that consent to one transfer does not waive future enforcement}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 4. Accessory after the fact: 4.1 {{c1::Timing}}: Liability as an accessory after the fact arises {{c2::after the crime is complete}}, not before or during. 4.2 {{c3::Conduct}}: It involves helping a {{c4::known felon}} avoid or escape {{c5::arrest, trial, conviction, or punishment}}. 4.3 {{c6::Separate offense}}: It is charged as a {{c7::separate, typically lesser offense}}, often called {{c8::obstruction of justice}} or a similar crime. 4.4 Distinction: {{c9::Accomplices}} help bring about the crime and are liable for the crime itself and foreseeable additional crimes, while {{c10::accessories after the fact}} only assist {{c11::after the crime}} and are punished for that post-crime assistance.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. Co-conspirator liability: 1.1 Each conspirator is liable for co-conspirators' crimes that are: 1.1.1 {{c1::Foreseeable}}, and 1.1.2 Committed {{c2::in furtherance of the conspiracy}}. 2. Withdrawal: 2.1 Under {{c3::common law}}, one cannot withdraw from the {{c4::conspiracy itself}} once the agreement is made. 2.2 Under the {{c5::MPC}}, withdrawal from the conspiracy is possible if the withdrawing party {{c6::thwarts the conspiracy}} (for example, by stopping it or notifying police). 3. Withdrawal from subsequent crimes: 3.1 Even if a conspirator cannot withdraw from the conspiracy itself at common law, one can withdraw from co-conspirators' {{c7::subsequent crimes}}, including the target offense of the conspiracy. 3.2 An {{c8::affirmative act}} is required: Withdrawal is effective when the withdrawing party makes an affirmative act that {{c9::notifies his co-conspirators}} he is withdrawing. 3.3 The withdrawal must be {{c10::timely}}: It must give enough time for co-conspirators to abandon plans for the target offense. 3.4 The withdrawing party must attempt to {{c11::neutralize the effect of any assistance}} he provided to the original conspiracy.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Affirmative (voluntary) waste occurs when a {{c1::life tenant (LT)}} engages in acts of commission that unreasonably consume, exploit, or deplete the {{c2::property or its natural resources}}. General rule: The LT {{c3::cannot consume or exploit natural resources}} on the land except in limited circumstances: - {{c4::Necessary for repairs or maintenance}} of the land. - When the grant {{c5::expressly gives the right to exploit}}. - When the land was used for {{c6::exploitation of resources prior to the grant}} (prior use). - {{c7::Open mines doctrine}}: If exploitation occurred before the life estate, the LT may only extract from {{c8::already-open mines}} and may not open new mines or substantially expand beyond prior use.

subject: Torts
cloze: Defense of property as a defense to intentional torts: 1. {{c1::Availability}}: - Available to {{c2::prevent a tort against property}}. 2. {{c3::Permissible force}}: - Only {{c4::reasonable, non-deadly force}} may be used. - Force that is {{c5::deadly or causes serious bodily harm}} is not allowed for defense of property alone. 3. {{c6::Privileged entrants}}: - Defense of property is {{c7::unavailable}} if the initial actor had a {{c8::privilege to enter}} the land (e.g., to recapture chattel). 4. {{c9::Mistake rules}}: - A {{c10::reasonable mistake}} is allowed as to whether an {{c11::intrusion occurred}}. - No mistake is allowed as to whether a {{c12::privilege existed}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 2. Custody 2.1. The accused is in {{c1::custody}} when a {{c2::reasonable person}} would not feel {{c3::free to leave}}. 3. Interrogation 3.1. {{c4::Interrogation}} consists of statements or actions by police that are reasonably likely to elicit {{c5::incriminating responses}}. 3.2. {{c6::Unsolicited or volunteered statements}} by the accused are not protected by Miranda because they are not the product of {{c4::interrogation}}. 3.3. {{c7::Routine questioning}}, such as during {{c8::booking}} or a {{c9::probation interview}}, is not considered interrogation. 3.4. {{c10::Public-safety exception}}: police may interrogate a suspect without giving Miranda warnings when reasonably necessary to protect {{c11::public safety}} (for example, where the defendant has information about a {{c12::bomb}} that could explode in public).

subject: Torts
cloze: Certain {{c1::special situations}} support negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED) even without zone-of-danger or bystander elements, because the negligence creates a {{c2::great likelihood of serious emotional distress}}. Classic examples include: 1. {{c3::Erroneous report of a relative’s death}}. 2. {{c4::Mishandling of a corpse}} (e.g., losing, damaging, or desecrating a loved one’s body).

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A third party that benefits from a contract entered into between other parties is a {{c1::third-party beneficiary}}. 2. Types of third-party beneficiaries 2.1 {{c2::Intended third-party beneficiaries (TPBs)}} 2.1.1 The parties to the contract {{c3::intend}} for the TPB to benefit from the contract. 2.1.2 An intended TPB has {{c4::rights under the contract}}. 2.2 {{c5::Incidental third-party beneficiaries}} 2.2.1 An incidental TPB stands to benefit from the contract although {{c6::not intended}} by the parties to the contract. 2.2.2 An incidental TPB has {{c7::no rights under the contract}}. 3. Determining TPB status 3.1 Whether a TPB is an intended beneficiary under the contract is a {{c8::question of fact}}. 3.2 Courts look at the following factors: 3.2.1 Is the TPB {{c9::expressly designated}} in the contract? 3.2.2 Does the TPB {{c10::directly benefit from some performance}} under the contract? 3.2.3 Does the TPB {{c11::have rights under the contract}}? 3.2.4 Does the TPB stand in such a {{c12::relationship to the promisee}} under the contract that an intent to benefit the third party can be inferred? 3.2.5 If the answer to any of the above is yes, it is more likely that the TPB is {{c13::intended}}. 4. TPB characteristics 4.1 TPBs are {{c14::not parties to the contract}}; they are merely beneficiaries. 4.2 {{c15::Intended}} TPBs have a right to {{c16::sue for breach of contract}} even though they are not parties to the contract. 4.3 {{c17::Creditor TPBs}}: The benefit is conferred based on a {{c18::debt owed by the promisee}} to the third-party beneficiary. 4.4 {{c19::Donee TPBs}}: The benefit is conferred {{c20::gratuitously (as a gift)}}.

subject: Family Law
