cloze: {{c1::Annulment}} is a judicial declaration that an alleged marriage was {{c2::invalid from its inception}} due to an {{c3::impediment at the time of marriage}}, so the marriage is treated as if it {{c4::never occurred}}. A marriage may be annulled if it is {{c5::void}} or {{c6::voidable}} (the exact classification varies by state). Common grounds include {{c7::bigamy or polygamy}}, {{c8::consanguinity}}, {{c9::non-age}}, {{c10::incurable physical impotence}}, and {{c11::incapacity to consent}}. Many states allow {{c12::temporary spousal support}} during the annulment action, and most courts divide property to approximate each party’s {{c13::pre-marriage position}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Scope and attachment of the right 1.1 The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} protects the defendant from {{c2::unreasonable delay}} between the time charges are filed and the beginning of trial. 1.2 The speedy-trial right attaches once the defendant has been {{c3::arrested or formally charged}}. 2. Standard for violations 2.1 Whether the right has been violated is determined by the {{c4::totality of the circumstances}}. 3. Factors (Barker v. Wingo) 3.1 Relevant factors include: 3.1.1 {{c5::Length of delay}}, 3.1.2 {{c6::Reason for delay}} (including whether the defendant caused or consented to the delay), 3.1.3 Whether the delay has {{c7::prejudiced the defendant}}, and 3.1.4 Whether the defendant {{c8::asserted the right}}. 4. Remedy 4.1 The remedy for a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial is {{c9::dismissal of the case with prejudice}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: An {{c1::affirmative easement}} entitles its holder to make {{c2::affirmative use}} of the {{c3::servient estate}} (such as crossing, laying utilities, or drawing water). A {{c4::negative easement}} entitles its holder to {{c5::restrict the servient estate}} from {{c6::otherwise permissible activities}}, such as interfering with light, air, support, or the flow of an artificial stream.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Licensing and permit schemes for speech are {{c1::prior restraints}} because they require {{c2::government approval before speaking}}. The government may require licenses or permits for speech only if it has a {{c3::reasonable justification}} for doing so. Such schemes must operate like {{c4::procedural due process}} systems: • They must contain {{c5::clear, reasonable standards}} that limit official discretion; and • They must provide {{c6::review for denied permits or licenses}}. A person may {{c7::challenge a denial of a permit or license on constitutional grounds}}, even if the person has {{c8::violated the permit requirement}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}}, when Congress has not acted, state and local governments may regulate only if their laws are neither {{c2::discriminatory}} nor {{c3::unduly burdensome}} on interstate commerce. A state or local law regulating interstate commerce is invalid if it: 1. {{c4::Discriminates against out-of-state competition}}; 2. {{c5::Unduly burdens interstate commerce}}; or 3. {{c6::Regulates wholly out-of-state (extraterritorial) activity}}. Examples of invalid regulations include laws {{c7::protecting local businesses}}, {{c8::requiring local operations}} (such as in-state processing or offices), and laws {{c9::limiting access to in-state products}} for protectionist reasons.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: {{c1::Relation back}}: The relation back doctrine applies when a party amends a pleading to add a new claim or defendant after the {{c2::statute of limitations}} has run. If relation back is allowed, the amended pleading will be treated as if it was filed when the original pleading was filed. 1. Requirements for relation back: 1.1 {{c3::New claim}}: An amendment adding a new claim will relate back if the new claim concerns the {{c4::same conduct, transaction, or occurrence}} as the original pleading, i.e., if the new claim is based on the same general set of facts as the original pleading. 1.2 {{c5::New or substituted defendant}}: An amendment adding or substituting a defendant will relate back if: 1.2.1 The amendment concerns the {{c6::same conduct, transaction, or occurrence}} as the original pleading; and 1.2.2 Within {{c7::90 days}} of filing of the original pleading: 1.2.2.1 The new defendant {{c8::knew of or received notice of the action}}; and 1.2.2.2 The new defendant {{c9::knew or should have known}} that, but for a {{c10::mistake}}, she would have been named originally. This typically applies when the plaintiff sued the wrong defendant first, but the right defendant was aware of the mistake.

subject: Con Law
cloze: First Amendment defamation rules are triggered when the plaintiff is a {{c1::public official}} or {{c2::public figure}}, or when the speech involves a {{c3::matter of public concern}}. 1. {{c4::Public figure}}: - One who has {{c5::pervasive fame or notoriety}}; OR - One who {{c6::voluntarily assumes a central role}} in a particular {{c7::public matter or controversy}}. 2. {{c8::Public official}}: - A {{c9::public office holder}}. 3. {{c10::Matter of public concern}}: - A statement that relates to a {{c11::community interest or concern}}, including {{c12::national interests}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: {{c1::Substantive due process}} involves determining whether the government has adequate reasons for depriving a person of {{c2::life, liberty, or property}}. It encompasses both {{c3::fundamental}} and {{c4::non-fundamental}} rights. 1. Applicable levels of scrutiny 1.1. If a {{c5::non-fundamental right}} is burdened, the court applies {{c6::rational basis}} review. 1.2. If a {{c7::fundamental right}} is burdened, the court applies {{c8::strict scrutiny}}. 2. Substantive due process vs. Equal Protection Clause (EP) 2.1. Similarities: Under both {{c1::substantive due process}} and {{c9::equal protection}}, a court reviews the {{c10::substance of the law, not the procedures}} used to enact or enforce it. 2.2. Differences: {{c1::Substantive due process}} usually involves laws affecting the rights of {{c11::all persons}} to engage in some conduct or activity. {{c9::Equal protection}} usually involves laws {{c12::treating certain people or classes of people differently}} than others, often based on some trait.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. To be justiciable in federal court, a case must contain a {{c1::ripe}} claim and a {{c2::live controversy}} (i.e., it cannot be {{c3::moot}}). 2. {{c4::Ripeness}}: The dispute must have matured sufficiently to warrant a decision; the plaintiff is not entitled to review of a law or government act before it has been effectuated. 3. {{c5::Mootness}}: A live controversy must exist at all stages of review. If the circumstances causing the plaintiff's harm cease to exist after the plaintiff files suit, the case must be dismissed as moot, unless an exception applies. 3.1 Exception: {{c6::Wrongs capable of repetition but evading review}}: Arises where the injury ceases before complete litigation of the claim, but the plaintiff can reasonably expect to be subject to the same harm in the future. Example: A disabled bar examinee seeks an injunction because of denied accommodations and cannot complete the exam before his case is heard; the case is not moot because he will need to take the bar exam again. 3.2 Exception: {{c7::Voluntary cessation by defendant}}: The defendant has ceased the acts giving rise to the plaintiff's suit, but can resume them at any time. 3.3 Exception: {{c8::Class action lawsuits}}: Only {{c9::one member of the class must have an ongoing injury}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Common carriers}} (such as buses, trains, and airlines) and {{c2::innkeepers}} (such as hotels) are held to a {{c3::high standard of care}} toward their passengers or guests and may be liable even for {{c4::slight negligence}} that harms them.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Classifications based on {{c1::race}} or {{c2::national origin}} are {{c3::suspect classifications}} under Equal Protection and are reviewed under {{c4::strict scrutiny}}. The government must show a {{c5::compelling governmental interest}} and that the classification is {{c6::narrowly tailored}} to achieve that interest, even when the law {{c7::benefits minorities}} (e.g., affirmative action programs).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Definition and purpose of the answer 1.1 The {{c1::answer}} is the {{c2::defendant's response}} to the complaint. 1.2 In the answer, the defendant {{c3::states defenses to each claim asserted}} and {{c4::admits or denies each count}} of the plaintiff's complaint. 1.3 Defenses can be {{c5::pleaded in the alternative}} (e.g., deny a contract existed but also assert performance if it did). 2. Timing of the answer 2.1 The answer must be filed within {{c6::21 days}} after {{c7::service of process}}. 2.2 If the defendant files a {{c8::Rule 12 motion}} first, the answer is due within {{c9::14 days}} after the court {{c10::rules on that motion}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: A premarital agreement may be {{c1::revoked or amended}} only by a {{c2::written agreement}} {{c3::signed by both parties}}, and an {{c4::amendment}} is enforceable {{c5::without separate consideration}}. Courts {{c6::strictly scrutinize}} enforcement of premarital agreements under the {{c7::UPAA}} and similar laws, focusing on: - {{c8::Voluntariness}} (no fraud, duress, or overreaching), - {{c9::Full and fair financial disclosure}} or a valid waiver, and - Whether the terms were {{c10::unconscionable}} at {{c11::execution}} (and sometimes at {{c12::enforcement}}). Whether each party had {{c13::independent legal counsel}} may be an important factor, and some states {{c14::require}} counsel or a meaningful chance to obtain it.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 {{c2::Battery}} is an {{c3::intentional harmful or offensive contact}} to P's person by D. 2. {{c4::Elements}} 2.1 {{c5::Harmful or offensive contact}} by D. 2.1.1 {{c6::Harmful contact}} is contact that causes pain, injury, or similar harm. 2.1.2 Contact is {{c7::offensive}} if it would be considered offensive by a {{c8::reasonable person}} and P has not consented. 2.2 Contact to {{c9::P's person}}. 2.2.1 Includes anything {{c10::closely connected}} to P's person (e.g., P's hat). 2.3 {{c11::Intent}}. 2.4 {{c12::Causation}}. 2.4.1 {{c13::Indirect contact}} is sufficient, i.e., causing the force that gives rise to harmful or offensive contact. 2.4.2 For example: {{c14::greasing a floor so that P will slip and fall}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: These doctrines operate as defenses to {{c1::contract formation or enforcement}}: 1. {{c2::Illegality and public policy}}: Contract subject matter or purpose is illegal, or enforcement would frustrate protective public policy. 2. {{c3::Misrepresentation (fraud)}}: A party relies to their detriment on a {{c4::material}} false assertion, concealment, or misstatement. 3. {{c5::Undue influence}}: A {{c6::susceptible party}} enters a contract under {{c7::excessive pressure}}. 4. {{c8::Duress}}: A {{c9::wrongful act or threat}} overcomes a party's {{c10::free will}} ({{c11::physical duress}} makes a contract {{c12::void}}; {{c13::non-physical duress}} makes it {{c14::voidable}}). 5. {{c15::Unconscionability}}: The {{c16::bargaining process}} or {{c17::contract terms}} are so {{c18::unfair or oppressive}} that the court may refuse to enforce all or part of the contract.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Statements of a party-opponent}} 1.1 Out-of-court statements by a party are admissible if {{c2::offered against that party}}. 1.2 {{c3::Judicial statements}}: statements made in pleadings or testimony may be used against the party. 1.3 {{c4::Adoptive statement}}: a party's acquiescence in another's statement can be treated as the party's own statement. 1.4 {{c5::Silence}}: can be a statement or admission if: 1.4.1 The party {{c6::heard, understood, and was capable of responding}}; and 1.4.2 A {{c7::reasonable person}} in the party's position would have responded. 2. {{c8::Vicarious statements}} 2.1 A vicarious statement is a statement by someone other than the person against whom the statement is offered. 2.2 {{c9::Agency}}: a statement by an agent or employee on matters within the {{c10::scope of the agency or employment}} and made during the relationship is admissible against the principal. 2.3 {{c11::Authorized speaker}}: a statement by a person authorized by a party to speak on her behalf is admissible against the party. 2.4 {{c12::Co-conspirator}}: a co-conspirator's statements are admissible against a defendant if made {{c13::during and in furtherance of the conspiracy}}. 3. {{c14::Declarant-witness's prior statements}} 3.1 A prior statement by a declarant who {{c15::testifies and is subject to cross-examination}} is admissible and treated as non-hearsay if it is: 3.1.1 {{c16::Inconsistent}} with the declarant's testimony and given {{c17::under oath}} at a prior proceeding or deposition. 3.1.2 A {{c18::prior consistent statement}} offered to rebut a {{c19::charge of fabrication, improper motive or influence}}, or to rehabilitate credibility. 3.1.3 A prior statement of {{c20::identification after perception}}, used to identify a person the declarant perceived earlier.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Under the {{c1::doctrine of waste}}, a {{c2::life tenant (LT)}} owes duties to {{c3::future interest holders}} not to unreasonably use, change, or neglect the property in ways that harm their interests. There are three main types of waste: {{c4::affirmative (voluntary) waste}}, {{c5::permissive waste}}, and {{c6::ameliorative waste}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Right to an impartial jury: - The defendant has a right to an {{c1::impartial jury}}. - The defendant may question potential jurors during {{c2::voir dire}} about possible prejudices relevant to the case, such as {{c3::racial bias}} or {{c4::views about the death penalty}}. 2. For-cause strikes: - Jurors can be {{c5::struck for cause}} if their views would {{c6::prevent or substantially impair}} them from performing their duties. 3. Peremptory challenges – general rule: - The parties may generally exercise {{c7::peremptory challenges}} for any reason, without stating a cause. 4. Equal-protection limits on peremptories: - Peremptory challenges may not be used to exclude jurors on account of {{c8::race}} or {{c9::gender}}. - Such use of peremptories violates the {{c10::Equal Protection Clause}} (a {{c11::Batson}} violation).

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::UCC}} approach to PER: - Even when there is an integrated writing, its terms may be {{c2::explained or supplemented}} by certain extrinsic evidence. 2. {{c3::Course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade}}: - {{c4::Course of dealing}}: prior conduct between the parties that establishes a {{c5::common basis of understanding}}. - {{c6::Course of performance}}: conduct between the parties in performing the {{c7::current contract}} that shows how they interpret its terms. - {{c8::Usage of trade}}: a practice or method of dealing regularly observed in a {{c9::place, vocation, or trade}} such that parties expect it to be followed. 3. Effect: - These forms of extrinsic evidence may be used to {{c10::explain or supplement}} the written terms of a UCC contract. - The parties’ own {{c11::course of dealing or performance}} can show that their {{c12::specific customs}} take precedence over {{c13::general trade usage}}. 4. Hierarchy of terms: - {{c14::Express terms}} of the contract generally carry greater weight than inconsistent extrinsic evidence. - When possible, express terms should be {{c15::reconciled}} with course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade; only if they cannot reasonably be reconciled do express terms {{c16::control}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. {{c1::Revival}}: where a will is revoked and the revoking instrument is subsequently revoked, the original will is {{c2::presumptively revived}}. 1.1 Exception: the revoked will is not revived if the testator's statements or other evidence make clear she {{c3::did not intend to revive}} the prior will. 1.2 {{c4::Re-execution}}: a revoked will may be re-executed by a subsequent will or codicil if {{c5::testamentary formalities}} are satisfied. 2. {{c6::Dependent Relative Revocation}} ({{c7::DRR}}): a court doctrine under which a court {{c8::disregards a revocation}} that was done to create an alternative disposition to the original will, but was based on a {{c9::mistake of fact or law}}. 2.1 The court will apply DRR and revive the revoked will if doing so would come closer to giving effect to what the testator {{c10::tried, but failed, to do}} than would {{c11::intestate succession}}. 2.2 Requirements (a court may apply DRR and ignore the revocation where): 2.2.1 The revocation was premised on some {{c12::mistake of law or fact}}. 2.2.2 The revocation would not have occurred absent the testator's mistaken belief that some {{c13::other plan for disposition}} of property was valid. 2.2.3 The originally revoked will is {{c14::closer to the testator's preference}} than would be intestate succession.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Capacity-related doctrines in criminal law include: 1. {{c1::Infancy}}: rules limiting criminal liability for very young offenders. 2. {{c2::Diminished capacity}}: a mental state defense based on a mental defect short of insanity. 3. {{c3::Competency to stand trial and be sentenced}}: due process limits on trying/sentencing those who cannot understand proceedings or assist counsel. 4. {{c4::Competency for execution}}: limits on executing those who cannot understand the nature and purpose of the punishment.

subject: Torts
cloze: A {{c1::professional}} must act with the {{c2::knowledge and skill}} of a {{c3::reasonably competent member of the profession}} in good standing in {{c4::similar communities}} under similar circumstances. {{c5::Medical professionals}} (such as physicians) are generally held to a {{c6::national standard of care}}, rather than a purely local standard.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Debtor consent}} requirement 1.2 Debtor consent can be shown in one of two ways: 1.2.1 The debtor agrees to strict foreclosure in an {{c2::authenticated record}}; or 1.2.2 The debtor {{c3::fails to object within 20 days}} after the secured party sends notice of the proposed strict foreclosure. 2. {{c4::Notice of intent to keep collateral}} 2.1 The secured party must send an {{c5::authenticated notice}} stating that the collateral is being kept in {{c6::satisfaction of the debt}}. 2.2 The notice must be sent to the {{c7::debtor}} and to any other {{c8::secured party}} who has provided {{c9::notice of a claim to the collateral}} and has {{c10::perfected}} a security interest in the collateral by filing or notation on a {{c11::certificate of title}}. 3. {{c12::Objection and its effect}} 3.1 If no notified party objects within {{c13::20 days}} after the notice is sent, the strict foreclosure may proceed. 3.2 If any notified party objects within 20 days, the secured party must {{c14::dispose of the collateral by sale}} instead of keeping it.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Conversion}} of goods: • Damages = {{c2::fair market value (FMV) of the goods at the time of the conversion}}. 2. Additional losses for buyers and sellers in UCC sales: • Parties may also recover {{c3::lost profits}} or damages for {{c4::other losses}} resulting from a breach or nonconformance. • {{c5::Incidental damages}}: reasonable expenses incurred because of the breach (e.g., {{c6::inspection, transportation, care and custody of goods, costs of cover or resale}}). • {{c7::Consequential damages}} (primarily for buyers): losses resulting from the seller's breach that the seller had {{c8::reason to know}} about at the time of contracting (e.g., {{c9::lost production, lost resale profits}}), subject to {{c10::mitigation}} ({{c11::cover}} where reasonable). 3. Overall principle: • These damages {{c12::supplement}} the primary contract, market, and cover measures to {{c13::fully compensate}} the injured party.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. Negligence basics: {{c1::Negligence}} is analyzed under an {{c2::objective standard}} by comparing defendant's actions to those of a {{c3::reasonable person under the same or similar circumstances}}. 2. Elements of negligence: 2.1 {{c4::Duty of care}}: Defendant has a duty to conform to a specific standard of care. 2.1.1 {{c5::Reasonably prudent person}}: Defendant's duty is to behave like a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances presented. 2.1.2 {{c6::Exception}}: In certain situations, an {{c7::alternative standard of care}} applies. 2.2 {{c8::Breach of duty}}. 2.3 {{c9::Causation}}: {{c10::Actual cause}} (cause in fact) and {{c11::proximate cause}} (legal cause). 2.4 {{c12::Damages}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Dissolution}} – definition and effect 1.1 Dissolution {{c2::terminates the corporation’s legal existence}}, but the corporation continues solely to {{c3::wind up and liquidate its affairs}}. 1.2 After dissolution, the corporation may not carry on any {{c4::new or regular business}}; it is limited to {{c5::winding up activities}} (collecting assets, paying debts, distributing remaining assets). 2. {{c6::Voluntary dissolution}} 2.1 Nature: Treated as a {{c7::fundamental corporate change}}. 2.2 Approval: Requires {{c8::board approval}} and {{c9::shareholder approval}} under the applicable voting rules. 3. {{c10::Administrative dissolution}} 3.1 Initiated by the {{c11::state}} (e.g., secretary of state). 3.2 Typical grounds: Failure to comply with {{c12::statutory requirements or corporate formalities}} such as filing reports or paying fees. 3.3 Cure: Generally {{c13::curable}} by correcting the default and following statutory {{c14::reinstatement}} procedures. 4. {{c15::Judicial dissolution}} 4.1 Who can bring the action? - {{c16::Attorney general}}. - {{c17::Shareholders}}. 4.2 Attorney general’s grounds: - Corporation {{c18::abused its authority}}. - Corporation {{c19::committed fraud}}. - Corporation {{c20::acted unlawfully}}. 4.3 Shareholders’ grounds: - {{c21::Deadlock}} among the board or shareholders that threatens {{c22::irreparable injury}} to the corporation. - Corporation has {{c23::abandoned its business}} and failed to dissolve. - Corporate assets are being {{c24::wasted or misused for non-corporate purposes}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Definition and nature 1.1 {{c1::Depositions}} are {{c2::oral proceedings in which an attorney may examine any person under oath}}. 1.2 Testimony is {{c3::sworn and subject to penalties for perjury}}. 2. Who may be deposed and how 2.1 {{c4::Parties}}: A {{c5::notice of deposition}} is sufficient to compel a party's attendance. 2.2 {{c6::Non-parties}}: Non-parties may be deposed, but must be {{c7::subpoenaed}}. 2.3 Documents: A {{c8::subpoena duces tecum}} is used to compel a deponent to bring documents or other tangible things to the deposition. 3. Scope 3.1 The scope of examination may cover {{c9::any issue within the scope of discovery}}. 4. Objections 4.1 Deponent's counsel may object to questions on the record, but the deponent is still {{c10::required to answer}}. 4.2 Exception: If an objection is based on {{c11::privilege}} (i.e., answering would reveal privileged information), counsel may {{c12::instruct the deponent not to answer}}. 5. Length and limits 5.1 A deposition is generally limited to {{c13::one day of seven hours}}. 5.2 A party must seek {{c14::court approval}} to take {{c15::more than 10 depositions}} or to {{c16::depose the same person twice}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Arson}} is the {{c2::malicious}} {{c3::burning}} of the {{c4::dwelling house}} {{c5::of another}}. 1.1 Malicious: 1.1.1 Requires {{c6::intent or extreme recklessness}}. 1.2 Burning: 1.2.1 Requires some {{c7::damage to the structure caused by fire}}. 1.2.2 Damage from {{c8::smoke, water, or explosions}} is not sufficient at {{c9::common law}}. 1.3 Dwelling house: 1.3.1 A structure where someone {{c10::lives}}. 1.3.2 Dwelling-house requirement is a {{c11::common law}} limitation. 1.3.3 On the {{c12::MBE}}, modern statutes may define arson to include burning a {{c13::non-residential structure}}. 1.4 Of another: 1.4.1 Another person's {{c14::dwelling}}. 1.4.2 At common law, there is no arson if you {{c15::own the dwelling but do not reside there}}. 1.5 Damage required: 1.5.1 There must be {{c16::charring or more substantial damage}}. 1.5.2 Mere {{c17::discoloration or blackening}} is insufficient.

subject: Torts
cloze: Manufacturing defect: 1. Definition: 1.1 A {{c1::manufacturing defect}} exists when a particular product {{c2::departs from its intended design}}, causing it to be {{c3::more dangerous than all of the manufacturer's other products of the same kind}}. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – {{c4::consumer-expectation test}}: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that the product {{c5::failed to perform as safely as an ordinary consumer would expect}} when used in an intended or reasonably foreseeable way.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Modern {{c1::burglary statutes}} typically broaden the {{c2::common law}} definition: 1. {{c3::Breaking requirement}}: - Many modern statutes {{c4::do not require a breaking}}; {{c5::unauthorized entry}} is sufficient. 2. {{c6::Nighttime requirement}}: - {{c7::Nighttime}} is often {{c8::eliminated as an element}}. 3. {{c9::Covered structures}}: - Statutes commonly extend burglary to {{c10::non-dwelling structures}} (e.g., stores or other buildings) beyond {{c11::dwellings used for sleeping}}. 4. {{c12::Intended offense}}: - The intended offense is broadened beyond {{c13::felonies}} to include {{c14::misdemeanors, especially theft}}. - The intended crime {{c15::need not be completed}}. Exam note: - On the {{c16::MBE}}, apply {{c1::modern statutory rules}} for burglary unless the question specifically directs you to use the {{c2::common law}} definition.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 2. {{c1::Challenging a plea}} 2.1 Appellate courts will not disturb valid pleas unless: 2.1.1 The plea was made {{c2::involuntarily}} (e.g., due to a misunderstanding). 2.1.2 The court that took the plea {{c3::lacked jurisdiction}}. 2.1.3 The defendant had {{c4::ineffective assistance of counsel}}, or 2.1.4 The {{c5::prosecutor failed to honor the plea agreement}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: An {{c1::easement by prescription}} is acquired through use of another's land, similar to acquiring title by {{c2::adverse possession}}. 1.1 Requirements: The acquirer's use of another's land must be: 1.1.1 {{c3::Continuous}} for the applicable statutory period; 1.1.2 {{c4::Open and notorious}} so that the owner knows or should know of the use; 1.1.3 {{c5::Actual}}; and 1.1.4 {{c6::Hostile, meaning without the owner's permission}}. 2. Termination by prescription: An easement can also be {{c7::terminated by prescription}} if the servient landowner interferes with the easement in a way that satisfies the same requirements (continuous, open and notorious, actual, and hostile) for the statutory period.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 {{c2::Assault}} is an {{c3::intentional act}} by D creating P's {{c4::reasonable apprehension}} of {{c5::immediate harmful or offensive contact}} to P's person, or something closely attached to P's person (e.g., hat, cane). It is also considered an {{c6::attempted battery}}. 2. {{c7::Elements}} 2.1 {{c8::Act by D}} that creates a reasonable apprehension in P. 2.1.1 P has {{c9::awareness}} of D's act and has a reasonable expectation that it will result in immediate harmful or offensive contact to P's person. 2.1.2 {{c10::Apparent ability}} is sufficient, as long as D's conduct could reasonably create P's apprehension, even if D appears incapable of accomplishing the threatened harm. 2.2 Of {{c11::immediate}} harmful or offensive contact to P's person. 2.2.1 P must apprehend an {{c12::immediate or imminent battery}}. 2.2.2 {{c13::Words or threats alone}} are usually insufficient, unless coupled with some {{c14::overt act}} (e.g., picking up a weapon, clenching fists). 2.2.3 {{c15::Threats of future battery}} are insufficient. 2.3 {{c16::Causation}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: The following hearsay exceptions apply regardless of whether the declarant is available; availability is {{c1::immaterial}}: 1. {{c2::Present state of mind}} - A statement of the declarant’s then-existing {{c3::state of mind}} (e.g., intent, plan, motive) or emotional, sensory, or physical condition. 2. {{c4::Excited utterance}} - A statement relating to a {{c5::startling event or condition}} - Made while the declarant was under the {{c6::stress of excitement}} that it caused. 3. {{c7::Present sense impression}} - A statement {{c8::describing or explaining}} an event or condition - Made while or {{c9::immediately after}} the declarant perceived it. 4. Statements for {{c10::medical diagnosis or treatment}} - Statements made for (and reasonably pertinent to) {{c11::medical diagnosis or treatment}} - Describing {{c12::medical history, symptoms, or the general cause}} of the condition. 5. {{c13::Past recollection recorded}} - A record that reflects a matter the witness once knew about but now cannot recall well enough to testify fully and accurately - Made or adopted when the matter was {{c14::fresh in memory}} - Accurately reflects the witness’s knowledge. 6. {{c15::Business records}} - Records of acts, events, conditions, opinions, or diagnoses - Made at or near the time by (or from information transmitted by) someone with {{c16::knowledge}} - Kept in the course of a {{c17::regularly conducted business}} activity - Making the record was a {{c18::regular practice}} of that activity. 7. {{c19::Public records or reports}} - Records or statements of a public office that set out the office’s {{c20::activities}}, observations under a {{c21::legal duty to report}}, or factual findings from legally authorized investigations (subject to limitations in criminal cases). 8. {{c22::Judgments and prior convictions}} - Evidence of a final judgment of conviction for a crime punishable by {{c23::death or imprisonment for more than one year}}, offered to prove any fact essential to the judgment. 9. {{c24::Ancient documents}} - Statements in a document at least {{c25::20 years}} old that is authenticated. 10. Documents affecting {{c26::property interests}} - Statements in a document that affects an interest in property (e.g., deeds, wills, mortgages), if relevant to the document’s purpose and authenticated. 11. {{c27::Learned treatises}} - Statements in a reliable, authoritative treatise, periodical, or pamphlet, used with an expert and {{c28::read into evidence}} (but not received as an exhibit). 12. {{c29::Family records}} - Statements of personal or family history contained in family Bibles, genealogies, inscriptions on rings, engravings on urns or tombstones, or similar family records. 13. {{c30::Market reports and similar commercial publications}} - Market quotations, lists, directories, or other published compilations that are generally relied upon by the public or by persons in particular occupations.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 2. {{c1::De facto corporation}} 2.1 Definition 2.1.1 A {{c2::de facto corporation}} exists where an entity’s formation fails to strictly comply with incorporation formalities, but it carries on business as a corporation and may still be {{c3::treated as a properly formed corporation}}. 2.2 Requirements for de facto corporation 2.2.1 A {{c4::corporate law exists}} under which the entity could have become legally incorporated. 2.2.2 There was a {{c5::good faith effort to comply}} with the state’s incorporation laws. 2.2.3 The business {{c6::acted like a corporation}} (e.g., conducting business in its corporate name).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Solicitation}} is {{c2::inciting, urging, or otherwise asking another to commit a crime}} with the {{c3::intent that they commit the crime}}. 1.1 No {{c4::affirmative response}} from the solicited party is required; the crime is complete upon the asking. 1.2 Solicitation {{c5::merges with the target offense}}. 2. Merger and relationship to conspiracy: 2.1 Solicitation is complete when the defendant asks the {{c6::solicitee}} to commit the felony. 2.2 If the solicitee agrees, the agreement gives rise to {{c7::conspiracy}}, and the solicitation {{c8::merges with the conspiracy}} (the only crime remaining is conspiracy). 2.3 It does not matter if the solicited party is {{c9::convicted}} or if the solicited crime was {{c10::impossible to commit}}. 3. Defenses: There are very few defenses that apply to solicitation. 3.1 {{c11::Refusal by the solicitee}} is not a defense. 3.2 {{c12::Impossibility}} and {{c13::withdrawal}} are not defenses at common law. 3.3 Under the {{c14::MPC}}, {{c15::renunciation}} is a defense if the defendant prevents the commission of the crime, but at {{c16::common law}} (followed by most jurisdictions) renunciation is not a defense.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::remainder}} is a {{c2::future interest in a third person}} (someone other than the grantor) that becomes possessory {{c3::immediately upon the natural termination}} of a prior estate of known, fixed duration, {{c4::without cutting short that prior estate}}. It must be {{c5::expressly created in the same conveyance}} as the prior estate and is {{c6::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}. An interest that {{c7::cuts off a prior transferee}} is an {{c8::executory interest}}, not a remainder. Remainders are classified as either {{c9::vested}} or {{c10::contingent}}. Vested remainders include {{c11::indefeasibly vested}}, {{c12::vested subject to total divestment}}, and {{c13::vested subject to open (class gifts)}}. A {{c14::contingent remainder}} exists where there is a {{c15::condition precedent}}, an {{c16::unascertained or unborn taker}}, or {{c17::both}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Annual shareholder meetings}}: - The corporation must hold annual meetings for {{c2::electing directors}} and conducting other shareholder business. 2. {{c3::Special shareholder meetings}}: - Special meetings may be called to conduct business requiring {{c4::shareholder approval}}. 3. {{c5::Notice}} of shareholder meetings: - Notice of any shareholder meeting must be sent to shareholders {{c6::eligible to vote}}. - Notice must reasonably inform shareholders of the {{c7::time}}, {{c8::place}}, and {{c9::purpose}} of the meeting (especially for special meetings and fundamental changes).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Insanity – General Rule: 1. Scope of the defense: 1.1 {{c1::Legal insanity}} is a {{c2::complete defense}} to {{c3::all crimes}}, regardless of the {{c4::mens rea or intent requirement}}. 1.2 If the defendant is found legally insane under the applicable test, he is {{c5::entitled to acquittal}} (typically followed by {{c6::commitment proceedings}}). 2. Jurisdictional tests: 2.1 Jurisdictions adopt one of several {{c7::insanity tests}} to determine whether the defendant was so mentally ill at the time of the offense that he should be excused. 2.2 The four main tests are: {{c8::M'Naghten}}, {{c9::Irresistible Impulse}}, {{c10::MPC}}, and {{c11::Durham}}. 2.3 On the {{c12::MBE}}, the question will expressly state which {{c13::insanity test}} applies.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Rule 11 requires the {{c1::attorney or pro se party}} to sign all pleadings, written motions, and other papers. The signature acts as a {{c2::certification}} that, to the best of the signor's knowledge, after {{c3::all reasonable inquiry}}: 1. The filing is not for an {{c4::improper purpose}} (e.g., harassment, delay). 2. {{c5::Non-frivolous legal contentions}} made are warranted by law. 3. {{c6::Factual contentions}} have {{c7::evidentiary support}}, or are likely to have evidentiary support and are {{c8::specifically so identified}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Contracts subject to the {{c1::Statute of Frauds}} require {{c2::special proof of their existence}} or they may be {{c3::invalid or unenforceable}}. The SoF can generally be satisfied by: (1) a {{c4::signed writing}}; (2) a {{c5::UCC merchant confirmation}}; (3) qualifying {{c6::performance}}; and (4) {{c7::real estate part performance}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: A {{c1::disclaimer}} limits or eliminates liability for {{c2::implied warranties}}, but generally cannot disclaim {{c3::express warranties}}. Disclaimers must be {{c4::conspicuous}} and, to disclaim the implied warranty of {{c5::merchantability}}, must {{c6::mention "merchantability"}}. A {{c7::limitation of remedy}} restricts the buyer’s recovery upon breach of warranty (e.g., to {{c8::repair or replacement only}}). Remedy limitations are generally valid for all warranties unless {{c9::unconscionable}} or they {{c10::fail of their essential purpose}}. Damages for breach of warranty are usually measured by the {{c11::difference between the value of the goods as delivered and the value as warranted}}, plus allowable {{c12::incidental}} and {{c13::consequential}} damages (subject to any valid limitations).

subject: Evidence
cloze: Experts may provide opinions on facts or issues in the case if their testimony meets foundational requirements and stays within the permissible {{c1::scope of expert opinions}}. Foundationally, expert testimony must be {{c2::helpful}} to the trier of fact, offered by a {{c3::qualified}} expert, held to a {{c4::reasonable degree of certainty}}, based on a {{c5::proper factual basis}}, and grounded in {{c6::reliable principles and methods}} (with additional {{c7::Daubert-style factors}} for scientific evidence). As to scope, experts may generally opine on {{c8::ultimate issues}}, but in criminal cases they may not opine directly on the {{c9::defendant’s actual mental state}} when it is an element of the crime or a defense.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. General rule: When property is divided upon marriage dissolution, there are two main approaches used, depending on the state. 1.1 {{c1::Equitable division of marital property}}: Each spouse takes their {{c2::separate property}} and the court divides property acquired during the marriage on an {{c3::equitable basis}}. This is the {{c4::most popular approach}}—assume this approach for MEE purposes unless provided otherwise. 1.2 {{c5::Community property}}: Property acquired during the marriage is owned {{c6::50/50 by each spouse}}, unless acquired by {{c7::gift or bequest}}, in which case it is considered {{c8::separate property}}. 1.3 Approach to property division (courts will do the following): 1.3.1 {{c9::Categorize property}}: Classify property as {{c10::marital or separate}}. 1.3.2 {{c11::Determine equitable distribution of marital property}}: Distribute marital property between spouses based on {{c12::relevant factors}}. Note: If asked to divide marital property, discuss the {{c13::approach}} and how it works, then explain how the relevant factors will influence how the court would divide the property. 1.4 {{c14::Modification}}: Property distribution decrees are generally {{c15::not modifiable}} in most states.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::In general}} 1.1 Land bordering watercourses (natural or artificial bodies of water, such as lakes and rivers) is governed by either the {{c2::riparian doctrine}} or the {{c3::prior appropriation doctrine}}. 2. {{c4::Riparian doctrine}} 2.1 Under the riparian doctrine, water belongs to those who {{c5::own land bordering the watercourse}} (riparian owners). 2.2 {{c6::Reasonable use theory}} (majority): riparian owners share rights to {{c7::reasonable use}} and are liable to other owners if their use {{c8::unreasonably interferes}} with others' use; courts balance the {{c9::utility of the use}} against the {{c10::gravity of the harm}}. 2.3 {{c11::Natural flow theory}} (minority): riparian owners may be {{c12::enjoined}} for any use resulting in a {{c13::substantial or material reduction}} in others' water quantity, quality, or velocity. 2.4 Under both theories, {{c14::natural uses}} (e.g., household use) generally prevail over {{c15::artificial uses}} (e.g., manufacturing or irrigation). 3. {{c16::Prior appropriation doctrine}} 3.1 Under the prior appropriation doctrine, water rights are originally acquired by {{c17::actual beneficial use}}. 3.2 {{c18::Priority of beneficial use}} determines rights to the water; the {{c19::first}} individual to make a beneficial (productive) use of the water has the {{c20::superior legal right}} to continued use.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: A {{c1::partnership}} is formed when {{c2::two or more people}} associate to carry on a {{c3::for-profit business}} as {{c4::co-owners}}. No {{c5::formal or written agreement}} is required, and the parties do not need to {{c6::intend to form a “partnership”}} as such. A partnership can be found where their {{c7::conduct shows an intent to associate as co-owners}} in a for-profit business.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Domicile requirement for divorce}}: - To establish subject-matter jurisdiction over a divorce action, at least {{c2::one spouse must be domiciled}} in the forum state where the action is brought. 2. {{c3::Durational residency}} requirements: - Many states require a {{c4::minimum period of residency}} before a spouse can file for divorce. - Purpose: To ensure a {{c5::genuine connection}} to the forum and to prevent {{c6::forum shopping}}. 3. {{c7::Full Faith and Credit}} for divorce decrees: - Under the U.S. Constitution’s Full Faith and Credit Clause, a divorce decree granted by one state must be {{c8::recognized by other states}} if the rendering state had proper jurisdiction. - Jurisdiction for Full Faith and Credit purposes is satisfied when {{c9::one or both spouses was domiciled}} in the state that issued the decree. - Other states may, in limited circumstances, {{c10::collaterally attack}} the decree by disputing the existence of {{c11::domicile}} in the rendering state.

subject: Corporations
cloze: The board of directors generally acts {{c1::collectively}} through meetings or unanimous written consent. 1. {{c2::Board meetings}} - May be {{c3::regular or special}}. - May be held in person or by any means allowing all directors to {{c4::simultaneously hear one another}} (e.g., videoconference). 2. {{c5::Notice}} - {{c6::Regular meetings}} may usually be held without notice. - {{c7::Special meetings}} generally require notice, often at least {{c8::two days'}} notice. 3. {{c9::Quorum}} - Usually set by the {{c10::articles or bylaws}}. - If not specified, a quorum is a {{c11::majority of the number of directors}}. 4. {{c12::Action without a meeting}} - The board may act without a meeting if {{c13::all directors provide written consent}}. - The written consent must {{c14::describe the action taken}} and be signed or authenticated by all directors.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In assessing fairness of personal jurisdiction, courts also consider the {{c1::forum state's interest}} in hearing the case. State’s interest factor • Core question: Does the forum state have an {{c2::interest in allocating its limited judicial resources}} to hearing this matter? • Weaker state interest: The forum state’s interest is less compelling when: – The case involves {{c3::nonresident actors}}. – The relevant acts are {{c4::nonresident acts}} (occurred outside the forum). – The case involves {{c5::significant complexity}} that burdens the forum’s resources without a strong local connection.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Under {{c1::common law}}, conspiracy is {{c2::bilateral}}, requiring that {{c3::at least two parties have genuine criminal intent}}. If one party is {{c4::feigning agreement}} (e.g., an undercover officer), there is {{c5::no conspiracy}} under strict common law. Under the {{c6::MPC}}, conspiracy can be {{c7::unilateral}}, so {{c8::one party with criminal intent}} may be convicted even if the other is {{c9::feigning agreement}}. On the bar exam, unless otherwise instructed, apply the {{c10::common law bilateral rule}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Third-party standing}}: A plaintiff with standing may assert the rights of a third party where the plaintiff has suffered injury and either: 1.1 The plaintiff's injury {{c2::adversely affects his relationship with third parties}}. Example: A doctor can assert patients' rights in challenging abortion restrictions; a bar owner can assert underage males' rights in challenging a ban on beer sales to underage males. 1.2 The injured party is {{c3::unlikely or unable to assert his own rights}}. Example: An association can challenge a law requiring disclosure of member identities, because members could not challenge the law directly without revealing their identities. 2. {{c4::Organizational standing}}: 2.1 {{c5::Direct injury}}: Organizations always have standing if the injury is to the organization itself. 2.2 Suits on behalf of members: Organizations may sue on members' behalf if: 2.2.1 There is an {{c6::injury to the members}} that would give members standing to sue individually; 2.2.2 The injury is {{c7::related to the organization's purpose}}; and 2.2.3 Neither the {{c8::claim nor the relief requires participation of individual members}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Forgery}} – general rule: 1.1 {{c2::Creating or altering}} a written document with {{c3::purported legal significance}} to be false, with the {{c4::intent to defraud}}. 2. Required elements: 2.1 {{c2::Creating or altering}}: 2.1.1 For example: {{c5::drafting, adding to, or deleting from a document's contents}}. 2.1.2 Also includes {{c6::offering a forged document as genuine}} even if the defendant did not create the forged document. 2.2 Document with {{c3::purported legal significance}}: 2.2.1 A document that carries {{c7::legal value}} (e.g., a check or contract), not something like a painting. 2.3 To be {{c8::false}}: 2.3.1 {{c9::Modifying the document into something it is not}}. 2.3.2 {{c10::Changing its legal significance}}, not just making it inaccurate. 2.4 With {{c4::intent to defraud}}: 2.4.1 Forgery is a {{c11::specific intent}} crime. 2.4.2 Actually defrauding somebody is not required; the {{c12::mere intent to defraud is sufficient}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Discovery is a {{c1::court-mandated, party-driven process}} of exchanging information, supervised by the {{c2::court}} but conducted by the {{c3::parties}}. It is framed by two overarching questions—what is the {{c4::scope of discovery}} and whether information is {{c5::privileged}}—and it proceeds through early case management steps ({{c6::meet-and-confer, initial disclosures, and a scheduling order}}) and then formal tools like {{c7::depositions, requests for production, interrogatories, and requests for admission}}, followed by {{c8::expert}} and {{c9::pretrial}} disclosures.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Miranda governs when police must give warnings before questioning a suspect and what those warnings must include. 1. When Miranda applies 1.1. Miranda protections apply only when a suspect is both in {{c1::custody}} and subjected to {{c2::interrogation}}. 1.2. If required warnings are not given before custodial interrogation, the suspect’s statements are generally {{c3::inadmissible}}, subject to narrow exceptions (such as the {{c4::public-safety exception}}). 2. Core concepts 2.1. {{c1::Custody}} is an objective, reasonable-person standard (whether a reasonable person would feel free to leave). 2.2. {{c2::Interrogation}} is limited to police words or conduct reasonably likely to elicit {{c5::incriminating responses}}; some questioning (e.g., routine booking) and {{c6::volunteered statements}} fall outside Miranda. 3. Required warnings and constitutional basis 3.1. Before custodial interrogation, police must substantially advise the suspect of the {{c7::right to remain silent}}, that {{c8::anything said can be used against him in court}}, the {{c9::right to counsel}}, and {{c10::appointment of counsel if indigent}}. 3.2. Miranda is grounded in the {{c11::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}}, not the {{c12::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: A {{c1::legal separation}} is a {{c2::judicially recognized parting}} of the spouses that {{c3::does not terminate the marriage}}. It is {{c4::not a divorce}}: - The parties {{c5::remain married}}. - They {{c6::cannot remarry}}. In a separation proceeding, the court can decide: - {{c7::Property}} rights and division, - {{c8::Spousal support}}, - {{c9::Child custody}}, and - {{c10::Child support}}. In some states, a legal separation can later be {{c11::converted into an absolute divorce}} at the request of the parties after a {{c12::specified period of time}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Government may regulate {{c1::obscenity}}, which is {{c2::unprotected speech}}. 1. Definition and test: Expression is obscene if all of the following are met: 1.1 It appeals to {{c3::prurient interests}} (sexually stimulating): 1.1.1 Uses an {{c4::average person standard}}: how would the average person, applying {{c5::community standards}}, view the material as a whole? 1.2 It is {{c6::patently offensive}} in its sexual portrayal: 1.2.1 The material must offend community standards regarding the {{c7::portrayal of sexual matters}}; and 1.2.2 Any law prohibiting obscene material must {{c8::specify what is deemed patently offensive}}; and 1.3 Taken as a whole, the material lacks {{c9::serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value}}: 1.3.1 This is determined based on a {{c10::national reasonable-person standard}}, not a local community standard (unlike the first two prongs).

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::Commerce Clause}} gives Congress broad authority to regulate {{c2::interstate and intrastate commerce}}. 1. {{c3::Interstate commerce}}: Congress may regulate the {{c4::channels and instrumentalities of interstate commerce}} and {{c5::persons and things in interstate commerce}}, as well as {{c6::economic activities that, in the aggregate, substantially affect interstate commerce}}. 2. {{c7::Intrastate commerce}}: Congress’s power depends on whether the activity is {{c8::economic}} or {{c9::non‑economic}}. 3. {{c10::Dormant Commerce Clause}}: limits {{c11::state laws that burden interstate commerce}} by interfering with {{c12::Congress’s commerce power}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Children are generally held to the standard of care of a {{c1::reasonable child of similar age, education, intelligence, and experience}} under like circumstances, rather than the reasonably prudent adult standard. Very young children—typically those under about {{c2::6–7 years old}}—are generally deemed to {{c3::lack capacity to be negligent}}. Under the {{c4::adult activities exception}}, a child who engages in an inherently dangerous or otherwise adult activity (such as {{c5::driving a car or operating a motorboat}}) must conform to the {{c6::adult standard of care}} for that activity.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Laws requiring disclosure of group membership (e.g., membership lists) are subject to {{c1::strict scrutiny}} if they create a {{c2::chilling effect}} on association. Rule: Disclosure requirements must meet strict scrutiny when they would {{c3::chill association}}—that is, {{c4::inhibit the group's ability or willingness to associate}}. The government must show a {{c5::compelling interest}} and that the disclosure requirement is {{c6::narrowly tailored}} and the {{c7::least restrictive means}} of achieving that interest.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Expert disclosures 1.1 At least {{c1::90 days before trial}}, parties must identify experts who may be used at trial. 1.2 They must provide an expert report containing the expert's {{c2::opinions}}, the {{c3::data and information considered}}, the expert's {{c4::qualifications}}, and similar details. 2. Pretrial disclosures 2.1 Parties must provide detailed information about evidence to be used at trial at least {{c5::30 days before trial}}. 2.2 This includes {{c6::documents and other exhibits}} to be used as evidence and the identity of {{c7::witnesses who will testify}} at trial.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A valid express private trust requires the following elements: 1. {{c1::Settlor with capacity to convey}} 1.1 The settlor must have capacity to convey, which is the same capacity required to create a {{c2::will}}. 2. {{c3::Clear present intent}} to create a {{c4::trust relationship}} 2.1 The settlor must have absolutely clear intent and must understand the nature of the act (i.e., what a trust is). 2.2 A {{c5::writing}} is not required unless required by the {{c6::Statute of Wills}} or {{c7::Statute of Frauds}} (for example, for {{c8::real property}}). 3. {{c9::Competent trustee with duties}} 3.1 The settlor must name a trustee, but once established, a trust will not fail solely because a trustee does not exist; in such cases, a trustee will be {{c10::appointed}}. 3.2 Trustee capacity: In most states, anyone who can {{c11::hold title to property}} can act as a trustee. 4. {{c12::Definite beneficiary}} 4.1 At the time of trust creation, the settlor must either specifically {{c13::identify the beneficiaries by name}} or sufficiently {{c14::describe how the beneficiaries will be ascertained}}. 4.2 This requirement does not apply to {{c15::charitable trusts}}. 4.3 The {{c16::sole trustee}} cannot be the {{c17::sole beneficiary}} of a trust. 5. {{c18::Present and clear disposition}} of specific {{c19::trust property}} 5.1 The settlor must have specific property they want to place in trust. 5.2 The trust property must be specifically described or {{c20::ascertainable with certainty}} from its description. 6. {{c21::Valid trust purpose}} 6.1 The trust must be for a purpose that is not {{c22::illegal}}, {{c23::impossible}}, or {{c24::contrary to public policy}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. Intrusion upon seclusion 1.1 Definition: Intrusion upon P's {{c1::private affairs}} in a manner that would be {{c2::highly offensive to a reasonable person}}. 1.2 Requirements 1.2.1 P must have a {{c3::reasonable expectation of privacy}}. 1.2.1.1 There is {{c4::no reasonable expectation of privacy in public}}. 1.2.2 The intrusion must be {{c5::highly offensive}}. 1.2.2.1 For example, {{c6::peeping, eavesdropping, or using hidden cameras}} in P's domain. 1.3 {{c7::No newsworthiness exception}} for intrusion. 2. Disclosure (public disclosure of private facts) 2.1 Definition: {{c8::Public disclosure}} of P's {{c9::private information}}. 2.2 Requirements (the disclosure must be): 2.2.1 {{c10::Highly offensive to a reasonable person}}. 2.2.1.1 {{c11::Public activities are not objectionable}}. 2.2.1.2 For example, D announces that the mayor frequents strip clubs—no liability because the acts occur {{c12::in public}}. 2.2.2 {{c13::Publicized}}: Made available to a public audience. 2.2.3 Subject to a {{c14::newsworthiness exception}}: No liability if otherwise private facts are {{c15::newsworthy}}. 3. Defenses 3.1 {{c16::Consent}} is a valid defense. 3.2 {{c17::Privilege}} is a valid defense to disclosure.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Termination by {{c1::Estoppel}} 1.1 An easement is terminated by estoppel where the {{c2::servient owner reasonably relies}} on the easement holder's {{c3::conduct or representations indicating an intent to abandon}} the easement. 1.2 {{c4::Non-use alone is insufficient}} to create estoppel; there must be conduct or representations plus reasonable reliance. 2. Termination by {{c5::Release}} 2.1 The easement holder can terminate the easement by executing and delivering a {{c6::deed of release}} to the servient tenement owner. 2.2 Because an easement is an interest in land, the release generally must satisfy {{c7::deed formalities}}. 3. Termination by {{c8::Abandonment}} 3.1 An easement is terminated by abandonment if its holder {{c9::physically demonstrates an intent to permanently abandon}} the easement. 3.2 {{c10::Mere words or non-use are insufficient}} without physical acts that are inconsistent with continued use.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the Takings Clause, the government may take private property only for {{c1::public use}}. 1. {{c2::Broad definition}}: - A taking is for public use if the government has a {{c3::reasonable belief}} that the taking will benefit the public, a {{c4::low standard}}. 2. {{c5::Rational relationship test}}: - Public use is satisfied if the taking is {{c6::rationally related}} to a {{c7::legitimate public purpose}}, such as economic redevelopment or eliminating blight. - Property may be transferred to {{c8::private parties}} so long as the overall project satisfies this public purpose standard.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A non-party absentee may seek {{c1::permissive intervention}} in a pending suit. Permissive intervention is allowed in the court’s {{c2::discretion}} if any of the following apply: 1. {{c3::Common question of law or fact}}: • The absentee has a claim or defense that shares a {{c4::common question of law or fact}} with the underlying action. 2. {{c5::Conditional statutory right}}: • The absentee has a {{c6::conditional statutory right to intervene}}. 3. {{c7::Government officer or agency}}: • The absentee is an {{c8::officer or agency}}; and • An existing claim or defense relates to that officer/agency or to a {{c9::statute, regulation, or order}} administered by the officer/agency. In deciding whether to allow permissive intervention, the court must consider whether intervention will {{c10::unduly delay or prejudice}} adjudication of the {{c11::original parties’ rights}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: If the adverse possessor’s use of the land {{c1::violated}} a restrictive covenant, the covenant will {{c2::not run with the land}} once title is acquired by adverse possession. By contrast, if the adverse possessor’s use {{c3::complied}} with the covenant, the covenant {{c4::will run with the land}} and continue to bind future owners.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::General warranty deeds}} include {{c2::six covenants for title}}. These covenants concern the {{c3::condition of title}}, not the physical condition of the property. 2. {{c4::Present covenants}} (breached, if at all, at the time of delivery): 2.1 {{c5::Seisin}}: the grantor covenants that he is the {{c6::rightful owner}} (i.e., has title and possession) and that the deed covers the described land. 2.2 {{c7::Right to convey}}: the grantor covenants that he has the {{c8::right to convey}} the property. 2.3 Covenant {{c9::against encumbrances}}: the grantor covenants that the land is {{c10::free from encumbrances}} (e.g., servitudes, mortgages), except as otherwise stated. 3. {{c11::Future covenants}} (breached, if at all, only after delivery): 3.1 {{c12::Quiet enjoyment}}: the grantor covenants that the grantee will not be {{c13::disturbed by a third party's claim of lawful title}}. 3.2 {{c14::Warranty}}: the grantor agrees to {{c15::defend against lawful claims of title by others}}. 3.3 {{c16::Further assurances}}: the grantor promises to {{c17::perform future acts reasonably necessary to perfect the title conveyed}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach}}: 1. {{c2::Property}} Cases: - Courts apply the law of the {{c3::state most significantly related to the property transaction}}, which in practice usually means the {{c4::state where the property is located}}, especially for land. 2. {{c5::Corporation}} Cases: - Courts generally apply the law of the {{c6::state where the corporation is incorporated}}, which is treated as having the {{c7::most significant relationship}} to internal corporate affairs.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Fourth Amendment Applicability – Government vs. Private Conduct 1. {{c1::Government conduct requirement}} 1.1 The Fourth Amendment applies only to {{c2::government conduct}}. 1.2 Government conduct includes actions by {{c3::police and other law enforcement officials}} and by {{c4::other government agents}} acting in an investigative or enforcement capacity. 2. {{c5::Purely private conduct}} 2.1 The Fourth Amendment does {{c6::NOT}} protect against {{c7::purely private conduct}}. 2.2 A search or seizure by a private individual acting on their own initiative is {{c8::not subject to Fourth Amendment limits}}. 3. {{c9::Authorized private conduct as government action}} 3.1 {{c10::Private persons acting at the direction of government agents}} are treated as {{c11::government actors}}. 3.2 If the government {{c12::instigates, encourages, or directs}} the private actor’s search or seizure, the conduct is {{c13::attributable to the government}} and the Fourth Amendment applies.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under {{c1::Federal Rule 60(b)}}, a court may relieve a party from a final judgment or order on the following specific grounds: 1. {{c2::Mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect}} • Example: relief from a {{c3::default judgment}} entered against a defendant who did not receive {{c4::actual notice}}. 2. {{c5::Newly discovered evidence}} that could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial • The evidence must have {{c6::existed at the time of trial}}. • The moving party must have made {{c7::diligent efforts}} to discover it. • The evidence would likely have {{c8::changed the result}}. 3. {{c9::Fraud, misrepresentation, or misconduct}} by the opposing party • The fraud or misconduct must be established by {{c10::clear and convincing evidence}}. • It must have prevented the party from {{c11::fully and fairly presenting her case}}. 4. The {{c12::judgment is void}} • Example: a judgment rendered by a court that lacked {{c13::subject matter jurisdiction}}. • A judgment is not void merely because it is {{c14::erroneous}}. 5. The judgment has been {{c15::satisfied, released, or discharged}} • Includes judgments based on an earlier judgment that was later {{c16::reversed or vacated}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 1. In General: 1.1 Judgments of {{c1::foreign nations}} are {{c2::not given full faith and credit}}, but may be recognized on {{c3::comity}} principles (i.e., voluntary recognition). 1.2 In choosing whether to recognize a foreign judgment, courts look at: 1.2.1 Whether the foreign court had {{c4::jurisdiction}}; and 1.2.2 Whether {{c5::fair procedures}} were used in adjudicating the case. 2. Effect of recognition: 2.1 If a foreign judgment is {{c6::recognized}}, it is {{c7::enforced the same as another state's valid judgment}} would be.

subject: Con Law
cloze: State taxes affecting {{c1::interstate commerce}} must have a {{c2::substantial connection}} to the state and may not {{c3::discriminate against or unduly burden}} interstate commerce. A state may not use its tax system to {{c4::help in-state businesses}} or {{c5::discriminate against interstate commerce}}. 1. Initial analysis 1.1 Ask whether the tax {{c6::discriminates against interstate commerce}}. 1.1.1 If yes: The tax is {{c7::invalid}} and violates the {{c8::Dormant Commerce Clause}}. 1.1.2 If no: Ask whether the {{c9::burden}} placed on interstate commerce outweighs the {{c10::benefits}} to the state. 2. Three requirements for a valid, non-discriminatory tax on interstate commerce 2.1 {{c11::Substantial nexus}}: The tax must have a substantial nexus to the taxing state, meaning the item or activity taxed is based on significant in-state activity. 2.2 {{c12::Fair apportionment}}: The tax must be fairly apportioned; the state may tax only the portion of the activity that is connected to the state. 2.3 {{c13::Fair relationship}}: The tax must be fairly related to services or benefits provided by the state, meaning that the tax is fairly related to some government service or benefit. 3. Intergovernmental immunity 3.1 States may not directly {{c14::tax or regulate federal government property or activities}} without the consent of Congress. 3.2 Exception: {{c15::Indirect, non-discriminatory taxes}} are valid if they do not unreasonably burden the federal government, such as a {{c16::state income tax on a federal employee working in the state}}, which is permissible because it is not a direct tax on the federal government itself.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Some privacy-related rights have {{c1::separate or evolving standards of review}} and are often tested as distinct doctrines. 1. {{c2::Right to abortion}} - Treated as a key privacy-related right with its own specialized doctrinal framework, rather than simply receiving the same strict scrutiny as other privacy rights. 2. {{c3::Right to engage in private, consensual homosexual activity}} - Adults have a protected {{c4::liberty interest}} in engaging in private, consensual sexual conduct. - Laws criminalizing private, consensual homosexual activity have been struck down as violating {{c5::liberty and privacy}} interests, even though the Court did not clearly label a specific level of scrutiny. 3. {{c6::Right to refuse medical treatment}} - Competent adults have a {{c7::liberty interest}} in refusing unwanted medical treatment, including potentially {{c8::life-sustaining}} treatment. - States may assert countervailing interests (e.g., preserving life, preventing suicide, protecting third parties) and may require {{c9::procedural safeguards}} such as clear and convincing evidence of the patient’s wishes.

subject: Torts
cloze: Self-defense as a defense to intentional torts: 1. {{c1::Retreat rules}}: - {{c2::Majority rule}}: {{c3::No duty to retreat}} before using force, including deadly force, if otherwise justified. - {{c4::Minority rule}}: Some jurisdictions require {{c5::retreat, if it can be done safely, before using deadly force}}. 2. {{c6::Initial aggressor limitations}}: - An {{c7::initial aggressor}} generally {{c8::cannot claim self-defense}}. - Self-defense is available to an initial aggressor only if: • The {{c9::initial threat has terminated}}; or • The plaintiff responds to {{c10::non-deadly force with deadly force}}, escalating the confrontation.

subject: Evidence
cloze: As to {{c1::scope}}, experts may generally offer opinions on {{c2::ultimate issues}} in the case, including matters that bear directly on elements or defenses, so long as the testimony is otherwise admissible. However, there is a key {{c3::criminal-case limitation}}: an expert may not state an opinion about whether the {{c4::defendant}} did or did not have the {{c5::mental state or condition}} that constitutes an {{c6::element of the crime charged}} or of a {{c7::defense}}. Thus, while an expert may describe diagnoses, symptoms, and hypotheticals, the expert cannot testify directly that the defendant {{c8::"did" or "did not" possess the required mens rea}} (such as specific intent or knowledge) when that mental state is itself a legal element.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Sixth Amendment jury-trial rights in criminal cases: 1. Core right and presence: - The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} guarantees a right to a {{c2::jury trial in criminal prosecutions}}. - The defendant has a right to be {{c3::present at all critical stages}} (e.g., jury selection). 2. When a jury is required: - A jury trial is required when the potential term of imprisonment {{c4::exceeds 6 months}} (a serious offense). 3. Basic jury requirements: - The jury must have at least {{c5::6 jurors}}. - For serious offenses, the verdict must be {{c6::unanimous}}. 4. Jury pool and impartiality: - The {{c7::jury pool (venire)}} must be a {{c8::representative cross-section of the community}}, but the seated jury need not be. - The defendant is entitled to an {{c9::impartial jury}} and may question jurors about relevant biases and seek to {{c10::strike biased jurors for cause}}. 5. Peremptory challenges and equal protection: - Parties may exercise {{c11::peremptory challenges}}, but they may not be used to exclude jurors on the basis of {{c12::race or gender}}, which would violate {{c13::equal protection}}. 6. Judge-directed verdicts: - The judge may direct a verdict of {{c14::acquittal}} but may not {{c15::direct a verdict of guilt}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: {{c1::Rule of destructibility of contingent remainders}} 1. {{c2::Common-law rule}} 1.1 A {{c3::contingent remainder}} is {{c4::destroyed}} if it remains contingent when the {{c5::preceding estate ends}}. 1.2 If the {{c6::condition precedent}} is not satisfied before or at the time the prior estate ends, the contingent remainderman takes {{c7::nothing}}. 2. {{c8::Modern rule}} 2.1 Most modern jurisdictions have {{c9::abolished}} the rule of destructibility. 2.2 If the prior estate ends before the condition is satisfied, the {{c10::grantor or the grantor’s estate}} holds a {{c11::reversion}}. 2.3 When the {{c12::condition is later satisfied}}, the {{c13::grantee}} can take under the {{c14::contingent remainder}}, rather than having the interest destroyed.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 In the event of a breach, {{c1::non-monetary remedies}} ({{c2::equitable relief}}) may be available if money damages are {{c3::unavailable or inadequate}}. 2. {{c4::Specific performance}} and related equitable relief: 2.1 Specific performance is usually available only for contracts involving {{c5::real estate}} or {{c6::unique goods}} (e.g., antiques, art). 2.2 For {{c7::service contracts}}, courts may issue {{c8::injunctions}} preventing breach (e.g., enforcing a non-compete clause), but will not order {{c9::specific performance of personal services}}. 3. {{c10::Rescission}}: 3.1 Rescission is {{c11::cancellation of a contract}}. 3.2 The purpose is to {{c12::restore the parties to their pre-contract positions}}. 3.3 Rescission often arises where there is {{c13::mistake, misrepresentation, duress}}, or some other {{c14::defense to contract formation or enforcement}}. 4. {{c15::Reformation}}: 4.1 Reformation is a remedy whereby a contract is {{c16::changed so that it reflects the parties' original intent}}. 4.2 It can arise where there is a {{c17::mistake in contract formation}} such that the final written contract varies from a prior agreement of the parties. 4.3 It can also arise where the contract is inaccurate due to {{c18::misrepresentation}}. 5. {{c19::Reclamation}} (UCC): 5.1 In UCC contracts, {{c20::unpaid sellers}} may {{c21::stop delivery or reclaim goods}} from an {{c22::insolvent buyer}}. 5.2 An unpaid seller generally {{c23::cannot reclaim goods from subsequent good-faith purchasers for value}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Intentional interference with business relationships}} arises when a {{c2::third party}} intentionally interferes with an existing {{c3::contract or business expectancy}}. 2. Elements: 2.1 {{c4::Plaintiff has a valid contractual relationship or business expectancy}}. 2.2 The relationship or expectancy is {{c5::between plaintiff and a third party}}. 2.3 {{c6::Defendant has knowledge}} of the relationship or expectancy. 2.4 Defendant {{c7::intentionally interferes}} with that relationship or expectancy. 2.5 The interference must be {{c8::intentional; negligence is insufficient}}. 2.6 Defendant's interference {{c9::causes a breach, termination, or failure of performance}} in plaintiff's contract or expectancy. 2.7 Plaintiff suffers {{c10::damages}}. 3. Privilege defenses: 3.1 Defendant's conduct may be {{c11::privileged}} when it is a proper attempt to {{c12::obtain business or protect defendant's own interests}}. 3.2 Example: legitimately {{c13::competing for plaintiff's customers}}.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: Partners owe the partnership and fellow partners the following duties: 1. {{c1::Duty of loyalty}}: each partner must 1.1 {{c2::account for property, profits, or benefits}} derived in connection with the partnership business; 1.2 {{c3::refrain from competing}} with the partnership; and 1.3 refrain from {{c4::dealing with the partnership as, or on behalf of, a party with an adverse interest}} to the partnership. 2. {{c5::Duty of care}}: each partner must refrain from engaging in misconduct, specifically 2.1 {{c6::grossly negligent or reckless conduct}}; 2.2 {{c7::intentional misconduct}}; or 2.3 {{c8::knowing violations of the law}}. 3. {{c9::Duty of obedience}}: partners are agents of the partnership and, as such, must {{c10::obey all reasonable directions}} from the partnership. 4. {{c11::Duty to provide complete and accurate information}}: partners must provide each other and the partnership {{c12::complete and accurate information}} concerning the partnership. 5. {{c13::Partnership books and information}}: every partner has a {{c14::right to inspect and copy}} partnership financial information. Note: discuss the relevant duty if the facts show {{c15::malfeasance, misconduct, or disloyalty}} by a partner.

subject: Torts
cloze: The {{c1::transferred intent doctrine}} for intentional torts: 1. When it arises 1.1 D acts with the intent to commit a given {{c2::intentional tort}} but instead: 1.1.1 Commits the intended tort against a {{c3::different person}} than intended; or 1.1.2 Commits a {{c4::different tort}} than intended against the original person; or 1.1.3 Commits a {{c5::different tort}} against a {{c6::different person}} than intended. 2. Effect of transferred intent 2.1 D's original intent {{c7::transfers}} to the tort actually committed and/or the person actually harmed. 2.2 D is therefore {{c8::liable}} as if D had intended the actual tort against the actual victim. 3. Torts covered 3.1 Transferred intent applies only to the classic intentional torts: {{c9::assault}}, {{c10::battery}}, {{c11::false imprisonment}}, and {{c12::trespass}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Federal courts will not adjudicate certain constitutional issues that constitute {{c1::political questions}}. 1. Political questions involve issues that: 1.1 The {{c2::Constitution commits to another branch of government}} (i.e., not the judiciary); or 1.2 Are {{c3::inherently incapable of judicial resolution or enforcement}}. 2. Common political questions deemed {{c4::non-justiciable}} include: 2.1 Actions under the {{c5::Guarantee Clause}} (republican form of government); 2.2 Challenges to the conduct of {{c6::foreign policy}}; 2.3 Challenges to {{c7::impeachment and removal proceedings}}. 3. Non-political questions deemed {{c8::justiciable}} include: 3.1 {{c9::Production of presidential papers or communications}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The First Amendment protects {{c1::freedom of the press}}, including the right to {{c2::publish matters of public concern}}. Any restriction or punishment on such publication must be {{c3::narrowly tailored}} to further a {{c4::state interest of the highest order}}, which effectively applies {{c5::strict scrutiny}} to such regulations.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, when the decedent is survived by {{c2::descendants who are also descendants of the surviving spouse}} and the spouse has {{c3::no other descendants}}, the surviving spouse takes {{c4::the entire intestate estate}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A {{c1::tenancy by the entirety}} is a {{c2::marital concurrent estate}}, similar to a joint tenancy, but held only between a {{c3::married couple}}. 2. Creation 2.1 It is created by a {{c4::conveyance to a married couple}} and requires the same four unities as a joint tenancy ({{c5::time, title, interest, and possession}}). 2.2 In many jurisdictions, a tenancy by the entirety is {{c6::presumed in any conveyance made jointly to a married couple}}, absent contrary intent. 3. Characteristics 3.1 {{c7::Right of survivorship}}: The property automatically passes to the {{c8::surviving spouse}} upon the death of the other spouse. 3.2 {{c9::No unilateral right to convey or partition}}: One spouse may not unilaterally convey or partition her interest; an attempt to do so is {{c10::invalid and will not destroy the tenancy}}. 3.3 {{c11::Protection from individual creditors}}: Creditors of one spouse alone {{c12::cannot reach that spouse's interest}}; only {{c13::joint creditors of the couple}} can reach property held in a tenancy by the entirety. 4. Severance 4.1 A tenancy by the entirety can be severed, which creates a {{c14::tenancy in common}}, in only a few ways: 4.1.1 {{c15::Death}} of one co-tenant. 4.1.2 Issuance of a {{c16::divorce decree}}. 4.1.3 {{c17::Execution by a joint creditor}} (for example, foreclosure by a creditor of both spouses).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Definition and purpose 1.1 {{c1::Interlocutory injunctions}} are court orders requiring a person to do or cease doing a specific action {{c2::before trial}}. 1.2 Their purpose is to prevent {{c3::irreparable injury}} that will occur before there is a final judgment. 2. Security requirement 2.1 The {{c4::movant}} must provide {{c5::security}} that will be used to compensate the {{c6::defendant}} for damage caused by the injunction if the {{c7::plaintiff does not ultimately prevail}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Unless restricted by lease terms, a tenant may transfer her leasehold interest either {{c1::in whole (assignment)}} or {{c2::in part (sublease)}}. In an {{c3::assignment}}, the tenant transfers the {{c4::entire leasehold}} and the {{c5::assignee comes into privity of estate with the landlord}}, while the {{c6::original tenant usually remains in privity of contract}}. In a {{c7::sublease}}, only a {{c8::partial interest}} is transferred; the {{c9::original tenant remains the landlord’s tenant in privity of estate and contract}}, and the {{c10::sublessee is typically not directly liable to the landlord}}. Lease provisions restricting assignment or sublease are {{c11::enforceable but construed against landlords}}, and {{c12::landlord consent may waive such restrictions unless clearly reserved}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: For felony-murder liability: - The defendant must be {{c1::guilty of the underlying felony}}, and any {{c2::valid defense to that felony}} is also a defense to felony murder. - Under the {{c3::merger doctrine}}, the underlying felony must be {{c4::independent of the killing}}; felonies that are essentially assaultive homicides merge and cannot serve as predicates (e.g., {{c5::involuntary manslaughter}} cannot be the underlying felony). - The victim’s death must be a {{c6::foreseeable (proximate) result}} of the felony and must {{c7::occur before the defendant reaches a place of temporary safety}}. - Under the majority {{c8::co-felon death rule}}, the defendant is {{c9::not liable for the death of a co-felon}} killed by {{c10::police or the original victim}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General Definition 1.1 {{c1::Defamation}} is a {{c2::false statement}} concerning the plaintiff, made by the defendant to at least {{c3::one person other than the plaintiff}}, that is {{c4::harmful to the plaintiff's reputation}}. 1.2 The statement must be one of {{c5::fact (or implying specific facts)}}, not mere pure opinion, and must be {{c6::defamatory}} in that it adversely affects reputation. 2. Common Law Elements 2.1 {{c7::False and defamatory statement}}: The statement must be false and defamatory, meaning it adversely affects the plaintiff's reputation and is based on specific facts. 2.2 {{c8::Concerning the plaintiff}}: It must be reasonably understood that the statement concerns a {{c9::living plaintiff or a very small group of plaintiffs}}. 2.3 {{c10::Publication}}: The statement must be communicated to at least {{c11::one person other than the plaintiff}}. 2.4 {{c12::Harmful to reputation}}: The statement must be of a kind that harms the plaintiff's reputation, such that a {{c13::reasonable person}} would think less of the plaintiff.
