subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Definition of logical relevance: 1.1 Evidence is {{c1::relevant}} if it tends to make the existence of any {{c2::fact of consequence}} more or less probable than it would be without the evidence. 1.2 Relevant evidence may be {{c3::admissible}}, but it is not automatically admissible. 1.3 {{c4::Irrelevant evidence}} is inadmissible. 2. Limitations on relevance: 2.1 Logical relevance does not equal {{c5::probative value}}: evidence can be logically relevant but have low probative value. 2.2 {{c6::Discretionary exclusion (Rule 403)}}: A court may exclude relevant evidence if its probative value is {{c7::substantially outweighed}} by a danger of {{c8::unfair prejudice, confusion, misleading the jury, undue delay, waste of time, or needless cumulative evidence}}. 2.3 {{c9::Public policy exclusions}}: Relevant evidence may also be excluded based on public policy, such as evidence of {{c10::liability insurance}}, {{c11::subsequent remedial measures}}, {{c12::settlement offers and negotiations}}, {{c13::withdrawn guilty pleas}}, and {{c14::offers to pay medical expenses}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Future interests following a life estate: 1.1 {{c1::Reversion}}: 1.1.1 A reversion is the {{c2::future interest retained by the grantor}} when a life estate does not provide for disposition of the property to a third party. 1.1.2 Example: O grants "{{c3::to A for life}}." A is the life tenant; {{c4::O has a reversion}} that becomes possessory when A dies. 1.2 {{c5::Remainder}}: 1.2.1 A remainder is the {{c6::future interest in a third person}} that becomes possessory upon the {{c7::natural expiration of the preceding life estate}}. 1.2.2 The remainder is {{c8::created in the same instrument}} that creates the life estate. 1.2.3 Example: O grants "{{c9::to A for life, then to B}}." A is the life tenant; {{c10::B has a remainder}} that becomes possessory when A dies.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. General rule and exception 1.1 General rule: {{c1::Shareholders, directors, and officers are not personally liable for corporate obligations}}. 1.2 Exception – {{c2::piercing the corporate veil}}: They can be held personally liable under the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil. 1.3 Consequence: When the corporate veil is pierced, the {{c3::corporate entity is disregarded}} in order to hold shareholders, officers, directors, and others personally liable. 2. Acts justifying piercing the veil (courts will pierce the corporate veil where): 2.1 {{c4::Ignoring corporate formalities / alter ego}}: Where a shareholder dominates the corporation to the extent that the corporation is not being treated as a separate entity, i.e., the corporation is being used as an {{c5::alter ego of the shareholders}}, resulting in some basic injustice. 2.2 {{c6::Inadequate capitalization}}: The corporation was undercapitalized (underfunded) at the time of incorporation. This is not established by insolvency alone, but insolvency shortly after formation is a prime indicator of inadequate capitalization. 2.3 {{c7::Fraud or illegality}}: The corporate entity may be disregarded if there is fraud or other illegality, to prevent fraud or other illegality, or to prevent a shareholder from using the corporation to {{c8::avoid existing personal liabilities}}. 3. Scope of liability 3.1 Once the corporate veil is pierced, persons composing the corporation may be held {{c9::personally liable}}, but usually only those involved in {{c10::active management}} will be held liable.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Tenant's duty to {{c1::repair}} at common law: 1.1 The tenant has a duty to {{c2::maintain the premises}}. 1.2 The tenant must make {{c3::ordinary repairs}} to keep the property in its pre-lease condition. 1.3 This duty can be largely {{c4::modified by the lease terms}}. 2. Residential leases and {{c5::implied warranty of habitability}}: 2.1 In residential leases, the tenant's duty to repair is {{c6::limited}} by the implied warranty of habitability. 2.2 The {{c7::landlord}} generally bears responsibility for maintaining basic habitability. 2.3 The tenant still must avoid {{c8::damage}} and may need to make {{c9::minor, ordinary repairs}}, but cannot be forced to {{c10::waive habitability protections}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Terminating custodial interrogation 1.1. An accused may terminate a {{c1::custodial interrogation}} at any time by invoking the {{c2::right to remain silent}} or the {{c3::Fifth Amendment right to counsel}}. 2. Waiver 2.1. Any waiver of Miranda rights must be {{c4::knowing}} and {{c5::voluntary}}, and may be {{c6::express or implied}}. 2.2. The {{c7::prosecution}} bears the burden of proving a valid waiver by a {{c8::preponderance of the evidence}}. 3. Due process voluntariness 3.1. Independently of Miranda, the {{c9::Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause}} requires that confessions be {{c10:voluntary}} under the {{c11::totality of the circumstances}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule and burden of proof: 1.1 The {{c1::Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause}} requires that the government prove guilt {{c2::beyond a reasonable doubt}} in all criminal cases. 1.2 The prosecution must prove {{c3::all elements of every crime charged}} beyond a reasonable doubt. 1.3 The burden of proof on the elements is always on the {{c4::prosecution}} and cannot be shifted to the defendant; a state law that shifts the burden to the defendant to prove he is not guilty is {{c5::unconstitutional}}. 1.4 The defendant has the burden of proving any {{c6::affirmative defenses}} he raises. 1.5 State laws may vary on what {{c7::burden}} the defendant must satisfy for affirmative defenses; there is no single constitutional requirement. 1.6 A conviction is valid so long as a {{c8::rational judge or jury}}, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, could find the defendant {{c9::guilty beyond a reasonable doubt}}. 2. Jury instructions and mandatory presumptions: 2.1 A judge cannot give {{c10::mandatory jury instructions}} that effectively direct a finding on an {{c11::element}} of a charged crime. 2.2 Requiring the jury to apply a {{c12::mandatory presumption}} regarding an element of the charged crime violates {{c13::due process}}. 2.3 For example, in a murder trial where a body was never found, the court cannot instruct the jury to {{c14::presume that a missing person is dead}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Intervention allows a non-party {{c1::absentee}} to voluntarily {{c2::join (intervene in)}} an already pending suit as a {{c3::plaintiff}} or {{c4::defendant}}. There are two main types: {{c5::intervention as of right}} and {{c6::permissive intervention}}. In diversity cases, intervenors generally must establish {{c7::an independent basis for subject-matter jurisdiction}} because {{c8::supplemental jurisdiction does not extend to diversity-based intervention}}. Unlike {{c9::compulsory joinder}}, which narrowly {{c10::forces indispensable absentees into the case}}, intervention {{c11::allows interested absentees to join voluntarily}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Most jurisdictions classify murder crimes into various {{c1::degrees}} by statute. 1. {{c2::First-degree murder}} (arises if a killing is either): 1.1 {{c3::Deliberate and premeditated}}: 1.1.1 The defendant must have killed in a {{c4::dispassionate}} manner; and 1.1.2 The defendant must have {{c5::considered or reflected on the killing, even if only momentarily}}. 1.1.3 It is a {{c6::specific intent}} crime, so {{c7::voluntary intoxication}} and {{c8::mistake of fact}} are valid defenses. 1.2 {{c9::Felony murder}}: a killing during an {{c10::enumerated felony}}. Many states list felonies that may serve as the basis for felony murder. 2. {{c11::Second-degree murder}}: 2.1 A {{c12::homicide that does not rise to first-degree murder}}. 2.2 Note: if first-degree murder is not mentioned as a possibility in an MBE question or in the answer choices, assume the question involves {{c13::second-degree murder}}, which is often the {{c14::default category}} on the MBE.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Work product is generally {{c1::protected}} from discovery, but it may be discovered if the requesting party shows {{c2::substantial need}} for the material and that it is {{c3::not otherwise available}} (cannot, without undue hardship, obtain its substantial equivalent by other means). Objections to discovery based on privilege must be stated with {{c4::particularity}}, typically identifying the nature of the material withheld and the {{c5::specific privilege}} asserted, without disclosing the privileged information itself.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule: Police may {{c1::observe and use their senses}} from any place where they are {{c2::legitimately present}} when conducting a search or investigation. 2. Seizure based on {{c3::plain view}} (police may seize evidence in plain view without a warrant if): 2.1. Police are {{c4::legitimately on the premises}} from which they viewed the evidence to be seized. 2.2. {{c5::Criminal activity or contraband is immediately apparent}}. 2.3. Police have {{c6::probable cause}} to believe that the plainly viewed evidence is contraband or relates to a crime. 3. Scope of plain view searches: 3.1. Includes anything viewable from {{c7::land or public property}}, even if only viewable through {{c8::binoculars}}. 3.2. {{c9::"Plain smell"}} is included within the plain view doctrine. 3.3. If a smell gives rise to {{c10::probable cause}} from a place of legitimate police presence, they can {{c11::search that item}}. 4. Limitations: 4.1. Police cannot use technology {{c12::not generally available to the public}} to view evidence that would otherwise be hidden (e.g., {{c13::infrared scanners that can view through walls}}). 4.2. Note: Use of {{c14::drones}} for plain view searches is unsettled law and thus unlikely to appear on the MBE.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. General rule: An {{c1::offeror}} may revoke her offer, which terminates the offer and the offeree's {{c2::power of acceptance}}. 2. Methods of revocation: 2.1. {{c3::Direct revocation}}: an {{c4::unambiguous statement}} by the offeror to the offeree indicating unwillingness or inability to contract. 2.2. {{c5::Indirect revocation}}: the offeree becomes aware of the offeror's {{c6::unambiguous conduct or statement}} indicating an unwillingness or inability to contract. 3. Timing and limitations: 3.1. Revocation is only effective upon {{c7::receipt}} by the offeree. 3.2. An offer cannot be revoked once it has been {{c8::accepted}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Misrepresentation}} is a {{c2::false statement of material fact}} that is {{c3::relied upon}} by the other party. {{c4::Fraud}} adds {{c5::intentional or reckless}} misrepresentation ({{c6::scienter}}) and intent to {{c7::induce reliance}}. A contract induced by material misrepresentation or fraud is generally {{c8::voidable}} by the misled party. 2. {{c9::Duress}} occurs when a party’s assent is induced by an {{c10::improper threat}} that leaves the victim {{c11::no reasonable alternative}}. It can include {{c12::physical}}, {{c13::economic}}, or {{c14::legal}} threats. A contract made under duress is typically {{c15::voidable}} (and may be {{c16::void}} under extreme physical duress).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: A conspiracy terminates when the {{c1::target crime is completed}} or when the conspirators {{c2::abandon the plan}}. {{c3::Impossibility}} is {{c4::not a defense}} to conspiracy. {{c5::Withdrawal}} is generally {{c6::not a defense}} to the conspiracy itself once the agreement (and any required overt act) has occurred, but a {{c7::timely and effective withdrawal}} may protect the defendant from liability for {{c8::co-conspirators' subsequent substantive crimes}} committed in furtherance of the conspiracy.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Assault}} (two theories of assault at common law): 1.1 Assault as a {{c2::threat}} ({{c3::general intent}} crime): 1.1.1 {{c4::Intentional creation of the victim's reasonable apprehension of imminent bodily harm}}; and 1.1.2 {{c5::Words alone are usually insufficient}}. 1.2 Assault as an {{c6::attempted battery}} ({{c7::specific intent}} crime): 1.2.1 Specific intent crime because it involves {{c8::attempt}}; and 1.2.2 Both assault as a threat and assault as an attempted battery constitute assault for {{c9::MBE purposes}} unless instructed otherwise. 2. {{c10::Battery}} (general intent crime): 2.1 An {{c11::unlawful application of force to the person of another resulting in bodily injury or offensive touching}} (this is a completed assault); and 2.2 Under modern statutes, both assault and battery have {{c12::aggravated}} counterparts, which usually arise when the assault or battery is carried out with the use of a {{c13::weapon}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under the {{c1::collateral order exception}}, an interlocutory order may be immediately appealed if it: 1. Is {{c2::collateral}} – too distinct from the merits of the case; 2. Is too {{c3::important}} to be denied immediate review; and 3. Would essentially be {{c4::unreviewable}} if the parties waited for final judgment.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 4. Miranda warnings 4.1. Police must inform the accused that: 4.1.1. He has the {{c1::right to remain silent}}. 4.1.2. {{c2::Anything he says can be used against him in court}}. 4.1.3. He has the {{c3::right to the presence of an attorney}}. 4.1.4. An attorney will be {{c4::appointed if he cannot afford one}}. 4.2. {{c5::Substantial compliance}} in reading the warnings is sufficient; the warnings need not be perfectly worded. 4.3. Failure to give Miranda warnings implicates the {{c6::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}}, not the {{c7::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A {{c1::will}} is an instrument that directs the disposition of a person's property when they die. It has {{c2::no legal effect before the testator's death}} and becomes operative upon death. A will may be {{c3::revoked or amended until the testator's death}}, and named beneficiaries have only an {{c4::expectancy interest}} (no present property rights). 1. Basic execution requirements (formal, attested will) 1.1. {{c5::In writing}}. 1.2. {{c6::Signed by the testator}}. 1.2.1. Any mark intended to be a signature suffices. 1.2.2. If the testator is incapable of signing, the will may be signed by another person in the testator's presence and at the testator's direction. 1.3. {{c7::Signed by at least two witnesses}}. 1.3.1. The witnesses must see the testator sign the will (or acknowledge the signature) and must sign as witnesses within a reasonable time. 1.3.2. The signing must occur in the testator's presence, which many states define by a {{c8::"line of sight"}} test, while others use a broader {{c9::"conscious presence"}} test. 1.3.3. Under the {{c10::UPC}}, the witnesses may sign within a {{c11::reasonable time}} after the testator's signature. 1.4. In many states, a {{c12::licensed notary}} can satisfy the requirement for witnesses. 2. {{c13::Attestation clause}} 2.1. An attestation clause is a clause included immediately between the testator's and witnesses' signatures in a will. 2.2. It sets forth the execution elements above and recites that they were satisfied. 2.3. The attestation clause constitutes {{c14::prima facie evidence}} of the facts recited in the clause (i.e., that the execution requirements have been satisfied).

subject: Contracts
cloze: Under the UCC, {{c1::FOB (Free On Board)}} terms allocate risk and expense to a {{c2::named location}}. The seller bears the risk and expense of getting the goods to the {{c3::named FOB location}}, and risk of loss passes to the buyer when the goods {{c4::reach that location}}. For example, if the contract states "{{c5::FOB Boise}}," the seller must get the goods to {{c6::Boise}}, and risk of loss passes to the buyer once the goods {{c7::arrive in Boise}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General partnership rule: 1.1. In a {{c1::partnership}}, each {{c2::partner}} is vicariously liable for torts committed by {{c3::any other partner}} in the {{c4::ordinary course of the partnership business}}. 2. Scope of partnership business: 2.1. The tort must be committed {{c5::within the scope of the partnership}} or in the {{c6::ordinary course of its business}}. 2.2. Purely personal acts {{c7::outside partnership business}} generally do not create vicarious liability for other partners.

subject: Corporations
cloze: The {{c1::default rule}} is that the {{c2::promoter is personally liable}} for contracts he enters into on behalf of a {{c3::not-yet-formed corporation}}. The promoter {{c4::remains personally liable even after incorporation}} unless there is a valid {{c5::novation}}. A {{c5::novation}} is an agreement among the {{c6::promoter}}, the {{c7::third party}}, and the {{c8::corporation}} under which the third party {{c9::releases the promoter and substitutes the corporation as the obligor}}. Separately, the corporation may agree to {{c10::indemnify the promoter}} if he is held liable on the contract after formation, but indemnification {{c11::does not itself release the promoter}} from personal liability to the third party.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. Publication 1.1 {{c1::Publication}} means communication of the defamatory statement to at least {{c2::one person other than the plaintiff}}. 1.2 Publication may be {{c3::intentional or negligent}}; it is enough that the defendant either intended or should have foreseen that the statement would be heard or read by a {{c4::third person}}. 2. Liability for Republication 2.1 A {{c5::republisher}} of a defamatory statement is liable to the {{c6::same extent as the original publisher}}. 2.2 Each separate publication can give rise to a {{c7::separate cause of action}}, subject to any applicable {{c8::single-publication rules}}. 3. Internet Service Providers (ISP) Immunity 3.1 {{c9::Internet service providers (ISPs)}} and similar online platforms are generally {{c10::not liable}} for defamatory statements made by others and posted on their platforms. 3.2 This immunity arises from {{c11::federal statute}} (e.g., {{c12::Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act}}), which protects providers and users of interactive computer services from being treated as the {{c13::publisher or speaker}} of information provided by another content provider.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Tenth Amendment}}, all powers not granted to the {{c2::federal government}}, nor prohibited to the {{c3::states}}, are {{c4::reserved to the states}}. This limits Congress’s ability to {{c5::regulate or tax states as states}}. Under the {{c6::anti-commandeering}} principle, Congress cannot require states to {{c7::enact laws}} or {{c8::administer federal law}}, and thus may not commandeer state {{c9::legislative}} or {{c10::executive}} processes. However, federal regulations that are {{c11::generally applicable}}—i.e., that apply to both the {{c12::public}} and {{c13::private}} sectors—are usually valid (for example, {{c14::federal minimum wage}} laws can bind state and local governments). Congress may also restrict state activities that violate {{c15::civil liberties and civil rights}}, including through its {{c16::Fourteenth Amendment}} enforcement power.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Member-managed LLCs}} 1.1 In a member-managed LLC, all {{c2::members}} generally owe fiduciary duties of {{c3::care}} and {{c4::loyalty}} to each other and to the LLC. 2. {{c5::Manager-managed LLCs}} 2.1 In a manager-managed LLC, only {{c6::managers}} owe fiduciary duties of care and loyalty to the LLC and, where applicable, to the members. 2.2 {{c7::Non-managing members}} generally do not owe these fiduciary duties simply by virtue of being members. 2.3 The members can {{c8::ratify}} a manager’s act that would otherwise violate the {{c9::duty of loyalty}}, typically with informed approval. 3. {{c10::Good faith and fair dealing}} 3.1 Regardless of management structure, all {{c11::members and managers}} have an obligation of {{c12::good faith and fair dealing}} in the performance and enforcement of the operating agreement. 3.2 This obligation generally cannot be {{c13::eliminated}} but may be {{c14::defined or shaped}} in the operating agreement, subject to statutory limits.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Nature and purpose of discovery: - Discovery is a {{c1::court-mandated process}} of acquiring and producing information in civil cases. - It is conducted primarily by the {{c2::parties}}, who seek and exchange information from {{c3::parties and non-party witnesses}}. - The {{c4::court}} supervises discovery, manages deadlines, and resolves disputes, but does not typically {{c5::participate directly in the exchange of information}}. - The purpose of discovery is to provide access to {{c6::relevant information}} so parties can {{c7::prepare their cases, narrow issues, and promote fair and efficient resolution}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. Trustee {{c1::powers}} 1.1 The trustee can only exercise powers {{c2::expressly or impliedly conferred}}, most often conferred by the {{c3::trust terms}}. 1.2 The trustee has powers necessary and appropriate to properly {{c4::invest, manage, and distribute}} trust property, so long as those powers are not contrary to the trust terms. 2. Trustee {{c5::duties}} 2.1 {{c6::Duty to administer}}: The trustee must administer the trust in {{c7::good faith}} and in a {{c8::prudent}} manner, in accordance with the trust terms and the beneficiaries' interests. 2.2 {{c9::Duty of loyalty}}: The trustee must avoid {{c10::self-dealing}} and cannot enter into a transaction in which they are dealing with the trust in their individual capacity, absent court approval or a contrary trust provision. 2.3 {{c11::Duty to report}}: The trustee must keep beneficiaries {{c12::reasonably informed}} of the trust and its administration. 2.4 {{c13::Duty to separate trust property and keep records}}: The trustee must not {{c14::commingle}} trust property with their own or another trust's property, and must maintain {{c15::proper records}}. 2.5 {{c16::Duty to enforce claims and defend the trust}}: The trustee must {{c17::enforce claims}} the trust has and {{c18::defend the trust}} against claims. 2.6 {{c19::Duty to preserve property and make it productive}}: The trustee must {{c20::preserve}} trust property, including the duty to make property {{c21::productive}} (for example, by investing funds, leasing or managing land, or collecting claims).

subject: Family Law
cloze: Unmarried cohabitants generally do not receive any {{c1::special marital status}} merely from living together, unless they satisfy the requirements for a {{c2::common law marriage}}. They can, however, {{c3::enforce valid express contracts}}, rely on {{c4::implied-in-fact contracts or joint venture/partnership theories}}, and seek {{c5::equitable or restitutionary remedies}} such as resulting trusts, constructive trusts, or quantum meruit upon breakup.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Perfection of security interests in {{c1::motor vehicles}}: 1. Certificate-of-title system: 1.1 Many vehicles are treated as {{c2::certificate-of-title goods}} under special titling statutes. 2. General rule: 2.1 A security interest in a motor vehicle covered by a certificate of title is generally perfected by {{c3::notation of the lien on the vehicle’s certificate of title}}. 2.2 A standard Article 9 {{c4::financing statement}} is usually not sufficient if the statute requires title notation instead. 3. Practical effect: 3.1 The secured party must ensure its lien is properly {{c5::recorded on the title}} to achieve perfection and priority over other creditors and purchasers.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Beneficiaries can {{c1::modify or revoke}} a private trust with the {{c2::consent of the settlor and all beneficiaries}}. Without the settlor’s consent, {{c3::all beneficiaries}} may agree to modification or revocation only if it {{c4::does not frustrate a material purpose of the trust}}. The requirement that "all beneficiaries" consent includes {{c5::unborn or unascertained beneficiaries}}, which can make unanimous consent impossible; some states allow appointment of a {{c6::representative for minor, unborn, or unascertained beneficiaries}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: After transfer, the {{c1::transferee court}} must decide which {{c2::choice-of-law rules}} to apply. If venue in the original district was {{c3::proper}}, the transferee court applies the {{c4::choice-of-law rules of the original (transferor) court}}, regardless of which party sought the transfer. This prevents a party from obtaining more favorable substantive law simply by transferring the case. Exception: If the original venue was {{c5::improper}}, the transferee court applies {{c6::its own choice-of-law rules}}, rather than those of the original court.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: If the defendant is {{c1::personally served in the forum state}}, they are likely subject to {{c2::personal jurisdiction}} within that forum. Three recognized exceptions: 1. {{c3::Fraud}}: A defendant who is served after being {{c4::lured into the forum under false pretenses}}. 2. {{c5::Force}}: A defendant who is served after being {{c6::brought involuntarily into the forum by force}}. 3. {{c7::Witness}}: A defendant who is served while {{c8::responding to a court subpoena}}. Note: Personal jurisdiction can be established through {{c9::personal service}} even if the defendant's presence is {{c10::transient and unrelated to the suit}}, so long as {{c11::no exception applies}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: A search is ordinarily valid only if conducted under a properly executed {{c1::search warrant}}, unless a warrant exception applies. A valid warrant requires three core things: (1) {{c2::probable cause}}, usually established by a police {{c3::affidavit}} setting out facts showing a fair probability that evidence will be found; (2) {{c4::particularity}}, meaning the warrant must describe with reasonable precision the {{c5::place to be searched}} and the {{c6::items to be seized}}; and (3) issuance by a {{c7::neutral and detached magistrate}}. Even if a warrant is later found invalid, the {{c8::exclusionary rule}} does not apply if officers relied on it in objective {{c9::good faith}}, subject to narrow exceptions (e.g., {{c10::no probable cause at all}}, {{c11::facial defect}}, {{c12::police deceit}}, or a {{c13::magistrate who has abandoned the judicial role}}).

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Economic rights}} – overview 1.1. Laws affecting economic rights (economic liberties) are generally reviewed under the {{c2::rational basis}} test. 1.2. The Constitution provides only {{c3::minimal protection}} for economic liberties; the government almost always wins under {{c2::rational basis}} review of economic regulation. 1.3. A higher level of protection for economic interests may arise under specific provisions such as the {{c4::Takings Clause}} or the {{c5::Contract Clause}}. 2. {{c5::Contract Clause}} – overview 2.1. The Contract Clause limits {{c6::state and local}} interference with {{c7::existing contracts}}. 2.2. It applies only to {{c6::state or local}}—not {{c8::federal}}—impairment of existing contractual obligations, including government obligations. 2.3. Different levels of scrutiny apply to state interference with {{c9::private}} contracts versus interference with {{c10::government}} contracts.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under {{c1::permissive joinder}}, the {{c2::plaintiff}} seeks to join non-parties as {{c3::co-plaintiffs or co-defendants}}. 1. Joining additional plaintiffs: joining additional plaintiffs relies on their {{c4::willingness to join}}; a non-party that the plaintiff seeks to join as a co-plaintiff must agree to join. 2. Joining additional defendants: joining additional defendants lies in the hands of the {{c5::plaintiff}}; a non-party that the plaintiff seeks to join as a co-defendant {{c6::cannot refuse joinder}}. 3. Requirements: 3.1 {{c7::Same transaction or occurrence}}: joined parties must assert a right to relief arising from the same transaction or occurrence as the original plaintiff's claim; defendants may be joined if the right to relief asserted against them arises from the same transaction or occurrence. 3.2 {{c8::Common question of law or fact}}: there must be at least one common question of law or fact in the joined parties' claims or in the claims against them. 4. {{c9::Jurisdiction}}: the court must have jurisdiction over the joined parties and claims (including personal jurisdiction and subject-matter jurisdiction). 5. Distinction from {{c10::impleader}}: permissive joinder involves joinder of non-parties by the plaintiff, whereas impleader involves joinder of non-parties by a defending party.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Offensive and defensive use of prior judgment: {{c1::non-mutual issue preclusion}} may be used {{c2::defensively}} or {{c3::offensively}}, although courts are reluctant to allow offensive use. 1. {{c4::Defensive}} use of prior judgment: 1.1 The {{c5::defendant}} seeks to prevent the {{c6::plaintiff}} from relitigating an issue the plaintiff lost in a prior suit against a different party. 1.2 Defensive non-mutual issue preclusion is allowed if the party against whom issue preclusion is asserted had a {{c7::full and fair opportunity}} to litigate the issue previously. 1.3 Example: a defendant in a second case can preclude the plaintiff from relitigating an issue the plaintiff lost to another defendant in a prior case; this is permitted because the party asserting issue preclusion was not a party in the prior litigation. 2. {{c8::Offensive}} use of prior judgment: 2.1 The {{c9::plaintiff}} seeks to prevent the {{c10::defendant}} from relitigating an issue that the defendant previously lost in a prior suit against a different party. 2.2 Offensive non-mutual issue preclusion is {{c11::highly disfavored}} and rarely allowed. 2.3 The court will allow offensive use only if deemed {{c12::fair}} after balancing factors. 2.4 Factors considered include: 2.4.1 Whether the party against whom the prior judgment is asserted had a {{c13::full and fair opportunity}} to litigate. 2.4.2 Whether that party could {{c14::foresee multiple suits}} being filed. 2.4.3 Whether the party asserting issue preclusion {{c15::controlled or could have joined}} the prior litigation. 2.4.4 Whether there are any {{c16::inconsistent judgments}} on the record.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Most common methods of service of process in federal court: 1. {{c1::Personal service}} 1.1. Delivery of the summons and complaint directly to the defendant. 2. {{c2::Substituted service}} 2.1. Leaving the summons and complaint with a third person at the defendant's {{c3::usual abode}}. 2.2. The third person must be {{c4::legally competent}} and must {{c5::reside at the abode}}. 3. Service upon defendant's {{c6::authorized agent}} 3.1. Service on an agent authorized by {{c7::appointment or by law}} to receive service of process. 3.2. Receipt of service must be within the {{c8::scope of the agency}}. 4. Any method permitted under {{c9::state law}} 4.1. The federal court may use any method of service permitted by the law of the state {{c10::where the federal court sits}} or {{c11::where service is effected}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A {{c1::request for production (RFP)}} under {{c2::FRCP 34}} is a written request to a {{c3::party}} to make available for inspection, review, and/or copying {{c4::documents, electronically stored information (ESI), or other tangible things}} within that party’s {{c5::possession, custody, or control}}. The responding party must serve a written response within {{c6::30 days after service}} of the RFP, unless the time is modified. A {{c7::non-party}} cannot be compelled to respond to a Rule 34 request alone; instead, a non-party may be compelled to produce materials only {{c8::under a subpoena (e.g., Rule 45)}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}}, some otherwise invalid state laws may be upheld because of specific exceptions: 1. {{c2::Market participant doctrine}} – When the state is acting as a {{c3::market participant}} rather than a regulator, it may {{c4::favor its own citizens}} in buying or selling products, hiring labor, or giving subsidies (e.g., {{c5::in-state tuition discounts}}). 2. {{c6::Traditional government function}} – The state can sometimes {{c7::discriminate against non-residents}} when the law involves a {{c8::traditional government function}}, giving it more leeway to prefer residents. 3. {{c9::Congressional approval}} – A state may burden or discriminate in interstate commerce when {{c10::Congress has unmistakably authorized}} the state to do so, overriding ordinary DCC constraints.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::Constitution}} applies only to {{c2::governmental action}} (federal, state, or local). Private conduct generally does not have to comply with the Constitution, subject to the exceptions below. 1. Exceptions (the Constitution will apply to private conduct where): 1.1 {{c3::Exclusive public function}}: a private entity performs a task {{c4::traditionally and exclusively performed by the government}} (narrow exception). This arises only if a private entity exclusively operates a governmental function (e.g., private prisons, running elections). 1.2 {{c5::Significant state involvement}} ({{c6::entanglement}}): the government affirmatively authorizes, encourages, or facilitates private conduct. 1.2.1 The state must {{c7::affirmatively approve or validate}} the private conduct; merely permitting it is insufficient. 1.2.2 Examples of state action: a court enforces a {{c8::racially restrictive covenant}}; the state provides books to private schools that {{c9::racially discriminate}}. 1.2.3 Examples of no state action: the government grants a {{c10::liquor license to a racially discriminatory private club}}; a private school receiving government funds fires a teacher over speech. 2. Indirect regulation of private conduct: Congress may indirectly regulate private conduct through the {{c11::Commerce Clause}} (if the conduct affects interstate commerce) or through the {{c12::13th Amendment}} (which enables Congress to pass legislation enforcing the 13th Amendment’s ban on slavery).

subject: Torts
cloze: Element 4: {{c1::Foreseeable use}} (including foreseeable misuse). 1. Foreseeable use: 1.1 P must use the product in a {{c2::foreseeable}} manner. 1.2 Foreseeable use includes {{c3::normal}} and {{c4::reasonably anticipated}} ways of using the product. 2. Foreseeable misuse: 2.1 P’s {{c5::misuse}} of the product can still satisfy this element if the misuse is {{c6::foreseeable}}. 2.2 If the misuse is {{c7::unforeseeable or highly abnormal}}, it may {{c8::break causation}} or serve as a {{c9::defense}} to strict liability.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Historically, the law developed several special doctrines to modify strict estate-system outcomes involving future interests: 1. {{c1::Rule of destructibility of contingent remainders}} (common law: contingent remainders not vested when the prior estate ends are {{c2::destroyed}}; modern: {{c3::no destruction}}, grantor holds a {{c4::reversion}} until the condition is satisfied). 2. {{c5::Merger (Shelley’s Rule / Rule in Shelley’s Case}}) (common law: "to A for life, then to A’s heirs" gives A a {{c6::fee simple absolute}} by {{c7::merger}}; modern: rule {{c8::abolished}}, A has a {{c9::life estate}}, A’s heirs {{c10::contingent remainders}}, and O a {{c11::reversion}}). 3. {{c12::Doctrine of Worthier Title}} (common law: "to A for life, then to O’s heirs" voids the interest in {{c13::O’s heirs}} and presumes O retained a {{c14::reversion}}; modern: usually a {{c15::rebuttable rule of construction}}). Modern law generally {{c16::abolishes or softens}} these doctrines to better effectuate the grantor’s {{c17::intent}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Definition of {{c1::novation}} 1.1 A novation is a {{c2::new contract}} that {{c3::substitutes a new party}} into an existing contract. 1.2 The new party receives the {{c4::benefits}} and assumes the {{c5::duties}} that belonged to an original party. 2. Requirements for novation 2.1 A previous {{c6::valid contract}}. 2.2 {{c7::All parties, including the new party, agree}} to a new contract. 2.3 The new contract {{c8::extinguishes the contractual duties between the original parties}}. 2.4 A new {{c9::valid and enforceable contract}}. 3. Effect of novation 3.1 The {{c10::original party is excused from performance}} and no longer has any contractual {{c11::obligations or liabilities}} on the original contract.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A will may be contested for any number of reasons challenging its {{c1::validity}}. 1. Common grounds for contesting a will 1.1. {{c2::Lack of capacity}} or lack of {{c3::testamentary intent}}. 1.2. {{c4::Defective execution}} (failure to comply with required formalities). 1.3. {{c5::Undue influence, fraud, or mistake}}. 1.4. Will has been {{c6::revoked}}. 2. Standing to contest a will 2.1. Generally, only those with a {{c7::pecuniary interest}} have standing to contest. 2.2. This includes beneficiaries, someone who should be a beneficiary, or someone who would benefit if the decedent had died {{c8::intestate}}. 3. {{c9::No-contest clauses}} 3.1. A no-contest ({{c10::in terrorem}}) clause is a clause in a will providing that a beneficiary loses their interest under the will if they contest it. 3.2. A no-contest clause does not apply to suits challenging the {{c11::executor's appointment}}, {{c12::jurisdiction}}, or asking the court to {{c13::interpret the will}}. 4. Application of no-contest clauses 4.1. States vary on how strictly they apply no-contest clauses. 4.2. {{c14::Majority}}: no forfeiture of interest if the beneficiary challenges in good faith and on the basis of probable cause. 4.3. {{c15::Minority}}: no-contest clauses are given full effect regardless of the challenging beneficiary's cause or intent.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Fourth Amendment – Warrant Requirement and Main Exceptions 1. {{c1::General reasonableness rule}} 1.1 Government searches and seizures must be {{c2::reasonable}} under the {{c3::Fourth Amendment}}. 1.2 Reasonableness generally requires a valid {{c4::search warrant}}. 2. {{c5::Warrant vs. exceptions framework}} 2.1 First ask: Was there a {{c6::valid search warrant}}? 2.2 If yes, the search is generally {{c7::reasonable}}, subject to scope and execution. 2.3 If there is no valid warrant, the search is presumed {{c8::unreasonable}} unless it falls within a recognized {{c9::exception to the warrant requirement}}. 3. {{c10::Main warrant exceptions}} ("SPACE-S") 3.1 {{c11::Search incident to arrest}}. 3.2 {{c12::Plain view}} search. 3.3 {{c13::Automobile}} search. 3.4 Valid {{c14::consent}} to search. 3.5 {{c15::Exigent circumstances}}. 3.6 {{c16::Stop and frisk}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Miscellaneous rules affecting adverse possession include: (1) {{c1::statute of limitations and disability}} (SoL does not begin if the true owner was under a legal disability when possession began); (2) {{c2::future interests}} (SoL does not run against future interest holders until their interest becomes possessory); (3) {{c3::restrictive covenants}} (whether the covenant runs depends on whether the adverse possessor’s use complied with or violated it); (4) {{c4::color of title}} (adverse possession of part under a defective claim can give title to the entire described tract); (5) {{c5::government land}} (generally immune from adverse possession); and (6) {{c6::leasing and marketable title}} (the adverse possessor may lease the land, but title is not marketable until quieted).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 3. Defenses and exceptions to accomplice liability: 3.1 {{c1::Withdrawal (renunciation)}}: 3.1.1 An accomplice can avoid liability by withdrawing {{c2::before the principal commits the crime}}. 3.1.2 Effective withdrawal generally requires the accomplice to {{c3::repudiate prior aid or encouragement}}, {{c4::do all that is possible to counteract or neutralize}} the prior assistance, and {{c5::withdraw before the chain of events is in motion and unstoppable}}. 3.2 {{c6::Member of a protected class}}: 3.2.1 A person in the class the statute is designed to protect is {{c7::not liable as an accomplice}} to violations of that statute. 3.2.2 Example: {{c8::A minor victim in statutory rape is not an accomplice to statutory rape}}. 3.3 {{c9::Parties not provided for in the statute}}: 3.3.1 A party the statute is clearly designed to regulate is {{c10::not treated as an accomplice}} to the other regulated party. 3.3.2 Example: {{c11::A purchaser of illegal drugs is not an accomplice to the seller}} under a statute criminalizing sale.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Federal {{c1::Rule 12}} provides several mechanisms for attacking the {{c2::sufficiency or form of the pleadings}}. 1. {{c3::Rule 12(b) defenses}} may be raised by motion or in the answer, and some are {{c4::waived if not raised in the first Rule 12 response}}. 2. {{c5::Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses}} may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any {{c6::Rule 12 motion}} must be filed {{c7::before the answer}} if a responsive pleading is allowed. 3. Other Rule 12 motions include a {{c8::motion for a more definite statement}}, a {{c9::motion to strike}}, and a {{c10::motion for judgment on the pleadings}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. General duty: 1.1 A tenant has a duty not to commit {{c1::waste}}, meaning they may not substantially harm or improperly alter the landlord's {{c2::reversionary interest}}. 2. Types of waste: 2.1 {{c3::Voluntary (affirmative) waste}}: Overt acts that substantially {{c4::reduce the property's value}} (e.g., removing fixtures). 2.2 {{c5::Permissive waste}}: Waste by {{c6::neglect or omission}}, such as failing to take reasonable steps to protect the property. 2.3 {{c7::Ameliorative waste}}: Unauthorized alterations that {{c8::change or increase value}} without the {{c9::landlord's consent}}, even if seemingly beneficial.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In class actions, {{c1::traditional subject-matter jurisdiction}} still governs unless a special statute like CAFA applies. 1. For {{c2::federal question}} jurisdiction, the same rules apply as in individual cases—the claims must {{c3::arise under federal law}}, and the fact that the case is a class action does not change the analysis. 2. For {{c4::diversity}} jurisdiction (absent CAFA): - The court looks only to the {{c5::named class representatives}} to determine: • {{c6::Citizenship}}: The representatives must be {{c7::completely diverse from all opposing parties}}. • {{c8::Amount in controversy}}: Each representative’s {{c9::individual claim}} must {{c10::exceed $75,000}}. - The {{c11::citizenship}} and {{c12::claim amounts}} of absent class members are disregarded. - If these requirements are not satisfied, jurisdiction may still arise under {{c13::another statute such as CAFA}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Definition}} 1.1 A {{c2::limited liability company (LLC)}} is a business entity that combines {{c3::partnership-style pass-through taxation}} with {{c4::corporation-style limited liability}}. 1.2 The owners of an LLC are called {{c5::members}}, and members may also serve as {{c6::managers}}. 2. {{c7::Formation requirements}} 2.1 An LLC is formed by filing a {{c8::certificate of formation}} (or {{c9::articles of organization}}) with the state. 2.2 The filing must generally include: • The LLC’s {{c10::name}}; • The address of the LLC’s {{c11::registered office}}; and • The name and address of the LLC’s {{c12::registered agent}}. 2.3 Once properly filed and accepted, a separate legal entity is created that can own property, sue and be sued, and {{c13::shield members from personal liability}} for the LLC’s debts and obligations (subject to exceptions).

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Priority Rule for Crops}} 1.1 A {{c2::perfected security interest in crops}} takes priority over an {{c3::interest in the land}} on which the crops are planted. 1.2 This is true {{c4::regardless of the relative time of filing or perfection}}. 2. {{c5::Effect of the Rule}} 2.1 Even if the {{c6::landowner or mortgagee}} recorded first, a {{c7::perfected crop lender}} still has priority in the {{c8::crops themselves}}. 2.2 The {{c9::land interest}} continues to encumber the {{c10::real property}}, but the crop secured party has the {{c11::superior claim in the crops}}. 3. {{c12::Summary}} 3.1 "{{c13::Crops beat dirt}}": a perfected security interest in crops {{c14::outranks competing land interests}} as to the crops, {{c15::no matter who filed first}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 In some transactions, {{c1::security interests are perfected automatically once they have attached}}; no filing or possession is required. 1.2 Automatic perfection occurs in the following situations. 2. {{c2::PMSI in consumer goods}}: 2.1 A {{c3::purchase-money security interest (PMSI)}} arises when a creditor sells goods to the debtor and/or advances funds to the debtor to buy goods, reserving a security interest in the goods themselves. 2.2 Example: A sells B a TV on credit. Once the security interest is created and {{c4::attached}} (when B receives the goods), A has a PMSI in the TV that is {{c5::automatically perfected}}. 2.3 {{c6::Consumer goods only}}: automatic perfection only occurs for PMSIs in consumer goods. A PMSI in {{c7::inventory or equipment}} must be perfected by filing. 2.4 Limitations: {{c8::motor vehicles}} covered by a certificate of title (which require {{c9::notation on the title}}) and {{c10::fixtures}} (which require a proper {{c11::fixture filing}}) are not automatically perfected, even if they are consumer goods. 3. {{c12::Small assignment of accounts}}: 3.1 An SI is automatically perfected when {{c13::accounts or payment intangibles are assigned}}, and 3.2 The assignment does not transfer a {{c14::significant portion of the assignor’s outstanding accounts or payment intangibles}}. 4. {{c15::Sale of payment intangibles or promissory notes}}: 4.1 A security interest in a sale of payment intangibles or promissory notes is {{c16::automatically perfected upon attachment}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: The corporation’s {{c1::board of directors (BoD)}} serves as the central management body. 1. {{c2::Number of directors}} - Set by the {{c3::articles of incorporation or bylaws}}, which may specify a fixed number or a {{c4::variable range}}. - There must be at least {{c5::one director}}. 2. {{c6::Election of directors}} - Directors are elected by {{c7::shareholders}}. - Election typically occurs at the {{c8::annual shareholder meeting}}. 3. {{c9::Removal of directors}} - Shareholders may remove directors {{c10::with or without cause}}. - The {{c11::articles of incorporation}} may restrict removal to {{c12::for-cause only}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Tenant's control: 1.1 A tenant may be liable in tort for injuries to third persons caused by {{c1::dangerous conditions}} on portions of the premises within the tenant's {{c2::control}}. 2. Duty of care: 2.1 The tenant must exercise {{c3::reasonable care}} to keep areas under their control reasonably safe. 2.2 If the tenant {{c4::knows or should know}} of a dangerous condition and fails to {{c5::remedy or warn}}, they may be liable for resulting injuries. 2.3 The landlord's duties in other areas do {{c6::not eliminate}} the tenant's own duty in areas the tenant controls.

subject: Evidence
cloze: {{c1::Hearsay}} statements are admissible if they concern a declarant's {{c2::state of mind, emotion, sensation, or physical condition}} existing at the time the statement was made. 1. Statement of {{c3::then-existing state of mind}}: 1.1 Usually offered to show a declarant's {{c4::intent}} at the time the statement was made or as a circumstantial inference that the declarant's intent was likely carried out. 1.2 Distinguish from statements offered as {{c5::circumstantial evidence of the declarant's state of mind}}, which are {{c6::not hearsay}}. 1.3 Statements of intent may be admissible as circumstantial evidence tending to show that an act was committed at a later time. 2. Statement of {{c7::then-existing condition}}: 2.1 Usually offered to establish some {{c8::physical condition, symptom, or sensation}} that the declarant experienced at the time of the statement. Items to note: 1. The statement must concern a {{c9::then-existing condition or mental state}}. 2. Statements of {{c10::memory or belief}} are inadmissible because they do not reflect on a then-existing condition.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: 1. {{c1::Dissociation}} (any partner ceasing to be associated in carrying on the partnership business): 1.1 Definition: Dissociation occurs when a partner {{c2::ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership business}}. 1.2 Causes: Dissociation can be caused by: - The partner’s voluntary {{c3::withdrawal}}; - The happening of an {{c4::agreed-upon event}}; - {{c5::Valid expulsion}} of the partner under the agreement or statute; - The partner’s {{c6::bankruptcy}}; or - Similar significant events. 1.3 Effects: - Dissociation terminates the dissociated partner’s {{c7::legal relationship with the partnership as a current partner}}. - The partner’s rights to {{c8::profits}} and {{c9::management}} end. - The partner’s {{c10::fiduciary duties}} terminate prospectively, but remain with respect to {{c11::matters occurring before dissociation}}. 1.4 Buyout obligation: - If the partnership {{c12::continues its business}} after dissociation, it must {{c13::purchase the dissociated partner’s partnership interest}} for its value.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Even if the defendant has sufficient {{c1::minimum contacts}} with the forum, due process imposes an additional {{c2::fairness}} requirement on the exercise of personal jurisdiction. • Standard: The exercise of personal jurisdiction must be {{c3::fair}} and must not offend {{c4::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}}. • Framework: Courts apply this fairness requirement by weighing three main factors: {{c5::(1) relatedness of the contacts and the claim, (2) convenience to the defendant, and (3) the forum state's interest in hearing the case}}. All three factors are {{c6::balanced together}} to decide whether asserting personal jurisdiction comports with due process.

subject: Torts
cloze: Express warranty liability in products cases: 1. Definition: 1.1 An {{c1::express warranty}} is a {{c2::statement of material fact or promise}} regarding goods sold that becomes part of the {{c3::basis of the bargain}}. 2. Who can sue and reliance: 2.1 Any {{c4::consumer or bystander}} can sue for breach of express warranty. 2.2 {{c5::Bystanders}} need not have relied personally on the express warranty, so long as the {{c6::original purchaser}} did. 3. Elements (same as for implied warranties): 3.1 Existence of an express warranty {{c7::relied upon by the purchaser}}. 3.2 {{c8::Breach}}: the product fails to live up to the warranty ({{c9::nonconformity}}). 3.3 {{c10::Causation}}: actual and proximate. 3.4 {{c11::Damages}}: {{c12::personal injury, property damage, and economic loss}}. 4. Defenses: 4.1 {{c13::Assumption of risk}}. 4.2 {{c14::Contributory negligence}}. 4.3 {{c15::Comparative negligence}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A defendant may attack the validity of the plaintiff's complaint through {{c1::Rule 12(b) defenses}}, which may be raised by motion or in the answer. 1. The {{c2::Rule 12(b) defenses}} are: 1.1 Lack of {{c3::subject-matter jurisdiction (SMJ)}}; 1.2 {{c4::Insufficiency of service of process}}*; 1.3 Lack of {{c5::personal jurisdiction (PJ)}}*; 1.4 {{c6::Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted}}; 1.5 {{c7::Improper venue}}*; 1.6 {{c8::Failure to join a necessary party under Rule 19}}; and 1.7 {{c9::Insufficiency of process}}*. 2. {{c10::Waiver}}: Defenses marked with an asterisk ({{c11::PJ, venue, insufficiency of process, and insufficiency of service of process}}) are waived if not included in the defendant's {{c12::first Rule 12 motion}} or, if no Rule 12 motion is made, in the {{c13::first responsive pleading}}, provided they were then available. 3. {{c14::Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses}} may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any {{c15::Rule 12 motion}} must be filed {{c16::before the answer}} if a responsive pleading is allowed.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In General 1.1. The {{c1::mailbox rule}} governs offers and acceptances transmitted via mail or similar non-instantaneous means (it generally does not apply to {{c2::email or instantaneous communications}}). 1.2. {{c3::Offers}} are effective upon {{c4::receipt}} by the offeree. 1.3. {{c5::Rejections and counteroffers}} are effective upon {{c6::receipt}} by the offeror. 1.4. {{c7::Acceptances}} are effective upon {{c8::dispatch}} if properly addressed and stamped, unless an exception applies. 2. Method of Communication 2.1. Unless otherwise provided, offers invite acceptance in any {{c9::reasonable manner under the circumstances}}. 2.2. Example: A sends an offer to B via email and B accepts via text message; a valid contract has been formed. 2.3. If acceptance is via {{c10::instantaneous two-way communication}} (e.g., phone), it is treated as if the parties are in each other's presence, and the mailbox rule does not apply. 3. Limitations on the Mailbox Rule 3.1. If the offer {{c11::stipulates that acceptance is not effective until received}}, the offer controls (the offeror can opt out of the mailbox rule). 3.2. If the offeree sends both a {{c12::rejection and an acceptance}}, the {{c13::first communication to arrive}} controls. 3.3. For {{c14::option contracts}}, acceptance is effective upon {{c15::receipt}}, not dispatch. 4. Revocation 4.1. {{c16::Revocation of an offer}} is effective only upon {{c17::receipt}} by the offeree; the mailbox rule does not apply to revocations.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General confrontation right: 1.1 The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} gives the defendant the right to {{c2::confront adverse witnesses}}. 2. In-person testimony and cross-examination: 2.1 The defendant has a right to have adverse witnesses {{c3::testify in person}} and be subject to {{c4::cross-examination}}. 3. When in-person confrontation is not required: 3.1 In-person testimony is not required if BOTH are satisfied: 3.1.1 Exclusion of in-person testimony is necessary to further an {{c5::important public policy}}; and 3.1.2 The {{c6::reliability of the testimony}} is otherwise assured. 4. Courtroom control: 4.1 The defendant can be {{c7::removed from the courtroom}} for {{c8::disruptive behavior}} without violating the confrontation right, so long as reasonable alternatives consistent with {{c9::due process}} are provided.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Status vs. economic incidents}}: - A court can determine {{c2::marital status}} (e.g., divorced or still married) based on {{c3::domicile alone}}. - However, adjudicating {{c4::property rights}} and {{c5::support obligations}} involves economic incidents that require {{c6::personal jurisdiction}}. 2. {{c7::Property outside the state}}: - A court generally does not have jurisdiction to determine rights to {{c8::property located outside the state}} (especially real property) unless it has {{c9::personal jurisdiction}} over the parties whose interests are affected. 3. {{c10::Support orders}} (spousal or child support): - A court cannot enter binding {{c11::support decrees}} against a party unless it has {{c12::personal jurisdiction}} over that party. - In practice, to fully resolve {{c13::property division}} and {{c14::support}}, courts typically need {{c15::personal jurisdiction over both spouses}}, not just status jurisdiction based on one spouse’s domicile.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 3. Final judgment requirement and appellate jurisdiction limits 3.1 {{c1::Final judgment rule}} - The Supreme Court generally reviews a case only after a {{c2::final judgment}}. - The judgment must be from either: • A {{c3::lower federal court}}; or • A {{c4::state's highest court}} that can decide the case. 3.2 Limits on appellate jurisdiction - Under {{c5::Article III}}, the Supreme Court has {{c6::appellate jurisdiction}} subject to "{{c7::such Exceptions and under such Regulations as the Congress shall make}}." - Congress may {{c8::limit or make exceptions}} to the Court's appellate jurisdiction by statute. - Congress may not use this power to {{c9::expand original jurisdiction}} or otherwise {{c10::contradict Article III}} requirements.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Particularity requirement: - A valid search warrant must be {{c1::precise on its face}}. It must describe, with {{c2::reasonable precision}}, the {{c3::place to be searched}} and the {{c4::items or persons to be seized}}. - The description must be specific enough that officers can reliably {{c5::identify the correct premises}} and {{c6::limit the search}} to evidence described in the warrant, avoiding {{c7::general exploratory searches}}. - Overly broad or vague warrants that fail to reasonably particularize the place or items (i.e., {{c8::general warrants}}) are {{c9::constitutionally defective}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Strict foreclosure}} is an {{c2::Article 9 default remedy}} in which, upon {{c3::default}}, the {{c4::secured party}} may {{c5::keep the collateral}} instead of selling it. 1.3 The collateral is retained in {{c6::full or partial satisfaction}} of the secured debt. 2.2 Strict foreclosure is an {{c7::alternative to a disposition (sale)}} of the collateral; if strict foreclosure is not permitted, the secured party must {{c8::dispose of the collateral by sale}} to realize on the security interest.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::periodic tenancy}} is a leasehold that is continuous for {{c2::successive intervals}} (for example, weeks or months) until either party gives {{c3::notice of termination}}. 2. Creation: A periodic tenancy can be created {{c4::expressly}}, by {{c5::implication}}, or by {{c6::operation of law}}. 2.1 {{c7::Express agreement}}: The landlord conveys to the tenant for an agreed recurring interval. 2.2 {{c8::Implication}}: A lease that does not specify duration but provides for {{c9::rent to be paid at set intervals}} creates a periodic tenancy by implication. 2.3 {{c10::Operation of law}} (two situations): 2.3.1 {{c11::Invalid lease}}: If the tenant takes possession under an invalid lease (for example, a lease that violates the {{c12::Statute of Frauds}}), a periodic tenancy arises upon the landlord's {{c13::acceptance of payment}}; the period of the tenancy is determined by the {{c14::period the payment covers}}. 2.3.2 {{c15::Holdover tenant}}: If the landlord {{c16::accepts rent from a holdover tenant}}, a periodic tenancy arises for the {{c17::period the payment covers}}. 3. Termination: The tenant (or landlord) must give {{c18::proper notice}} of termination. 3.1 {{c19::Sufficient time}}: The party terminating must give notice {{c20::one full period in advance}}; {{c21::year-to-year tenancies}} generally require {{c22::six months'}} notice. 3.2 {{c23::Effective date}}: The effective date of termination must fall at the {{c24::end of a period}} of the tenancy. 3.3 Note: The parties can {{c25::agree by contract to modify}} these notice requirements.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: {{c1::Charitable purpose}} requirement: - The purpose must be considered to {{c2::benefit the public}}. - Courts look to the {{c3::effect of the gift, not the settlor's motive}}. - Example: A trust to build a public swimming pool next to the settlor’s home is charitable if it {{c4::benefits the public}}, even if the settlor wants personal use. {{c5::Political initiatives}}: - A trust supporting political initiatives, including efforts aimed at a {{c6::present change in law}}, can qualify as charitable if it serves a public benefit. - A trust in favor of a {{c7::political party}} is not a valid charitable trust.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule: A defendant {{c1::breaches his duty}} when his conduct falls short of the {{c2::standard of care owed under the circumstances}}. 2. Ways to show breach of the applicable standard of care (plaintiff can argue): 2.1 {{c3::Reasonably prudent person (RPP) standard}}. 2.2 {{c4::Negligence per se}}. 2.3 {{c5::Specialized standard of care}}. 2.4 {{c6::Custom or usage in an industry}} (not an automatic breach, but may be relevant evidence). 3. {{c7::Res ipsa loquitur}}: 3.1 The very occurrence of the accident causing plaintiff's injuries {{c8::suggests negligent conduct}}. 3.2 It arises when the facts cannot establish breach of duty because the {{c9::circumstances surrounding the event are unknown to the plaintiff}}. 4. Requirements for res ipsa loquitur (plaintiff must show): 4.1 {{c10::Inference of negligence}}: The harm would not normally occur absent negligence. 4.2 {{c11::Attributable to defendant}}: This type of harm normally results from negligence by one in defendant's position. 4.3 This is often satisfied by showing that the {{c12::injury-causing instrumentality was in defendant's exclusive control}}. 4.4 The injury was {{c13::not attributable to the plaintiff}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A {{c1::fixture}} is a once-movable {{c2::chattel}} that is {{c3::annexed (affixed) to real property}} such that it becomes part of the realty. 1.2 Fixture issues often arise with {{c4::leaseholds}} but apply to all real property estates. 1.3 Fixtures {{c5::pass with ownership of the land}}. 1.4 Exception: A {{c6::life tenant's representative}} may remove annexed chattel within a {{c7::reasonable time after the life tenant's death}}. 2. Determining whether a chattel has become a fixture 2.1 {{c8::Intent controls}}: The annexor's intent is usually determinative. 2.2 The fixture issue almost always arises where annexors affix their {{c9::own chattel to their own property}}. 2.3 Chattel {{c10::integrated into a structure}} (for example, heating pipes, bricks built into a wall) almost always becomes a fixture. 3. Landlord–tenant rules 3.1 The {{c11::agreement between landlord and tenant}}, if it exists, is controlling. 3.2 {{c12::Tenant installations}}: A tenant may remove chattel she installed if: 3.2.1 Removal occurs {{c13::before the lease expires}}; and 3.2.2 Removal does not cause {{c14::substantial harm to the property}}. 4. Waste 4.1 If the tenant impermissibly removes fixtures, she commits {{c15::voluntary waste}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Trusts terminate automatically at the expiration of a {{c1::specified trust term}} or when their purposes have become {{c2::accomplished, unlawful, impossible, or contrary to public policy}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::life estate}} is a {{c2::present possessory estate measured by a life}}. The {{c3::life tenant (LT)}} has ordinary ownership rights but must {{c4::maintain the property, make reasonable repairs, and avoid waste}}. A life estate can be {{c5::defeasible or indefeasible}}. When the life estate ends, either a {{c6::reversion in the grantor}} or a {{c7::remainder in a third party}} becomes possessory. A {{c8::life estate pur autre vie}} is measured by {{c9::someone else’s life, including after transfer of a life estate}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. General rule - Under the {{c1::merger doctrine}}, two or more offenses may merge, prohibiting the defendant from being {{c2::convicted of both offenses}}. 2. Relationships where merger arises - Merger concerns the relationship between either: - An {{c3::inchoate offense}} and its completed {{c4::substantive offense}}, or - An offense and its {{c5::lesser included offense}}. 3. Purpose/Effect - Prevents {{c6::multiple convictions}} when one crime is essentially {{c7::part of another}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::fee simple}} that {{c2::automatically transfers to a third party}} upon the happening of a specified {{c3::event or condition}}. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 {{c4::Automatic forfeiture}}: Upon occurrence of the event or condition, the estate automatically transfers to a third person. It is similar to a {{c5::fee simple determinable}}, but ownership automatically shifts to a {{c6::third person, not back to the grantor}}. 2.2 {{c7::Potentially infinite}}: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur. 2.3 {{c8::Transferable}}: The estate is {{c9::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}, subject to the occurrence of the condition. 2.4 {{c10::Absolute restraints on alienation are void}}. 3. Creation and future interest: 3.1 Creation: {{c11::Clear durational or conditional language}} is required; words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient. 3.2 Accompanying future interest: A third party holds a {{c12::shifting executory interest}}. The executory interest is transferable and is {{c13::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Corporation's liability for pre-incorporation contracts: 1. {{c1::General rule}}: {{c2::The corporation is not liable}} for pre-incorporation transactions, even those for its benefit, because there is {{c3::no principal–agent relationship}}. 2. {{c4::Adoption}}: The corporation becomes liable if it {{c5::expressly or impliedly adopts}} a contract by: 2.1 {{c6::Accepting the benefits of the transaction}}, or 2.2 {{c7::Giving an express acceptance of liability for the debt}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: In {{c1::concurrent estates}}, co-tenants share core rights and duties: (1) {{c2::possession}} of the whole subject to {{c3::ouster}} rules; (2) treatment of {{c4::rents and profits}} from {{c5::own use}} versus {{c6::third parties and depleting uses}}; (3) limits on {{c7::adverse possession}} against co-tenants absent {{c8::actual ouster}}; (4) obligations for {{c9::carrying costs}}, {{c10::repairs}}, and {{c11::improvements}}; (5) remedies for {{c12::waste}}; and (6) rights to {{c13::partition or sale}} and limits on {{c14::agreements not to partition}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::UCC}} modification rules 1.1 No {{c2::consideration}} is required for a {{c3::good-faith modification}} of a contract for the {{c4::sale of goods}}. 1.2 A modification must be in {{c5::writing}} if: 1.2.1 The contract as modified falls within the {{c6::Statute of Frauds}}; or 1.2.2 The original contract {{c7::requires modifications to be in writing}}. 1.3 {{c8::Parol evidence}} is admissible to show {{c9::subsequent modifications}} to a contract.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Regulatory taxes 1.1 Congress can use {{c1::taxes}} to achieve a {{c2::regulatory effect}}. 1.2 A regulatory tax is valid if: 1.2.1 The tax’s {{c3::dominant intent}} is to {{c4::raise revenue}}; and 1.2.2 There is some {{c5::reasonable relationship}} between the tax and the {{c6::regulation or conduct}} being influenced. 1.3 The {{c7::reasonable relationship}} requirement is a {{c8::low burden}} to satisfy. 2. Regulatory spending (conditional funding) 2.1 Congress can use its {{c9::spending power}} to regulate indirectly by attaching {{c10::conditions}} to the receipt of {{c11::federal funds}}. 2.2 These conditions must {{c12::not be overly or unduly coercive}}, especially when imposed on the {{c13::states}}. 2.3 If the conditions are {{c14::non-coercive}} and {{c15::tied to the federal program}}, Congress may {{c16::influence or regulate behavior}} through {{c17::conditional funding}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: In UCC sales using a carrier, {{c1::contract type}} determines when risk of loss passes. In a {{c2::shipment contract}}, the seller is only obligated to {{c3::deliver the goods to a carrier}}, and risk of loss passes to the buyer when the seller {{c4::delivers the goods to the carrier}}. If a contract requires shipment by a third-party carrier but is silent on shipment terms, a {{c5::shipment contract is presumed}}. In a {{c6::destination contract}}, the seller must {{c7::ensure the goods reach the buyer at the named destination}}, and risk of loss passes to the buyer only when the buyer {{c8::takes delivery at the destination}}.

subject: Agency
cloze: Step 1: {{c1::Actual authority}} 1. Ask first: Did the agent have {{c2::actual authority}}? - Actual authority exists when the {{c3::principal has authorized the agent}} (expressly or impliedly) to act on the principal’s behalf and the agent {{c4::reasonably believes}} she is so empowered. 2. Effect of actual authority on the principal: - If the agent had actual authority, the {{c5::principal is bound}} to the contract entered into by the agent with the third party. - This is true regardless of whether the {{c6::third party knew}} about, or even believed in, the agent’s authority. 3. Effect of actual authority on the agent: - When the agent acts within the {{c7::scope of her actual authority}}, she generally {{c8::cannot be held liable to the principal}} for entering into the contract. - Merely contracting within authorized bounds does not itself create liability from the agent to the principal.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Definition of a vested remainder 1.1 A {{c1::vested remainder}} is a {{c2::future interest in a transferee}} that automatically becomes {{c3::possessory upon the natural expiration of the preceding estate}}. 2. Limitations on vested remainders 2.1 A remainder is vested only if: 2.1.1 It is {{c4::not subject to any condition precedent}}; and 2.1.2 It is vested in an {{c5::ascertained (known) person}}. 2.2 If an interest is {{c6::subject to a condition precedent}} or held by an {{c7::unknown or unascertained person}}, it is a {{c8::contingent remainder}}, not a vested remainder.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule on adult trespassers: 1.1 {{c1::Unknown or undiscovered trespassers}}: - {{c2::No duty of care}} is owed. 1.2 {{c3::Anticipated trespassers}} (owner has reason to believe trespassers will be on the land): 1.2.1 Activities: - The owner has a duty to exercise {{c4::reasonable care}} in carrying out activities on the property. 1.2.2 Dangerous conditions: - The owner has a duty to {{c5::make safe or warn}} of any {{c6::known, concealed, man-made hazards}}. - This duty is {{c7::narrow and typically applies to artificial hazards}}. - Classic examples: {{c8::spring guns, traps, and similar artificial hazards}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 4. Pretrial conferences 4.1 A pretrial conference is held before the court, as needed, to {{c1::move the case forward}} and {{c2::encourage settlement}}. 5. Final pretrial conference and order 5.1 A final pretrial conference may be set to finalize the {{c3::issues to be resolved at trial}} and the {{c4::evidence to be presented}}, memorialized in a {{c5::pretrial conference order}}. 5.2 Issues not included in the pretrial conference order are generally {{c6::excluded at trial}}. 5.3 The pretrial conference order may be modified only to prevent {{c7::manifest injustice}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. In general: {{c1::Actual cause (cause in fact)}} establishes a causal connection between the alleged breach of duty and the resulting injury. 1.1 "{{c2::But for}}" test: But for defendant's alleged breach of duty, plaintiff's injury would not have occurred. 2. {{c3::Substantial factor test}}: 2.1 For {{c4::multiple causes}} of plaintiff's injury, defendant's breach is the actual cause if it was a {{c5::substantial factor}} in bringing about plaintiff's injury. 2.2 Application: Used when multiple causes bring about plaintiff's injury and {{c6::any one of them alone would have caused the injury}}. 2.3 Example: Fires start on D1's land and D2's land, each of which spreads to plaintiff's land and destroys plaintiff's house. 3. {{c7::Burden-shifting test}} ({{c8::alternative causation}}): 3.1 For several possible causes of plaintiff's injury. 3.2 Application: Used when {{c9::multiple defendants act (often simultaneously)}}, only one causes plaintiff's injury, but it is {{c10::unclear which defendant caused the injury}}. 3.3 Example: Plaintiff is hit by a stray bullet at a busy firing range and it is unknown which shooter hit plaintiff. 3.4 {{c11::Burden of proving actual cause shifts to defendants}}. 3.5 If no defendant can prove another defendant was responsible, {{c12::all defendants are jointly and severally liable}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 remedy that allows a {{c1::secured party}}, after {{c2::default}}, to {{c3::keep the collateral}} instead of selling it, in {{c4::full or partial satisfaction}} of the debt. Its use is governed by rules on {{c5::debtor consent}}, {{c6::authenticated notice}} and {{c7::20-day objection}} by the debtor and certain other secured parties, and {{c8::special consumer protections}} that limit partial satisfaction with deficiency and impose a {{c9::60%/90-day sale rule}} for certain consumer-goods loans.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::vested remainder}} is a remainder given to an {{c2::ascertained person}} and {{c3::not subject to a condition precedent}}. There are three main types: 1. {{c4::Indefeasibly vested remainder}} – a remainder in an {{c5::identified taker with no conditions precedent}} remaining, so the taker is certain to take possession when the prior estate ends. Example: "To A for life, then to B" – B has an indefeasibly vested remainder. 2. {{c6::Vested remainder subject to total divestment}} – a vested remainder that may be {{c7::cut off by a condition subsequent}}. Example: "To A for life, then to B, but if B ever divorces, then to C" – B has a vested remainder subject to total divestment. 3. {{c8::Vested remainder subject to open}} (a {{c9::class gift}}) – a remainder {{c10::vested in at least one member of a class}} where the class is {{c11::capable of expanding}}. Example: "To A for life, then to A’s children" – if A has one child, that child has a vested remainder subject to open in favor of later-born children.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: {{c1::Wiretapping and eavesdropping}}: 1. General rule: {{c2::Electronic surveillance}} (e.g., wiretapping, eavesdropping) that violates a {{c3::reasonable expectation of privacy}} constitutes a {{c4::search under the Fourth Amendment}} and requires a {{c5::warrant}}. 2. Warrant requirements for electronic surveillance: 2.1 {{c6::Probable cause}} that a specific crime is being or has been committed. 2.2 The warrant must {{c7::name the suspects}} subject to surveillance. 2.3 The warrant must {{c8::describe with particularity the subject of conversations}} that can be surveilled. 2.4 Surveillance must be limited to {{c9::short periods of time}}. 2.5 Surveillance must {{c10::terminate when the desired information is obtained}} and must be {{c11::turned over to the court}}. 3. {{c12::Assumption of risk / one-party consent}}: 3.1 All speakers assume the risk that the person to whom they are speaking is wired and/or recording the conversation; therefore, police {{c13::do not need a warrant}} if they get someone to wear a wire and talk to the suspect. 3.2 A speaker who makes no attempt to keep a conversation private has {{c14::no reasonable expectation of privacy}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Either party may file a motion for {{c1::summary judgment}} asking the court to enter judgment. The motion must be filed no later than {{c2::30 days after the close of discovery}}. 1. {{c3::Burden for moving party}}: There is {{c4::no genuine dispute of material fact}}, and the moving party is {{c5::entitled to judgment as a matter of law}}. In other words, no reasonable person could find for the non-moving party. The motion is based on {{c6::pleadings and evidence submitted}}. 2. {{c7::Burden-shifting}}: If a party moves for summary judgment, the burden shifts to the non-moving party to show that a {{c8::triable issue}} exists. The non-moving party may submit a request for more time to take discovery (and must specify the {{c9::discovery sought}} and {{c10::how it will help}}). 3. {{c11::Evidence}}: The evidence is examined in the {{c12::light most favorable to the non-moving party}}. The court can look at the {{c13::whole record of admissible evidence}}. Note: this distinguishes summary judgment from {{c14::Rule 12(b)(6)}} or {{c15::12(c)}} motions, in which the court may only look at the {{c16::complaint or pleadings}}. 4. {{c17::Partial summary judgment}}: The court can grant summary judgment on only certain {{c18::claims or issues}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Ultra vires acts}} 1.1 Definition 1.1.1 A corporation takes an {{c2::ultra vires act}} when it acts {{c3::outside of its stated purpose as set forth in the articles of incorporation}}. 1.2 Consequences of ultra vires acts (three possibilities) 1.2.1 {{c4::Shareholder suit}}: Shareholders may sue the corporation to {{c5::enjoin the ultra vires act}}. 1.2.2 {{c6::Corporate suit}}: The corporation may sue an officer or director responsible for the ultra vires act for resulting {{c7::damages}}. 1.2.3 {{c8::State action}}: The state may bring an action to {{c9::dissolve the corporation}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. Definition of a resulting trust 1.1 A {{c1::resulting trust}} is an equitable trust {{c2::implied or imposed by law}}, most often when an {{c3::express trust fails}} or does not fully dispose of the trust property. 2. When resulting trusts arise 2.1 Common triggers include when: • The intended {{c4::beneficiary is dead}} and no substitute is provided. • The trust terms are {{c5::void or unenforceable}}. • The trust purpose is fully {{c6::satisfied}} and surplus remains (in some jurisdictions). 3. Who benefits 3.1 In a resulting trust, the {{c7::settlor}} usually becomes the beneficiary. 3.2 The {{c8::trustee}} holds property in trust and conveys title back to the settlor. 3.3 If the settlor has died, the trustee conveys title to the settlor's {{c9::estate}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Intervention and compulsory joinder are distinct joinder devices. 1. {{c1::Intervention}}: • A non-party absentee {{c2::voluntarily chooses}} to join the suit. • The absentee may join as a {{c3::plaintiff}} or {{c4::defendant}}. • Governed by {{c5::intervention as of right}} and {{c6::permissive intervention}} rules. • Generally {{c7::more lenient and flexible}}, used when absentees seek to protect their own interests in an ongoing case. 2. {{c8::Compulsory joinder}}: • The court {{c9::forces an absentee into the case}} when the person is {{c10::necessary or indispensable}} to a just adjudication. • It is {{c11::narrow}} and used only when very necessary to protect parties or avoid {{c12::inconsistent obligations}}. • If an indispensable absentee cannot be joined, the court may {{c13::dismiss the action}}. 3. Key distinction: • Intervention is {{c14::voluntary}} from the absentee’s perspective; compulsory joinder is {{c15::mandatory}} at the court’s direction.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. Definition of annulment: • {{c1::Annulment}} is a judicial declaration that an alleged marriage was {{c2::invalid from its inception}} because an {{c3::impediment existed at the time of marriage}}. • As a result, the marriage is treated as if it {{c4::never legally occurred}}. 2.
