Void vs. voidable marriages: • A marriage may be annulled if it is either {{c5::void}} or {{c6::voidable}}. • Whether a particular ground makes a marriage void or voidable {{c7::varies by state}}. • {{c8::Void}} marriages are considered invalid even without a decree, but an annulment action is often brought to {{c9::clarify the parties’ status}}. • {{c10::Voidable}} marriages are treated as valid {{c11::unless and until a court annuls them}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Sixth Amendment jury-trial right: - The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} provides a right to a {{c2::jury trial in criminal prosecutions}}. 2. Right to be present at critical stages: - The defendant has a right to be {{c3::present for all critical stages}} of the proceeding, including {{c4::jury selection}}. 3. When a jury is required – serious offense: - A jury trial is required for a {{c5::serious offense}}. - A serious offense is one for which the potential term of imprisonment {{c6::exceeds 6 months}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. The {{c1::Fourth Amendment}} only applies if a person has a {{c2::reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP)}} regarding the place or thing searched and/or the items seized. 2. {{c3::Standing}} to challenge a government search or seizure requires that the {{c4::defendant personally}} had a REOP, determined by the {{c5::totality of the circumstances}}. 2.1. The question is whether the defendant’s expectation of privacy is one that {{c6::society is prepared to recognize as reasonable}} under all the circumstances.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 3. {{c1::Contract theory of plea bargaining}} 3.1 Plea agreements will be {{c2::enforced against both parties}}, but the judge is {{c3::not required to accept or adhere to the agreement}}. 3.2 The prosecutor can {{c4::threaten the defendant with a more serious charge}} than he was initially facing and may {{c5::follow through on that threat}} if the defendant does not accept the plea, so long as the prosecutor has {{c6::probable cause}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: {{c1::Subsequent remedial measures}} 1. Evidence of repairs or other remedial measures taken after an injury is {{c2::inadmissible}} to prove {{c3::fault, a defective product or design, or an inadequate warning}}. 2. The same evidence is {{c4::admissible}} to {{c5::rebut a claim or defense that there was no feasible precaution}} or to prove {{c6::ownership or control}} when those issues are disputed.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A {{c1::limited/designated public forum}} is a government property that the government {{c2::affirmatively opens for speech}} but {{c3::can close at any time}}. Examples include {{c4::public school facilities}} opened for outside group meetings and {{c5::advertising space in government property}} opened for private ads. While the forum is open, the {{c6::same rules as a traditional public forum}} apply: the government may not {{c7::discriminate based on viewpoint}}, and {{c8::content-based}} restrictions must satisfy {{c9::strict scrutiny}} (while content-neutral time, place, and manner limits must meet public forum standards). If the government {{c10::closes the forum entirely}} to speech, it is no longer a limited/designated public forum. If the government {{c11::restricts}} the forum to certain {{c12::types of speech}} or {{c13::classes of speakers}}, remaining regulations are analyzed under the {{c14::non-public forum}} test (reasonable and viewpoint neutral).

subject: Family Law
cloze: Provisions in a premarital agreement that attempt to predetermine {{c1::child custody}} or {{c2::child support}} are {{c3::not binding}} on the court and may be {{c4::void}} in some states. Courts decide custody and support at the time of {{c5::dissolution}} based on the {{c6::best interests of the child}}. The rationale is that custody and support are considered {{c7::rights of the child}}, not purely contractual rights of the parents, and thus {{c8::cannot be bargained away in advance}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Disposition of property}} – definition 1.1 A disposition of property includes a {{c2::sale, lease, or other disposition}} of corporate property. 2. When a disposition is a {{c3::fundamental change}} 2.1 A disposition of {{c4::all or substantially all}} of the corporation’s property, {{c5::outside the regular or ordinary course of business}}, is treated as a fundamental corporate change. 2.2 "All or substantially all" assets means the transaction leaves the corporation without {{c6::significant continuing business activities}}. 2.3 The disposition must be {{c7::outside the ordinary course}} of the corporation’s business; large transactions in the ordinary course are not fundamental changes. 3. Approval requirements 3.1 Because it is a fundamental change, such a disposition requires: - Approval by the {{c8::board of directors}}; and - Approval by the {{c9::shareholders}} under the applicable voting rules.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Automobile stop}}: 1.1 {{c2::Reasonable suspicion}} is required. 1.2 To stop or pull over a vehicle, police must have reasonable suspicion that a {{c3::law has been violated}}. 1.3 {{c4::Pretextual stops}}: An ulterior motive for a stop is permissible if police have {{c5::probable cause of a traffic violation}}. 2. {{c6::Accompanying searches}} (police may search): 2.1 Police may frisk passengers and search the {{c7::passenger compartment}} (but not the trunk) if the officer reasonably believes {{c8::weapons may be present}}. 2.2 Police can {{c9::order passengers out of the vehicle}}. 2.3 The {{c10::entire car}} may be searched if {{c11::probable cause}} arises pursuant to the {{c12::automobile search exception}}. 2.4 An automobile may also be searched {{c13::incident to a lawful arrest}}, subject to the limits on searches incident to arrest. 3. {{c14::Police checkpoints}}: 3.1 Checkpoints must relate to a {{c15::vehicle-specific purpose}}. 3.2 A police checkpoint or roadblock that stops cars without {{c16::individualized suspicion}} (e.g., DUI checkpoints) must: 3.2.1 Stop cars using a {{c17::neutral, articulable standard}} (e.g., every fourth car); and 3.2.2 Serve purposes related to {{c18::automobiles and their mobility}}. 3.3 For example, {{c19::DUI checkpoints}} that relate to {{c20::road safety}} are valid, but {{c21::drug checkpoints}} aimed at {{c22::general crime control}} are unconstitutional.

subject: Torts
cloze: Prima facie {{c1::intentional torts}} share common elements and a special doctrine: 1. Common elements 1.1 {{c2::Act by D}}: some {{c3::volitional movement}}. 1.2 {{c4::Intent}}: either {{c5::specific intent}} (to bring about a specific harm) or {{c6::general intent}} (knowledge with {{c7::substantial certainty}} that the tortious result will occur). 1.3 {{c8::Causation}}: D's conduct must be a {{c9::substantial factor}} in bringing about the resulting harm. 1.4 {{c10::Damages}}: {{c11::compensatory}} damages are generally available, and {{c12::punitive}} damages may be awarded for {{c13::malicious}} conduct. 2. {{c14::Transferred intent doctrine}} (special rule) 2.1 Applies to classic intentional torts: {{c15::assault}}, {{c16::battery}}, {{c17::false imprisonment}}, and {{c18::trespass}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: First Amendment constraints on defamation apply when the case involves a {{c1::public official}}, a {{c2::public figure}}, or a {{c3::matter of public concern}}. At a high level: - Special {{c4::definitions}} matter (public figure, public official, matter of public concern). - The plaintiff must prove both {{c5::falsity}} and {{c6::fault}}, with {{c7::actual malice}} required for public officials and public figures. - {{c8::Damages}} are limited, especially for {{c9::private figures}} on {{c10::matters of public concern}}, where {{c11::actual malice}} is required for {{c12::presumed or punitive damages}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Hearsay PIS – impeachment only 1.1 If a prior inconsistent statement (PIS) is {{c1::hearsay}} and does **not** fall within a hearsay exemption or exception, it is admissible only to {{c2::impeach credibility}}. 1.2 It is **inadmissible** as {{c3::substantive evidence}} to prove the truth of the matter asserted and may be considered only for its impact on the witness’s {{c4::credibility}}. 2. Nonhearsay or exception PIS – substantive use 2.1 If the PIS is {{c5::not hearsay}} or falls under a hearsay {{c6::exemption or exception}}, it may be considered {{c7::for any purpose}}. 2.2 Such a PIS is admissible both for {{c2::impeachment}} and as {{c3::substantive evidence}} of the facts asserted in the statement.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Creation 1.1 Four {{c1::unities}} must concurrently exist when the tenants take their interests: 1.1.1 {{c2::Time}}: Joint tenants must take their interests at the {{c3::same time}}. 1.1.2 {{c4::Title}}: Joint tenants must receive their interests through the {{c5::same instrument}}. 1.1.3 {{c6::Interest}}: Joint tenants must take {{c7::equal and identical interests}}. 1.1.4 {{c8::Possession}}: Joint tenants must have {{c9::equal possessory rights}}. 1.2 {{c10::Express intent required}}: The grantor must expressly intend to create a {{c11::joint tenancy}}; otherwise, a {{c12::tenancy in common}} is presumed. 1.3 {{c13::Right of survivorship}}: If one joint tenant dies, the surviving joint tenants automatically take equal possession of the {{c14::deceased tenant's share}}. 1.4 {{c15::Transferability}}: A joint tenant's interest is {{c16::alienable inter vivos}}, but {{c17::not devisable or descendible}} because of the right of survivorship. 2. {{c18::Severance}} and transfer of interests 2.1 Severance: Severance by any joint tenant (e.g., by sale) creates a {{c19::tenancy in common}} with respect to the severed interest. 2.2 Transfer: A joint tenant's interest becomes a tenancy in common upon {{c20::transfer}}; this does not destroy the entire joint tenancy if {{c21::two or more joint tenants remain}}. 2.3 Mortgage ({{c22::lien theory}} versus {{c23::title theory}}) 2.3.1 {{c24::Lien theory jurisdiction (majority)}}: A joint tenant can take a mortgage on her interest {{c25::without severing the joint tenancy}} because {{c26::no title passes to the mortgagee}}. 2.3.2 {{c27::Title theory jurisdiction (minority)}}: The joint tenancy is {{c28::severed}} if any joint tenant takes a mortgage on her interest because {{c29::title passes to the mortgagee}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 {{c1::Purchase-money security interests (PMSIs)}} are {{c2::"superpriority"}} interests, meaning they can be superior to prior perfected security interests in the same goods, if statutory conditions are met. 2. {{c3::PMSI in inventory}}: 2.1 A PMSI in inventory has priority over other security interests in the same inventory and its {{c4::proceeds}} (including instruments, chattel paper, and identifiable cash proceeds) if: 2.1.1 The PMSI is {{c5::perfected when the debtor takes possession}} of the inventory; and 2.1.2 Other parties who have filed security interests in the inventory receive {{c6::authenticated notification}} of the PMSI {{c7::before the debtor takes possession}} of the inventory; and 2.1.3 The notification states that a PMSI will be taken in the debtor’s inventory and {{c8::describes the kind or type of inventory}}. 3. {{c9::PMSI in goods other than inventory or livestock}} (e.g., equipment or consumer goods): 3.1 A PMSI in such goods has priority over other security interests in the same goods and their proceeds if the PMSI is perfected {{c10::before or within 20 days after}} the debtor receives possession of the collateral; and 3.2 There is {{c11::no requirement to notify}} other security interest holders. 4. {{c12::Conflicting PMSIs}}: 4.1 Where there are multiple PMSIs in the same collateral, priority goes to the secured party who has a PMSI as the {{c13::seller of the collateral}} (as opposed to a mere lender); or 4.2 Otherwise, priority goes to the {{c14::first secured party to file or perfect}}. 4.3 Example: A takes a $300 loan from a bank to buy a $500 TV, giving the bank an SI in the TV. A then signs a $200 credit agreement with the TV store to complete the purchase, and the store retains an SI in the TV. The store, as the seller of the collateral, has priority over the bank as the lender.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Extrinsic evidence may be used to impeach a witness, except on {{c1::collateral matters}}. 1. {{c2::Extrinsic evidence}} 1.1 Extrinsic evidence is any evidence other than the witness's {{c3::testimony at the current proceeding}}. 1.2 It includes evidence of {{c4::out-of-court prior inconsistent statements}}. 1.3 Extrinsic evidence of {{c5::contradictory facts}} is generally admissible to impeach a witness on {{c6::material, non-collateral matters}}. 2. {{c7::Collateral matter}} 2.1 A collateral matter is a fact {{c8::not material to the issues}} in the case; it says nothing about the witness's credibility other than to contradict. 2.2 Example: Witness 1 testifies he was headed to the store when he saw the defendant commit murder. The defense cannot call Witness 2 to testify that Witness 1 was really headed to see his mistress. This is collateral (i.e., not material) to what Witness 1 saw. 2.3 Test: To determine if evidence is collateral, ask whether the evidence would be {{c9::material to an issue in the case}} if the witness had not made the contrary assertion. If not, it is likely {{c10::collateral}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Appointment of federal officers}} - The {{c2::President}} appoints {{c3::ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal officers}} with the {{c4::advice and consent of the Senate}}. - {{c5::Congress}} cannot give itself appointment power, but may vest appointment of {{c6::inferior officers}} in the {{c7::President alone}}, the {{c8::courts}}, or {{c9::heads of departments}}. 2. {{c10::Removal of federal officers}} - The {{c11::President}} may remove {{c12::high‑level executive officers}} and, subject to statutory {{c13::good‑cause or similar limits}}, other executive appointees. - {{c14::Congress}} has no general removal power; it removes executive officers and {{c15::Article III judges}} only through {{c16::impeachment}}. 3. {{c17::Impeachment}} - The {{c18::House}} impeaches by {{c19::majority vote}} for {{c20::treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors}}. - The {{c21::Senate}} tries impeachments and may remove upon conviction by the constitutionally required {{c22::supermajority vote}}.

subject: Agency
cloze: In the absence of anything contrary in their agreement, the agent owes the principal duties of {{c1::loyalty}}, {{c2::obedience}}, and {{c3::care}}. 1. {{c4::Loyalty}}: 1.1 The agent has a {{c5::fiduciary duty of undivided loyalty}} to the principal; 1.2 The agent breaches this duty if he has {{c6::adverse interests}} and fails to disclose such interests; and 1.3 The agent cannot act on behalf of two different principals with {{c7::adverse interests}}. 2. {{c8::Obedience}}: 2.1 The agent must obey the principal's {{c9::lawful instructions}}; and 2.2 The agent's interpretation of the principal's instructions must be {{c10::reasonable under the circumstances}}. 3. {{c11::Care}}: 3.1 The agent must carry out his agency with {{c12::reasonable care}}; 3.2 Reasonable care is judged in light of {{c13::local community standards}}; and 3.3 A {{c14::duty to notify}} is included in the duty of care: the agent must notify the principal of all agency-related matters that come to the agent's attention, and all such matters are {{c15::imputed to the principal}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Termination When {{c1::Necessity Ends}} 1.1 Easements by necessity automatically end when the {{c2::need that created them ceases}}. 1.2 This mode applies specifically to easements created {{c3::by necessity}}. 2. Termination by {{c4::Destruction of the Servient Tenement}} 2.1 Destruction of the servient tenement {{c5::terminates an easement}}. 2.2 Exception: If the destruction results from the {{c6::willful conduct of the servient owner}}, the easement is not terminated on this basis. 3. Termination by {{c7::Merger}} 3.1 An easement terminates automatically if {{c8::one person acquires title to both the easement and the servient land}}. 3.2 Once merged, later {{c9::re-dividing the merged title will not revive}} the easement. 4. Termination by {{c10::Prescription}} 4.1 The servient owner may extinguish an easement by interfering with its use using the elements of {{c11::adverse possession}}. 4.2 Typically, this requires {{c12::open and notorious, actual, continuous, exclusive, and hostile interference for the statutory period}}. 5. Termination by {{c13::Expiration or Condition}} 5.1 If the easement was established for a {{c14::set term}}, expiration of that term terminates the easement. 5.2 If the easement is made to expire upon {{c15::stated conditions}}, occurrence of the stated conditions will terminate the easement.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Lack of consent in rape/sexual assault exists when: 1. Penetration is accomplished by {{c1::force or threat of immediate bodily harm}}; 2. The victim is {{c2::incapable of consenting due to lack of capacity}} (e.g., unconsciousness, intoxication); or 3. The victim is {{c3::fraudulently caused to believe the act is not intercourse}}. However, {{c4::fraud or trickery alone does not constitute rape}}; there must be {{c5::penetration without contemporaneous consent or capacity to consent}}. Example: {{c6::A mere false promise to marry to induce intercourse is not rape}} if the victim otherwise has capacity and contemporaneously consents.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: {{c1::Actus reus}} is the {{c2::physical act (or legally significant omission)}} required to commit a given crime. It is a required component of every common law crime, along with {{c3::mens rea}}. 1. Requirements 1.1 {{c4::Voluntary physical act}}: To satisfy the actus reus requirement, the defendant must perform a voluntary physical act, meaning a {{c5::voluntary bodily movement}}. 2. {{c6::Omission as actus reus}} (failure to act) 2.1 A failure to act can constitute actus reus if: 2.1.1 The defendant had a {{c7::specific legal duty to act}} (for example, by statute, contract, special relationship, voluntary assumption of care, or creation of the risk); 2.1.2 The defendant had {{c8::knowledge of the facts giving rise to the duty}}; and 2.1.3 It was {{c9::reasonably possible}} for the defendant to perform the duty.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}} limits state and local regulation of {{c2::interstate commerce}} when Congress has not acted. A state or local law is generally invalid if it {{c3::discriminates against out-of-state competition}}, {{c4::unduly burdens interstate commerce}}, or {{c5::regulates wholly out-of-state activity}}, unless an {{c6::exception}} applies (such as a {{c7::necessary important state interest}}, {{c8::market participant}} status, a {{c9::traditional government function}}, or {{c10::clear congressional approval}}).

subject: Real Property
cloze: Zoning Power – Source and Limits: 1. Source of zoning power 1.1. Government may enact zoning laws to reasonably control {{c1::land use}}. 1.2. Local governments (cities and counties) must be authorized by an {{c2::enabling act}} to exercise zoning power. 2. Limits on zoning ordinances 2.1. Zoning ordinances must be reasonably related to the {{c3::public welfare}}. 2.2. They must not be {{c4::overly or unduly restrictive}}. 2.3. They must not be {{c5::racially discriminatory}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Supreme Court {{c1::original jurisdiction}} 1.1 Under {{c2::Article III}}, the Supreme Court has original jurisdiction over: - {{c3::Suits between states}}; and - Cases involving {{c4::foreign ambassadors and other foreign ministers}}. 1.2 Filing requirements - These original jurisdiction cases must be filed in {{c5::federal court}}. - Suits between states must be filed in the {{c6::Supreme Court}} itself. 1.3 Limits on Congress - {{c7::Congress cannot expand}} the Court's original jurisdiction beyond what Article III provides. - Congress may regulate {{c8::appellate}} jurisdiction, but cannot create new categories of {{c9::original jurisdiction}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 3. Suits against {{c1::state officers}} (in federal court) 3.1 {{c2::Injunctive relief}} - Suits seeking injunctive relief for violations of the {{c3::Constitution}} or {{c4::federal law}} may be brought against state officers. - Under the {{c5::Ex parte Young}} doctrine, a plaintiff can sue a state officer in his or her {{c6::official capacity}} for {{c7::prospective relief}} to stop an ongoing violation of federal law. - The suit is treated as not being against the {{c8::state itself}}, so 11th Amendment immunity does not apply. 3.2 {{c9::Personal-capacity damages}} - Suits seeking {{c10::money damages}} to be paid by the state officer {{c11::personally}} (not from the state treasury) may be brought. - These are {{c12::personal-capacity}} suits; any judgment is collected from the officer’s {{c13::personal assets}}, not the state. Limits - {{c14::Retrospective relief}} requiring payment from the {{c15::state treasury}} is barred when the {{c16::state is the real party in interest}}. - Suits nominally against officers but effectively against the {{c17::state}} (e.g., to impose liability on the state treasury) remain barred by sovereign immunity.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Border searches}}: 1.1 At borders, officials may conduct {{c2::routine searches of persons and their effects (including vehicles)}} without a {{c3::warrant}}, {{c4::probable cause}}, or {{c5::reasonable suspicion}}. 1.2 The "{{c6::border}}" is any place where one can arrive in the U.S. from a foreign country (e.g., there is a border at Denver International Airport). 2. {{c7::Detentions}}: 2.1 {{c8::Reasonable suspicion}} is required. 2.2 Officials may detain a traveler at the border if they have reasonable suspicion she is {{c9::smuggling contraband}}. 3. {{c10::International mail}}: 3.1 Officials can open and inspect international mail if they have reasonable suspicion it contains {{c11::contraband}}. 4. {{c12::Immigration}}: 4.1 Officials may {{c13::raid a business to determine the citizenship status of its employees}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: A buyer of goods can take free of an {{c1::unperfected}} security interest if: 1. {{c2::Timing}}: The buyer buys the goods {{c3::before the secured party perfects}} its security interest. 2. {{c4::Value and delivery}}: The buyer {{c5::gives value}} and {{c6::receives delivery}} of the goods. 3. {{c7::Knowledge}}: The buyer has {{c8::no knowledge of the security interest}} at the time of purchase and delivery. If these elements are satisfied, the buyer’s interest {{c9::has priority}} and the buyer {{c10::takes free of}} the unperfected security interest.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Embezzlement}} is the {{c2::fraudulent conversion}} of another's personal property by one in {{c3::lawful possession}}. 2. Required elements: 2.1 {{c4::Fraudulent conversion}}: The defendant uses another's property beyond the scope of, or inconsistent with, the defendant's possessory rights. 2.2 By one in {{c5::lawful possession}}: The defendant must have lawful possession at the time of conversion. 3. Distinguished from larceny: Both involve obtaining property through misappropriation, but the circumstances of the taking differ. 3.1 {{c6::Embezzlement}}: Conversion of property already in the defendant's {{c7::rightful possession}}. 3.2 {{c8::Larceny}}: Taking property {{c9::not in the defendant's possession}} (a {{c10::trespassory taking}}). 4. Special issues refuting embezzlement: 4.1 {{c11::Intent to restore}}: If the defendant takes property with the intent to restore the exact property, no embezzlement has occurred; it must be the exact same property—substituting different monetary bills of equal value does not suffice. 4.2 {{c12::Claim of right}}: Like larceny, embezzlement will not arise if the misappropriation is made under a claim of right to the property (i.e., the defendant believes the property belongs to him).

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Integration issues can arise where part of a will becomes {{c1::separated}} (for example, pages of a multipage, stapled will become separated). The issue is whether the separate pages can be {{c2::integrated}} and construed as the testator's complete will. 1. Test for integration (a document will be integrated into a will if): 1.1 {{c3::Physical presence}}: the document was physically present at the time of the will's execution; and 1.2 {{c4::Intent of inclusion}}: the testator intended the document to be part of the will. 2. {{c5::Evidence}}: witness testimony and other {{c6::extrinsic evidence}} may be used to establish that the requirements for integration have been satisfied. 3. {{c7::Presumption}}: the integration requirements are presumed where there is a {{c8::physical connection of pages}} (for example, staples or paperclips) or when there is some {{c9::internal coherence}} (i.e., the pages, when combined, comprise a complete, orderly disposition).

subject: Con Law
cloze: Right to Travel under Equal Protection 1. Fundamental right and standard of review - The {{c1::right to travel}} is a {{c2::fundamental right}}. - When a law burdens {{c3::interstate movement}} or penalizes recent arrivals, it is usually analyzed under {{c4::equal protection}}. - Standard of review: {{c5::strict scrutiny}}. 2. How the issue arises - Typically arises when laws {{c6::impede movement between states}} or {{c7::discriminate against new residents}}. - A common form is a {{c8::durational residency requirement}}: a rule requiring some minimum in-state residency period to qualify for a state benefit or privilege. 3. Durational residency requirements A. {{c9::Invalid}} durational residency requirements (fail strict scrutiny): - A {{c10::1-year}} residency requirement to receive {{c11::welfare}} benefits. - A {{c12::1-year}} residency requirement to receive {{c13::subsidized medical care}}. - A {{c14::1-year}} residency requirement to {{c15::vote in state elections}}. B. {{c16::Valid}} durational residency requirements (permitted): - A {{c17::30-day}} residency requirement to {{c18::vote in state elections}}. - A {{c19::1-year}} residency requirement to {{c20::obtain a divorce}} in the state. 4. Framing - Although the right to travel can also be framed as a {{c21::substantive due process}} liberty, it is often tested as an {{c22::equal protection classification}} problem involving durational residency.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 Almost any Secured Transactions essay will involve issues of {{c1::priority}}. Always note the type of {{c2::collateral}} involved (goods, inventory, livestock, equipment, etc.) and the type of {{c3::parties}} involved (secured party vs. secured party, secured party vs. unsecured party, secured party vs. lien creditor, etc.). 1.2 Priority between parties is generally governed by the following rules. 2. {{c4::Attached vs. unattached/unsecured interests}}: 2.1 An {{c5::attached security interest}} prevails over a mere {{c6::unsecured or unattached interest}}. 2.2 Beware scenarios where someone has signed a {{c7::security agreement}} but the secured party has not yet given {{c8::value}} or the debtor has no {{c9::rights in the collateral}}—attachment has not yet occurred, so priority may fail. 3. {{c10::Perfected vs. unperfected}} security interests: 3.1 A {{c11::perfected security interest}} prevails over an {{c12::unperfected security interest}}. 3.2 This rule applies even if the perfected party took its interest with {{c13::knowledge of an earlier unperfected interest}}. 4. {{c14::Perfected vs. perfected}} security interests: 4.1 As between conflicting perfected security interests, the {{c15::"first to file or perfect"}} rule applies: the party that first either files a financing statement or otherwise perfects its interest has priority. 4.2 When there are conflicting perfected SIs, priority goes to the party that first filed or perfected (usually the first to file). 4.3 Where collateral is not subject to filing (or cannot be perfected by filing), the {{c16::first to perfect}} obtains priority. 4.4 {{c17::Knowledge of a prior unperfected SI}} does not prevent a prospective secured party from filing first to obtain priority under the {{c18::first-to-file-or-perfect rule}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, when the decedent is survived by a {{c2::parent but no descendant}}, the surviving spouse takes {{c3::$300,000}} plus {{c4::75%}} of the {{c5::remaining}} intestate estate, and the balance {{c6::25% of the remainder}} goes to the {{c7::parent(s)}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general ({{c1::common law}}): A {{c2::material breach}} occurs when one party's failure to perform under the contract {{c3::substantially deprives the other party of the benefit of the bargain}}. 1.1 Material breach by one party {{c4::excuses performance}} by the other. 1.2 {{c5::Materiality}} of breach is a {{c6::question of fact}}. 1.3 Damages: Damages are recoverable for any breach to the extent they are {{c7::foreseeable}} as a probable result of the breach. 2. {{c8::Timeliness of performance}}: 2.1 Failure to perform by the time stated in a contract is {{c9::not a material breach}} if performance is rendered within a {{c10::reasonable time}} after the time stated. 2.2 Exception: {{c11::"Time is of the essence" clauses}}. 2.2.1 If timely performance is {{c12::essential as stated in the contract}}, failure to perform by that time is a {{c13::material breach}}. 2.2.2 This arises if one party indicates as a term of the contract that performance by a given date is {{c14::essential}}. 3. Note: Material breach rules apply to {{c15::common law contracts}} and do not apply to {{c16::UCC}} contracts.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 3. {{c1::Corporation by estoppel}} 3.1 Persons who {{c2::treat an entity as a corporation}} are {{c3::estopped from denying}} that the entity is a corporation, particularly when attempting to {{c4::avoid liability}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Zoning}} and lewd speech or conduct: 1.1 Government may use zoning to regulate lewd speech or conduct if the regulation is designed to combat {{c2::secondary effects}} (such as crime or lower property values), not to suppress the {{c3::content of the speech}}. 1.2 Example: An ordinance limiting {{c4::strip clubs}} to a small section of a city can be valid if it is designed to combat a drop in property values or a rise in crime. 2. Pornography and private possession: 2.1 {{c5::Private possession of pornography}} is generally not punishable. 2.2 Exception: Government may criminalize private possession of {{c6::child pornography}}. 2.3 Child pornography requires that {{c7::actual children are depicted}}; {{c8::adults portraying children}} is not child pornography. 3. Profanity/indecent speech: 3.1 {{c9::Profane or indecent speech}} is generally protected. 3.2 However, profane or indecent speech is punishable if either: 3.2.1 The speech is aired over {{c10::broadcast media (not cable)}}; or 3.2.2 The speech occurs in {{c11::public schools}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. Falsity and Fault Framework 1.1 {{c1::Falsity}} and {{c2::fault}} are always required concepts in defamation law. 1.2 At {{c3::common law}}, there was {{c4::no requirement that the plaintiff prove fault}}; liability could be imposed without showing negligence or intent. 1.3 Modern {{c5::constitutional rules}} (e.g., under the {{c6::First Amendment}}) impose {{c7::fault requirements}} in many cases and allocate the burden of proving {{c8::falsity or truth}}. 1.4 Depending on whether the plaintiff is a {{c9::public official}}, {{c10::public figure}}, or {{c11::private figure}}, and whether the matter is of {{c12::public concern}}, the plaintiff may need to prove {{c13::falsity}} and a particular level of {{c14::fault}} (e.g., negligence or {{c15::actual malice}}), or the defendant may bear the burden of proving {{c16::truth}}. 2. Damages (at Common Law) 2.1 The plaintiff's burden of proving {{c17::damages}} depends on: (a) the {{c18::type of plaintiff}}; (b) whether the statement involves a {{c19::matter of public concern}}; and (c) whether the defamation is {{c20::libel, slander, or slander per se}}. 2.2 Historically, some forms of {{c21::libel}} and {{c22::slander per se}} allowed {{c23::presumed damages}}, while other types of {{c24::slander}} required proof of {{c25::special damages}}, subject to modern constitutional limits. 3. Truth as a Defense 3.1 {{c26::Truth}} is a {{c27::complete defense}} to defamation. 3.2 If the defendant establishes that the {{c28::gist or sting}} of the statement is true, the plaintiff cannot recover for defamation, even if the statement is slightly inaccurate in detail.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Administrative searches}} 1.1 Government agencies may conduct routine searches or inspections of {{c2::highly regulated businesses or industries}}. 1.2 For example: {{c3::building code inspections}}, {{c4::inspections for food safety}}, and {{c5::airline passenger searches}}. 1.3 A {{c6::warrant}} is required for inspections of {{c7::private residences or commercial buildings}}. 1.4 Administrative warrants require {{c8::less particularity}} than standard criminal warrants. 1.5 A {{c9::general and neutral enforcement plan}} for the searches will suffice to validate the warrant. 2. {{c10::Public school searches}} 2.1 To conduct a search, school officials must have {{c11::reasonable grounds}} to believe the search is necessary. 2.2 This is a {{c12::less burdensome standard than probable cause}}. 2.3 A public school search is reasonable if: 2.3.1 The search offers a {{c13::moderate chance}} of finding evidence of wrongdoing. 2.3.2 The procedure for searching is {{c14::reasonably related to the objectives}} of the search. 2.3.3 The search is {{c15::not excessively intrusive}} in light of the student’s age, sex, and the nature of the infraction. 2.4 Drug tests: {{c16::Random urinalysis}} is permissible for public school students participating in {{c17::extracurricular activities}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Government properties that are not traditional {{c1::public forums}} may impose greater restrictions on speech, including {{c2::limited/designated public forums}} and {{c3::non-public forums}}. In {{c4::limited/designated public forums}}, the government opens property for speech but can close it at any time; while open, {{c5::public forum rules}} apply (no viewpoint discrimination and {{c6::strict scrutiny}} for content-based limits). Once the forum is closed or speech is restricted to certain classes, treat it as a {{c7::non-public forum}}. In {{c8::non-public forums}}, which are not by tradition or designation open for public communication (e.g., {{c9::military bases, airports, internal government systems}}), the government may regulate speech if the regulation is {{c10::reasonably related to a legitimate governmental purpose}} and {{c11::viewpoint neutral}}; it may distinguish among {{c12::subjects}} but not among {{c13::viewpoints}} on an allowed subject.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 3. Categorical exclusions and felony-murder limits: 3.1 The death penalty cannot be imposed if the defendant was {{c1::under 18 years old}} at the time of the offense. 3.2 It cannot be imposed if the defendant is {{c2::mentally disabled}}. 3.3 It cannot be imposed if the defendant is {{c3::insane at the time of execution}}. 3.4 In {{c4::felony murder}} cases, the death penalty is barred if either: 3.4.1 The defendant was not a {{c5::major participant}} in the underlying felony, or 3.4.2 The defendant did not act with {{c6::depraved indifference to human life}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Article II gives the {{c1::President}} major {{c2::foreign affairs}} powers, including making treaties, appointing ambassadors, and serving as {{c3::Commander in Chief}}. This area covers {{c4::treaties}}, {{c5::executive agreements}}, and the President’s general {{c6::foreign affairs authority}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Common Law – Mirror-Image Rule 1.1. Under common law, acceptance must {{c1::mirror the offer}} ({{c2::mirror-image rule}}). 1.2. An acceptance that adds or changes terms is a {{c3::rejection and counteroffer}}. 2. UCC Article 2 – Additional Terms in Acceptance 2.1. Under the UCC, the effect of additional terms depends on whether both parties are {{c4::merchants}}. 3. One or Both Parties Are Non-Merchants 3.1. If {{c5::one or both parties are non-merchants}}, the {{c6::terms of the offer govern}}. 3.2. A {{c7::contract is formed}} despite the additional terms. 3.3. The additional terms are {{c8::excluded}} and treated as {{c9::mere proposals to modify}} the contract. 4. Both Parties Are Merchants 4.1. If {{c10::both parties are merchants}}, additional terms in the acceptance generally {{c11::become part of the contract}} unless an exception applies. 4.2. Exceptions: (a) The additional terms {{c12::materially alter}} the offer; (b) The offer {{c13::expressly limits acceptance to its terms}}; or (c) The {{c14::offeror objects}} to the additional terms within a {{c15::reasonable time}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Element 1: D is a {{c1::commercial supplier}}. 1. Commercial supplier status: 1.1 A commercial supplier has a strict duty to supply {{c2::safe goods}}. 1.2 A commercial supplier is one who {{c3::routinely deals in the product sold}} and is in the {{c4::stream of commerce}}. 1.3 Examples of commercial suppliers: 1.3.1 {{c5::Manufacturer}}. 1.3.2 {{c6::Distributor}}. 1.3.3 {{c7::Supplier or retailer}}. 1.4 Non-commercial actors (no strict products liability): 1.4.1 {{c8::Casual or occasional sellers}}. 1.4.2 {{c9::Service providers}} (primary role is service, not product sale).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Seventh Amendment}} right to a civil jury trial 1.1 Scope: The Seventh Amendment provides the right to a jury trial in federal civil actions at {{c2::law}}, but not in suits in {{c3::equity}} (i.e., not where only {{c4::equitable relief}} is sought). 1.2 {{c5::Demand}} for jury trial - A party may include a demand for a jury trial in {{c6::any pleading}}. - Deadline: The demand must be served no later than {{c7::14 days}} after service of the last pleading directed to a {{c8::triable issue}}. - {{c9::Waiver}}: Failure to make a timely demand waives the right to a jury trial. 1.3 {{c10::Jury size}} and {{c11::verdict}} - Number of jurors: A civil jury must have at least {{c12::6}} and no more than {{c13::12}} jurors. - Verdict: Unless the parties stipulate otherwise, the verdict must be {{c14::unanimous}} and returned by at least {{c15::6}} jurors. 1.4 Mixed legal and equitable claims - When a case involves both {{c16::legal}} and {{c17::equitable}} claims, the jury decides the underlying factual issues for the legal (law) claims {{c18::first}}. - Any remaining equitable claims are then decided by the {{c19::judge}}, who is {{c20::bound}} by the jury’s factual findings on the legal issues.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: {{c1::Interrogatories (FRCP 33)}} are {{c2::written questions propounded by one party to an opposing party}}. They are typically used to obtain {{c3::basic factual information}}, especially the {{c4::identity of documents}} and the {{c5::identity of people who may have information related to claims and defenses}}. The responding party must serve answers or objections within {{c6::30 days from service}} (unless the court or a stipulation provides otherwise).

subject: Con Law
cloze: 4. State court decisions and {{c1::adequate and independent state grounds}} 4.1 Bar on review when state law is adequate and independent - The Supreme Court cannot review a state court judgment that rests on an {{c2::independent}} and {{c3::adequate}} state law ground. - "Adequate" means the state law ground {{c4::fully supports the judgment}} by itself. - "Independent" means the state law ground is {{c5::not based on or intertwined with federal law}}. 4.2 Mixed state and federal grounds - If a state court decision is based on both federal and state law, the Supreme Court will not review if the judgment {{c6::can stand on the state law ground alone}}. - The Court will review only if it appears that the state law ground is {{c7::not adequate}} or {{c8::not independent}}, such that the judgment may necessarily depend on {{c9::federal law}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Either party may file a {{c1::motion for a new trial}} if judgment was entered but serious errors occurred at trial. The motion must be filed within {{c2::28 days}} after entry of judgment. 1. {{c3::Grounds for a new trial}} (potential errors include, but are not limited to): 1.1 {{c4::Prejudicial error}}: a serious legal or procedural error that makes the judgment unfair (e.g., the judge {{c5::misstates the law}} or gives {{c6::incorrect jury instructions}}). 1.2 {{c7::Prejudicial misconduct}}: misconduct by a party, attorney, juror, etc. (e.g., the jury considers {{c8::evidence that was excluded}} at trial). 1.3 {{c9::Judgment against the weight of the evidence}}: the jury erred in reaching its verdict given the evidence before it. 1.4 {{c10::Newly discovered evidence}}: important evidence that could not, with {{c11::reasonable diligence}}, have been discovered in time for trial. 1.5 {{c12::Excessive or inadequate damages}}: the court cannot {{c13::increase}} a jury award ({{c14::additur}} violates the Seventh Amendment), but the judge can order a new trial or offer {{c15::remittitur}} if convinced the award is too high. 1.5.1 {{c16::Remittitur}}: if the jury awards an amount that is so high it {{c17::shocks the conscience}}, the court can order a new trial or offer the plaintiff a choice of accepting a {{c18::lesser figure set by the court}} or undergoing a new trial. 2. {{c19::Motion for new trial vs. JMOL or RJMOL}} 2.1 In granting a new trial, the court is not {{c20::directing judgment}} in favor of a party but is instead saying the process should {{c21::restart}} because there was some error necessitating a {{c22::do‑over}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: During {{c1::escrow}} (after a valid {{c2::land sale contract}} but before {{c3::delivery of the deed}}), {{c4::equitable conversion}} treats the {{c5::buyer}} as owning the {{c6::real property}} in equity. The {{c7::seller}} is treated as owning {{c8::personal property}}—the {{c9::right to the sale proceeds}}—and holds {{c10::legal title in trust}} for the buyer. For {{c11::claims or judgments against the seller arising before the contract}}, any judgment is converted into an {{c12::interest in the sale proceeds}} and is {{c13::not enforceable against the real property}}, protecting the buyer.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. UCC {{c1::Article 9}} generally gives parties broad discretion to create their own terms regarding security agreements. Common issues include: 1.1 {{c2::After-acquired property clauses}}: These extend the security interest to property {{c3::acquired by the debtor after signing the security agreement}}. 1.2 {{c4::Future advances}}: 1.2.1 Security agreements may contemplate {{c5::future loans or advances}} from the creditor to the debtor based on the debtor's present collateral or collateral to be acquired in the future. 1.2.2 In such cases, a {{c6::new security agreement is not required}} for each future advance. 1.2.3 For example: L loans $2,000 to D secured by inventory in D's business; the security agreement provides for future advances; D may obtain additional loans in the future from L secured by the same collateral. 1.3 {{c7::Specification clauses}}: 1.3.1 Parties may include clauses specifying terms and creating provisions for {{c8::potential events}}. 1.3.2 For example: parties may define what constitutes a {{c9::default}} or may provide for {{c10::acceleration of payments}} upon the happening of a certain event (e.g., one missed payment).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: The {{c1::answer}} is the {{c2::defendant's responsive pleading}} to the complaint. It must be filed within {{c3::21 days}} after service of process (or {{c4::14 days}} after a ruling on a {{c5::Rule 12 motion}}) and must {{c6::respond to each allegation}} and {{c7::raise any affirmative defenses}} (or risk waiver). The defendant may also assert {{c8::counterclaims}}—both {{c9::compulsory}} and {{c10::permissive}}—in the answer.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Attempt is an {{c1::inchoate offense}} that generally requires {{c2::specific intent}} to commit a crime and an {{c3::overt or substantial step}} beyond mere preparation (often framed as being {{c4::dangerously close}} to completion). Key defenses/limitations: {{c5::legal impossibility is a defense}}, {{c6::factual impossibility is not}}, and {{c7::abandonment is not a defense at common law}} once the {{c8::overt act with specific intent}} has occurred.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Rule: The holder of a {{c1::profit à prendre}} generally has an {{c2::implied easement}} to enter and pass over the servient land as {{c3::reasonably necessary}} to exercise the profit. 2. Profit à prendre and access: 2.1 A profit à prendre is a {{c4::nonpossessory right to enter another’s land and remove natural resources}} (e.g., minerals, timber, game). 2.2 Because the profit would be {{c5::useless without access}}, the law implies an {{c6::easement of access}} as reasonably necessary to locate, reach, and remove the resources. 3. Scope: The implied easement covers only such routes and methods of access as are {{c7::reasonably necessary}} to use the profit and may not {{c8::unreasonably burden}} the servient estate.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Supremacy Clause}}, {{c2::federal laws}} trump conflicting {{c3::state and local laws}}. 1. Express preemption 1.1 If a federal law expressly provides that it is the {{c4::exclusive authority in a given area}}, it preempts state and local laws in that area. 1.2 Express preemption provisions are {{c5::narrowly construed}}. 2. Implied preemption 2.1 If a federal law is silent on preemption, it may still implicitly preempt state law in three situations: 2.1.1 {{c6::Mutual exclusivity}}: Federal and state laws are mutually exclusive, so complying with both is impossible. States may set {{c7::stricter requirements}} if compliance with both federal and state laws is possible. 2.1.2 {{c8::Obstacle preemption}}: State law impedes a federal objective. 2.1.3 {{c9::Field preemption}}: Congress evidences a clear intent to legislate exclusively and/or to preempt state law. Examples include {{c10::immigration}} and {{c11::bankruptcy}} law. 2.2 If a state law does not fall into any of the above three situations, it is likely {{c12::valid under the Supremacy Clause}}. 3. State constitutions 3.1 State constitutions may provide {{c13::broader rights and protections}} than the federal Constitution. 3.2 State constitutions may not provide {{c14::lesser protections that conflict with federal constitutional rights}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Acceptance by Shipment under the UCC 1.1. In a sale of goods, a {{c1::merchant}} may accept an offer to buy goods by: 1.1.1. Providing a {{c2::promise to ship goods}} (often by written confirmation); or 1.1.2. Promptly shipping {{c3::conforming goods}}. 2. Shipment of Nonconforming Goods 2.1. Shipment of {{c4::nonconforming goods}} generally acts as an {{c5::acceptance}} of the offer. 2.2. That shipment also constitutes a {{c6::breach}} of contract. 2.3. Exception – {{c7::Accommodation Shipment}}: 2.3.1. If the seller {{c8::seasonably notifies}} the buyer that the nonconforming shipment is offered only as an {{c9::accommodation}}, 2.3.2. Then the shipment operates as a {{c10::counteroffer}} rather than an acceptance, and there is no breach if the buyer rejects.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Fifth Amendment}} right to counsel ({{c2::Miranda}}) 1.1. {{c3::Not automatic}}: the accused must invoke this right by {{c4::unambiguously requesting}} the presence of counsel during {{c5::custodial interrogation}}. 1.2. {{c6::Not offense-specific}}: once invoked, police must stop questioning on {{c7::all subjects}}. 2. {{c8::Sixth Amendment}} right to counsel 2.1. {{c9::Automatic}}: attaches once {{c10::formal charges have been filed}} and applies at all subsequent {{c11::critical stages}}. 2.2. {{c12::Offense-specific}}: police may still question the defendant about {{c13::other, uncharged crimes}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: An {{c1::arrest}} occurs when police take an individual into {{c2::custody}} for purposes of {{c3::criminal prosecution}} or {{c4::interrogation}}. 1. {{c5::Probable cause}} is always required for any valid arrest. 1.1 Probable cause means {{c6::trustworthy facts or knowledge}} sufficient for a {{c7::reasonable person}} to believe that the suspect has committed or is planning to commit a crime. 2. {{c8::Warrants are rarely required}} for arrests. 2.1 Police generally do not need a warrant before arresting a person in a {{c9::public place}}. 2.2 Exception: {{c10::Non-emergency home arrests}} require an {{c11::arrest warrant}} and {{c12::reasonable belief the suspect is at home}}. 2.3 Police may only {{c13::enter the home}} if they have reason to believe the suspect is in the home. 3. A {{c14::search warrant}} is required for police to execute an arrest of a suspect in a {{c15::third party's home}}. 3.1 A search warrant is not required for an {{c16::emergency (exigent circumstances) arrest}} occurring in the arrestee's own home.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: In contract cases under the {{c1::Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach}}, courts look to: 1. Key Contract Contacts: - The {{c2::place of contracting}}. - The {{c3::place of negotiation}}. - The {{c4::place of performance}}. - The {{c5::location of the subject matter of the contract}}. - The {{c6::domicile, residence, nationality, place of incorporation, and place of business of the parties}}. 2. Default Tendency: - If the {{c7::place of negotiation and the place of performance are the same}}, courts generally apply {{c8::that forum’s law}} as having the most significant relationship.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule for proceeds priority}} 1.1 A {{c2::perfected security interest in proceeds}} generally has the {{c3::same date of priority}} as the security interest in the {{c4::original collateral}} that generated the proceeds. 2. {{c5::Effect of type of original collateral}} 2.1 {{c6::Filing collateral}}: The secured party would normally achieve priority by {{c7::filing a financing statement}} (for example, {{c8::goods, accounts, and general intangibles}}). 2.2 {{c9::Non-filing collateral}}: The secured party would normally achieve priority by {{c10::possession or control, not filing}} (for example, {{c11::cash, chattel paper, negotiable documents, and instruments}}).

subject: Con Law
cloze: A preliminary injunction restricting {{c1::pretrial discussion}} to preserve a fair trial is valid only if it is {{c2::the only way to preserve a fair trial}}. A party must comply with a {{c3::valid injunction}} until it is {{c4::vacated or overturned}}. As a general rule, a party cannot {{c5::collaterally challenge an injunction it has violated}}; the proper course is to seek to have the injunction modified, vacated, or overturned before disobeying it.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Traditional 4-part test for a {{c1::preliminary injunction}} 1.1 {{c2::Irreparable injury}} ({{c3::no adequate remedy at law}}). 1.2 {{c4::Reasonable likelihood of success on the merits}}. 1.3 {{c5::Balance of hardships}} favors granting the injunction. 1.4 {{c6::Public interest}} supports granting the injunction. 2. Procedural notes 2.1 {{c7::Notice and a hearing}} are required for the adverse party. 2.2 Preliminary injunctions are {{c8::appealable}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Impeachment casts an adverse reflection on the {{c1::veracity}} of a witness's testimony. {{c2::Any party}} may impeach {{c3::any witness}}. 1. Methods of impeachment 1.1 {{c4::Contradiction}}. 1.2 {{c5::Prior inconsistent statement}} ({{c6::PIS}}). 1.3 {{c7::Bias or interest}}. 1.4 {{c8::Sensory deficiencies}} (for example, the witness's senses were incapable of producing the perceptions to which the witness testified). 1.5 {{c9::Reputation and/or opinion evidence of untruthfulness}} (admissible to impeach the witness's veracity by use of extrinsic evidence). 1.6 {{c10::Prior acts of misconduct}} bearing on truthfulness. 1.7 {{c11::Prior criminal conviction}}. 1.8 (Subject to specific rules) use of {{c12::extrinsic evidence}}, which may be prohibited on {{c13::collateral matters}}. 2. Evidence supporting witness credibility 2.1 Evidence supporting a witness's credibility is {{c14::inadmissible}} unless the witness's credibility has been {{c15::attacked}} (i.e., the witness has been impeached). 2.2 Exception: the witness's {{c16::prior consistent statement}} is admissible to rehabilitate if the statement was made {{c17::before}} the witness had a {{c18::motive to fabricate}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Strict products liability}} applies when a {{c2::commercial supplier}} provides a {{c3::defective, unreasonably dangerous product}} that {{c4::actually and proximately causes}} injury or property damage to a {{c5::foreseeable user or bystander}} through a {{c6::foreseeable use}}. Overview of elements: 1. {{c7::Commercial supplier}}. 2. {{c8::Defective, unreasonably dangerous product}}. 3. {{c9::Causation without substantial alteration}}. 4. {{c10::Foreseeable use, including foreseeable misuse}}. 5. {{c11::Foreseeable user or bystander with physical injury or property damage (not purely economic loss)}}.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: 2. {{c1::Dissolution}} (termination of the partnership as a going concern) and winding up: 2.1 Dissolution – causes: - Dissolution is the {{c2::termination of the partnership as a going concern}}. - It is caused by the happening of an {{c3::agreed-upon event}}, {{c4::expiration of a term}} in the partnership agreement, {{c5::issuance of a judicial decree}}, or similar events. - In an {{c6::at-will partnership}} (with no specific undertaking or definite term), any partner can cause dissolution at any time by providing {{c7::notice of dissolution}}. 2.2 Winding up – process and distribution: 2.2.1 After dissolution, the partnership must {{c8::cease new business}}, {{c9::wind up existing activities}}, and {{c10::liquidate assets to cash}}. 2.2.2 The partnership continues in existence only for the {{c11::limited purpose of winding up}} until the {{c12::winding-up process is complete}}. 2.2.3 Asset distribution priority: - First, liabilities are paid to {{c13::creditors}}. - Then, any remaining amounts are distributed to {{c14::partners individually}}, typically according to their {{c15::partnership interests}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Acceptance is the offeree’s {{c1::clear expression of assent}} to the terms of the offer, in the manner specified by the {{c2::offeror (master of the offer)}}. At {{c3::common law}}, acceptance must {{c4::mirror the terms of the offer}} (mirror-image rule). Under the {{c5::UCC}}, an acceptance can include {{c6::additional terms}} (with different treatment depending on whether the parties are {{c7::merchants}}), and a {{c8::merchant}} may accept by {{c9::promising to ship}} or {{c10::promptly shipping conforming goods}}; shipment of {{c11::nonconforming goods}} usually operates as an {{c12::acceptance and breach}} unless clearly offered only as an {{c13::accommodation}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: For {{c1::protected speech}}, the threshold question is whether a restriction is {{c2::content-based}} or {{c3::content-neutral}}. 1. {{c4::Content-based restrictions}}: - The government targets speech because of its {{c5::content}}—its {{c6::subject matter}} or {{c7::viewpoint}}. - Reviewed under {{c8::strict scrutiny}}, requiring a {{c9::compelling government interest}} and {{c10::narrow tailoring}}. 2. {{c11::Content-neutral restrictions}}: - Apply to all expression regardless of {{c12::content or viewpoint}}, often as {{c13::time, place, or manner}} regulations. - Reviewed under {{c14::intermediate scrutiny}}, requiring an {{c15::important or significant government interest}}, {{c16::narrow tailoring}}, and {{c17::ample alternative channels}} for communication.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Insecurity}} arises when a party to a {{c2::contract}} has {{c3::reasonable grounds}} to believe the other party will be unwilling or unable to perform under the contract. 1.2 A {{c4::justifiably insecure party}} may demand {{c5::adequate assurances}} that the other party will perform and may {{c6::suspend its own performance}} in the meantime. 1.3 This doctrine arises out of the {{c7::UCC}}, but many states apply it to {{c8::non-UCC contracts}} as well. 2. Demand for adequate assurances 2.1 The demand must be made {{c9::in writing}} and must be based on {{c10::reasonable and justified grounds for insecurity}}. 2.2 No response is required if the demand is {{c11::unjustified or unreasonable}} (i.e., if the party seeking adequate assurances is unreasonably insecure). 2.3 A justifiably insecure party may {{c12::suspend performance until adequate assurances are provided}}. 3. Adequate assurances 3.1 Adequate assurances are a {{c13::commercially reasonable commitment}} (within {{c14::30 days}}) from a party that it will perform under the contract. 3.2 If adequate assurances are not provided within a reasonable time (no more than {{c15::30 days under the UCC}}), the insecure party may treat the contract as {{c16::repudiated}}. 3.3 Failure to respond to an {{c17::unreasonable demand}} is not a repudiation. 3.4 If adequate assurances are provided, the formerly insecure party must perform; failure to do so will constitute a {{c18::breach}}. 4. Insecurity vs. anticipatory repudiation 4.1 Insecurity involves {{c19::uncertainty}} regarding the other party's performance. 4.2 {{c20::Anticipatory repudiation}} involves a {{c21::clear indication}} the other party will not perform.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Larceny is a {{c1::specific intent}} crime. 1. Specific intent to {{c2::permanently dispossess}} the owner - "Permanently" includes keeping the property for an {{c3::unreasonable period of time}}. - The intent must exist {{c4::at the time of the taking}}. - No larceny if the defendant takes property under a {{c5::claim of right}} (believing it is theirs) or merely as {{c6::security for a debt}}. 2. {{c7::Continuing trespass doctrine}} - When an initial taking is {{c8::trespassory}} (without consent), the trespass is treated as continuing. - If the defendant initially borrows property intending to {{c9::return}} it but later decides to {{c10::keep}} it, larceny arises at the moment the {{c11::intent to permanently deprive}} is formed. - This doctrine allows a {{c12::later-formed intent}} to satisfy the intent element of larceny when the original taking was wrongful.

subject: Agency
cloze: Where an agent {{c1::purports to act on behalf of a principal but lacks authority}} to do so, the principal may still be bound by the agent's acts if the principal subsequently {{c2::ratifies}} the acts. 1. {{c3::Requirements}} 1.1 Agent {{c4::purported to act on the principal's behalf}}. For example, the agent entered into a contract with a third party without authority to do so. 1.2 Principal has {{c5::knowledge of material facts}} of the act (such as the contract terms). The principal must know or reasonably should know the material facts when the agent's act is affirmed or ratified. 1.3 Principal {{c6::affirmed (ratified) the agent's conduct}}. 1.3.1 Affirmance can be {{c7::express or implied}} (conduct by the principal consistent with approval of the otherwise unauthorized act). 1.3.2 If the principal {{c8::accepts the benefits}} of the agent's act when it is still possible to decline, the principal will be deemed to have ratified the agent's act. 2. {{c9::Effect of ratification}} 2.1 A principal who ratifies an agent's unauthorized act becomes {{c10::liable to third parties}} for those acts. For example, if a principal ratifies a contract the agent entered into without authority, the principal is bound to the contract and can be held liable to the third party.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Congress’s {{c1::taxing and spending power}} is very broad. Congress may {{c2::tax and spend}} in any way it deems necessary to provide for the {{c3::general welfare}}, and on bar exam questions this is usually the correct basis for federal authority when the law involves {{c4::taxation}}, {{c5::spending}}, or Congress’s limited {{c6::police power}} areas (the {{c7::military}}, {{c8::Indian reservations}}, {{c9::federal land}}, and the {{c10::District of Columbia}}). Within this power, Congress may: - Impose {{c11::taxes}} that need only {{c12::reasonably relate to raising revenue}} (a low threshold), and measures labeled as {{c13::penalties}} can be upheld as {{c14::taxes}} if they {{c15::function like taxes}}; and - Use {{c16::taxes and spending as regulatory tools}}, through {{c17::regulatory taxes}} (where {{c18::raising revenue}} remains the {{c19::dominant purpose}} and there is a {{c20::reasonable relationship}} to the regulation) and {{c21::regulatory spending}} (attaching {{c22::non-coercive conditions}} to federal funds to influence behavior).

subject: Torts
cloze: Constitutional Considerations 1. General Rule 1.1 {{c1::First Amendment}} considerations arise when defamation involves a {{c2::public figure}}, {{c3::public official}}, and/or a {{c4::matter of public concern}}. 2. Public Figures and Public Officials 2.1 {{c5::Public figure}}: A person who has {{c6::pervasive fame or notoriety}}, or who {{c7::voluntarily assumes a central role in a public matter}}. 2.2 {{c8::Public official}}: A {{c9::public office holder}}. 3. Additional Elements: Fault 3.1 The plaintiff must prove that the defendant was at {{c10::fault}}, with standards differing for public versus private figures. 3.2 {{c11::Public official or public figure}}: The plaintiff must prove {{c12::"actual malice"}}, meaning {{c13::knowledge of the statement's falsity}} or {{c14::reckless disregard}} as to whether it was false. 3.3 {{c15::Private figure}}: The minimum constitutional standard is {{c16::negligence}} with respect to truth or falsity. 4. Falsity 4.1 {{c17::Public officials and public figures}} must {{c18::prove falsity}}. 4.2 {{c19::Private figures}} must prove falsity only if the speech pertains to a {{c20::matter of public concern}}. 4.3 If the plaintiff is a {{c21::private figure}} and the speech is a {{c22::matter of purely private concern}}, states may place the burden on the {{c23::defendant to prove truth}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A remainder is {{c1::contingent}} if it is either: 1.1.1 Subject to a {{c2::condition precedent}}; or 1.1.2 Created in favor of an {{c3::unascertained or unborn person}}. 2. Remainder subject to a condition precedent 2.1 The remainderman’s taking is contingent on the prior occurrence of some {{c4::event or condition}}. 2.2 Once the event or condition occurs, the interest automatically becomes an {{c5::indefeasibly vested remainder}}. 2.3 Example: If B is unmarried at the time of the conveyance, A has a {{c6::life estate}}, B has a {{c7::contingent remainder}} (because marriage is a condition precedent), and the grantor has a {{c8::reversion}} in case B is not married when A dies. If B gets married during A’s life, B has an {{c9::indefeasibly vested remainder}}. 3. Remainder in unborn or unascertained persons 3.1 A remainder created in favor of {{c10::unborn or unascertained persons}} is contingent. 3.2 The remainder is contingent on the grantee being {{c11::born or ascertained}}. 3.3 Example: If B is alive, a remainder to the {{c12::heirs of B}} is contingent because the heirs of B cannot be {{c13::ascertained until B dies}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: Jurisdiction over {{c1::marriage-related actions}} is vested in {{c2::state courts}}. 1. {{c3::Annulment}}: Jurisdiction is typically proper in any state in which either spouse is {{c4::domiciled}}, and in most states also in the state where the {{c5::marriage was entered into and recognized}}. 2. {{c6::Divorce}}: Subject-matter jurisdiction is generally based on {{c7::domicile}} of one or both spouses in the forum, sometimes coupled with a {{c8::durational residency}} requirement to limit {{c9::forum shopping}}. Sister states must recognize a valid divorce decree under the {{c10::Full Faith and Credit Clause}} if the rendering state had proper {{c11::domicile-based jurisdiction}}. 3. {{c12::Status vs. property/support}}: A court can adjudicate {{c13::marital status}} based on domicile alone, but it may not determine rights in {{c14::out-of-state property}} or enter binding {{c15::support orders}} unless it has {{c16::personal jurisdiction over both spouses}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Protective orders}} 1.1 Definition: A protective order is a {{c2::court order limiting discovery of material}}. 1.2 Purpose: Sought by a party seeking to prevent or restrict disclosure, usually to prevent disclosure of material that is {{c3::privileged, highly embarrassing, a trade secret, and/or clearly outside the scope of appropriate discovery}}. 1.3 Meet-and-confer requirement: The moving party must certify that they have, in {{c4::good faith}}, {{c5::conferred or attempted to confer}} with affected parties to resolve the dispute without court action. 1.4 Standard: The court may issue a protective order for {{c6::good cause}}. 1.5 Possible terms: The order can {{c7::limit, condition, delay, or bar discovery}} of the affected information. 2. {{c8::Motion to compel}} 2.1 Definition: A motion to compel is a motion asking the court to {{c9::order disclosure or discovery of requested material}}. 2.2 Typical use: Often arises when the {{c10::discoveree (the party holding information)}} refuses to produce materials or claims the materials are {{c11::privileged}}. 2.3 Certification: The motion must certify that the moving party has made a {{c12::good faith attempt to obtain discovery without court intervention}}. 2.4 Procedure and decision: The judge will {{c13::hold a hearing or otherwise confer with the parties}} regarding the dispute and then {{c14::decide whether the material must be produced or may be withheld}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. General rule: An {{c1::adoption}} terminates the {{c2::legal relationship between biological parents and their child}} (if not already terminated) and establishes a new {{c3::legal parent-child relationship}} between the {{c4::adoptive parent}} and child. 2. Process: 2.1. {{c5::Consent of both biological parents}} is generally required. 2.2. An {{c6::unwed father's}} consent may not be necessary if he has not {{c7::assumed parental responsibility}}. 2.3. But an unwed father considered {{c8::fit to be a parent}} has a {{c9::constitutional right}} to have an {{c10::opportunity to develop a quality relationship}} with his infant child. 2.4. Consent of the {{c11::adoptee}} may be required for prospective adoptees over a certain age (usually {{c12::12 or older}}, depending on state law). 3. Withdrawal of biological parent consent: 3.1. Withdrawal is {{c13::not allowed after}} the adoption is finalized. 3.2. Before an adoption decree is entered, withdrawal may be allowed if the court determines it is in the adoptee's {{c14::best interests}}. 4. Payment prohibited: 4.1. Most states prohibit adopting parents from paying money to biological parents beyond {{c15::pregnancy-related medical expenses}} (i.e., it is illegal to {{c16::buy and sell children}}).

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. New debtor in different state 1.1 This issue arises when a {{c1::new debtor}} located in a {{c2::different state}} becomes bound by another person’s security agreement. 1.2 If collateral is transferred to a new debtor in a different state, a security interest perfected under the law of the original debtor’s state remains perfected until {{c3::one year after the sale or transfer of the collateral}} or until {{c4::perfection in the original state lapses}}, whichever occurs first.

subject: Contracts
cloze: In non-carrier UCC sales, risk of loss depends on whether the seller is a {{c1::merchant}}. If the seller is a {{c2::merchant}}, risk of loss passes to the buyer when the buyer {{c3::takes physical possession}} of the goods. If the seller is a {{c4::non-merchant}}, risk of loss passes to the buyer upon {{c5::tender of delivery}}—when the seller {{c6::makes the goods available to the buyer}}.

subject: Agency
cloze: In the absence of anything to the contrary in their agreement, the principal owes the agent duties of {{c1::compensation}}, {{c2::reimbursement and indemnification}}, and {{c3::cooperation}}. 1. {{c4::Compensation}}: unless the agent agrees to act gratuitously, the principal owes the agent a duty to compensate him reasonably. 2. {{c5::Reimbursement and indemnification}}: the principal must reimburse and indemnify the agent for all {{c6::expenses and losses reasonably incurred}} in carrying out the agent's duties, including {{c7::legal liability}} incurred by the agent. 3. {{c8::Cooperation}}: the principal must cooperate with the agent to help the agent carry out agency functions.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under {{c1::Rule 12(c)}}, either {{c2::the plaintiff or the defendant}} may move for {{c3::judgment on the pleadings}}. The motion is proper when the {{c4::pleadings (typically the complaint and the answer)}} show that {{c5::one party must prevail as a matter of law}}. Example: If the {{c6::defendant's answer admits all allegations}} in the plaintiff's complaint, the {{c7::plaintiff}} must win as a matter of law and may obtain judgment on the pleadings.

subject: Con Law
cloze: {{c1::Freedom of association}} protects the right to participate in a {{c2::gathering, club, or organization}} to pursue {{c3::First Amendment–protected goals}} (e.g., political advocacy). Government interference with this right usually triggers {{c4::strict scrutiny}} and is valid only if: 1. The government acts to further a {{c5::compelling governmental interest}}; and 2. That interest cannot be achieved by {{c6::less restrictive means}}. This analysis is largely analogous to {{c7::strict scrutiny}} applied to other fundamental rights.

subject: Torts
cloze: Overview of negligence defenses affecting damages or barring recovery: 1. {{c1::Comparative negligence}} reduces, rather than completely bars, recovery by assigning percentages of fault and reducing plaintiff’s damages by his share. 2. {{c2::Contributory negligence}} in some jurisdictions bars recovery entirely for any contributing negligence by the plaintiff, subject to the {{c3::last clear chance}} doctrine. 3. {{c4::Assumption of risk}}, including {{c5::express assumption of risk}}, applies when the plaintiff knowingly and voluntarily faces a specific risk and thereby may bar or limit recovery; these defenses generally do {{c6::not apply to intentional torts}}, though a plaintiff can consent to them.

subject: Torts
cloze: In {{c1::bystander}} negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED), a plaintiff {{c2::outside the zone of danger}} may recover for emotional distress from injury to another if: 1. The plaintiff and the injured person are {{c3::closely related}}. 2. The plaintiff is {{c4::present at the scene}} of the injury. 3. The plaintiff {{c5::personally observes or perceives}} the event as it happens.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::Contract Clause}} limits state interference with existing contracts. 1. Basic prohibition 1.1. States cannot {{c2::substantially impair}} {{c3::existing contractual duties}}. 2. Who is bound 2.1. The Contract Clause applies only to {{c4::state or local}} interference with contracts. 2.2. It does {{c5::not}} apply to the {{c6::federal government}}. 3. What contracts are covered 3.1. The Clause covers interference with {{c3::existing}} contractual obligations, not {{c7::future}} contracts. 3.2. It includes both: - {{c8::Private contracts}} (between private parties); and - {{c9::Government contracts}} (where the state or local government is a party). 4. Different scrutiny levels 4.1. Different levels of scrutiny apply depending on whether the state is interfering with {{c8::private contracts}} or its own {{c9::government contracts}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Definition and limitations 1.1 A {{c1::vested remainder}} is a future interest in a transferee that automatically becomes {{c2::possessory upon the natural expiration of the preceding estate}}. 1.2 By definition, a vested remainder cannot: 1.2.1 Be subject to any {{c3::condition precedent}}; or 1.2.2 Vest in an {{c4::unknown or unascertained person}}. 2. Types of vested remainders 2.1 {{c5::Indefeasibly vested remainder}}: certain to become possessory upon termination of the prior estate. 2.2 {{c6::Vested remainder subject to total divestment}}: vested but subject to a {{c7::condition subsequent}} that can cut off the interest after it becomes possessory. 2.3 {{c8::Vested remainder subject to open}} ({{c9::class gift}}): vested in a described {{c10::class of takers}}, at least one of whom is capable of taking, but the class can {{c11::expand as more qualifying members are born}}. 3. Class gifts and closing 3.1 A class remains {{c12::open}} while new members can be created and {{c13::closes}} when no new members can be added. 3.2 Under the {{c14::Rule of Convenience}}, the class closes whenever any member can {{c15::demand distribution}}; {{c16::after-born class members take nothing}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Congress has {{c1::broad authority to delegate legislative powers}} to executive officers and administrative agencies via enabling statutes, and agency rules can have the {{c2::force and effect of law}}. 1. Scope of delegation 1.1 Congress may authorize agencies to {{c3::fill in statutory details, make policy choices within a framework, and promulgate rules with the force of law}}. 1.2 Courts {{c4::rarely invalidate}} delegations on nondelegation grounds. 2. Limitations on delegation 2.1 Congress must provide {{c5::intelligible standards}} to define and guide the scope of delegated authority. 2.2 Congress may not {{c6::delegate executive or judicial enforcement powers to itself or its own officers}} (e.g., by creating congressional commissions that enforce or prosecute law while under congressional control). 2.3 On exams, because delegation doctrine is {{c7::very broad and deferential}}, answer choices resting on {{c8::“excessive delegation”}} are usually wrong.

subject: Corporations
cloze: A {{c1::promoter}} acts on behalf of a {{c2::not-yet-formed corporation}} to obtain {{c3::capital commitments (funding)}}, usually by forming {{c4::contracts with parties interested in becoming shareholders upon incorporation}}. Promoters also work on {{c5::corporate planning and formation}} and often become {{c6::incorporators}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: An offer is an {{c1::objective manifestation of a present intent to contract}} such that a {{c2::reasonable offeree}} would believe the communication {{c3::invites acceptance}}. It requires {{c4::definite and certain terms}} and {{c5::communication to an identified offeree}}. Under {{c6::UCC Article 2}}, the key requirement is a certain or {{c7::ascertainable quantity term}}, while many other terms (including {{c8::price}}) may be left open if the parties {{c9::intended to contract}} and there is a {{c10::reasonably certain basis for a remedy}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Fairness in personal jurisdiction first looks at the {{c1::relatedness}} between the defendant’s contacts with the forum and the plaintiff’s claim. 1. Relatedness of contacts and claim • Question: Does the plaintiff’s claim {{c2::arise from or relate to}} the defendant’s contacts with the forum state? 2. {{c3::Specific jurisdiction}} • Definition: Exists when the plaintiff’s claim {{c4::arises from or relates to the defendant’s in-state contacts}}. • Minimum contacts: Only {{c5::minimum contacts}} with the forum need to be established. • Scope: The defendant can only be sued in that forum for claims {{c6::arising from those in-state contacts}}. 3. {{c7::General jurisdiction}} • Definition: Appropriate when the plaintiff’s claim {{c8::does not arise from the defendant’s in-state contacts}}, but the defendant’s contacts with the forum are so substantial that it is {{c9::essentially at home}} there. • Contacts: The defendant must have {{c10::systematic and continuous}} contacts with the forum state. • "At home" examples (for a corporation): The {{c11::place of incorporation}} or the {{c12::principal place of business}} in the forum state. • Scope: If general jurisdiction is found, the defendant can be sued in that forum for {{c13::any claim, whether arising in or outside of the forum}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General Rule 1.1 {{c1::Necessity}} is a defense to {{c2::torts against property}} ({{c3::trespass to land, trespass to chattels, conversion}}) when the defendant damages the plaintiff's property in an effort to avoid a greater danger. 1.2 Requirements: 1.2.1 The defendant's interference with the plaintiff's property must be {{c4::reasonably necessary}} to avoid an {{c5::immediate threatened injury}}. 1.2.2 The {{c6::threatened injury}} must be more serious than the interference undertaken to avert it. 2. Public Necessity 2.1 {{c7::Public necessity}} is an {{c8::absolute defense}}. 2.2 The defendant's invasion of the plaintiff's property must be reasonably necessary to protect the {{c9::community or a large group of people}}. 2.3 Because it is an absolute defense, the plaintiff {{c10::cannot recover any damages}}. 3. Private Necessity 3.1 {{c11::Private necessity}} is a {{c12::limited defense}}. 3.2 The defendant invades the plaintiff's property to protect the defendant's {{c13::own property, self, or a small group}}. 3.3 Because it is a limited defense, the plaintiff can recover {{c14::damages for actual harm}} to the plaintiff's property, unless the defendant trespassed {{c15::for the plaintiff's benefit}}. 4. Property Owner Liability 4.1 If a property owner repels or expels a trespasser who interfered with or invaded the owner's property out of a valid necessity (for example, the trespasser seeks shelter from a terrible storm), 4.2 The owner will be {{c16::liable for any damage caused}} to the trespasser.

subject: Agency
cloze: Even when an agent lacks {{c1::actual authority}}, the principal can be held liable for the agent's acts if the agent acted with {{c2::apparent authority}}. The agent's acts will be binding on the principal if a {{c3::third party}} can show that the agent acted with apparent authority.
