If a third party {{c4::knows the agent lacks actual authority}}, apparent authority does not exist. 1. {{c5::Requirements}} (agent acts with apparent authority if): 1.1 The principal {{c6::holds the agent out as having authority}} to act on the principal's behalf; and 1.2 The principal's conduct causes a third party to {{c7::reasonably rely}} on the agent's appearance of authority. 2. {{c8::Principal's manifestation required}} 2.1 The principal must {{c9::affirmatively act or fail to act}} in a way that causes the third party's reasonable belief; a mere {{c10::assertion of authority by the agent}} is insufficient to bind the principal. 2.2 {{c11::Affirmative act}}: words or conduct by the principal that cause the third party's reasonable belief in the agent's authority. 2.3 {{c12::Inaction}}: inaction by the principal, where a duty to act exists, that causes the third party's reasonable belief in the agent's authority (for example, where the principal knows the third party wrongly believes the agent has authority to act, the principal has a duty to correct). 3. {{c13::Comparison to actual authority}} 3.1 Apparent authority: based on the principal's words or conduct, the {{c14::reasonable third party}} believes that the agent is authorized. 3.2 Actual authority: based on the principal's words or conduct, the {{c15::reasonable agent}} believes that he is authorized.

subject: Agency
cloze: Principals are generally not liable for acts committed by {{c1::independent contractors}} because their work is outside the scope of an {{c2::employment/servant-type agency relationship}}. 1. Distinguishing independent contractors from an employment/servant relationship: 1.1. The distinction turns on the principal/employer's right to {{c3::control the manner and method by which a person performs their job}}. 1.2. {{c4::Employment relationship}}: the employee is compensated on a time basis (e.g., per hour, per year, etc.), and the employer has a right to control the manner and method by which the employee performs the job. 1.3. {{c5::Independent-contractor relationship}}: the independent contractor is hired to do a particular job, is paid a given amount for that particular job, and the principal has {{c6::limited rights to control the manner and method}} in which the independent contractor performs. 2. Principal's liability for independent-contractor acts: 2.1. {{c7::Public policy}} dictates that principals should be liable for certain torts committed by independent contractors. 2.2. Principals can be held liable for independent-contractor torts where: 2.2.1. The contractor is performing {{c8::inherently dangerous activities}} (acts performed by the independent contractor that are, by nature, inherently dangerous); or 2.2.2. The principal {{c9::knowingly hires an incompetent independent contractor}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: As a {{c1::general rule}}, the {{c2::corporation has no liability}} on {{c3::pre-incorporation contracts}} entered into by promoters, because it {{c4::did not exist}} when the contracts were made. The corporation becomes liable if it {{c5::adopts}} the contract: - {{c6::Express adoption}} occurs when the corporation formally approves the contract, such as by {{c7::board resolution}}. - {{c8::Implied adoption}} occurs when the corporation {{c9::accepts or retains the benefits}} of the contract with knowledge of its terms. {{c10::Adoption}} makes the {{c11::corporation liable}} on the contract, but it {{c12::does not by itself release the promoter}} from personal liability; a {{c13::novation}} is still required to cut off promoter liability.

subject: Evidence
cloze: In civil and criminal cases, specific instances of the defendant's {{c1::bad conduct}} are generally inadmissible to prove {{c2::character}} (i.e., action in conformity with that character), but are admissible if {{c3::independently relevant}}. In other words, prior bad acts are inadmissible unless the acts are relevant to an issue other than the defendant's character or criminal disposition. 1. Common non-character uses of prior acts ({{c4::MIMIC}}) 1.1 {{c5::Motive}}. 1.2 {{c6::Intent}}. 1.3 {{c7::Mistake or absence of mistake}}, including {{c8::knowledge}}. 1.4 {{c9::Identity}}, where the prior act is extremely similar or unique. 1.5 {{c10::Common plan or scheme}}. 2. {{c11::Sexual assault or molestation cases}} 2.1 In cases involving charges of sexual assault or child molestation, evidence of the defendant's prior acts of sexual assault or molestation is {{c12::admissible to show propensity}}, subject to other rules of evidence. 3. {{c13::Balancing}} 3.1 Prior acts evidence is always subject to {{c14::Federal Rule of Evidence 403}} balancing ({{c15::probative value}} versus danger of {{c16::unfair prejudice}}).

subject: Real Property
cloze: Ameliorative waste consists of {{c1::life tenant acts that materially change the property but economically benefit the land}}. Under the {{c2::common law rule}}, ameliorative waste was generally {{c3::prohibited}}, and a life tenant could not substantially alter the property even if the change {{c4::increased its market value}}. In {{c5::most modern jurisdictions}}, ameliorative waste is usually {{c6::permitted}}, especially where {{c7::neighborhood conditions have changed}} and the alteration {{c8::increases the property's value}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Religion is protected under both the {{c1::Free Exercise Clause}} and the {{c2::Establishment Clause}} of the {{c3::First Amendment}}. 1. {{c4::Free Exercise Clause – Overview}}: - Prohibits government from punishing people solely because of their {{c5::religious beliefs or religiously motivated conduct}}. - Laws that {{c6::target religious practice or beliefs}} face {{c7::strict scrutiny}} (must be {{c8::necessary to achieve a compelling interest}}). - {{c9::Neutral laws of general applicability}} are generally valid even if they {{c10::incidentally burden religion}}. 2. {{c11::Establishment Clause – Overview}}: - Prohibits government from {{c12::establishing or sponsoring religion}} or {{c13::preferring one religion over another}}. - Traditional {{c14::Lemon test}}: secular purpose, primary effect neither advances nor inhibits religion, and no excessive entanglement. - Government generally may not {{c15::delegate powers to religious institutions}}, and {{c16::school-sponsored prayer}} in {{c17::public schools}} is generally invalid.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A person who has {{c1::testamentary capacity}} to make a valid will can revoke a will at any time before their death. 1. Revocation by {{c2::written instrument}}: a will or any part of it can be revoked or changed as long as there is: 1.1 {{c3::Intent}}: present intent to revoke. 1.2 {{c4::Formalities}}: the instrument revoking the will is made with the same formalities required for will execution. 2. Revocation by {{c5::physical act}}: a will may be revoked in most states by burning, tearing, or otherwise destroying the will. 2.1 {{c6::Present intent}} required: the testator must intend to revoke at the time of the physical act. 2.2 Act by another ({{c7::revocation by proxy}}): a person other than the testator may revoke the will by physical act if done at the testator's {{c8::direction}} and in the testator's {{c9::presence}}. 3. {{c10::Partial revocation}}: 3.1 Revocation may be accomplished by making {{c11::marks of cancellation}} on the will (e.g., crossing out provisions) in most states. 3.2 Where such marks are found on a will known to have last been in the testator's possession, a {{c12::presumption}} is created that the marks were made by the testator with the requisite intent to revoke.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Limits on amount of bail 1.1 Bail cannot be higher than necessary to ensure that the defendant will {{c1::appear at trial}}. 2. Detention without bail 2.1 {{c2::Detention without bail is constitutional}}. 2.2 However, a decision to refuse bail is {{c3::immediately appealable}}. 3. Due process limits 3.1 {{c4::Arbitrary denial of bail}} violates {{c5::due process}}. 4. Grounds for denying bail 4.1 To justify denial of bail, the government must show either: 4.1.1 The defendant poses a {{c6::flight risk}}, or 4.1.2 The defendant poses a {{c7::danger to the community}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Search incident to a lawful arrest ({{c1::SILA}}) is a categorical exception to the warrant requirement that permits officers, following a {{c2::lawful arrest}}, to search the {{c3::arrestee}} and certain areas and items closely associated with the arrest for weapons and destructible evidence. Core SILA covers the arrestee’s person and the area within his {{c4::immediate control}} and must be {{c5::contemporaneous}} with the arrest. Related doctrines include: (1) limited {{c6::protective sweeps}} of adjoining areas when officers reasonably believe there is danger or accomplices; (2) {{c7::inventory searches}} of the arrestee’s belongings or impounded property when jailing, if done under standardized procedures; (3) {{c8::vehicle searches incident to arrest}}, limited to the passenger compartment when the arrestee is unsecured or officers reasonably believe evidence of the offense of arrest is inside, but not the trunk without probable cause or consent; and (4) special rules for certain items, such as warrantless {{c9::breathalyzer}} tests after a probable-cause DUI arrest and the requirement of a {{c10::warrant}} to search digital information on seized {{c11::cell phones}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Misunderstanding}} occurs when an {{c2::ambiguous term}} is reasonably given {{c3::different meanings}} by the parties. If neither or both know of the ambiguity, there is generally {{c4::no contract}} as to that term; if only one knows, the contract is construed in favor of the {{c5::innocent party’s}} reasonable meaning. 2. {{c6::Mistake}} is a belief not in accord with the facts at the time of contracting. - {{c7::Mutual mistake}}: Both parties are mistaken about a {{c8::basic assumption}} that {{c9::materially affects}} the exchange, and the adversely affected party did not {{c10::bear the risk}}. The contract is usually {{c11::voidable}} by that party. - {{c12::Unilateral mistake}}: Only one party is mistaken. Relief is generally denied unless the non-mistaken party {{c13::knew or should have known}} of the mistake or enforcement would be {{c14::unconscionable}}, and the mistaken party did not bear the risk; then the contract may be {{c15::rescinded or reformed}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 3. {{c1::Mistaken omission or misstatement of intent}} 3.1 {{c2::General rule}}: Courts provide {{c3::no relief}} and admit {{c4::no extrinsic evidence}} just to show that a will {{c5::omitted a provision}} or contains terms that {{c6::do not reflect the testator’s actual intent}}. 3.2 Relief may be available only if there is a {{c7::separate ground for contesting the will}} (e.g., {{c8::fraud}}, {{c9::undue influence}}, {{c10::duress}}, or lack of capacity), in which case extrinsic evidence may be considered for that purpose.

subject: Corporations
cloze: A {{c1::subscription agreement}} is an agreement whereby a person agrees to {{c2::buy a specified number of shares}} from a corporation at a {{c3::given price}}. Subscription agreements typically arise in connection with {{c4::formation}} or {{c5::early-stage financing}} of the corporation.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. {{c1::Disclaimers}} 1.1. A person may {{c2::disclaim an interest}} that otherwise would pass to them from a decedent or the decedent's estate. 1.2. Requirements ({{c3::federal tax}} purposes) 1.2.1. The disclaimer must be {{c4::in writing}}. 1.2.2. The disclaimer must be {{c5::irrevocable}}. 1.2.3. The disclaimer must be {{c6::filed within nine months}} of the decedent's death. 1.2.4. States may impose additional requirements, although most are satisfied by compliance with the federal requirements. 1.3. Effect 1.3.1. The disclaimed interest passes as if the {{c7::disclaiming party predeceased the decedent}}. 2. {{c8::Advancements}} 2.1. Advancements are {{c9::lifetime gifts}} made with the intent that the gift be applied against any share the heir or beneficiary inherits from the decedent's or testator's estate. 2.2. {{c10::Common law}} 2.2.1. Gifts were {{c11::automatically deducted}} from the beneficiary's or heir's remaining interest. 2.3. {{c12::Modern requirement}} 2.3.1. In most states, a gift is treated as an advancement only if either: 2.3.1.1. The decedent declared her intent to make the gift an advancement in a {{c13::contemporaneous writing}}; or 2.3.1.2. The beneficiary or heir {{c14::acknowledged in writing}} that the gift is an advancement. 3. Applicability beyond intestacy 3.1. The above rules generally apply to gifts or interests that pass in forms beyond intestacy, such as {{c15::by will}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Evidence of a witness's (W's) {{c1::bias}}, prior {{c2::misconduct}}, or {{c3::reputation for untruthfulness}} may be used to impeach W. 1. Impeachment by establishing {{c1::bias}}. 1.1 Bias may be established through {{c4::cross-examination}} or {{c5::extrinsic evidence}}. 1.2 {{c6::Foundation requirement}}: W must be questioned on cross-examination regarding the facts that show bias or interest so that W has an {{c7::opportunity to explain or deny}}. 2. Impeachment by prior instances of {{c2::misconduct}}. 2.1 W may be questioned on cross-examination about any prior misconduct that is {{c8::probative of truthfulness}} (i.e., lying or deceit). 2.2 An {{c9::arrest}} alone is not misconduct; there must be an act of {{c10::lying or deceit}}. 2.3 {{c11::No extrinsic evidence}} is permitted: W may only be asked about prior misconduct, and the questioning attorney must {{c12::accept W's answer}}. 3. Impeachment based on {{c3::opinion or reputation for untruthfulness}}. 3.1 W may be impeached by testimony describing W's {{c13::reputation for untruthfulness}} in the community or by {{c14::opinion testimony}} about W's untruthful character.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Website}}: {{c2::Interactive sites}} are more likely to have the requisite {{c3::minimum contacts}}; {{c4::passive sites}} are less likely. 1.1. {{c5::Interactive}}: {{c6::Two-way communication between user and operator}} (e.g., information exchanged for the purpose of {{c7::soliciting business}}; {{c8::purchases allowed}}). 1.2. {{c9::Passive}}: Site makes information available to interested viewers, but {{c10::no business is transacted}}. 2. {{c11::Putting goods into the stream of commerce}}: Manufacturers may be held liable if they could {{c12::reasonably expect consumers to purchase their products in the forum state}}. {{c13::Mere awareness that component parts may reach the forum as part of another product is insufficient}}. 3. {{c14::Targeting the forum state}}: The Supreme Court has increasingly equated {{c15::minimum contacts}} with {{c16::targeting of the forum state}}. This requires some {{c17::deliberate activity within, and cultivation of, the state}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Government may regulate {{c1::commercial speech}} under standards similar to {{c2::intermediate scrutiny}}. 1. {{c3::Unprotected commercial speech}}: 1.1 Commercial speech is not protected if it is either: 1.1.1 {{c4::False, misleading, or deceptive}}; or 1.1.2 {{c5::Illegal or concerns illegal activity}}. 1.2 The government may freely regulate unprotected commercial speech. 2. {{c6::Protected commercial speech}}: 2.1 Protected commercial speech is speech that concerns {{c7::lawful activity}} and is {{c8::not misleading}}. 2.2 The government can regulate protected commercial speech only if all of the following are met: 2.2.1 There is a {{c9::substantial government interest}} in regulating the speech; 2.2.2 The regulation {{c10::directly advances}} that government interest; and 2.2.3 The regulation is {{c11::not more extensive than necessary}} to serve that government interest. 2.3 A valid commercial speech regulation must be {{c12::narrowly tailored}}, but it need not be the {{c13::least restrictive alternative}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Equitable Right of Redemption}} 1.1 At any time {{c2::prior to a judicial foreclosure sale}}, the {{c3::mortgagor}} has an equitable right to {{c4::redeem}} the property. 1.2 To redeem, the mortgagor must {{c5::pay the amount due}} (typically full debt plus interest and costs). 2. {{c6::Equitable Mortgages and Redemption}} 2.1 An {{c7::equitable mortgage}} arises when the creditor appears to hold {{c8::legal title via a deed}}, but the transaction is in substance a {{c9::secured loan}}. 2.2 In such situations, the mortgagor still retains the {{c10::equitable right of redemption}} before foreclosure. 3. {{c11::Statutory Right of Redemption}} 3.1 In some jurisdictions, the mortgagor is given an additional {{c12::statutory right of redemption}} {{c13::after the foreclosure sale}}. 3.2 This statutory right allows the mortgagor, for a specified {{c14::post-sale period}}, to {{c15::buy back the property}}, typically by paying the {{c16::foreclosure sale price}} or other statutory amount. 3.3 The statutory right exists only where {{c17::provided by statute}} and can extend the mortgagor’s ability to recover the property beyond the sale date.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Accomplice liability attaches when a person {{c1::intentionally aids, counsels, or encourages}} a principal {{c2::before or during}} the crime, and is liable for the target crime and other {{c3::probable or foreseeable}} crimes. It is limited by defenses such as {{c4::effective withdrawal}} and statutory exceptions, and it is distinct from {{c5::accessory after the fact}}, which punishes help given {{c6::after}} the crime to a {{c7::known felon}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. Intentional misrepresentation ({{c1::fraud, deceit}}) 1.1 Elements 1.1.1 D {{c2::misrepresents a past or present material fact}}. 1.1.2 D {{c3::knows or believes the misrepresentation is false}}. 1.1.3 D {{c4::intends to induce P to act or refrain from acting}} in reliance on the misrepresentation. 1.1.4 {{c5::Actual reliance}} by P (causation: P must actually rely on the misrepresentation). 1.1.5 {{c6::Justifiable reliance}} by P (P must be justified in relying on the misrepresentation). 1.1.6 {{c7::Damages}}: P must suffer {{c8::monetary loss}}. 2. Negligent misrepresentation 2.1 Elements 2.1.1 D misrepresents a past or present material fact in a {{c9::business or professional setting}}. 2.1.2 {{c10::Breach of a duty of care}} owed to a particular P (that is, D knew P could rely on the misrepresentation). 2.1.3 {{c11::Actual and justifiable reliance}} by P. 2.1.4 {{c12::Damages}}: P must suffer {{c13::monetary loss}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Shareholders influence and monitor the corporation through two main mechanisms: 1. {{c1::Governance authority}}: shareholders exert control over the corporation by {{c2::electing and removing directors}}, {{c3::adopting, amending, or repealing bylaws}}, and {{c4::approving fundamental changes}} to the corporate structure (such as {{c5::mergers}}, {{c6::sales of assets outside the ordinary course of business}}, and {{c7::dissolution}}). 2. {{c8::Inspection rights}}: shareholders have statutory rights to inspect the corporation's books and records. They may inspect for any {{c9::proper purpose}}—one {{c10::reasonably related to their interest as shareholders}}—upon timely written notice stating that purpose, and they may inspect certain {{c11::core records}} even without showing a proper purpose.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Duty to {{c1::pay rent}}: 1.1 The tenant must pay rent as {{c2::agreed in the lease}}. 1.2 If the tenant fails to pay rent and wrongfully holds over, a {{c3::tenancy at sufferance}} arises. 2. Duty not to use for {{c4::illegal purposes}}: 2.1 The tenant must not use the premises for illegal purposes, such as ongoing criminal enterprises. 2.2 For illegal use, the landlord may {{c5::terminate the lease}} or seek {{c6::damages and injunctive relief}}. 2.3 {{c7::Occasional, minor illegal activities}} usually do not amount to a material breach justifying termination.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::General baseline rule}} 1.1 The {{c2::11th Amendment}} and the related doctrine of {{c3::sovereign immunity}} bar suits against {{c4::state governments}} in {{c5::federal court}}. 1.2 Under the 11th Amendment, federal courts cannot hear claims from a {{c6::private party}} or {{c7::foreign government}} against a state government. 1.3 Sovereign immunity also generally bars suits against states in {{c8::state court}}. Scope - Applies to suits where the {{c9::state is the defendant}} and would be liable from the {{c10::state treasury}}. - Applies to suits by {{c11::citizens of that state}}, {{c12::citizens of other states}}, and {{c13::foreign citizens or governments}}, unless an exception applies.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Under the {{c1::UCC}}, {{c2::risk of loss}} rules determine which party bears the loss when goods are lost or destroyed before the buyer has fully taken responsibility. The main categories are: {{c3::shipment vs. destination contracts}}, {{c4::merchant vs. non-merchant sellers in non-carrier cases}}, {{c5::FOB (Free On Board) terms and the named location}}, and {{c6::effects of destruction before risk passes and breach (rejection/revocation)}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: {{c1::Issue}} are the decedent's {{c2::lineal descendants}} (i.e., children, grandchildren, etc.). There must be a legally recognized {{c3::parent-child relationship}}. 1. {{c4::Adoption}} and effect on natural parents 1.1. Adoption generally {{c5::severs the child's inheritance relationship with the natural parents}} and substitutes the adoptive parents. 1.2. {{c6::Stepparent adoption}} creates a parent-child relationship between the child and the stepparent for purposes of inheritance. 1.3. In a typical stepparent adoption, adoption will not prevent the adoptee from inheriting from the {{c7::other genetic parent}} who is not the one being replaced by the stepparent. 2. {{c8::Posthumously born children}} 2.1. A posthumously born child is {{c9::conceived before, but born after, the death of the mother's husband}}. 2.2. If the child is born within {{c10::280 days}} of the husband's death, there is a rebuttable presumption that the child is the husband's and the child will inherit as if born before the husband's death. 2.3. Under the {{c11::Uniform Parentage Act}}, this presumption period is extended to {{c12::300 days}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: A {{c1::corporation}} is a {{c2::legal entity separate from its owners}}. Corporations have the following general characteristics: 1. {{c3::Centralized management}}: management rights are centralized in a {{c4::board of directors (BoD)}}, who delegate day-to-day management to {{c5::corporate officers}}. Unlike partnerships, management is generally not spread among owners (i.e., shareholders). 2. {{c6::Limited liability}}: only the corporation itself can be liable for its obligations; {{c7::shareholders, board members, and officers are generally not personally liable}} for the corporation's obligations. 3. {{c8::Transferability of ownership}}: shareholders can freely transfer their ownership interests (i.e., shares) unless prohibited by the {{c9::articles of incorporation or bylaws}}. 4. {{c10::Continuity}}: corporations can {{c11::exist in perpetuity}}; changes in ownership do not affect the corporation's existence. 5. {{c12::Personhood}}: corporations are considered {{c13::legal persons}} for most intents and purposes and are entitled to certain {{c14::constitutional protections}} (e.g., {{c15::due process and equal protection}}).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. General rule 1.1 {{c1::Entrapment}} is an available defense to criminal liability if a {{c2::law enforcement agent has induced the defendant to commit a crime}}. 2. Required elements 2.1 {{c3::Criminal design originated with law enforcement}}: the criminal design is the {{c4::idea or plan for the crime}}. 2.2 The defendant was {{c5::not otherwise predisposed to commit the crime}}: 2.2.1 The defendant must have had {{c6::no predisposition to commit the given crime prior to his contact with law enforcement}}. 2.2.2 {{c7::Law enforcement providing an opportunity}} for a person to commit a crime is {{c8::not, by itself, entrapment}}. 2.2.3 Example: an {{c9::undercover officer}} buys drugs from a dealer; the officer merely provided an opportunity for the defendant to make a sale. Note: this is a {{c10::very narrow defense}} and is {{c11::rarely effective}} because it is negated by any predisposition on the defendant's part; as a result, it is {{c12::unlikely to be a correct MBE answer}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Fundamental rights are protected under both {{c1::5th Amendment substantive due process}} and {{c2::14th Amendment equal protection}}. {{c1::Substantive due process}} applies if a right is denied to {{c3::all}}; {{c2::equal protection}} applies if a right is denied to {{c4::some but not others}}. Government actions that do not implicate a fundamental right receive only {{c5::rational basis}} review. Major categories of fundamental rights include: (1) an inferred {{c6::right to privacy}} covering marriage, procreation, and family-related rights; (2) certain autonomy interests such as {{c7::abortion}}, {{c8::private consensual homosexual activity}}, and {{c9::refusal of medical treatment}}; and (3) the fundamental rights to {{c10::vote}} and to {{c11::travel}}, often analyzed under the {{c2::Equal Protection Clause}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::right to travel}} and the {{c2::right to vote}} are both {{c3::fundamental rights}}. Although they can also be analyzed under {{c4::substantive due process}}, they frequently arise as {{c5::classification}} problems under {{c6::equal protection}}. Under equal protection: - Both rights generally trigger {{c7::strict scrutiny}} when a law significantly burdens them. - Right to travel questions often involve {{c8::durational residency requirements}} and other laws that {{c9::impede movement between states}}. - Right to vote questions often involve laws that {{c10::deny some citizens the right to vote}}, {{c11::malapportionment}}, or election structures that may {{c12::dilute votes}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Effect of merger}}: - Upon effectiveness of the merger, the {{c2::surviving corporation}}: • {{c3::Owns all property}} of the constituent corporations; and • {{c4::Assumes all obligations and liabilities}} of the constituent corporations. - The constituent corporations (other than the survivor) {{c5::cease to exist as separate entities}}. 2. {{c6::Short-form merger}}: - A short-form merger is a simplified statutory merger procedure used when a parent corporation owns a very high percentage of a subsidiary. - When a parent corporation owns at least {{c7::90%}} of the stock of a subsidiary: • The subsidiary can be {{c8::merged into the parent corporation}} (or vice versa, depending on statute); • The merger can occur {{c9::without approval of the shareholders of either corporation}} (no shareholder vote for parent or subsidiary). - The same basic effects apply: the {{c10::surviving corporation owns all property and assumes all obligations}} of the constituent corporations.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Prior convictions: {{c1::felonies not involving dishonesty or false statement}}. 1.1 If the witness (W) is the criminal defendant (D), the conviction is admissible only if the government shows that its {{c2::probative value outweighs its prejudicial effect}}. 1.2 If W is a non-defendant, the conviction is admissible, but the court can exclude it under {{c3::Rule 403 balancing}}. 1.3 {{c4::Misdemeanors}} are inadmissible for impeachment unless they {{c5::involve dishonesty or false statements}}. 2. Prior convictions involving an act of {{c6::dishonesty or false statement}}. 2.1 Such convictions are {{c7::always admissible}} to impeach; the court has {{c8::no discretion}} to exclude them under Rule 403 (a rare exception), and this includes both {{c9::felonies and misdemeanors}}. 2.2 Acts of dishonesty or false statement are those where the prior conviction required proof or admission of an act of {{c6::dishonesty or false statement}} (e.g., {{c10::perjury}}, {{c11::fraud}}). 3. Convictions more than {{c12::10 years}} old (felonies and misdemeanors). 3.1 These are not admissible for impeachment unless their {{c13::probative value substantially outweighs their unfair prejudice}} (the {{c14::inverse}} of ordinary Rule 403 balancing) and the adverse party is given {{c15::advance notice}}. 3.2 The 10-year period is measured from the later of (a) the {{c16::date of conviction}} or (b) the {{c17::date of release from confinement}} for that conviction.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under {{c1::Rule 23}}, an individual or small group can represent a larger group ({{c2::class}}) sharing a common interest in a lawsuit. Usually {{c3::plaintiffs}} form the class, though {{c4::defendants}} can also form a class action. Certification requirements ({{c5::Rule 23(a)}}): 1. {{c6::Numerosity}}: The class size must be so numerous that {{c7::joinder is impracticable}}. There is no exact threshold as to class size; it depends on the context of the case and claims. 2. {{c8::Commonality}}: There must be {{c9::questions of law or fact common to the entire class}}. 3. {{c10::Typicality}}: The {{c11::claims or defenses of the class representatives}} are {{c12::typical of those of the class}}. 4. {{c13::Adequacy}}: The class representatives will {{c14::fairly and adequately protect the interests of the entire class}} (e.g., the representatives must not have {{c15::conflicts of interest}} with class members, and class counsel must be {{c16::competent}}).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Requirement to plead affirmative defenses 1.1 Certain defenses are {{c1::waived if not explicitly pleaded}} in the answer. 1.2 These must be set out as {{c2::affirmative defenses}} in the answer. 2. Common affirmative defenses 2.1 {{c3::Contributory negligence}}. 2.2 {{c4::Claim preclusion (res judicata)}}. 2.3 {{c5::Statute of frauds}}. 2.4 {{c6::Fraud}}. 2.5 {{c7::Statute of limitations}}. 2.6 {{c8::Self-defense}}. 3. Waiver 3.1 Affirmative defenses are typically {{c9::waived}} if not {{c10::pleaded in the answer}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Exceptions: situations where {{c1::physician–patient privilege does not apply}}. 1. {{c2::Patient’s condition is a legal issue}}. 1.1. The privilege does not apply when the patient’s physical or mental condition is itself in issue, such as in a {{c3::personal injury}} or medical condition claim. 2. {{c4::Crime/tort/escape purposes}}. 2.1. The privilege does not apply when the physician’s services were sought to aid in the commission of a {{c5::crime or tort}}, or to {{c6::escape capture or apprehension}}. 3. {{c7::Dispute between doctor and patient}}. 3.1. The privilege does not apply when there is a dispute between doctor and patient, such as a {{c8::malpractice}} or fee dispute, where the communications are relevant to the controversy.

subject: Torts
cloze: Common requirements for {{c1::protective defenses}} (self-defense, defense of others, defense of property): 1. {{c2::Reasonable belief}}: D must reasonably believe a {{c3::tort is being committed or is about to be committed}}. 2. {{c4::Proper timing}}: The tort must be {{c5::in progress or imminent}}. 3. {{c6::Reasonable force}}: The force used must be {{c7::proportionate to the threat of harm}}. - {{c8::Deadly force}} is allowed only if D reasonably believes a {{c9::life is in danger}}. - Deadly force is {{c10::never permitted to protect property alone}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: MPC Test (Combined Cognitive/Volitional Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The MPC standard is a combination of {{c1::M'Naghten}} and {{c2::Irresistible Impulse}}. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 As a result of the defendant's {{c3::mental disease}}, the defendant lacked the capacity either to {{c4::appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct}} or to {{c5::conform his conduct to the requirements of the law}}. 2.2 This test examines both {{c6::cognitive}} capacity and {{c7::volitional}} capacity.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. {{c1::Mistake as to nature of instrument}} 1.1 Occurs when the testator is {{c2::mistaken about what document he is signing}} (e.g., does not realize it is his will). 1.2 {{c3::Extrinsic evidence}} is admissible to show the testator was mistaken as to the nature of the instrument. 1.3 This mistake may nullify the {{c4::testamentary intent}} requirement and render the will {{c5::invalid}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Methods of proving a {{c1::prior inconsistent statement (PIS)}} 1.1 A PIS may be established through {{c2::cross-examination}} of the witness or by {{c3::extrinsic evidence}}. 2. Collateral-matter limitation 2.1 {{c3::Extrinsic evidence}} of a PIS is **inadmissible** if the PIS relates only to a {{c4::collateral matter}}. 2.2 A {{c4::collateral matter}} is one relevant only to contradiction and not to any substantive issue or other valid impeachment theory. 3. Foundation requirement 3.1 Generally, the witness must be given an {{c5::opportunity to explain or deny}} the PIS. 3.2 This foundation is **not required** for a PIS made by a {{c6::hearsay declarant}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. Nature of a constructive trust 1.1 A {{c1::constructive trust}} is not actually a traditional trust, but an {{c2::equitable remedy}} imposed by a court. 2. Purpose and operation 2.1 It is used to prevent {{c3::unjust enrichment}} resulting from {{c4::wrongful conduct}} (e.g., fraud, breach of fiduciary duty). 2.2 The court imposes a constructive trust on property in the {{c5::wrongdoer's possession}} or its {{c6::traceable proceeds}}. 2.3 The wrongdoer is treated as if holding the property {{c7::in trust for the person who should benefit in equity}} and is typically required to {{c8::convey legal title}} to that person.

subject: Real Property
cloze: RAP and contingent purchase rights 1. {{c1::Options}} and {{c2::rights of first refusal}} are {{c3::contingent interests}} in property. 2. RAP application 2.1 These contingent interests violate the {{c4::Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP)}} if they could possibly be {{c5::exercised outside the perpetuities period}} (lives in being plus {{c6::21 years}}). 2.2 If there is {{c7::any chance, however remote}}, that the option or right of first refusal could be exercised beyond the perpetuities period, the interest is {{c8::void from the outset}} under RAP.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Impeachment by {{c1::contradiction}} 1.1 {{c1::Contradiction}} allows use of **any evidence** to show that the witness (W) has made contradictory statements on {{c2::material issues}}. 2. Impeachment by {{c3::prior inconsistent statement (PIS)}} 2.1 A {{c3::PIS}} is a statement by W, made before trial, that {{c4::conflicts with W’s present testimony}}. 2.2 W’s {{c3::prior inconsistent statements}} may be used to {{c5::impeach}} W’s present testimony by showing W has changed or contradicted their story. 2.3 {{c3::PIS}} is a specific form of {{c1::contradiction}} focusing on W’s own prior words.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule 1.1 Party representatives must {{c1::meet and confer}} with each other and/or the court at various times throughout the proceeding. 1.2 Most of these conferences are for {{c2::discovery}} purposes. 2. Mandatory meet and confer 2.1 Parties must meet at least {{c3::21 days before}} the scheduling conference to: 2.1.1 Discuss {{c4::claims, defenses, and settlement}}; and 2.1.2 Develop a {{c5::plan for discovery}}. 2.2 Parties must present a {{c6::written discovery plan}} to the court within {{c7::14 days}} of the meet and confer.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule 1.1 Parties must disclose certain information {{c1::without awaiting discovery requests}} from the opposing party. 2. Initial disclosures – parties must disclose: 2.1 {{c2::Sources of discoverable information}} – witnesses and documents that they may use to support their claims or defenses. 2.2 {{c3::Damages}} – a computation of each category of damages claimed. 2.3 {{c4::Insurance}} – any insurance agreement that may be used to satisfy all or part of a judgment. 3. Timing of initial disclosures 3.1 Initial disclosures must be made within {{c5::14 days}} of the parties' mandatory meet and confer. 3.2 Parties served or joined later must make initial disclosures within {{c6::30 days}} of being served or joined. 4. Duty to supplement 4.1 Parties must {{c7::supplement}} their mandatory disclosures if the produced information becomes {{c8::incomplete or incorrect}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Tangible goods are {{c1::physical goods}} that can serve as collateral under Article 9, and they are divided into four main categories: 1. {{c2::Farming goods}}: - Items {{c3::used or produced in farming}}. - Examples: {{c4::crops, livestock, farm products}}. 2. {{c5::Consumer goods}}: - Goods used or bought primarily for {{c6::personal, family, or household}} purposes. - Examples: {{c7::home furniture, a family car, household electronics}}. 3. {{c8::Inventory}}: - Goods held by a business for {{c9::sale or lease}}, or furnished under a {{c10::contract of service}}. - Includes raw materials, work in progress, and materials consumed in business if held for {{c11::short‑term use or turnover}}. 4. {{c12::Equipment}}: - {{c13::Catchall category}} for tangible goods that do not fit as farming goods, consumer goods, or inventory. - Typically {{c14::long‑term business goods}} used in operations (e.g., {{c15::factory machinery, office computers, restaurant ovens}}).

subject: Torts
cloze: In {{c1::zone-of-danger}} negligent infliction of emotional distress (NIED): 1. The defendant’s {{c2::negligence}} must place the plaintiff in a {{c3::close risk of bodily harm}} (within the {{c4::zone of danger}} of physical impact), such that the act nearly causes physical harm. 2. The plaintiff must suffer {{c5::severe emotional distress}}. 3. Traditionally, the plaintiff had to show a {{c6::physical manifestation}} of that distress, which could appear immediately or days later. 4. There is a {{c7::jurisdictional split}}: many modern jurisdictions now allow recovery for {{c8::severe emotional distress alone without physical symptoms}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general ({{c1::common law}}): Under a common law contract, if one party has {{c2::substantially performed}}, the other party is {{c3::obligated to perform and complete performance}}. 1.1 {{c4::Substantial performance}} is usually considered at least {{c5::halfway complete}}. 1.2 {{c6::Less than perfect performance}} by one party does not excuse the other party from his obligation to perform. 1.3 Thus, substantial performance by Party A obligates Party B to perform, but Party B may seek {{c7::money damages}} for the {{c8::difference between the performance rendered and the performance expected}}. 1.4 Substantial performance issues commonly arise in {{c9::construction contracts}} or other similar {{c10::service contracts}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Mistakes in wills may occur in executing the will or in the inclusion or omission of provisions, but relief is often {{c1::limited}}. The main categories are: 1. {{c2::Mistake as to nature of instrument}} – Testator is mistaken about what document is being signed (e.g., does not realize it is a will); {{c3::extrinsic evidence}} may be used to show lack of {{c4::testamentary intent}}, and the will may fail. 2. {{c5::Mistake in inducement}} – Testator is mistaken about the {{c6::reasons for making the will or a particular gift or omission}}; courts generally do {{c7::not grant relief}} unless there is an {{c8::independent ground to contest the will}} (fraud, undue influence). 3. {{c9::Mistaken omission or misstatement of intent}} – Courts traditionally do {{c10::not admit extrinsic evidence}} to add omitted provisions or correct terms that do not reflect actual intent, absent another ground like fraud. 4. {{c11::Reformation under the UPC}} – Courts may {{c12::reform a will}} to conform to the testator’s intent when a {{c13::mistake of law or fact}} is shown by {{c14::clear and convincing evidence}}, and may use {{c15::extrinsic evidence}} to resolve both {{c16::latent and patent ambiguities}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Groundwater}} 1.1 Groundwater is water {{c2::beneath the surface}} that is {{c3::not confined to a known channel}} (e.g., water in wells). 1.2 Different states use different approaches to groundwater; the most common are: 1.2.1 {{c4::Reasonable use}} (used in many eastern states). 1.2.2 {{c5::Prior appropriation}} (used in many western states). 2. {{c6::Surface water}} 2.1 Surface water is water from {{c7::rain, springs, or other runoff}} that has not yet reached a natural watercourse. 2.2 Landowners can generally use surface water as they please, but may be liable for {{c8::interrupting its flow}} in a way that impacts other owners. 2.3 Liability depends on which theory applies: 2.3.1 {{c9::Natural flow theory}}: owners cannot {{c10::unreasonably alter natural drainage}}. 2.3.2 {{c11::Common enemy theory}}: owners can do anything to {{c12::change drainage or combat flow}} unless it causes {{c13::unnecessary damage}} to others' land. 2.3.3 {{c14::Reasonable use theory}}: liability is determined by {{c15::balancing the utility of the owner's use}} against the {{c16::gravity of the harm}} from that use.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Ultra vires acts}}: when a corporation acts {{c2::outside the purposes stated in its articles of incorporation}}, with potential {{c3::shareholder injunctions}}, {{c4::corporate suits for damages}}, and {{c5::state dissolution}}. 2. {{c6::De facto corporation}}: treats an entity with {{c7::defective formation}} as a corporation if key requirements are met. 3. {{c8::Corporation by estoppel}}: parties who {{c9::treat an entity as a corporation}} are {{c10::estopped from denying}} its corporate status to avoid liability.

subject: Con Law
cloze: When a state or local law interferes with the state’s own {{c1::government contracts}}, the Contract Clause applies a {{c2::stricter scrutiny}}. 1. Threshold: substantial impairment 1.1. First determine whether the law {{c3::substantially impairs}} or interferes with existing {{c1::government contracts}}. 2. Test for substantial impairment of government contracts 2.1. Laws that substantially impair existing government contracts are subject to {{c2::stricter scrutiny}}. 2.2. Such laws must be: 2.2.1. {{c4::Reasonable}}; and 2.2.2. {{c5::Necessary}} to serve an {{c6::important public purpose}}. 3. Level of scrutiny 3.1. This “{{c4::reasonable}} and {{c5::necessary}} to serve an {{c6::important public purpose}}” standard is stricter than the {{c7::intermediate-type}} scrutiny used for {{c8::private contracts}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 2. {{c1::Mistake in inducement}} 2.1 Occurs when the testator is mistaken about the {{c2::reasons or facts that led him to make the will or a particular gift or omission}}. 2.2 {{c3::General rule}}: No relief is available merely because the testator’s motive or reason was mistaken. 2.3 {{c4::Exception}}: Relief may be available if there is a {{c5::separate ground for contesting the will}}, such as {{c6::fraud}}, {{c7::undue influence}}, or {{c8::duress}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general: If a contract is within the {{c1::Statute of Frauds}}, it must satisfy SoF requirements to be {{c2::valid or enforceable}}. 2. Contracts within the Statute of Frauds (common law and UCC): 2.1 {{c3::Marriage contracts}}: Promises made in {{c4::consideration of marriage}}. 2.2 {{c5::Service contracts}} incapable of being performed within {{c6::1 year}}: 2.2.1 The SoF does not apply to deals or contracts that say nothing about time for performance because they are technically capable of performance within one year. 2.3 {{c7::Land-related contracts}}: Transfers of property interests, including {{c8::leases for terms greater than one year}}. 2.4 {{c9::Executor promises}}: Promises by executors or administrators to personally answer for the debts of the decedent's estate. 2.5 {{c10::Suretyship}}: Promises to pay the {{c11::debt of another}}. 2.6 {{c12::UCC}}: {{c13::Sales of goods for $500 or more}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Damages Considerations 1. In General 1.1 Damages depend on the {{c1::type of plaintiff}}, the {{c2::content of the statement}}, and whether the defamatory statement constitutes {{c3::libel, slander, or slander per se}}. 2. Libel 2.1 {{c4::Libel}} is a {{c5::written or otherwise recorded}} (including {{c6::TV and radio broadcasts}}) defamatory statement. 2.2 {{c7::Public figures and public officials}} who prove the constitutional requirements ({{c8::falsity and actual malice}}) may recover {{c9::presumed and punitive damages}} for reputational harm {{c10::without any proof of actual damages}}. 2.3 {{c11::Private figures}} who prove only {{c12::negligence}} may recover presumed or punitive damages only if the speech relates to a {{c13::matter of private concern}}. 2.4 If the speech involves a {{c14::matter of public concern}} and the plaintiff is a private figure, the plaintiff may recover only {{c15::proved actual damages}} unless {{c16::actual malice}} is also shown. 2.5 Note: {{c17::TV and radio broadcasts}} are treated as {{c18::libel}}. 3. Slander 3.1 {{c19::Slander}} is a {{c20::spoken defamatory statement}}. 3.2 The plaintiff must generally prove {{c21::special damages}} (a specific economic loss) unless the statement constitutes {{c22::slander per se}}. 4. Slander Per Se 4.1 {{c23::Slander per se}} is slander that falls into certain categories where {{c24::damages are presumed}}. It includes statements that: 4.1.1 Adversely reflect on the plaintiff's {{c25::business or professional reputation}}; 4.1.2 Claim that the plaintiff has a {{c26::loathsome disease}}; 4.1.3 Claim that the plaintiff committed a {{c27::crime of moral turpitude}}; or 4.1.4 Impute a woman's {{c28::lack of chastity}} (often modernized as serious sexual misconduct).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::No self-help}} 1.1 A landlord may not use {{c2::self-help}} to recover possession after a tenant’s breach. 1.2 Prohibited measures include {{c3::forcibly removing the tenant or belongings}}, {{c4::changing locks}}, and {{c5::shutting off utilities}}. 2. {{c6::Security deposit}} 2.1 A security deposit is typically collected at lease inception to secure against {{c7::damages or abandonment}}. 2.2 When the lease {{c8::terminates}}, the landlord must {{c9::return the security deposit}} to the tenant. 2.3 The landlord may deduct only for {{c10::actual damages}} or other {{c11::contractually permitted losses}} (such as {{c12::unpaid rent or authorized fees}}). 3. {{c13::Retaliatory eviction}} 3.1 A landlord is prohibited from {{c14::retaliatory eviction}} or other {{c15::retaliatory measures}} when a tenant {{c16::lawfully exercises protected rights}}. 3.2 Protected activities include {{c17::reporting housing code or other violations}} and {{c18::asserting or enforcing statutory or contractual tenant rights}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Certain parties lack capacity to contract: {{c1::infants}}, {{c2::mentally incompetent persons}}, and some {{c3::intoxicated persons}} (where the other party has {{c4::reason to know}} of the intoxication). Contracts with such parties are generally {{c5::voidable}} at the option of the party lacking capacity, who has a {{c6::right to disaffirm}}. However, minors face key limitations, including possible {{c7::implied affirmation (ratification)}} after gaining capacity and {{c8::quasi-contract liability}} for the reasonable value of {{c9::necessities}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Justification defenses of {{c1::self-defense}} and {{c2::defense of others}} allow a defendant to use {{c3::non-deadly}} or, in some circumstances, {{c4::deadly}} force when certain conditions are met. 1. {{c5::Non-deadly self-defense}}: A person who is {{c6::not at fault}} may use {{c7::proportionate non-deadly force}} when he {{c8::reasonably believes}} it is necessary to protect himself from {{c9::imminent unlawful force}}. There is generally {{c10::no duty to retreat}}. 2. {{c11::Deadly self-defense}}: A person who is not at fault may use deadly force when {{c12::confronted with unlawful force}} and he reasonably believes he faces {{c13::imminent death or great bodily harm}}. Under the {{c14::majority rule}}, there is {{c15::no duty to retreat}} before using deadly force. 3. {{c16::Initial aggressor}}: An initial aggressor can regain the right to self-defense by {{c17::effectively withdrawing and communicating that withdrawal}}, or when the victim {{c18::unexpectedly escalates a minor confrontation into a deadly one}}. 4. {{c19::Defense of others}}: The {{c20::same basic rules}} apply as for self-defense. A defendant may use force to protect another when he {{c21::reasonably believes}} the person he is protecting would be {{c22::legally entitled}} to use that level of force in self-defense.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Bilateral contract}}: 1.1. Exchange of {{c2::mutual promises}}. 1.2. Each party is both a {{c3::promisor and a promisee}}. 1.3. Example: A offers to sell his car to B for $5,000 and B promises to purchase A's car at that price. 2. {{c4::Unilateral contract}}: 2.1. Offer requires {{c5::performance as the manner of acceptance}}. 2.2. Offeror–promisor agrees to pay upon {{c6::completion of the act requested by the promisee}}; once the act is completed, the contract is formed. 2.3. Example: A promises to pay B $100 if B paints A's fence; B is not obligated to paint A's fence, but if B does, a contract is formed and A must pay B $100. 3. {{c7::Quasi-contract}} ({{c8::restitution / unjust enrichment}}): 3.1. Not a contract, but a {{c9::restitution remedy designed to prevent unjust enrichment}}. 3.2. An {{c10::implied-in-law obligation}} arises when there is an unenforceable or non-existent agreement, but one side has realized a benefit. 3.3. Elements: (a) P has {{c11::conferred a benefit on D}}; (b) P {{c12::reasonably expects to be paid}}; (c) D {{c13::knowingly accepted the benefit}}; and (d) D will be {{c14::unjustly enriched if P is not compensated}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Classifications must be {{c1::discriminatory}} to be reviewed under {{c2::heightened scrutiny}} ({{c3::intermediate}} or {{c4::strict}} scrutiny). There are three ways to prove a discriminatory classification: 1. {{c5::Law discriminates on its face}}: By its terms, the law treats classes of people differently. 2. {{c6::Facially neutral law applied in a discriminatory manner}}: The law does not create a classification by its terms, but does so as applied (for example, only men are arrested under an otherwise valid law). 3. {{c7::Discriminatory motive or purpose}} behind the law and/or its application: 3.1 Test: The plaintiff must show both: 3.1.1 {{c8::Disparate impact}}: the law has a discriminatory impact (it creates a classification in practice), and 3.1.2 {{c9::Discriminatory purpose}}: the law was enacted or maintained for reasons involving discrimination. Demonstrating discriminatory impact alone is not enough; there must be some evidence of the government's discriminatory motive. 4. {{c10::Challenger bears burden}}: The burden is on the party challenging the classification to show that it is discriminatory.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Buyers can sometimes take goods free of a secured creditor’s interest, especially when they {{c1::lack knowledge that the sale violates the secured party’s rights}}. Priority issues most often arise in three contexts: 1. {{c2::Buyers vs. unperfected secured parties}}. 2. {{c3::Buyers in the ordinary course of business (BIOCs) vs. perfected secured parties}}. 3. {{c4::Consumer-to-consumer ("garage sale") rule for PMSIs in consumer goods}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A {{c1::defendant}} can remove a case originally filed in state court to federal court if the federal court would have had {{c2::subject-matter jurisdiction}} (i.e., {{c3::diversity}} or {{c4::federal question}}). 1. Removal rules 1.1. The case must be one that {{c5::could have been filed in federal court}}. 1.2. Only {{c6::defendants}} can remove, and {{c7::all defendants must agree}} to removal. 1.3. A case can be removed only to the {{c8::federal district court embracing the state court}} in which the case was originally filed. 1.4. A defendant who files a {{c9::permissive counterclaim}} in state court {{c10::waives the right to remove}}. 2. Timing 2.1. The defendant must remove within {{c11::30 days}} of service of the first removable document (usually service of process). 3. Procedure 3.1. The defendant must file a {{c12::notice of removal}} in both state and federal courts. 3.2. The notice must {{c13::state the grounds for removal}} and include {{c14::copies of all documents served in state court}}, and it must be {{c15::signed}}. 3.3. All {{c16::adverse parties}} must receive notice of removal. 4. Diversity jurisdiction limitations ({{c17::forum-defendant rule}}) 4.1. A defendant cannot remove a diversity case if the plaintiff filed suit in any {{c18::defendant's home state}}. 4.2. In other words, no removal if any defendant is a {{c19::citizen of the forum state}}. 5. Remand 5.1. If removal is improper, the federal court can {{c20::remand}} the case to state court. 5.2. For {{c21::improper procedure}}, the plaintiff must move to remand within {{c22::30 days}}. 5.3. For {{c23::lack of subject-matter jurisdiction}}, the plaintiff can move to remand {{c24::at any time}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A {{c1::regulatory taking}} occurs when government regulation goes so far in restricting property use or value that it effectively takes the property. 1. {{c2::Total denial of economic value}}: - A regulation that denies the owner {{c3::all economic value}} in the property is a taking and requires just compensation. 2. {{c4::Near-total denial of economic value}}: - A regulation that denies {{c5::nearly all economic value}} may be a taking, depending on: • The {{c6::social goals}} promoted by the regulation; • The {{c7::diminution in value}} to the owner; and • The extent of interference with the owner’s {{c8::reasonable investment-backed expectations}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Seller {{c1::breaches}} and the {{c2::buyer keeps the goods}} (depends on whether buyer accepts): 1. {{c3::Non-acceptance}} (buyer rightfully rejects but still has the goods): • Damages = {{c4::fair market value (FMV) of perfectly delivered goods − FMV of the goods actually delivered}}. 2. {{c5::Acceptance}} (buyer accepts nonconforming goods): • Damages = {{c6::difference in value between the goods as delivered and the goods as ordered}} ({{c7::value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered}}). 3. {{c8::Superior nonconforming goods}}: • If the seller delivers nonconforming but {{c9::superior goods}}, the buyer is {{c10::not responsible}} for the {{c11::increased value of the superior goods}} when computing damages.

subject: Contracts
cloze: The {{c1::implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose}} arises when: (1) the buyer has a {{c2::particular (special) purpose}} for the goods; (2) the buyer {{c3::relies on the seller}} to select or furnish suitable goods; and (3) the seller has {{c4::reason to know}} of the buyer’s particular purpose and {{c5::reliance}}. When these conditions are met, the seller impliedly warrants that the goods are {{c6::fit for the buyer’s particular purpose}}, and this can apply to {{c7::any seller}}, not just merchants.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Waiving Miranda Rights 1. A valid Miranda waiver must be {{c1::knowing}} and {{c2::voluntary}}. 2. The waiver may be {{c3::express}} or {{c4::implied}} from the suspect’s conduct, but in either case must satisfy the {{c5::knowing and voluntary}} standard. 3. The burden is on the {{c6::prosecution}} to prove a valid waiver by a {{c7::preponderance of the evidence}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Easements can be terminated in several recognized ways. The main modes are: (1) {{c1::estoppel}}; (2) {{c2::end of necessity}}; (3) {{c3::destruction of the servient tenement}}; (4) {{c4::release by deed}}; (5) {{c5::abandonment by physical acts showing permanent intent to give it up}}; (6) {{c6::merger of ownership of the easement and servient estate}}; (7) {{c7::prescription using adverse possession elements}}; and (8) {{c8::expiration by its own terms (fixed term or stated condition)}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: Unmarried cohabitants do not have any {{c1::special legal or marital status}} merely by living together. They are treated as spouses only if they satisfy the requirements for a {{c2::common law marriage}}. Express contracts between unmarried cohabitants to {{c3::share property or economic benefits}} are generally {{c4::enforceable}} under ordinary contract law, but a contract is {{c5::invalid}} if {{c6::sexual services}} are the {{c7::sole consideration}} supporting the agreement.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Who may be impeached and for what 1.1 {{c1::Officers subject to impeachment}} 1.1.1 The {{c2::President}}, {{c3::Vice President}}, {{c4::federal judges (including Article III judges)}}, and other {{c5::federal civil officers}} may be impeached. 1.2 {{c6::Grounds for impeachment}} 1.2.1 {{c7::Treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors}}. 2. {{c8::Impeachment in the House of Representatives}} 2.1 {{c9::Charging decision}} 2.1.1 The {{c10::House of Representatives}} has the {{c11::sole power of impeachment}}. 2.1.2 A {{c12::simple majority vote}} in the House is required to {{c13::impeach}}. 3. {{c14::Trial and removal in the Senate}} 3.1 {{c15::Senate trial}} 3.1.1 Once impeached, the officer is {{c16::tried in the Senate}}. 3.2 {{c17::Vote required for conviction and removal}} 3.2.1 Conviction and removal from office require the constitutionally required {{c18::supermajority vote}} in the Senate.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. A {{c1::joint will}} is the will of {{c2::two or more people}} executed in a {{c3::single document}}. 1.1. It is {{c4::admissible to probate upon the death of either testator}}. 1.2. If one testator {{c5::revokes}} the joint will, it generally remains {{c6::valid as the other’s will}}. 1.3. A joint will may be interpreted as a {{c7::contract for a will}}—often a {{c8::contract not to revoke}}—especially where it is executed pursuant to a {{c9::promise between the parties not to revoke}}. 2. {{c10::Mutual wills}} are {{c11::separate wills}} of two or more people that contain {{c12::reciprocal or substantially similar provisions}}. 2.1. Mutual wills are {{c13::usually not interpreted}} as a {{c14::binding contract}} to make a will or not to revoke; courts generally require {{c15::additional evidence of a contract}} (such as explicit contractual language or separate proof).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Landlord's implied duties to the tenant 1.1 Duty to {{c1::deliver possession}} on the first day of the lease. 1.1.1 Majority ({{c2::English Rule}}): The landlord must deliver {{c3::actual (physical) possession}} to the tenant on the first day of the lease. 1.1.2 Minority ({{c4::American Rule}}): The landlord need only deliver {{c5::legal possession}}; the new tenant is responsible for {{c6::evicting a holdover tenant}}. 1.2 Tenant's remedy for breach of the duty to deliver possession: {{c7::money damages}}. 2. Other implied protections 2.1 {{c8::Implied covenant of quiet enjoyment}}. 2.2 {{c9::Implied warranty of habitability}} (residential leases). 2.3 {{c10::Tort liability}} (landlord's liability in tort for dangerous conditions, as provided by common law and statutes).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A {{c1::forum-selection clause}} is a contractual provision selecting a forum for disputes. When a {{c2::valid}} forum-selection clause specifies a {{c3::federal district}} as the chosen forum, federal courts ordinarily {{c4::transfer the case to that district}}. The clause is given {{c5::controlling weight}} in all but the most exceptional cases. The court may refuse to transfer only if {{c6::public-interest factors}} present a {{c7::compelling reason}} not to enforce the clause. Relevant public-interest factors include court congestion, local interest in the dispute, the forum’s familiarity with the governing law, and avoiding unnecessary conflict-of-laws or foreign-law problems. Private convenience factors generally carry reduced weight when a valid forum-selection clause exists.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Option contracts}} (common law and UCC when firm-offer rule does not apply): 1.1. Definition: An option contract is a {{c2::separate promise to keep an offer open}} for a specified period. 1.2. Consideration requirement: 1.2.1. {{c3::Common law}}: {{c4::consideration is required}} for the option; without it, the offeror may generally revoke. 1.2.2. {{c5::UCC}}: when the {{c6::firm-offer rule}} does not apply, an option to keep a goods offer open also {{c7::requires consideration}}. 2. {{c8::UCC firm offers}} (UCC § 2-205): 2.1. Elements: 2.1.1. A {{c9::merchant}}. 2.1.2. An offer to {{c10::buy or sell goods}}. 2.1.3. In a {{c11::signed writing}}. 2.1.4. That gives {{c12::assurances the offer will be held open}}. 2.2. Effect: 2.2.1. The offer is irrevocable for the {{c13::time stated}}, or if no time is stated, for a {{c14::reasonable time}} not exceeding {{c15::three months}}. 2.2.2. {{c16::No consideration is required}} to make the firm offer irrevocable.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Rule Against Perpetuities – Core Rule and Measuring Life 1. Core RAP Statement 1.1 No property interest is valid unless it must {{c1::vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being}} at the time the interest was created. 1.2 A future interest is {{c2::void}} if there is any {{c3::possibility, no matter how remote}} that it will {{c4::vest more than 21 years after the death of the measuring life}}. 2. Measuring Life 2.1 A {{c5::measuring life}} is a {{c6::life in being at the time the interest is created}}. 2.2 The measuring life is someone whose {{c7::actions during life, at death, or within 21 years after death}} determine whether the future interest vests within the RAP period. 2.3 If there is any {{c8::conceivable scenario}} in which the interest could vest later than {{c9::21 years after the measuring life’s death}}, the interest {{c10::violates RAP and is void}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. {{c1::Valid contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will}} are generally {{c2::enforceable}}. 1.1. They are governed by {{c3::ordinary contract law}}, not by will law, and {{c4::are not themselves wills}}. 1.2. They must satisfy {{c5::standard contract requirements}} such as mutual assent and consideration. 2. {{c6::Most states}} require contracts involving wills to be {{c7::in writing}}. 3. Under the {{c8::UPC}} and similar statutes, the writing requirement can be satisfied by one of three alternatives: 3.1. {{c9::Provisions in the will stating the material provisions of the contract}}; OR 3.2. An {{c10::express reference in the will to the contract}} plus {{c11::extrinsic evidence}} proving the contract terms; OR 3.3. A {{c12::separate writing signed by the decedent/testator}} evidencing the contract.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Illegality and public policy can render a contract unenforceable. 1. In general: {{c1::Illegality}} is a defense to {{c2::contract formation or enforcement}}. 2. {{c3::Illegal subject matter}}: 2.1 If the subject matter of the contract is illegal, the contract is {{c4::not enforceable}}. 3. {{c5::Legal subject matter but illegal purpose}}: 3.1 If the subject matter is legal but the contract is formed for an illegal purpose, the contract is only enforceable by a party who {{c6::did not know of the illegal purpose}}. 4. {{c7::Timing of legality}}: 4.1 Legality is judged based on the {{c8::law in effect at the time of contract formation}}. 5. {{c9::Public policy and enforcement}}: 5.1 Even where terms violate a {{c10::public policy}}, a court may enforce the contract to avoid {{c11::frustrating that public policy}}. 5.2 This is especially true where the violated policy is intended to {{c12::benefit or protect the party seeking relief}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: After default, Article 9 governs what a {{c1::secured party}} may do with {{c2::collateral}}. 1. {{c3::Disposition & notice}} (overview) - A secured party may {{c4::dispose of collateral}} (e.g., by sale, lease, or other disposition) after default, but the disposition must be conducted in a {{c5::commercially reasonable}} manner and preceded by {{c6::reasonable authenticated notice}} to the debtor. - A proper sale {{c7::discharges the foreclosing security interest}} and all {{c8::subordinate interests}}, and the purchaser generally takes the {{c9::debtor’s rights in the collateral}}. 2. {{c10::Surplus & deficiency}} (overview) - If proceeds exceed the obligation, the secured party must pay any {{c11::surplus}} to the debtor. - If proceeds are less than the obligation, the debtor is generally liable for a {{c12::deficiency}}. - {{c13::Exception}}: For collateral consisting of {{c14::accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, or promissory notes}}, neither party is liable for a surplus or deficiency. 3. {{c15::Right to redeem}} (overview) - Until the collateral is sold or the debt is discharged by {{c16::strict foreclosure}}, the debtor or another secured party may {{c17::redeem}} by paying the {{c18::remaining obligation plus reasonable repossession expenses}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Right to {{c1::effective assistance of counsel}} 1.1. The {{c2::Sixth Amendment}} includes the right to effective assistance of counsel. 2. Ineffective assistance standard 2.1. To establish ineffective assistance of counsel on appeal, the defendant must show: 2.1.1. {{c3::Deficient performance}} by counsel; and 2.1.2. A {{c4::reasonable probability}} that the outcome of the trial would have been different absent counsel's {{c5::deficient performance}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A party's duty to perform under a {{c1::contract}} may be discharged if an {{c2::unforeseen event}} occurs that {{c3::undermines (frustrates)}} one or both parties' {{c4::principal purpose}} for entering into the contract. 2. Requirements (a contract may be discharged if): 2.1 An {{c5::unexpected event}} {{c6::destroys}} one or both parties' principal purpose for entering into the contract. 2.1.1 Whether {{c7::performance is still possible}} after the event is {{c8::irrelevant}}. 2.1.2 The issue is whether performance after the unforeseen event {{c9::nullifies one or both parties' original purpose}} for the contract. 2.2 The unforeseen event is {{c10::not the fault of the frustrated party}}. 2.3 The {{c11::non-occurrence}} of the event was a {{c12::basic assumption}} of the contract; it does not have to be a stated assumption in the contract. 3. Frustration of purpose vs. impossibility 3.1 {{c13::Impossibility}} concerns {{c14::duties specified in the contract}} (whether they can be performed at all). 3.2 {{c15::Frustration of purpose}} concerns the {{c16::reasons a party entered into the contract}} (whether the value or purpose of performance remains). 3.3 Example: A landlord rents space to B, a restaurateur, to open an ice cream parlor. If the property is destroyed by an earthquake, A and B are excused from performing due to {{c17::impossibility}}. However, if the city passes an ordinance banning the sale of sweetened food, the contract's purpose is {{c18::frustrated}} because A knew B intended to open an ice cream parlor.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: General Rule for {{c1::Recognition of Divorce Decrees}}: 1. {{c2::Full Faith and Credit}} Requirement: 1.1 A state must give full faith and credit to a divorce decree issued by a sister state if BOTH of the following are satisfied: (a) The decree is {{c3::valid under the law of the rendering state}}; and (b) The rendering state had {{c4::proper jurisdiction}}. 2. Jurisdiction Basis: 2.1 Proper jurisdiction is ordinarily satisfied if at least {{c5::one spouse is domiciled}} in the state that granted the divorce. 3. Effect: 3.1 When these requirements are met, other states must {{c6::recognize the divorce status and its legal effects}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::In personam jurisdiction}}: jurisdiction over persons. 1.1. The court may {{c2::render a judgment (money or injunction) against an individual}} based on that person's {{c3::contacts with the forum state}}. 2. {{c4::In rem jurisdiction}}: jurisdiction over {{c5::property or status}}, including ownership disputes. 2.1. The court adjudicates the rights of parties with respect to {{c6::property located in the forum state}}. 2.2. The judgment is binding as to the {{c7::disposition of property rights or status}}, not as to the parties personally. 2.3. In rem jurisdiction often involves {{c8::estate issues, business proceedings, or property disputes}} (e.g., an action to quiet title). 3. {{c9::Quasi in rem jurisdiction}}: permits a court without personal jurisdiction over a defendant to determine certain types of disputes between a plaintiff and defendant when {{c10::property is located in the forum state}}. 3.1. Property is {{c11::attached}} for some reason not necessarily involving the property itself (e.g., an action against a defendant and his assets due to fears he will flee the state). 3.2. The court may render a judgment as to the parties {{c12::with respect to the property}} (rather than a judgment over the person generally or over the property itself).

subject: Contracts
cloze: Under the {{c1::Parol Evidence Rule (PER)}}, extrinsic evidence of prior or contemporaneous agreements or negotiations is generally inadmissible to supplement or contradict a written contract that is an {{c2::integration}} of the parties’ agreement. At {{c3::common law}}, PER bars prior or contemporaneous extrinsic evidence that would change a completely integrated writing, but permits certain categories of extrinsic evidence (e.g., {{c4::partial integration or separate-agreement terms}}, {{c5::mistake, misrepresentation/fraud/duress/illegality}}, {{c6::conditions precedent}}, {{c7::later modifications}}, and {{c8::interpretation}}). Under the {{c9::UCC}}, even where there is a writing, its terms may be explained or supplemented by {{c10::course of dealing, course of performance, and usage of trade}}, though {{c11::express terms}} generally control.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. Malicious prosecution 1.1 Definition: D initiates a {{c1::frivolous charge or claim}} against P with an {{c2::improper purpose}} (for example, filing a false police report). 1.2 Elements 1.2.1 D {{c3::commenced a prior criminal or civil legal proceeding}} against P. (Note: {{c4::Prosecutors are immune}}.) 1.2.2 The prior proceeding {{c5::terminated in P's favor}}. 1.2.3 There was {{c6::no probable cause}} for the original proceeding (for example, D knew P was not guilty in a criminal case or not liable in a civil case, or D had {{c7::insufficient facts to reasonably believe}} in P's guilt or fault). 1.2.4 D had an {{c8::improper purpose}} in initiating the proceeding. 1.2.5 P suffered {{c9::damages}}. 2. Abuse of process 2.1 Definition: D {{c10::uses the legal system}} for an {{c11::ulterior purpose}} to threaten or act against P. 2.2 Elements 2.2.1 {{c12::Wrongful use of process}} for an ulterior purpose. 2.2.2 A {{c13::definite act or threat}} against P to accomplish that ulterior purpose.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Parties may amend their pleadings once as a {{c1::matter of course}}. Additional amendments may be granted with consent of the other parties or with court permission ({{c2::amendment without right}}). 1. {{c3::Amendment as a matter of course}}: 1.1 Within {{c4::21 days}} after service of the pleading; or 1.2 If the pleading is one that requires a response, within {{c5::21 days}} of service of the {{c6::responsive pleading or pre-answer motion}} (e.g., a Rule 12 motion). For example, if the defendant answers the plaintiff's complaint, the plaintiff has 21 days from service of the answer to amend the complaint as a matter of course. 1.3 A party has {{c7::14 days}}, or the time remaining on the initial 21-day deadline (whichever is longer), to respond to an amended pleading. 2. {{c8::Amendment without right}}: 2.1 With the {{c9::written consent of the adverse party}}; or 2.2 With {{c10::leave of court}} (i.e., the court's permission), sought by motion. Leave should be granted freely when {{c11::justice so requires}} (a lenient standard). In deciding whether to grant leave, the court looks to: 2.2.1 The {{c12::length of and reasons for the movant's delay}}; 2.2.2 Potential {{c13::prejudice}} to the parties; and 2.2.3 {{c14::Futility}} of amendment.

subject: Torts
cloze: Inadequate warning (warning/instruction defect): 1. Basic duty to warn: 1.1 A manufacturer must adequately warn of {{c1::non-obvious risks}} associated with a product's use. 1.2 The duty includes warning of {{c2::foreseeable dangers from misuse}} of the product. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – adequacy of warnings: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that the product failed to have {{c3::clear and complete warnings}} of any dangers that would not have been {{c4::ordinarily apparent to consumers}}. 3. Unavoidably unsafe products: 3.1 Some products cannot be made safe for their ordinary use (e.g., chain saws, firearms). 3.2 For such {{c5::unavoidably unsafe products}}, the manufacturer must give: 3.2.1 {{c6::Proper instructions for use}}; and 3.2.2 {{c7::Adequate warnings of known dangers}}. 4. Foreseeability limit on duty to warn: 4.1 The manufacturer is not liable for risks that were {{c8::unforeseeable at the time the product was marketed}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A {{c1::fair process}} (e.g., notice, hearings) is required for the government to take or deprive a person's {{c2::life, liberty, or property}}. Due process rights arise only if the government {{c3::acts to deprive an individual}}, not when the government acts generally. 1. Analysis: 1.1 Has there been a deprivation of life, liberty, or property? 1.1.1 {{c4::Liberty deprivation}} exists when there is a loss of {{c5::significant freedom of action}} or a freedom provided by the {{c6::Constitution or statute}} (e.g., institutionalization, government restriction of fundamental rights). 1.1.2 {{c7::Property deprivation}} exists when there is a {{c8::legitimate claim or entitlement}} to a benefit under law that goes unfulfilled (e.g., public school attendance, welfare). 1.2 What procedures are required? (determined by balancing): 1.2.1 {{c9::Importance of the individual interest}} involved; 1.2.2 {{c10::Value of additional or substitute procedural safeguards}} to that interest; against 1.2.3 The {{c11::government’s interest}} (i.e., fiscal or administrative efficiency). Usually, fair procedures, an {{c12::unbiased decision-maker}}, and {{c13::notice}} of the government’s action will be required. 2. Examples where procedural due process requirements arise include: {{c14::terminating welfare or social security benefits}}; {{c15::separating a child from parents}}; {{c16::punitive damages awards}}; and determining {{c17::enemy combatant status}} for citizens captured in foreign countries.

subject: Torts
cloze: Public nuisance – definition and private recovery: 1. Definition: {{c1::Public nuisance}} is an {{c2::unreasonable interference}} with the {{c3::health, safety, or property rights}} of the {{c4::community at large}}. 2. Who may sue: • Usually brought by a {{c5::public authority}} on behalf of the public. • A {{c6::private party}} may recover only if she suffered {{c7::unique damage not suffered by the public at large}} (a {{c8::special injury}}).

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General Eighth Amendment rule: 1.1 The {{c1::Eighth Amendment}} prohibits {{c2::cruel and unusual punishment}}. 1.2 This includes a prohibition on punishments that are {{c3::grossly disproportionate to the offense}}. 2. Disproportionality and juveniles: 2.1 An example of gross disproportionality is a {{c4::life sentence for minor vandalism}}. 2.2 {{c5::Life without parole}} is not permissible for {{c6::juveniles convicted of non-homicide crimes}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Private nuisance – definition and elements: 1. Definition: {{c1::Private nuisance}} is a {{c2::substantial, unreasonable interference}} with another individual’s {{c3::use or enjoyment of her property}}. 2. {{c4::Substantial interference}}: • Must be {{c5::offensive, annoying, or inconvenient}} to the {{c6::average person in the community}}. • Not substantial if the plaintiff is {{c7::hypersensitive}} or using the property for a {{c8::specialized, abnormal purpose}}. 3. {{c9::Unreasonable interference}}: • The {{c10::severity of the plaintiff’s injury}} must {{c11::outweigh the utility}} of the defendant’s conduct. • An interference can be {{c12::substantial but not unreasonable}} (e.g., {{c13::required train horns in a city center}}).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Waste between co-tenants}} 1.1 A co-tenant can bring an {{c2::action for waste}} against another co-tenant whose conduct harms or improperly alters the property. 1.2 Types of waste may include {{c3::affirmative waste}} (voluntary acts that substantially reduce value), {{c4::permissive waste}} (neglect causing deterioration), and {{c5::ameliorative waste}} (unauthorized changes that alter the property's character), depending on the jurisdiction. 1.3 Waste actions may be brought {{c6::during the life of the co-tenancy}} to prevent or remedy improper uses. 2. {{c7::Partition and sale}} 2.1 Any co-tenant generally has the right to seek {{c8::judicial partition}}. 2.2 {{c9::Partition in kind}}: If feasible, a court prefers to {{c10::physically divide the property}} among co-tenants. 2.3 {{c11::Partition by sale}}: If physical division is not practical or would significantly reduce value, a court may order a {{c12::sale}} and {{c13::apportion the proceeds}} according to co-tenants' interests. 3. {{c14::Agreements not to partition}} 3.1 Co-tenants may {{c15::agree not to partition}} the property. 3.2 Such agreements are enforceable only if limited to a {{c16::reasonable duration}} and serve {{c17::legitimate purposes}}. 3.3 An agreement that {{c18::permanently or unreasonably restricts partition}} is {{c19::void as an unreasonable restraint on alienation}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Implied warranties in products liability: 1. Types of implied warranties: 1.1 Warranty of {{c1::merchantability}}: Goods must be of {{c2::average acceptable quality}} and fit for their {{c3::ordinary purpose}}. 1.2 Warranty of {{c4::fitness for a particular purpose}}: Arises when the {{c5::seller knows the buyer’s particular purpose}} and the {{c6::buyer relies on the seller’s skill or judgment}}. 2. Who is protected: Protection extends to the {{c7::buyer}} and the buyer’s {{c8::family, household, and guests}} who suffer personal injury. 3. Claim structure: Plaintiff must prove an applicable {{c9::implied warranty}}, {{c10::breach}}, {{c11::causation}} (actual and proximate), and {{c12:damages}} (personal, property, or economic), subject to defenses such as {{c13::assumption of risk}} and {{c14::contributory/comparative negligence}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Certain categories of information are generally {{c1::undiscoverable}} because they are {{c2::privileged}}.
