These include: - {{c3::Attorney–client}} privilege. - {{c4::Work-product}} protection. - {{c5::Physician–patient}} privilege. - {{c6::Clergy–penitent}} privilege. - {{c7::Marital}} privilege. - {{c8::Journalist–source}} privilege (in some contexts). - {{c9::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}}. If material is protected by one of these privileges, it is generally {{c10::outside the scope of discovery}} unless an exception applies.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::tenancy at sufferance}} is the default tenancy that arises when a tenant {{c2::continues to possess property after the lease expires}} (i.e., a {{c3::holdover tenant}}). 2. Creation: 2.1 The tenant {{c4::holds possession beyond the lease's expiration}}. 2.2 The {{c5::expired lease's terms and conditions}} automatically carry over to govern the tenancy at sufferance. 3. Landlord's options: 3.1 {{c6::Sue to evict}} (and recover damages), or 3.2 {{c7::Impose a new periodic tenancy}}. 3.2.1 {{c8::Raised rent}}: The landlord can demand {{c9::higher rent}} for both the holdover period and any new periodic tenancy if the landlord gave {{c10::notice of the increase before}} the lease expired. 3.2.2 {{c11::Commercial leases}}: If the expired lease was for {{c12::one year or longer}}, the new periodic tenancy can be {{c13::year-to-year}}. 4. Exception: Imposing a new periodic tenancy must be {{c14::reasonable}}. 4.1 A new periodic tenancy is unreasonable if: 4.1.1 The tenant only remains in possession for {{c15::a few hours}}. 4.1.2 The tenant is {{c16::not at fault}} for the delay in vacating (for example, due to illness). 4.1.3 The lease is {{c17::seasonal}} (for example, a ski cabin or beach house).

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}}: In a {{c2::common law marriage}}, a couple is legally considered married without having registered or performed the usual legal requirements for marriage; common law marriage has been {{c3::abolished in most states}}. 2. {{c4::Requirements}} (where recognized, a common law marriage is established by) 2.1 {{c5::Consent}}: There must be an exchange of consent between two people to be in a {{c6::permanent, exclusive marital relationship}}; an agreement to {{c7::cohabitate alone is insufficient}}. 2.2 {{c8::Cohabitation}}: The couple must cohabitate. 2.3 {{c9::Holding out publicly as spouses}}: The parties must hold themselves out publicly as spouses living together, for example by using a {{c10::joint bank account}}, sharing the {{c11::same last name}}, or {{c12::telling others they are married}}. 3. {{c13::Recognition in other states}}: Though largely abolished, if a valid common law marriage is formed under one state's laws, it is generally recognized as a valid marriage in other states, even in states where common law marriage is illegal.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Fundamental rights are protected under both the {{c1::5th Amendment}} (federal) and the {{c2::14th Amendment}} (states). 1. {{c3::Substantive Due Process (SDP)}} 1.1. SDP applies when a law or government action {{c4::denies a right to everyone}} or regulates everyone the same way with respect to that right (no classification among groups). 1.2. If a {{c5::fundamental right}} is burdened, {{c6::strict scrutiny}} applies; if not, the law receives {{c7::rational basis}} review. 2. {{c8::Equal Protection (EP)}} 2.1. EP applies when a law or government action {{c9::grants or denies a right to some people but not others}}, creating a classification. 2.2. If a classification burdens a {{c5::fundamental right}} (such as voting or travel), {{c6::strict scrutiny}} usually applies. 3. {{c7::Rational basis}} review 3.1. When no fundamental right is implicated, whether under SDP or EP, the government action is reviewed under {{c7::rational basis}}, and will be upheld if it is {{c10::rationally related}} to a {{c11::legitimate government interest}}.

subject: Agency
cloze: Agency concerns the relationship that exists between an {{c1::agent}} and a {{c2::principal}} whereby the agent {{c3::acts on the principal's behalf}} and is subject to the principal's {{c4::control}}. The {{c5::principal}} is the person for whom the agent acts, and the {{c6::agent}} is the person who acts on the principal’s behalf and is subject to the principal’s control.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Rule Against Perpetuities – Covered Interests and Analysis Steps 1. Interests Subject to RAP 1.1 RAP applies to: (a) {{c1::Contingent remainders}}. (b) {{c2::Gifts to open classes}}. (c) {{c3::Executory interests}}. 1.2 In many jurisdictions, RAP also applies to: (a) {{c4::Options to purchase}}. (b) {{c5::Rights of first refusal}}. 1.3 RAP does {{c6::not apply}} to {{c7::vested remainders}}. 2. Step-by-Step RAP Analysis 2.1 {{c8::Determine the interests created}} by the conveyance, identifying all future interests. 2.2 {{c9::Isolate the interests}} that are of a type covered by RAP. 2.3 For each covered interest, {{c10::select an appropriate measuring life}} and ask whether the interest {{c11::must vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after that life’s death}}. 2.4 If there is any {{c12::possibility, no matter how remote}}, that the interest could vest beyond {{c13::21 years after the measuring life’s death}}, the interest {{c14::violates RAP and is void}}. 2.5 If an interest violates RAP, {{c15::strike only the offending future interest}} from the conveyance. 2.6 Whatever remains after striking the invalid interest is {{c16::enforced as the new conveyance}}. 3. Modern Reforms (Exam Note) 3.1 Many states have {{c17::reformed the common law RAP}}, often by providing an {{c18::alternative vesting period}} such as a {{c19::90-year wait-and-see period}}. 3.2 On the bar exam, unless told otherwise, apply the {{c20::traditional common law RAP}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::remainder}} is a {{c2::future interest in a third person}} (someone other than the grantor) that becomes possessory {{c3::immediately upon the natural termination}} of a prior estate of known, fixed duration (usually a life estate or term of years), and {{c4::does not cut short the prior estate}}. A remainder must be {{c5::expressly created in the same conveyance}} in which the preceding estate is created. A remainder is {{c6::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}. A true remainder {{c7::cannot cut off or divest an interest held by a prior transferee}}; if it does, it is an {{c8::executory interest}}, not a remainder.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Three types of vested remainders 1.1 {{c1::Indefeasibly vested remainder}} 1.1.1 Becomes {{c2::possessory immediately and certainly}} upon termination of the prior estate. 1.1.2 There is {{c3::no condition subsequent}} that can cut off the interest once it becomes possessory. 1.2 {{c4::Vested remainder subject to total divestment}} 1.2.1 The interest is vested, but it is subject to a {{c5::condition subsequent}}. 1.2.2 The remainderman can be {{c6::divested after taking possession}} if the condition subsequent occurs. 1.3 {{c7::Vested remainder subject to open}} ({{c8::class gift}}) 1.3.1 The remainder is vested in a described {{c9::class of takers}}, at least one of whom is {{c10::alive and capable of taking possession}}. 1.3.2 The class can {{c11::expand as additional qualifying members are born}}. 1.3.3 The share of existing class members can be {{c12::partially reduced}} as the class opens to additional members.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 1. General Rule: {{c1::Express choice-of-law provisions in contracts}} are generally {{c2::adhered to regardless of the choice-of-law approach}} that would otherwise be applied by a court. Where no choice-of-law provision exists, courts will use one of the {{c3::three choice-of-law approaches}}. 2. Exceptions: Choice-of-law provisions in the contract will not be applied or honored where: 2.1 {{c4::Contrary to public policy}}: Applying the law of the contract-designated forum would conflict with a {{c5::fundamental policy of a different forum that has a materially greater interest}} than the designated forum in determining the particular issue. 2.2 {{c6::No substantial relationship}}: The contracting parties' chosen forum bears {{c7::no substantial relationship to the parties or the transaction}}, such that there is no reasonable basis for the choice. 2.3 {{c8::Lack of consent}}: There was {{c9::no true consent by all parties to the choice of the designated forum}}; this can arise due to {{c10::fraud, mistake, or contracts of adhesion}}. 3. Default rules: Express choice-of-law provisions are always enforced with regard to {{c11::default (as opposed to mandatory) rules}}. Default rules are {{c12::gap fillers that can be modified by agreement of the parties}} even in entirely local matters.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under the doctrine of {{c1::ademption}}, a gift of {{c2::specific property}} in a will fails if it is no longer in the testator's estate at death. 1. Applies to {{c3::specific devises only}} 1.1. Ademption only occurs with {{c4::specific gifts that are satisfied only by giving the actual described property}}. 1.2. Example: T's will gives T's diamond necklace to A, but T sells it before her death. Upon T's death, the gift to A is adeemed (it fails) because the gift was a specific item of irreplaceable property. 2. Not applicable to {{c5::general or demonstrative devises}} 2.1. {{c6::General devise}}: gift of a dollar amount payable from the estate's assets. 2.2. {{c7::Demonstrative devise}}: gift of a general amount that identifies some asset as a source of the payment (e.g., certain stock holdings). Where a general or demonstrative gift cannot be fully satisfied from the identified asset (e.g., the stock is not worth as much as provided in the demonstrative legacy), the estate generally must sell off other property to satisfy the gift. 3. Exception in {{c8::intent-theory states}} 3.1. A minority of states apply the {{c9::"intent theory" of ademption}}, under which an adeemed bequest is saved if evidence establishes that ademption would be inconsistent with the testator's intent. 3.2. Effect: the beneficiary gets {{c10::the monetary value of the specific bequest or replacement property}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. General rule: Once a court enters a decree regarding {{c1::spousal support}}, {{c2::child support}}, or {{c3::child custody}}, the decree generally is only modifiable upon a showing of a {{c4::significant change in circumstances}}. 1.1. Significant change in circumstances required: Standards differ slightly for each type of order, but if modification arises on the exam, look for and note any {{c4::significant change in circumstances}}. 2. Spousal support: 2.1. Changing a support award requires a {{c5::substantial, material, and unanticipated change}} in either party's circumstances. 2.2. {{c6::Self-induced changes}} generally will not justify modifying a support order (e.g., a party cannot voluntarily take a lower-paying job and get reduced support obligations). 3. Child support: 3.1. Child support orders are modifiable based on a {{c7::substantial change in circumstances}} that affects either: 3.1.1. The {{c8::needs of the children}}, or 3.1.2. The {{c9::ability of the parent to pay}}. 3.2. {{c6::Self-induced changes}}: Same rules as for spousal support. 4. Child custody: 4.1. Modification of a child custody order requires the parent to show a {{c5::substantial, material change in circumstances}}. 4.2. Courts will not change a custody order unless the change is in the child's {{c10::best interests}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 An {{c1::assignment}} is a transfer of {{c2::rights under a contract}} to a third party after the contract is formed. 1.2 A party (the {{c3::assignor}}) can assign rights under a contract to a third party (the {{c4::assignee}}), who is then in a contractual relationship with the remaining party (the {{c5::obligor}}). 1.3 {{c6::Consideration}} is not required for an assignment, but an assignment without consideration is considered {{c7::gratuitous}}. 1.4 The assignor can transfer only the {{c8::rights the assignor has}} in a contract at the time of assignment. 2. Common law limitations 2.1 Common law bars any assignment that {{c9::substantially changes the duties of the obligor}}. 2.2 Assignment of the {{c10::right to payment}} is not a substantial change. 2.3 An assignment of rights fails if the obligor's {{c11::risk}} is substantially altered. 3. Contractual limitations on assignment (contracts may contain non-assignment clauses) 3.1 "{{c12::Non-assignment of contract}}" language bars {{c13::delegation of the assignor's duties only}}; it does not prohibit assignment of rights. 3.2 "{{c14::Non-assignment of rights}}" language bars the {{c15::right to assign, but not the power to assign}} (i.e., an assignment is still effective between assignor and assignee, but the obligor may sue the assignor for breach). 3.3 Language stating that any assignment is {{c16::void}} makes an assignment {{c17::ineffective}} (i.e., the assignor has neither the power nor the right to assign).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Robbery}} – general rule: 1.1 {{c2::Wrongful taking}}. 1.2 Of another's {{c3::personal property}}. 1.3 From his {{c4::person or presence}}. 1.4 By {{c5::force or threat of injury}}. 1.5 With the {{c6::intent to permanently deprive}}. 2. Robbery requirements and notes: 2.1 Robbery is {{c7::assault or battery plus larceny}}. 2.2 Victim's {{c4::person or presence}} is interpreted {{c8::broadly}}. 2.3 Force or threat of injury: a {{c9::small amount of force or threat}} will suffice; the threat of injury must be to the {{c10::victim, a member of her family, or a person in her presence}}; and the victim must give up the property because she feels threatened or harmed; {{c11::threats of future harm are insufficient}}. 2.4 Larceny vs. robbery: robbery requires {{c5::force or threats}} to obtain the victim's property, whereas {{c12::larceny}} does not. For example, a {{c13::pickpocket}} commits larceny if the victim does not notice the act, but commits robbery if the victim notices and is confronted by force or threat. 3. {{c14::Extortion}} – general rule: 3.1 Obtaining property through {{c15::threats of future harm or exposing information}}. 3.2 Extortion vs. robbery: extortion does {{c16::not require a taking from the victim's person or presence}}. 3.3 Extortion involves threats of {{c17::future, rather than immediate, harm}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Basic {{c1::Parol Evidence Rule (PER)}}: - Under PER, evidence that is {{c2::extrinsic to a written contract}} is inadmissible to supplement or contradict the written contract when the writing is an {{c3::integration}} of the parties’ agreement. 2. {{c4::Integration}} requirement: - The writing must be intended as a {{c5::final expression}} of the parties’ agreement. - {{c6::Complete integration}}: the writing is intended to be final and the {{c7::complete and exclusive}} statement of the agreement. - {{c8::Partial integration}}: the writing is final as to the terms it contains but {{c9::does not include all terms}} of the agreement. 3. {{c10::Merger (integration) clause}}: - A merger clause recites that the written contract is the {{c11::complete and final agreement}} of the parties. - It is strong evidence of {{c12::integration}} (often complete integration) but is {{c13::not dispositive}}. 4. Temporal scope of PER: - PER bars evidence of {{c14::prior negotiations and agreements}} and {{c15::contemporaneous oral agreements}} that would supplement or contradict the integrated writing. - PER does **not** bar evidence of {{c16::agreements or modifications made after}} the integrated writing.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Federal courts must have authority over the {{c1::claim in question}}, which is {{c2::subject-matter jurisdiction (SMJ)}}, as opposed to {{c3::personal jurisdiction}}, which concerns authority over the {{c4::parties or property}}. 1.1. SMJ refers to the court’s ability to exercise that authority over the {{c5::type of case}}. 2. The {{c6::Constitution}} provides limits on the types of cases that federal courts can hear. 3. SMJ {{c7::cannot be waived}}. 4. Types of federal subject-matter jurisdiction: 4.1. {{c8::Diversity jurisdiction}}. 4.2. {{c9::Federal-question jurisdiction}}. 4.3. {{c10::Supplemental jurisdiction}}. 4.4. {{c11::Removal jurisdiction}}. 5. By contrast, {{c12::state courts}} are presumed to have subject-matter jurisdiction over all types of cases, except where federal courts have {{c13::exclusive}} SMJ. 5.1. In a narrow set of cases, federal courts have exclusive SMJ (e.g., {{c14::patent infringement}}).

subject: Contracts
cloze: Buyer {{c1::breaches}} and the {{c2::seller has the goods}}: 1. {{c3::Market damages}}: • Damages = {{c4::contract price − market price at the time of delivery}}. 2. {{c5::Resale and lost-profit damages}}: • Damages = {{c6::contract price − resale price + provable lost profits}}. 3. Choice of measure: • The seller may use either the {{c7::market-minus-contract}} measure or the {{c8::resale-plus-lost-profits}} measure, depending on which better captures the loss, especially for {{c9::lost-volume sellers}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: {{c1::Easement appurtenant}} entitles the owner of a {{c2::dominant estate}} to use a {{c3::servient estate}}'s land and {{c4::passes automatically with the dominant estate}} even if not mentioned in a conveyance. An {{c5::easement in gross}} entitles an {{c6::individual or entity, not a dominant landowner}} to use the {{c7::servient estate}}, attaches only to the {{c8::servient estate}}, and there is {{c9::no dominant estate}}. Typical examples include rights to place {{c10::billboards}}, run {{c11::utility lines}}, or {{c12::fish}} in another's pond. Unlike a {{c13::license}}, an easement in gross is generally {{c14::irrevocable}} and may be {{c15::transferred}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. When an implied promise in a land sale contract is breached, the buyer must {{c1::notify the seller before closing}} and give a {{c2::reasonable time}} to {{c3::cure}} the defect. 2. If the seller fails to cure, the buyer may: 2.1 {{c4::Rescind}} the contract. 2.2 Sue for {{c5::damages}}. 2.3 Demand {{c6::specific performance}}. 2.4 File a suit to {{c7::quiet title}} where title is in dispute. 3. Under the {{c8::merger doctrine}}, if the buyer does not raise the defect before closing, the land sale contract {{c9::merges into the deed}}. 4. After merger, the seller is generally not liable for {{c10::contractual promises}} in the land sale contract, and the buyer’s remedies are limited to {{c11::covenants in the deed}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 A {{c1::delegation}} occurs when one party to a contract (the {{c2::delegator}}) delegates the {{c3::duties}} she owes to another party to the contract (the {{c4::obligee}}) to a third party (the {{c5::delegatee}}). 1.2 The obligee must generally {{c6::accept performance from the delegatee}}. 1.3 Only {{c7::duties}} may be delegated, whereas {{c8::rights}} are transferred to a third party via {{c9::assignment}}. 2. {{c10::Liability}}: 2.1 The delegator {{c11::remains liable}} for the delegatee's performance. 2.2 The obligee may sue the {{c12::delegator}} for {{c13::non-performance by the delegatee}}. 2.3 The obligee may sue the {{c14::delegatee}} only if the delegatee has {{c15::assumed the duties of the entire contract}}. 3. Exceptions (duties are {{c16::non-delegable}} if): 3.1 The duties involve {{c17::personal judgment or skill}}. 3.2 Delegation would {{c18::materially change the obligee's expectancy}} under the contract. 3.3 The contract {{c19::prohibits delegation}}. 3.4 Delegation is prohibited by {{c20::statute or public policy}}. 4. {{c21::Delegation vs. novation}}: 4.1 A {{c22::novation}} arises when all parties agree that a substitute person will take over duties under the contract. 4.2 A delegation occurs when one party unilaterally decides to delegate duties to a third party, but the original obligor (delegator) {{c23::remains liable absent novation}}.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: Under {{c1::partnership by estoppel}}, even where no actual partnership exists, parties may be held liable as if they were partners if: • They {{c2::hold themselves or others out as partners}} or {{c3::consent to being held out as partners}}; and • A {{c4::third party relies}} on that holding out in dealing with them. Effect: For that transaction, the law treats them as if a {{c5::partnership}} existed, potentially making them {{c6::jointly and severally liable}} as partners to the relying third party.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In General 1.1. Consideration is a {{c1::bargained-for exchange of legal value}} between the parties. 1.2. There must be a {{c2::benefit to the promisor}} or a {{c3::detriment to the promisee}}. 1.3. Consideration is a required element of every contract: the {{c4::promise must induce the detriment, and the detriment must induce the promise}}. 2. Detriment and Pre-Existing Duty 2.1. Detriment is an obligation to {{c5::do or refrain from doing something one would otherwise not be obligated to do or refrain from doing}}. 2.2. {{c6::Pre-existing duty}}: A promise to perform a pre-existing duty or obligation generally {{c7::does not constitute consideration}}. 2.3. Exception: A promise to {{c8::pay a debt after the statute of limitations has run}} is binding despite lack of new consideration. 3. Invalid Consideration 3.1. The following do not constitute consideration: 3.1.1. {{c9::Promises of gifts or conditional gifts}} (where the condition is merely a way to receive the gift). 3.1.2. {{c10::Illusory promises}}: a promise where there is {{c11::no real obligation to perform}} (for example, "I will do your chores if I feel like it" or "if I have time"). 4. {{c12::Promissory Estoppel}} (Reliance) 4.1. Courts may enforce a promise without consideration under promissory estoppel if: 4.1.1. The {{c13::promisor reasonably expects reliance}} by the promisee; 4.1.2. The {{c14::promisee acts or refrains from acting in detrimental reliance}}; and 4.1.3. {{c15::Injustice can be avoided only by enforcement}} of the promise.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Bystander claims for emotional distress}}: 1. General rule: When D's conduct is directed at a {{c2::third person}} and P (the bystander) suffers {{c3::severe emotional distress}}, P must prove the same {{c4::IIED elements}} with additional {{c5::intent and causation requirements}}. 2. Elements (IIED): 2.1 {{c6::Extreme and outrageous conduct}} by D. 2.2 {{c7::Severe emotional distress}} in P. 2.3 {{c8::Intent or recklessness}}. 2.4 {{c9::Causation}}. 3. Additional bystander requirements: 3.1 P was {{c10::present at the time}} of D's conduct. 3.2 P was a {{c11::close relative}} of the third person, or P's distress resulted in {{c12::bodily harm}}. 3.3 D {{c13::knew these facts}}. 4. Note: P does not need to establish the additional bystander requirements if P proves D had a {{c14::design or purpose to cause severe distress to P}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Exceptions that require declarant to be {{c1::unavailable}} 1.1 {{c2::Former testimony}}. 1.2 {{c3::Statements against interest}}. 1.3 {{c4::Dying declarations}}. 1.4 Statements of {{c5::personal or family history}}. 1.5 Statements offered against a party that {{c6::wrongfully procured the declarant's unavailability}}. 2. Meaning of "unavailable" 2.1 "Unavailability" refers to the declarant's {{c7::ability to testify}}. 2.2 For example: a declarant can be physically present in court but still be legally "unavailable" because she asserts a valid {{c8::privilege}}. 2.3 A declarant is unavailable if any of the following applies: 2.3.1 {{c9::Privilege}}: exempt from testifying due to a recognized privilege. 2.3.2 {{c10::Death or physical/mental sickness}} that prevents testimony. 2.3.3 {{c11::Refusal to testify}} despite a court order. 2.3.4 {{c12::Lack of memory}} regarding the subject matter. 2.3.5 {{c13::Absence}}: beyond the reach of the court's subpoena power, and the statement's proponent has not been able to procure the declarant's attendance or testimony by reasonable means.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: Partners in a general partnership have three key sets of default rights: 1. {{c1::Partnership Property}} – what counts as partnership property and how courts determine it. 2. {{c2::Partners’ Interest in Property}} – the partnership’s ownership of specific assets and limits on partners’ individual rights in those assets. 3. {{c3::Profits, Losses, and Management}} – partners’ transferable economic interests, default sharing of profits/losses, and default equal management rights.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A {{c1::mortgage}} is a {{c2::security interest in land}} that serves as collateral for the repayment of a loan (also known as a {{c3::mortgage lien}}). 1.2 Writing required: A mortgage must be in writing to satisfy the {{c4::Statute of Frauds}}. 1.3 {{c5::Mortgagor}}: The mortgagor is the {{c6::debtor/borrower/landowner}}. 1.4 {{c7::Mortgagee}}: The mortgagee is the {{c8::creditor/lender}}. 2. Parties' rights (theories of title) 2.1 {{c9::Lien theory}} (majority): The mortgagor has {{c10::title and the right to possession}} absent foreclosure; the mortgagee has only a {{c11::lien}}, conferring a right to take action for ownership of the land if the mortgagor defaults on the loan. 2.2 {{c12::Title theory}} (minority): The mortgagee has {{c13::title to the property during the loan term}}, not the mortgagor-borrower. 2.3 {{c14::Intermediate theory}} (minority): The mortgagor has title and the right to possession until {{c15::default}} occurs under the mortgage; after default, the mortgagee has title and the right to possession. 2.4 Note: Unless instructed otherwise, assume {{c16::lien theory}} applies on the MBE. 3. {{c17::Equitable mortgage}}; {{c18::acceleration clauses}} 3.1 Equitable mortgage: A debtor gives a creditor a {{c19::deed to his land as collateral}} for the debt (instead of executing a formal mortgage); {{c20::equity treats this as a mortgage}}. 3.2 Acceleration clauses: Terms in loan agreements that require the mortgagor to {{c21::pay off the full loan immediately}} if certain conditions are met (for example, if the mortgagor misses too many payments).

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the old framework, the state’s power to regulate abortion turned on {{c1::viability}}. Pre-viability: 1. The state may not {{c2::prohibit abortion}}. 2. It may regulate only if it does not create an {{c3::undue burden}} on a woman’s right to obtain an abortion. 3. Example of an undue burden: {{c4::spousal notification}} requirements. 4. Examples that are not an undue burden: {{c5::24-hour waiting periods}}, {{c6::partial-birth abortion bans}}, and {{c7::parental consent}} requirements (with proper safeguards). Post-viability: 5. The state may {{c8::prohibit abortion}}. 6. Exception: abortion must still be allowed when {{c9::medically necessary to protect the mother’s health}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: A {{c1::non-marital child}} is one born to an {{c2::unmarried woman}}. 1. Discrimination: 1.1. Distinctions based on {{c3::non-marital child status}} are almost always {{c4::unconstitutional}}. 1.2. If a child is denied benefits or rights (e.g., child support, government benefits, inheritance) due to non-marital status, it is likely {{c4::invalid}}. 2. Establishing {{c5::paternity}}: 2.1. A paternity suit may be brought to establish a non-marital child's {{c6::biological parent}}. 2.2. Such suits are often brought by the {{c7::child or mother}} to obtain {{c8::support}} from the child's father. 2.3. Once paternity is established, a {{c9::duty of support}} attaches. 2.4. Additionally, the father may seek {{c10::visitation}} and {{c11::custody}} rights. 3. Admissible evidence in paternity actions may include: 3.1. {{c12::Blood or genetic tests}}, which parties may be required to take. 3.2. {{c13::Prior statements regarding paternity}} by deceased family members. 3.3. {{c14::Medical testimony}} about a father's {{c15::sterility}} and/or probability of paternity based on {{c16::timing between intercourse and birth}}. 3.4. {{c17::Admissions or acknowledgments}} by the alleged parent.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Sixth Amendment confrontation right: 1.1 The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} gives the defendant the right to {{c2::confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses}}. 2. Main components of the confrontation right: 2.1 {{c3::Confrontation and in-person testimony}}: Adverse witnesses generally must {{c4::testify in person}} and be subject to {{c5::cross-examination}}, subject to limited public-policy exceptions and courtroom control. 2.2 {{c6::Co-defendant confessions (Bruton rule)}}: At a {{c7::joint jury trial}}, a co-defendant’s confession implicating the defendant is generally inadmissible against the defendant, subject to specific exceptions. 2.3 {{c8::Testimonial hearsay}}: Prior testimonial statements of an {{c9::unavailable}} witness are admissible only if the defendant had a prior opportunity to {{c10::cross-examine}} the declarant.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Consent, truth, and privilege}} are valid defenses to defamation. 2. Consent 2.1 {{c2::P consents to one or more required elements}} of defamation. 2.2 For example, P may consent to an {{c3::organization investigating her and sharing its findings with potential employers}}. 3. Truth 3.1 The allegedly defamatory statement is {{c4::true}}. 3.2 {{c5::Truth is a complete defense}} to a defamation claim. 4. Privilege 4.1 Certain types of statements are {{c6::privileged}}. 4.2 {{c7::Absolute privilege}} protects statements by {{c8::government officials in their official capacity}}. 4.3 {{c9::Qualified privilege}} limits D's liability for defamatory statements where: 4.3.1 D is invited to make the statement and/or the {{c10::recipient has an interest in the information}} (for example, an employment reference, credit report, or letter of recommendation); or 4.3.2 The statement is in the {{c11::public interest}} (for example, book reviews or a statement to a parole board).

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Confrontation Clause}} rule 1.1 The {{c1::Confrontation Clause}} bars admission, at a {{c2::joint trial}}, of an {{c3::out-of-court statement}} by a {{c4::non-testifying co-defendant}} if the statement {{c5::expressly implicates another defendant}}. 2. {{c6::Exceptions}} (a co-defendant's out-of-court statement is admissible if either condition is met) 2.1 {{c7::Declarant co-defendant testifies}}: The Confrontation Clause does not bar an out-of-court statement if the declarant co-defendant {{c8::testifies at trial and is subject to cross-examination}}. 2.2 {{c9::Redaction}}: The statement may be admitted if all portions referring to the non-declarant defendant are effectively redacted so that the non-declarant co-defendant's {{c10::identity is truly anonymous}}. 2.3 {{c11::Coerced confession rebuttal}}: The statement may be admitted when it is used solely to {{c12::rebut a charge that the defendant's own confession was coerced}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: If a tenant {{c1::breaches}} leasehold duties but {{c2::remains in possession}} of the premises, the landlord has two primary options: 1. {{c3::Eviction (summary proceeding)}} – the landlord may file a summary proceeding to {{c4::recover possession}}. 2. {{c5::Continue the lease and sue for rent}} – the landlord may keep the lease in effect and {{c6::sue for rent due and other amounts owed}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Negligent infliction of emotional distress ({{c1::NIED}}) allows recovery for {{c2::emotional harm caused by the defendant’s negligence}}, but recovery is typically limited to certain categories: 1. {{c3::Zone-of-danger}} cases (plaintiff is nearly physically harmed and suffers severe emotional distress, often with a physical manifestation requirement or split). 2. {{c4::Bystander}} claims (plaintiff outside the zone of danger, but closely related, present, and personally perceiving the injury to another). 3. {{c5::Special situations}} where negligence creates a {{c6::great likelihood of emotional distress}} (e.g., erroneous report of a relative’s death; mishandling of a corpse).

subject: Real Property
cloze: Nonconforming Uses – Definition, Compensation, and Amortization: 1. Definition 1.1. A nonconforming use is a once lawful existing use of property that becomes nonconforming under a {{c1::new zoning law}}. 2. Protection and compensation 2.1. The government generally cannot eliminate a lawful nonconforming use {{c2::all at once}} unless {{c3::just compensation}} is paid. 3. Amortization 3.1. The government may use {{c4::amortization}} to deal with nonconforming uses. 3.2. Amortization means the government allows the use to continue for a {{c5::set period of time}} or makes payments over a {{c6::set period of time}} until the landowner {{c7::recoups the value of the nonconforming use}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Under {{c1::UCC Article 2}}, an offer for the sale of goods generally must have a {{c2::certain or ascertainable quantity term}}. In {{c3::requirement}} and {{c4::output}} contracts, quantity is measured by the buyer’s requirements or seller’s output, but any increase must be in {{c5::good faith}} and cannot be {{c6::unreasonably disproportionate}} to a stated estimate or prior dealings. The UCC allows many {{c7::missing or open terms}}—especially {{c8::price}}—if the parties {{c9::intended to make a contract}} and there is a {{c10::reasonably certain basis for giving a remedy}} using {{c11::gap-filler provisions}}. However, courts generally {{c12::will not supply a quantity term}} beyond requirement or output structures.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Timing requirements under {{c1::Rule 60(b)}}: 1. General requirement • All Rule 60(b) motions must be made within a {{c2::reasonable time}}. 2. Grounds {{c3::1–3}} (mistake, newly discovered evidence, fraud/misconduct) • Must be brought within a {{c4::reasonable time}}, • And in any event no more than {{c5::one year}} after entry of judgment. 3. Grounds {{c6::4–6}} (void judgment, satisfied judgment, other reasons) • Must be brought within a {{c7::reasonable time}}. • There is {{c8::no one‑year cap}}, though delay must still be reasonable given the circumstances and finality concerns.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, the {{c2::surviving spouse’s share}} depends on the {{c3::family configuration}}. The spouse generally takes {{c4::the entire estate}} when there are only {{c5::shared descendants (and the spouse has no other issue)}} or when the spouse is {{c6::the only close survivor (no descendants or parents)}}. In other configurations, the spouse receives a {{c7::fixed dollar amount}} plus a {{c8::fraction of the remaining estate}}, with the exact amounts depending on whether the decedent leaves {{c9::parents}}, {{c10::shared descendants but the spouse has separate issue}}, or {{c11::non-spousal descendants}}. If there are {{c12::no heirs at all}}, the estate {{c13::escheats to the state}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: In tort cases under the {{c1::Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach}}, courts focus on: 1. Key Tort Contacts: - The {{c2::place of injury}}. - The {{c3::place where the conduct causing the injury occurred}}. - The {{c4::residence, domicile, nationality, place of incorporation, and place of business of the parties}}. 2. Most Significant Factor: - The {{c5::place of injury and the conduct that caused the injury}} are treated as the {{c6::most significant factors}}, especially when they occur in the same state.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::A condition}} is an agreed-upon {{c2::limitation on performance}} that makes a party's duty {{c3::contingent on the occurrence of some event}}. 1.1 Conditions are often indicated by words such as {{c4::"if," "provided that," "on condition that"}}. 1.2 {{c5::Condition vs. promise}}: Failure of a {{c6::promise}} is a {{c7::breach}} with damages; failure of a {{c8::condition}} means the related {{c9::performance obligation does not arise or is discharged}}. 2. Types of conditions: 2.1 Conditions may be {{c10::express or implied}}. 2.2 Main timing categories: • {{c11::Condition precedent}} – must occur {{c12::before performance is due}}. • {{c13::Condition subsequent}} – occurs {{c14::after performance has begun}} and, when it occurs, {{c15::excuses the duty to continue performing}}. 3. Interpretation, waiver, and excuse: 3.1 Courts interpret conditions in light of their {{c16::purpose}} and the parties' {{c17::intent}}. 3.2 A party protected by a condition may {{c18::waive}} it or be {{c19::estopped}} from enforcing it. 3.3 Conditions may be excused by {{c20::breach, anticipatory repudiation, waiver, or wrongful prevention or hindrance}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. General rule for lesser included offenses - A defendant cannot be convicted of a {{c1::target crime}} and a {{c2::lesser included offense}}. 2. Definition of lesser included offense - A lesser included offense consists of the {{c3::same, but not all, elements}} as the {{c4::greater crime}}. 3. Example - The defendant robs the victim, and during the robbery the defendant’s accomplice kills the victim. - The defendant can be convicted of {{c5::felony murder}} but not the lesser included {{c6::robbery}} offense. 4. Relationship to double jeopardy - This merger result is also barred by {{c7::double jeopardy}}, which prohibits {{c8::multiple punishments for the same offense}}. 5. Different-victim rule - Crimes with {{c9::different victims}} never merge.

subject: Contracts
cloze: A {{c1::modification}} changes the terms of an existing contract, while a {{c2::novation}} substitutes a new party and extinguishes the old party’s obligations. At {{c3::common law}}, modification generally requires {{c4::mutual assent}} and {{c5::consideration}} (subject to a modern {{c6::fair‑and‑unanticipated circumstances}} exception). Under the {{c7::UCC}}, {{c8::good‑faith modifications}} do not require consideration but may need to be in {{c9::writing}} under the {{c10::Statute of Frauds}} or a contract clause requiring written modifications. A novation is a new contract that {{c11::substitutes a new party}}, {{c12::extinguishes duties between the original parties}}, and {{c13::releases the original party}} from further contractual obligations and liability.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Incapacity}} – A party lacks legal capacity (e.g., {{c2::minor}}, {{c3::mentally incompetent}}, sometimes {{c4::severely intoxicated}}). Such contracts are generally {{c5::void or voidable}} by the incapacitated party. 2. {{c6::Statute of Frauds (SoF)}} – Certain contracts must satisfy {{c7::formal requirements}} (usually a {{c8::writing signed}} by the party to be charged). Failure to comply generally makes the contract {{c9::unenforceable}} against that party. 3. {{c10::Illegality}} – The contract’s {{c11::subject matter or purpose}} is illegal or against {{c12::public policy}} (e.g., crime, tort, usury). Such contracts are typically {{c13::void and unenforceable}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 1. In General: 1.1 When a transaction or event is connected to more than one {{c1::jurisdiction}}, and the potentially applicable laws differ, a {{c2::choice-of-law (COL)}} analysis is required to determine which law to apply. 1.2 There are three main approaches; generally, states use one of the following COL tests: 1.2.1 {{c3::Vested Rights Approach}} of the {{c4::First Restatement}}; 1.2.2 {{c5::Most Significant Relationship Approach}} of the {{c6::Second Restatement}}; and 1.2.3 {{c7::Governmental Interest Approach}}. 2. Diversity cases: 2.1 A federal court exercising {{c8::diversity jurisdiction}} over non-federal claims must apply the COL approach of the {{c9::state in which it sits}}. 2.2 Example: A federal court in State A exercising diversity jurisdiction over a tort claim filed by a citizen of State A against a citizen of State B must apply {{c10::State A's}} COL approach.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A {{c1::request for admission (RFA)}} under {{c2::FRCP 36}} is a written request that a {{c3::party}} admit the truth of {{c4::discoverable information}}, including {{c5::facts}}, {{c6::the application of law to fact}}, or the {{c7::genuineness of documents}}. If a matter is admitted, it is {{c8::conclusively established for purposes of the action}} and {{c9::need not be litigated at trial}}; the requesting party may {{c10::show the admission to the jury}}. The responding party must respond within {{c11::30 days from service}} (unless modified) by {{c12::admitting, denying, or stating that it lacks knowledge or information after a reasonable inquiry}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: The court may issue {{c1::sanctions}} for Rule 11 violations, either on the {{c2::court's own initiative}} or on an {{c3::opposing party's motion}}. 1. Limits on monetary sanctions: the court may not impose {{c4::monetary sanctions on represented parties for frivolous legal contentions}}, but may impose them on the attorney. 2. {{c5::Safe harbor}} (party-initiated motions only): 2.1 A Rule 11 motion is served but may not be filed with the court for {{c6::21 days}}, creating a safe harbor. 2.2 During this 21-day period, the opposing party may {{c7::withdraw the offending document or otherwise remedy the problem}}. 2.3 If the problem is not remedied or withdrawn within 21 days, the motion can be filed. 2.4 The judge need not provide a safe harbor when acting {{c8::on the court's own initiative}}. 3. Opportunity to be heard: before imposing sanctions, the court must give the attorney or party a {{c9::chance to be heard}}. 4. Monetary vs. non-monetary sanctions: the Rules {{c10::discourage monetary sanctions}} by urging {{c11::non-monetary sanctions}} and by creating a default rule that monetary sanctions are {{c12::payable to the court rather than to the movant}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Counteroffer 1.1. A counteroffer is a response to an offer that {{c1::adds new terms or changes the terms}} instead of purely accepting. 1.2. A counteroffer {{c2::terminates the original offer}} and {{c3::becomes a new offer}}. 2. Mere Bargaining / Requests for Information 2.1. Mere {{c4::bargaining or requests for information}} are {{c5::not counteroffers}}. 2.2. Questions like {{c6::"Would you consider..." or "Can you do any better on the price?"}} usually indicate bargaining, not a counteroffer. 2.3. Mere bargaining or information requests {{c7::do not terminate}} the original offer; the offeree {{c8::retains the power of acceptance}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. UCC Acceptance with Additional Terms 1.1. Under the {{c1::UCC}}, an expression of acceptance can include {{c2::additional terms}}. 1.2. First determine whether {{c3::both parties are merchants}}. 2. Both Parties Are Merchants 2.1. A {{c4::contract is formed}} despite additional terms. 2.2. The additional terms generally {{c5::become part of the contract unless}}: 2.2.1. The additional terms {{c6::materially change}} the offer; or 2.2.2. The offer {{c7::expressly limits acceptance}} to its own terms; or 2.2.3. The {{c8::offeror objects}} to the additional terms within a {{c9::reasonable time}}. 3. One or Both Parties Are Not Merchants 3.1. A contract is formed on the {{c10::original terms of the offer}}. 3.2. The additional terms {{c11::do not automatically become part}} of the contract. 3.3. The additional terms are treated as {{c12::proposals for addition}} to the contract.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Unconscionability allows a court to refuse to enforce all or part of a contract. 1. General rule: 1.1 Courts may refuse to enforce all or part of a contract that is {{c1::unfair or oppressive}} to one party. 1.2 The focus is on the {{c2::bargaining process}} and/or the {{c3::contract terms}}. 2. {{c4::Procedural unconscionability}} (bargaining process): 2.1 Involves unfairness in how the contract was formed (e.g., high-pressure sales tactics, fine print, surprise, or lack of meaningful choice). 2.2 Look for an {{c5::absence of meaningful choice}} by the disadvantaged party. 3. {{c6::Substantive unconscionability}} (contract terms): 3.1 Involves overly {{c7::harsh or one-sided terms}}. 3.2 Common examples include {{c8::adhesion contracts}} and {{c9::exculpatory clauses for intentional acts}}. 4. Effect: 4.1 If a court finds unconscionability, it may {{c10::refuse to enforce the contract}}, {{c11::enforce the remainder without the unconscionable term}}, or {{c12::limit the application}} of an unconscionable term.

subject: Agency
cloze: An agency relationship can be created by: 1. {{c1::Agreement by the parties}} – the principal and agent agree, expressly or impliedly, to the agency; a writing is not required. 2. {{c2::Apparent authority}} – the principal {{c3::holds another out as her agent}} to a third party, causing the third party reasonably to believe the person is authorized to act for the principal. 3. {{c4::Ratification}} – the principal {{c5::retroactively agrees to be bound}} by the previously unauthorized acts of an agent or purported agent, with knowledge of material facts and acceptance of the transaction or its benefits.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Protective sweeps}}: 1.1. Following an arrest in a home or building, police may conduct a {{c2::limited protective sweep}} of spaces immediately adjoining the arrest area. 1.2. Standard: Officers must have a {{c3::reasonable belief}} (based on specific facts) that {{c4::accomplices may be present}} or that there is {{c5::danger}}. 1.3. Scope: A {{c6::cursory inspection for persons}} (not a full evidentiary search), generally limited to spaces where a person could be hiding; expansion beyond adjoining areas requires {{c7::articulable facts suggesting danger}}. 2. {{c8::Inventory searches}}: 2.1. When jailing an arrested suspect or impounding property, police may conduct an inventory search of the {{c9::arrestee’s belongings or seized property}}. 2.2. Purpose: To {{c10::protect the owner’s property}}, {{c11::prevent claims of theft}}, and {{c12::maintain jail/impound security}}, not to search primarily for evidence. 2.3. Requirement: The inventory must be conducted pursuant to {{c13::standardized, good-faith procedures}} and may not be a {{c14::pretext for an investigatory search}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Under the UCC, damages in a sales contract depend on: (1) who {{c1::breached}} ({{c2::seller}} or {{c3::buyer}}); and (2) who {{c4::has the goods}} (buyer keeps, returns, or seller retains). For a {{c5::seller's breach}}, the buyer's damages differ based on whether the buyer {{c6::keeps the goods}} (usually {{c7::value-as-warranted minus value-as-delivered}}) or {{c8::returns/never receives}} them (usually {{c9::market-minus-contract}} or {{c10::cover-minus-contract}}, whichever is higher). For a {{c11::buyer's breach}}, the seller's damages differ based on whether the buyer {{c12::has the goods}} (often the {{c13::contract price}}) or the {{c14::seller keeps the goods}} (usually {{c15::contract-minus-market}} or {{c16::contract-minus-resale plus lost profits}}). Separate rules govern {{c17::conversion}} ({{c18::FMV at time of conversion}}), and in all cases both buyers and sellers may also recover additional {{c19::lost profits}} and other {{c20::incidental or consequential damages}} where available.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. In general: Plaintiff must {{c1::prove damages}} in negligence; damages are {{c2::not presumed}}, and {{c3::nominal damages are not available}}. 2. Types of damages: 2.1 {{c4::Personal injury damages}}: Defendant must compensate plaintiff for {{c5::all personal injury damages}}, including {{c6::past, present, and prospective}} damages. Both {{c7::economic and non-economic}} damages are recoverable. 2.2 {{c8::Property damage}}: Plaintiff can recover the {{c9::reasonable cost of repairs}}. If the property is irreparable, damages are the {{c10::full market value at the time the accident occurred}}. 2.3 {{c11::Punitive damages}}: Only recoverable if defendant's conduct is {{c12::wanton and willful, reckless, or malicious}}. Punitive damages are usually {{c13::not available in negligence cases}} and are more common with {{c14::intentional torts}}. 3. {{c15::Non-recoverable damages}} (plaintiff can never recover for): 3.1 {{c16::Interest from the date of damage in personal injury cases}}. 3.2 {{c17::Attorneys' fees}}. 4. {{c18::Duty to mitigate}}: Plaintiff must take {{c19::reasonable steps to mitigate damages}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Foreclosure reallocates rights among multiple creditors based on {{c1::priority rules}}. 1. {{c2::Priority of creditors}} - Creditors must {{c3::record}} their interests, and recorded interests usually take priority in the order of {{c4::recording}}. - {{c5::Purchase money mortgages (PMMs)}}, given to finance the purchase of the property, are {{c6::superior}} to other interests; if both a {{c7::seller PMM}} and a {{c8::third-party lender PMM}} exist, the {{c9::seller's PMM}} is senior. - Parties can alter the normal priority order by {{c10::subordination agreements}}. 2. {{c11::Effect of foreclosure on junior vs. senior interests}} - A properly conducted foreclosure of a {{c12::senior mortgage}} {{c13::terminates joined junior interests}}, leaving junior lienholders to seek {{c14::deficiency judgments}} against the debtor but not the land; junior lienholders are {{c15::necessary parties}} to a senior foreclosure. - Foreclosure of a {{c16::junior mortgage}} does {{c17::not affect senior interests}}; the buyer at a junior foreclosure sale takes the property {{c18::subject to}} all senior mortgages, which {{c19::remain enforceable against the land}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule on similar occurrences}} 1.1 Evidence of prior similar occurrences concerning the time, event, or person in the present controversy is often inadmissible as {{c2::irrelevant or as presenting an unfair risk of prejudice}}. 1.2 However, similar occurrences may be relevant and admissible for other, specific non-propensity purposes. 2. {{c3::Common admissible uses of similar occurrences}} 2.1 {{c4::Causation}}. 2.2 Prior accidents demonstrating: 2.2.1 A pattern of {{c5::fraudulent claims}}; or 2.2.2 {{c6::Pre-existing conditions}}. 2.3 {{c7::Intent or absence of mistake}}. 2.4 To rebut a defense of {{c8::impossibility}}. 2.5 {{c9::Value}} (e.g., similar transactions can establish value). 2.6 {{c10::Industry custom}} (e.g., to prove standard of care). 2.7 {{c11::Business routine}} (e.g., to show that a particular event occurred).

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Gender classifications}}: 1.1 Standard of review: {{c2::intermediate scrutiny plus}}. 1.2 Gender classifications receive heightened intermediate scrutiny: they must be {{c3::substantially related}} to an {{c4::important government purpose}}. 1.3 Additionally, courts often require an {{c5::exceedingly persuasive justification}} for the classification. 1.4 Classifications discriminating against {{c6::men}} are usually invalid, although some have passed intermediate scrutiny (e.g., {{c7::statutory rape laws applying only to men}}; {{c8::all-male military draft}}). 1.5 Classifications benefiting women: classifications based on {{c9::stereotypes}} are impermissible, but classifications designed to {{c10::remedy past discrimination or differences in opportunity}} will likely be upheld. 2. {{c11::Non-marital children (legitimacy classifications)}}: 2.1 These usually arise with {{c12::intestacy or inheritance statutes}}. 2.2 {{c13::Intermediate scrutiny}} applies if a law grants benefits to all marital children but denies benefits to some non-marital children. 2.3 Laws that deny benefits to {{c14::all non-marital children}} while granting benefits to all marital children are {{c15::unconstitutional on their face}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Most real property sales are negotiated by {{c1::real estate brokers}}. 1.1 {{c2::Seller's agent}} 1.1.1 A seller's agent is a broker who {{c3::obtains the listing from the seller}}, i.e., is engaged by the seller to assist in the sale of the property. 1.1.2 The seller's agent has a {{c4::fiduciary duty}} to the seller. 1.1.3 The seller's agent earns a {{c5::commission}} from the sale of the property once the sale closes. 1.1.4 The seller's agent may still earn a commission if the sale fails to close due to the {{c6::seller's fault}} (for example, the seller backs out). 1.2 {{c7::Buyer's agent}} 1.2.1 A buyer's agent's primary relationship is with the {{c8::buyer}}; for example, the agent shows the buyer potential properties the buyer may purchase. 1.2.2 The buyer's agent is typically compensated by receiving a portion of the {{c9::listing broker's commission}}, i.e., is paid out of the seller's agent's commission. 1.2.3 At {{c10::common law}}, a buyer's agent owed a fiduciary duty to the {{c11::seller}} because the buyer's agent was technically a {{c12::subagent of the seller's agent}}. 1.2.4 Under {{c13::modern statutes}}, a separate agreement between the buyer's agent and buyer is required; the buyer's agent owes a fiduciary duty to the {{c14::buyer}} but no fiduciary duty to the seller. 2. {{c15::Duty to disclose}} 2.1 Real estate agents have a duty to disclose {{c16::material information}} about the property of which they have {{c17::actual knowledge}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Where an estate's value is insufficient to pay its obligations and provide for disposition of property under a will, it must reduce ({{c1::abate}}) gifts in order to pay the obligations and satisfy some bequests and devises. 1. Requirement to pay obligations 1.1. The estate must always {{c2::pay off obligations before distributing assets}} (i.e., satisfy debts, expenses, taxes, etc.). 1.2. {{c3::Abatement}} occurs when, after doing so, the estate lacks sufficient funds to carry out disposition of property under the terms of the will. 2. Order of abatement 2.1. The testator's will may set out an {{c4::order of abatement}}. 2.2. Absent provisions in the will, most state statutes provide for an order of abatement setting a priority as to which categories of property in the estate will be sold off first. 2.3. Order (most states abate estate property in the following order): 2.3.1. {{c5::Property not disposed of by will}} (i.e., passing by intestacy). 2.3.2. {{c6::Residuary estate}} (i.e., the portion that would remain after all specific gifts and bequests have been made). 2.3.3. {{c7::General devises}} (abate pro rata). 2.3.4. {{c8::Specific devises and bequests}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Plea bargaining lets a defendant {{c1::plead guilty in exchange for concessions}}, but doing so {{c2::waives the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial}}. A valid plea must be {{c3::voluntary and intelligent}} and entered with an understanding of the {{c4::charge}}, {{c5::penalties}}, and {{c6::rights being waived}}. Once a plea is validly accepted, it can be attacked only on narrow grounds, such as {{c7::involuntariness}}, {{c8::lack of jurisdiction}}, {{c9::ineffective assistance of counsel}}, or {{c10::prosecutorial breach}}. Plea agreements are treated under {{c11::contract principles}} and are generally {{c12::enforced against both parties}}, but the {{c13::judge is not bound}} by the bargain, and the {{c14::prosecutor may threaten or pursue more serious charges supported by probable cause}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Public records}} (a public office or agency record is admissible if it): 1.1 Describes the {{c2::activities of a public office or agency}}. 1.2 Describes either: 1.2.1 {{c3::Matters observed}} pursuant to a {{c4::duty imposed by law}}, or 1.2.2 {{c5::Factual findings}} resulting from an {{c6::investigation made pursuant to authority granted by law}}. 1.3 Is made by a {{c7::public employee}} within the scope of their duty. 1.4 Is made at or near the {{c8::time of the event}}. 2. {{c9::Exception (criminal cases)}}: in criminal cases, police records or other criminal investigative reports are {{c10::inadmissible against the defendant}} as public records. 3. {{c11::Trustworthiness required}}: the court may exclude an otherwise qualifying public record if the source of information or other circumstances indicate a lack of trustworthiness. 4. {{c12::Absence of public record}}: certification or testimony from a public official that a {{c13::diligent search}} failed to find a record is admissible to: 4.1 Prove that the {{c14::record does not exist}}, or 4.2 Prove that a {{c15::matter did not occur}} (if records were kept regularly). 5. {{c16::Judgments and prior convictions}}: 5.1 Judgments: {{c17::certified copies}} are admissible in both civil and criminal cases to prove any {{c18::fact essential to the judgment}}. 5.2 Prior convictions: prior convictions are generally {{c19::inadmissible in criminal cases against non-defendants}} unless used for {{c20::impeachment}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A {{c1::tenancy in common}} is a {{c2::concurrent estate}} with multiple tenants in which each co-tenant owns a {{c3::distinct, undivided interest}} and each has a {{c4::right to possession of the whole estate}}. 2. Characteristics 2.1 {{c5::Freely transferable}}: Each tenant in common's interest is freely {{c6::descendible, devisable, and alienable}}; a co-tenant's interest can be transferred upon death. 2.2 {{c7::Rent}}: A co-tenant can lease his individual interest, which transfers his right of possession to the lessee, but all co-tenants have a {{c8::right to share in rents from a third-party lessee}}. 2.3 {{c9::No survivorship rights}}: Upon the death of a co-tenant, her interest {{c10::does not pass by operation of law to remaining co-tenants}}; instead, it {{c11::passes through her estate}}. 2.4 {{c12::Partition}}: A co-tenant may seek judicial partition (division of the property); if physical division is not feasible, the property may be {{c13::sold and the proceeds apportioned among the co-tenants}}. 2.5 {{c14::Default form}}: Modern law favors tenancy in common; it is the {{c15::default concurrent estate}} absent clear language creating another type of co-tenancy.

subject: Torts
cloze: Defense of others as a defense to intentional torts: 1. {{c1::Reasonable belief}} about the person aided: - D must reasonably believe that the person he is aiding {{c2::would have the right of self-defense}} against the aggressor. 2. {{c3::Scope of force}}: - D may use as much force as he could have used {{c4::if the injury were threatened to him}}, i.e., as if he were acting in {{c5::self-defense}} under the same circumstances.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Federal civil procedure requires several categories of {{c1::mandatory disclosures}} that must be made {{c2::without awaiting discovery requests}}. 1. Main categories 1.1 {{c3::Initial disclosures}} – basic information about witnesses, documents, damages, and insurance. 1.2 {{c4::Duty to supplement}} – ongoing obligation to correct or complete disclosures. 1.3 {{c5::Expert disclosures}} – advance identification of testifying experts and their reports. 1.4 {{c6::Pretrial disclosures}} – advance identification of trial evidence and witnesses. 2. Key timing structure 2.1 Initial disclosures are tied to the {{c7::mandatory meet-and-confer}} (and to {{c8::service/joinder for later-added parties}}). 2.2 Expert and pretrial disclosures are tied to specific {{c9::time periods before trial}} (experts earlier, pretrial disclosures closer to trial).

subject: Con Law
cloze: {{c1::Economic rights}} (economic liberties) receive {{c2::minimal constitutional protection}}. 1. Standard of review 1.1. Laws affecting economic rights are reviewed under the {{c3::rational basis}} test. 1.2. Under {{c3::rational basis}}, a law is upheld if it is {{c4::rationally related}} to a {{c5::legitimate governmental interest}}. 2. Scope and effect 2.1. The Constitution provides only {{c2::minimal protection}} for {{c1::economic liberties}}—laws affecting or amounting to a taking of one’s economic rights. 2.2. {{c3::Rational basis}} applies to economic regulations unless the infringement falls under a more specific protection, such as the {{c6::Contract Clause}} or the {{c7::Takings Clause}}. 2.3. In practice, the {{c8::government almost always wins}} under {{c3::rational basis}} review for economic regulation.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: General rule: A {{c1::perfected}} security interest usually {{c2::prevails over a buyer}} of the collateral. {{c3::BIOC exception}}: A {{c4::buyer in the ordinary course of business (BIOC)}} takes free of a {{c5::nonpossessory perfected}} security interest if: 1. The buyer has {{c6::no knowledge that the sale violates}} the terms of the seller’s security agreement; and 2. The buyer is a {{c7::BIOC}}, meaning the buyer {{c8::purchases in the ordinary course of business}} from a {{c9::seller who is in the business of selling goods of that kind}}. If these conditions are met, the BIOC {{c10::takes free of}} the nonpossessory perfected security interest.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general: An offer may be terminated by an {{c1::act of a party}} or by {{c2::operation of law}}. 2. Acts of parties: 2.1. {{c3::Revocation}} by the offeror. 2.2. {{c4::Rejection}} by the offeree. 2.3. {{c5::Lapse of time}}. 2.4. The offeror can set a {{c6::time limit for acceptance}}, at the end of which the offeree's {{c7::power of acceptance}} automatically terminates. 3. Operation of law: 3.1. {{c8::Death or insanity}} of either party. 3.2. {{c9::Destruction of the proposed contract's subject matter}}. 3.3. {{c10::Supervening illegality}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Acceptance of goods}} ({{c2::UCC}} contracts – in general): 1.1 A buyer does not officially {{c3::accept}} goods until they are {{c4::delivered}} and the buyer has a {{c5::reasonable opportunity to inspect}} them and/or notify the seller. 1.2 Modes of acceptance: 1.2.1 Buyer {{c6::confirms acceptance}}: • After a reasonable opportunity to inspect the goods, the buyer {{c7::indicates to the seller}} that the goods {{c8::conform}}, or that she will keep them despite {{c9::nonconformance}}. • If the buyer {{c10::accepts}} goods, she cannot later {{c11::reject}} them. 1.2.2 Buyer is {{c12::silent}} (acceptance by inaction): • The buyer fails to {{c13::reject or notify the seller of rejection}} within a {{c14::reasonable time}} after a reasonable opportunity to inspect. 1.3 Payment and inspection: 1.3.1 {{c15::Payment without an opportunity to inspect}} is {{c16::not acceptance}}.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: A {{c1::limited liability partnership (LLP)}} limits a partner's personal liability for the partnership's obligations and actions. 1. {{c2::Formation}}: Any partnership can become an LLP upon: 1.1 {{c3::Approval of the partners by vote}}; and 1.2 {{c4::Filing a statement of qualification}} with the state containing partner names, addresses, the LLP election, and the effective date. 2. {{c5::Liability}}: 2.1 A partner in an LLP is {{c6::not personally liable for partnership obligations}} of any sort; but 2.2 Every partner remains personally liable for {{c7::her own acts}} or acts that she {{c8::supervises or directs}}. 3. {{c9::Rights and obligations}}: The financial rights and obligations of LLP partners are the same as in a {{c10::standard general partnership}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Shareholder governance is exercised through {{c1::meetings}}, {{c2::voting rules}}, and {{c3::proxy voting}}. 1. Meetings: - Corporations must hold {{c4::annual shareholder meetings}} to elect directors and conduct other shareholder business, and may call {{c5::special meetings}} when matters requiring {{c6::shareholder approval}} arise. - {{c7::Notice}} of any shareholder meeting must be sent to shareholders eligible to vote. 2. Voting: - Unless the {{c8::articles of incorporation}} provide otherwise, each issued share is entitled to {{c9::one vote}}. - A {{c10::quorum}} of shares must be present (in person or by proxy) for votes to be valid. - Within each voting group, actions are approved if votes cast {{c11::in favor exceed those cast against}}. - Directors are generally elected by {{c12::plurality}}, and {{c13::cumulative voting}} may be used if authorized in the articles. 3. Proxies: - Shareholders may vote by {{c14::written proxy}}. - Proxy appointments are generally {{c15::revocable}}, but can be {{c16::irrevocable}} if {{c17::coupled with an interest}} and clearly stated to be irrevocable.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Trespass to chattel}} and {{c2::conversion}} are two separate but similar torts; the difference is the {{c3::level of interference}} with P's property and the {{c4::damages P can recover}}. 2. Elements: 2.1 D {{c5::intentionally interferes with P's right of possession}} in {{c6::tangible personal property (chattel)}}. 2.1.1 Interference usually occurs through {{c7::dispossession}} (depriving P of possessory rights in the chattel) or {{c8::damaging P's chattel}}. 2.1.2 {{c9::Trespass to chattel}}: {{c10::minor interference or damage}}. 2.1.3 {{c11::Conversion}}: {{c12::significant interference or damage}} that justifies D paying the chattel's {{c13::full value}}. 2.1.4 A {{c14::longer and/or more damaging use}} of P's chattel gives rise to conversion. 2.2 {{c15::Intent}}. 2.3 {{c16::Causation}}. 2.4 {{c17::Damages}}: P must have {{c18::some loss of use}}. 2.4.1 Trespass to chattel: P can recover {{c19::cost of repair}} or {{c20::rental value}} of the chattel. 2.4.2 Conversion: P can recover {{c21::full market value at the time of conversion}} or {{c22::repossess the chattel (replevin)}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. Definition of {{c1::common-law murder}}: 1.1 Common-law murder is the {{c2::unlawful killing of another human being with malice aforethought}}. 2. {{c3::Malice aforethought}} – qualifying mental states: 2.1 Malice aforethought exists, in the absence of mitigating circumstances, when the defendant kills with any of the following mental states: 2.1.1 {{c4::Intent to kill}}; 2.1.2 {{c5::Intent to inflict great bodily injury}}; 2.1.3 {{c6::Depraved or malignant heart}}: a killing committed with {{c7::reckless indifference to an unjustifiable risk of human life}}; or 2.1.4 {{c8::Felony murder}}: a killing caused during the attempt or commission of an {{c9::inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Former testimony is admissible {{c1::hearsay}} if the following requirements are met: 1. Declarant is {{c2::unavailable}}. 2. The prior testimony was given {{c3::under oath}}. 3. The party against whom the testimony is now offered was either: 3.1 A {{c4::party in the previous action}} and had an {{c5::opportunity to cross-examine}} the declarant; and 3.2 Had a {{c6::similar motive for cross-examining}} the declarant in the former hearing as in the current proceeding; or 3.3 A {{c7::predecessor in interest}} of a party in the previous action, in which there was an opportunity to cross-examine the declarant and a similar motive for doing so. 3.4 A predecessor in interest is one who has a {{c8::close privity-type relationship}} with the party in the earlier proceeding. 4. This exception applies in {{c9::civil actions only}}. 5. The MBE frequently tests this exception; remember that it only applies if the declarant is {{c10::unavailable}} and the prior testimony was {{c11::under oath}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Easements may be created by {{c1::express grant or reservation}}, {{c2::implication}}, {{c3::necessity}}, or {{c4::prescription}}. An {{c5::express easement}} is created by written {{c6::grant}} or {{c7::reservation}} that satisfies the {{c8::Statute of Frauds}}. An {{c9::implied easement}} arises from {{c10::prior or existing use}} and circumstances showing the parties likely {{c11::intended an easement}} even without a writing. An easement by {{c12::necessity}} typically arises when a parcel is {{c13::landlocked}} as a result of a conveyance and access is {{c14::strictly necessary}}. A {{c15::prescriptive easement}} is created by {{c16::adverse/hostile}}, {{c17::open and notorious}}, {{c18::continuous}} use for the {{c19::statutory period}}, analogous to adverse possession but conferring only a {{c20::use right}} rather than {{c21::title}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::defeasible fee}} is a {{c2::fee simple estate}} of potentially infinite duration that can be {{c3::terminated upon the occurrence of a specified event}}. It is a {{c4::present fee estate vested}} in a person, who may {{c5::lose the fee interest if the condition occurs}}. To create a defeasible fee, the grantor must use {{c6::clear words of intent}} that the estate will be {{c7::forfeited or end upon a stated event}}; mere {{c8::desire, hope, or aspiration}} is {{c9::insufficient}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. Express trusts – general 1.1 An {{c1::express trust}} is created with the property owner's {{c2::express intent}} to create a trust relationship. 2. Private trusts 2.1 A {{c3::private trust}} is created for the benefit of {{c4::defined and/or ascertainable persons}}. 2.2 A private trust may be created {{c5::inter vivos}} (during the settlor's life) or as a {{c6::testamentary trust}} (created by will). 3. Charitable trusts 3.1 A {{c7::charitable trust}} is created for the benefit of an {{c8::indefinite class of people}} or the {{c9::public generally}}. 3.2 The purpose must be {{c10::charitable in nature}} (e.g., {{c11::relief of poverty}}, {{c12::advancement of education or religion}}, {{c13::promotion of health}}, or other {{c14::community benefit}}).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Open vs. closed class in class gifts 1.1 A class is {{c1::open}} when new members can still be added (for example, while the life tenant is still alive and capable of having children). 1.2 A class {{c2::closes}} when no new members can be created (for example, at the {{c3::death of the life tenant}} or when it is otherwise impossible to add qualifying members). 2. Rule of Convenience 2.1 The {{c4::Rule of Convenience}} is a default rule that closes a class whenever any member of the class is {{c5::entitled to demand distribution}} of her share. 2.2 Once the class closes under the Rule of Convenience, {{c6::later-born or later-qualifying persons are excluded}} and {{c7::take nothing}} from that class gift. 3. Relationship to vested remainders subject to open 3.1 A {{c8::vested remainder subject to open}} is a {{c9::class gift}} where at least one class member’s interest is already vested, but the class remains open to additional members until it closes. 3.2 The timing of {{c10::class closing}}—either naturally when no more members can be created or earlier under the Rule of Convenience—determines {{c11::who shares in the vested class gift}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 2. {{c1::Due process}} considerations for pretrial identifications 2.1 A defendant can attack a pretrial identification as a denial of due process if it is {{c2::unnecessarily suggestive}} and there is a {{c3::substantial likelihood of misidentification}}. 2.2 Courts assess this under the {{c4::totality of the circumstances}}. 2.3 This is a {{c5::demanding}} standard; the procedure must be {{c6::extremely suggestive}}. 2.4 Example: Due process is likely violated if the perpetrator is believed to be {{c7::male}} and the defendant is the {{c8::only male in the lineup}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under {{c1::FRCP 35}}, a {{c2::physical or mental examination}} is available only {{c3::by court order}}, not as of right. The moving party must show that the person’s {{c4::physical or mental condition is in controversy}} and that there is {{c5::good cause}} for the examination. If the examination is ordered, {{c6::doctor–patient confidentiality or privilege as to that condition}} is effectively {{c7::waived for purposes of the litigation}}, allowing the examination results to be discovered and used in the case.

subject: Con Law
cloze: {{c1::Numerical set-asides (quotas)}} based on race or national origin are {{c2::highly disfavored}} under strict scrutiny. To be valid, they require {{c3::clear proof of persistent and readily identifiable discrimination}} by the government actor, and {{c4::general past wrongs or societal discrimination}} are {{c5::insufficient}}. As a result, such quotas are {{c6::unlikely to be upheld}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Special use permits}} 1.1. Certain property uses require a special use permit even where zoning generally allows the type of use (for example, {{c2::hospitals and drive-thrus in commercial districts}}). 2. {{c3::Exactions}} 2.1. An exaction is a {{c4::condition the government places on approval of a new development}}. 2.2. The condition is usually a {{c5::payment or gift of property to the government}} to offset the development's demands on public services. 2.3. For example: Due to population increase from a new housing development, the government will have to install new bus stops and traffic lights; the government can seek some exaction (for example, a payment) from the developer. 3. Requirements for valid exactions 3.1. {{c6::Nexus}}: There must be a {{c7::rational relationship (nexus)}} between the exaction sought by the government and the burden on public facilities created by the development. 3.2. {{c8::Proportionality}}: The exaction must {{c9::reasonably relate, in nature and scope, to the impact of the development}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General Rule: With valid {{c1::consent}}, police may search anything within the {{c2::scope of that consent}}. 2. Requirements for valid consent 2.1 {{c3::Voluntarily and intelligently}} made 2.1.1 Police cannot {{c4::falsely claim legal cause to search}}. 2.1.2 Police have {{c5::no obligation to inform suspects that they have a right to refuse consent}}. 2.2 {{c6::Authority to consent}} 2.2.1 The person giving consent must have {{c7::authority to consent}}. 2.2.2 Authority to consent must be {{c8::reasonably apparent}}. 2.3 {{c9::Scope of consent}} 2.3.1 The scope of consent can be {{c10::limited by the consenting party}}. 2.3.2 A {{c11::violation of the scope}} renders the entire search {{c12::non-consenting}}. 2.4 {{c13::Third-party consent}} 2.4.1 Third-party consent is allowed if the third party has {{c14::authority to consent}}. 2.4.2 Where multiple people have property rights (e.g., ownership, authorized use, occupancy), any single one can consent to the search of any area where that person has {{c15::authority to consent}}. 2.4.3 A {{c16::resident's}} right to consent or refuse generally trumps a {{c17::non-resident's}}. 2.4.4 For example: If both a {{c18::tenant}} and {{c19::landlord}} are present, the tenant's refusal trumps the landlord's consent. The scope of consent is dictated by the person present with the {{c20::highest authority to consent}}. 2.4.5 {{c21::Refusal trumps consent}}: If two persons with equal right to possession disagree on consent, there is {{c22::no valid consent}}.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 2. Application by Substantive Area – Torts and Contracts: 2.1 {{c1::Torts}} (place of injury / last event causing liability): - The court applies the law of the state where the {{c2::injury occurred}}. - Specifically, this is the state where the {{c3::last event giving rise to liability}} occurred, because that is where the tort right is deemed to {{c4::vest}}. 2.2 {{c5::Contracts}} (place of contracting vs. place of performance): - Default: The court applies the law of the state where the {{c6::contract was formed}} (the place of making). - Performance disputes: If the dispute concerns {{c7::performance}}, the court applies the law of the state where {{c8::performance was due}}. - Rationale: The right to {{c9::enforce the contract}} generally vests at {{c10::formation}}, but performance-related rights vest at the {{c11::place of performance}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: General rule: Unless {{c1::restricted by the terms of the lease}}, a tenant may transfer her leasehold interest either {{c2::in whole (an assignment)}} or {{c3::in part (a sublease)}}. An {{c4::assignment}} is a transfer of the tenant’s {{c5::entire remaining leasehold interest}} (both in duration and physical area) to another. A {{c6::sublease}} is a transfer of {{c7::less than the tenant’s entire leasehold interest}} (such as a shorter duration or only part of the premises).

subject: Corporations
cloze: Directors and officers owe a {{c1::duty of loyalty}} to the corporation, which prohibits them from {{c2::profiting at the corporation’s expense}}. 1. {{c3::Conflict of interest – definition}} 1.1 A conflict of interest exists when an officer or director has a {{c4::personal interest in a transaction}} in which the corporation is a party. 1.2 A conflict occurs if the officer or director knows that he or a family member is: 1.2.1 {{c5::A party to the transaction}}; or 1.2.2 Has a {{c6::beneficial financial interest}} in, or is so closely linked to, the transaction that it could reasonably be expected to {{c7::influence how the director or officer votes}} on the transaction; or 1.2.3 Is {{c8::affiliated with another entity that is a party to the transaction}} (for example, is an {{c9::agent or employee}} of the other entity).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 2. {{c1::Proximate cause and intervening acts}} 2.1 {{c2::Proximate cause}}: The actual result must be the {{c3::natural and probable consequence}} of the defendant's conduct, even if it does not occur {{c4::exactly as expected}}. 2.2 {{c5::Superseding factors}} 2.2.1 Superseding factors {{c6::break the chain of causation}} and relieve the defendant of liability for the result. 2.3 {{c7::Intervening acts and foreseeability}} 2.3.1 Intervening acts must be {{c8::entirely unforeseeable}} to be superseding and shield the defendant from liability. 2.3.2 Foreseeable intervening events—such as the victim's {{c9::refusal of medical treatment}} or {{c10::ordinary third-party medical negligence}}—are considered {{c11::foreseeable}} and therefore {{c12::do not break}} the causal chain; the defendant remains liable.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Evidence law distinguishes between {{c1::prior similar occurrences}} and {{c2::habit}} evidence. 1. {{c3::Similar occurrences – overview}} 1.1 Evidence of prior similar occurrences concerning the time, event, or person in the present controversy is often inadmissible as {{c4::irrelevant or as presenting an unfair risk of prejudice}}. 1.2 However, similar occurrences may be relevant and admissible for specific, non-propensity purposes (e.g., causation, certain prior accidents, intent, impossibility, value, industry custom, or business routine). 2. {{c5::Habit – overview}} 2.1 A person's habit may be relevant and admissible to show that the person acted in conformity with that habit on a given occasion. 2.2 Habit requires {{c6::highly specific conduct that is frequently repeated}}—i.e., a person's regular response to a specific set of circumstances.

subject: Evidence
