cloze: 1. {{c1::Habit evidence – definition and use}} 1.1 A person's {{c2::habit}} may be relevant and admissible to show that the person acted in conformity with that habit on a given occasion. 1.2 Habit is different from {{c3::character evidence}}: it involves a {{c4::regular response to a specific situation}}, not a general disposition. 2. {{c5::Requirements for habit}} 2.1 Habit conduct must be {{c6::highly specific and frequently repeated}}—i.e., a person's regular response to a specific set of circumstances. 2.2 Look for {{c7::regular, instinctive, habitual conduct}}. 2.3 Example: Evidence that a person habitually goes down a particular stairwell two steps at a time may be admissible as circumstantial evidence that she did so at the time in question.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Common law {{c1::burglary}} is defined as a {{c2::trespassory breaking and entering}} of the {{c3::dwelling house}} of {{c4::another}} {{c5::at nighttime}} with {{c6::intent to commit a felony therein}}. Modern {{c7::burglary statutes}} often {{c8::eliminate the breaking and nighttime requirements}}, {{c9::extend the crime to non-dwellings}}, and {{c10::broaden the intended offense to include misdemeanors such as theft}}. On the {{c11::MBE}}, apply {{c7::modern statutory rules}} unless directed to use the {{c12::common law}} definition.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. General applicability 1.1. UCC {{c1::Article 9}} applies to any transaction intended to create a {{c2::security interest}} in {{c3::personal property or fixtures}}. 2. Major exceptions (Article 9 does not apply to these transactions) 2.1. Transactions governed by {{c4::federal, state, or foreign law}} that expressly preempt Article 9. 2.2. Most {{c5::real property transactions}} involving interests or liens on land (for example, {{c6::mortgages on real property}}). 2.3. {{c7::Assignment of tort claims}} (except as to {{c8::proceeds and priority in proceeds from tort claims}}). 2.4. {{c9::Assignment of claims for wages}}. 3. Secured transactions versus contracts 3.1. {{c10::Contract law and UCC Article 2}} govern the rules for making and enforcing transactions in {{c11::goods and services}}. 3.2. {{c12::Secured transactions and UCC Article 9}} govern {{c13::how those transactions are protected or secured}}, not the {{c14::substantive rules of the underlying exchange}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Authority to sanction 1.1 A court may {{c1::sanction parties for discovery violations}}, either on its own initiative or upon motion of a party. 1.2 Grounds: The court can sanction any type of {{c2::failure to comply with discovery obligations or a discovery order}}. 1.3 Duty to supplement: The Rules impose a duty to {{c3::supplement initial disclosures, interrogatory answers, and responses to document requests and requests for admission}} when the produced information is {{c4::incomplete or incorrect}}. 2. Types of sanctions 2.1 {{c5::Partial violations}} 2.1.1 Definition: {{c6::Less serious discovery violations}} (e.g., frivolous objections in requests for admission). 2.1.2 Remedies: The court may issue an order {{c7::compelling the discoveree to respond}} to discovery requests and may {{c8::award the moving party its costs, including attorneys' fees}} for bringing the motion to compel. 2.2 {{c9::Complete violations}} 2.2.1 Definition: {{c10::Wholesale violations of discovery rules or court orders}} (e.g., violation of a discovery order). 2.2.2 Remedies: The court may: 2.2.2.1 {{c11::Strike pleadings}}. 2.2.2.2 {{c12::Disallow evidence}}. 2.2.2.3 {{c13::Establish disputed or unanswered facts as true}}. 2.2.2.4 {{c14::Issue monetary sanctions}}. 2.2.2.5 {{c15::Dismiss the plaintiff's case}} (very serious; generally requires {{c16::bad faith}}). 2.2.2.6 {{c17::Enter default judgment}} against a disobedient defendant (very serious; generally requires {{c16::bad faith}}). 2.2.2.7 {{c18::Hold the disobedient party in contempt of court}}. 3. Motion to compel prerequisite 3.1 A motion to compel is {{c19::not required}} before moving directly for sanctions in the case of serious violations or disobedience of a discovery order.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under the {{c1::Interlocutory Appeals Act}}, an appellate court may hear an appeal of a non-final order if the trial judge certifies that the order: • Involves a {{c2::controlling issue of law}}; • There is {{c3::substantial ground for difference of opinion}} on that issue; and • An immediate appeal may {{c4::materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation}}. In addition, in {{c5::class actions}}, an appellate court may review an order {{c6::granting or denying class certification}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: A {{c1::hearsay}} statement is admissible if the declarant made the statement under the {{c2::belief of impending death}} and the statement describes the {{c3::cause or circumstances}} of the impending death. 1. Requirements for {{c4::dying declaration}} (statement is admissible if): 1.1 Declarant is currently {{c5::unavailable}} (death of the declarant is {{c6::not required}}). 1.2 The out-of-court statement was made under the {{c7::belief of impending death}} (the declarant must only have believed he was dying when the statement was made). 1.3 The statement was made regarding the {{c8::cause or circumstances}} surrounding the belief of impending death. 2. The dying declaration exception is only available in: 2.1 {{c9::Civil cases}}; and 2.2 {{c10::Homicide cases}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Presidential immunity}} 1.1 The President has {{c2::absolute immunity}} from {{c3::civil suits arising from official actions taken while in office}}. 1.2 The President has {{c4::no immunity}} for actions occurring {{c5::prior to taking office}} or for {{c6::purely private conduct}}. 2. {{c7::Executive privilege}} 2.1 Executive privilege protects against disclosure of {{c8::presidential papers and conversations}}. 2.2 Important governmental interests in {{c9::criminal cases}} can override the privilege (e.g., in the {{c10::Watergate}} tapes case, presidential documents and phone logs were disclosed for evidentiary purposes, which overrode the privilege). 3. {{c11::Pardon power}} 3.1 The President has the power to pardon those accused or convicted of {{c12::federal crimes}} (not state crimes). 3.2 Exception: The President cannot pardon someone for offenses that led to {{c13::impeachment}} or undo the legal consequences of impeachment. 3.3 The President may also {{c14::commute federal criminal sentences}}. 3.4 {{c15::Congress cannot limit}} the President’s constitutional pardon power.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. General allocation of foreign-affairs powers 1.1 Article II gives the {{c1::President}} key foreign-affairs powers, including making treaties, appointing ambassadors, and acting as {{c2::Commander in Chief}}. 1.2 The President alone has authority to {{c3::represent the United States in foreign affairs}}. 2. Role of Congress 2.1 Congress retains foreign-affairs powers such as the power to {{c4::declare war}}, raise and support armies, and regulate foreign commerce. 3. Limits on other branches directing foreign representatives 3.1 Other branches generally may not {{c5::direct U.S. foreign representatives}} such as ambassadors. 3.2 Be cautious of answer choices where {{c6::Congress or the courts attempt to dictate diplomacy}} or specific instructions to ambassadors, as this typically intrudes on the President’s exclusive representational role.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Function of a deed 1.1 A {{c1::deed}} passes {{c2::legal title}} from the {{c3::grantor}} to the {{c4::grantee}}. 2. Validity requirements for a deed 2.1 {{c5::Lawful execution}} 2.1.1 The deed must be {{c6::signed by the grantor}}. 2.1.2 It must reasonably {{c7::identify the parties}}. 2.1.3 It must contain a {{c8::legal description}} of the real estate. 2.2 {{c9::Delivery}} 2.2.1 Delivery requires the grantor’s {{c10::intent to be presently bound}} by the conveyance. 2.2.2 {{c11::Title passes upon effective delivery}} and generally {{c12::cannot be rescinded}}. 2.2.3 {{c13::Present intent}} controls; {{c14::physical transfer is not required}}. 2.3 {{c15::Conditional or third‑party delivery}} 2.3.1 Courts look to the {{c16::grantor’s intent}} when a deed is delivered with conditions or via a third party (e.g., escrow). 2.3.2 A key question is whether the grantor {{c17::retained control or power to rescind}} the transfer. 2.4 {{c18::Acceptance}} 2.4.1 The grantee must accept the deed; acceptance is usually {{c19::presumed}}. 2.4.2 A {{c20::non‑existent or void entity}} cannot accept a deed. 2.4.3 An {{c21::express rejection}} by the grantee makes delivery {{c22::ineffective}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: An {{c1::easement by necessity}} can arise if access to or from a property is {{c2::impossible without the easement}}, so that the easement's existence becomes strictly necessary. 2. Creation: An easement by necessity usually arises when a {{c3::landowner sells a portion of her property}} and the resulting division deprives one lot owner of {{c4::access to a public road or utility}}. The owner of the {{c5::servient estate}} can choose a {{c6::reasonable location}} for the easement. 3. Termination: The easement by necessity {{c7::expires automatically when the necessity ends}}, such as when other access becomes available.

subject: Corporations
cloze: The corporation’s {{c1::board of directors (BoD)}} has primary responsibility for {{c2::corporate affairs and overall management}}. Its powers and responsibilities can be grouped into four main areas: 1. {{c3::Composition and selection}} (number, election, and removal of directors). 2. {{c4::Board procedures}} (meetings, notice, quorum, and action without a meeting). 3. {{c5::Delegation and committees}} (officers, executives, and limits on committee power). 4. {{c6::Fiduciary duties}} (duties of care and loyalty owed to the corporation.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::False pretenses}} – general rule: 1.1 Obtaining {{c2::title}} to another's property. 1.2 By using {{c3::false statements}}. 1.3 About a {{c4::past or existing fact}}. 1.4 With {{c5::intent to defraud}}. 2. Required elements of {{c1::false pretenses}}: 2.1 Obtaining title: the defendant obtains {{c6::ownership, not mere possession}}. 2.2 By false statements: there must be an {{c7::intentional false statement}}. 2.3 Of past or existing fact: a misrepresentation regarding a {{c8::future event is not sufficient}}. 2.4 Intent to defraud: the defendant must have the intent to steal, and the victim must be {{c9::deceived or act in reliance on the false statement in passing title}} to the defendant. 3. {{c10::Larceny by trick}} – general rule: 3.1 Obtaining {{c11::possession}}. 3.2 Of another's {{c12::personal property}}. 3.3 By using false statements of {{c4::past or existing fact}}. 4. {{c13::Possession vs. ownership}} as distinguishing factor: 4.1 In larceny by trick, the defendant acquires {{c14::possession only}}. 4.2 In false pretenses, the defendant acquires {{c15::title (ownership)}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: {{c1::Settlements, offers to settle, and plea bargaining}} 1. In {{c2::civil cases}}, compromises, settlement offers, and related statements (including factual admissions) about a {{c3::disputed claim}} are {{c4::inadmissible}} to prove {{c5::liability, fault, or the amount of a disputed claim}}. 2. This rule does not apply to statements made {{c6::before a claim was asserted or before there was a threat of litigation}}. 3. In {{c7::criminal cases}}, pleas, offers to plead, and related statements (including factual admissions) are {{c8::inadmissible}} to prove {{c9::guilt or the amount of punishment}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. Varying rights in share classes 1.1 Shares authorized by a corporation can have different {{c1::rights, preferences, and limitations}} depending on the {{c2::class of shares}}. 1.2 The articles can define almost any kind of differentiation between share classes. 1.3 Common differences between share classes involve: 1.3.1 {{c3::Rights to distributions and/or dividends}}. 1.3.2 The nature of {{c4::voting rights}}. 1.3.3 {{c5::Preference with regard to distributions}}. 2. Distribution rights 2.1 A corporation can distribute assets in the form of {{c6::dividends}}, {{c7::redemption of shares}}, or {{c8::liquidating distributions upon dissolution}}. 2.2 At least {{c9::one class of shares}} must be entitled to receive the corporation’s {{c10::net assets upon dissolution}}. 2.3 {{c11::Board discretion}}: The decision whether to declare a distribution is within the board of directors’ sole discretion, even where the articles authorize distributions. 2.4 Shareholders have {{c12::no general right to demand a distribution}}. 3. Consideration for shares 3.1 Shares can be issued by the corporation in exchange for any {{c13::tangible or intangible property or benefit}} to the corporation. 3.2 For example, in some states, a corporation can issue shares in exchange for {{c14::anything of value}}, including {{c15::money, property, or services rendered or to be rendered}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure – Concept}} 1.1 To avoid foreclosure, the {{c2::mortgagor}} can agree to convey a {{c3::deed to the property}} directly to the {{c4::mortgagee}}. 1.2 This deed is given in {{c5::satisfaction of the mortgage debt}} (in full or as agreed). 2. {{c6::Validity Requirements}} 2.1 Such a transaction is valid only if it is {{c7::fair and reasonable under the circumstances}}. 2.2 Courts may scrutinize it for {{c8::overreaching}} or {{c9::unconscionability}}, particularly when the mortgagor has {{c10::limited bargaining power}}. 3. {{c11::Practical Effect}} 3.1 If valid, the deed in lieu of foreclosure {{c12::extinguishes the mortgage debt}} to the extent agreed. 3.2 It ends the {{c13::mortgagor’s ownership interest}} and usually eliminates the need for {{c14::foreclosure proceedings}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 The defendant may be held liable if he {{c2::intends the harm caused but causes it to a different victim or object than intended}}. 1.2 Transferred intent often applies to {{c3::homicide}}, {{c4::battery}}, and {{c5::arson}}. 1.3 Transferred intent {{c6::does not apply to attempt}}. 1.4 {{c7::Defenses and mitigating circumstances}} may also be transferred. 2. {{c8::Effect}} 2.1 Under transferred intent, the defendant is usually charged with {{c9::two crimes}}: 2.1.1 {{c10::Attempt to commit the originally intended crime}}. 2.1.2 {{c11::The actual resulting crime}}. 2.2 Example: The defendant intends to shoot A but kills B instead. The defendant can be charged with the {{c12::attempted murder of A}} and the {{c13::actual murder of B}}. {{c14::Merger does not apply because there are different victims}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under the {{c1::cy pres doctrine}} for {{c2::charitable trusts}}, courts may {{c3::modify the terms of a charitable trust}} so the property is applied to a charitable purpose {{c4::as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intention}} when the original charitable purpose is {{c5::accomplished}} or becomes {{c6::impractical, unlawful, or wasteful}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: In real estate contracts, the buyer’s {{c1::part performance}} can satisfy the Statute of Frauds if the buyer has done {{c2::two of the following three}} acts: 1. {{c3::Full or part payment}} of the purchase price. 2. {{c4::Possession}} of the property. 3. {{c5::Improvements}} to the property. If the buyer meets this {{c6::two-out-of-three}} test, many courts will enforce the oral land contract despite the lack of a signed writing.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Definition 1.1 The {{c1::complaint}} is the {{c2::initial pleading}} in a lawsuit, filed by the {{c3::plaintiff}}, which begins an action and gives notice to opposing parties. 2. Required contents 2.1 {{c4::Statement of jurisdiction}} 2.1.1 A {{c5::short and plain statement}} of the grounds upon which the court's {{c6::jurisdiction}} depends (why the court has {{c7::subject-matter jurisdiction}}). 2.2 {{c8::Statement of the claim}} 2.2.1 A {{c9::short and plain statement}} of the plaintiff's claim, showing {{c10::entitlement to relief}}. 2.2.2 {{c11::Plausibility pleading standard}}: The complaint must contain sufficient factual matter to state a claim that is {{c12::plausible on its face}}. 2.2.3 Allegations are {{c13::accepted as true}}, but {{c14::conclusory allegations are ignored}}. 2.2.4 Plausibility means {{c15::factual content that allows the court to draw the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable}}. 2.2.5 Plausibility is {{c16::more than possibility but less than probability}}; judges may use their {{c17::judicial experience and common sense}}. 2.3 {{c18::Demand for judgment}} 2.3.1 A description of the {{c19::relief sought}} (e.g., money damages, injunction, declaratory relief).

subject: Corporations
cloze: A {{c1::merger}} is a {{c2::fundamental corporate change}} in which {{c3::two or more corporations combine into a single corporation}}, often with one absorbing another. Because mergers are fundamental changes, they generally require {{c4::board and shareholder approval}}, subject to limited exceptions (such as where the {{c5::surviving corporation experiences no significant changes}}). After a merger, the {{c6::surviving corporation owns all property and assumes all obligations}} of the constituent corporations. Special rules apply to {{c7::short-form mergers}} where a parent owns at least {{c8::90%}} of a subsidiary, and {{c9::dissenting shareholders}} typically have {{c10::appraisal rights}} to obtain fair market value for their shares if they properly dissent.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general: If the buyer has notified the seller of an {{c1::imperfect tender}} (delivery of {{c2::nonconforming goods}}), the seller may have an opportunity to {{c3::cure}}. 2. Requirements (when the seller can cure): 2.1 Seller gives buyer notice of intent to cure and {{c4::time for performance has not yet expired}}: The seller must give the buyer {{c5::reasonable notice}} and then deliver {{c6::conforming goods}} within the original contract time. 2.2 Seller had {{c7::reasonable grounds to believe}} the nonconforming goods would be acceptable: Reasonableness is usually based on the seller's {{c8::prior dealings with the buyer}}; in this case, the seller will have an {{c9::additional reasonable time}} period to tender conforming goods. 3. Note: The buyer {{c10::cannot compel the seller to cure}}; the {{c11::right to cure}} belongs to the seller under the {{c12::UCC}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::5th Amendment Takings Clause}} prohibits the government from taking private property for public use without just compensation. A taking occurs when {{c2::government action significantly damages private property or its use}}. There are two main types of takings: 1. {{c3::Possessory (physical) taking}} – when the government {{c4::takes or physically occupies private property}}, including permanent or significant physical invasions. 2. {{c5::Regulatory taking}} – when {{c6::government regulation adversely affects property value or the owner’s ability to use the property}}, and whether a taking has occurred depends on the {{c7::extent of economic interference}} with the owner’s rights.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under Federal {{c1::Rule 60(b)}}, a court may relieve a party from a {{c2::final judgment or order}} for several specified grounds and, in {{c3::extraordinary cases}}, for any other reason that justifies relief. Different grounds are subject to different {{c4::timing rules}}: some must be brought within a {{c5::reasonable time}} and no more than {{c6::one year}} after judgment, while others only have a {{c7::reasonable‑time}} requirement.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Material is within the scope of discovery if it is {{c1::non-privileged}}, {{c2::relevant to any party’s claim or defense}}, and {{c3::proportional to the needs of the case}}. Proportionality is assessed by considering: - {{c4::Amount in controversy}}. - {{c5::Importance of the issues at stake}} in the action. - {{c6::Resources of the parties}} involved. - {{c7::Importance of the discovery in resolving the issues}}. - {{c8::Parties’ relative access to the information}}. - Whether the {{c9::burden or expense}} of the proposed discovery {{c10::outweighs its likely benefit}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::tenancy at will}} is a tenancy with {{c2::no fixed duration}} that is terminable by {{c3::either party at any time}} without advance notice. 2. Creation: A true tenancy at will generally requires an {{c4::express agreement}} that the lease is {{c5::terminable at will}}. Without such an express agreement, courts usually treat the lease as an {{c6::implied periodic tenancy}}. 3. Termination (by will or by operation of law): 3.1 By will: Either party can terminate the lease at any time, but a {{c7::reasonable demand to vacate}} the premises is usually required. 3.2 By operation of law (occurs upon any of the following): 3.2.1 {{c8::Death}} of either party. 3.2.2 {{c9::Waste}} by the tenant. 3.2.3 {{c10::Assignment}} by the tenant. 3.2.4 {{c11::Transfer of title}} by the landlord. 3.2.5 {{c12::Lease to a third party}} by the landlord.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Fixtures – Definition}} 1.1 Fixtures are {{c2::goods that become attached to real property}} such that an interest in them arises under {{c3::real property law}}. 2. {{c4::Fixture Filing}} 2.1 A fixture filing is a {{c5::financing statement}} filed where a {{c6::mortgage on the related real property}} would be recorded. 3. {{c7::General Priority Rule (Fixtures vs. Real Property Interests)}} 3.1 Priority is governed by a {{c8::first‑to‑file‑or‑record}} rule. 3.2 The party who is first to {{c9::file a fixture filing}} or first to {{c10::record its real property interest}} takes priority. 4. {{c11::PMSI Exception in Fixtures}} 4.1 A {{c12::purchase‑money secured party}} in fixtures can obtain super‑priority. 4.2 If the PMSI secured party makes a fixture filing within {{c13::20 days}} after the goods become fixtures ({{c14::affixation}}), the PMSI {{c15::prevails even over a prior recorded real property interest}}. 5. {{c16::Summary}} 5.1 Default: {{c17::First to file or record wins}}. 5.2 Exception: {{c18::Timely PMSI fixture filing (within 20 days) beats earlier real property interests}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Misrepresentation (fraud) can make a contract voidable. 1. Definition: 1.1 Misrepresentation (fraud) consists of {{c1::false assertions, concealment, or misstatements}} about a {{c2::material fact}}. 1.2 It must occur {{c3::before contract formation or performance}}. 2. Reliance and effect: 2.1 The misrepresentation must {{c4::induce}} the other party to enter the contract. 2.2 The party must {{c5::reasonably}} and {{c6::detrimentally rely}} on the misrepresentation. 2.3 If these conditions are met, the contract is {{c7::voidable}} at the option of the {{c8::misled party}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::deed}} is the written instrument that passes {{c2::legal title}} in real property from the {{c3::grantor}} to the {{c4::grantee}}. For a deed to be effective, it must satisfy the formal requirements for {{c5::validity}} ({{c6::lawful execution}}, {{c7::delivery}}, and {{c8::acceptance}}). Deeds also vary in the scope of {{c9::covenants for title}} they provide: {{c10::general warranty deeds}} provide the broadest protections, {{c11::special warranty deeds}} provide more limited assurances tied to the grantor’s ownership period, and {{c12::quitclaim deeds}} provide {{c13::no covenants}}, merely conveying whatever interest the grantor has.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: As part of the fairness inquiry in personal jurisdiction, courts consider whether the chosen forum is convenient or would {{c1::severely disadvantage}} the defendant. Convenience factor • Core question: Would jurisdiction in the forum {{c2::severely disadvantage the defendant}}? • Relevant considerations: – {{c3::Distance}} to the courthouse and travel burden. – The defendant’s {{c4::inability to travel}} (e.g., health, financial constraints). – The defendant’s {{c5::lack of familiarity with the court system}}. • Severity requirement: Inconvenience must be so great that the defendant is inherently placed at a {{c6::severe disadvantage compared to the plaintiff}}. {{c7::Ordinary inconvenience}} of litigation is not enough to defeat jurisdiction.

subject: Evidence
cloze: The following hearsay exceptions apply only if the declarant is {{c1::unavailable}} (FRE 804): 1. {{c2::Former testimony}} - Testimony given as a witness at another hearing or deposition - Offered against a party (or, in civil cases, a {{c3::predecessor in interest}}) who had an {{c4::opportunity and similar motive}} to develop the testimony by direct, cross, or redirect examination. 2. {{c5::Statements against interest}} - A statement that was against the declarant’s {{c6::pecuniary, proprietary, or penal}} interest when made - A {{c7::reasonable person}} would not have made the statement unless it was true. 3. {{c8::Dying declarations}} - A statement made under a sense of {{c9::impending death}} - Concerning the {{c10::cause or circumstances}} of what the declarant believed to be impending death - Admissible in {{c11::civil cases}} and in {{c12::homicide prosecutions}}. 4. Statements of {{c13::personal or family history}} - Statements about the declarant’s own birth, adoption, marriage, divorce, legitimacy, relationship by blood or marriage, or similar facts of personal or family history - Or, in some cases, statements about {{c14::another person’s}} family history if the declarant was related or intimately associated. 5. Statements offered against a party that {{c15::wrongfully procured unavailability}} - A statement offered against a party who wrongfully caused, or acquiesced in wrongfully causing, the declarant’s {{c16::unavailability}} as a witness - And did so with the {{c17::intent to prevent}} the declarant from testifying.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Foreclosure Basics}} 1.1 Upon default, the {{c2::mortgagee}} can satisfy the debt through {{c3::foreclosure}}, typically by {{c4::judicial action}}. 1.2 The property is {{c5::sold at a foreclosure sale}} to satisfy the debt in whole or in part. 2. {{c6::Deficiency Judgment}} 2.1 If the {{c7::debt exceeds}} the {{c8::sale proceeds}}, the mortgagee may sue the mortgagor for the {{c9::remaining balance}}. 2.2 This remaining balance is called a {{c10::deficiency}}, and the court may enter a {{c11::deficiency judgment}} in favor of the mortgagee. 3. {{c12::Surplus Proceeds and Junior Liens}} 3.1 If sale proceeds {{c13::exceed the debt balance}}, the surplus does not go to the mortgagee. 3.2 {{c14::Junior lienholders}} are paid from any surplus in order of their {{c15::priority}}. 3.3 Any remaining surplus after junior liens are paid goes to the {{c16::mortgagor}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. {{c1::Power of appointment}} is authority granted to a person (the {{c2::donee}}) enabling the donee to designate a new owner of property and how they take it. 1.1 Meaning: The {{c3::donor-testator}} gives the donee a power of appointment. 1.2 This usually arises with {{c4::testamentary wills that create trusts}}. 1.3 Example: T's will leaves property in trust and gives C a power of appointment over the trust property. 2. {{c5::General vs. special}} (a power of appointment can be general or special) 2.1 {{c6::General power}}: The donee can exercise her power in favor of anyone, including {{c7::herself, her estate, her creditors, or the creditors of her estate}}. 2.2 {{c8::Special power}}: The power is exercisable in favor of a {{c9::limited class of appointees}} and cannot include the donee, her estate, her creditors, or the creditors of her estate. 3. {{c10::Present vs. testamentary power}} (the appointment power may be exercisable during the donee's life or only by the donee's will) 3.1 {{c11::Presently exercisable power}}: One exercisable by the donee during her life. 3.2 {{c12::Testamentary power}}: Exercisable only by the donee's will. 3.3 Example: T's will leaves property in trust and provides that C's exercise of her power of appointment is limited to her will, creating a {{c13::testamentary power of appointment}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Unilateral contracts and offer irrevocability: 1.1. In a {{c1::unilateral contract}}, an offer is generally revocable until {{c2::performance begins}}. 1.2. Once the offeree {{c3::starts performance}}, the offer becomes {{c4::irrevocable}} for a {{c5::reasonable time}} to allow completion of performance. 1.3. The start of performance must go beyond {{c6::mere preparation}}. 2. Effect of irrevocability: 2.1. Once irrevocable, the offeror may not {{c7::revoke}} for a reasonable time, but the offeree is not {{c8::obligated to complete performance}}. 2.2. If the offeree {{c9::completes performance within a reasonable time}}, a {{c10::contract is formed}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Lesser-included offenses and merger 1.1. {{c1::Lesser-included offenses}}: once jeopardy attaches for the {{c2::greater offense}}, the defendant cannot later be prosecuted for a {{c1::lesser-included offense}} based on the same conduct. 2. Examples of same vs. different offense 2.1. {{c3::Same offense}} example: First offense requires proof of {{c4::A, B, and C}}; second offense requires proof of {{c5::A and B}} only. The second offense is a {{c6::lesser-included offense}} and is barred as the same offense. 2.2. {{c7::Different offense}} example: First offense requires proof of {{c8::A and B}}; second offense requires proof of {{c9::A, C, and D}}. Each offense contains an {{c10::element the other does not}}, so they are {{c11::different offenses}} and Double Jeopardy does not bar the second prosecution.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Form-of-question objections}}: {{c2::1.1 Calls for narrative}}: a non-specific, open-ended question that allows the witness to tell a story rather than give specific testimony in response to specific questions. {{c3::1.2 Leading}}: the question itself suggests the answer; this is improper on {{c4::direct examination}} unless the witness is hostile or an adverse party, but it is acceptable on {{c5::cross-examination}}. {{c6::1.3 Assumes facts not in evidence}}: the question makes an assumption that has not been established on the record. {{c7::1.4 Argumentative}}: a question that is not designed or intended to elicit relevant facts, but instead is an argumentative assertion. {{c8::1.5 Compound}}: a question that asks more than one question at a time; attorneys must ask questions individually. {{c9::1.6 Beyond the scope of direct}}: arises on cross-examination; attorneys must confine their questions during cross-examination to the scope of direct examination (they cannot ask questions involving matters not discussed on direct). 2. {{c10::Testimonial objections}}: {{c11::2.1 Unresponsive or nonresponsive}}: the witness's testimony does not relate to or directly answer the question asked. These objections must be {{c12::specific and promptly made}}; otherwise they are deemed waived.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Life estate pur autre vie (p.a.v.): 1.1 A {{c1::life estate pur autre vie}} is a life estate measured by the {{c2::life of someone other than the life tenant}}. 1.2 Example: O grants "{{c3::to A for the life of B}}." A is the life tenant, holding the property until {{c4::B dies}}, at which point the property {{c5::reverts to O or passes under any reversion or remainder}}. 2. Transfer of life estates: 2.1 A {{c6::life tenant may transfer her life estate}} to another person. 2.2 The transferee then holds a {{c7::life estate pur autre vie}} measured by the {{c8::original measuring life}}. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life" and A transfers to B. {{c9::B holds a life estate pur autre vie measured by A’s life}}. When {{c10::A dies}}, B’s interest {{c11::terminates}}, and the property {{c12::returns to the grantor (reversion) or passes to any remainder-holder}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. No judge-directed guilty verdict: - A judge {{c1::cannot direct a verdict of guilt}} in a criminal jury trial. - Directing a guilty verdict would deprive the defendant of the {{c2::constitutional right to a jury determination of guilt}}. 2. Judge-directed acquittal allowed: - A judge {{c3::may direct a verdict of acquittal}} (e.g., via a motion for judgment of acquittal) when the evidence is {{c4::legally insufficient}} to support a conviction.

subject: Torts
cloze: Design defect: 1. Definition: 1.1 A {{c1::design defect}} exists when the product's {{c2::design itself}} creates an {{c3::unreasonable risk of danger}} to users or bystanders. 2. Plaintiff’s showing – {{c4::feasible alternative design}}: 2.1 The plaintiff must show that there was a {{c5::technologically and economically feasible alternative design or modification}}; and 2.2 The alternative design would be {{c6::safer as to the risk at issue}} (i.e., would have reduced or avoided the harm without unduly impairing the product's utility or making it prohibitively expensive).

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Lateral support when {{c1::buildings}} are present 1.1 When structures sit on the supported land, liability depends on whether the {{c2::land would have collapsed in its natural state}}. 2. {{c3::Strict liability}} for damage to buildings 2.1 The defendant is strictly liable for damage to buildings on adjacent land only if the plaintiff shows that the land would have {{c4::collapsed in its natural state}}, without the buildings, due to the defendant’s excavation. 2.2 If the extra weight of the buildings is {{c5::not necessary}} to cause subsidence, strict liability covers both land and building damage. 3. {{c6::Negligence}} standard for buildings 3.1 If the land would {{c7::not have collapsed}} in its natural state and subsidence occurs only because of the {{c8::added weight of buildings}}, strict liability does not apply to the building damage. 3.2 In that situation, the plaintiff must prove that the defendant was {{c9::negligent}} in excavating or removing support. 3.3 If negligence is proven, the defendant is liable for loss or damage to both the {{c10::adjacent land}} and its {{c11::buildings}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. Voluntary manslaughter (heat of passion theory): 1.1 Voluntary manslaughter is a {{c1::killing that would otherwise be murder}} but is mitigated when it results from {{c2::adequate provocation (a heat of passion killing)}}. 1.2 Adequate provocation {{c3::does not completely excuse}} the killing; it {{c4::reduces a murder charge to voluntary manslaughter}}. 2. Adequate provocation – required elements: 2.1 {{c5::Objective standard}}: The provocation would cause {{c6::sudden and intense passion}} in an {{c7::ordinary person}}, causing {{c8::loss of self-control}}. 2.2 {{c9::Subjective standard}}: The {{c10::defendant was in fact provoked}} and actually lost self-control. 2.3 {{c11::Cooling-off (objective)}}: There was {{c12::insufficient time for an ordinary person to cool off}} between the provocation and the killing. 2.4 {{c13::Cooling-off (subjective)}}: The defendant {{c14::did not in fact cool off}} between the provocation and the killing. 3. Effect of adequate provocation: 3.1 Adequate provocation is {{c15::not a complete defense to murder}}. 3.2 When proven, it {{c16::mitigates what would otherwise be murder down to voluntary manslaughter}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: {{c1::Hearsay}} is an {{c2::out-of-court statement}} offered to prove the {{c3::truth of the matter asserted}}. These statements are generally inadmissible, subject to certain {{c4::exceptions and exemptions}}. 1. {{c5::Statement}} 1.1 A "statement" is an {{c6::oral or written assertion, or non-verbal conduct intended as an assertion}}. 1.2 {{c7::Non-human assertions}} are not statements (e.g., test results, radar gun reading, dog barking). 1.3 Out-of-court statements are not hearsay if offered to prove anything other than the {{c8::truth of the matter they assert}}. 2. {{c9::Exemptions vs. exceptions}} (Federal Rules) 2.1 {{c10::Exemptions}}: statements are deemed {{c11::non-hearsay}} and thus admitted. 2.2 {{c12::Exceptions}}: statements are deemed {{c13::hearsay}}, but still admitted under an exception. 2.3 Beyond this distinction, there are no practical differences between hearsay exceptions and exemptions; they should be treated the same for admissibility. 2.4 Watch for answer choices that turn on this distinction. A witness's own prior out-of-court statement can be hearsay; thus, an answer that a statement is "not hearsay because the witness is on the stand" is incorrect.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Mortgagor transfer}} 1.1 Where the mortgagor sells the property, the {{c2::mortgage remains on the land}}; the grantee takes {{c3::subject to the mortgage}} but is not personally liable for repayment unless they {{c4::assume}} it. 1.2 The mortgagor remains {{c5::personally liable}} to the mortgagee for the loan. 1.3 {{c6::Assumption}} 1.3.1 If the grantee {{c7::promises to pay the existing mortgage loan}}, the grantee becomes {{c8::primarily liable}} to the mortgagee. 1.3.2 The original mortgagor is {{c9::secondarily liable as a surety}}. 2. {{c10::Mortgagee transfer}} 2.1 A mortgagee (creditor) can transfer her interest by: 2.1.1 {{c11::Endorsing the mortgage note and delivering it}} to the transferee; or 2.1.2 Executing a separate {{c12::assignment of the mortgage interest}}. 3. {{c13::Holder in due course}} 3.1 A holder in due course of a mortgage note takes it {{c14::free of any personal defenses}} the mortgagor could have raised against the original mortgagee (for example, lack of consideration, fraudulent inducement). 3.2 However, the holder in due course remains subject to {{c15::real defenses}} (for example, duress, fraud in the factum, incapacity, illegality, infancy, insolvency). 4. Requirements for {{c16::holder in due course}} status 4.1 {{c17::Negotiable note}}: The note must be a negotiable instrument made payable to the named mortgagee. 4.2 {{c18::Indorsed}}: The note must be signed (indorsed) by the named mortgagee. 4.3 {{c19::Delivered}}: The note must be delivered to the transferee. 4.4 {{c20::Good faith and value paid}}: The transferee must take the note in good faith (without notice of illegality or defenses) and pay value.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Right to Vote under Equal Protection 1. Fundamental right and standard of review - The {{c1::right to vote}} in general elections is a {{c2::fundamental right}}. - When a law {{c3::denies some citizens the right to vote}} or significantly burdens voting, it is analyzed under {{c4::equal protection}}. - Standard of review: {{c5::strict scrutiny}}. 2. Denial or dilution of the vote - Equal protection is triggered when laws {{c6::deny}} some citizens the right to vote or {{c7::dilute}} their voting power. 3. One-person, one-vote requirement - The {{c8::one-person, one-vote}} requirement must be satisfied for all {{c9::state and local elections}}. - For elected bodies, voting districts must be {{c10::substantially similar in population}} so that votes are weighted equally as nearly as practicable. 4. At-large elections - {{c11::At-large elections}} are systems in which all voters in the jurisdiction vote for {{c12::all office holders}}, rather than separate district representatives. - At-large election schemes are {{c13::constitutional}} if they are not adopted or maintained for a {{c14::discriminatory purpose}} (such as diluting minority voting strength). 5. Framing - Although the right to vote can also be understood as a {{c15::substantive due process}} liberty, exam questions typically frame denials or dilutions of the vote as {{c16::equal protection}} violations requiring {{c17::strict scrutiny}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 3. {{c1::Remedy}} for unconstitutional pretrial identifications 3.1 The defendant may move to {{c2::suppress}} any subsequent {{c3::in-trial (in-court) identifications}} made by the witness. 3.2 Suppression is {{c4::rare}}, because the government can often show an {{c5::independent source}} for the witness’s in-court identification. 3.3 Under the {{c6::independent source doctrine}}, an in-court identification is admissible if it rests on the witness’s {{c7::independent recollection}} (e.g., observations at the time of the crime) rather than the tainted pretrial procedure.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: This card covers three related pretrial protections in criminal procedure: 1. {{c1::Pretrial (preliminary) hearing}} for {{c2::probable cause to detain}}. 2. {{c3::Bail}} limits, including non-excessive and non-arbitrary bail and grounds for denial. 3. {{c4::Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial}}, evaluated under a totality-of-circumstances test with dismissal with prejudice as the remedy for violations.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Perfection by filing a {{c1::financing statement}}: 1. Filing as a primary method: 1.1 A secured party can usually perfect a security interest by filing with the appropriate {{c2::state filing office}}. 2. Required contents of a financing statement: 2.1 Identify the {{c3::debtor}}: 2.1.1 The debtor’s name must exactly match {{c4::official records}}. 2.1.2 For a business organization, the name must match the {{c5::Articles of Incorporation}} or other organizing document. 2.2 Identify the {{c6::secured party/creditor}}. 2.3 Contain an adequate {{c7::description of the collateral}} that reasonably identifies it. 2.4 Be {{c8::authorized by the debtor}}: 2.4.1 Authorization is usually satisfied when the debtor signs the {{c9::security agreement}}. 3. Effect of proper filing: 3.1 If these requirements are met and filing is in the proper place, the security interest is {{c10::perfected}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: At common law, tenants owed several key duties: 1. Duty to {{c1::repair}} and maintain the premises (subject in residential leases to the {{c2::implied warranty of habitability}}). 2. Duty not to commit {{c3::waste}} (including voluntary, permissive, and ameliorative waste). 3. Rules on {{c4::destruction of the premises}} (tenant owed rent at common law, may {{c5::terminate}} under modern law when destroyed without fault). 4. Duty to {{c6::pay rent}} and avoid {{c7::illegal uses}} of the property. 5. Possible tort liability for injuries to third persons from {{c8::dangerous conditions within the tenant's control}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::covenant}} is a {{c2::promise to do or refrain from doing something related to land}}; it is a {{c3::contractual limitation or promise}} regarding land. 1.1 Note: Covenants are {{c4::not property interests}}. 2. {{c5::Real covenant}}: A real covenant is a covenant concerning real property. 2.1 {{c6::Runs with the land at law}}: Subsequent owners may be {{c7::burdened by the covenant or may enforce it}}. 2.2 Different requirements apply for {{c8::burdens and benefits running with the land}}. 2.3 {{c9::Affirmative covenant}}: A promise to {{c10::do something related to land}}. 2.4 {{c11::Restrictive covenant}}: A promise to {{c12::refrain from doing something related to land}}. 3. Termination (a covenant can terminate by): 3.1 {{c13::Written release}}. 3.2 {{c14::Merger}} of the benefited and burdened estates. 3.3 {{c15::Condemnation}} of the burdened property. 4. Covenants vs. {{c16::equitable servitudes}} (difference is the {{c17::remedy}}): 4.1 Covenant: {{c18::Money damages}}. 4.2 Equitable servitude: {{c19::Injunction}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. {{c1::Operating agreement}} 1.1 The operating agreement is the primary {{c2::governing document}} of an LLC, similar to {{c3::corporate bylaws}}. 1.2 It governs: • Relations among {{c4::members}}; • The {{c5::rights and duties}} of members and managers; • The {{c6::management structure}} (member-managed vs manager-managed); • {{c7::Voting rights and procedures}}; • {{c8::Allocation and distribution of profits and losses}}; and • Procedures for {{c9::amending}} the agreement. 2. {{c10::Management structure}} 2.1 Default rule: By default, an LLC is {{c11::member-managed}}—each member has authority to participate in management. 2.2 The operating agreement may instead provide for a {{c12::manager-managed}} LLC with one or more managers and non-managing members. 3. {{c13::Voting}} 3.1 Voting is determined by the {{c14::operating agreement}}. 3.2 Voting may be: • {{c15::Per capita}} (equal voting rights); or • Proportionate to {{c16::ownership interests}}. 4. {{c17::Distributions}} 4.1 The operating agreement generally dictates how {{c18::profits and losses}} are allocated and distributed among members. 4.2 Absent an agreement, default {{c19::statutory rules}} control allocation and distribution, often per capita or by ownership share.

subject: Contracts
cloze: {{c1::Unconscionability}} allows a court to refuse to enforce a contract or clause that is so {{c2::unfair or oppressive}} that enforcement would be unjust. It has two main aspects: {{c3::procedural unconscionability}} (problems with the {{c4::bargaining process}}, like oppression or surprise) and {{c5::substantive unconscionability}} ({{c6::overly harsh or one-sided terms}}). Courts usually look for some degree of both, judged at the time of {{c7::contract formation}}. A court may {{c8::refuse to enforce}} the contract, {{c9::sever the unconscionable clause}}, or {{c10::limit its application}} to avoid an unconscionable result.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A prior restraint can be valid only if both {{c1::substantive}} and {{c2::procedural}} requirements are met. Substantive requirement – government interest: • There must be at least a {{c3::significant governmental interest}} justifying the restraint—a {{c4::special societal harm}}. • {{c5::National security}} may be a sufficient interest, but the harm must be {{c6::more than theoretical}}. Procedural safeguards: • The restraint must be {{c7::narrow, reasonable, and definite}}. • The scheme must provide a {{c8::prompt, final judicial determination}} for those whose speech is restrained.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Although only final orders are usually appealable, certain {{c1::interlocutory orders}} are reviewable {{c2::as of right}}: 1. {{c3::Injunctions}} – orders concerning an injunction. 2. {{c4::Receivers}} – orders concerning the appointment of a receiver. 3. {{c5::Patent}} – orders in patent cases where only an {{c6::accounting}} is left in the case. 4. {{c7::Property}} – orders affecting property, such as {{c8::attachment}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Purpose controls interpretation: 1.1 Courts interpret conditions in light of their {{c1::purpose}} and the parties' {{c2::intent}}. 1.2 {{c3::Substantial performance}} of a condition may suffice if it fulfills the condition's {{c4::purpose}}, particularly to avoid {{c5::forfeiture}}. 1.3 If a condition is designed to {{c6::protect one party}}, it will be interpreted consistent with that {{c7::protective intent}}. 2. Waiver and estoppel: 2.1 A party {{c8::protected or benefitted}} by a condition may {{c9::waive}} it, expressly or by {{c10::conduct inconsistent}} with insisting on strict compliance. 2.2 That party may be {{c11::estopped}} from enforcing the condition if the other party has {{c12::reasonably relied}} on conduct suggesting it would not be strictly enforced. 3. Excuse of conditions: 3.1 Conditions may be legally excused by {{c13::breach}} or {{c14::anticipatory repudiation}} by the party whose performance is conditioned. 3.2 A party whose performance is subject to a condition cannot {{c15::wrongfully prevent or hinder}} the condition's occurrence; such conduct results in {{c16::excuse of the condition}}. 3.3 {{c17::Waiver}} or {{c18::estoppel}} can also operate as an {{c19::excuse}}, treating the condition as {{c20::satisfied or disregarded}} so the duty remains.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Federal law governs {{c1::transfer of venue}} in civil cases. A case may be transferred from one federal district to another district in which the case {{c2::could have been filed}}, or to a district to which {{c3::all parties consent}}. When venue is {{c4::proper}}, transfer is discretionary based on the {{c5::interest of justice}} and {{c6::convenience of parties and witnesses}}. When venue is {{c7::improper}}, the court may {{c8::transfer in the interest of justice or dismiss}}. After transfer, special rules govern which court’s {{c9::choice-of-law rules}} apply, and {{c10::valid forum-selection clauses}} usually control the choice of federal district absent {{c11::compelling public factors}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: Courts may recognize {{c1::implied-in-fact contracts}} between unmarried cohabitants, formed by their {{c2::conduct}} rather than explicit words, to {{c3::share property, income, or assets}}. A court may also characterize the relationship as a {{c4::joint venture}} or {{c5::partnership}} when the parties combine efforts and resources for a {{c6::common economic or profit-seeking purpose}}. In some cases, courts may impose a {{c7::constructive trust}} as a remedial device to reflect an {{c8::equitable obligation to hold property for another}} and to prevent {{c9::unjust enrichment}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: {{c1::Public forums}} are government property that the government is constitutionally required to make available for speech (e.g., {{c2::sidewalks, parks}}). Regulations in public forums must be {{c3::content-neutral}}. Test for public forum restrictions (to be upheld, the restriction must): 1. Be {{c4::content-neutral}}: 1.1 It should regulate only the {{c5::time, place, or manner}} of speech; if the restriction is content-based, {{c6::strict scrutiny}} applies. 2. Be {{c7::narrowly tailored}} to serve an {{c8::important government purpose}}. 3. Leave open {{c9::adequate alternative channels of communication}}: 3.1 The regulation does not have to be the {{c10::least restrictive alternative}}. Notes: 4. {{c11::Permit fees that vary depending on the type of speech}} are content-based and {{c12::unconstitutional}}. 5. When held open for speech, restrictions on speech in {{c13::limited public forums}} are analyzed as {{c14::public forum}} restrictions.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. When jeopardy attaches 1.1. Jeopardy generally attaches at the {{c1::start of trial proceedings}}. 1.2. Jeopardy does {{c2::not}} attach merely from the {{c3::filing of charges}} or from {{c4::grand jury proceedings}} alone. 1.3. In a {{c5::jury trial}}, jeopardy attaches once the jury is {{c6::impaneled and sworn}}. 1.4. In a {{c7::bench trial}}, jeopardy attaches once the {{c8::first witness is sworn}}. 1.5. In {{c9::plea proceedings}}, jeopardy attaches once the court {{c10::accepts a guilty plea}}. 2. Exceptions allowing later prosecution for a greater offense 2.1. {{c11::New evidence}} for a greater offense becomes available after the first trial. 2.2. The defendant may be tried for {{c12::battery}} and later tried for {{c13::homicide}} if the victim subsequently {{c14::dies}} from the battery, because the greater offense was {{c15::not complete}} at the time of the first prosecution.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Under {{c1::equitable conversion}}, if the property is {{c2::destroyed or damaged before closing}} through no fault of either party, the {{c3::buyer}} bears the {{c4::risk of loss}} in {{c5::most jurisdictions}}, {{c6::even if the buyer has not taken possession}}. The parties may {{c7::reallocate}} this risk by {{c8::contract}} (e.g., keeping risk on the seller until closing). If the {{c9::seller}} receives {{c10::insurance proceeds}} for the loss, the seller must {{c11::credit those proceeds against the purchase price}}, preventing a {{c12::windfall}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: An {{c1::adverse possessor}} may {{c2::lease}} all or part of the land to a third party and still be treated as {{c3::in possession}}, because the tenant’s occupancy counts as the possessor’s own. However, title obtained by adverse possession is {{c4::not marketable}} until it is confirmed in an {{c5::action to quiet title}} or similar proceeding.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Infants generally have the right to disaffirm contracts, but a contract can nonetheless be {{c1::enforced against}} a former minor if there is {{c2::implied affirmation (ratification)}} after gaining capacity. Ratification can be shown where: 1) The {{c3::agreement was entered into before capacity}} (while the party was an infant); 2) The party has since {{c4::gained capacity}} (e.g., reached majority); 3) After gaining capacity, the party {{c5::retains the benefits}} of the contract rather than disaffirming. When these elements are met, the contract is considered {{c6::ratified}} and the former minor {{c7::loses the right to disaffirm}} on the basis of infancy.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General SILA rule for vehicles: 1.1. After arresting a recent occupant of a vehicle, police may search the vehicle’s {{c1::passenger compartment}}, including containers and the {{c2::glove box}}, incident to arrest only if, at the time of the search: 1.1.1. The arrestee is {{c3::unsecured}} and may {{c4::access the vehicle interior}}; or 1.1.2. Police {{c5::reasonably believe}} the vehicle contains {{c6::evidence of the offense for which the arrest was made}}. 2. Trunk limitation: 2.1. Police may not search the {{c7::trunk}} of the vehicle solely as a search incident to arrest. 2.2. To search the trunk, officers need {{c8::probable cause}} (e.g., to use the automobile exception) or {{c9::valid consent}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. Trust basics 1.1 A trust is a {{c1::fiduciary relationship}} in which a {{c2::trustee}} holds {{c3::legal title}} to property for the benefit of {{c4::beneficiaries}}. 1.2 Key roles: The {{c5::settlor}} creates the trust and transfers legal title to the trustee, who manages and administers property for the beneficiaries, who hold {{c6::equitable interests}}. 1.3 {{c7::Revocability}}: Under modern statutes, trusts are generally {{c8::revocable}} unless expressly made {{c9::irrevocable}}. 2. Main types of trusts 2.1 {{c10::Express trusts}}: intentionally created by the property owner, including {{c11::private trusts}} (for defined or ascertainable beneficiaries, inter vivos or testamentary) and {{c12::charitable trusts}} (for an indefinite class or the public). 2.2 {{c13::Resulting trusts}}: implied by law, most often when an {{c14::express trust fails}}, typically returning the beneficial interest to the {{c15::settlor}} or the settlor's {{c16::estate}}. 2.3 {{c17::Constructive trusts}}: {{c18::equitable remedies}} imposed on property held by a {{c19::wrongdoer}} to prevent {{c20::unjust enrichment}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: {{c1::Interpleader}} allows a property holder (the {{c2::stakeholder}}) to file a single lawsuit compelling all rival {{c3::claimants}} to litigate their competing rights to specific property or a fund in one proceeding. Interpleader in federal court is available through {{c4::Rule 22 interpleader}} and {{c5::statutory interpleader}}, which share the same basic function but differ in their {{c6::jurisdictional, service, and venue requirements}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Two overarching discovery questions: 1. {{c1::Scope of discovery}} – whether the requested information falls within the rules’ permissible scope (e.g., {{c2::relevance, proportionality, and non-privileged matter}}). 2. {{c3::Privilege and protection}} – whether the information is protected by a {{c4::privilege}} (such as attorney–client) or another protection like the {{c5::work-product doctrine}}. Even information within the scope of discovery is generally not discoverable if it is {{c6::privileged or protected}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Assumption of risk}} 1. The defendant can deny the plaintiff’s recovery by establishing that the plaintiff assumed the risk of damage caused by the defendant’s act. 2. Requirements (defendant’s burden) 2.1. The plaintiff {{c2::knew of the risk}} ({{c3::subjective standard; knowledge can be inferred from the facts}}); and 2.2. The plaintiff {{c4::voluntarily proceeded in the face of that risk}}. 3. {{c5::Express assumption of risk}} 3.1. A plaintiff can expressly assume the risk by {{c6::agreement}} (e.g., an {{c7::exculpatory clause}}). 3.2. Such clauses are less likely to be enforced if they are part of an {{c8::adhesion contract}} or otherwise against public policy. 4. Relationship to intentional torts 4.1. {{c9::None of these negligence defenses (comparative negligence, contributory negligence, or assumption of risk) applies to intentional torts}}. 4.2. However, a plaintiff can {{c10::consent to intentional torts}}, which may provide a separate defense.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Major common law crimes are grouped by their requisite mens rea: 1. {{c1::General intent crimes}}: Defendant is {{c2::aware of the actions and any attendant circumstances; intent may be inferred}}. Examples: {{c3::battery, rape, kidnapping, and false imprisonment}}. 2. {{c4::Specific intent crimes}} ({{c5::FIAT}}: {{c6::first-degree murder, inchoate crimes, assault, theft}}): Defendant has a {{c7::specific intent or objective to commit the particular crime}}. Examples: {{c8::attempt, larceny and robbery, forgery, false pretenses, embezzlement, conspiracy, assault, burglary, first-degree murder, and solicitation}}. 3. {{c9::Malice crimes}}: Involve {{c10::reckless disregard of, or undertaking an obvious risk from which a harmful result is expected}}. Examples: {{c11::common law murder (malice aforethought) and arson}}. 4. {{c12::Strict liability crimes}}: {{c13::No mens rea element is required}}. Examples: {{c14::statutory rape, regulatory crimes, administrative crimes, and morality crimes such as bigamy and polygamy}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Detrimental reliance}} as a basis for irrevocability: 1.1. An offer may be treated as irrevocable when the offeree {{c2::reasonably and foreseeably relies}} on the offer to their {{c3::detriment}}. 1.2. The reliance must be {{c4::substantial}} and of a kind that the offeror should {{c5::reasonably expect}} (e.g., {{c6::subcontractor bids relied on by a general contractor}}). 2. Effect of detrimental reliance: 2.1. The offeror may be {{c7::estopped from revoking}} the offer for a period necessary to {{c8::avoid injustice}}. 2.2. Courts may enforce the offer as an {{c9::option contract}} or provide {{c10::reliance-based remedies}}. 3. Bar exam focus: 3.1. Reasonable, foreseeable {{c11::detrimental reliance}} by the offeree can render an offer {{c12::irrevocable}}, especially in {{c13::construction bidding}} contexts.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Congress may {{c1::broadly delegate rulemaking authority}} to executive officers and administrative agencies by statute, and validly promulgated agency rules can have the {{c2::force and effect of law}}. Delegation is limited mainly by the requirement that Congress provide {{c3::intelligible standards}} and that it not {{c4::reserve executive or judicial enforcement powers to itself or its officers}}. Although excessive‑delegation challenges rarely succeed, {{c5::legislative vetoes and presidential line‑item vetoes}} have been held unconstitutional because they {{c6::bypass bicameralism and presentment or improperly reallocate legislative power}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: {{c1::Freedom of association}} protects the right to participate in groups to pursue {{c2::First Amendment–protected goals}}. Government interference generally triggers {{c3::strict scrutiny}}, and key doctrines address {{c4::the basic strict scrutiny test}}, {{c5::restrictions on group discrimination}}, {{c6::criminal liability for membership}}, and {{c7::disclosure requirements that chill association}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Learned treatises}}: 1.1 Arises with {{c2::expert testimony only}}. 1.2 Learned treatises are {{c3::accepted authority in a given field}}. 1.3 They must be established as {{c4::reliable and accepted authority}} by {{c5::testimony, admission, or judicial notice}}. 1.4 Experts can {{c6::rely on learned treatises on direct examination}} or can be {{c7::impeached with information from treatises on cross-examination}}. 1.5 If admissible, statements from learned treatises may only be {{c8::read into evidence}} (not received as exhibits). 2. {{c9::Family records}}: statements of fact found in family keepsakes (for example, jewelry engravings, family Bibles, genealogies). 3. {{c10::Ancient documents}}: an {{c11::authenticated document}} prepared {{c12::before January 1, 1998}}, used to prove the {{c13::truth of its contents}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: There are three main types of {{c1::defeasible fees}}: 1. {{c2::Fee simple determinable}} – The estate {{c3::automatically ends}} upon the specified event, and the property {{c4: :automatically reverts to the grantor}}. The grantor holds a {{c5::possibility of reverter}}. 2. {{c6::Fee simple subject to condition subsequent}} – The grantor {{c7::retains the power to terminate}} the grantee’s estate if the condition occurs, but termination is {{c8::not automatic}}; the grantor must {{c9::take affirmative action (reenter)}}. The grantor holds a {{c10::right of reentry}} ({{c11::power of termination}}). 3. {{c12::Fee simple subject to an executory interest}} – Upon the event, the estate {{c13::automatically shifts to a third party}}. That third party holds a {{c14::shifting executory interest}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Surplus and deficiency – General rule}} 1.1 {{c2::Surplus}} - If the proceeds from the disposition of collateral {{c3::exceed}} the remaining secured obligation: - The secured party must pay any {{c4::surplus}} to the debtor. 1.2 {{c5::Deficiency}} - If the proceeds from the disposition are {{c6::less than}} the remaining secured obligation: - The debtor remains liable for the {{c7::deficiency}} (the unpaid balance). 2. {{c8::Exception for certain collateral types}} - When the underlying transaction involves collateral consisting of: - {{c9::Accounts}}, - {{c10::Chattel paper}}, - {{c11::Payment intangibles}}, or - {{c12::Promissory notes}}, - {{c13::Neither party is liable}} for a surplus or a deficiency after disposition. - The secured party {{c14::keeps all proceeds}} without owing surplus. - The debtor is {{c15::not liable for any shortfall}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Overview 1.1. The {{c1::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}} is a {{c2::post-charge}} right that {{c3::automatically attaches once formal charges have been filed}} and protects the defendant at all subsequent {{c4::critical stages}} of the prosecution. 1.2. After attachment, police may not {{c5::deliberately elicit incriminating statements}} about the {{c6::charged offense}} outside the presence of counsel, and the right is {{c7::offense-specific}}. 2. Relation to the Fifth Amendment and ineffective assistance 2.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel differs from the {{c8::Fifth Amendment Miranda right to counsel}}, which must be {{c9::invoked}} and is {{c10::not offense-specific}}. 2.2. The Sixth Amendment also guarantees the right to {{c11::effective assistance of counsel}}, which requires a showing of {{c12::deficient performance}} and {{c13::prejudice (a reasonable probability of a different outcome)}} to establish a violation on appeal.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: When there is a more appropriate forum for the litigation, but the case cannot be {{c1::transferred}} there, a court may {{c2::dismiss the action}} under the doctrine of {{c3::forum non conveniens}}. 1. Adequate alternative forum 1.1. Because dismissal is consequential, a court will not grant forum non conveniens without finding that there is an {{c4::adequate alternative forum}}. 1.2. When adequacy is in doubt, a court may {{c5::stay the proceeding}} rather than dismiss, so that it can resume litigation if necessary. 2. Factors 2.1. The court evaluates forum non conveniens based on the same {{c6::public and private factors}} as for venue transfer (e.g., convenience, applicable law, burden on local courts and jurors). 2.2. A {{c7::strong showing}} of both public and private interests is generally required to justify {{c8::dismissal or a stay}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Federal courts must have an {{c1::ADR program}}, and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure actively encourage {{c2::settlement}} through various means, including {{c3::mandatory settlement conferences}}. 1. {{c4::ADR}}: {{c5::Alternative dispute resolution}} generally refers to any means of settling disputes {{c6::outside the courtroom}}, including {{c7::arbitration}} and {{c8::mediation}}. 2. {{c9::Mandatory settlement conference}}: A {{c10::court-appointed advisor}} meets with the parties privately and offers an {{c11::evaluation of the weaknesses}} of their respective cases. 3. {{c12::Settlement offers}}: A party defending a claim may make a {{c13::formal settlement offer}} at least {{c14::14 days before}} the date set for trial. 4. {{c15::Settlement for less than offer}}: If the claimant rejects a settlement offer and then obtains a judgment {{c16::less favorable than the unaccepted offer}}, the claimant must pay {{c17::costs incurred by the offering party after the offer was made}}. Ordinarily, costs do not include {{c18::attorney's fees}}. The exception involves litigation where {{c19::federal fee-shifting statutes}} define fees to be part of costs.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General Rule: If {{c1::probable cause}} exists, police may search an {{c2::entire vehicle}} (including the trunk) and any {{c3::containers or compartments}} inside that may contain the evidence they are searching for. 2. Requirements 2.1 Police must have {{c4::probable cause}} to search the vehicle. 2.2 Probable cause must {{c5::arise before the search begins}}. 3. Scope of permissible search 3.1 Police can search the {{c6::entire vehicle}} and {{c7::all containers within the vehicle}} that might contain the object for which they are searching. 3.2 For example: Police may open {{c8::packages or luggage}} that might contain evidence relating to the reason they searched the vehicle. 3.3 Police may search {{c9::passengers and their belongings}} if those containers might reasonably hold the object of the search.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Receipt of stolen property}} – general rule: 1.1 Receiving {{c2::possession and control}} of personal property. 1.2 That is {{c3::known to have been illegally obtained by another}}. 1.3 With the {{c4::intent to permanently deprive}} the owner of her interest in it. 2. Required elements: 2.1 Receipt of possession and control: {{c5::physical possession is not required}}; the defendant can have possession or control by designating the property's location or arranging to sell it for the original thief. 2.2 {{c6::Stolen personal property}}: the property must have been stolen at the time the defendant receives it. 2.3 {{c7::Knowledge}} it was illegally obtained by another: the defendant must {{c8::know or have reason to know}} the property is stolen. 2.4 {{c4::Intent to permanently deprive}} the owner of his interest. 2.5 {{c9::Police sting situations}}: if the police and the true property owner know of or arranged the defendant's receipt of the property, it is not truly stolen; however, the defendant can be convicted of {{c10::attempted receipt of stolen property}} if she intended to receive the property believing it to be stolen.

subject: Corporations
cloze: A corporation is formed when {{c1::articles of incorporation are filed with the state}}. A corporation formed in accordance with applicable laws is a {{c2::de jure corporation}}. 1. {{c3::Articles of incorporation}} (must include): 1.1 {{c4::Name}}: the corporate name. 1.2 {{c5::Shares}}: the maximum number of shares the corporation is authorized to issue. 1.3 {{c6::Incorporators}}: the names and addresses of each person who forms the corporation. 1.4 {{c7::Registered office and agent}}: the name and address of the initial registered agent and registered office. 1.5 {{c8::Optional provisions}}: the articles can include any other provisions regarding management, as long as they are legal. 2. {{c9::Statement of purpose}}: 2.1 Some states require a statement regarding the corporation's purpose. 2.2 Most corporations use {{c10::boilerplate language}} allowing the corporation to take any action necessary to carry out its business or affairs. 2.3 A corporation that includes a {{c11::narrow purpose}} in its articles {{c12::cannot take action unrelated to that purpose}}. 3. {{c13::Bylaws}}: written rules for managing the corporation, which provide for ordinary business conduct (e.g., election of board members, meeting times, etc.). 3.1 Must be adopted by the {{c14::incorporators or the board of directors}}. 3.2 {{c15::Shareholders can amend}} initial bylaws. 3.3 Bylaws can contain any provision for managing and regulating the corporation's affairs as long as it is {{c16::legal}}. 3.4 In conflicts between bylaws and the articles of incorporation, the {{c17::articles}} control.

subject: Real Property
cloze: {{c1::Merger (Shelley’s Rule / Rule in Shelley’s Case)}} 1. {{c2::When it arises}} 1.1 Applies when a conveyance gives a {{c3::life estate}} to a grantee and a {{c4::remainder to that same grantee’s heirs}}. 1.2 Classic form: "{{c5::to A for life, then to A’s heirs}}" while A is alive. 2. {{c6::Common-law effect}} 2.1 The {{c7::life estate}} in A and the {{c8::remainder in A’s heirs}} {{c9::merge in A}}. 2.2 A takes a {{c10::fee simple absolute}}. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life, then to A’s heirs"; at common law, A ends up with {{c11::fee simple absolute}}. 3. {{c12::Modern rule}} 3.1 Shelley’s Rule has been {{c13::abolished in most jurisdictions}}. 3.2 Instead: - A has a {{c14::life estate}}. - A’s heirs have {{c15::contingent remainders}} (unascertained while A is alive). - O retains a {{c16::reversion}} in case A dies without heirs. 3.3 Modern law generally {{c17::honors the grantor’s language}} rather than forcing merger.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Situations where extrinsic evidence is allowed despite the {{c1::Parol Evidence Rule (PER)}}: 1.1 {{c2::Partial integration / separate agreement}}: - The writing is only partially integrated, so {{c3::consistent additional terms}} may be admitted. - Additional terms are of a type that would {{c4::naturally be in a separate agreement}}. 1.2 {{c5::Mistake in writing (reformation)}}: - Evidence is admissible to show a {{c6::mistake in reducing the agreement to writing}} and to support {{c7::reformation}}. 1.3 {{c8::Misrepresentation, fraud, duress, or illegality}}: - PER does not bar evidence offered to show that the contract is {{c9::invalid or voidable}} for these reasons. 1.4 {{c10::Condition precedent}} to effectiveness: - Extrinsic evidence can show that a {{c11::condition had to occur before}} the written agreement would become effective. 1.5 {{c12::Subsequent modifications}}: - PER does not apply to oral or written modifications made {{c13::after}} the integrated writing; such later agreements are not "parol" as to that writing. 1.6 {{c14::Interpretation of terms}}: - Extrinsic evidence is admissible to clarify the {{c15::meaning the parties intended to give particular terms}}, especially ambiguous ones.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 {{c1::Restitution}} and {{c2::liquidated damages}} are additional types of damages that may be available. 2. {{c3::Restitution damages}}: 2.1 Restitution arises where a party has been {{c4::unjustly enriched}}. 2.2 Restitution is awarded based on the {{c5::value of the benefit wrongfully conferred}}. 2.3 A party cannot recover both {{c6::expectation damages}} and {{c7::restitution damages}} for the same loss. 3. {{c8::Liquidated damages}}: 3.1 Liquidated damages are {{c9::agreed-upon contract provisions}} that stipulate specified damages upon breach. 3.2 Requirements: A liquidated damages provision is valid only if: 3.2.1 Damages were {{c10::difficult to project at the time of contract formation}}. 3.2.2 The amount is a {{c11::reasonable estimate of probable actual damages}} and not a {{c12::penalty}}. 4. {{c13::Duty to mitigate}}: 4.1 The plaintiff cannot recover {{c14::reasonably avoidable damages}}; for example, the plaintiff must refrain from incurring additional losses after receiving notice of breach. 4.2 The plaintiff may recover the {{c15::reasonable cost of mitigation}} (e.g., the cost to avoid incurring further damages). 4.3 {{c16::Employment contracts}}: The plaintiff’s damages can be reduced if the defendant can show a {{c17::comparable job in the same locale}} was available to the plaintiff and the plaintiff failed to take it. 4.4 The defendant bears the {{c18::burden of showing}} the plaintiff's failure to mitigate.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::False imprisonment}}: 1.1 The {{c2::unlawful confinement}} of a person; 1.2 {{c3::Without their consent}}; and 1.3 Consent cannot be obtained through {{c4::coercion, threat, or deception}}. 2. {{c5::Kidnapping}}: 2.1 The unlawful confinement of a person that involves either: 2.1.1 Some {{c6::movement of the victim}} ({{c7::asportation}}); or 2.1.2 {{c8::Concealment}} of the victim in an unknown, hidden, or secret location. 2.1.3 Note: {{c9::false imprisonment can become kidnapping if the victim is moved and/or concealed}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: An {{c1::initial aggressor}} normally cannot claim self-defense, but may regain the right in either of two situations: 1. {{c2::Withdrawal and communication}}: - The initial aggressor {{c3::effectively withdraws}} from the confrontation before the need for self-defense arises; and - He {{c4::clearly communicates}} his desire to withdraw or stop fighting. 2. {{c5::Sudden deadly escalation by the victim}}: - The victim of the initial aggression suddenly {{c6::escalates a minor dispute into a deadly altercation}}. - The initial aggressor may then use otherwise justified self-defense, including {{c7::deadly force}} if the deadly self-defense requirements are met.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Service of process is delivery to the {{c1::defendant}} by the {{c2::plaintiff}} of the {{c3::summons and complaint}}, which satisfies the {{c4::notice requirement for personal jurisdiction}}. Subsequent papers filed with the court (e.g., motions, answers) do {{c5::not require formal service}}. Service requirements: 1. What must be served 1.1. {{c6::Summons}}: formal notice of the suit, signed by the court clerk, telling the defendant when and where to appear and identifying the court, the parties, and the plaintiff's attorney; and 1.2. Copy of the {{c7::complaint}}. 2. Timing 2.1. Service must be completed within {{c8::90 days}} of filing the case. 2.2. If not satisfied, the case is {{c9::dismissed without prejudice}}, unless the plaintiff shows {{c10::good cause for delay}}. 3. Who may serve 3.1. Any {{c11::non-party}} who is at least {{c12::18 years old}} may serve process.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In extraordinary circumstances, a judge can take a case from the jury and render a decision on an issue. This can occur during trial ({{c1::judgment as a matter of law, JMOL}}) or after a jury verdict ({{c2::renewed judgment as a matter of law, RJMOL}}). The court views the evidence in the light most favorable to the {{c3::non‑moving party}}. 1. {{c4::Judgment as a matter of law (JMOL)}} 1.1 A JMOL motion may be brought by either party before the case is {{c5::submitted to the jury}}. 1.2 Timing: the {{c6::defendant}} can move for JMOL at the {{c7::close of the plaintiff’s evidence}} or at the {{c8::close of all evidence}}; the {{c9::plaintiff}} can move at the {{c10::close of all evidence}}. 2. {{c11::JMOL standard}} 2.1 The court can grant JMOL on an issue if a {{c12::reasonable jury}} would not have a {{c13::sufficient evidentiary basis}} to disagree as to the result (i.e., {{c14::reasonable people could not disagree}}). 3. {{c15::Renewed motion for judgment as a matter of law (RJMOL)}} 3.1 After the court enters judgment based on a jury verdict, the {{c16::losing party}} can file an RJMOL seeking entry of judgment in its favor. 3.2 Timing: the motion must be filed within {{c17::28 days}} after entry of judgment. 3.3 Prerequisite: an RJMOL can be filed only if that party previously made a {{c18::JMOL motion}} at the appropriate time during trial. 4. {{c19::RJMOL standard}} 4.1 The standard is the same as for JMOL: the court may grant RJMOL if there is {{c20::insufficient evidence}} for a reasonable jury to have reached the verdict (i.e., {{c21::reasonable people could not disagree}} as to the correct result).

subject: Agency
cloze: Principals may be held liable to third parties for torts committed by their agents acting as {{c1::employees or servants}}. {{c2::Respondeat superior}} is the doctrine under which principal liability arises for torts committed within the {{c3::scope of agency or employment}}. For torts committed outside that scope (where respondeat superior does not apply) the principal can still be liable if the agent {{c4::acted with authority}}. 1. {{c5::Requirements}} (principal will be liable where): 1.1 An {{c6::employer-employee relationship}} exists between the principal and the party who caused the injury; the principal is generally not liable for {{c7::independent contractors}}. 1.2 The tortious conduct was committed {{c8::within the scope of employment}}, meaning: 1.2.1 The conduct was the {{c9::same or similar in nature}} to that which the employee was hired to perform; 1.2.2 The tort was committed {{c10::in service of the employer}}; and/or 1.2.3 The conduct was intended, at least in part, to {{c11::further the employer's goals}}. 2. {{c12::Intentional torts}} 2.1 The employer is usually {{c13::not liable}} because intentional torts are usually outside the scope of employment. 2.2 {{c14::Exception}}: the employer can be held liable where the intentional tort occurs as a {{c15::natural incident of carrying out the employer's business}} (for example, a bouncer using force while ejecting patrons).

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: For a will to be valid, the testator must have {{c1::testamentary capacity}} and the requisite {{c2::testamentary intent}}. Contests over the validity of a will often involve whether the testator had the requisite capacity or intent. 1. {{c3::Capacity}} (the person executing the will must be {{c4::18 or older}} and have mental capacity) 1.1 Age is determined at the time the will is {{c5::executed}}. 1.2 Mental capacity means that, at the time of execution, the testator understands: 1.2.1 The {{c6::nature of the act}} (that they are executing a will). 1.2.2 The {{c7::nature and extent of their property}}. 1.2.3 The persons who are the {{c8::natural objects of their bounty}}. 1.2.4 How these factors relate to form a {{c9::coherent plan of distribution}}. 1.3 There is a {{c10::rebuttable presumption}} that the testator had mental capacity.
