Physical ailments or drug addiction do not, by themselves, create a presumption of incapacity. 2. {{c11::Testamentary intent}} (the testator must intend that the instrument operate as their will) 2.1 Testamentary intent is usually established by the {{c12::provisions and language in the instrument itself}}. 2.2 {{c13::Present}} intent is required: the testator must have present testamentary intent; mere intent to make a will in the {{c14::future}} is insufficient. 2.3 {{c15::Extrinsic evidence}} is allowed to prove the presence or absence of testamentary intent. At common law, {{c16::strict compliance}} with formalities was required; under the UPC, {{c17::substantial compliance}} may be sufficient where intent is clear.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Function of the {{c1::Necessary and Proper Clause}} 1.1 The Necessary and Proper Clause enables Congress to take actions that are not themselves enumerated to {{c2::implement its express powers}}. 1.2 It authorizes any means that are {{c3::useful or convenient}}, so long as they are {{c4::not otherwise unconstitutional}}. 2. Implied powers 2.1 The Clause is the textual basis for Congress’s {{c5::implied powers}}. 2.2 These implied powers exist to {{c6::carry into execution Congress’s other enumerated powers}} (e.g., commerce, taxing and spending, military). 3. Not an independent source of power 3.1 The Necessary and Proper Clause is {{c7::not an independent or standalone source}} of congressional power. 3.2 Any law justified under the Clause must be {{c8::tied to another valid federal power}}. 3.3 On the MBE, the Necessary and Proper Clause by itself is usually an {{c9::incorrect answer choice}} for the source of Congress’s power to act.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Article 9 provides {{c1::temporary perfection}} when the {{c2::debtor or collateral moves to another state}}, but the secured party must act within specific {{c3::time limits}} or risk losing {{c4::perfection}} and {{c5::priority}}. Key scenarios: - {{c6::Debtor relocation}}: prior perfection continues for {{c7::four months}} after the move; the secured party must perfect in the new state within that four‑month window. - {{c8::Movement of collateral perfected by possession}}: perfection continues if {{c9::possession would perfect under the new state’s law}}. - {{c10::Titled vehicles}}: if a new certificate of title is issued in another state, the original perfection lasts as long as it would have {{c11::had the new title not been issued}}. - {{c12::New debtor in a different state}}: original perfection continues until {{c13::one year after the transfer}} or until {{c14::perfection in the original state lapses}}, whichever occurs first.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Supplemental jurisdiction allows a federal court to hear {{c1::additional claims}} (e.g., counterclaims and cross-claims) that do not, on their own, meet {{c2::diversity}} or {{c3::federal question jurisdiction}} requirements ({{c4::28 U.S.C. § 1367}}). It {{c5::cannot be used to get a case into federal court}} in the first place. 1. Requirements 1.1. {{c6::Common nucleus of operative fact (CNOF)}}. 1.2. Each additional claim must share a CNOF with an {{c7::existing claim that independently invokes federal question or diversity jurisdiction}}. 1.3. Same transaction or occurrence: supplemental claims share a CNOF if they arise from the {{c8::same transaction or occurrence}} as the underlying claim. 2. Discretionary refusal The court may refuse to hear a supplemental claim if: 2.1. The original jurisdiction claims are {{c9::dismissed early}} in the proceeding. 2.2. The supplemental claim raises a {{c10::novel or complex state law}} issue. 2.3. The supplemental claim {{c11::substantially predominates}} over the original jurisdiction claims. 3. Limitation in diversity cases 3.1. In diversity cases, the {{c12::plaintiff}} cannot use supplemental jurisdiction to overcome a {{c13::lack of complete diversity}} (this limitation does not apply to defendants). 3.2. However, the plaintiff may use supplemental jurisdiction to overcome an {{c14::insufficient amount in controversy}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A {{c1::charitable trust}} is a trust that has the purpose of benefitting an {{c2::unascertained group of people or the public at large}}. {{c3::Indefinite beneficiaries}} required: - The trust must be created in favor of a {{c4::reasonably large class of indefinite beneficiaries}}. - It cannot be for the benefit of {{c5::identifiable individuals}}. - A trust benefitting a single {{c6::charitable organization}} whose activities meet the charitable requirements is acceptable. - Test: Beneficiaries are indefinite and unascertainable if they are {{c7::unnamed and changing over time}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Police use of force to effectuate arrest: 1. {{c1::Non-deadly force}} (NDF) 1.1 Police may use NDF as {{c2::reasonably necessary}} to {{c3::effectuate a lawful arrest}}. 2. {{c4::Deadly force}} (DF) 2.1 Police may use DF to {{c5::prevent the escape of a fleeing felon}}; 2.2 AND only when the fleeing felon {{c6::poses a threat of death or serious bodily harm}}. Key idea: Police deadly force to arrest generally requires {{c7::both a fleeing felon and a serious threat to life or grave injury}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. In general: A single piece of the debtor's property may serve as collateral for multiple creditors who all have their own {{c1::security interest}}. {{c2::Perfection}} is relevant to the {{c3::priority}} of these interests. Once a security interest is {{c4::attached}} it is enforceable, but it must be perfected in order to give its holder (the creditor) priority over other potential security interests in the same collateral. 2. Significance of perfection: A {{c5::perfected security interest}} generally has priority over {{c6::unperfected security interests}} in the same collateral. {{c7::Attachment is a prerequisite to perfection}}. 3. Methods of perfection: 3.1 {{c8::Filing}}. 3.2 Taking {{c9::possession}}. 3.3 {{c10::Automatic perfection}} (e.g., certain {{c11::purchase-money security interests (PMSIs)}}). 3.4 {{c12::Control}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Fifth Amendment privilege}} 1.1 Witnesses before the grand jury may invoke the {{c2::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}} and refuse to answer questions that may incriminate them. 2. {{c3::Immunity}} 2.1 Prosecutors may grant {{c4::immunity}} to compel testimony. 2.2 {{c5::Use or derivative-use immunity}} is sufficient: the government may not use the {{c6::compelled testimony}} or any {{c7::evidence derived from it}} against the witness in a later criminal case (except for {{c8::perjury or false statements}}). 3. {{c9::Exclusionary rule does not apply}} 3.1 The {{c10::exclusionary rule does not apply}} to grand jury proceedings. 3.2 An indictment may be based on evidence that would be {{c11::inadmissible at trial}} because it was obtained in violation of the {{c12::Fourth, Fifth, or Sixth Amendments}}. 3.3 The usual remedy for unlawful evidence is {{c13::suppression at trial}}, not {{c14::dismissal of the indictment}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: {{c1::Marriage}} is the legal union of two individuals; the law imposes various legal obligations and liabilities on the parties. 1. Limitations on who can marry 1.1 {{c2::Age}}: Most states impose a minimum age requirement, usually {{c3::18}}, before a person can consent to marriage. Some states allow minors to marry if there is {{c4::parental consent or judicial approval}}. 1.2 {{c5::Consanguinity}}: People who are too closely related are prohibited from marrying each other. 1.3 {{c6::Capacity}}: Each party must have the mental capacity to comprehend and voluntarily consent to the marriage. 1.4 {{c7::Physical capacity}}: In many states, marriage is {{c8::voidable}} if one party is physically unable to consummate the marriage and the other party was unaware of the physical condition. 1.5 {{c9::Bigamy/polygamy}}: No person may marry who has a prior undissolved marriage to another living spouse. 2. Bigamy/polygamy exceptions 2.1 {{c10::Removal of impediment}}: Under the {{c11::Uniform Marriage and Divorce Act}}, a bigamous marriage can be validated upon removal of the impediment (i.e., when the prior marriage is terminated). 2.2 {{c12::Presumption of validity}}: Under the presumption of validity, the {{c13::last of several marriages}} is presumed valid, which may be rebutted by evidence that the prior marriages still persist.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. Basic voting rule: - Unless the {{c1::articles of incorporation}} provide otherwise, each issued share is entitled to {{c2::one vote}}. 2. {{c3::Quorum}} requirement: - A quorum of shares must be present (in person or by proxy) for any shareholder vote to be valid. 3. {{c4::Approval standard}} for shareholder actions: - Within each voting group, an action is approved if votes cast {{c5::in favor}} of the action exceed votes cast {{c6::opposing}} the action. 4. {{c7::Election of directors}}: - Directors are elected by {{c8::plurality}} vote (candidates with the most votes win, even without a majority). 5. {{c9::Cumulative voting}} (if authorized by the articles): - Each share may cast as many votes as there are {{c10::board vacancies}} to be filled. - A shareholder may {{c11::allocate or concentrate}} all or some of these votes on a single candidate (e.g., if there are five vacancies, each share gets five votes).

subject: Partnerships
cloze: 1. No individual interest in specific partnership property • Partners have {{c1::no individual ownership interest}} in specific items of partnership property. • The {{c2::partnership, as an entity}}, owns the property. 2. Protection against partners’ personal creditors • Because partners lack a separate interest in specific partnership assets, a partner’s {{c3::personal creditors}} {{c4::cannot reach partnership property}} to satisfy that partner’s personal debts. 3. Partner’s {{c5::transferable interest}} • Each partner instead has a transferable interest consisting of: – Her share of partnership {{c6::profits and losses}}; and – Her right to receive {{c7::distributions}} from the partnership. • This transferable interest is a {{c8::distinct economic interest}} that can be assigned or made subject to a charging order, but it {{c9::does not confer management rights}} on the transferee.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 2. Death penalty requirements: 2.1 The death penalty may only be imposed if the {{c1::victim dies}} as a result of the defendant’s crime. 2.2 A statute authorizing the death penalty must not be {{c2::unconstitutionally vague}}. 2.3 The sentencer (usually the jury) must be allowed to consider {{c3::mitigating circumstances}}. 2.4 Examples of mitigation include the defendant’s {{c4::abusive childhood}} or {{c5::mental impairment}}. 2.5 There must be at least one {{c6::statutory aggravating circumstance}} (e.g., prior convictions) to support imposing death.

subject: Torts
cloze: Nuisance is an {{c1::intentional invasion}} of {{c2::public or private property rights}} that {{c3::substantially and unreasonably interferes}} with their peaceful and quiet enjoyment. It describes a {{c4::type of harm, not a standalone tort}}. Two main types: • {{c5::Private nuisance}} – substantial and unreasonable interference with an individual’s use or enjoyment of land. • {{c6::Public nuisance}} – unreasonable interference with the {{c7::health, safety, or property rights of the community at large}}, with private recovery only if the plaintiff suffers {{c8::unique harm}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: A conflicted director or officer will not be personally liable if a {{c1::safe harbor}} applies. 2. Safe harbors – the conflicted transaction is protected if it is either: 2.1 {{c2::Fair to the corporation}} given the circumstances existing at the time; or 2.2 {{c3::Approved}}, after {{c4::full disclosure of all material facts}}, by either: 2.2.1 {{c5::Disinterested shareholders}}; or 2.2.2 A majority of {{c6::disinterested board members}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Under the {{c1::corporate opportunity doctrine}}, fiduciary duties prevent officers and directors from {{c2::diverting a business opportunity to themselves}} when: 3.1 The corporation would have an {{c3::interest or reasonable expectancy}} in the opportunity; and 3.2 The officer or director does not first {{c4::give the corporation an opportunity to act}} on the opportunity.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 In an {{c1::accord and satisfaction}}, the parties to an existing contract agree to accept {{c2::different performance}} in satisfaction of the original obligation. 2. {{c3::Accord}} 2.1 An accord is a {{c4::new agreement to accept alternative performance}} in lieu of the original performance obligation. 2.2 {{c5::Consideration}} for the accord is generally required. 2.3 Consideration when the alternative performance is of lesser value 2.3.1 Consideration is sufficient if the new consideration is either: 2.3.1.1 {{c6::Different from the originally bargained-for consideration}}. 2.3.1.2 To be {{c7::paid or rendered to a third party}}. 2.3.1.3 Given to resolve a {{c8::good-faith dispute concerning the original contract}}. 3. {{c9::Satisfaction}} 3.1 Satisfaction is the {{c10::performance of the accord agreement}}. 3.2 Satisfaction {{c11::discharges both the original contract and the accord}}. 4. Effect of breach of an accord 4.1 If there has been no satisfaction (i.e., the accord is breached), the nonbreaching party may sue under either the {{c12::original obligation}} or the {{c13::accord}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Pre-incorporation transactions involve {{c1::promoters}} acting on behalf of a {{c2::not-yet-formed corporation}} to obtain capital and plan the business. By default, the {{c3::promoter is personally liable}} on pre-incorporation contracts, and the {{c4::corporation is not liable}} unless it later {{c5::adopts}} the contracts. Promoter liability can change after incorporation through {{c6::novation}} (substituting the corporation and releasing the promoter) and {{c7::indemnification}} (the corporation agreeing to reimburse the promoter if he is held liable). The corporation becomes liable only if it {{c5::expressly or impliedly adopts}} the contract. A {{c8::subscription agreement}} is a contract under which a person agrees to {{c9::purchase a specified number of shares from the corporation at a stated price}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Under the {{c1::attractive nuisance doctrine}}, a landowner must take reasonable care to eliminate dangers or protect {{c2::child trespassers}} if ALL of the following are met: 1. {{c3::Dangerous condition}}: The owner is {{c4::aware or should be aware}} of a dangerous condition on the property. 2. {{c5::Children nearby}}: The owner {{c6::knows or should know that children are in the vicinity}}. 3. {{c7::Inability to appreciate risk}}: The condition is likely to cause injury given a child's {{c8::inability to appreciate the risk}}. 4. {{c9::Risk outweighs utility/cost}}: The {{c10::magnitude of the risk outweighs}} the condition’s {{c11::utility}} or the {{c12::expense of remedying it}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Concurrence requirement}} 1.1 The defendant's {{c2::criminal act}} and the requisite {{c3::intent (mens rea)}} for the crime must {{c4::occur simultaneously}}. 1.2 If the {{c5::harmful act}} occurs {{c6::before}} the intent forms, there is {{c7::no concurrence}} for that offense. Example: • The defendant plans to murder the victim at her home, but {{c8::accidentally runs over and kills}} her with his car before he can carry out the plan. • He is not guilty of murder based on the car incident because his homicidal intent did not {{c9::concur with the act that caused her death}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. Conditional Acceptance – General Rule 1.1. A conditional acceptance occurs when the offeree {{c1::purports to accept but only on certain conditions or with different terms}}. 1.2. A conditional acceptance {{c2::terminates the original offer}} and {{c3::becomes a new offer}}. 1.3. Look for words like {{c4::"if," "only if," "provided that," "on the condition that"}}. 2. Example 2.1. Offer to mow lawn; offeree says, {{c5::"I accept if you also edge the walkway."}} This is a {{c6::new offer}}, and the original offeree becomes the {{c7::offeror}}. 3. Exception – Conditions Included Anyway 3.1. If the offeree’s condition merely insists on a term that would be {{c8::included in the contract anyway by operation of law}}, the response {{c9::does not terminate}} the original offer. 3.2. Example: Demanding an {{c10::implied warranty}} that would already be part of the contract does not convert the response into a counteroffer.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Hot Pursuit and Emergency Searches: 1. General Rule: If {{c1::exigent circumstances}} exist, police can {{c2::search or seize evidence without a warrant}}. {{c3::Hot pursuit}}, {{c4::evanescent evidence}}, and {{c5::emergencies}} are forms of exigent circumstances justifying a warrantless search or seizure. 2. {{c6::Hot pursuit}} 2.1 While actively pursuing a {{c7::fleeing felon}}, police can search for anything relating to the pursuit or can search for their own protection. 2.2 The permissible scope is as broad as {{c8::reasonably necessary}} to prevent the suspect from {{c9::escaping or resisting}}. 2.3 Police can {{c10::enter a private dwelling}} after attempting arrest in a public place if they have {{c11::probable cause}}. 3. {{c12::Evanescent evidence}} 3.1 Police can search or seize evidence that could {{c13::disappear if they had to secure a warrant}}. 3.2 For example: {{c14::drugs that may be discarded or destroyed}} or {{c15::DNA evidence that may not last}}. 3.3 Reasonableness is judged by the {{c16::totality of the circumstances}}. 4. {{c17::Emergency}} 4.1 Warrantless searches are justified for emergencies that {{c18::threaten health or safety}} if not immediately acted upon. 4.2 For example: Police see someone {{c19::injured or threatened with injury}}, {{c20::bomb threats}}, or the need to find the source of a {{c21::food or drug contamination}}. 4.3 Whether an emergency exists is viewed {{c22::objectively}}. Note: A valid {{c23::plain-view}} search or seizure can arise from any of the above warrantless searches.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A party that has had an opportunity to litigate a claim cannot relitigate the claim once {{c1::final judgment}} has been rendered. {{c2::Claim preclusion}} ({{c3::res judicata}}) is an {{c4::affirmative defense}}. 1. Requirements: 1.1 {{c5::Same parties}}: the second case was brought by the same party against the same party (e.g., same plaintiff against same defendant). An entity in {{c6::privity}} with a party is considered the same party (e.g., an employee and employer are the same party for claim preclusion purposes). 1.2 {{c7::Same claim}}: the same claim is at issue in the first and subsequent suits. A "claim" refers to the {{c8::transaction or series of transactions or occurrences}} giving rise to the action. Even if not previously raised, a claim can be precluded if it is sufficiently related to prior claims. 1.3 {{c9::Final judgment on the merits}} in original claim: there was a final judgment on the merits in the first action. A judgment is final even if it is being {{c10::appealed}}. A {{c11::dismissal with prejudice}} operates as a judgment on the merits. Technical dismissals (e.g., lack of subject matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, or improper venue) are {{c12::not on the merits}} because they do not evaluate the substance of the plaintiff's claim.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 2. {{c1::Junior interests}} 2.1 Junior interests are {{c2::terminated by foreclosure of a superior claim}}, assuming the junior interest holders are {{c3::properly joined}}. 2.2 Upon foreclosure of a {{c4::senior interest}}, junior interest holders {{c5::cannot look to the land}} to satisfy their debts. 2.3 Junior interest holders can seek a {{c6::deficiency judgment}} against the debtor, but they have {{c7::no further interest}} in the subject property. 2.4 Necessary parties: junior interest holders are {{c8::necessary parties}} and must be included in a senior foreclosure action; otherwise, the junior interest will {{c9::remain on the land}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Governing law}}: As a general rule, the law of the state where the {{c2::debtor is located}} governs {{c3::perfection of a security interest}}. 1.1 {{c4::Individual debtors}}: The debtor is located at the place of the debtor’s {{c5::principal residence}}. 1.2 {{c6::Registered organizational debtors}}: The debtor is located in the state under whose laws it is {{c7::organized}} (for example, where the {{c8::articles of incorporation}} are filed). 1.3 {{c9::Unregistered organizational debtors}} (for example, a partnership): The debtor is located at its {{c10::place of business}}, or, if it has more than one place of business, at its {{c11::chief executive office}}. 2. Common {{c12::exceptions}} to the general governing-law rule: 2.1 {{c13::Certificate of title goods}}: Where goods are covered by a certificate of title (e.g., an automobile), the law of the state issuing the {{c14::most recent certificate of title}} governs perfection. 2.2 {{c15::Agricultural liens}}: Perfection is governed by the law of the state in which the {{c16::farm product}} is located. 2.3 {{c17::Possessory security interests}}: Perfection is governed by the law of the state in which the {{c18::collateral is located}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::11th Amendment}} and related doctrine of {{c2::sovereign immunity}} generally bar suits against {{c3::state governments}} in {{c4::federal court}} and often in {{c5::state court}} as well, subject to narrow {{c6::exceptions}} and the possibility of suing {{c7::state officers}} for {{c8::injunctive relief}} or {{c9::personal-capacity damages}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: If a party is aggrieved by an order that is not otherwise appealable, it may seek an {{c1::extraordinary writ}}: 1. Types: • {{c2::Mandamus}} – to compel a lower court or official to perform a duty. • {{c3::Prohibition}} – to prohibit a lower court from taking or continuing unauthorized action. 2. Requirements: • The party must show {{c4::irreparable harm}} will occur; and • That the {{c5::normal route of appeal is inadequate}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Lateral support}} – definition 1.1 Ownership of land includes the right to have the land supported in its {{c2::natural state}} by {{c3::adjoining land}}. 1.2 A neighboring landowner who {{c4::excavates}} or otherwise removes lateral support can be liable if this causes {{c5::subsidence}} or damage to the adjacent land. 2. {{c6::Strict liability}} for land in its natural state 2.1 If the excavating landowner’s conduct causes damage to adjacent land in its {{c7::natural condition}} (without buildings or artificial additions), the excavator is {{c8::strictly liable}}. 2.2 Strict liability applies even if the defendant used {{c9::utmost care}} in making the excavation. 2.3 This rule focuses on whether the {{c10::land itself}} would have subsided due to the removal of support, independent of any {{c11::added structures}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The Constitution recognizes an {{c1::inferred right to privacy}}, which is not expressly stated but arises from the {{c2::penumbras}} of various constitutional provisions and protects intimate and family decisions from undue government interference. Privacy rights that typically receive {{c3::strict scrutiny}} when substantially burdened include: - The {{c4::right to marry}}. - The {{c5::right to procreate}}. - Rights concerning {{c6::family and children}}, including: - The {{c7::right to custody of one's children}}. - The {{c8::right to keep the family together}} (e.g., extended family living arrangements). - The {{c9::right to control children's upbringing}} (education, religious upbringing). - The {{c10::right to contraceptives}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: In categorizing property, courts must distinguish between {{c1::separate}} and {{c2::marital}} property. 1. {{c1::Separate property}} (generally includes): 1.1 Before marriage: property acquired before marriage by either spouse. 1.2 By gift or bequest: property acquired by {{c3::gift, bequest, devise, or descent}} (i.e., family money) during marriage by either spouse. 1.3 {{c4::Separate property proceeds}}: property acquired with separate property proceeds by either spouse. 1.4 Appreciation because of time: appreciation of separate property due to the {{c5::passage of time}} (as opposed to the efforts of either spouse). 2. {{c2::Marital property}} (generally): 2.1 Definition: {{c6::all property acquired during marriage that is not separate property, regardless of who holds title}}. 2.2 Appreciation because of effort: appreciation of separate property due to the {{c7::efforts of either spouse}} is usually marital property. 2.3 {{c8::Pensions}}: the portion of a pension earned by one spouse during marriage is considered marital property. 2.4 {{c9::Professional license or degree}}: in some states, reimbursement may be ordered if one spouse provided support that contributed to the other spouse's degree or license. 3. {{c10::Commingled property}}: separate property that is inextricably mingled with marital property, or with separate property of the other spouse, can become marital property.

subject: Torts
cloze: Element 3: {{c1::Causation}} and no {{c2::substantial alteration}}. 1. Causation: 1.1 The defective product must be the {{c3::actual cause}} of P’s injury (but-for the defect, no injury). 1.2 The defective product must also be the {{c4::proximate cause}} of P’s injury (the type of harm is a {{c5::foreseeable result}} of the defect). 2. No substantial alteration: 2.1 The product must not be {{c6::substantially altered}} between leaving the commercial supplier and reaching the consumer. 2.2 A {{c7::substantial alteration}} that introduces or changes the defect can {{c8::break the causal chain}} and defeat strict liability.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Default and self-help repossession}} 1.1 Default is generally {{c2::defined in the security agreement}}, not by {{c3::Article 9}}. 1.2 Upon default, a secured party may {{c4::take possession of collateral without judicial process (self-help)}}, or may {{c5::collect on non-goods via authenticated notification}}, so long as {{c6::no breach of the peace}} occurs. 1.3 Reclaiming possession through self-help is allowed only if it does not involve a {{c7::breach of the peace}}. 2. {{c8::Breach of the peace}} 2.1 A breach of the peace occurs when repossession is made {{c9::over the debtor's protest}}. 2.2 {{c10::Violence, threats of violence, or breaking and entering}} will likely constitute a breach of the peace. 2.3 {{c11::Simple trespass}} in order to repossess property is generally permissible. 2.4 Example: It is permissible to {{c12::unlock and hot-wire a car}} used as collateral if the car is sitting in a driveway. 3. {{c13::Collection rights for non-goods collateral}} 3.1 When the collateral is {{c14::non-goods}} (for example, {{c15::accounts or instruments}}), upon default the secured party can notify the person owing the debtor (the {{c16::account debtor}}). 3.2 The secured party must send {{c17::authenticated notification}} to the account debtor stating that the amount due has been {{c18::assigned}} and that {{c19::payment must be made to the secured party}}. 3.3 Upon such notification, the account debtor can discharge his obligation only by {{c20::paying the secured party}}. 3.4 Example: A loans B $10,000, for which A receives a promissory note. A takes out a loan from C for $5,000 using B's promissory note as collateral. A defaults on C's loan. C may notify B of A's default and require that B pay C on the promissory note.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Definition: An {{c1::easement by implication from prior use}} arises when a {{c2::common grantor}} previously used one part of a single tract in an {{c3::easement-like way}} to benefit another part, and then conveys or divides the land. 2. Elements ({{c4::PCNI}}): 2.1 {{c5::Prior easement-like use}}: An easement-like use exists prior to the {{c6::division of a single tract}} of land. 2.2 {{c7::Continuous and apparent}}: The common grantor’s use is continuous and apparent (not sporadic or hidden). 2.3 {{c8::Reasonably necessary}}: The use is reasonably necessary for enjoyment of the {{c9::dominant tenement}}. 2.4 {{c10::Intended to continue}}: Circumstances show that the parties intended the use to continue after the division of the land. 3. Effect: When these elements are satisfied, the law {{c11::implies an easement}} in favor of the benefited parcel (dominant estate) over the burdened parcel (servient estate).

subject: Real Property
cloze: For adverse possession, the {{c1::statute of limitations}} does not begin to run if the true owner was under a {{c2::legal disability}} (such as {{c3::minority}} or {{c4::mental incompetence}}) when the adverse possession began. Only disabilities that {{c5::exist at the start of adverse possession}} toll the period. As to {{c6::future interests}}, the limitations period does not run against {{c7::future interest holders}} (e.g., {{c8::remaindermen}}) until their interest becomes {{c9::possessory}}. Adverse possession against the present estate holder does not by itself cut off the future interest until the period runs after the future interest {{c10::vests in possession}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 If an {{c1::unforeseen event}} occurs after {{c2::contract formation}} but before performance is complete, performance may be excused as {{c3::impossible}} or {{c4::impracticable}}. 2. Requirements 2.1 An unforeseen event, which {{c5::neither party assumed would occur}}, must make completing performance either: 2.1.1 {{c6::Impossible}}: performance is {{c7::objectively impossible}}; or 2.1.2 {{c8::Impracticable}}: performance is only possible with {{c9::extreme and unreasonable difficulty or expense}}. 3. Common unforeseen events 3.1 {{c10::Substantial damage or destruction}} of the contract's subject matter. 3.2 The damage or destruction must {{c11::not have been either party's fault}}. 3.3 {{c12::Death}}: Contract obligations generally survive the death of a party, unless the deceased party's contract obligations are {{c13::non-delegable}} (usually only {{c14::unique personal services}} are non-delegable). 3.4 {{c15::Subsequent law or regulation}} (e.g., supervening illegality): if performance becomes {{c16::illegal}}, there is excuse by impossibility. 4. Note on terminology 4.1 The {{c17::MBE}} often uses the term {{c18::"impossibility"}} broadly to encompass both impossibility and impracticability.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 {{c2::Intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED)}} is {{c3::extreme and outrageous conduct}} by D causing P's {{c4::severe emotional distress}}. 2. {{c5::Elements}} 2.1 {{c6::Extreme and outrageous conduct}} by D. 2.1.1 Conduct that {{c7::exceeds the bounds of decency}} in a civilized society. 2.1.2 {{c8::Mere insults alone}} are insufficient. 2.1.3 Conduct must be outrageous to a reasonable person unless one of the following applies: 2.1.3.1 D targets P's {{c9::known sensitivity or weakness}}. 2.1.3.2 D's conduct is {{c10::continuous or repetitive}}. 2.1.3.3 D targets a P who is a member of a {{c11::protected or vulnerable class}} (e.g., elderly, children, pregnant women). 2.1.3.4 D is a {{c12::common carrier or innkeeper}}. 2.2 {{c13::Severe emotional distress}} in P. 2.2.1 P must suffer severe emotional distress from D's conduct. 2.2.2 {{c14::Physical symptoms are not necessary}}. Note: if P does not suffer severe emotional harm, there is no IIED even if D's conduct is extreme and outrageous. 2.3 {{c15::Intent or recklessness}}. 2.3.1 Intent includes purpose or knowledge with substantial certainty; {{c16::recklessness}} is when D disregards the likely consequences of his acts. 2.4 {{c17::Causation}}.

subject: Agency
cloze: An agent acts with {{c1::actual authority}} when, at the time of taking an act having legal consequences for the principal, the agent {{c2::reasonably believes that the principal wishes the agent to act}}. Actual authority is the authority the agent reasonably believes he possesses based on his dealings with the principal. 1. {{c3::Express vs. implied actual authority}} 1.1 {{c4::Express actual authority}}: authority expressly provided to the agent by the principal (in writing or orally from principal to agent). For example, if the principal directs the agent to engage in a precise task, in doing so, the agent has express actual authority. 1.2 {{c5::Implied actual authority}}: authority the agent reasonably believes he has based on the principal's actions (words or conduct). This includes {{c6::incidental acts reasonably necessary}} to complete a task or transaction on the principal's behalf. For example, if the principal tells the agent to hire an employee, the agent has authority to take actions reasonably necessary to do so (such as placing a job posting and interviewing candidates). 2. {{c7::Termination}} 2.1 {{c8::Lapse of time}} (specified or unspecified). 2.2 {{c9::Happening of an agreed-upon event}}. 2.3 {{c10::Change of circumstances}} or other similar events that make it unreasonable for the agent to believe he still has authority.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. Secured party’s right to dispose of collateral - Upon {{c1::default}}, a {{c2::secured party}} may {{c3::dispose of collateral}} by sale, lease, or other disposition. - Any disposition must be conducted in a {{c4::commercially reasonable}} manner. 2. {{c5::Notice requirement}} - The secured party must give the {{c6::debtor}} notice of the intended disposition. - The notice must be in an {{c7::authenticated record}}. - It must be sent within a {{c8::reasonable time}} before the sale or other disposition. 3. {{c9::Effect of a proper sale}} - The sale {{c10::discharges the security interest}} under which the sale is being made. - It also discharges any {{c11::subordinate security interests and liens}}. - The purchaser generally takes the {{c12::debtor’s rights in the collateral}} (subject to any senior interests).

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Basic scope of the taxing and spending power 1.1 Congress may {{c1::tax and spend}} in any way it deems necessary to provide for the {{c2::general welfare}}. 1.2 This "{{c3::general welfare}}" standard is interpreted {{c4::very broadly}}. 2. Typical bar exam context 2.1 On bar exam questions, Congress’s taxing and spending power is usually the correct basis for federal authority when the statute concerns: 2.1.1 {{c5::Taxation}}; 2.1.2 {{c6::Spending}}; or 2.1.3 One of Congress’s limited {{c7::police power}} areas: - The {{c8::military}}; - {{c9::Indian reservations}}; - {{c10::federal land or property}}; or - The {{c11::District of Columbia}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. In general: {{c1::Vicarious liability}} arises when a defendant commits a tort against a plaintiff and a {{c2::third person is held liable because of a legal relationship}} with the defendant. 2. Common vicarious liability relationships: 2.1. {{c3::Employers for employees under respondeat superior}}. 2.2. {{c4::Employers for independent contractors}} (generally no liability, subject to exceptions). 2.3. {{c5::Partners}} in a partnership. 2.4. {{c6::Parent–child}} (no true vicarious liability; only potential direct negligence). 2.5. {{c7::Tavernkeepers}} and similar alcohol vendors (often under {{c8::dram shop}} rules).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: {{c1::Rule 22 interpleader}} is an ordinary federal civil action and does {{c2::not itself create subject-matter jurisdiction}}. In diversity cases, it therefore requires {{c3::complete diversity}} (the stakeholder diverse from all {{c4::claimants}}) and an {{c5::amount in controversy exceeding $75,000}}. {{c6::Personal jurisdiction}} and {{c7::venue}} are determined under the {{c8::usual federal rules}} that apply in any civil case—there is no special nationwide service or special venue rule for Rule 22 interpleader.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: To be subject to personal jurisdiction, the defendant must have such {{c1::minimum contacts}} with the forum state that exercising jurisdiction does not offend {{c2::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}}. 1. Analysis: {{c3::minimum contacts, relatedness, and fairness}}. 2. Minimum contacts: the defendant must have sufficient minimum contacts with the forum state; the inquiry focuses on: 2.1. {{c4::Purposeful availment}}: did the defendant avail herself of the forum state's laws? 2.2. {{c5::Foreseeability}}: did the defendant know of or anticipate being held accountable for her in-forum activities? 3. {{c6::Fair play and substantial justice}} (see related cards for more detail): given the defendant's contacts, the exercise of jurisdiction must not offend these notions; the inquiry focuses on factors such as: 3.1. {{c7::Convenience}}: would litigating in the forum severely disadvantage the defendant? 3.2. The {{c8::state's interest}}: does the forum state have an interest in providing redress for residents or an interest in the outcome?

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. The usual remedy for breach of a {{c1::contract to make, not make, or revoke a will}} is a {{c2::constructive trust}}. 2. In practice, when a testator breaches such a contract—such as by failing to provide for the contracting party—the court generally: 2.1. {{c3::Admits the will to probate}} as written; and 2.2. {{c4::Imposes a constructive trust}} on the affected property in favor of the {{c5::intended contract beneficiary}}. 3. The constructive trust allows the court in {{c6::equity}} to carry out the promised disposition, even though {{c7::legal title passes under the probated will}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: An {{c1::express warranty}} is any {{c2::affirmation of fact, promise, description, sample, or model}} relating to the goods that becomes part of the {{c3::basis of the bargain}}. Seller’s statements or representations about the goods (e.g., “waterproof to 20 feet”) create an express warranty if they are part of the bargain. An express warranty is {{c4::breached}} if the product {{c5::fails to conform}} to the seller’s promise, description, sample, or model.

subject: Family Law
cloze: Procedural and state-of-mind requirements exist for a valid {{c1::marriage}}. 1. {{c2::Procedural requirements}} (most states require both a {{c3::license}} and {{c4::solemnization}}) 1.1 License: A marriage license must be obtained from the appropriate government-designated licensing officer prior to solemnization. 1.2 Solemnization: The marriage must be solemnized by an authorized {{c5::clergy member}} or {{c6::judicial officer}}. The license must be completed and signed by the person who solemnized the marriage and filed with the appropriate government office, creating a {{c7::public record}} of the marriage. 2. {{c8::State-of-mind requirements}} 2.1 {{c9::Consent}}: Both parties must consent to marriage, meaning they each intend to take on the obligations of marriage. 2.2 Factors for evaluating consent 2.2.1 {{c10::Capacity}}: Parties must have capacity to understand and agree to their actions (e.g., one under the influence of drugs or alcohol may lack capacity to enter into marriage). 2.2.2 {{c11::Intent}}: Parties must intend to enter a marriage relationship of their own free will; {{c12::fraud, duress, or coercion}} will negate the consent requirement.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: {{c1::Rule 23(b)(1)}}: 1. {{c2::Anti-prejudice device}}. 2. Used where separate actions by or against class members would create a risk of {{c3::inconsistent decisions}} or {{c4::impair or impede the interests}} of other class members. Note: Uncommon and unlikely to be heavily tested on the MBE. {{c5::Rule 23(b)(2)}}: 1. {{c6::Injunction or declaratory judgment}}. 2. Allows a class where the {{c7::primary relief sought is injunctive or declaratory relief}} (i.e., not primarily damages). Example: {{c8::employment discrimination or civil rights}} cases. {{c9::Rule 23(b)(3)}}: 1. {{c10::Damages}}. 2. The most common class action type; used where the primary relief sought is damages. Requirements for (b)(3): 1. {{c11::Predominance}}: {{c12::Common questions of law or fact predominate over individual questions}}; and 2. {{c13::Superiority}}: A class action is {{c14::superior to other procedures}} to resolve the dispute. Additional (b)(3) features: - Class members have {{c15::opt-out rights}}: The judgment binds only class members who do not opt out. - {{c16::Notification}} required: All reasonably identifiable class members must be notified of the pendency of the action, including {{c17::opt-out rights}} and the {{c18::right to appear through separate counsel}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Testimony in the form of opinion is inadmissible unless the witness qualifies to give either {{c1::lay}} or {{c2::expert}} opinion. 1. Lay opinion requirements (opinion testimony is admissible as lay opinion if it is): {{c3::1.1 Rationally based}}: the opinion is rationally based on the witness's perception. {{c4::1.2 Helpful}}: the opinion is helpful to the trier of fact because it gives the jury more information regarding the witness's perception than the perception alone; {{c5::legal conclusions}} are inadmissible because they are deemed unhelpful. {{c6::1.3 Not expert}}: the opinion is not based on scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge (i.e., it is not in the realm of expert opinion). 2. Examples of admissible lay opinion testimony: {{c7::2.1 Speed of a car}}. {{c8::2.2 Emotional state of an individual}}. {{c9::2.3 Voice or handwriting recognition}}. {{c10::2.4 Sense recognition}} (e.g., smells, tastes, sounds). {{c11::2.5 Intoxication}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: {{c1::Charitable trusts}} can be {{c2::perpetual}}. - The {{c3::Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP)}} does {{c4::not apply}} to charitable trusts. - By contrast, {{c5::private trusts}} are subject to RAP, and all interests must {{c6::vest, if at all, within the RAP period}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, when the decedent is survived by {{c2::descendants who are also descendants of the spouse}} and the spouse has {{c3::other issue from outside the relationship}}, the surviving spouse takes {{c4::$225,000}} plus {{c5::one-half}} of the {{c6::remaining property}}. Example: If the estate is {{c7::$375,000}} and the decedent leaves a spouse, their joint child, and the spouse’s child from a prior relationship, the spouse receives {{c8::$225,000}} + {{c9::½ of the $150,000 remainder}} = {{c10::$300,000}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The following lists classifications and the {{c1::standard of review}} they receive: 1. {{c2::Rational basis}}: 1.1 {{c3::Alienage}}, but only if the classification: 1.1.1 Relates to {{c4::self-government}}, and 1.1.2 Relates to the {{c5::democratic process}}, or 1.1.3 Is a {{c6::congressional action concerning immigration}}. 1.2 All other classifications not qualifying for strict or intermediate scrutiny receive rational basis review (for example, {{c7::age}}, {{c8::disability}}, {{c9::wealth}}, and {{c10::economic regulations}}). 2. {{c11::Intermediate scrutiny}} ({{c12::quasi-suspect classifications}}): 2.1 {{c13::Gender}}. 2.2 {{c14::Non-marital children}} (illegitimacy). 3. {{c15::Strict scrutiny}} ({{c16::suspect classifications}} and certain {{c17::fundamental rights}}): 3.1 {{c18::Race}}. 3.2 {{c19::National origin}}. 3.3 {{c20::Alienage}} (except when subject only to rational basis as noted above). 3.4 {{c21::Right to travel}}. 3.5 {{c22::Right to vote}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule: Any person in any proceeding ({{c1::civil or criminal}}) may refuse to answer a question if her response might incriminate herself. The privilege is only available for {{c2::compelled testimonial or communicative evidence}}. 1.1 {{c3::Testimonial}}: verbal or otherwise communicative evidence. 1.2 {{c4::Lineups and physical evidence}}: not testimonial. 1.3 {{c5::Compelled}}: elicited or induced. 1.3.1 Evidence produced from the defendant's {{c6::free will}} is not compelled (e.g., the defendant's existing diary is not compelled). 1.3.2 {{c7::Lie detector tests, custodial interrogations, and similar procedures}} are compelled, and the {{c8::Fifth Amendment privilege}} will apply. 2. Scope: The privilege applies to {{c9::natural persons, not entities}}. 2.1 A {{c10::legal entity}} (e.g., corporation, partnership) has no Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. 3. Exceptions (the privilege does not apply if): 3.1 {{c11::Grant of immunity}}: The government grants immunity from prosecution for self-incriminating testimony. 3.2 {{c12::Incrimination is not possible}}: For example, the statute of limitations has run. 3.3 {{c13::Extinguished by waiver}}: The defendant waives the privilege. 3.3.1 At trial, the prosecution {{c14::cannot comment on the defendant's silence or failure to testify}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: In an {{c1::assignment}}, the tenant transfers the {{c2::entire leasehold interest}} (both duration and physical area) to the assignee. Privity: • The {{c3::assignee is in privity of estate}} with the landlord and is bound by {{c4::covenants that run with the land}}. • The {{c5::assignor remains in privity of contract}} with the landlord absent novation. Rent and liability: • The {{c6::assignee owes rent directly to the landlord}} while in possession. • The {{c7::assignor remains liable for unpaid rent}} and other contractual obligations unless the landlord expressly releases the tenant via {{c8::novation}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: The {{c1::Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA)}} creates a separate basis for federal subject-matter jurisdiction in certain large class actions. 1. Jurisdictional requirements: - {{c2::Minimal diversity}}: Jurisdiction exists if {{c3::any class member}} is diverse from {{c4::any opposing party}} (only one diverse pairing is needed). - {{c5::Aggregated amount in controversy}}: The {{c6::aggregated claims of all class members}} must {{c7::exceed $5 million}}. 2. Exclusions – CAFA does not apply to: - Class actions with {{c8::fewer than 100 class members}}. - Certain {{c9::shareholder claims against corporate management}}. - Certain {{c10::state securities law fraud}} class actions. If these CAFA requirements are met and no exclusion applies, CAFA can provide {{c11::federal subject-matter jurisdiction}} even when traditional {{c12::complete diversity}} or {{c13::$75,000 individual}} requirements for diversity are not satisfied.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Shelter Rule, Wild Deeds, and Estoppel by Deed: 1. Issues that can arise with {{c1::recording statutes}} and the {{c2::chain of title}}: 1.1 {{c3::Shelter rule}} 1.1.1 One who takes from a {{c4::bona fide purchaser (BFP)}} will prevail against any interest the transferor-BFP would have prevailed against, even if the transferee had {{c5::actual notice}} of a prior conveyance. 1.1.2 This protects {{c6::donees, heirs, or devisees of BFPs}} who cannot qualify as BFPs and would not otherwise receive protection under notice or race-notice statutes. 1.2 {{c7::Wild deeds}} 1.2.1 A wild deed is a recorded deed {{c8::unconnected to the chain of title}} (for example, due to a clerk's filing error or the failure to record a prior deed). 1.2.2 {{c9::Record notice cannot be derived}} from a wild deed. 1.2.3 A wild deed cannot exist in a {{c10::tract index}} system. 1.3 {{c11::Estoppel by deed}} 1.3.1 A grantor who conveys title to land he does not then own is {{c12::estopped from subsequently acquiring the same land}} as against that grantee. 1.3.2 When the grantor later acquires title, {{c13::title automatically passes}} to the benefit of the earlier grantee. 1.3.3 This prevents one from conveying land they do not presently own and later validly acquiring it against the grantee (for example, through a will).

subject: Con Law
cloze: Criminal liability based on group membership is limited. The government must prove: 1. {{c1::Active affiliation}} – the defendant actively affiliated with a group involved with {{c2::illegal activities}}; 2. {{c3::Knowledge}} – the defendant had {{c4::knowledge of the group's illegal activities}}; and 3. {{c5::Specific intent}} – the defendant acted with the {{c6::specific intent of furthering those activities}}. Absent any of these elements, criminalizing membership violates {{c7::freedom of association}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general: Under {{c1::UCC}} contracts, the seller's performance must be {{c2::perfect}} with respect to the goods delivered and the manner of delivery. {{c3::Imperfect tender}} means the seller sends defective or nonconforming goods. 2. Buyer's options upon seller's imperfect tender (the buyer can either): 2.1 {{c4::Keep}}: Retain the goods delivered and sue for damages; or 2.2 {{c5::Reject}}: Reject some or all of the goods and sue for damages. 3. Requirements for {{c6::rejection}} (a buyer who rejects goods must): 3.1 {{c7::Notify the seller}} of rejection within a reasonable time; 3.2 {{c8::Hold the rejected goods using reasonable care}}; and 3.3 {{c9::Give the seller a reasonable time to arrange for removal}} of the goods. 3.4 If the seller gives no information regarding removal, the buyer can {{c10::return the goods to the seller, store the goods for the seller, or resell the goods on behalf of the seller}} (for the seller's benefit). 4. {{c11::Installment contracts}} (where delivery of goods occurs in separate lots): 4.1 Rejection: The buyer can only reject a delivery/installment if: 4.1.1 The defect {{c12::substantially impairs the value of that installment}}; and 4.1.2 The defect {{c13::cannot be cured}}. 4.1.3 Rejection is {{c14::limited to the defective installment}}, not the entire contract. 4.1.4 The buyer can {{c15::cancel the entire contract}} due to a defective installment only if the nonconformity in that installment {{c16::substantially impairs the value of the entire contract}}. 4.2 Note: A seller of imperfect goods may have a right to {{c17::cure}} under the UCC, depending on the time for performance and the seller's reasonable belief that the tender would be acceptable.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Common law rule: 1.1 When the premises were destroyed without fault, the {{c1::tenant}} bore the risk of loss. 1.2 The tenant remained obligated to {{c2::pay rent}} even after destruction. 1.3 The tenant generally could {{c3::not terminate}} the lease solely due to destruction. 2. Modern law: 2.1 Modern law generally allows the {{c4::tenant}} to {{c5::terminate the lease}} when the premises are substantially or totally destroyed without fault of either party. 2.2 Upon proper termination, the tenant's obligation to {{c6::pay future rent}} usually ends from the time of destruction or as provided by law or contract.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: A {{c1::partnership}} is formed when {{c2::two or more people}} associate to carry on a {{c3::for-profit business}} as {{c4::co-owners}}. No {{c5::formal written agreement}} or use of the label “partnership” is required; intent can be {{c6::inferred from conduct}}. To determine whether a partnership exists, courts look primarily to whether the parties {{c7::intended to carry on a business as co-owners}}, and then to objective factors such as {{c8::profit-sharing}}, {{c9::control}}, {{c10::capital contributions}}, and {{c11::joint ownership of property}}. Even if no actual partnership exists, parties may still be liable to third parties as if they were partners under the doctrine of {{c12::partnership by estoppel}} when they {{c13::hold themselves or others out as partners}} or {{c14::consent to being so held out}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::contingent remainder}} is a remainder that fails the requirements for vesting. A remainder is contingent if: • There is a {{c2::condition precedent}} to the future interest becoming possessory; or • The future interest is given to an {{c3::unascertained or unborn taker}}; or • {{c4::Both}} a condition precedent and an unascertained taker are present. Contingent remainders still {{c5::wait for the natural termination}} of the prior estate and {{c6::do not divest a prior transferee}}. If a future interest instead {{c7::cuts off or divests}} a prior transferee’s interest, it is an {{c8::executory interest}}, not a contingent remainder.

subject: Family Law
cloze: Jurisdiction over {{c1::annulment}} actions is in {{c2::state courts}}. 1. {{c3::Domicile-based jurisdiction}}: A state in which {{c4::either spouse is domiciled}} has subject-matter jurisdiction to enter an annulment decree. 2. {{c5::Place-of-marriage jurisdiction}}: In {{c6::most states}}, courts in the state where the {{c7::marriage was entered into and recognized}} also have jurisdiction to adjudicate an annulment. 3. Key idea: Annulment jurisdiction focuses on the parties’ {{c8::domicile}} and, in many jurisdictions, the {{c9::state of celebration of the marriage}}.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: There are three types of partnerships that may arise on essays. 1. {{c1::General partnership}}: any association of two or more people as co-owners of a {{c2::for-profit business}}. 1.1 Formation: no {{c3::formal agreement}} is required; the parties' intent to associate as co-owners can be {{c4::inferred from their conduct}}. 1.2 Liability: all partners are {{c5::personally and jointly liable}} for all partnership debts. 2. {{c6::Limited liability partnership (LLP)}}: a partnership in which partners' potential for {{c7::personal liability}} is {{c8::limited}}. 3. {{c9::Limited partnership (LP)}}: a partnership with different levels of partners (at least one {{c10::general partner}} and at least one {{c11::limited partner}}). 4. Note on partnership rules: the rules on these cards generally apply to all partnership types, unless otherwise noted. These are {{c12::default rules}}, but {{c13::partnership agreements}} can create different rights, duties, and obligations.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: General rule: Under the {{c1::Fourth Amendment}}, a search is ordinarily valid only if conducted pursuant to a properly executed {{c2::search warrant}}. Unless a recognized {{c3::exception to the warrant requirement}} applies (e.g., exigent circumstances, consent, search incident to arrest, automobile exception), the government must obtain a valid warrant before conducting a search.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Invoking the Right to Remain Silent (Fifth Amendment) 1. An accused may terminate a {{c1::custodial interrogation}} at any time by invoking the {{c2::right to remain silent}}. 2. Once this right is invoked, police must {{c3::immediately cease all questioning}}. 3. Only the {{c4::accused}} may {{c5::reinitiate dialogue}} about the investigation. 4. Police may resume questioning only after a {{c6::significant period of time}} has passed, and generally only about {{c7::unrelated crimes}}, and only after giving {{c8::fresh Miranda warnings}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Jury size: - The jury must contain at least {{c1::6 jurors}}. 2. Unanimity: - For {{c2::serious offenses}}, the jury’s verdict must be {{c3::unanimous}}. 3. Representative cross-section requirement: - The {{c4::jury pool (venire)}} must be a {{c5::representative cross-section of the community}}. - The actually chosen, seated jury {{c6::does not have to be representative}} as long as the pool is representative.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Core SILA rule: Police may, without a warrant, {{c1::search a lawfully arrested person and the area within his immediate control}}. 1.1. The {{c2::arrest must be lawful}} (supported by probable cause and otherwise valid). 1.2. The search must be {{c3::contemporaneous with the arrest}} (roughly same time and place). 1.3. Scope of area: The search is limited to the area within the arrestee’s {{c4::immediate reach or movement}} (his "{{c5::wingspan}}")—places where he could obtain weapons or destroy evidence. 1.4. Purpose: {{c6::officer safety}} (to find weapons) and {{c7::preservation of evidence}} (to prevent destruction).

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Fourteenth Amendment and Confessions 1. Independently of Miranda, the {{c1::Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause}} requires that confessions be {{c2::voluntary}} to be admissible. 2. Voluntariness is assessed under the {{c3::totality of the circumstances}}, considering factors such as the suspect's {{c4::age}}, {{c5::mental and physical condition}}, {{c6::education}}, and the {{c7::duration, manner, and setting}} of the interrogation.

subject: Real Property
cloze: In a land sale contract, {{c1::equitable conversion}} treats the {{c2::buyer}} as the owner of the {{c3::real property}} and the {{c4::seller}} as owning a {{c5::personal property}} right to the {{c6::sale proceeds}} while holding {{c7::legal title in trust}} for the buyer between contract and closing. This affects (1) protection from the seller’s {{c8::pre-contract creditors}}, (2) allocation of {{c9::risk of loss}} if the property is destroyed before closing (usually the {{c10::buyer}}, absent a different contract allocation), and (3) whether each party’s interest passes as {{c11::realty or personalty}} if a party {{c12::dies before closing}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. Definition of a merger: - A {{c1::merger}} occurs when {{c2::two or more corporations combine into a single corporation}}; often one corporation {{c3::absorbs another}}. 2. Mergers as fundamental corporate changes: - A merger is a {{c4::fundamental corporate change}} and therefore generally requires formal approval from each constituent corporation. 3. Requirements for approval (each corporation generally must obtain): 3.1 {{c5::Board approval}}: - A board vote in accordance with the rules for authorizing board action (for example, a {{c6::majority or supermajority}} as required). 3.2 {{c7::Shareholder approval}}: - Approval by a {{c8::majority of the shareholders entitled to vote}} (unless a higher vote is required by statute or the articles). 3.3 {{c9::Exception – no significant change to surviving corporation}}: - The surviving corporation’s shareholders {{c10::need not approve}} a merger where the surviving corporation has {{c11::no significant changes}}, such as: • Its {{c12::articles of incorporation}} do not differ post-merger; and • The shareholders’ {{c13::shares and rights do not change}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. General temporary perfection when debtor or collateral moves 1.1 Issues arise when the {{c1::debtor or the collateral moves from one state to another}}. 1.2 A security interest perfected in the original state generally remains {{c2::temporarily perfected}} after the move. 1.3 This temporary perfection gives the secured party time to {{c3::perfect in the new state}}. 1.4 If the secured party fails to perfect in the new state within the applicable period, the security interest becomes {{c4::unperfected}} and loses its {{c5::original priority date}}. 2. Debtor relocation – four‑month rule 2.1 If the debtor relocates to a new state, a security interest perfected under the law of the original state remains perfected for {{c6::four months}} after the debtor’s relocation. 2.2 To remain continuously perfected and keep the original priority date, the secured party must perfect under the law of the new jurisdiction {{c7::before the four‑month period expires}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: At {{c1::common law}}, rape is: 1. {{c2::Unlawful carnal knowledge}} of a woman; 2. By a {{c3::man other than her husband}}; and 3. {{c4::Without effective consent}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Purpose of preliminary hearing 1.1 A pretrial (preliminary) hearing may be required to determine whether there is {{c1::probable cause}} to {{c2::detain}} the suspect. 2. When a preliminary hearing is required 2.1 A preliminary hearing is required if both of the following are true: 2.1.1 The defendant is {{c3::incarcerated or released on bail}} (it is not required if the defendant is released only on the condition that she appear for trial), and 2.1.2 There has been {{c4::no prior determination of probable cause}}. 3. Effect of prior probable cause determination 3.1 A preliminary hearing is {{c5::not required}} if the arrest was made with a {{c6::warrant}}, because a magistrate has already determined probable cause. 4. Timing 4.1 If a preliminary hearing is required, it must occur within {{c7::48 hours}} of detention.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The Constitution prohibits state and federal governments from passing {{c1::retroactive laws}}, which generally involve either {{c2::ex post facto laws}} or {{c3::bills of attainder}}. 1. {{c2::Ex Post Facto Clause}} 1.1. The Ex Post Facto Clause prohibits {{c2::ex post facto laws}}. 1.2. Test: A law is an ex post facto law if it either: 1.2.1. {{c4::criminally punishes conduct that was lawful when done}}; 1.2.2. {{c5::increases punishment}} for a crime after it has been committed; or 1.2.3. {{c6::reduces the burden required to convict}} a person for a crime after it has been committed. 1.3. The Ex Post Facto Clause does not apply to {{c7::civil liability}}; retroactive civil legislation need only satisfy {{c8::rational basis}} review. 2. {{c3::Bill of attainder}} 2.1. A bill of attainder is a {{c9::legislative act}} that {{c10::punishes specific individuals or identifiable groups without a judicial trial}}. 2.2. {{c3::Bills of attainder}} are {{c11::prohibited under the Constitution}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule for independent contractors: 1.1. Employers are generally {{c1::not vicariously liable}} for torts committed by {{c2::independent contractors}}. 2. Major exceptions – when the hiring party may be liable: 2.1. {{c3::Inherently dangerous activities}}. 2.2. {{c4::Non-delegable duties}}. 2.2.1. Example: Businesses that hold property open to the public have a {{c5::non-delegable duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for customers}}. 2.2.2. Liability may still attach even if {{c6::maintenance or safety is entrusted to an independent contractor}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Statements regarding {{c1::physical condition}} are admissible if made to {{c2::medical personnel}} for the purpose of {{c3::diagnosis or treatment}}. 1. Requirements: 1.1 Statement must be made to medical personnel (includes anyone involved in {{c4::treatment or diagnosis}}; not necessarily a doctor). 1.2 Statement must be {{c5::pertinent to assisting in the diagnosis or treatment}} of a condition. 1.2.1 Related statements (such as an {{c6::admission}}) about an {{c7::injury-causing event}} are usually inadmissible. 1.2.2 Example: a statement by the declarant to an {{c8::emergency room doctor}} that she was shot will be admissible, but the {{c9::identity of the shooter}} will not, as it is not pertinent to treatment. 1.3 Distinguish from statements of {{c10::then-existing physical condition}}: statements concerning then-existing (i.e., contemporaneous) physical condition are admissible regardless of whether they are made to medical personnel.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. Elements of accomplice liability: 1.1 Conduct: The defendant must {{c1::aid, counsel, or encourage}} the principal {{c2::before or during}} the commission of the crime. 1.2 Mental state: The defendant must intend {{c3::to assist the principal}} and {{c4::that the principal commit the crime}}. 2. Scope of accomplice liability: 2.1 An accomplice is liable for the crimes he {{c5::committed or counseled}} and for any other crimes that are {{c6::probable or foreseeable results}} of the planned crime. 2.2 The additional crimes must be {{c7::natural and probable consequences}} of the intended offense, not bizarre or extraordinary acts by the principal.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach}}, a court applies the law of the state where the relevant right {{c2::vested}}—typically the place of the {{c3::last act or event}} that created the right being asserted. This basic {{c4::"last act"}} principle is then implemented by {{c5::subject-matter–specific rules}} (e.g., torts, contracts, property, corporations).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In {{c1::statutory interpleader}}, only {{c2::minimal diversity}} is required—at least one {{c3::claimant}} must be diverse from at least one other claimant. The {{c4::amount in controversy}} need only be {{c5::$500 or more}}. Statutory interpleader also authorizes {{c6::nationwide service of process}} on anyone in the U.S. and permits {{c7::venue}} in any district where any {{c8::claimant resides}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. In general: {{c1::Secured parties}} are liable for failure to comply with {{c2::Article 9}}. Several remedies are available to the debtor. 1.1 {{c3::Actual damages}}: The debtor can recover damages reasonably calculated to put the debtor in the position she would have been in {{c4::had no violation occurred}}. 1.2 {{c5::Statutory minimum damages for consumer goods}}: If the collateral involved is {{c6::consumer goods}}, the debtor is entitled to at least {{c7::10% of the cash price}} of the goods plus the {{c8::interest charges to be paid over the life of the loan}}. 1.3 {{c9::Loss of deficiency judgment}}: The secured party may lose the right to a deficiency judgment for failure to comply. 1.3.1 {{c10::Non-consumer transactions (rebuttable presumption rule)}}: The value of the collateral seized is {{c11::presumed equal to the debt owed}} unless the secured party proves otherwise. 1.3.2 {{c12::Consumer transactions (three possible approaches)}}: Courts take one of three approaches: 1) Apply the {{c13::rebuttable presumption rule}}; 2) {{c14::Deny the secured party any deficiency judgment}}; or 3) Allow the secured party to recover a {{c15::deficiency minus the actual damages the debtor can prove}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Shareholder governance authority: 1. General concept: Shareholders exert control over the corporation primarily through {{c1::voting powers}}, rather than {{c2::day-to-day management}}. 2. Key powers: 2.1 {{c3::Elect and remove directors}}: Shareholders have the power to {{c4::elect the board of directors}} and, subject to applicable procedures, {{c5::remove directors}}. 2.2 {{c6::Bylaws}}: Shareholders can {{c7::adopt, amend, or repeal bylaws}}, subject to any allocation of bylaw power in the articles of incorporation. 2.3 {{c8::Fundamental changes}}: Shareholder approval is required for major structural changes to the corporation, including: 2.3.1 {{c9::Mergers}}. 2.3.2 {{c10::Sale of assets outside the ordinary course of business}} (typically a sale of substantially all assets). 2.3.3 {{c11::Dissolution}} (voluntary winding up).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: {{c1::Specific intent crimes}} require that the defendant have a {{c2::specific intent or objective}} to commit the crime or bring about a particular result. Mnemonic: {{c3::FIAT}} – {{c4::First-degree murder, Inchoate crimes, Assault, Theft}}. Major common law specific intent crimes: - {{c5::Attempt}} (inchoate). - {{c6::Conspiracy}} (inchoate). - {{c7::Solicitation}} (inchoate). - {{c8::Larceny and robbery}} (theft). - {{c9::Burglary}}. - {{c10::Forgery}}. - {{c11::False pretenses}}. - {{c12::Embezzlement}}. - {{c13::Assault}}. - {{c14::First-degree murder}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Element 2: Product is {{c1::defective}} and {{c2::unreasonably dangerous}}. 1. Defective product: 1.1 The product must contain a {{c3::defect}}. 1.2 The defect may be in {{c4::manufacture}}, {{c5::design}}, or {{c6::warnings}} (details covered elsewhere). 2. Unreasonably dangerous: 2.1 The defect must make the product {{c7::unreasonably dangerous}} to the user or consumer. 2.2 "Unreasonably dangerous" means the product poses a danger beyond what an {{c8::ordinary consumer would expect}} or that {{c9::outweighs its utility}} (depending on the test).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Use of force to prevent a crime: 1. {{c1::Non-deadly force}} (NDF) 1.1 NDF is permissible to {{c2::prevent a serious breach of the peace}}. 2. {{c3::Deadly force}} (DF) 2.1 {{c4::Common law}} rule: 2.1.1 DF was permissible to {{c5::prevent the commission of any felony}}. 2.2 {{c6::Modern law}} rule: 2.2.1 DF is permissible to {{c7::terminate or prevent a dangerous felony}}; and 2.2.2 Only when the felony {{c8::threatens a serious risk to human life}}. Key contrast: CL = {{c9::any felony}}; Modern = {{c10::dangerous, life‑threatening felonies only}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A life insurer incorporated in {{c1::Delaware}} with its principal place of business in {{c2::California}} faces claims to policy proceeds from residents of {{c3::New Jersey}}, {{c4::Nevada}}, and {{c5::California}}. Because the insurer is a citizen of both {{c6::Delaware}} and {{c7::California}}, the presence of a {{c8::California}} claimant defeats {{c9::complete diversity}}, so {{c10::Rule 22 interpleader}} based on diversity is improper. However, {{c11::statutory interpleader}} is proper because there is {{c12::minimal diversity}} among the {{c13::claimants}} (they are from different states) and, assuming at least {{c14::$500}} in controversy, the statutory requirements are satisfied.

subject: Real Property
cloze: {{c1::Color of title}} is a {{c2::defective or invalid written claim of title}} (such as a void deed) that appears to convey property but does not actually do so. If an adverse possessor actually occupies {{c3::part}} of the land described in the instrument under color of title, that possession can allow them to acquire title to {{c4::the entire parcel described}} in the instrument, not just the portion physically occupied.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Mortgagee’s Right to Possession Before Foreclosure}} 1.1 The mortgagee’s right to possess before foreclosure depends on the {{c2::jurisdiction}}. 2. {{c3::Lien Theory}} 2.1 The mortgage is treated as a {{c4::lien on title}}. 2.2 The {{c5::mortgagor}} keeps legal and equitable title and the right to {{c6::possession}} until foreclosure. 2.3 Therefore, under lien theory, the mortgagee has {{c7::no right to possess prior to foreclosure}}. 3. {{c8::Title Theory}} 3.1 The mortgage is viewed as transferring {{c9::legal title}} to the {{c10::mortgagee}}, subject to the mortgagor’s equitable rights. 3.2 The mortgagee has the right to {{c11::possess the property at any time upon demand}}, even before default, unless otherwise agreed. 4. {{c12::Intermediate Theory}} 4.1 The mortgage is initially treated as a {{c13::lien}}, but upon {{c14::default}} the mortgagee acquires a right to {{c15::possession}}. 4.2 Thus, under intermediate theory, the mortgagee’s right to possess arises {{c16::upon default}}. 5. {{c17::Other Routes to Possession and Duties}} 5.1 In any jurisdiction, the mortgagee can take possession with the mortgagor’s {{c18::consent}} or after {{c19::abandonment}} of the property. 5.2 A mortgagee in possession must {{c20::account for rents and profits}}. 5.3 A mortgagee in possession must {{c21::manage the property with reasonable care}}. 5.4 The mortgagee in possession may incur {{c22::tort liability to third parties}} arising from the condition or management of the property.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Directors owe the corporation {{c1::fiduciary duties}} that constrain how they exercise their powers. 1. {{c2::Duty of care}} (overview) - Directors must act with the care of a {{c3::reasonably prudent person}} in similar circumstances. - They should be {{c4::adequately informed}} and act in {{c5::good faith}}. - The {{c6::business judgment rule}} generally protects directors who act in good faith, on an informed basis, and in the honest belief that their decisions are in the corporation’s best interests. 2. {{c7::Duty of loyalty}} (overview) - Directors must put the {{c8::corporation’s interests}} ahead of their own. - They must avoid {{c9::self-dealing}} and {{c10::conflicts of interest}} absent proper disclosure and approval. - They may not {{c11::usurp corporate opportunities}} or {{c12::unfairly compete}} with the corporation. 3. {{c13::Beneficiaries of the duties}} - These duties are owed to the {{c14::corporation}} (and indirectly to {{c15::shareholders}}), and breaches may be pursued via {{c16::derivative suits}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Purpose and appealability 1.1 A {{c1::temporary restraining order (TRO)}} is issued by the court when necessary to prevent {{c2::immediate, irreparable injury}} to a party. 1.2 A TRO is {{c3::not immediately appealable}} unless it is {{c4::extended and treated as a preliminary injunction}}. 2. Expiration and extension 2.1 A TRO expires {{c5::14 days}} from issuance. 2.2 The court may extend a TRO for {{c6::good cause}} or with the {{c7::adverse party's consent}}. 2.3 If extended beyond the initial period, the TRO is treated as a {{c8::preliminary injunction}} and thus becomes {{c9::appealable}}. 3. Notice to the adverse party 3.1 Notice to the adverse party is {{c10::not required}} if the moving party either: 3.1.1 Shows {{c11::immediate and irreparable injury}} will result to her before the adverse party can be heard in opposition; or 3.1.2 Describes {{c12::reasonable yet unsuccessful efforts}} made to give the adverse party notice. 4. Actual notice and enforcement 4.1 A party must have {{c13::actual notice}} of the TRO before they can be held in {{c14::contempt}} for violating it.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule: The {{c1::exclusionary rule}} applies only to searches or seizures in violation of a {{c2::federal statute}} or the {{c3::U.S. Constitution}}. 2. The exclusionary rule does not apply to: 2.1 {{c4::Grand jury proceedings, civil proceedings, parole hearings, or administrative cases}}. 2.2 Violations of the {{c5::knock-and-announce rule}} in executing search warrants. 2.3 Evidence seized as a result of {{c6::Miranda violations}} (although such evidence may be excluded under the Fifth Amendment on other grounds). 3. Excluded evidence and impeachment: 3.1 {{c7::Confessions resulting from Miranda violations or illegally obtained evidence}} may be used to {{c8::impeach the defendant's testimony at trial}} (but only the defendant's testimony). 4. Government good-faith defenses to the exclusionary rule (illegally obtained evidence will not be excluded if the government demonstrates that it relied in {{c9::good faith}} on either): 4.1 A {{c10::reasonably relied upon but defective search warrant}}. 4.2 A warrant obtained in good faith that is later found {{c11::invalid}}, except in limited situations where reliance was unreasonable. 4.3 A {{c12::judicial opinion or statute}} that was later {{c13::changed or declared invalid}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: An {{c1::easement by implication}} is an easement the law implies from the circumstances, even though it is not expressly granted. There are two main situations: 1. {{c2::Implied easement from prior use by a common grantor}}: When a common grantor uses one part of a tract to benefit another before division, and that use is continuous and apparent, reasonably necessary, and intended to continue, an easement by implication may arise in favor of the benefited parcel after the land is divided. 2. {{c3::Implied easements without prior use}}: Even if there was no prior use, an easement may be implied based on (a) {{c4::subdivision plats}} (lots sold with reference to a map/plan), or (b) the needs of a holder of a {{c5::profit à prendre}} to cross the land as reasonably necessary to extract resources.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Specific intent for {{c1::attempt}}: - The defendant must {{c2::specifically intend}} to commit a {{c3::particular target crime}}. - Attempt generally requires a {{c4::higher mens rea}} than some completed offenses; {{c5::recklessness or negligence}} alone is not enough for attempt liability.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Competency for execution in capital cases: 1. A defendant cannot be {{c1::executed}} if he is incapable of {{c2::understanding the nature and purpose of the punishment}} at the time of execution. 2. The focus is on whether, at the {{c3::time of execution}}, mental disease or defect prevents him from understanding that he is going to be executed and {{c4::why}}. 3. This rule is grounded in the {{c5::Eighth Amendment}} prohibition on {{c6::cruel and unusual punishment}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Every land sale contract contains an implied promise that the seller will provide {{c1::marketable title}} at closing. 2. {{c2::Marketable title}} means title that is {{c3::free from a reasonable risk of litigation}} at the time of {{c4::closing}}. 3. Defects that render title {{c5::unmarketable}} include: 3.1 Title acquired by {{c6::adverse possession}} that has not been {{c7::quieted}}. 3.2 Title {{c8::encumbered by interests}} such as {{c9::servitudes, mortgages, or future interests}}, subject to the seller’s right to satisfy mortgages or liens with the {{c10::sale proceeds at closing}}. 3.3 Existing {{c11::zoning ordinance violations}} at the time of sale. 4. Waiver: The implied promise of marketable title can be {{c12::waived by the buyer}}, but {{c13::not by the seller}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Necessity}} 1.1 Necessity is a valid defense if the defendant believed his conduct was {{c2::reasonably necessary to avoid an imminent and greater injury to society}}. 1.2 {{c3::Objective standard}}: the defendant's commission of the crime must, in fact, be reasonably necessary; {{c4::good faith alone is insufficient}}. 1.3 Exceptions: necessity is not available if either 1.3.1 The crime committed {{c5::results in the death of another}}; or 1.3.2 The defendant {{c6::caused the events giving rise to the necessity}}. 2. {{c7::Duress}} 2.1 Duress is a valid defense to a crime the defendant committed under a {{c8::reasonable belief}} that the crime was necessary to {{c9::prevent death or serious bodily harm}} to the defendant or a member of the defendant's family. 2.2 Example: someone points a gun at the defendant and threatens to kill him if he does not rob a bank. 2.3 Exception: duress is {{c10::not a defense to intentional homicide crimes}}. 3. {{c11::Consent}} 3.1 Consent of the victim is generally {{c12::not a defense}}, but may be available if it {{c13::negates an element of the offense}}. 3.2 Consent is {{c14::never available for certain offenses}} (e.g., statutory rape). 3.3 Requirements: to be valid, it must be established that 3.3.1 Consent was {{c15::voluntarily and freely given}}; 3.3.2 The party was {{c16::legally capable of consenting}}; and 3.3.3 {{c17::No fraud}} was involved in obtaining consent.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1.
