Use of proxies: - Shareholders can vote their shares via a {{c1::proxy}}, allowing another person to cast the vote on their behalf. - The proxy must be executed in {{c2::writing}} (or another valid record form permitted by statute). 2. {{c3::Revocability}} of proxies: - A proxy appointment is generally {{c4::revocable}} by the shareholder. - Revocation can occur by {{c5::notice to the corporation}}, by issuing a {{c6::later-dated proxy}}, or by the shareholder {{c7::attending and voting in person}} (subject to statute). 3. {{c8::Irrevocable proxies}} – exception: - A proxy may be irrevocable if: (a) it is {{c9::coupled with an interest}} (e.g., a pledgee, purchaser, creditor, or party to a voting agreement), and (b) it {{c10::clearly states that it is irrevocable}}. - Even an "irrevocable" proxy can often terminate according to its {{c11::terms}} or when the {{c12::underlying interest ends}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under {{c1::Rule 12}}, a defendant may move to dismiss for {{c2::failure to state a claim}} or move for {{c3::judgment on the pleadings}} due to the plaintiff's failure to bring a {{c4::plausible claim}}. The defendant is arguing that, even assuming all allegations in the plaintiff's complaint or pleadings are true, the plaintiff cannot win. If granted, the plaintiff will usually be given {{c5::leave to amend}} her complaint. Failure to state a claim vs. motion for judgment on the pleadings: 1. {{c6::Timing of filing}}: 1.1 Before the defendant files an answer: a {{c7::Rule 12(b)(6)}} motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. 1.2 After the defendant files an answer: a {{c8::Rule 12(c)}} motion for judgment on the pleadings. 2. {{c9::Materials reviewed by court}}: 2.1 On a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the court reviews the sufficiency of the {{c10::plaintiff's complaint alone}}. 2.2 On a Rule 12(c) motion, the court reviews {{c11::all pleadings}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. In general: {{c1::Proximate cause}} establishes that it is fair under the law to hold defendant responsible for plaintiff's injuries. 2. {{c2::Foreseeability}}: 2.1 Foreseeability is the {{c3::measuring stick for proximate cause}}. 2.2 Defendant is liable for the {{c4::foreseeable outcome}} of his conduct. 2.3 Note: An outcome does not have to be {{c5::likely}} to be foreseeable. On the MBE, unlikely things are often foreseeable; if it is {{c6::reasonably possible}}, it is probably foreseeable. 3. {{c7::Direct causes}}: 3.1 If plaintiff's injury is the direct consequence of defendant's negligent conduct, defendant is liable unless the outcome is {{c8::unusually bizarre or unpredictable}}. 4. {{c9::Indirect causes and intervening forces}}: 4.1 Intervening forces that occur after defendant's conduct to cause plaintiff's injuries will not cut off defendant's liability if they are {{c10::foreseeable}}. 4.2 An intervening force is usually foreseeable if either: 4.2.1 It is a {{c11::normal response or reaction}} to defendant's negligent act, or 4.2.2 Defendant's negligence {{c12::increased the risk}} that an intervening force would cause harm to plaintiff. 4.3 Injuries to {{c13::rescuers}} are usually considered foreseeable. 5. {{c14::Eggshell skull rule}}: 5.1 Defendant {{c15::takes plaintiff as he finds him}} and is liable for the {{c16::full extent of plaintiff's injuries}}, regardless of whether the extent of those injuries is foreseeable. 6. Note: Proximate cause (i.e., foreseeability) is a {{c17::question of fact}} that is usually left to the {{c18::jury or fact-finder}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: MBE questions occasionally invoke language from the {{c1::Model Penal Code (MPC)}} fault standards. It is important to know these definitions: 1. {{c2::Purposely}} ({{c3::subjective standard}}) 1.1 A person acts purposely when his {{c4::conscious objective is to engage in certain conduct or cause a certain result}}. 2. {{c5::Knowingly}} ({{c6::subjective standard}}) 2.1 A person acts knowingly when he is {{c7::aware that his conduct is of a particular nature}} or knows that his conduct will {{c8::necessarily or very likely cause a particular result}}. 3. {{c9::Recklessly}} ({{c10::subjective standard}}) 3.1 A person acts recklessly when he is {{c11::aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk and consciously disregards it}}. 4. {{c12::Negligently}} ({{c13::objective standard}}) 4.1 A person acts negligently when he {{c14::fails to become aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk}}. {{c15::Note:}} The MBE generally tests {{c16::common law}}, unless otherwise instructed. Though the MBE usually tells you which law is applicable, when in doubt, {{c17::apply common law}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: {{c1::Payment or offers to pay medical expenses}} 1. Payment of, or offers to pay, medical expenses are {{c2::inadmissible}} when offered to prove {{c3::liability for the injuries}}. 2. Related statements, including factual admissions, are {{c4::admissible}} unless {{c5::another exclusionary rule}} applies. 3. Offers to pay medical expenses in exchange for a {{c6::liability release}} are treated as {{c7::settlement offers}} and are {{c8::inadmissible}} to prove liability or the amount of a disputed claim.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 2. Methods of Supreme Court review 2.1 {{c1::Discretionary review}} by {{c2::writ of certiorari}} - Most cases reach the Supreme Court through a {{c3::certiorari}} petition. - The Court has {{c4::complete discretion}} to grant or deny review. 2.2 {{c5::Mandatory review}} from three-judge district courts - Certain cases are heard in the first instance by a {{c6::three-judge federal district court panel}} deciding {{c7::injunctive relief}}. - Appeals from these panels go {{c8::directly}} and {{c9::mandatorily}} to the Supreme Court. - These appeals {{c10::bypass the federal courts of appeals}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: UCC Article 9 governs security interests in certain goods related to real property or other goods. 1. {{c1::Fixtures}} – goods attached to real property; priority is generally {{c2::first to file or record}}, with a {{c3::PMSI fixture‑filing exception}} that can defeat a prior real property interest. 2. {{c4::Accessions}} – goods physically united with other goods that {{c5::do not lose their identity}}; a {{c6::security interest continues}} after the collateral becomes an accession. 3. {{c7::Crops}} – a {{c8::perfected security interest in crops}} has priority over {{c9::interests in the land}} where they are grown, {{c10::regardless of time of filing or perfection}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Revenue requirement for taxes 1.1 To qualify as a valid {{c1::tax}}, a federal charge must {{c2::reasonably relate to revenue production}}. 1.2 This {{c3::reasonable relationship}} standard is a {{c4::low threshold}}. 2. Penalties functioning as taxes 2.1 A measure labeled as a "{{c5::penalty}}" rather than a "{{c6::tax}}" may still be upheld under the {{c7::taxing power}}. 2.2 The key question is whether the measure {{c8::behaves similarly to a tax}}, such as: - It is {{c9::collected by the tax authorities}}; - It is {{c10::calculated by reference to income, status, or similar tax-like factors}}; and - It is {{c11::not so punitive as to be purely regulatory}}. 2.3 Example: The {{c12::Affordable Care Act individual mandate}} payment was treated as a {{c13::tax}} because it {{c14::functioned like a tax}}, even though Congress called it a {{c15::penalty}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In General 1.1. Unless acceptance is limited by the terms of the offer, the offeree may accept by {{c1::partial performance (for bilateral contracts)}} or {{c2::complete performance (for unilateral contracts)}}. 2. {{c3::Unilateral Contracts}} 2.1. {{c4::Complete performance}} is required to accept a unilateral contract. 2.2. The offeree is {{c5::not obligated to start or complete performance}}. 2.3. Failure to perform does not give rise to breach because {{c6::no contract is formed absent complete performance}}. 2.4. Revocability: Once the offeree {{c7::begins performance}}, many courts treat the offer as {{c8::irrevocable for a reasonable time}} to allow completion. 2.5. Notice: The offeree is not required to give notice upon the start of performance, but must {{c9::notify the offeror within a reasonable time upon completion}}, unless the offeror {{c10::learns of the performance by other reasonable means}} or notice is {{c11::waived}}. 3. {{c12::Bilateral Contracts}} 3.1. {{c13::Partial performance (or beginning performance)}} gives rise to acceptance of a bilateral contract. 3.2. The offeree must {{c14::make the offeror aware of the acceptance}}, either by performance in the offeror's presence or by {{c15::reasonable notice}}. 4. {{c16::Offers Requiring Acceptance by Promise}} 4.1. An offer that appears to require acceptance by promise may still be accepted by performance if: 4.1.1. The offeree {{c17::begins to perform}}; and 4.1.2. The offeror {{c18::knows the offeree has begun performance and acquiesces}}. 4.2. However, an offer may always {{c19::limit methods of acceptance}}, in which case the stated method controls.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Rule: An {{c1::easement may be implied from a subdivision plat}} even without prior use. 2. Subdivision plat doctrine: 2.1 When a landowner subdivides a tract and sells lots with reference to a recorded {{c2::map or subdivision plat}}, purchasers acquire {{c3::implied easements consistent with the plat}}. 2.2 Common examples are implied easements over {{c4::streets, alleys, and other ways}} shown on the plat that provide access to the lots. 3. Rationale: By selling lots with reference to the plat, the grantor is treated as having {{c5::intended}} that the streets and ways shown be available for use by the lot owners, so the law {{c6::implies easements}} to make the lots usable as depicted.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Due process and competency during trial and sentencing: 1. The {{c1::Due Process Clause}} forbids a defendant from being {{c2::tried, convicted, or sentenced}} if, because of {{c3::mental disease or defect}}, he is incompetent. 2. A defendant is incompetent if he is unable either to: a. {{c4::Understand the nature of the proceedings}}, or b. {{c5::Assist his lawyer}} in the preparation of his defense. 3. This requirement applies at both {{c6::trial}} and {{c7::sentencing}}, and proceedings must be suspended or adjusted until competence is restored.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Rule 12 provides motions that address the {{c1::clarity and content}} of the pleadings. 1. {{c2::Motion for a more definite statement (Rule 12(e))}}: • Available when a pleading is so {{c3::vague or ambiguous}} that the defendant cannot reasonably {{c4::prepare a response}}. • The motion asks the court to require the {{c5::pleader (usually the plaintiff)}} to {{c6::clarify or specify the allegations}}. 2. {{c7::Motion to strike (Rule 12(f))}}: • Allows a party to seek removal of {{c8::redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous}} material from a pleading. • The court may also {{c9::strike such material on its own (sua sponte)}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Contributory negligence}} 1. In contributory negligence jurisdictions, the plaintiff is {{c2::barred from recovery}} if the defendant establishes that the plaintiff’s negligence {{c3::contributed to her injuries}}. 2. {{c4::Last clear chance doctrine}} 2.1. The plaintiff can rebut the defendant’s contributory negligence defense by proving the defendant had the {{c5::last clear chance to avoid the injury-causing accident}}. 2.2. If the defendant had this final clear opportunity and failed to act reasonably, the plaintiff may {{c6::still recover despite her contributory negligence}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Automatic standing}} refers to situations where a defendant is presumed to have a {{c2::reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP)}} in premises to be searched. 2. A defendant has automatic standing if the defendant: 2.1. {{c3::Owns}} the premises to be searched; or 2.2. Has a {{c4::right to possess}} the premises to be searched; or 2.3. {{c5::Lives in}} the premises to be searched; or 2.4. Is an {{c6::overnight guest}} in the premises to be searched.

subject: Corporations
cloze: Shareholder inspection rights: 1. General right: Shareholders may {{c1::inspect the corporation's books and records}} for any {{c2::proper purpose}} upon {{c3::written notice}}. 2. Proper purpose: 2.1 Definition: A purpose is proper if it is {{c4::reasonably related to the person's interest as a shareholder}}. 3. Notice requirements: 3.1 Timing: The shareholder must provide at least {{c5::five days'}} written notice to the corporation. 3.2 Content: The notice must {{c6::state the proper purpose}} for the inspection. 4. Records available without proper purpose: Certain core records may be inspected {{c7::regardless of proper purpose}}, including: 4.1 {{c8::Articles of incorporation and bylaws}}. 4.2 {{c9::Annual reports and meeting minutes}}. 4.3 {{c10::Board of directors resolutions regarding share classifications}}. 4.4 {{c11::Corporate communications to shareholders}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}}: {{c2::1.1 Communications between an attorney and client or the client's representatives are privileged}} in all proceedings unless waived. {{c3::1.2 Organizational clients}}: the privilege applies to any employee {{c4::authorized to speak to the attorney}}. 2. Requirements for protection (to be protected, a communication must be): {{c5::2.1 Intended to be confidential}}. {{c6::2.2 Made to facilitate legal services}}. 3. Exceptions (privilege does not apply to): {{c7::3.1 Crime or fraud}}: the privilege does not apply if a client seeks legal services to aid in the planning or commission of a fraud or a crime. {{c8::3.2 Attorney defending malpractice claim}}: the privilege does not apply if the communication relates to an alleged breach of the attorney's duty. 4. Joint representation of parties: {{c9::4.1 No privilege between joint clients}}: where an attorney acts for both parties in a transaction, no privilege can be invoked in a lawsuit between the parties. {{c10::4.2 However, the privilege can be claimed in a suit between either or both of the parties and a third person}}. 5. Fees not covered: {{c11::5.1 Records of fee payments, including fee arrangements and payments, are generally considered outside the attorney-client privilege}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. Possessory security interest and movement of collateral 1.1 If collateral in one state is perfected by a {{c1::possessory security interest}} in that state and the collateral is moved to a new state, the security interest remains perfected as long as it would be perfected by {{c2::possession}} under the laws of the {{c3::new state}}. 2. Cars/vehicles and certificate of title 2.1 If a vehicle covered by a {{c4::certificate of title}} is moved from one state to another and the new state issues a new certificate of title, the original perfected security interest lasts as long as it would have lasted {{c5::had the new title not been issued}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Durham Test (Product Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant’s conduct was the {{c1::product}} of a {{c2::mental illness}}. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 {{c3::But for}} his mental illness, the defendant would not have acted. 2.2 The defendant's conduct must be the {{c4::product of a mental illness}} to qualify as legally insane under this test.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule: The {{c1::exclusionary rule}} prohibits the introduction of evidence obtained in violation of the {{c2::defendant's constitutional rights}} in a criminal trial. 2. "{{c3::Fruit of the poisonous tree}}" doctrine: 2.1 {{c4::Evidence derived or obtained from illegal government conduct}} is excludable against the defendant. 2.2 This arises when {{c5::illegal police action leads to additional evidence}}. 3. Exceptions (illegally obtained evidence is admissible if the government can {{c6::break the causal chain}} between the illegal government conduct and the seized evidence; common ways to break the chain): 3.1 {{c7::Independent source}}: The government had an independent source for obtaining the evidence, i.e., independent from the original illegality. 3.2 {{c8::Inevitable discovery}}: The government would have discovered the illegally derived evidence even without the illegal conduct. 3.3 {{c9::Attenuation}}: The connection between the unlawful search or seizure and the challenged evidence is too remote and attenuated; this includes {{c10::intervening acts of free will by the defendant}} (e.g., after an initial illegality, the defendant consciously leads police to the evidence). 4. Remedy for exclusionary rule violations: 4.1 {{c11::Harmless error review}} on appeal. 4.2 For admission of illegally seized evidence to be upheld on appeal, the government must show that the error was {{c12::harmless beyond a reasonable doubt}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 3. {{c1::Senior interests}} 3.1 Senior interests are {{c2::unaffected}} by junior interest foreclosures. 3.2 A buyer of foreclosed property takes the property {{c3::subject to}} any senior interests. 3.3 The buyer is {{c4::not personally liable}} for the senior debt, but the senior mortgage {{c5::remains on the land}} and can be foreclosed if not paid.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. Who may redeem - The following parties have a right to {{c1::redeem}} collateral after default: - The {{c2::debtor}}; and - Any other {{c3::secured party or lienholder}} in the collateral. 2. When redemption is available - The right to redeem exists: - Until the secured party has {{c4::disposed of the collateral}} by sale or other disposition; or - Until the secured party has {{c5::discharged the debt by retaining the collateral}} ({{c6::strict foreclosure}}). 3. How to redeem – Amount required - To redeem, the redeeming party must: - Tender {{c7::all remaining obligations secured by the collateral}} (pay the full unpaid secured debt); and - Pay {{c8::reasonable expenses}} incurred by the secured party in {{c9::repossessing and holding}} the collateral (e.g., repossession and storage costs).

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Valid {{c1::contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will}} are generally enforceable if they satisfy {{c2::ordinary contract requirements}} such as mutual assent and consideration, and they are {{c3::governed by contract law rather than will law}}. Most states require such contracts to be {{c4::in writing}}. Under the {{c5::UPC}}, the writing requirement can be satisfied by: (1) will provisions stating the {{c6::material provisions of the contract}}; (2) an {{c7::express reference in the will to the contract}} plus extrinsic evidence of its terms; or (3) a separate {{c8::writing signed by the decedent}} evidencing the contract. On breach, courts typically {{c9::admit the will to probate}} and impose a {{c10::constructive trust}} in favor of the intended beneficiary. A {{c11::joint will}} is a single document executed by two or more testators and may be interpreted as a {{c12::contract not to revoke}}, while {{c13::mutual wills}} are separate but reciprocal wills that are {{c14::usually not treated as a binding contract}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In a certified class action, the court must address: (1) {{c1::certification}} (timing, defining the class and issues, and appointing adequate class counsel); (2) {{c2::appeal}} of the certification decision; (3) the {{c3::binding effect of any class judgment}} on absent class members (subject to {{c4::opt-out rights}}, if applicable); and (4) court {{c5::approval of any class settlement}} as {{c6::fair, reasonable, and adequate}} after seeking input from absent class members.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Application to federal and state governments: The {{c1::Bill of Rights}} ({{c2::BoR}}) applies directly only to the {{c3::federal government}}. Certain provisions of the BoR apply to state and local governments through the {{c4::incorporation doctrine}}. 1. Incorporation: the Supreme Court has held specific BoR provisions applicable to the states by incorporating them into the {{c5::14th Amendment Due Process (DP) Clause}}. Most BoR provisions are now incorporated. 2. Exceptions: certain provisions of the BoR are not incorporated by the 14th Amendment to the states, including: 2.1 {{c6::3rd Amendment}} right not to have soldiers quartered in homes; 2.2 {{c7::5th Amendment}} right to {{c8::grand jury indictment in criminal cases}}; and 2.3 {{c9::7th Amendment}} right to {{c10::jury trial in civil cases}}. 3. Reverse incorporation: the {{c11::14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause}} does not apply directly to the federal government, but has been held to apply to the federal government through the {{c12::5th Amendment Due Process Clause}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In diversity cases, federal courts must apply {{c1::state substantive law}} and {{c2::federal procedural law}}. Use the following analysis to determine whether a state law is {{c3::substantive}} and thus must be applied. 1. Is there a valid federal law on point? 1.1. Determine whether there is a valid {{c4::federal provision}} (e.g., the Constitution, a federal statute, or a Federal Rule) that is {{c5::on point and directly conflicts}} with state law. 1.2. If yes, the {{c6::federal law governs}} (assuming it is valid under the Constitution or the {{c7::Rules Enabling Act}}). 2. If no federal law is on point, apply the Erie tests 2.1. {{c8::Outcome determinative test}}: Would applying or ignoring the state rule significantly affect the outcome of the case? If yes, the state law is substantive and should be applied. 2.2. {{c9::Balance of interests test}}: Does either the federal or state system have a strong interest in applying its rule? If one has a clearly stronger interest, apply that law. 2.3. {{c10::Forum shopping avoidance test}}: If the federal court ignores the state law, would it encourage litigants to {{c11::flock to federal court or avoid state court}}? If yes, the state law is substantive and should be applied. 3. Matters always governed by state substantive law 3.1. {{c12::Elements of a claim or defense}}. 3.2. {{c13::Statutes of limitations}}. 3.3. {{c14::Conflict/choice-of-law rules}}. 3.4. {{c15::Rules for tolling the statute of limitations}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: {{c1::Interpleader}} is a joinder device that allows a {{c2::stakeholder}} (a property holder exposed to multiple liability) to bring all rival {{c3::claimants}} into a single lawsuit to resolve competing claims to the same property or fund. The {{c4::stakeholder}} initiates the action to avoid {{c5::multiple suits}} and {{c6::inconsistent judgments}}. A stakeholder plaintiff may also {{c7::name itself as an adverse claimant defendant}} so that its own interest can be adjudicated in the same proceeding.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Requesting waiver 1.1. The {{c1::plaintiff}} may request that the {{c2::defendant}} waive formal service by {{c3::mailing}} the defendant the complaint and a formal request to waive service. 1.2. If the defendant denies the request or fails to respond, the plaintiff must serve through another acceptable method, and the defendant must {{c4::pay for the cost of that service}} (unless good cause for failure to waive is shown). 2. Effect of waiver 2.1. If the defendant agrees to waive service, the defendant's time to answer the complaint is extended to {{c5::60 days}} from the date the waiver request was sent (instead of the normal {{c6::21 days}} after service). 3. Preservation of objections 3.1. Waiving service does {{c7::not waive the right to object to venue or jurisdiction}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: RAP and class gifts 1. RAP requirements for class gifts 1.1 For a {{c1::class gift}} to satisfy the {{c2::Rule Against Perpetuities}}, the {{c3::class must be closed}} and {{c4::all conditions precedent}} must be satisfied for {{c5::every member}} within the {{c6::perpetuities period}}. 1.2 If the class remains {{c7::open}} or conditions precedent might be satisfied for some members {{c8::beyond the perpetuities period}}, the class gift may {{c9::violate RAP}}. 2. Rule of Convenience 2.1 The {{c10::Rule of Convenience}} is a {{c11::rule of construction}} that may save a class gift that would otherwise violate RAP. 2.2 Under the Rule of Convenience, the class {{c12::closes}} when at least {{c13::one class member}} is entitled to {{c14::immediate possession or enjoyment}}. 2.3 By closing the class at that time, the Rule of Convenience can prevent {{c15::later-born members}} from joining the class and creating {{c16::remote vesting problems}} under RAP.

subject: Family Law
cloze: To be valid, a premarital agreement must satisfy three main requirements: 1. {{c1::Writing}} – The agreement must be in writing to satisfy the {{c2::Statute of Frauds}}. 2. {{c3::Voluntariness}} – The agreement must be entered into {{c4::voluntarily}}, free from {{c5::fraud, duress, or overreaching}}. 3. {{c6::Full and fair disclosure}} – Each party must {{c7::fully and fairly disclose}} his or her {{c8::financial situation}} (or {{c9::knowingly waive}} the right to disclosure after {{c10::adequate knowledge}}). If these requirements are not met, the premarital agreement may be {{c11::unenforceable}} in whole or in part under the {{c12::UPAA}} or similar state law.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. General rule. 1.1. Every item of physical evidence must be {{c1::authenticated}}, meaning the proponent must show that the evidence is {{c2::what the proponent claims it is}}. 1.2. Proving authentication: may be proved by {{c3::any means that serve to establish authenticity}} (a {{c4::low burden}}). For example, an item may be compared with an already authenticated item. 1.3. {{c5::Self-authenticating evidence}}: certain writings that contain identifying information do not need separate authentication. For example, {{c6::deeds, notarized documents, and newspapers}}. 2. Specific authentication issues. 2.1. {{c7::Ancient documents}} (automatically authenticated if all are met): 2.1.1. The document is {{c8::20 or more years old}}. 2.1.2. It does not present any {{c9::irregularities on its face}}. 2.1.3. It is found in a {{c10::place of natural custody}}. 2.2. {{c11::Photos}}: a witness with {{c12::personal knowledge}} must authenticate by confirming that the photo fairly and accurately depicts what it purports to show (does the fact testified to equal the fact perceived?). 2.3. {{c13::Voice}}: whether heard firsthand or through a recording, a voice may be identified by {{c14::anyone who heard the voice at any time}}. 2.4. {{c15::Non-unique items}}: 2.4.1. A non-unique item is {{c16::facially indistinguishable from others of its kind}} (e.g., a bag of white powder, a generic syringe). 2.4.2. The proponent must establish that the proffered evidence is the {{c17::same item it is claimed to be}}, usually through a {{c18::chain of custody}}; the item will be admissible absent large breaks in the chain.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule 1.1. Once the {{c1::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}} attaches, police may not {{c2::deliberately elicit incriminating statements}} from the defendant about the {{c3::charged offense}} outside the presence of counsel. 2. Attachment and application 2.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel attaches once {{c4::formal charges have been filed}} (such as {{c5::indictment, information, or arraignment}}). 2.2. It applies to all subsequent {{c6::critical stages}} of the judicial proceedings. 3. Scope of the Sixth Amendment right 3.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel is {{c7::offense-specific}}. 3.2. Police may question the defendant about any other {{c8::uncharged crimes}} without violating the defendant's Sixth Amendment rights.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Rape (now often called {{c1::sexual assault or sexual battery}}) generally involves {{c2::non-consensual sexual intercourse or penetration}}. 1. At {{c3::common law}}, rape required unlawful carnal knowledge of a woman by a man not her husband and without effective consent. 2. {{c4::Modern statutes}} typically remove the {{c5::marital requirement}}, require only the {{c6::slightest penetration}}, and focus on {{c7::lack of consent or capacity}}. 3. Lack of consent is usually shown by {{c8::force or threats}}, {{c9::incapacity}} (e.g., unconsciousness, intoxication), or certain {{c10::frauds about the nature of the act}}, but not by mere {{c11::deceit about collateral matters}} such as a promise to marry.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::fee simple}} in which the {{c2::grantor retains the power to terminate}} the grantee's estate upon the happening of a specified {{c3::event or condition}}. 2. Characteristics: 2.1 {{c4::Forfeiture not automatic}}: If the event or condition occurs, the grantee still retains title until the grantor affirmatively exercises the {{c5::right of reentry}}. This is what distinguishes a fee simple subject to condition subsequent from a {{c6::fee simple determinable}}. 2.2 {{c7::Potentially infinite}}: The duration can be infinite so long as the event or condition does not occur, or if it occurs, the grantor does not exercise the right of reentry. 2.3 {{c8::Transferable}}: The estate is {{c9::alienable, devisable, and descendible}}, subject to the possibility that it will end upon the occurrence of the condition and the grantor's exercise of the right of reentry. 3. Creation and future interest: 3.1 Creation: {{c10::Clear durational or conditional language}} must also carve out a {{c11::right of reentry in favor of the grantor}}. It must be explicit that the grantor has the right to retake upon occurrence of the event or condition. {{c12::Words of desire, hope, or aspiration are insufficient}}. 3.2 Accompanying future interest: The grantor retains a {{c13::right of reentry (power of termination)}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::First Amendment}} protects freedom of expression, including {{c2::speech}}, {{c3::press}}, {{c4::assembly}}, and {{c5::association}}. In analyzing a speech problem, you generally: 1. {{c6::Identify the type of speech and any unprotected or lesser-protected category}}, applying that category's specific test if applicable. 2. For protected speech, determine whether the restriction is {{c7::content-based (strict scrutiny)}} or {{c8::content-neutral (intermediate scrutiny)}}. 3. Consider {{c9::where the speech occurs}} and apply the {{c10::public forum doctrine}}. 4. If the case involves the {{c11::press publishing matters of public concern}}, recognize that restrictions must be {{c12::narrowly tailored to serve a state interest of the highest order}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: {{c1::Mens rea}} is the mental element required at the time a crime is committed and is a required element of common law crimes, along with {{c2::actus reus}}. At common law, the main mental-state categories (or related bases of liability) are: 1. {{c3::Specific intent}} 2. {{c4::General intent}} 3. {{c5::Malice}} 4. {{c6::Strict liability}} 5. {{c7::Vicarious liability}}. These categories determine what {{c8::mental state the prosecution must prove and what defenses may be available}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General Double Jeopardy rule 1.1. A defendant cannot be retried for the {{c1::same offense}} once {{c2::jeopardy has attached}}. 1.2. Double jeopardy issues arise when a defendant is prosecuted for one crime and tried, then later charged again based on the {{c1::same offense}}. 2. Same offense (Blockburger) test 2.1. Two offenses are different if conviction for one offense requires proof of an {{c3::element not included}} in the other offense. 2.2. This is the {{c4::same-elements (Blockburger) test}}: if each offense contains an {{c5::element the other does not}}, they are {{c6::different offenses}}; if not, they are the {{c7::same offense}} for Double Jeopardy purposes.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Breathalyzer tests}} (DUI arrests): 1.1. Following a {{c2::lawful arrest}} based on {{c3::probable cause for drunk driving}}, police may require a {{c4::warrantless breathalyzer test}} incident to the arrest. 1.2. Rationale: Breath tests are considered {{c5::minimally intrusive}} and fall within the {{c6::search-incident-to-arrest}} exception. 2. {{c7::Cell phones}} (digital information limitation): 2.1. Police may {{c8::seize}} a cell phone incident to arrest but may not {{c9::search the digital contents}} of the phone incident to arrest without a {{c10::warrant}}. 2.2. Officers generally must obtain a warrant to search {{c11::text messages, emails, photos, or other digital data}} stored on a phone seized during an arrest, absent an independent exception such as {{c12::exigent circumstances}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule 1.1. A suspect who is in {{c1::custody}} must be informed of {{c2::Miranda rights}} before {{c3:interrogation}}. 1.2. If Miranda warnings are required but not given before custodial interrogation, the suspect’s subsequent statements are generally {{c4::inadmissible}} in the {{c5::prosecution’s case-in-chief}}. 1.3. Miranda applies only when the accused is both in {{c1::custody}} and subjected to {{c3::interrogation}} ("{{c6::custodial interrogation}}".).

subject: Evidence
cloze: Hearsay exceptions are grouped by whether the declarant must be {{c1::unavailable}} or whether availability is {{c2::immaterial}}. 1. Declarant {{c3::unavailability required}} (FRE 804) - {{c4::Former testimony}} exception - {{c5::Statements against interest}} - {{c6::Dying declarations}} - Statements of {{c7::personal or family history}} - Statements offered against a party that {{c8::wrongfully procured the declarant's unavailability}} 2. Declarant {{c9::availability immaterial}} (availability not required) - {{c10::Present state of mind}} - {{c11::Excited utterances}} - {{c12::Present sense impressions}} - Statements of {{c13::physical condition}} for {{c14::medical diagnosis or treatment}} - {{c15::Past recollection recorded}} - {{c16::Business records}} - {{c17::Public records or reports}} - {{c18::Judgments and prior convictions}} - {{c19::Ancient documents}} - Documents affecting {{c20::property interests}} - {{c21::Learned treatises}} - {{c22::Family records}} - {{c23::Market reports}} and similar commercial publications

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 2. {{c1::Causation requirement – Cause-in-fact}} 2.1 The defendant's conduct must be a {{c2::cause-in-fact}} of the result. 2.2 Basic test: {{c3::But for}} the defendant's conduct, the result would not have occurred. 2.3 {{c4::Homicide and manslaughter rule}}: 2.3.1 Any act by the defendant that {{c5::hastens the victim's death}} is a cause-in-fact, even if death was already {{c6::inevitable}}. Note: Cause-in-fact is also called {{c7::actual cause}}.

subject: Family Law
cloze: When unmarried cohabitants separate, courts may use {{c1::equitable or restitutionary remedies}} to allocate property and prevent {{c2::unjust enrichment}}. A {{c3::resulting trust}} arises when one party {{c4::pays purchase money for property}} placed in another’s name with intent to {{c5::retain a beneficial ownership interest}}. A {{c6::constructive trust}} is imposed where one party holds title obtained through {{c7::wrongful conduct}}, treating that party as a {{c8::trustee}} to strip away {{c9::unjust enrichment}}. {{c10::Quantum meruit}} is a {{c11::quasi-contract}} remedy allowing recovery of the {{c12::fair market value of services rendered}} when no enforceable contract or property right exists.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Certain categories of otherwise relevant evidence are excluded on {{c1::public policy}} grounds because admitting them would discourage {{c2::socially valuable behavior or settlement}}. The main categories are: 1. {{c3::Liability insurance}} (cannot prove fault or ability to pay; can show ownership, control, or motive). 2. {{c4::Subsequent remedial measures}} (cannot prove fault, defect, or inadequate warning; can show ownership/control or rebut "no feasible precaution"). 3. {{c5::Compromises, settlement offers, and plea-related statements}} (cannot prove liability, fault, amount of disputed claim, guilt, or punishment; limited to disputed claims or actual plea talks). 4. {{c6::Payments or offers to pay medical expenses}} (cannot prove liability; related statements and combined settlement-like offers may be treated differently).

subject: Con Law
cloze: In higher education admissions, {{c1::student body diversity}} may be a {{c2::compelling interest}}. Universities may consider {{c3::race or national origin}} as {{c4::one factor}} in a {{c5::holistic, individualized}} admissions process, but may not treat race as a {{c6::defining or decisive criterion}} (e.g., automatic admission based solely on race). They must also show that there are {{c7::no workable race-neutral alternatives}} that would achieve the desired diversity.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A party must have a {{c1::concrete interest}} in the outcome of a claim to have the claim heard in federal court. 1. Requirements: 1.1 {{c2::Injury}}: The plaintiff must have suffered some injury or show a likelihood of imminent injury. 1.2 {{c3::Causation and redressability}}: The plaintiff must allege that the defendant caused the injury and that the court can grant a proper remedy. 1.3 {{c4::No generalized grievances}}: The plaintiff cannot sue solely as a U.S. citizen or taxpayer to compel the government to act in a particular way. 1.3.1 Exception: {{c5::Taxpayers have standing to challenge specific government expenditures that violate the Establishment Clause}}. 2. Congress: Congress cannot automatically {{c6::confer standing}}, but it can {{c7::create new statutory rights that, if violated, may give rise to standing}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: When a decedent's estate does not pass to a surviving spouse, but instead to descendants, {{c1::intestacy statutes}} control how distributions are made. States vary, but generally use one of the two approaches below. 1. {{c2::Per capita with representation}} ({{c3::modern per stirpes}}, majority rule) 1.1. The estate is divided into equal shares at the {{c4::first generation at which there are living takers}}. 1.2. Each living person at that level takes one share. 1.3. Each share of a deceased person at that level passes {{c5::by representation}} to that person's descendants. 1.4. Example: X dies intestate and has three children, A, B, and C. Only A is alive at X's death (B and C predecease X). A has one child, J. B is survived by one child, K. C is survived by three children, L, M, and N. X's estate is divided into three equal shares: A takes one share; B's share goes to K; L, M, and N split C's share (i.e., L, M, and N each get one-third of C's one-third share). 2. {{c6::Per capita at each generation}} ({{c7::UPC}} and a growing number of states) 2.1. The estate is divided into equal shares at the first generation with living takers, as above. 2.2. However, the shares that would have gone to deceased persons at that level are {{c8::combined into a pool}}. 2.3. That combined pool is {{c9::divided equally among all takers at the next generation}}. 2.4. This approach {{c10::avoids penalizing takers for having a larger family}}. 2.5. Example: Using the same scenario above, A still takes one-third, but the remaining two-thirds (representing B and C's shares) is combined and divided equally among B and C's surviving children, K, L, M, and N. Thus, K, L, M, and N each receive one-fourth of the remaining two-thirds.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::negative easement}} entitles the holder to {{c2::prevent the servient landowner from engaging in otherwise permissible actions}} on his own land. 1.1 Four traditional categories of acts may be prevented: 1.1.1 {{c3::Light}}; 1.1.2 {{c4::Air}}; 1.1.3 {{c5::Subjacent or lateral support}}; and/or 1.1.4 {{c6::Flow of water from an artificial stream}}. 2. Creation: A negative easement can only be created by {{c7::express grant}}, usually a {{c8::writing signed by the grantor}}. 3. Note: {{c9::Restrictive covenants}} are utilized more frequently than negative easements to prevent a landowner from engaging in certain activities on their land.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 1. General Rule (Second Restatement): - Under the {{c1::Most Significant Relationship Approach}} of the {{c2::Second Restatement}}, the court applies the law of the state that has the {{c3::most significant relationship}} to the issue at hand. 2. General Factors Considered in All Cases: - {{c4::Relevant policies of the forum and other interested jurisdictions}}. - {{c5::Relevant policies underlying the substantive field of law}}. - {{c6::Ease of applying the candidate law}}. - Whether applying a given law will aid {{c7::certainty, uniformity, and predictability}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Definition of a life estate: 1.1 A {{c1::life estate}} is a {{c2::present possessory estate}} that lasts only for the {{c3::life of a designated person}}, usually the {{c4::life tenant (LT)}}. 2. Defeasibility of life estates: 2.1 A life estate can be {{c5::defeasible like fee estates}} (e.g., {{c6::determinable, subject to condition subsequent, or subject to an executory interest}}) or {{c7::indefeasible}}. 3. Rights and duties of the life tenant: 3.1 The life tenant has {{c8::ordinary ownership rights}} (possess, use, and enjoy the property) during the measuring life. 3.2 The life tenant must {{c9::maintain the property and make reasonable repairs}}. 3.3 The life tenant {{c10::cannot commit waste}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::Free Exercise Clause}} of the First Amendment prohibits the government from {{c2::punishing someone solely on the basis of that person's religious beliefs or religiously motivated conduct}}. Government action that {{c3::targets religious practice or beliefs}} must be {{c4::necessary}} to achieve a {{c5::compelling governmental interest}}—i.e., it is subject to {{c6::strict scrutiny}}—and the Court has essentially {{c7::never upheld}} punishment under this standard. However, the Clause only applies when the {{c8::purpose}} of a law is to burden religion. {{c9::Neutral laws of general applicability}}—not designed to regulate or interfere with religion—are generally {{c10::valid}} even if they {{c11::incidentally burden religious practice}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Animal Conduct}} 1. Property damage from trespassing animals 1.1. Animal owners are {{c2::strictly liable}} for {{c3::reasonably foreseeable damage resulting from their animal’s trespass}} on another’s property. 1.2. This does not apply to {{c4::household pets}}. 2. Personal injuries 2.1. {{c5::Wild animals}}: Owners are strictly liable to {{c6::licensees and invitees}} for {{c7::unprovoked injuries}} caused by their wild animals. 2.2. {{c8::Domestic animals}}: There is no strict liability unless owners {{c9::know of their animal’s unusually dangerous propensities}}. 2.2.1. Example: If a dog has previously bitten people, its owner is strictly liable; but the negligence standard applies if this is the first time this dog has bitten anyone. 3. Trespassers 3.1. Trespassers are generally {{c10::not entitled to recovery under strict liability for animal conduct}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Appointment of {{c1::principal officers}} 1.1 {{c2::President and Senate}} 1.1.1 Under the {{c3::Appointments Clause}}, the {{c4::President}} appoints {{c5::ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal (high‑level) officers}} with the {{c6::advice and consent of the Senate}}. 2. Appointment of {{c7::inferior officers}} 2.1 {{c8::Congress’s role}} 2.1.1 Congress {{c9::cannot give itself appointment powers}}. 2.1.2 Congress may vest the appointment of inferior officers in the {{c10::President alone}}, the {{c11::courts of law}}, or the {{c12::heads of departments or agencies}}. 2.2 Definition of {{c13::inferior officers}} 2.2.1 They are typically those who {{c14::work under presidentially appointed principal officers}} and {{c15::can be removed by those principal officers}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A landlord may be liable to a tenant for injuries occurring on the leased property. A landlord is liable for injuries involving: 1.1 {{c1::Common areas}}: The landlord owes a {{c2::duty of reasonable care}} in maintaining and repairing common areas (e.g., hallways, stairs). 1.2 {{c3::Latent defects}}: The landlord has a duty to {{c4::disclose hidden defects}} that he knows or should reasonably know of. 1.3 {{c5::Assumption of repairs}}: If the landlord chooses to undertake repairs, he is liable for harm caused by {{c6::negligent repairs}}. 1.4 {{c7::Public use}}: The landlord is liable for {{c8::known defects}} if he knows the property is for public use and knows or should know that the tenant is unlikely to repair (for example, a concert hall or convention center). 1.5 {{c9::Seasonal or short-term lease of a furnished dwelling}}: The landlord is liable for {{c10::defects that cause harm to the tenant}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}}, a discriminatory or burdensome state law may still be upheld if it is {{c2::necessary}} to an {{c3::important, non-economic state interest}} and there are {{c4::no reasonable, non-discriminatory alternatives}} that would adequately achieve that interest.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Expert opinion testimony is admissible only if several {{c1::foundational requirements}} are satisfied: 1. {{c2::Helpful}} – The testimony must assist the {{c3::trier of fact}} by applying specialized knowledge beyond the ken of average jurors. 2. {{c4::Qualified expert}} – The witness must have sufficient {{c5::knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education}}. 3. {{c6::Reasonable degree of certainty}} – The expert must believe the opinion to a {{c7::reasonable degree of professional certainty}}. 4. {{c8::Proper factual basis}} – The opinion must rest on: - {{c9::Admitted evidence}}, - The expert’s {{c10::personal knowledge}}, or - {{c11::Inadmissible information reasonably relied upon by experts in the field}}. 5. {{c12::Reliable principles and methods}} – The opinion must be grounded in {{c13::reliable principles and methods}} that are {{c14::reasonably relied upon by experts}} in that area.

subject: Family Law
cloze: Premarital agreements ({{c1::prenups}}) are {{c2::contracts}} by which prospective spouses {{c3::alter default legal rules}} governing property and support at {{c4::divorce or death}}. {{c5::Marriage}} is sufficient {{c6::consideration}}. Under the {{c7::UPAA}}, validity turns on {{c8::writing}}, {{c9::voluntariness}}, and {{c10::full and fair financial disclosure}} (or a knowing waiver). The agreement can be {{c11::amended or revoked only by a later written agreement signed by both parties}}, and {{c12::no new consideration}} is required for an amendment. Courts {{c13::strictly scrutinize}} prenups, focusing on {{c9::voluntariness}}, {{c10::disclosure}}, and {{c14::unconscionability}}. {{c15::Child custody and support}} provisions are {{c16::not binding}} because courts decide those issues based on the {{c17::best interests of the child}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Doctor–patient and psychotherapist/social worker–patient privileges protect certain {{c1::confidential treatment-related communications}} from disclosure. 1. {{c2::Physician–patient privilege}} (statutory; generally applied via {{c3::state law}} in federal court): 1.1. Protects information confidentially conveyed by a {{c4::patient to a physician}}. 1.2. Applies to communications made for purposes of {{c5::diagnosis or treatment}}, that are {{c6::pertinent to diagnosis or treatment}}, and that the patient {{c7::intends to be confidential}}. 1.3. Subject to specific {{c8::exceptions}} (e.g., condition in issue, crime/tort/escape, doctor–patient dispute). 2. {{c9::Psychotherapist/social worker–patient privilege}}: 2.1. Protects {{c10::confidential communications}} by a client to a psychotherapist or social worker. 2.2. Applies in {{c11::civil and criminal cases}} when the client intends confidentiality and the communication is made to {{c12::facilitate therapy or social work}}. 2.3. Operates in most respects like the {{c13::attorney–client privilege}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Although the basic rule is that only {{c1::final orders}} are appealable, several types of non-final ({{c2::interlocutory}}) orders can be reviewed before final judgment, including: (1) certain interlocutory orders reviewable {{c3::as of right}}; (2) {{c4::discretionary interlocutory review}} under the {{c5::Interlocutory Appeals Act}} and for {{c6::class certification}} decisions; (3) the {{c7::collateral order exception}} for important, collateral, effectively unreviewable orders; and (4) {{c8::extraordinary writs}} such as {{c9::mandamus}} or {{c10::prohibition}} when normal routes of appeal are inadequate and irreparable harm is threatened.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Liability based on representation}} in products cases can arise from: (1) {{c2::breach of an express warranty}}; and (2) {{c3::misrepresentation of fact}}. 1. {{c4::Express warranty}} overview: 1.1 Definition: A {{c5::statement of material fact or promise}} regarding goods sold that becomes part of the {{c6::basis of the bargain}}. 1.2 Elements: Existence of an express warranty {{c7::relied upon by the purchaser}}, {{c8::breach}} when the product fails to live up to the warranty, {{c9::actual and proximate causation}}, and {{c10::personal, property, or economic damages}}. 1.3 Who can sue and defenses: Any {{c11::consumer or bystander}} can sue; {{c12::bystanders}} need not have relied personally if the {{c13::original purchaser}} did. Defenses include {{c14::assumption of risk, contributory negligence, and comparative negligence}}. 2. {{c15::Misrepresentation of fact}} overview: 2.1 Liability when the seller {{c16::misrepresents a material fact}} about the {{c17::quality or use}} of the goods, {{c18::intends to induce reliance}}, and the misrepresentation induces {{c19::justifiable reliance}}. 2.2 For {{c20::strict liability based on misrepresentation}}, the buyer need not {{c21::personally rely}} on the misrepresentation.

subject: Contracts
cloze: In a sale by a {{c1::merchant seller who deals in goods of the kind}}, the seller automatically gives an {{c2::implied warranty of merchantability}}. This warranty provides that the goods are {{c3::fit for their ordinary purpose}}. It arises {{c4::by operation of law}} in UCC sales by such merchants, without the need for specific statements or promises.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Trusts terminate automatically at the expiration of a {{c1::specified trust term}} or when their purposes have become {{c2::accomplished, unlawful, impossible, or contrary to public policy}}. In most states, a {{c3::private trust}} is {{c4::revocable or modifiable by the settlor}} unless the trust {{c5::expressly prohibits modification or revocation}}. {{c6::Beneficiaries}} may also seek modification or revocation, either with {{c7::settlor consent}} or, if all agree and it {{c8::does not frustrate a material purpose}}, without settlor consent. For {{c9::charitable trusts}}, courts may apply the {{c10::cy pres doctrine}} to modify the trust when its original charitable purpose is {{c11::accomplished}} or becomes {{c12::impractical, unlawful, or wasteful}}, so that the property is applied to a purpose {{c13::as near as possible to the settlor’s charitable intention}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Overview of deed types 1.1 Deeds differ in the scope of {{c1::covenants for title}} they provide to the grantee. 2. {{c2::General warranty deed}} 2.1 A general warranty deed includes {{c3::six covenants for title}}. 2.2 It provides the {{c4::broadest protection}} to the grantee, usually covering defects arising {{c5::both before and during}} the grantor’s ownership. 3. {{c6::Special warranty deed}} 3.1 Under a special warranty deed, the grantor assures that: 3.1.1 He has not {{c7::conveyed the land to another}}; and 3.1.2 The land is {{c8::free from encumbrances}} that attached {{c9::while the grantor owned the land}}. 3.2 The grantor does {{c10::not warrant against title defects}} arising {{c11::before}} his period of ownership. 4. {{c12::Quitclaim deed}} 4.1 A quitclaim deed transfers {{c13::whatever interest the grantor purports to have}} in the property. 4.2 It includes {{c14::no covenants for title}}, not even a promise that the grantor {{c15::has title to convey}}. 4.3 It offers the {{c16::least protection}} to the grantee, who takes the risk that the grantor may have {{c17::no interest}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: In criminal cases, the {{c1::defendant}} may introduce evidence of her good character, which the {{c2::prosecution}} may rebut; with limited exceptions, the prosecution may not first introduce evidence of the defendant's character. 1. {{c3::Defense use of character evidence}} 1.1 The defendant may introduce evidence of {{c4::pertinent good character}}. The trait offered must be pertinent to the charged crime (e.g., the defendant's reputation for peacefulness is irrelevant to a forgery charge). 1.2 Method: The defendant may call a witness to testify to the defendant's good character based on {{c5::reputation or opinion}}, but not {{c6::specific instances of conduct}}. 1.3 Prosecution rebuttal: Once the defendant offers character evidence, the prosecution may rebut by: 1.3.1 {{c7::Cross-examining the defendant's character witness}}, including inquiry into specific instances of the defendant's misconduct or prior arrests to test the witness's knowledge or opinion; or 1.3.2 {{c8::Calling a witness to testify to the defendant's bad character}}, limited to the same character trait that the defendant has put in issue. 2. {{c9::Prosecution use of character evidence}} 2.1 The prosecution may not initiate the introduction of character evidence about the defendant to prove conduct, except in the following situations: 2.1.1 In {{c10::sexual assault or child molestation cases}}, the prosecution may offer evidence of the defendant's other acts of sexual assault or child molestation. 2.1.2 If the defendant first offers evidence of the {{c11::victim's character trait}}, the prosecution may offer evidence that the defendant has the {{c12::same character trait}}. 2.2 On {{c13::direct examination}}, reputation and opinion evidence is admissible; evidence of specific instances is inadmissible. 2.3 On {{c14::cross-examination}} of a character witness, reputation, opinion, and specific instances of conduct are admissible to test the witness's basis.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Conspiracy is an {{c1::inchoate offense}} based on an {{c2::agreement}} to commit a crime or achieve an {{c3::unlawful objective}}. It generally requires: (1) an agreement between two or more people (which may be tacit and without each conspirator knowing all others), (2) intent to enter into the agreement, (3) intent to commit the target crime or unlawful objective, and in many jurisdictions (4) an {{c4::overt act}} in furtherance (not required at common law). At {{c5::common law}}, conspiracy is {{c6::bilateral}} and requires at least two parties with genuine criminal intent; under the {{c7::MPC}}, it can be {{c8::unilateral}} so one party with criminal intent may be guilty even if the other is feigning agreement. A conspiracy ends when the {{c9::target offense is completed}} or when the conspirators {{c10::abandon the plan}}. {{c11::Impossibility}} is not a defense, and {{c12::withdrawal}} generally does not defeat the conspiracy once formed, though it may limit liability for {{c13::co-conspirators' subsequent crimes}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. General rule 1.1 Otherwise discoverable information need not be disclosed if a {{c1::privilege}} applies. 1.2 Privileges are generally determined under the {{c2::Federal Rules of Evidence}}. 2. {{c3::Attorney–client privilege}} 2.1 Scope: Protects {{c4::confidential communications between attorney and client made for the purpose of obtaining or providing legal advice}}. 2.2 Requirements: To invoke the attorney–client privilege, a party must show that the communication was: 2.2.1 {{c5::Made between client and counsel}}. 2.2.2 {{c6::Intended to be and was, in fact, kept confidential}}. 2.2.3 {{c7::Made for the purpose of obtaining or providing legal advice}}. 3. {{c8::Work product doctrine}} 3.1 Scope: Protects {{c9::material prepared by or for an attorney in anticipation of litigation or for trial}}. 3.2 Rule: Items prepared in anticipation of litigation or for trial are not discoverable unless the opposing party shows: 3.2.1 A {{c10::substantial need}} for the materials. 3.2.2 An {{c11::inability, without undue hardship, to obtain the substantial equivalent}} of the materials by other means.

subject: Torts
cloze: Misrepresentation-based products liability: 1. Misrepresentation of fact elements: 1.1 In the course of a sale, the seller makes a {{c1::misrepresentation}} regarding a {{c2::material fact}} concerning the {{c3::quality or use}} of the goods. 1.2 The seller {{c4::intends to induce reliance}} by the buyer (or class of buyers). 1.3 The misrepresentation induces {{c5::justifiable reliance}}. 2. Strict liability based on misrepresentation: 2.1 For {{c6::strict liability based on misrepresentation}}, the buyer need not {{c7::personally rely}} on the misrepresentation for the seller to be liable; it is enough that the misrepresentation reaches and induces reliance by the purchasing public in a way that causes the plaintiff's harm.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Due process requires that the {{c1::defendant}} must be sufficiently {{c2::notified of a pending lawsuit}}. Requirement: Notice must be {{c3::reasonably calculated, under the circumstances, to apprise interested parties of the pendency of the action and afford them an opportunity to be heard}}. Methods: 1. {{c4::Traditional methods of notice}} satisfy due process, such as {{c5::personal delivery, registered mail, or delivery to an appointed agent}}. 2. The {{c6::plaintiff need not deliver notice personally}}; it can be given by a {{c7::court-appointed agent}} or an {{c8::agent hired by the plaintiff}}. 3. If the plaintiff {{c9::knows that notice was not received by the defendant}} (e.g., mail returned undelivered), the plaintiff {{c10::cannot proceed if practical alternatives to giving notice exist}}.

subject: Corporations
cloze: A {{c1::limited liability company (LLC)}} is a flexible business entity that combines {{c2::partnership-style pass-through taxation}} with {{c3::corporation-style limited liability}}. Owners are called {{c4::members}} and may also serve as managers. Key points: 1. {{c5::Formation}}: LLCs are formed by filing a {{c6::certificate of formation (or articles of organization)}} with the state, including the LLC’s {{c7::name}}, {{c8::registered office}}, and {{c9::registered agent}}. 2. {{c10::Operating agreement & governance}}: The operating agreement functions like {{c11::corporate bylaws}} and governs member/manager relations, rights and duties, management structure, voting and distribution rules, and amendment procedures. 3. {{c12::Management, voting, and distributions}}: By default, LLCs are {{c13::member-managed}}, but may be {{c14::manager-managed}}; voting and distributions are largely {{c15::contractual under the operating agreement}}. 4. {{c16::Duties and good faith}}: Fiduciary duties of {{c17::care and loyalty}} depend on the management structure, but all members and managers owe {{c18::good faith and fair dealing}} in performing and enforcing the operating agreement.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A will can dispose of property by reference to {{c1::acts or events occurring after}} the testator executes the will. In other words, identification of a {{c2::beneficiary}} or the {{c3::amount or nature of a gift}} in a will may be determined by some future act or event. Such provisions are valid as long as the act or event has some {{c4::independent significance}} during the testator's lifetime other than providing a gift in the will. 1. Identifying beneficiaries 1.1 A future act or event can involve identification of beneficiaries. For example: T's will leaves "$10,000 to each of my gardeners employed at my death." Two years after executing the will, T fires one gardener and hires three others, who remain employed until T dies. The gifts to the gardeners employed at death are valid because it is presumed that T did not hire and fire gardeners solely to change who would benefit under the will; the {{c5::employment decisions have independent significance}}. 2. Identifying property 2.1 A future act or event can involve identification of property. For example: T's will leaves "all automobiles I own at my death to A." T owns three cars at the time of execution, later sells one and buys two more before she dies, leaving A with a bequest of the four automobiles T owns at her death. The bequest is valid because it is presumed that T did not buy and sell cars solely to change A's gift; the {{c6::transactions have independent significance}} beyond the will.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: A {{c1::strict liability}} crime is one in which {{c2::no intent or awareness is required}} as to one or more elements of the offense—there is effectively {{c3::no mens rea requirement}} for those elements. Strict liability is commonly found in: • {{c4::Statutory rape}}; • {{c5::Regulatory or public welfare offenses}} (e.g., safety, food, or environmental regulations); • Certain {{c6::morality crimes}}. For these elements, the prosecution need only prove the {{c7::prohibited act and circumstances}}, not any particular mental state.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: A {{c1::counterclaim}} is an offensive claim, either {{c2::compulsory}} or {{c3::permissive}}, raised by the defendant against the plaintiff, which may be pleaded in the defendant's answer to the complaint. 1. {{c4::Jurisdictional requirement}}: The defendant must ensure the court has jurisdiction to hear any counterclaim. Note: {{c5::Compulsory counterclaims}} will almost always have {{c6::supplemental jurisdiction}}. 2. {{c7::Compulsory counterclaim}} (same transaction or occurrence): 2.1 A compulsory counterclaim is a claim by the defendant against the plaintiff that arises from the {{c8::same transaction or occurrence}} as one of the plaintiff's claims. 2.2 It is {{c9::required in the answer}}: it must be filed in the defendant's answer or it will be {{c10::waived}} (i.e., the defendant cannot assert it in a separate action at a later time). 3. {{c11::Permissive counterclaim}} (different transaction or occurrence): 3.1 A permissive counterclaim is a claim by the defendant against the plaintiff that {{c12::does not arise from the same transaction or occurrence}} as any of the plaintiff's claims. 3.2 It is {{c13::not required in the answer}}: it may be filed with the defendant's answer to the complaint, but does not have to be (i.e., it can be asserted in a {{c14::separate action}} filed by the defendant).

subject: Con Law
cloze: Some categories of speech receive {{c1::lesser or no First Amendment protection}} and are evaluated under {{c2::category-specific tests}} rather than ordinary strict or intermediate scrutiny. Examples include: - {{c3::Obscenity}}. - {{c4::Defamation}}. - {{c5::Incitement}} to imminent lawless action. - {{c6::Commercial speech}} (protected, but under reduced protection and a specialized test). Because these categories are {{c7::unprotected or lesser-protected}}, the government has {{c8::greater leeway}} to regulate them, and courts apply the {{c9::specific doctrinal test}} for that category.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::No general federal police power}} 1.1 Congress has no general police power to legislate for the {{c2::health, safety, welfare, or morals}} of the public. 2. Limited federal "police" power areas 2.1 Congress effectively has a police power only for legislation concerning: 2.1.1 The {{c3::military}}. 2.1.2 {{c4::Indian reservations}}. 2.1.3 {{c5::federal land and territories}}. 2.1.4 The {{c6::District of Columbia}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Certain orders are immediately appealable even without a final judgment. 1. {{c1::Injunctions}}: Orders concerning injunctions (granting, denying, modifying, or dissolving) are typically subject to {{c2::interlocutory appeal}}. 2. {{c3::Class actions}}: Orders {{c4::granting or denying class certification}} may be appealed on an interlocutory basis. 3. {{c5::Controlling legal questions}}: Some orders involving {{c6::debatable questions of controlling law}} may be appealed if: i. The order involves a {{c7::controlling issue of law}}, ii. There is {{c8::substantial ground for difference of opinion}}, and iii. An {{c9::immediate appeal may materially advance termination of the litigation}}. 4. {{c10::Multiple claims and/or parties}}: In such cases, the trial court may enter a {{c11::final judgment as to one or more claims or parties}}, and that judgment is immediately {{c12::appealable}} even though other claims or parties remain.

subject: Con Law
cloze: When speech occurs on {{c1::government property}}, the {{c2::public forum doctrine}} determines how the First Amendment applies. Types of forums: - {{c3::Traditional public forum}} – e.g., streets and parks, historically open to speech. - {{c4::Designated public forum}} – government property the state has intentionally opened for {{c5::expressive activity}}. - {{c6::Non-public forum}} (including limited public forums) – property {{c7::not traditionally or fully open}} to public expression. The forum classification affects the {{c8::level of scrutiny}} and how strictly courts review {{c9::speech regulations}} on that property.

subject: Evidence
cloze: {{c1::Present sense impression}} (a hearsay statement is admissible if it): 1. {{c2::Describes or explains an event or condition}}; and 2. Is made {{c3::contemporaneously with the event or immediately thereafter}}. 3. {{c4::Timing is key}}: the statement must be made while, or immediately after, the declarant {{c5::perceives the condition or event}} described in the statement. {{c6::Excited utterance}} (a hearsay statement is admissible if it): 1. {{c7::Relates to a startling or exciting event or condition}}; and 2. Was made while the declarant was {{c8::under the stress or excitement of the event}}. 3. The declarant's {{c9::emotional state is key}}: the declarant must be under such excitement or stress that one would not normally have an {{c10::opportunity to fabricate}} the statement.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General definition of vicarious liability: 1.1. {{c1::Vicarious liability}} arises when a defendant commits a tort and a {{c2::third person is held liable due to his legal relationship with the defendant}}. 2. {{c3::Respondeat superior}} – employer liability for employees: 2.1. Basic rule: {{c4::Employers are liable}} for torts committed by {{c5::employees within the scope of their employment}}. 2.2. “Scope of employment” generally includes acts: 2.2.1. Of the kind the employee is {{c6::employed to perform}}. 2.2.2. Substantially within the {{c7::authorized time and space}} limits. 2.2.3. {{c8::Motivated, at least in part, by a purpose to serve the employer}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Rescission}} of a contract serves to {{c2::discharge duties}} under the contract. 1.2 Rescission occurs when the parties {{c3::agree to rescind}} their contract. 1.3 The agreement to rescind is itself a {{c4::new, binding contract}} supported by {{c5::consideration}}, except in {{c6::at-will employment}}. 2. Limitations 2.1 {{c7::Mutual rescission}} may generally be made {{c8::orally}}. 2.2 Exception: A {{c9::writing}} is required if the contract to be rescinded is subject to the {{c10::Statute of Frauds}} and/or the {{c11::UCC}} writing requirements. 2.3 Parties cannot rescind a contract if the rights of a {{c12::third-party beneficiary}} have {{c13::vested}}. 3. Unilateral rescission 3.1 {{c14::Unilateral rescission}} occurs when only one party wants to rescind the contract. 3.2 It is usually only granted where there is a {{c15::defense to contract enforcement or formation}} (e.g., {{c16::mistake, misrepresentation, duress, lack of consideration}}). Unilateral rescission is typically a {{c17::court-ordered remedy}} where there is a valid defense, and is distinguished from {{c18::mutual rescission}}, where both parties agree to rescind. 4. At-will employment 4.1 An {{c19::at-will employment}} agreement may be {{c20::terminated by either party at any time}}. 4.2 A promise of {{c21::"permanent" employment}} is generally considered to create an {{c22::at-will employment relationship}} (not lifetime employment).

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Article 9 requires that {{c1::collateral}} be properly {{c2::classified}}, because the type of collateral affects how a security interest is created, perfected, and prioritized. At a high level, collateral falls into two broad groupings: 1. {{c3::Tangible goods}}: physical goods, which Article 9 divides into farming goods, consumer goods, inventory, and equipment. 2. {{c4::Intangible (and quasi‑tangible) property}}: rights to payment or other property interests, such as instruments, documents, chattel paper, accounts, deposit accounts, and general intangibles. Each subcategory has specific definitions and consequences for attachment, perfection, and priority, so correctly identifying the collateral type is a critical first step in any secured transactions analysis.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In federal civil litigation, courts use several types of {{c1::conferences}} to manage the case and promote efficient resolution. Party representatives must {{c2::meet and confer}} with each other and/or the court at various points, most commonly in connection with {{c3::discovery}}. Key case-management conferences include: 1. {{c4::Mandatory meet and confer}} (before the scheduling conference, to plan discovery and discuss claims/settlement); 2. {{c5::Scheduling conference}} (leading to a scheduling order that sets major case deadlines); 3. {{c6::Pretrial and final pretrial conferences}} (to move the case forward, encourage settlement, and finalize trial issues and evidence in a binding pretrial order).

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Presidential removal power}} 1.1 {{c2::High‑level executive officers}} 1.1.1 The {{c3::President}} may remove {{c4::high‑level executive officers}} as part of the executive power. 1.2 {{c5::Other executive appointees}} 1.2.1 {{c6::Congress}} may, by statute, {{c7::limit the President’s power to remove certain executive officials}}, for example by requiring {{c8::good cause}} for removal. 2. {{c9::Congressional removal power}} 2.1 {{c10::No general removal authority}} 2.1.1 Congress has {{c11::no general power to remove executive officers}} and may not {{c12::reserve removal power for itself}}. 2.2 {{c13::Impeachment as Congress’s removal mechanism}} 2.2.1 Congress may remove executive officers only through the {{c14::impeachment process}}, not by ordinary legislation or resolutions. 2.2.2 {{c15::Article III judges}} likewise cannot be removed by Congress except through {{c16::impeachment and conviction}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Documents extrinsic to the will (i.e., not physically part of the will) may be {{c1::incorporated by reference}} into the will in most states. 1. Requirements (a document will be incorporated by reference where): 1.1 {{c2::Intent to incorporate}}: the will manifests the testator's intent to incorporate the document. 1.2 {{c3::Authenticated document}}: the will sufficiently describes the document such that it can be authenticated. 1.2.1 The description must be such that the document can be {{c4::reasonably identified}}. 1.2.2 The document must {{c5::correspond to the will's description}}. 1.3 {{c6::In existence upon will execution}}: the document must be in existence at the time the will is executed. 2. {{c7::Tangible personal property exception}}: in most states, a will may incorporate by reference a document (i.e., statement or list) that disposes of the testator's tangible personal property. 2.1 The document can be prepared {{c8::before or after execution of the will}} and can be {{c9::changed before the testator's death}}. 2.2 Requirements: the document must be: 2.2.1 {{c10::Signed by the testator}}. 2.2.2 Describe the items and to whom they are devised with {{c11::reasonable certainty}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Seller {{c1::breaches}} and the {{c2::seller keeps the goods}} or the {{c3::buyer returns them}}: 1. Basic rule: • Buyer's damages = the {{c4::higher}} of: (a) {{c5::FMV of the goods at the time of breach − contract price}}; OR (b) {{c6::Buyer's costs of covering or replacing the goods − contract price}}. 2. Purpose: • To put the {{c7::buyer}} in as good a position as if the seller had {{c8::fully performed}}, rewarding {{c9::efficient cover}} and protecting {{c10::expectation}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 2. {{c1::Revoking acceptance}} ({{c2::UCC}} contracts): 2.1 General rule: Once the buyer has {{c3::accepted}} goods, she cannot later {{c4::reject}} them. 2.2 Exception – revocation of acceptance: 2.2.1 The buyer can revoke acceptance if she {{c5::discovers a defect}} after acceptance. 2.2.2 The buyer must revoke within a {{c6::reasonable time}} after discovering the defect. 2.3 Substantive requirements: 2.3.1 The defect must {{c7::substantially impair the goods' value}} to the buyer, and either: • The buyer accepted on the {{c8::reasonable belief that the defect would be cured}} and it has not been, or • The buyer was {{c9::excusably ignorant of the defect}} at acceptance or reasonably relied on the seller's {{c10::assurance that the goods conformed}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: Limitation on evidence of victim's character in {{c1::sexual assault}} cases: In sexual assault cases—both criminal and civil—special rules limit the {{c2::defendant's}} ability to present evidence of the victim's {{c3::sexual behavior or predisposition}}. 1. {{c4::Civil cases}} 1.1 {{c5::Reputation, opinion, and specific instances}} of the victim's sexual behavior or predisposition are admissible only if the {{c6::probative value substantially outweighs}} the danger of {{c7::unfair prejudice}}. 1.2 In the case of {{c8::reputation}} evidence, the {{c9::plaintiff}} must put her reputation in controversy in some way. 1.3 This is a {{c10::two-pronged}} standard and is different from the usual {{c11::Federal Rule of Evidence 403}} discretionary exclusion standard. 2. {{c12::Criminal cases}} 2.1 Reputation and opinion evidence of the victim's sexual behavior or predisposition are {{c13::inadmissible}}. 2.2 Evidence offered to prove the victim's sexual behavior or sexual disposition is generally inadmissible. 3. {{c14::Exceptions in criminal cases}} 3.1 Specific instances of the victim's sexual behavior are admissible to show that a {{c15::third party}} is the source of physical injury or DNA evidence. 3.2 Specific instances of prior {{c16::consensual sexual intercourse}} between the victim and the defendant are admissible to show {{c17::consent}}. 4. {{c18::Procedure}} 4.1 A party must {{c19::disclose the intent}} to offer such evidence. 4.2 The party must {{c20::describe its purpose and relevance}}. 4.3 The party must {{c21::notify the victim}} and file the motion at least {{c22::14 days before trial}}, unless the court, for good cause, allows a later filing.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Judicial lien creditors}} 1.1 Judicial lien creditors ({{c2::JLCs}}) are those who acquire a lien on collateral through {{c3::judicial attachment, levy, or similar judicial process}}. 2. {{c4::Perfected secured party vs. JLC}} 2.1 A {{c5::prior perfected security interest}} prevails over a JLC. 2.2 A JLC prevails only if the creditor becomes a JLC {{c6::before a secured party files or perfects}}. 2.3 {{c7::Future advances}}: If a secured party makes future advances to the debtor, the secured party has priority for those future advances if: 2.3.1 The future advance was made {{c8::before, or within 45 days after,}} the lien arose; or 2.3.2 The future advance was made {{c9::without knowledge of the lien}}. 3. {{c10::Unperfected secured party vs. JLC}} 3.1 A {{c11::JLC prevails}} over an {{c12::unperfected secured party}}. 3.2 {{c13::PMSI grace period exception}}: A secured party who {{c14::attaches a PMSI in collateral before}} the JLC acquires an interest in the collateral has priority if the secured party {{c15::files within 20 days after}} the debtor receives the collateral.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Appeals involve both {{c1::standards of review}} and {{c2::limits on appellate jurisdiction}}. 1. Standards of review: appellate courts review {{c3::questions of law de novo}}, are highly deferential to {{c4::findings of fact}}, and review {{c5::discretionary rulings}} only for {{c6::abuse of discretion}}. 2. {{c7::Final Judgment Rule}}: an appeal generally lies only from a {{c8::final judgment}} that resolves the {{c9::entire case on the merits}}; otherwise, the appellate court lacks jurisdiction. 3. Exceptions/interlocutory appeals: certain orders—such as {{c10::injunctions}}, {{c11::class certification decisions}}, some {{c12::controlling legal questions certified for appeal}}, and {{c13::separate final judgments}} as to some claims or parties—are immediately appealable despite the lack of a final judgment. 4. Timing: a {{c14::notice of appeal}} must be filed in the trial court within {{c15::30 days}} after entry of the appealable judgment or order.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A {{c1::prior restraint}} is a {{c2::court order or other governmental ban on speech or publication before it occurs}}. Prior restraints are {{c3::presumptively invalid}} and are subject to {{c4::strict scrutiny}}, making them very difficult to uphold. They often arise as {{c5::court orders or injunctions preventing speech or publication}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Land sale contracts (subject to the {{c1::Statute of Frauds}}) must be: 1.1 {{c2::In writing}}. 1.2 {{c3::Signed}} by the party to be bound. 1.3 Sufficiently definite to articulate {{c4::essential terms}} (for example, identify grantor and grantee, intent to convey, consideration to be paid, and a description of the land). 2. Exception: {{c5::Partial performance}}. 2.1 A land sale contract outside the Statute of Frauds is enforceable against the seller if the buyer does any {{c6::two}} of the following: 2.1.1 Pays all or part of the {{c7::purchase price}}. 2.1.2 Takes {{c8::possession}}. 2.1.3 Makes {{c9::substantial improvements}}. 3. Land sale process: 3.1 {{c10::Contract}}: Agreement to buy and sell land. 3.2 {{c11::Escrow period}}: Transfer of funds through escrow. 3.3 {{c12::Closing}}: Completion of escrow and delivery of the deed. 3.4 {{c13::Conveyance}}: Successful deed transfer, upon which property is conveyed to the new owner.

subject: Trusts And Estates
