cloze: A will and/or its provisions can be revoked by {{c1::operation of law}} upon the happening of certain events, usually involving changes in {{c2::marital status}} or the {{c3::birth or adoption of children}}. 1. {{c4::Marriage}} following execution of a will (omitted spouse): 1.1 In most states: marriage after execution has {{c5::no effect}} on the existing will (i.e., the new spouse remains omitted). 1.2 Under the {{c6::UPC}}: where a person marries after executing a will and the spouse survives the testator, the omitted spouse will take a share of the decedent's estate equivalent to what their {{c7::intestate share}} would be, unless: 1.2.1 The will {{c8::provides for the omitted spouse}}. 1.2.2 The will was made {{c9::in contemplation of marriage}}. 1.2.3 The will otherwise makes clear that the {{c10::omission was intentional}}. 2. {{c11::Divorce}} following execution of a will: 2.1 Revokes all bequests made in favor of the former spouse, unless the will {{c12::expressly provides otherwise}}. 2.2 The {{c13::remainder of the will remains valid}}. 2.3 Effect: the will is treated as if the former spouse {{c14::predeceased}} the testator. 3. {{c15::Pretermitted children}}: arises where the testator's will does not provide for children born or adopted after the will was executed. Most states give the pretermitted child a share of the testator's estate equal to what they would have received through {{c16::intestate succession}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. {{c1::Undue influence}} (a will is invalid if executed while the testator was subject to undue influence that effectively overrode the testator's free will) 1.1. Requirements (the will contestant has the burden of proof and must show): 1.1.1. {{c2::Influence was exerted}} on the testator. 1.1.2. The testator's {{c3::mind and free will were overpowered}}. 1.1.3. The testator's will would not have been executed {{c4::absent the undue influence}}. 1.2. Presumption (a presumption of undue influence arises if): 1.2.1. A {{c5::confidential relationship}} (e.g., attorney–client) existed between the testator and the beneficiary who exerted influence. 1.2.2. The beneficiary {{c6::participated to a significant degree in executing, drafting, or procuring}} the testator's will. 1.2.3. Once established, the {{c7::burden shifts to the proponent of the will}} (usually the beneficiary) to prove the will was not induced by undue influence. 2. {{c8::Fraud}} (where a will or one or more of its provisions are the result of fraud, the will or the provision is invalid) 2.1. Requirements (it must be shown that the testator has been intentionally deceived as to): 2.1.1. The {{c9::character or content of the will or its provisions}}; and/or 2.1.2. {{c10::Facts extrinsic to the will}} that would induce the will or a particular provision or disposition in the will; and 2.1.3. The testator {{c11::acted in reliance on the misrepresentation}} (i.e., he would not have made the gift or executed the will if he knew the facts).

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Constitutional role in federal court}} 1.1 The {{c2::Fifth Amendment}} requires a {{c3::grand jury indictment}} for most {{c4::federal felony}} prosecutions. 1.2 The grand jury’s function is to determine whether there is sufficient {{c5::probable cause}} to bring charges against a suspect. 2. {{c6::Indictment process}} 2.1 The {{c7::prosecutor}} presents evidence (witness testimony and other materials) to the grand jury. 2.2 The grand jury {{c8::votes}} on whether to issue an indictment. 2.3 If the grand jury {{c9::finds probable cause}}, it issues an {{c10::indictment}} authorizing the government to proceed with prosecution. 3. {{c11::Scope}} 3.1 The grand jury is a {{c12::charging body, not a trial body}}: it does not determine {{c13::guilt beyond a reasonable doubt}}, only whether there is {{c14::probable cause}} to charge.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. Sellers in land sale contracts are subject to an implied promise to {{c1::disclose}} and make no {{c2::material false statements}}. 2. The seller must not {{c3::materially misrepresent facts}} or make false statements concerning the property. 3. The seller has a duty to disclose {{c4::known, latent material defects}}—defects that are {{c5::not readily observable or discoverable on reasonable inspection}}. 4. This disclosure duty may be disclaimed only if the disclaimer is {{c6::clear and specific}}. 5. For {{c7::new property}}, the seller–builder is subject to an {{c8::implied warranty of quality in construction}}, covering {{c9::latent construction defects}} that render the property {{c10::unfit for its intended use}} or materially impair its value.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. Appropriation 1.1 Definition: Use of P's {{c1::name or likeness}} for {{c2::commercial purposes}} (for example, promotion or advertisement) without {{c3::P's consent}}. 1.2 {{c4::Newsworthiness exception}}: No liability for use of P's name or likeness for the purpose of {{c5::reporting news}}. 2. False light 2.1 Definition: {{c6::Widespread publication}} of a {{c7::falsehood or material misrepresentation}} about P that would be {{c8::highly offensive to a reasonable person}}. 2.2 Includes {{c9::mischaracterization of P's views or conduct}}. 2.3 Matters of public concern: D must have {{c10::actual malice or reckless disregard for the truth}} of the matter publicized. 2.4 Note: This mirrors the {{c11::constitutional considerations for defamation}}. 2.5 {{c12::No newsworthiness exception}} for false light. 3. Defenses to false light 3.1 {{c13::Consent}}: A valid defense, although D may be liable if his actions {{c14::exceed the consent given}}. {{c15::Mistake as to whether consent was given}} is not a valid defense. 3.2 {{c16::Privilege}}: May be available as a defense to false light if D has an {{c17::absolute or qualified privilege}} to publication. 3.3 {{c18::Truth is not a valid defense}} to invasion of privacy claims, including false light.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. Types of custody: 1.1 {{c1::Legal custody}}: the right to make major decisions affecting the child's life. 1.2 {{c2::Physical custody}}: possession and control of the child. 1.3 {{c3::Joint custody}}: can be either or both of the following: 1.3.1 Parents share decision-making, but the child lives with one parent. 1.3.2 The child divides time between each parent's home. 2. Custody factors: In determining custody, courts focus on the child's {{c4::best interests}}, looking at multiple factors, including: 2.1 {{c5::Parents' wishes}}. 2.2 {{c6::Child's wishes}}, given more weight if the child is older, and significantly less weight for young children (e.g., under age eight). 2.3 {{c7::Ability and willingness of each parent to provide for the child's needs}}. 2.4 {{c8::Interaction and interrelationship}} of the child with parents, siblings, and others who affect the child's best interests. 2.5 Child's {{c9::adjustment to home, school, and community}}. 3. Visitation: 3.1 When one parent is granted sole physical custody, the other parent is generally entitled to {{c10::reasonable visitation}}. 3.2 Exception: Visitation rights may be denied if the court determines visitation would {{c11::endanger the child's wellbeing}}. 3.3 Non-parents: Non-parents may be given visitation rights if: 3.3.1 The non-parent has a {{c12::substantial relationship}} with the child. 3.3.2 Non-parent visitation is in the child's {{c13::best interests}}. 3.3.3 The fact finder gives {{c14::special consideration to the wishes of fit parents}} regarding visitation rights.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: {{c1::Felony murder}} is a homicide that occurs during the attempt or commission of certain qualifying felonies. The only intent required is the {{c2::intent to commit the underlying felony}}. Qualifying felonies are typically {{c3::inherently dangerous or specifically enumerated by statute}}, such as {{c4::burglary, arson, rape, robbery, and kidnapping}}. Felony-murder liability is limited: the defendant must be {{c5::guilty of an independent underlying felony (merger doctrine)}}, {{c6::defenses to the felony apply to felony murder}}, the death must be a {{c7::foreseeable result that occurs before the defendant reaches a place of temporary safety}}, and {{c8::most jurisdictions do not impose liability for a co-felon killed by police or the victim}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: {{c1::Doctrine of Worthier Title}} 1. {{c2::When it arises}} 1.1 Applies when the {{c3::grantor}} creates a {{c4::life estate in another}} but purports to create a {{c5::future interest in the grantor’s own heirs}}. 1.2 Classic form: "{{c6::to A for life, then to O’s heirs}}." 2. {{c7::Common-law effect}} 2.1 A purported {{c8::remainder or executory interest}} in the grantor’s heirs is {{c9::void}}. 2.2 The law presumes that the {{c10::grantor retained a reversion}} instead. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A for life, then to O’s heirs"; the {{c11::contingent remainder in O’s heirs}} is void. 2.4 Result: A has a {{c12::life estate}} and O has a {{c13::reversion}}. 3. {{c14::Modern rule}} 3.1 Often treated as a {{c15::rule of construction}} rather than a strict invalidating rule. 3.2 Courts may presume a {{c16::reversion in O}}, but that presumption can be {{c17::rebutted by clear contrary intent}} in the instrument. 3.3 If the grantor clearly intends a future interest in "O’s heirs," modern courts may {{c18::honor the future interest}} rather than collapsing it into a reversion.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Perfection by {{c1::possession}}: 1. General rule: 1.1 A secured party may perfect a security interest by taking {{c2::possession}} of many types of collateral. 2. Collateral that can be perfected by possession (examples): 2.1 {{c3::Goods}} (e.g., a pawnshop situation). 2.2 {{c4::Negotiable documents}}. 2.3 {{c5::Instruments}}. 3. Collateral that cannot be perfected by possession: 3.1 Intangible or quasi-intangible collateral generally cannot be perfected this way, including: 3.1.1 {{c6::Accounts}}. 3.1.2 {{c7::Certificate-of-title goods}} (typically perfected by notation on title). 3.1.3 {{c8::Electronic chattel paper}}. 3.1.4 {{c9::General intangibles}}. 4. Effect: 4.1 When allowed, maintaining {{c10::possession}} of the collateral perfects the security interest as long as possession continues.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. {{c1::Present recollection refreshed}} (use of documents to refresh W's memory during testimony). 1.1 {{c2::Anything}} can be used to refresh W's memory. 1.2 W cannot {{c3::read aloud from a document}} while testifying, but may look at it briefly, then continue testimony unassisted. 1.3 The {{c4::opposing party}} may inspect and offer into evidence anything used to refresh W's memory. 1.4 The document used to refresh is {{c5::not read into evidence}} (distinguish from {{c6::recorded recollection}}). 2. {{c6::Recorded recollection}} (contents of a record or document W previously made or adopted are read into evidence). 2.1 Requirements for recorded recollection: 2.1.1 W once had {{c7::personal knowledge}} of the record's subject matter. 2.1.2 W's {{c8::memory is now insufficient}} to testify fully and accurately as to the record's contents (i.e., present recollection refreshed was ineffective). 2.1.3 The record was {{c9::made or adopted}} by W when the matter was {{c10::fresh in W's memory}}. 2.1.4 The record {{c11::accurately reflects W's knowledge}}. 2.2 {{c6::Recorded recollection}} is a {{c12::hearsay exception}}; as such, its contents may be {{c13::read into evidence}} (distinguish from {{c1::present recollection refreshed}}).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Mistake of law}} 1.1 Mistake of law is {{c2::almost never a defense}}. 1.2 Lacking awareness or knowledge that an act constitutes a crime, even if reasonable, is {{c3::not a defense}} to that crime. 1.3 Exceptions (rare): a mistake of law can be a defense where either 1.3.1 The defendant {{c4::reasonably relied on an invalid statute or official interpretation}}; or 1.3.2 The mistake or ignorance {{c5::negates an element of a crime requiring knowledge of the law}}. 2. {{c6::Mistake of fact}} 2.1 Mistake of fact is available as a defense only if it {{c7::negates a requisite intent element (mens rea)}} for the crime. Note: mistake includes ignorance. 3. Requisite mens rea element and availability of mistake of fact defense 3.1 {{c8::Specific intent}}: {{c9::any mistake of fact}} is a defense. 3.2 {{c10::Malice and general intent}}: only a {{c11::reasonable}} mistake of fact is a defense. 3.3 {{c12::Strict liability}} (i.e., no intent): {{c13::mistake of fact is never a defense}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Criminal liability for result crimes requires both {{c1::concurrence}} and {{c2::causation}}. 1. {{c3::Concurrence}}: The defendant's criminal {{c4::act}} and required {{c5::mens rea}} must occur at the same time. 2. {{c6::Causation}}: The defendant’s conduct must be both a {{c7::cause-in-fact}} and a {{c8::proximate cause}} of the result, with liability usually turning on whether any {{c9::intervening act}} is {{c10::foreseeable}} or {{c11::superseding}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Fourth Amendment Standing – Reasonable Expectation of Privacy 1. {{c1::Standing requirement}} 1.1 A defendant may challenge a search or seizure under the Fourth Amendment only if {{c2::they have standing}}. 1.2 Standing means the {{c3::defendant’s own}} Fourth Amendment rights were violated. 2. {{c4::Reasonable Expectation of Privacy (REP)}} 2.1 The core test for standing is whether the defendant had a {{c5::reasonable expectation of privacy}} in the place searched or item seized. 2.2 The expectation must be both: (a) {{c6::Subjectively}} held by the defendant; and (b) {{c7::Objectively reasonable}}—one society is prepared to recognize. 3. {{c8::Application}} 3.1 If the defendant lacks a reasonable expectation of privacy in the thing or place searched, they {{c9::cannot invoke the Fourth Amendment}}, even if the search was unreasonable as to someone else. 3.2 The search is assessed only for {{c10::persons whose own REP was infringed}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Joint and several liability}}: 1.1. Arises if the acts of {{c2::two or more defendants combine to produce a single, indivisible injury}}. 1.2. Each defendant is jointly and severally liable for {{c3::the entire harm}} if his actions were {{c4::a factor in bringing about the plaintiff's injury}}. 1.3. Note: Most states have replaced traditional joint and several liability with {{c5::apportionment of damages by percentages of fault}}. 1.4. Defendants {{c6::acting in concert}}: If two or more defendants act in concert and injure the plaintiff, each is jointly and severally liable for the plaintiff's entire injury; this applies even if the injury and defendants' culpability are {{c7::divisible}}. 1.5. {{c8::Satisfaction}}: If the plaintiff recovers fully from one defendant, she may not recover more from another jointly liable defendant. 2. {{c9::Contribution}}: 2.1. A defendant who pays more than her share of damages under joint and several liability can assert a claim against {{c10::jointly liable parties for the excess paid}}. 2.2. Contribution is {{c11::not applicable to intentional tort liability}}. 2.3. Contribution is usually imposed in proportion to {{c12::relative fault}}. 3. {{c13::Indemnity}}: 3.1. Involves shifting {{c14::the entire loss}} between or among defendants. 3.2. Available by {{c15::contract}}, in {{c16::vicarious liability}} situations, or under {{c17::strict products liability}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Prima facie case for an {{c1::intentional tort}} requires: 1. {{c2::Act by D}} 1.1 There must be some {{c3::volitional movement}} by D. 2. {{c4::Intent}} 2.1 {{c5::Specific intent}}: D intends to bring about a {{c6::specific harmful or offensive result}}. 2.2 {{c7::General intent}}: D knows with {{c8::substantial certainty}} that the {{c9::tortious result}} will occur from D's act. 3. {{c10::Causation}} 3.1 D's conduct must be a {{c11::substantial factor}} in bringing about the resulting harm. 4. {{c12::Damages}} 4.1 {{c13::Compensatory (monetary) damages}} are available for intentional torts. 4.2 {{c14::Punitive damages}} are available when the intentional tort is committed with {{c15::malice}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 {{c2::False imprisonment}} is an {{c3::intentional act}} by D resulting in P's {{c4::restraint or confinement}} to a {{c5::bounded area}}. 2. {{c6::Elements}} 2.1 {{c7::Act (or omission)}} resulting in P's restraint or confinement. 2.1.1 Restraint or confinement does not have to be {{c8::physical}}. 2.1.2 For example: can be {{c9::threats of force}} or {{c10::invalid use of legal authority}}. 2.1.3 {{c11::Duration is not important}}; brief confinement will suffice. 2.2 P is confined to a {{c12::bounded area}}. 2.2.1 P must be {{c13::aware of or harmed by}} the confinement. 2.2.2 P's {{c14::freedom of movement}} must be limited. 2.2.3 P must not be aware of any {{c15::reasonable means of escape}}. 2.2.4 If a reasonable person could get out (e.g., by opening an {{c16::unlocked door}}), there is no false imprisonment. 2.3 {{c17::Causation}}. 3. {{c18::Shopkeeper's privilege}} 3.1 A store may detain a suspected thief if: 3.1.1 The store has {{c19::reasonable cause}} to believe a theft occurred. 3.1.2 The store detains the suspect in a {{c20::reasonable manner}} (only {{c21::nondeadly force}} is permitted) for purposes of {{c22::investigation}}. 3.1.3 The detention is {{c23::reasonable in length and scope}}. 3.2 The shopkeeper may be held liable for any harm caused by acts {{c24::exceeding the privilege}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Implied warranty of {{c1::fitness for a particular purpose}} in products liability: 1. Arises when: 1.1 The {{c2::seller knows or has reason to know the buyer's particular purpose}} for purchasing the goods, and 1.2 The {{c3::buyer relies on the seller's skill or judgment}} to select suitable goods. 2. Content: The seller impliedly warrants that the goods are {{c4::fit for that particular purpose}}. 3. Example: A {{c5::shoe store salesperson}} selecting shoes for a buyer who needs them for {{c6::running on trails}}. 4. Breach: If the goods are not fit for the particular purpose in these circumstances, the implied warranty of fitness is {{c7::breached}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. {{c1::Revocability of assignments}}: 1.1 Assignments made {{c2::for consideration}} are {{c3::irrevocable}}. 1.2 {{c4::Gratuitous assignments}} are generally {{c5::revocable}}. 1.3 Exception: a gratuitous assignment becomes irrevocable if either: 1.3.1 The {{c6::obligor has already performed}}. 1.3.2 The assignee has received a {{c7::written claim or tangible object signifying the right to collect}} (e.g., stock certificate). 1.3.3 The assignee has {{c8::detrimentally relied}} on the assignment ({{c9::estoppel}}). 2. {{c10::Assignee's right to sue}}: 2.1 Against {{c11::obligor}}: The assignee can sue the obligor for {{c12::non-performance}}, and the obligor can raise any {{c13::defense to the contract that could have been raised against the assignor}}. 2.2 Against {{c14::assignor}}: The assignee can sue the assignor for breach of any of the assignor's {{c15::implied warranties}}, including: 2.2.1 There was {{c16::no prior assignment of the same right}}. 2.2.2 The right to assign was {{c17::not subject to defenses}}. 2.2.3 The assignor will {{c18::not interfere with the assigned right}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Classic RAP hypotheticals and exception 1. {{c1::Age contingency beyond 21}} for an {{c2::open class}} 1.1 A conveyance to an open class that is contingent on members reaching an {{c3::age over 21}} is a classic RAP problem. 1.2 Such a conveyance is {{c4::void under RAP}} if there is any possibility that some class member’s interest might vest more than {{c5::21 years after a life in being}} at the time of creation. 2. {{c6::Fertile octogenarian}} 2.1 RAP assumes that {{c7::any woman is capable of giving birth regardless of age or physical condition}}. 2.2 This presumption keeps certain {{c8::classes open indefinitely}} for RAP analysis. 2.3 Example: Grantor conveys "to A for life, then to A's children who reach 30." A is 80 and has a 40-year-old son. 2.3.1 This violates RAP because A’s son could die, A could have a daughter at 81, then die when she is 82. The daughter’s interest would not vest until she reaches {{c9::30}}, which is more than {{c10::21 years after A’s death}}. 3. {{c11::Charity-to-charity exception}} 3.1 RAP {{c12::does not apply}} to conveyances from {{c13::one charity to another charity}}. 3.2 Future interests entirely between {{c14::charitable organizations}} are therefore {{c15::exempt from RAP}}, even if they might otherwise vest remotely.

subject: Contracts
cloze: A person who {{c1::lacked capacity to contract}} (such as an infant, mentally incompetent person, or qualifying intoxicated person) generally has a {{c2::right to disaffirm}} the contract. Exercising this right renders the contract {{c3::voidable}} at the option of the incapacitated party, allowing them to {{c4::avoid contractual obligations}}. Disaffirmance must generally occur during the period of incapacity or within a {{c5::reasonable time after}} capacity is gained or regained.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: {{c1::Impleader}} allows a {{c2::defending party}} to join a non-party who may be liable to the defending party for all or part of the claim brought by the plaintiff against the original defendant. It allows the defendant to assert claims for {{c3::indemnity, contribution, or similar reimbursement}} against another party for the claim the defendant is defending. 1. Effect and terminology: 1.1 The original defendant becomes a {{c4::third-party plaintiff}}. 1.2 The newly joined party is the {{c5::third-party defendant}}. 2. Requirements and procedure: 2.1 A defending party may implead a third-party defendant by filing a {{c6::third-party complaint}} within {{c7::14 days}} after serving its answer. 2.2 After 14 days, the defending party must obtain the {{c8::court's permission}} to implead. 2.3 The impleader claim must be {{c9::derivative}}: the third-party plaintiff cannot claim that the third-party defendant is solely liable to the plaintiff; impleader usually falls away if the original plaintiff's claim against the defendant fails. 2.4 {{c10::Jurisdiction}}: the court must have personal jurisdiction over the impleaded party and subject-matter jurisdiction over the claims; the court will generally have {{c11::supplemental jurisdiction}} over indemnity or contribution claims. 3. Additional claims involving the third-party defendant: 3.1 Once the third-party defendant is joined, the third-party defendant may assert its own claims against other parties as long as the court has {{c12::subject-matter jurisdiction}} over each claim. 3.2 The original plaintiff may assert claims against the third-party defendant arising from the {{c13::same transaction or occurrence}} as the plaintiff's original claims against the third-party plaintiff/defendant.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 A tenant has an implied right to {{c1::quiet use and enjoyment of the premises}}, without interference from the landlord. 1.2 Breach may occur by {{c2::actual}} or {{c3::constructive}} eviction. 1.3 Breach may occur by the landlord's {{c4::wrongful conduct}} causing loss of use and enjoyment by the tenant. 2. Actual eviction 2.1 Actual eviction occurs when the landlord {{c5::wrongfully evicts or excludes}} the tenant from the property. 3. Constructive eviction 3.1 Constructive eviction occurs when the landlord's {{c6::actions or inactions}} render the property {{c7::uninhabitable or unusable}}. 3.2 Elements of constructive eviction: 3.2.1 {{c8::Breach of duty}}: The landlord breached a duty to the tenant. 3.2.2 {{c9::Substantial interference}}: Major and/or chronic problems (for example, a leaky roof) are caused by the landlord's wrongful conduct. 3.2.3 {{c10::Notice and opportunity to cure}}: The tenant must inform the landlord of the problem and give a reasonable opportunity to repair; the landlord must fail to act meaningfully. 3.2.4 {{c11::Vacate}}: The tenant must vacate the premises within a reasonable period after the landlord fails to repair.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) – Overview 1. Core Rule 1.1 No property interest is valid unless it must {{c1::vest, if at all, no later than 21 years after the death of a life in being}} at the time the interest was created. 1.2 A future interest is {{c2::void}} if there is any {{c3::possibility, no matter how remote}} that it will vest more than {{c4::21 years after the death of the measuring life}}. 1.3 A {{c5::measuring life}} is a {{c6::life in being at creation}} whose life events determine whether the interest vests within the RAP period. 2. Application and Analysis 2.1 RAP applies to certain future interests, including {{c7::contingent remainders}}, {{c8::gifts to open classes}}, and {{c9::executory interests}} (and sometimes {{c10::options and rights of first refusal}}). 2.2 To analyze a conveyance, {{c11::identify the future interests}}, {{c12::apply RAP only to covered interests using a measuring life}}, and if an interest violates RAP, {{c13::strike only the offending interest and enforce what remains}}. 2.3 On the bar exam, unless told otherwise, apply the {{c14::common law RAP}} rather than modern reforms (such as a {{c15::90-year wait-and-see period}}).

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Under common law: 1. {{c1::Specific intent}} 1.1 The defendant must have a {{c2::specific intent or objective to commit the given crime}}. 1.2 Specific intent must always be {{c3::affirmatively proven}}; it is {{c4::never merely inferred from the act alone}}. 1.3 {{c5::Mistake of fact}} and {{c6::voluntary intoxication}} are recognized defenses to specific intent crimes. 2. {{c7::General intent}} 2.1 The defendant must be {{c8::aware of his actions and any attendant circumstances}}; a general intent to do the proscribed act is sufficient. 2.2 General intent may be {{c9::inferred from the defendant’s conduct and the surrounding circumstances}}. 2.3 {{c10::Most crimes are general intent crimes}} at common law. The classification as {{c11::specific vs. general intent}} controls what the prosecution must prove and which {{c12::defenses (especially mistake of fact and voluntary intoxication)}} are available.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Conspiracy is an {{c1::agreement}} between {{c2::two or more people}} to commit a crime or achieve an {{c3::unlawful objective}}. Required elements: • An {{c4::agreement}} between two or more people, which may be {{c5::tacit}} and does not require that all conspirators {{c6::know of each other's existence}}. • {{c7::Intent to enter into the agreement}}. • {{c8::Intent to commit the target crime}} or pursue the {{c9::unlawful objective}}. • In many jurisdictions, an {{c10::overt act}} in furtherance of the conspiracy is required, but an overt act is {{c11::not required at common law}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: There are three main types of product defects in products liability: 1. {{c1::Manufacturing defect}} – a particular product departs from its intended design so that it is more dangerous than other units, judged under a {{c2::consumer-expectation}} standard. 2. {{c3::Design defect}} – the product's design itself creates an {{c4::unreasonable risk of danger}}, often evaluated by whether there was a {{c5::feasible, safer alternative design}}. 3. {{c6::Inadequate warning}} (warning/instruction defect) – the manufacturer fails to give adequate warnings or instructions about {{c7::non-obvious risks}}, including {{c8::foreseeable misuse}} and special rules for {{c9::unavoidably unsafe products}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule: An existing {{c1::statute}} may establish a {{c2::standard of care}}, in which case the statutory standard will {{c3::replace the general common law standard of reasonable care}}. 2. Requirements: The statutory standard of care will apply if the statute satisfies three criteria: 2.1 Plaintiff must prove that the {{c4::harm suffered is the type the statute was meant to prevent}}. 2.2 Plaintiff is in the {{c5::class of victims the statute was meant to protect}}. 2.3 The statute {{c6::imposes a specific standard of conduct}}—says what to do or not to do. 3. Statutory standard of care does not apply if: 3.1 {{c7::Compliance is more dangerous than noncompliance}}; or 3.2 {{c8::Compliance is impossible}} under the circumstances. 4. {{c9::Negligence per se}}: 4.1 Violation of the statute means plaintiff must only prove {{c10::causation and damages}}, not {{c11::breach of duty}}. 4.2 Under the {{c12::majority rule}}, violation of the statute establishes a {{c13::conclusive presumption of duty and breach of duty}}. 4.3 {{c14::Compliance}} does not automatically clear defendant of liability.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: 1. Partner’s economic ({{c1::transferable}}) interest • Each partner has a transferable interest consisting of her share of partnership {{c2::profits and losses}} and her right to receive {{c3::distributions}}. 2. Default share of profits and losses • Each partner’s share of {{c4::profits}} is {{c5::equal}} absent an alternative agreement. • Each partner must contribute to partnership {{c6::losses}} in proportion to her {{c7::share of profits}} (so by default, losses are shared equally). 3. Default management rights • Absent an alternative agreement, all partners have {{c8::equal rights in the management}} of the partnership business. • Management rights are {{c9::distinct from the transferable economic interest}} and generally {{c10::cannot be transferred}} without consent of the other partners.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Under the {{c1::PMSI in consumer goods}} "{{c2::garage sale}}" rule, a second consumer buyer of consumer goods takes free of the PMSI if the buyer: 1. Buys {{c3::without knowledge of the security interest}}; 2. Buys {{c4::for value}}; and 3. Buys {{c5::before a financing statement covering the goods has been filed}}. When these elements are met, the second consumer buyer {{c6::takes free of}} the PMSI in the consumer goods.

subject: Real Property
cloze: A {{c1::sublease}} is a transfer of {{c2::less than the tenant’s entire leasehold interest}} from the sublessor (original tenant) to the sublessee. Privity: • The {{c3::sublessor remains in privity of estate and privity of contract}} with the landlord; the landlord–tenant relationship is unchanged. • There is typically {{c4::no direct privity}} between the landlord and sublessee. Rent and liability: • The {{c5::sublessee pays rent to the sublessor}}, not the landlord. • The sublessee is {{c6::not directly liable to the landlord for rent}} and {{c7::not bound by lease covenants unless expressly assumed}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Symbolic speech refers to {{c1::expressive or communicative conduct}}, meaning {{c2::conduct intended to convey a message}}. 1. Test for regulating symbolic speech 1.1 The government can regulate symbolic speech if: 1.1.1 The regulation furthers an {{c3::important governmental interest}}; 1.1.2 That governmental interest is {{c4::unrelated to the suppression of the message}} (if the restriction is aimed at speech more than conduct, it is likely unconstitutional); and 1.1.3 The impact on speech is {{c5::no greater than necessary}} to further the important governmental interest. 2. Examples 2.1 {{c6::Burning the U.S. flag}} is protected symbolic speech. 2.2 {{c7::Burning a cross}} is protected symbolic speech unless it is {{c8::intended to threaten}} (e.g., a true threat against a particular person or group). 2.3 {{c9::Public nudity}} is generally not protected as symbolic speech.

subject: Real Property
cloze: If a tenant {{c1::breaches}} and {{c2::abandons}} the premises, the landlord’s options are often summarized as {{c3::SIR}}: 1. {{c4::Surrender}} – the landlord may {{c5::treat abandonment as an offer of surrender}} and, by accepting it, {{c6::terminate the lease and release the tenant from further liability}}. 2. {{c7::Ignore (minority rule)}} – under the {{c8::minority rule}}, the landlord may {{c9::ignore the abandonment and not re-let}}, holding the tenant {{c10::liable for unpaid rent}} as it accrues. 3. {{c11::Re-let (majority rule)}} – under the {{c12::majority rule}}, the landlord must {{c13::make reasonable efforts to re-let}} and may then {{c14::recover losses}} from the breaching tenant, typically the {{c15::difference between contract rent and new rent plus re-letting costs}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Witnesses to a will must be {{c1::competent}}, and in most states there are limitations on witnesses who stand to {{c2::benefit from the will}}. 1. {{c3::Competency}} 1.1 The witness must have sufficient {{c4::maturity and mental capacity}} to understand and appreciate the nature of what they witness and attest to. 1.2 The witness must be capable of sufficiently {{c5::testifying in court}} if required. 2. {{c6::Interested witnesses}} (a witness who stands to benefit under the will) 2.1 {{c7::Common law}}: the entire will could not be {{c8::probated}} if there was an interested witness (this rule has been mostly abolished). 2.2 {{c9::Majority rule}}: the will is valid, but the {{c10::gift to the witness-beneficiary is void}}. 2.3 Exceptions (under the majority approach, an interested witness can still be a beneficiary if either): 2.3.1 There were at least {{c11::two other disinterested witnesses}} (i.e., three total witnesses, two of whom were disinterested); or 2.3.2 The interested witness would take if there were {{c12::no will}} (i.e., the interested witness would have taken as an heir through {{c13::intestate succession}}). In that case, the witness may take the lesser of the {{c14::intestate share}} or the {{c15::bequest}}. 3. {{c16::UPC rule}} 3.1 Under the UPC, the presence of an interested witness does not invalidate the will or any part of it, and the gift to the interested witness is {{c17::not automatically void}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Diminished capacity as a defense based on mental defect: 1. It is based on a mental defect {{c1::short of legal insanity}} and is a {{c2::mental state defense}}. 2. It is available if the defendant can show that his mental defect {{c3::prevented him from forming the mental state required}} for the crime, typically {{c4::negating an element}} of the offense. 3. The defense is usually limited to {{c5::specific intent crimes}}, and jurisdictions vary on whether and how they recognize it.

subject: Con Law
cloze: In addition to privacy rights, the Constitution protects other key fundamental rights, including the {{c1::right to vote}} and the {{c2::right to travel}}, which are usually analyzed under the {{c3::Equal Protection Clause}}. 1. {{c1::Right to vote}} - A {{c4::fundamental right}} in elections for federal, state, and local offices. - Restrictions or dilution of voting power are generally reviewed under {{c3::equal protection}}. - Laws that significantly burden voting (e.g., {{c5::poll taxes}} or severe residency/registration requirements) are subject to {{c6::strict scrutiny}}. - The {{c7::“one person, one vote”}} principle requires legislative districts of roughly equal population. 2. {{c2::Right to travel}} - A {{c4::fundamental right}} to move between states and become a resident of another state. - Often protected through {{c3::equal protection}}, especially when {{c8::new residents}} are treated less favorably than {{c9::long-term residents}}. - Laws that penalize travel—such as harsh {{c10::durational residency requirements}} for essential benefits—are subject to {{c6::strict or close scrutiny}}, while reasonable, non-punitive residency requirements (e.g., for voting or in-state tuition) may be upheld.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the old framework, while abortion was a protected right, the government had no duty to {{c1::subsidize abortions}} and no duty to {{c2::provide abortions in public hospitals}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Infants are legally obligated to pay for {{c1::necessities}} even though they generally lack capacity to contract. Necessities typically include essentials such as {{c2::food}}, {{c3::clothing}}, and {{c4::medical care}}. This liability is based on {{c5::quasi-contract (restitution)}}, not on enforcing the contract itself, so the infant cannot be sued for {{c6::breach of contract}}. Instead, the provider may recover the {{c7::reasonable value}} of the necessities supplied, even if the infant {{c8::disaffirms}} the underlying contract.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Under common law, {{c1::malice}} is a mental state in which the defendant {{c2::acts with reckless disregard of, or undertakes an obvious risk from which, a harmful result is expected}}. Malice applies to the crimes of {{c3::arson}} and {{c4::common law murder}}. The prosecution must show that the defendant either {{c5::intended the harmful result}} or at least {{c6::consciously disregarded an obvious and serious risk}} of that result.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Deadly self-defense is justified when: 1. {{c1::No fault}}: The defendant is not at fault and is not the {{c2::initial aggressor}}. 2. {{c3::Confronted with unlawful force}}: The attacker is using or attempting to use unlawful force. 3. {{c4::Reasonable belief}} of {{c5::imminent death or great bodily harm}}: The defendant reasonably believes he faces an imminent threat of death or great bodily harm. 4. {{c6::Duty to retreat – majority rule}}: Under the {{c7::majority rule}}, there is {{c8::no duty to retreat}} before using deadly force.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Laws restricting speech can be struck down on grounds of {{c1::vagueness}} or {{c2::overbreadth}}. 1. Vagueness 1.1 A law is vague if a {{c3::reasonable person cannot tell whether speech is prohibited or permitted}}. 1.2 Example: A law prohibiting people from assembling and "conducting themselves in an annoying manner" is unconstitutionally vague because a reasonable person must {{c4::guess at what behavior is punishable}}. 2. Overbreadth 2.1 A law is overbroad if it {{c5::regulates substantially more speech than the Constitution allows to be regulated}}. 2.2 An overbroad law may validly restrict {{c6::unprotected speech}}, but in doing so it also restricts {{c7::protected speech}}. 2.2.1 Example: A law prohibiting all live entertainment may validly restrict {{c8::obscenity}}, but it also invalidly prohibits {{c9::protected speech in concerts or theater}}. 2.3 If a speech restriction is overbroad, it generally {{c10::cannot be enforced against anyone}}, even a person whose own speech is not protected. 3. Note 3.1 Statutes restricting speech that are both vague and overbroad are almost always {{c11::unconstitutional}} and will not be upheld.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: 1. {{c1::Contract liability}}: all partners are liable for any contract made in the {{c2::scope of the partnership business}} and other contracts {{c3::expressly authorized}} by the partners. 1.1 {{c4::Power to bind}}: a partner can bind the partnership for any transaction in the {{c5::ordinary course of the partnership business}}, unless 1.1.1 the partner has {{c6::no authority}} to act on behalf of the partnership; and 1.1.2 the other side has {{c7::knowledge or notice}} that the partner lacks authority. 1.2 Acts outside ordinary partnership business: acts by individual partners {{c8::outside the scope of the partnership business}} do not bind the partnership unless {{c9::all partners authorize}} the act. 2. {{c10::Tort liability}}: partners are liable for torts committed by a partner or employee if the tort is committed either 2.1 in the {{c11::ordinary course of partnership business}}; or 2.2 with {{c12::authority of the partnership}}. For example, Partner A can be liable for fraud committed by Partner B in the course of partnership business, even though A had no knowledge or participation in the fraud. 3. Nature and extent of liability: 3.1 all partners are {{c13::jointly and severally liable}}. That is, an action can be brought against any one or several of the partners as individuals or against the partnership; and 3.2 all partners are jointly and severally liable for {{c14::all partnership debts}} if the partnership cannot satisfy the debts itself.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Common-law {{c1::larceny}} is a {{c2::specific intent}} crime consisting of a {{c3::trespassory taking and carrying away}} (asportation) of another's {{c4::tangible personal property}}, {{c5::without the owner's consent}}, and with the {{c6::intent to permanently dispossess}} the owner. Special applications include the {{c7::continuing trespass doctrine}} (later-formed intent to keep borrowed property can become larceny) and {{c8::larceny of found property}} when the {{c9::true owner is known or reasonably ascertainable}} and the finder decides to keep it (but not for {{c10::abandoned property}}).

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: Pretrial lineups and showups raise two main constitutional issues: 1. {{c1::Right to counsel}} at post-charge, in-person lineups and showups (but not at non-live procedures). 2. {{c2::Due process}} limitations on unnecessarily suggestive procedures that create a substantial likelihood of misidentification under the {{c3::totality of the circumstances}}. 3. {{c4::Remedy}}: potential suppression of the witness’s {{c5::in-court identification}}, unless the government can show an {{c6::independent source}} for that identification.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Automatic perfection and {{c1::purchase-money security interests (PMSIs)}}: 1. Automatic perfection: 1.1 In some transactions, once the security interest has {{c2::attached}} to the collateral, perfection occurs {{c3::automatically}} without filing or possession. 2. PMSIs: 2.1 A PMSI exists where a creditor: 2.1.1 {{c4::Sells goods}} to the debtor on credit and retains a security interest in those goods; and/or 2.1.2 {{c5::Advances funds}} to the debtor to buy specific goods and takes a security interest in those same goods. 2.2 Certain PMSIs automatically perfect upon attachment: 2.2.1 A classic example is a PMSI in {{c6::consumer goods}}, which is often automatically perfected when the interest attaches (subject to exceptions). 3. Effect: 3.1 For automatically perfected SIs, the secured party is {{c7::perfected at the moment of attachment}}, gaining priority benefits without additional steps.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Felony murder}} as a malice mental state: 1.1 Felony murder: a killing caused during the {{c2::attempt or commission}} of an {{c3::inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony}}. 1.2 Intent required: only the {{c4::intent necessary to commit the underlying felony}} is required; no separate intent to kill is needed. 1.3 Statutorily enumerated felonies are often summarized as {{c5::BARKK}}: 1.3.1 {{c6::Burglary}}; 1.3.2 {{c7::Arson}}; 1.3.3 {{c8::Robbery}}; 1.3.4 {{c9::Kidnapping}}; and 1.3.5 Sometimes other listed felonies, where the statute dictates that a killing resulting from the crime constitutes felony murder. 2. {{c10::Causation}} in murder: 2.1 The defendant's act must be both the {{c11::actual cause}} and the {{c12::proximate cause}} of the victim's death. 2.2 Any act by the defendant that {{c13::hastens the victim's death}}, even if death was already inevitable, is treated as a cause.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Spousal support}} (also called {{c2::alimony}} or {{c3::maintenance}}) can be awarded if a spouse's separate property and earning capacity are insufficient for that spouse's reasonable maintenance. 1.1 {{c4::Discretion}}: Courts have significant discretion in determining whether and to what extent to award spousal support. Needs are determined under the {{c5::totality of the circumstances}}. 1.2 {{c6::Purpose}}: Spousal support ensures sufficient income for a spouse who became economically dependent, in whole or in part, due to the marriage relationship. 1.3 {{c7::Terms}}: Spousal support can be awarded short-term or indefinitely, and as a lump sum or periodic payments. 2. Types of spousal support: Common types include {{c8::Permanent Periodic Spousal Support}}, {{c9::Rehabilitative Spousal Support}}, {{c10::Lump Sum Spousal Support}}, and {{c11::Reimbursement Spousal Support}}. 3. Factors: Relevant factors in determining spousal support include: 3.1 {{c12::Financial resources}} of each party. 3.2 {{c13::Standard of living}} established during the marriage. 3.3 {{c14::Time necessary for the party seeking support to obtain employment}}, including education and training. 3.4 {{c15::Contribution of each party to the marriage}}, including childcare, career support of the other spouse, and contributions to the home. 3.5 {{c16::Ability of the spouse paying support to meet their own needs}}. 4. Marital fault: {{c17::Marital fault (e.g., infidelity) is not a relevant factor in most states}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: States may not {{c1::discriminate against non-state residents}} with respect to certain fundamental rights. The issue arises where a state law is {{c2::intentionally protectionist}} and concerns rights relating to {{c3::important commercial activities}} or {{c4::civil liberties}}. The Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause protects only {{c5::citizens}}; {{c6::corporations and aliens}} are not citizens for these purposes. 1. Analysis 1.1 A discriminatory state law will be invalid if it: 1.1.1 Relates to {{c7::civil liberties or important commercial activities}}; and 1.1.2 Is not {{c8::necessary to achieve an important government interest}}, such as where the law is intentionally protectionist, there is no substantial justification, or {{c9::less restrictive means}} are available. 2. Examples 2.1 Valid: Laws requiring higher fees for non-state residents at {{c10::public golf courses}} or higher fees for {{c11::hunting licenses}} for non-state residents. 2.2 Invalid: An {{c12::income tax on non-residents only}}, {{c13::limiting bar admission to state residents}}, or {{c14::different fees for commercial fishing licenses}} charged only to non-residents. 3. Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause 3.1 The Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause primarily applies to restrictions on the {{c15::right to interstate travel}}. 3.2 It is {{c16::narrowly construed}} and is unlikely to be a {{c17::correct answer choice}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Timing}}: 1.1. A search warrant must be executed without {{c2::unreasonable delay}} after it is issued. 2. {{c3::Knock-and-announce}} requirement: 2.1. Police must {{c4::knock and announce their purpose}}, then wait a {{c5::reasonable time}} for admittance before entering on their own accord. 2.2. Exception: Knock-and-announce is not required if officers have {{c6::reasonable suspicion}} that announcing their presence would be {{c7::dangerous}}, {{c8::futile}}, or would {{c9::inhibit the investigation}}. 3. {{c10::Scope of search}}: 3.1. The search is limited to what is {{c11::reasonably necessary to discover items described in the warrant}}. 3.2. Police can {{c12::detain people}} found on the searched premises. 3.3. But police cannot {{c13::search detained persons}} unless they are {{c14::specifically named in the warrant}} or a {{c15::valid warrantless search exception}} exists.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}} at pretrial identifications 1.1 A suspect has a right to counsel at any {{c2::post-charge, in-person lineup or showup}}. 1.2 This right {{c3::does not apply}} to {{c4::non-live identification procedures}}, such as {{c5::photographic lineups}} or {{c6::fingerprinting}}. 1.3 A {{c7::lineup}} is when a witness is shown {{c8::several possible suspects}}. 1.4 A {{c9::showup}} is when a witness is asked to identify {{c10::a single suspect}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: {{c1::Comparative negligence}} 1. Basic concept 1.1. The defendant can establish that the plaintiff’s injuries are at least partially the result of the plaintiff’s own negligence. 1.2. The fact-finder {{c2::apportions fault between the plaintiff and defendant by percentage}} and {{c3::reduces the plaintiff’s recoverable damages accordingly}}. 2. Types of comparative negligence 2.1. {{c4::Partial (modified) comparative negligence}} 2.1.1. The plaintiff can recover damages only if he was {{c5::less than 50% at fault (or 50% or less in some states)}}. 2.1.2. If the plaintiff’s fault exceeds the jurisdiction’s cutoff, the claim is {{c6::barred (inactionable)}}. 2.2. {{c7::Pure comparative negligence}} 2.2.1. The plaintiff can recover damages even if he was {{c8::more than 50% at fault}}. 2.2.2. Recovery is reduced by the plaintiff’s {{c9::percentage of fault}}.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. {{c1::Consumer transactions}} – no partial satisfaction plus deficiency 1.1 In consumer transactions, a secured party may not keep collateral in {{c2::partial satisfaction}} of the debt and then seek a {{c3::deficiency judgment}} for the remaining unpaid balance. 2. {{c4::Consumer goods with high payment threshold}} – {{c5::60%/90‑day rule}} 2.1 Where the debtor has paid at least {{c6::60%}} of a PMSI or other loan in consumer goods, the secured party must {{c7::sell the collateral within 90 days}} after repossession, unless the debtor {{c8::waives}} the right to require a sale. 3. Policy 3.1 These rules protect {{c9::consumer debtors}} from secured creditors retaining valuable consumer goods while still pursuing a {{c10::deficiency}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Undue influence can make a contract voidable. 1. Definition: 1.1 Undue influence occurs when a contract is entered into under {{c1::excessive pressure}}. 1.2 It typically involves a party who is {{c2::unduly susceptible to pressure}}. 2. Elements: 2.1 A {{c3::susceptible party}} (e.g., due to weakness, dependency, or special relationship). 2.2 {{c4::Excessive or overbearing pressure}} applied by the other party. 3. Effect: 3.1 A contract induced by undue influence is {{c5::voidable}} at the option of the {{c6::influenced (susceptible) party}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Irresistible Impulse Test (Volitional Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant acted due to an {{c1::irresistible impulse}}. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 Due to a {{c2::mental illness}}, the defendant was unable to {{c3::control his actions}} or {{c4::conform his conduct to the law}}. 2.2 This test focuses on the defendant’s {{c5::volitional capacity}} (ability to control behavior), even if he may know his conduct is wrong.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Insanity: 1. General rule: 1.1 {{c1::Legal insanity}} is a complete defense to {{c2::all crimes}}, regardless of the {{c3::mens rea or intent requirement}}. 1.2 Depending on the jurisdiction, one of {{c4::four legal insanity tests}} is used to determine whether the defendant was so mentally ill when he committed the crime that he should be entitled to acquittal. 2. Four legal insanity tests (jurisdiction will specify which applies): 2.1 {{c5::M'Naghten test}} – focuses on whether, due to mental disease or defect, the defendant lacked the ability to know the {{c6::wrongfulness}} of his conduct or understand the {{c7::nature and quality}} of his act. 2.2 {{c8::Irresistible Impulse test}} – focuses on whether, due to mental illness, the defendant was unable to {{c9::control his actions}} or {{c10::conform his conduct to the law}}. 2.3 {{c11::MPC test}} – combines cognitive and volitional components: whether, as a result of mental disease, the defendant lacked the capacity either to {{c12::appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct}} or to {{c13::conform his conduct to the requirements of the law}}. 2.4 {{c14::Durham test}} – asks whether the defendant's conduct was the {{c15::product of a mental illness}} (i.e., he would not have acted {{c16::but for}} his mental illness). 3. Note: 3.1 On the {{c17::MBE}}, the question will indicate which insanity test applies.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Under the {{c1::Statute of Frauds}}, certain contracts require {{c2::special proof of their existence}}. If SoF requirements are not met, the contract may be {{c3::invalid or unenforceable}}. The purpose of the SoF is to prevent {{c4::fraud and perjury}} by requiring {{c5::reliable evidence}} of the agreement, such as a writing or qualifying performance.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments}} each contain an {{c2::enabling clause}} authorizing Congress to adopt appropriate legislation to enforce the rights these Amendments guarantee. 1. {{c3::13th Amendment}}: prohibition on {{c4::slavery and involuntary servitude}}. Congress can adopt legislation prohibiting almost any {{c5::private racial discrimination}} that constitutes a {{c6::badge or incident of slavery}}. For example, Congress can pass a law prohibiting employers from discriminating in hiring on the basis of race. There is {{c7::no state action requirement}}: the 13th Amendment applies to private action by its terms. 2. {{c8::14th Amendment}}: prohibits states from depriving any person of life, liberty, or property without {{c9::due process}} and {{c10::equal protection}}. Congress can adopt legislation to {{c11::enforce existing rights and guarantees}}, but may not {{c12::expand existing or create new constitutional rights}}. 2.1 Congress must {{c13::point to a history and pattern of state violations of rights}}; and 2.2 The legislation must be {{c14::congruent and proportional}} to remedying the violation. 3. {{c15::15th Amendment}}: prohibits state and federal governments from denying any citizen the {{c16::right to vote on the basis of race or color}}. These powers can be limited by other constitutional principles. The 15th Amendment is much less likely to appear on the bar exam.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: The following are common methods of transferring property {{c1::outside of probate}}. 1. {{c2::Inter vivos gift}} (a gift given by a living person to another living person) 1.1 Requirements ({{c3::intent, delivery, and acceptance}}): 1.1.1 The {{c4::donor intends to make a gift}}. 1.1.2 The donor {{c5::delivers the gift}} (actual or constructive delivery). 1.1.3 The {{c6::donee accepts}} the gift. 2. {{c7::Joint tenant bank account}} 2.1 A surviving joint tenant is generally entitled to the money in a jointly held account when the other joint tenant dies. 2.2 This usually arises where the account is in the names of two or more people. 3. {{c8::Totten trust}} or {{c9::POD (payable-on-death) account}} 3.1 Deposit of funds in one's own bank account held {{c10::in trust for another}} (e.g., A opens an account for herself as trustee for B). 3.2 This creates a valid {{c11::revocable trust}}, even though the depositor retains control. 3.3 Funds pass to the designated {{c12::beneficiary}} upon the trustee's death. 3.4 The arrangement is {{c13::revocable}} by the trustee-depositor by withdrawing funds before death or revoking the trust by will. 4. {{c14::Life insurance}} 4.1 A {{c15::contract}} between the policyholder and the insurance company under which a beneficiary is named. 4.2 Unless the contract provides otherwise, the policyholder cannot change the {{c16::beneficiary through a provision in their will}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: If venue in the original district is {{c1::improper}}, the court may either {{c2::transfer the case in the interest of justice}} or {{c3::dismiss the case}}. When venue is improper, transfer is often favored to serve the {{c4::interest of justice}}, especially where dismissal might bar the claims (for example, by limitations). The case must be transferred to a federal district where it {{c5::could have been brought}} or, in appropriate circumstances, to a district to which {{c6::all parties consent}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: {{c1::Liability insurance}} 1. Evidence of liability insurance is {{c2::not admissible}} to prove {{c3::fault or a party's ability to pay damages}}. 2. Evidence of insurance is admissible to prove other matters, such as {{c4::ownership, control, or motive}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Probable cause}} requirement: - A valid search warrant must be based on probable cause that {{c2::evidence, contraband, or fruits or instrumentalities of crime}} will be found in the place to be searched. - Probable cause is usually demonstrated by a police {{c3::affidavit}} submitted to the magistrate. - The affidavit must set out {{c4::facts}} showing a {{c5::fair probability}} that evidence will be found; it may incorporate information from {{c6::anonymous sources}}. 2. False statements in the affidavit ({{c7::Franks}}-type challenge): - A defendant can attack a warrant by showing that: (1) The affidavit contained a {{c8::false statement}}; (2) The affiant included the false statement {{c9::intentionally or with reckless disregard for the truth}}; and (3) The false statement was {{c10::material to the finding of probable cause}}. - If these elements are met, the false material is {{c11::excised}}; if the remaining content does not establish probable cause, the {{c12::warrant is invalid}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Breaking (common law): - {{c1::Breaking must be trespassory}}. - {{c2::Actual breaking}}: {{c3::opening or enlarging an opening}} (e.g., opening an unlocked door or raising a window). - {{c4::Constructive breaking}}: entry by {{c5::threat, force, fraud, or duress}}. - {{c6::Fraud negates any apparent consent}} the victim may have given. - No trespassory breaking: entering with {{c7::valid consent}} or through a {{c8::wide open door}} is not a breaking. - Under many {{c9::modern statutes}}, {{c10::breaking is not required}}. Entering: - Entering is satisfied when {{c11::any portion of the body or the instrument used for the breaking}} passes inside the structure. Dwelling and "of another": - {{c12::Dwelling}}: a structure used for {{c13::sleeping purposes}}. - "{{c14::Of another}}": {{c15::occupancy}} is sufficient; {{c16::ownership is irrelevant}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. {{c1::Codicils}} (amendments, modifications, or alterations to a previously executed will) 1.1 A codicil must be executed with the same {{c2::formalities}} required for a will (e.g., in writing, signed by the testator, and properly witnessed, depending on the jurisdiction). 1.2 When a codicil is validly executed, the original will is treated as {{c3::republished}} and is deemed to have been executed on the date the codicil was executed. 2. {{c4::Holographic wills}} (handwritten, unwitnessed wills; not recognized in all states) 2.1 Requirements for a valid holographic will 2.1.1 The will must be in the testator's {{c5::handwriting}}. Some states require the entire will to be handwritten; others allow some typewritten text so long as the typed portion is not material. Under the {{c6::UPC}}, only the {{c7::material portions}} must be in the testator's handwriting. 2.1.2 The will must be {{c8::signed}} somewhere by the testator. 2.1.3 The document must, as a whole, reflect the testator's {{c9::intent that it operate as a will}}. For example, a letter signed by the testator requesting changes to an existing will is not itself a will because it contemplates a {{c10::future writing}} that will constitute the will. 2.2 A valid holographic will {{c11::replaces and revokes}} any prior valid will to the extent of inconsistency. 2.3 {{c12::Oral (nuncupative) wills}} are not permitted in most states.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Congress’s legislative powers under {{c1::Article I}} include key {{c2::enumerated powers}}, like {{c3::taxing and spending}}, {{c4::regulating commerce}}, establishing uniform rules of {{c5::naturalization}} and {{c6::bankruptcy}}, and raising and supporting the {{c7::military}}. Two important constitutional clauses shape how Congress exercises its powers and how members of Congress are protected: 1. {{c8::Speech or Debate Clause}}: Members of Congress are immune from civil and criminal liability for {{c9::legislative acts}} and for activities and documents {{c10::essential to their legislative duties}}. 2. {{c11::Necessary and Proper Clause}}: Congress may adopt any means not otherwise unconstitutional that are useful or convenient to {{c12::carry into execution its express powers}}, thereby creating {{c13::implied powers}}. However, this Clause is {{c14::not an independent source of power}} and must be tied to another federal power.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Congress may use {{c1::conditional grants}} of federal funds to {{c2::induce, but not compel}}, state regulatory or legislative action (for example, conditioning {{c3::highway funds}} on a minimum drinking age of {{c4::21}}). For conditions on federal grants to be valid: - The condition must be {{c5::expressly stated}}, so states clearly understand the terms. - The condition must {{c6::relate to the purpose}} of the underlying law or program (a {{c7::germaneness}} requirement). - The condition cannot be {{c8::unduly coercive}}; Congress cannot so heavily penalize refusal that states have no real choice.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: An easement's scope is determined by the {{c1::terms or conditions that created it}}. In interpreting an easement's scope, courts will consider the {{c2::reasonable intent of the original parties}}. 2. {{c3::Expansion}}: Easement holders {{c4::cannot unilaterally expand}} the scope of their easement (for example, through overuse or misuse). {{c5::Overuse or misuse does not terminate}} the easement; the remedy for a violation is {{c6::an injunction or damages}}. 3. {{c7::Duty to repair}}: The easement holder has a duty to make repairs if he is the {{c8::sole user}}. If both the servient landowner and the easement holder use an easement, the {{c9::repair costs are apportioned}} between them.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Under the {{c1::UCC}}, a buyer's post-delivery rights turn on (1) whether and how she has {{c2::accepted}} the goods, and (2) whether she can later {{c3::revoke that acceptance}}. A buyer generally does not accept until she has a {{c4::reasonable opportunity to inspect}} and either indicates acceptance or fails to seasonably reject. Even after acceptance, the buyer may in limited circumstances revoke if a {{c5::defect substantially impairs the goods' value}} and specific conditions related to {{c6::cure, ignorance, or reliance on assurances}} are met.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. For diversity jurisdiction, every {{c1::plaintiff}} must be of diverse citizenship from every {{c2::defendant}}. 2. Determining citizenship for diversity purposes differs for {{c3::individuals}} and {{c4::businesses}}. 3. Natural persons: 3.1. A natural person is a citizen of the state where they are {{c5::domiciled}} at the time the suit is filed. 3.2. Domicile is the state where the person was last both: 3.2.1. {{c6::Present}}; and 3.2.2. {{c7::Intending to remain indefinitely}}. 3.3. A person always has {{c8::one—and never more than one—domicile}}. You keep your domicile until you acquire a new one. 3.4. Factors for determining a person’s domicile include simultaneous: 3.4.1. {{c9::Physical}} factor: actual presence in the state; and 3.4.2. {{c10::Mental}} factor: intent to make the state a permanent home (e.g., where the person votes, works, is licensed, etc.). 4. Businesses. 4.1. Corporations: 4.1.1. A corporation is a citizen of every state in which it is {{c11::incorporated}} and of the state where it maintains its {{c12::principal place of business (PPB)}}. 4.1.2. A corporation can have {{c13::multiple states of citizenship}}. 4.1.3. To determine the PPB, look to where the corporation’s high-level decisions are made—the {{c14::“nerve center”}}, usually the corporate headquarters. 4.2. Unincorporated businesses (e.g., LLCs, LLPs): 4.2.1. An unincorporated association is a citizen of {{c15::all states in which any partner or member is a citizen}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Appellate courts review different trial-court decisions under distinct standards of review. 1. Questions of law: reviewed {{c1::de novo}}; the appellate court may substitute its judgment for that of the trial judge. 2. Questions of fact: a. Non-jury (bench) trials: factual findings will not be disturbed unless {{c2::clearly erroneous}}. b. Jury trials: factual findings will not be disturbed unless a {{c3::reasonable jury}} could not have reached the same conclusion. 3. Mixed questions of law and fact: reviewed {{c4::de novo}}. 4. Discretionary matters (e.g., evidentiary rulings): reviewed for {{c5::abuse of discretion}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Speech or Debate Clause}}: basic rule 1.1 The Speech or Debate Clause protects members of Congress from liability for {{c2::legislative conduct}}. 2. Scope of immunity 2.1 Members of Congress have {{c3::criminal and civil immunity}} for {{c4::legislative acts}}. 2.2 The immunity extends to {{c5::activities and documents}} that are {{c6::essential to the performance of legislative duties}}. 3. Key idea 3.1 The Clause is designed to protect the {{c7::independence and integrity of the legislative process}}, not {{c8::personal or political acts}} unrelated to legislation.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 An {{c1::executory interest}} is a future interest in a {{c2::third party}} that takes effect by {{c3::cutting short some other interest}}. 1.2 There are two types: {{c4::shifting}} and {{c5::springing}}. 1.3 An executory interest includes any future interest in a transferee that is {{c6::not a remainder}}. 1.4 Executory interest holders {{c7::lack standing to sue for waste}}. 1.5 Transferability: executory interests are generally {{c8::devisable, descendible, and usually transferable inter vivos}}. 2. {{c9::Shifting executory interest}} 2.1 A shifting executory interest always follows a {{c10::defeasible fee}} or a {{c11::vested remainder subject to total divestment}}. 2.2 It cuts short an interest in {{c12::someone other than the grantor}}. 2.3 Example: O grants "to A so long as A uses the property for storage, but if A stops using it for storage, then to B." A has a {{c13::fee simple subject to an executory interest}}, and B has a {{c14::shifting executory interest}}. If A stops using the property for storage, A’s interest is {{c15::cut short}}, and B takes. 3. {{c16::Springing executory interest}} 3.1 A springing executory interest cuts short a present interest held by the {{c17::grantor or the grantor’s estate}}. 3.2 Example: O grants "to A when A gets married." A has an {{c18::executory interest}}, and O has a {{c19::fee simple subject to an executory interest}}; if A gets married, possession {{c20::springs from O to A}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Classifications based on {{c1::race}} or {{c2::national origin}} are {{c3::suspect classifications}} reviewed under {{c4e::strict scrutiny}}. Common applications include {{c5::affirmative action and quotas}}, {{c6::university admissions diversity policies}}, and {{c7::public school race-based assignments}}, all of which must satisfy a {{c8::compelling interest}} and be {{c9::narrowly tailored}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: When a tenant {{c1::breaches leasehold duties}}, the landlord’s remedies depend on whether the tenant {{c2::retains possession}} or {{c3::abandons}} the premises. If the tenant stays, the landlord may {{c4::evict}} or {{c5::continue the lease and sue for rent}}. If the tenant abandons, the landlord may {{c6::accept surrender}}, {{c7::ignore abandonment (minority)}}, or, under the {{c8::majority rule}}, must {{c9::reasonably attempt to re-let and recover losses}}. The landlord may not {{c10::use self-help}} to regain possession, must {{c11::properly handle and return any security deposit}} (minus only {{c12::legitimate damages or contractually permitted losses}}), and may not engage in {{c13::retaliatory eviction}} or retaliation when the tenant {{c14::exercises protected rights}} such as reporting housing code violations.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: Ex Parte vs. Consent Divorces and Domicile: 1. {{c1::Ex Parte Divorce}} (One-Spouse Domicile/Appearance): 1.1 A divorce where only {{c2::one spouse appears}} and the decree is based on that spouse’s {{c3::domicile}} in the rendering state. 1.2 The enforcing state may {{c4::examine whether domicile was bona fide}}, although there is a {{c5::rebuttable presumption}} that the domicile found by the rendering court is {{c6::genuine}}. 2. {{c7::Consent Divorce}} (Both Spouses Participate): 2.1 Both spouses {{c8::appear or consent}} before the rendering court. 2.2 Full faith and credit will be given if the court had {{c9::proper jurisdiction}}, which is satisfied when at least {{c10::one spouse is domiciled}} in the forum (and is especially strong if both are domiciled). 3. Key Contrast: 3.1 Ex parte divorces are more vulnerable to {{c11::collateral attacks on domicile and jurisdiction}}. 3.2 Consent divorces receive {{c12::stronger full faith and credit protection}} because both spouses were before the rendering court.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General rule: Defendant owes a {{c1::duty of care}} to behave like a {{c2::reasonably prudent person}} to all {{c3::foreseeable plaintiffs in the zone of danger}}. 2. Default standard of care: 2.1 {{c4::Reasonably prudent person (RPP)}}. 2.2 Defendant's duty is to behave like a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances. 2.3 The RPP is considered to be someone with defendant's {{c5::physical characteristics}}, but with the {{c6::knowledge and mental capacity of an ordinary person}}. 3. Foreseeable victims: 3.1 Those within the {{c7::zone of danger}}. 3.2 Zone of danger: the area around defendant's activities in which a plaintiff could foreseeably be injured. 3.3 {{c8::Rescuer's exception}}: If defendant puts himself or another in danger and a third person attempts to rescue, defendant can be held liable for the rescuer's injuries, even if the rescuer was unforeseeable. 3.4 {{c9::Firefighter's rule}}: The rescuer's exception does not apply to emergency personnel (e.g., firefighters or police) if their injury results from a risk inherent to the job. 3.5 {{c10::Prenatal injury}}: A duty of care is owed to a {{c11::viable fetus}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: 1. Requirements ({{c1::hearsay statements in the form of business records}} are admissible if they are): 1.1 A {{c2::record of an act, event, condition, opinion, or diagnosis}} made or recorded by a business (for example, receipts, reports, patient records). 1.2 Made in the {{c3::regular course of business}} (i.e., as a regular practice). 1.3 Made by, or from information transmitted by, {{c4::someone with knowledge}}, at or near the {{c5::time of the matters described}}. 1.4 {{c6::Authenticated or certified in writing}}. 1.4.1 {{c7::Trustworthiness}}: the court may exclude an otherwise qualifying record if circumstances indicate a lack of trustworthiness. 1.4.2 {{c8::Absence of record}}: records meeting these requirements may be admitted to show that a matter {{c9::did not occur or exist}}. 2. {{c10::Police reports}}: in criminal cases, police reports or other criminal investigative reports are {{c11::inadmissible against the defendant}} as business records or public records. 3. {{c12::Multiple hearsay}} issues: 3.1 Business records often involve {{c13::multiple layers of hearsay}}. 3.2 Every layer must fall into some {{c14::exception or exemption}} to be admissible. 3.3 Example: minutes of a business meeting with a {{c15::secretary's notes of participants' statements}}; the secretary's notes are one level of hearsay, and the participants' statements are another.

subject: Torts
cloze: Defamation is a {{c1::false statement of fact}} about the plaintiff, {{c2::published to at least one third person}}, that {{c3::harms the plaintiff’s reputation}}. At common law, the core elements are: (1) a {{c4::false and defamatory statement of fact}}; (2) that {{c5::concerns the plaintiff}}; (3) {{c6::publication}} to at least one third person; and (4) {{c7::harm to reputation}}. {{c8::Falsity}} and {{c9::fault}} are always part of the analysis, though {{c10::constitutional law}} determines who must prove falsity or truth and what level of fault is required. Liability extends to those who {{c11::republish}} defamatory statements, subject to special federal protection for {{c12::internet service providers}}. {{c13::Damages}} and the plaintiff’s burden to prove them vary based on the {{c14::type of plaintiff}}, whether the speech involves a {{c15::matter of public concern}}, and whether the defamation is {{c16::libel, slander, or slander per se}}. {{c17::Truth}} is a {{c18::complete defense}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: When a state or local law interferes with {{c1::private contracts}}, the Contract Clause uses an {{c2::intermediate-type scrutiny}}. 1. Threshold: substantial impairment 1.1. First ask whether the law {{c3::substantially impairs}} a party’s rights under an {{c4::existing}} private contract. 1.2. If there is no {{c3::substantial impairment}}, the Contract Clause is not violated. 2. Test for substantial impairment of private contracts 2.1. If the law does substantially impair contractual rights, it violates the Contract Clause unless the law: 2.1.1. Serves an {{c5::important and legitimate public interest}}; and 2.1.2. Is {{c6::reasonable and narrowly tailored}} in promoting that interest. 3. Level of scrutiny 3.1. This standard is often characterized as an {{c2::intermediate-type scrutiny}} for state interference with {{c1::private contracts}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Absent parties may be forced to join a case if they are deemed {{c1::necessary parties}}. Named defendants can seek {{c2::dismissal for failure to join a Rule 19 party}}. 1. Necessary parties: absentees are necessary when either: 1.1 Without the absentee, the court cannot grant {{c3::complete relief}}, considering whether multiple suits might follow if the absentee is not made a party. 1.2 The absentee has a {{c4::legal interest}} that may be {{c5::impaired or impeded}} if the case proceeds without them. 1.3 The absentee has an interest that creates a risk of {{c6::multiple or inconsistent rulings and obligations}}. The test is not whether joinder would be merely {{c7::efficient}}. {{c8::Joint tortfeasors}} are not necessary parties. 2. Requirements for joinder: an absentee can be joined as a necessary party if: 2.1 There is {{c9::personal jurisdiction}} over the absentee; and 2.2 Joining the absentee will not {{c10::destroy subject-matter jurisdiction}} (e.g., diversity). 3. {{c11::Indispensable parties}}: if a necessary party cannot be joined, ask whether the party is so indispensable that the case should be dismissed. The court looks at these factors: 3.1 Whether an {{c12::alternative forum}} is available. 3.2 The likelihood of {{c13::prejudice}} to the parties or others if the case goes forward. 3.3 Whether the court can {{c14::shape potential relief to avoid prejudice}}. 3.4 Whether the plaintiff would have an {{c15::adequate remedy}} if the case is dismissed.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: This card covers the federal rules governing (1) the {{c1::Seventh Amendment right}} to a civil jury trial and basic jury mechanics, (2) {{c2::voir dire}} and the use of {{c3::for-cause}} and {{c4::peremptory}} challenges, and (3) {{c5::non-jury (bench) trials}} and the judge’s {{c6::fact-finding duties}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Intoxication: 1. {{c1::Voluntary intoxication}}: 1.1 Only a defense to {{c2::specific intent crimes}}. 1.2 Voluntary intoxication means the defendant {{c3::chose to consume an intoxicant}}. 1.3 {{c4::Alcoholics and addicts}} are considered voluntarily intoxicated. 1.4 Voluntary intoxication is {{c5::not available}} as a defense if the defendant becomes intoxicated {{c6::in order to commit the crime}}. 2. {{c7::Involuntary intoxication}}: 2.1 A defense to {{c8::all crimes}}. 2.2 Arises when the defendant was given an intoxicant {{c9::without her knowledge}} or {{c10::forced to consume}} an intoxicant. 2.3 Requirements: an intoxicant is taken involuntarily if taken: 2.3.1 {{c11::Without knowledge of its nature}}, 2.3.2 Under {{c12::direct duress}} imposed by another person, or 2.3.3 Pursuant to {{c13::medical advice}} without notice of its intoxicating effect. 2.4 Involuntary intoxication may be treated as a {{c14::mental illness}} if, because of the intoxication, the defendant satisfies the relevant jurisdiction's {{c15::insanity test}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Common-law {{c1::larceny}} is the {{c2::trespassory taking and carrying away}} of another's {{c3::tangible personal property}} without consent and with intent to permanently dispossess the owner. 1. {{c4::Taking (caption)}}: Obtaining control or possession of the property. If the defendant already has {{c5::possession}} when he misappropriates it, the crime is generally {{c6::embezzlement}}, not larceny. 2. {{c7::Carrying away (asportation)}}: Any {{c8::slight movement}} of the property satisfies this requirement. 3. Property of another: Must be {{c9::tangible personal property}} belonging to {{c10::someone other than the defendant}}. 4. {{c11::Without consent}} (trespassory): Against the victim's free will; consent obtained by {{c12::fraud or duress}} is invalid, and this requirement distinguishes larceny from {{c13::larceny by trick}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: State laws often determine when courts may exercise jurisdiction. A federal court must analyze jurisdiction as would the state court in which it sits and must follow applicable {{c1::state statutes}}. Note: the court's exercise of jurisdiction must also satisfy {{c2::constitutional requirements}}. Most state statutes grant courts in personam jurisdiction if: 1. {{c3::Service of process}}: the defendant is personally served in the forum state. The duration of the defendant's presence is irrelevant. 2. {{c4::Domicile}}: the defendant is domiciled in the forum state. Domicile means the defendant maintains a {{c5::permanent home}} in the forum state. A court can exercise jurisdiction over domiciled persons even if they are not physically present when served. 3. {{c6::Consent}}: the defendant consents to jurisdiction (expressly or impliedly). 4. {{c7::Long-arm statute}}: the defendant's acts fall within the state's long-arm statute. 4.1. {{c8::General/unlimited long-arm statute}}: confers the state's courts with jurisdiction to the full extent allowed by the Constitution. 4.2. {{c9::Limited/enumerated long-arm statute}}: specifies when state courts can exercise jurisdiction based on particular acts or contacts.

subject: Agency
cloze: Once a valid {{c1::contract}} is entered into by an agent with a third party on the principal's behalf, the liabilities of the principal and the agent to the third party depend on whether the principal was {{c2::disclosed}} to the third party. 1. {{c3::Third party vs. principal}} 1.1 If the {{c4::agent had authority}}, the principal is liable to the third party. 2. {{c5::Third party vs. agent}} (liability of the agent depends on whether the principal is disclosed) 2.1 {{c6::Disclosed principal}}: where the third party knows of the principal's existence and identity: 2.1.1 The {{c7::principal is liable}}; the {{c8::agent is not liable}}. 2.1.2 Only the {{c9::principal}}, not the agent, can {{c10::enforce the contract}}. 2.2 {{c11::Undisclosed and/or unidentified principal}}: both the {{c12::agent and the principal are liable}} to the third party, and {{c13::either can enforce}} the contract. If the agent enforces the contract, the principal is entitled to all {{c14::rights and benefits}} under the contract.
