Definitions 3.1 {{c15::Undisclosed principal}}: the third party does not know of the principal's existence or identity. 3.2 {{c16::Unidentified principal}}: the third party knows that a principal exists but does not know the principal's identity.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Residential property}} must be fit for {{c2::basic human dwelling}}. 1.2 {{c3::Residential only}}: The implied warranty of habitability does not apply to {{c4::commercial leases}}. 1.3 {{c5::Absolute duty}}: The warranty cannot be waived or modified by lease terms. 1.4 {{c6::Local housing code or case law}} specifies the standard for breach. 1.5 Examples: {{c7::No heat in winter, no plumbing, no running water}}, or similar conditions may constitute a breach of the implied warranty of habitability. 2. Tenant's remedies (after giving notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure) 2.1 {{c8::Move}}: Vacate the premises and terminate the lease. 2.2 {{c9::Repair and deduct}}: Make reasonable repairs and deduct the costs from future rent. 2.3 {{c10::Reduce or withhold rent}}: Reduce rent or stop payment until a court determines the fair rental value given the breach; the tenant must place withheld rent in {{c11::escrow}}. 2.4 {{c12::Remain and sue}}: Remain in possession and seek {{c13::money damages}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Commerce Clause}}, Congress has broad power to regulate {{c2::interstate commerce}}. 1. {{c3::Channels of interstate commerce}} (e.g., highways, waterways, air traffic corridors). 2. {{c4::Instrumentalities of interstate commerce}} (e.g., trucks, planes, trains) and {{c5::persons and things in interstate commerce}}. 3. {{c6::Economic activities}} that, in the {{c7::aggregate}}, have a {{c8::substantial effect}} on interstate commerce. This is a {{c9::broad power}} when Congress regulates interstate economic activity.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Steps and tools in discovery: 1. Initiating discovery: - {{c1::Meet and confer}} to discuss claims and develop a proposed discovery plan. - Make {{c2::initial disclosures}} of discoverable information, insurance, and damages information. - Obtain a {{c3::scheduling order}} from the court setting discovery deadlines. 2. Conducting discovery: - Use formal tools such as {{c4::depositions}}, {{c5::requests for production}}, {{c6::interrogatories}}, and {{c7::requests for admission}}. - After fact discovery, provide {{c8::expert disclosures}} and {{c9::pretrial disclosures}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In General: A {{c1::contract}} is a {{c2::promise or set of promises enforced by law}}; a {{c3::legally enforceable agreement}}. 2. Requirements to form a valid contract: A contract is formed when there exists: 2.1 {{c4::Mutual assent}}: A {{c5::meeting of the minds}}, demonstrated by an {{c6::offer and valid acceptance}}, determined by the parties' {{c7::objective (not subjective) manifestations of assent}}. 2.2 {{c8::Consideration}}: A {{c9::bargained-for exchange of legal value}} between the parties. 2.3 {{c10::No defenses to contract formation}}: No defenses to formation exist that would invalidate the contract. 3. {{c11::Void, voidable, and unenforceable contracts}}: If there is a valid defense to contract formation or enforcement, a contract may become: 3.1 {{c12::Void}}: The contract {{c13::never had any legal effect}}. 3.2 {{c14::Voidable}}: {{c15::One or both parties may elect to void}} the contract. 3.3 {{c16::Unenforceable}}: An otherwise valid contract that is {{c17::unenforceable because a defense applies}} (e.g., {{c18::incapacity, Statute of Frauds}}).

subject: Contracts
cloze: The test for offer is {{c1::objective}}: Would a {{c2::reasonable person in the offeree's position}} believe the communication {{c3::is an offer inviting acceptance}}? {{c4::Vague or incomplete terms}} are usually treated as {{c5::preliminary negotiations}}, and mere {{c6::price quotes}} or {{c7::invitations to deal}} do not create a {{c8::power of acceptance}}. As a general rule, {{c9::advertisements, catalogs, and circulars}} are {{c10::not offers}} but invitations to negotiate. An advertisement becomes an offer only if it is {{c11::highly specific as to quantity}} and {{c12::clearly indicates who may accept and how}}, leaving {{c13::nothing essential open to negotiation}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: Under {{c1::Rule 60(b)(6)}}, a court may relieve a party from a final judgment or order for {{c2::"any other reason that justifies relief"}}. • This catchall is used only in {{c3::extraordinary circumstances}}. • It is not a substitute for the more {{c4::specific grounds}} in Rule 60(b)(1)–(5) and cannot be used to evade their {{c5::time limits}} or element requirements. • Courts typically require {{c6::exceptional hardship or injustice}} that cannot be addressed under the other subsections.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. {{c1::Living wills}} and {{c2::durable healthcare powers}} (a.k.a. durable healthcare powers of attorney) are forms of {{c3::advanced healthcare directives}}, which are instructions regarding an individual's health care if they become unable to make such decisions on their own. 1.1 Creation (states vary on requirements, but most are similar to those needed for will execution): 1.1.1 In {{c4::writing}}. 1.1.2 {{c5::Signed}} by the testator or principal, or another at his direction. 1.1.3 {{c6::Witnessed by two adults}}. 1.2 Revocation: Both a living will and a durable healthcare power of attorney may be {{c7::revoked}}. 2. {{c8::Living will}} 2.1 A document specifying {{c9::life-sustaining and pain-alleviating measures}} one does or does not want if he is indefinitely incapacitated. 2.2 Example: Directs what measures one wants if they become terminally ill or are in a {{c10::persistent vegetative state}}. 3. {{c11::Durable healthcare power of attorney}} 3.1 A document that {{c12::appoints an individual as agent}} to make healthcare decisions on behalf of the principal. 3.2 Becomes effective only if the {{c13::principal is incapacitated}}. 3.3 Extends to {{c14::all healthcare questions}}, unless otherwise limited. 4. {{c15::Family consent}} 4.1 Most states have laws that apply where a person becomes terminally ill or otherwise indefinitely incapacitated and there is {{c16::no living will or durable healthcare power of attorney}}. 4.2 {{c17::Close relatives}}, usually in an order provided by statute, may act as {{c18::surrogate decision-makers}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. General Rule: Police may detain a person for an investigative purpose if they have {{c1::reasonable suspicion}} of {{c2::criminal activity}}. 2. Allowable scope of stop and frisk 2.1 Length: Detention must be {{c3::no longer than necessary}} to verify or dispel the suspicion. 2.2 Frisk: If police have reasonable suspicion the person is {{c4::armed or dangerous}}, they may {{c5::frisk for weapons}}. 2.3 {{c6::Plain feel}}: If police have reasonable belief during the frisk that what they feel is a {{c7::weapon or contraband}}, they may seize the suspected item. 2.3.1 Officers cannot {{c8::manipulate the item}} to develop reasonable belief. 2.3.2 It must be {{c9::plain touch only}}. 2.3.3 Evidence validly seized is {{c10::admissible}}. 3. Stop vs. arrest 3.1 A stop is a {{c11::brief detention}}, less intrusive than an {{c12::arrest}}. 3.2 Police may develop {{c13::probable cause to arrest}} based on anything occurring or discovered during the stop and/or frisk. Note: Stop and frisk is often called a {{c14::Terry stop}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: In K–12 public schools, systems may not {{c1::assign students to schools on the basis of race}} simply to achieve integration. {{c2::Racial balancing for its own sake}} is generally {{c3::not a compelling state interest}} under strict scrutiny, making voluntary race-based assignment plans constitutionally suspect.

subject: Contracts
cloze: UCC Article 2 recognizes several types of warranties in the sale of goods, including {{c1::express warranties}} and two key {{c2::implied warranties}} ({{c3::merchantability}} and {{c4::fitness for a particular purpose}}). An express warranty is created by the seller’s {{c5::affirmations of fact, promises, descriptions, samples, or models}} that become part of the {{c6::basis of the bargain}}, and is breached when the goods {{c7::fail to conform}}. In addition, a {{c8::merchant seller who deals in goods of the kind}} automatically gives an implied warranty of merchantability that the goods are {{c9::fit for their ordinary purpose}}. A separate implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when the seller has {{c10::reason to know of the buyer’s special purpose and reliance}}, and the buyer actually {{c11::relies on the seller to select suitable goods}}. The parties can structure warranty liability by using {{c12::disclaimers}} (which can limit or eliminate {{c13::implied warranties}}, but generally not {{c14::express warranties}}) and by {{c15::limiting remedies}} for breach (e.g., to repair or replacement), subject to {{c16::unconscionability}} and the limitation not {{c17::failing of its essential purpose}}. {{c18::Damages for breach of warranty}} are typically measured by the {{c19::difference between the value of the goods as delivered and the value as warranted}}, plus allowable {{c20::incidental and consequential damages}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Zoning Variances – Definition and Requirements: 1. Definition of variance 1.1. A variance is government permission for a landowner to be {{c1::exempt from or vary the literal restrictions of a zoning ordinance}}. 2. Requirements for obtaining a variance 2.1. The landowner must show {{c2::undue hardship}}. 2.2. The landowner must also show that granting the variance will {{c3::not be contrary to the public welfare}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: In federal class actions, jurisdictional issues arise in three main areas: 1. {{c1::Personal jurisdiction over absent class members}} is handled collectively rather than individually. Absent members do not each need {{c2::minimum contacts}} with the forum; instead, due process is protected by class procedures such as {{c3::reasonable and adequate notice}}, an {{c4::opportunity to opt out}} where applicable, and {{c5::adequate representation}} by the named class representatives. 2. {{c6::Traditional subject-matter jurisdiction}} (federal question and diversity) generally follows the usual rules, but in diversity class actions the court looks only to the {{c7::class representatives’ citizenship and amount in controversy}} to determine diversity. 3. The {{c8::Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA)}} provides a separate, more permissive basis for federal subject-matter jurisdiction in certain large, multi-state class actions, using {{c9::minimal diversity}} and an {{c10::aggregated amount in controversy}}, and it excludes certain {{c11::small class actions}} and specified {{c12::corporate}} and {{c13::state securities}} claims.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: If land is subdivided into parcels under a {{c1::common development scheme}}, and only some parcels have {{c2::negative servitudes}}, these restrictions may be impliedly binding against all subdivided parcels. 1.1 Purpose: Allows lot owners to {{c3::enforce restrictions on the use of property against other subdivision lot owners}}, typically through {{c4::injunction}}. 1.2 Exam note: This usually arises where an owner divides land into smaller lots to create a {{c5::common development scheme or subdivision}}. The reciprocal negative servitude is created by {{c6::implication}} if the following are met. 2. Requirements for creation by implication: 2.1 {{c7::Common scheme}}: The developer evidenced an intent to create a negative servitude under a common scheme for all subdivided parcels. 2.1.1 A common scheme may be evidenced by a {{c8::recorded plat}}, a {{c9::general pattern of restrictions}}, and/or {{c10::oral representations to early buyers}}. 2.2 {{c11::Notice}}: The owner of the subject lot had notice of the restriction in the deeds of other subdivision lots. 2.2.1 Notice may be one of three types: 2.2.1.1 {{c12::Actual notice}}: literal knowledge of the restriction. 2.2.1.2 {{c13::Inquiry notice}}: the neighborhood’s character indicates a common restriction. 2.2.1.3 {{c14::Record notice}}: the chain of title for the owner’s lot includes a prior deed containing a negative covenant or servitude.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: In criminal law, {{c1::vicarious liability}} is liability imposed on {{c2::one person for another’s criminal conduct}}, even though the person held liable may be {{c3::personally without fault}}. It most often arises in: • {{c4::Employment relationships}} (employers for employees); • {{c5::Business or corporate associations}} (corporations for acts of officers or agents); • Certain {{c6::statutory or regulatory schemes}} that spread responsibility to those in control. The law {{c7::imputes liability based on the relationship and control}} rather than on the liable person’s own mens rea.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. {{c1::Article I}} as the main source of congressional power 1.1 Article I of the Constitution provides most of Congress’s powers. 2. Core {{c2::enumerated powers}} to remember 2.1 {{c3::Taxing and spending}} power. 2.2 {{c4::Commerce}} power. 2.3 Power to establish uniform rules of {{c5::naturalization}} and {{c6::bankruptcy}}. 2.4 Power to {{c7::raise and support the military}} (armed forces). 3. Relationship to execution of the laws 3.1 Congress {{c8::enacts laws}} pursuant to its Article I powers. 3.2 The {{c9::executive branch}} is obligated to {{c10::execute the laws}} passed by Congress, but this is not itself a separate congressional power.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Carrying costs}} 1.1 Each co-tenant is responsible for his {{c2::fair share}} of carrying costs necessary to preserve the property or title, such as {{c3::property taxes, mortgage interest, and similar expenses}}. 1.2 A co-tenant who pays more than his share of carrying costs may seek {{c4::contribution}} from the other co-tenants. 2. {{c5::Repairs}} 2.1 A co-tenant who makes {{c6::reasonable, necessary repairs}} to the property may seek contribution from other co-tenants for their fair share. 2.2 Most courts require the repairing co-tenant to give {{c7::notice}} to the other co-tenants before performing the repairs as a condition of obtaining contribution. 3. {{c8::Improvements}} 3.1 {{c9::Voluntary improvements}} generally do {{c10::not}} give the improving co-tenant any right to {{c11::contribution}} from other co-tenants. 3.2 At {{c12::partition or sale}}, the improving co-tenant is entitled to {{c13::credit for any increase in value}} attributable to the improvement and must bear any {{c14::loss in value}} attributable to it. 3.3 Courts usually measure this credit or debit by the {{c15::change in market value}}, not by the {{c16::cost of the work}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Jury instructions}} 1.1 Parties may file requested jury instructions to be given to the jury during deliberations. Instructions are usually given to the jury at the {{c2::close of the evidence}}. 1.2 {{c3::Proposed instructions}}: before final arguments, the court gives the parties its proposed jury instructions. 1.3 {{c4::Objections}}: parties must have an opportunity to object before {{c5::final arguments}} and before the instructions are given to the jury. Failure to object in a timely manner {{c6::waives the issue for appeal}}. 2. {{c7::Jury verdicts}} 2.1 Court’s role: the court decides the {{c8::type of verdict}} to be used. 2.2 {{c9::General verdict}}: the jury finds for the {{c10::plaintiff or defendant}} and decides the amount of {{c11::damages or other relief}} due. 2.3 {{c12::Special verdict}}: the jury is asked to make specific {{c13::factual findings}}, and the court {{c14::applies the law to those facts}}. The court submits questions to the jury regarding each {{c15::ultimate fact}} and then makes legal conclusions based on the jury’s findings. Parties must object to proposed jury questions before the jury {{c16::deliberates}}. 2.4 {{c17::General verdict with interrogatories}}: the court may require a general verdict and also ask the jury to answer specific written questions concerning {{c18::ultimate facts}}. The purpose is to {{c19::ensure the jury properly considered important issues}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. General Rule 1.1 The defendant has a legal privilege to use {{c1::peaceful means}} to recover possession of {{c2::chattel taken unlawfully}}, and may use {{c3::reasonable, non-deadly force}} if in {{c4::fresh pursuit}} of the chattel-taker. 1.2 Recapture of chattels is also a defense to {{c5::assault, battery, and false imprisonment}}. 2. Limitations and Requirements 2.1 The defendant-owner must make a {{c6::timely demand}} for return of the chattel. 2.2 Exception to demand requirement: 2.2.1 A demand is not required if making the demand would be {{c7::futile or dangerous}}. 2.2.2 The defendant-owner may recapture from the {{c8::original wrongdoer}} or a {{c9::third person who knows}} the chattel was wrongfully obtained. 2.2.3 Recapture is {{c10::not available if the chattel is in the hands of an innocent party}}. 3. Use of Force 3.1 {{c11::Reasonable force}} may be used to recapture the chattel only if the defendant is in {{c12::fresh pursuit}} of one who has wrongfully obtained possession. 3.2 {{c13::No deadly force or force likely to cause serious bodily harm}} is permitted.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A {{c1::charitable trust}} is a trust that has the purpose of benefitting an {{c2::unascertained group of people or the public at large}}. Key features: - {{c3::Indefinite, unascertainable beneficiaries}} (not specific, identifiable individuals; a single qualifying charitable organization is allowed). - {{c4::Charitable purpose that benefits the public}}, based on the {{c5::effect of the gift, not the settlor’s motive}}; some {{c6::political-initiative}} trusts qualify, but not those {{c7::favoring a political party}}. - Can be {{c8::perpetual}} because the {{c9::Rule Against Perpetuities does not apply}}. - Can be {{c10::modified under cy pres}} to redirect property to a similar charitable purpose if the original purpose fails or becomes impractical.

subject: Torts
cloze: 1. Parent–child relationship: 1.1. {{c1::Parents are not vicariously liable}} for their children’s torts solely because of the parent–child relationship. 1.2. Parents may be {{c2::directly (independently) negligent}} if they: 1.2.1. Had reason to know of the child’s {{c3::dangerous propensities}}; or 1.2.2. {{c4::Facilitated or failed to supervise}}, enabling the tort. 2. Tavernkeepers and alcohol vendors: 2.1. Businesses serving alcohol may be liable to third parties injured by an intoxicated patron if the business was {{c5::negligent in serving the patron}}. 2.2. This often arises under {{c6::dram shop statutes}} or similar rules. 2.3. Common cases: serving a {{c7::visibly intoxicated patron}} or serving a {{c8::minor}} who later causes injury.

subject: Conflicts Of Law
cloze: 1. General Rule: Under the {{c1::Governmental Interest Approach}}, the court analyzes the {{c2::policies behind the conflicting laws in each forum}} and how those policies would be furthered by application to the case at hand. 1.1 How it works: 1.1.1 Courts start with the {{c3::presumption that the forum's law should apply}}. 1.1.2 The court may {{c4::examine the policies behind its laws and those of the other forum involved}}. 1.1.3 If another forum has an interest, the court will {{c5::reconsider the forum's policies to determine whether it has a legitimate interest in applying its own law}}. 1.1.4 The court may then apply the {{c6::other forum's laws, the forum's laws, or a modified version of either}}. 2. Substantive areas of law: The approach and analysis {{c7::do not vary or add additional factors based on specific areas of law}}. 2.1 Exam tip: If the Governmental Interest Approach arises on your exam, be prepared to {{c8::discuss each forum's interest in having its laws applied given the facts presented}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Possession rights}} 1.1 Each co-tenant has an {{c2::undivided right to possess the whole property}}; there is no right to an exclusive physical portion absent agreement. 1.2 No co-tenant has the right to {{c3::exclusive possession}} against the others unless there is an {{c4::ouster}}—conduct that actually excludes or clearly denies the others' right to possess. 2. {{c5::Rent and profits}} 2.1 {{c6::Own use}}: A co-tenant in exclusive possession is {{c7::not required to pay rent}} to, or reimburse, other co-tenants for his own use of the land, absent {{c8::ouster}} or an agreement to pay rent. 2.2 {{c9::Third-party rents}}: Each co-tenant has a right to {{c10::share proportionately in rents}} collected from third-party tenants. 2.3 {{c11::Depleting uses}}: Each co-tenant has a right to share in {{c12::profits from uses that deplete the property's value}} (e.g., timber, oil and gas, mining). 3. {{c13::Adverse possession between co-tenants}} 3.1 A co-tenant may not ordinarily acquire title to the exclusion of other co-tenants through adverse possession. 3.2 To adversely possess against co-tenants, the possessor must {{c14::actually oust the others or clearly repudiate the co-tenancy}} and then satisfy {{c15::all adverse possession elements}} for the {{c16::full statutory period}} after ouster or repudiation.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: 1. Overview of secured transactions 1.1. Secured transactions involve transactions based on {{c1::credit}} and are governed by {{c2::UCC Article 9}}. 1.2. One party (the {{c3::debtor}} ) receives something from another party (the {{c4::creditor or secured party}}) without paying immediately. 1.3. To ensure the debtor will pay eventually, the debtor gives the creditor rights to a piece of the debtor's property as {{c5::collateral}} (a {{c6::security interest}}). 2. Security interest and collateral 2.1. A {{c7::security interest}} is a right given to the creditor in the debtor's property. 2.2. {{c8::Collateral}} is the property in which the creditor obtains rights. 2.3. The security interest allows the creditor to {{c9::take or sell the collateral if the debtor defaults}}. 2.4. The arrangement is usually memorialized in a {{c10::security agreement}}. 3. Attaching and perfecting security interests 3.1. {{c11::Attachment}} is the process by which collateral is used to secure the creditor's interest. Once a security interest attaches, the creditor has a {{c12::right to take the collateral if the debtor defaults}}. 3.2. {{c13::Perfection}} is the process by which the creditor secures her rights in the collateral {{c14::as against third parties}}. When third parties also have an interest in the same collateral, the creditor must perfect her security interest to have {{c15::priority over those third parties}}.

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Purposeful availment}}: The defendant must {{c2::purposefully avail herself of the forum state's laws}}, i.e., reach out in a {{c3::non-accidental manner}}. Examples include {{c4::using the state’s roads, doing business in the state, or otherwise deliberately engaging with the forum}}. 2. {{c5::Foreseeability}}: The defendant must {{c6::know or reasonably anticipate that she could be held accountable for her activities in the forum state}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Buyer {{c1::breaches}} and the {{c2::buyer has the goods}}: 1. Damages: • Seller's damages = {{c3::contract price}}. 2. Situations where this arises: • Goods are {{c4::kept by the buyer}}; OR • Goods are {{c5::destroyed after risk of loss passes to the buyer}}; OR • Goods are {{c6::returned to the seller but the seller is unable to resell}} them. 3. Rationale: • The seller is entitled to the {{c7::full contract price}} when, in substance, the buyer has {{c8::consumed the benefit}} of the goods or made {{c9::resale effectively impossible}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Involuntary manslaughter}} is a killing committed with {{c2::criminal negligence}} or during the commission of an {{c3::unlawful act not constituting felony murder}}. 2. Criminal negligence: 2.1 Arises if the defendant is {{c4::grossly negligent}}. 2.2 Example: The defendant is {{c5::texting while driving}} and hits and kills a pedestrian in a crosswalk. 3. Commission of an unlawful act: 3.1 A killing caused by an {{c6::unlawful act}} may give rise to involuntary manslaughter. 3.2 Misdemeanors: A killing resulting from a misdemeanor will give rise to involuntary manslaughter if either: 3.2.1 The act was {{c7::inherently wrongful (malum in se)}}, or 3.2.2 Death was a {{c8::foreseeable or natural consequence}} of the misdemeanor act ({{c9::malum prohibitum}}). 3.3 Felonies: Any killing caused during the commission of a {{c10::felony not giving rise to felony murder}} will be at least involuntary manslaughter. 4. Exam note: If MBE questions simply state {{c11::"manslaughter"}} without distinguishing between voluntary and involuntary manslaughter, {{c12::both types must be considered}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Implied warranty of {{c1::merchantability}} in products liability: 1. General rule: In every {{c2::sale of goods}} by a {{c3::merchant who deals in goods of that kind}}, there is an implied warranty of merchantability. 2. Content of the warranty: 2.1 The seller warrants that the goods are of {{c4::average acceptable quality}} (i.e., without significant defects). 2.2 The goods must be generally {{c5::fit for their ordinary purpose}}. 3. Breach: If the goods are not of average acceptable quality or not fit for their ordinary purpose, the implied warranty of merchantability is {{c6::breached}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: {{c1::General intent crimes}} require that the defendant be {{c2::aware of his actions and any attendant circumstances}}, and the necessary intent may be {{c3::inferred from the doing of the act itself}}. Major common law general intent crimes: - {{c4::Battery}}. - {{c5::Rape}}. - {{c6::Kidnapping}}. - {{c7::False imprisonment}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. General Rule of Acceptance 1.1. Acceptance arises upon the offeree's {{c1::clear expression of assent}} to the terms of the offer. 1.2. The {{c2::offeror is the master of the offer}} and can dictate the {{c3::mode and manner}} by which an offer is accepted. 2. {{c4::Mirror-Image Rule}} (Common Law) 2.1. Under the mirror-image rule, acceptance must {{c5::mirror the offer's terms}}. 2.2. An acceptance cannot {{c6::add, omit, or change}} terms of the offer. 2.3. A response that varies the offer's terms is treated as a {{c7::counteroffer}}, not an acceptance.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Overview of {{c1::zoning power}}, {{c2::variances}}, and {{c3::nonconforming uses}}: 1. {{c4::Zoning power}} allows government to regulate land use under an {{c5::enabling act}}, but ordinances must serve the {{c6::public welfare}} and cannot be {{c7::overly restrictive}} or {{c8::racially discriminatory}}. 2. {{c9::Variances}} permit deviation from the literal zoning terms if the owner shows {{c10::undue hardship}} and that the variance is {{c11::not contrary to the public welfare}}. 3. {{c12::Nonconforming uses}} are once lawful uses made unlawful by new zoning and generally cannot be {{c13::eliminated immediately}} without {{c14::just compensation}}, though the government may use {{c15::amortization}} to phase them out.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 {{c1::Anticipatory repudiation}} arises when one party to a {{c2::contract}} makes it {{c3::clear}} that they will not perform under the contract. 1.2 Effect: Anticipatory repudiation {{c4::excuses performance}} by the other party. 2. Requirements (anticipatory repudiation arises if one party to a contract): 2.1 Makes an {{c5::unambiguous statement}} or engages in {{c6::unambiguous conduct}}. 2.2 Does so {{c7::prior to the time performance is due}} (i.e., before full performance is due). 2.3 Clearly {{c8::indicates they will not perform}}. 2.4 Example: A hires B to remodel A's kitchen. B is almost finished when A tells B she does not want the remodel and will not pay. B can treat the contract as {{c9::breached}}, which excuses B's obligation to continue working. 2.5 Note: Distinguish from {{c10::insecurity}}, which involves mere uncertainty regarding the other party's performance. 3. Withdrawal of repudiation 3.1 A repudiation can be {{c11::withdrawn}} unless the other party has either: 3.1.1 {{c12::Materially changed position}} in reliance on the repudiation; 3.1.2 {{c13::Cancelled the contract}} in response to the repudiation; or 3.1.3 Indicated they consider the repudiation to be {{c14::final}}. 4. Non-repudiating party's options (they may either): 4.1 Treat the anticipatory repudiation as a {{c15::total repudiation}} and {{c16::sue immediately}}. 4.2 {{c17::Suspend performance}} until the performance date is due and wait to sue. 4.3 Treat the repudiation as an {{c18::offer to rescind}} and treat the contract as {{c19::discharged}}. 4.4 {{c20::Ignore}} the repudiation and {{c21::urge the promisor to perform}}.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. Exceptions permitting retrial after jeopardy attaches 1.1. {{c1::Hung jury}}: If the jury cannot reach a verdict and is discharged, the defendant may be retried. 1.2. {{c2::Mistrial due to manifest necessity}}: 1.2.1. The defendant may be retried when there is a {{c3::manifest necessity}} to abort the original trial, such as when the defendant is too ill to continue or when a juror engages in serious misconduct. 1.2.2. The defendant may be retried if the trial is discontinued at the {{c4::defendant's request}} on grounds not constituting an {{c5::acquittal}}. 1.3. {{c6::Retrial after a successful appeal by the defendant}}: 1.3.1. The defendant can be retried after a successful appeal unless the basis for reversal was {{c7::insufficient evidence to support a guilty verdict}}. 1.4. {{c8::Breach of a plea bargain agreement}}: If the defendant breaches a plea agreement, the prosecution may reinstate original charges and retry the defendant. 1.5. {{c9::Separate sovereigns doctrine}}: 1.5.1. The defendant can be tried for the same conduct in {{c10::different states}}. 1.5.2. The defendant can be tried for the same conduct in both {{c11::federal and state court}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Larceny can arise with {{c1::found property}}. 1. {{c2::Lost or misplaced}} property - Larceny occurs if the finder: • Knows or can {{c3::reasonably ascertain}} the identity of the {{c4::true owner}} at the time of finding, and • Intends to {{c5::permanently deprive}} that owner by keeping the property. 2. {{c6::Abandoned}} property - Truly abandoned property—where the owner has intentionally {{c7::relinquished all rights}}—cannot be the subject of larceny. 3. Distinction - The key question is whether there is a {{c8::reasonably identifiable owner}} when the property is found. If so, and the finder decides to keep it permanently, larceny of found property can occur.

subject: Con Law
cloze: A {{c1::non-public forum}} is government property that is not, by {{c2::tradition or designation}}, a forum for public communication and that can be {{c3::closed to speech}}. Common examples include {{c4::military bases}}, {{c5::airport terminals}}, and {{c6::internal government office mail systems}}. In a non-public forum, the government may regulate speech if the regulation is {{c7::reasonably related}} to a {{c8::legitimate governmental purpose}} and is {{c9::viewpoint neutral}}. Content-neutrality is not required: the government may {{c10::allow some subjects but not others}}. However, once it opens a {{c11::subject}} to speech, it may not favor one {{c12::viewpoint}} over another on that subject. When a {{c13::limited/designated public forum}} is closed or restricted to certain types or classes of speech, further speech restrictions are evaluated under this {{c14::non-public forum}} standard.

subject: Secured Transactions
cloze: Primary methods of perfecting a {{c1::security interest (SI)}} under Article 9: 1. {{c2::Filing a financing statement}}: The most common method; requires correctly naming the debtor, identifying the secured party, adequately describing the collateral, and debtor authorization. 2. {{c3::Perfection by possession}}: The secured party may perfect by taking possession of many types of tangible or quasi-tangible collateral (e.g., goods, negotiable documents, and instruments), but not of most intangibles. 3. {{c4::Automatic perfection}} in limited situations, particularly for certain {{c5::purchase-money security interests (PMSIs)}}. 4. Special rule for {{c6::motor vehicles}} covered by a certificate of title: generally perfected by {{c7::notation of the lien on the certificate of title}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: If an intestate decedent dies with {{c1::no heirs at all}}—no surviving spouse, descendants, parents, or other qualifying relatives—the intestate estate {{c2::escheats to the state}} under a typical UPC-style system. {{c3::Escheat}} is the default rule to prevent property from remaining ownerless.

subject: Corporations
cloze: 1. Overview of corporate securities 1.1 Corporations obtain funding by issuing {{c1::securities}}, which are of two main types: {{c2::debt}} and {{c3::equity}}. 2. {{c2::Debt securities}} ({{c4::bonds}}) 2.1 Definition: With debt securities, the corporation {{c5::borrows funds from an outside creditor and promises to repay}} the creditor. 2.2 Holders of debt securities have {{c6::no ownership interest}} in the corporation. 3. {{c3::Equity securities}} ({{c7::stock}}) 3.1 Definition: Equity securities represent {{c8::investment in the corporation}}; holders (shareholders) become {{c9::part owners}} of the corporation. 3.2 {{c10::Authorized shares}}: The maximum number of shares the corporation may issue, as prescribed in the articles of incorporation. 3.3 {{c11::Issued/outstanding shares}}: Shares that have been sold to investors and are currently held by them. 3.4 {{c12::Reacquired shares}}: Shares that the corporation buys back; these revert from being issued/outstanding to {{c13::authorized but unissued}}. 4. {{c14::Classes of shares}} 4.1 Corporations may choose to issue different classes of stock; each class of shares can have different {{c15::series}} within a class. 5. Articles requirements for share classes 5.1 The {{c16::articles of incorporation}} must authorize each class and set forth: 5.1.1 The {{c17::number of shares}} of each class. 5.1.2 The {{c18::name or distinguishing designation}} for each class. 5.1.3 A description of the {{c19::rights, preferences, and/or limitations}} afforded to each class of shares.

subject: Con Law
cloze: Under the {{c1::Tenth Amendment}}, powers not granted to the {{c2::federal government}} nor prohibited to the {{c3::states}} are {{c4::reserved to the states}}. This limits Congress’s ability to {{c5::regulate or tax states as states}} and bars {{c6::commandeering}} of state legislative or executive processes by requiring states to enact laws or administer federal law. However, Congress may regulate states through {{c7::generally applicable laws}} that cover both public and private actors, may restrict state activities that violate {{c8::civil liberties and civil rights}} (including via the {{c9::Fourteenth Amendment}}), and may influence state policy through {{c10::conditional grants of federal funds}} that satisfy specific requirements.

subject: Contracts
cloze: {{c1::Mutual mistake}} occurs when {{c2::both parties}} are mistaken about the same underlying factual assumption at the time of contract formation. The contract is {{c3::voidable by an adversely affected party}} if: - {{c4::Both parties are mistaken}} concerning a {{c5::basic assumption of fact}}; - The mistake {{c6::materially affects}} the agreed-upon exchange; and - The adversely affected party did {{c7::not assume the risk}} of the mistake. Mnemonic: {{c8::BMA}} – Basic assumption, Material effect, no Assumption of risk.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Use of force to make arrests and prevent crimes depends on: 1. {{c1::Who is acting}} ({{c2::police}} vs. {{c3::private citizens}}) 2. {{c4::Level of force}} ({{c5::non-deadly}} vs. {{c6::deadly}}) 3. {{c7::Purpose}} ({{c8::effectuating an arrest}} vs. {{c9::preventing a crime}}, including {{c10::common-law}} vs. {{c11::modern}} crime‑prevention rules). Generally, {{c12::non-deadly force}} may be used as reasonably necessary to {{c13::effectuate an arrest}} or {{c14::prevent a serious breach of the peace}}, while {{c15::deadly force}} is limited to {{c16::fleeing felons who pose a serious threat to life}} and {{c17::dangerous, life‑threatening felonies}}.

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: Defense of others: 1. {{c1::Same rules as self-defense}}: - Defense of others generally follows the {{c2::same substantive rules}} as self-defense, including the non-deadly vs. deadly force framework. 2. {{c3::Reasonable belief standard}}: - The defendant may use force to protect another if he {{c4::reasonably believes}} that the person he is protecting could have {{c5::legally acted in self-defense}}. 3. {{c6::Apparent entitlement}}: - The modern rule focuses on the defendant's {{c7::reasonable belief}} in the third person’s entitlement to self-defense, even if that person was not actually entitled, so long as the belief was reasonable.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: 1. Definition of a trust 1.1 A trust is a {{c1::fiduciary relationship}} in which the {{c2::trustee}} holds {{c3::legal title}} to property for the benefit of {{c4::beneficiaries}}, who hold {{c5::equitable interests}}. 2. Key parties and roles 2.1 {{c6::Settlor}}: The person who creates the trust and transfers legal title to the trustee. 2.2 {{c7::Trustee}}: Holds legal title and {{c8::manages and administers}} trust property as a {{c9::fiduciary}}. 2.3 {{c10::Beneficiaries}}: Persons or entities for whose benefit the trust is administered. 3. Revocability 3.1 Under modern statutes, trusts are generally {{c11::revocable}} unless the terms expressly state that the trust is {{c12::irrevocable}}. 3.2 A {{c13::revocable trust}} allows the settlor to {{c14::modify or terminate}} the trust during life; an {{c15::irrevocable trust}} generally cannot be altered or revoked once created, absent appropriate consent or court approval.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. {{c1::Priority of creditors}} 1.1 Creditors must {{c2::record}} their interests. 1.2 Recorded interests generally take priority in the order in which they are {{c3::recorded}}. 1.3 {{c4::Purchase money mortgages (PMMs)}} are {{c5::superior to all other interests}} in the property. 1.4 A PMM is a mortgage given in exchange for funds used to {{c6::buy the property}}. 1.5 A PMM may be given either to the {{c7::seller}} as part of the purchase price or to a {{c8::third-party lender}}; if both exist, the {{c9::seller's PMM}} is senior to the {{c10::third-party lender's PMM}}. 1.6 Creditors can contractually agree to {{c11::subordinate}} their priority to a junior creditor.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: In federal court, the {{c1::Fifth Amendment}} generally requires a {{c2::grand jury}} for felony prosecutions to determine whether there is sufficient {{c3::probable cause}} to bring charges. The {{c4::prosecutor}} presents evidence, and the grand jury votes on whether to issue an {{c5::indictment}}. Grand jury proceedings are conducted in {{c6::secret}} and operate under special {{c7::procedural rules}} that sharply limit the {{c8::suspect’s rights}} and modify the usual trial protections for witnesses. Within grand jury proceedings, witnesses still retain the {{c9::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}}, may receive {{c10::immunity}} in exchange for testimony, and the {{c11::exclusionary rule does not apply}}—so an indictment can rest on evidence that would be {{c12::inadmissible at trial}}. Subtopics: 1) {{c13::Constitutional role}} of the grand jury in federal court. 2) {{c14::Procedural rules}} governing grand jury proceedings. 3) {{c15::Fifth Amendment privilege, immunity, and exclusionary rule limits}} in grand jury practice.

subject: Torts
cloze: Implied warranty claims in products liability: 1. Who can sue: 1.1 The {{c1::buyer}}. 1.2 The buyer's {{c2::family, household, and guests}} who suffer personal injury. 2. Elements: 2.1 {{c3::Warranty}}: Existence of an applicable implied warranty (merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose). 2.2 {{c4::Breach}}: The product fails to live up to the applicable warranty. 2.3 {{c5::Causation}}: {{c6::actual and proximate}} causation between breach and injury. 2.4 {{c7::Damages}}: {{c8::personal injury, property damage, and economic loss}} are all recoverable. 3. Defenses: 3.1 {{c9::Assumption of risk}}. 3.2 {{c10::Contributory negligence}} (where applicable). 3.3 {{c11::Comparative negligence}} (where applicable).

subject: Partnerships
cloze: A {{c1::limited partnership}} contains two types of partners, {{c2::general}} and {{c3::limited}} partners, and must contain one or more of each type. 1. {{c4::Rights, duties, and obligations}}: 1.1 {{c5::General partners}}: Manage and control day-to-day operations and owe the same {{c6::fiduciary duties}} as partners in a general partnership. 1.2 {{c7::Limited partners}}: Usually passive investors with limited authority. They owe {{c8::no fiduciary duties}} to the partnership, and unless the partnership agreement provides otherwise, they may {{c9::compete with the partnership}} and have interests {{c10::adverse to the partnership}}. 2. {{c11::Liability}}: 2.1 General partners: {{c12::Personally, jointly, and severally liable}} for all partnership obligations. Incoming general partners are not liable for obligations the partnership incurred before they became general partners. 2.2 Limited partners: Liable only to the extent of their {{c13::investment}}. 3. {{c14::Formation}}: A limited partnership is formed by {{c15::filing a certificate of limited partnership with the state}}. The certificate generally must contain the {{c16::names and addresses of each general partner}} and their {{c17::signatures}}.

subject: Contracts
cloze: Misunderstanding and mistake are defenses related to problems in the parties' understanding at the time of contract formation. 1. {{c1::Misunderstanding (ambiguity)}}: focuses on ambiguous terms and whether the parties attached the {{c2::same meaning}}, with different results depending on who is aware of the ambiguity. 2. {{c3::Mutual mistake}}: both parties share the {{c4::same mistaken belief about a basic factual assumption}}, which can make the contract {{c5::voidable by the adversely affected party}} if certain conditions are met. 3. {{c6::Unilateral mistake}}: only one party is mistaken; the contract generally remains enforceable, but in limited circumstances the {{c7::mistaken party}} may {{c8::void the contract}}.

subject: Torts
cloze: Nuisance – remedies and defense: 1. Remedies: • {{c1::Money damages}} to compensate for interference with use or enjoyment. • {{c2::Injunctive relief}} to abate, limit, or prevent the nuisance, especially where harm is ongoing or damages are inadequate. 2. Defense – {{c3::"coming to the nuisance"}}: • A plaintiff generally cannot recover if he {{c4::came to the nuisance}}, e.g., by {{c5::purchasing property next to a long‑existing smelting plant}} that creates the complained‑of interference.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: To determine whether a search or seizure is valid under the Fourth Amendment, use a structured approach: 1. {{c1::General rule}}: Government searches and seizures of evidence must be {{c2::reasonable}} under the {{c3::Fourth Amendment}}. 2. {{c4::Applicability}}: Is there qualifying {{c5::government conduct}} (including private actors directed by government agents), rather than {{c6::purely private conduct}}? 3. {{c7::Standing}}: Does the defendant have a {{c8::reasonable expectation of privacy}} in the place or item searched? 4. {{c9::Warrant vs. exceptions}}: Was there a valid {{c10::search warrant}}? If not, must the search be justified by a {{c11::recognized warrant exception}} (e.g., {{c12::search incident to arrest}}, {{c13::plain view}}, {{c14::automobile search}}, {{c15::consent}}, {{c16::exigent circumstances}}, or {{c17::stop and frisk}})?

subject: Criminal Law
cloze: 1. Defense of dwelling 1.1 {{c1::Non-deadly force}}: allowed to {{c2::prevent or terminate an unlawful entry or attack on one's dwelling}}. 1.2 {{c3::Deadly force}}: may be used if one reasonably believes 1.2.1 Force is necessary to {{c4::prevent an attack on oneself or others}} by a person who made or attempted a {{c5::violent entry}}; or 1.2.2 Force is necessary to {{c6::prevent entry by a person who intends to commit a felony in the dwelling}}. 2. Defense of property (non-dwelling) 2.1 {{c7::Deadly force is not allowed}}. 2.2 {{c8::Non-deadly force}} may be used if {{c9::reasonably necessary to defend against unlawful interference with possessions or trespass on property}}. 2.3 The need to use force must {{c10::reasonably appear imminent}}; force is not permitted if a {{c11::request to desist would be sufficient}}. 3. Recovery of property 3.1 Force is not allowed to regain property wrongfully taken, unless one is in {{c12::immediate pursuit}} of the taker. 3.2 Example: D steals A's purse; A can only use {{c13::reasonable force}} to recover the purse if she is {{c14::immediately pursuing}} D.

subject: Contracts
cloze: 1. In general 1.1 In order to enforce rights under a contract, a {{c1::third-party beneficiary's (TPB's) rights must vest}}. 1.2 {{c2::Vesting}} of rights occurs when the TPB does any of the following: 1.2.1 {{c3::Accepts benefits}}: accepts the benefits of the contract in a manner requested by the parties to the contract. 1.2.2 {{c4::Sues to enforce}}: brings suit to enforce the contract. 1.2.3 {{c5::Detrimental reliance}}: detrimentally relies on the contract (i.e., materially changes position in justifiable reliance on the contract). 2. Enforcing the contract 2.1 A TPB can sue the {{c6::promisor}}. 2.2 The promisor can assert any of his own {{c7::defenses}}. 2.3 The {{c8::promisee}} can sue the promisor at law and in equity for {{c9::specific performance}}. 2.4 A {{c10::creditor beneficiary}} can sue the promisee on the {{c11::existing obligation}} between them. 2.5 A {{c12::donee beneficiary}} may only sue the promisee if {{c13::detrimental reliance}} exists.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. General rule: Before and during marriage, each spouse {{c1::owns and controls their own property}}, but property acquired during marriage may become owned as a {{c2::tenancy by the entirety}}. 1.1 {{c3::Tenancy by the entirety}}: In many states, where spouses take title to real property jointly, a tenancy by the entirety is {{c4::presumptively created}}. If the marriage is dissolved, the parties hold the property as {{c5::tenants in common}}. 1.2 {{c6::Spousal support obligation}}: Each spouse has an obligation to {{c7::support the other}}, and one spouse may be held liable for the other spouse's purchases. Under {{c8::agency principles}}, one spouse can be held liable to third parties for purchases made by the other spouse where {{c9::expressly or impliedly authorized}}. 1.3 {{c10::Necessaries doctrine}}: One spouse may be held liable to creditors for {{c11::necessaries}} purchased by the other spouse, such as food, medical care, shelter, and clothing.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Lateral and {{c1::subjacent support}} protect a landowner’s right to have land, in its {{c2::natural state}}, physically supported by neighboring or underlying estates. 1. {{c3::Lateral support}} (side support) - Ownership of land includes the right to have the land, in its natural state, supported by {{c4::adjoining land}}. - An adjoining owner who {{c5::excavates}} can be liable if removal of support causes {{c6::subsidence}} of the neighboring land or damage to its structures. 2. {{c7::Subjacent support}} (under-surface support) - Subjacent support concerns {{c8::underground structures}}—such as {{c9::mines, tunnels, or parking garages}}—that must support the {{c10::surface estate}}. - Subjacent owners owe {{c11::strict liability}} duties to support the surface land and pre-existing structures, and can be liable in {{c12::negligence}} for damage to later-constructed buildings.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The First Amendment limits what kinds of {{c1::damages}} defamation plaintiffs can recover. 1. {{c2::Public figures or public officials}}: - With proof of {{c3::actual malice}}, may recover {{c4::compensatory damages}}. - With proof of {{c5::actual malice}}, may also recover {{c6::punitive damages}} where state law allows. 2. {{c7::Private figures}}: 2.1 {{c8::Matters of public concern}}: - At least {{c9::negligence}} must be shown for {{c10::actual (compensatory) damages}}. - {{c11::Actual malice}} is required for {{c12::presumed or punitive damages}}. 2.2 {{c13::Purely private-concern}} matters: - The state may allow {{c14::presumed or punitive damages}} on a lesser showing, consistent with state law. - But at minimum, {{c15::negligence}} is typically required.

subject: Con Law
cloze: 1. Application (how {{c1::Equal Protection}} applies to federal, state, and local governments): 1.1 The {{c2::14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause}} applies directly to {{c3::state and local governments}}. 1.2 Equal Protection applies to the {{c4::federal government}} by incorporation through the {{c5::5th Amendment Due Process Clause}} (the Equal Protection Clause does not apply directly to the federal government). 1.3 The same Equal Protection {{c6::analysis and levels of scrutiny}} apply whether Equal Protection is applied through the 5th or 14th Amendment. 2. Analysis (if you see anything that could implicate Equal Protection, ask): 2.1 Is there a {{c7::discriminatory classification}}? To receive {{c8::heightened scrutiny}}, a discriminatory classification must be proved. 2.2 What {{c9::level of scrutiny}} applies given the classification? 2.2.1 {{c10::Suspect classifications}} receive {{c11::strict scrutiny}}. 2.2.2 {{c12::Quasi-suspect classifications}} receive {{c13::intermediate scrutiny}}. 2.2.3 All other alleged classifications receive {{c14::rational basis}} review. 2.3 Does the classification satisfy the appropriate level of scrutiny?

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. Timing of certification 1.1 The court must determine at an {{c1::early practicable time}} whether to allow the case to proceed as a {{c2::class action}} (i.e., certify the class). 2. Requirements upon certification 2.1 If a class is certified, the court must: 2.1.1 Define the {{c3::class}} (i.e., who can be a class member), and the class {{c4::claims, issues, and defenses}}; and 2.1.2 Appoint {{c5::class counsel}}. 2.2 Class counsel must {{c6::fairly and adequately represent}} the interests of the class as a whole.

subject: Family Law
cloze: 1. Spousal support in annulment: • Many states allow {{c1::temporary spousal support}} (alimony pendente lite) while an annulment suit is pending. • {{c2::Fewer states}} allow {{c3::ongoing or post-annulment spousal support}} once the marriage has been declared invalid. • Where permitted, post-annulment support usually depends on {{c4::statutory provisions}} and factors similar to those in {{c5::divorce}} (such as need and ability to pay). 2. Property division on annulment: • Most courts attempt to divide property so as to place the parties, as nearly as possible, in the {{c6::positions they occupied before the marriage commenced}}. • Courts often treat property acquired during the putative marriage under {{c7::equitable principles}}, sometimes analogizing to {{c8::partnership or joint ownership}}. • Some jurisdictions have specific {{c9::statutory schemes}} for property rights after annulment, especially where there was a {{c10::good-faith belief in the validity}} of the marriage.

subject: Partnerships
cloze: In partnership law, there are two key end-of-relationship concepts: 1. {{c1::Dissociation}} (partner leaves, partnership may continue): - A dissociation occurs when a partner ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership business. - It can be triggered by {{c2::withdrawal, agreed events, valid expulsion, bankruptcy}}, or similar events. - Dissociation ends the partner’s rights to {{c3::profits}} and {{c4::management}} and cuts off {{c5::fiduciary duties going forward}}, while duties remain for pre-dissociation matters. - If the partnership continues, it must {{c6::buy out the dissociated partner’s interest}}. 2. {{c7::Dissolution}} (partnership ends as a going concern): - Dissolution is the {{c8::termination of the partnership as a going concern}}. - It may be triggered by {{c9::agreed events, expiration of a term, judicial decree, or a partner’s notice in an at-will partnership}}. - After dissolution, the partnership exists only to {{c10::wind up}}, {{c11::liquidate assets}}, pay {{c12::creditors first}}, and then {{c13::distribute remaining assets to partners}}.

subject: Real Property
cloze: If the {{c1::buyer or seller}} dies after execution of a {{c2::land sale contract}} but before {{c3::closing}}, {{c4::equitable conversion}} controls how their interests pass. The {{c5::seller}} holds a {{c6::personal property}} interest in the {{c7::sale proceeds}}, so on the seller’s death this passes as {{c8::personalty}} and the seller’s estate can sue for the {{c9::sale proceeds}}. The {{c10::buyer}} holds an {{c11::equitable real property}} interest in the {{c12::land}}, so on the buyer’s death this passes as {{c13::realty}} and the buyer’s estate can sue for {{c14::delivery of the property}} (specific performance).

subject: Civil Procedure
cloze: 1. The plaintiff’s complaint must make a {{c1::good-faith allegation}} that the amount of damages or injury in controversy {{c2::exceeds $75,000}}, excluding {{c3::interest and costs}}. 2. Lenient standard for dismissal: 2.1. To dismiss for insufficient amount in controversy, there must be {{c4::no legal possibility}} that recovery will exceed $75,000. 2.2. The amount actually awarded is {{c5::irrelevant}}. 3. Equitable relief claims: 3.1. The court looks at the {{c6::value of the harm}} caused. 3.2. The court may view the amount either from the {{c7::plaintiff’s perspective}} or the {{c8::defendant’s perspective}}: 3.2.1. Does the act requiring injunctive relief harm the plaintiff by more than $75,000? 3.2.2. Or would it cost the defendant more than $75,000 to comply with the injunction sought? 4. Aggregating claims to meet $75,000: 4.1. One plaintiff can {{c9::aggregate all of her claims}} against a single defendant. 5. Multiple plaintiffs or multiple defendants: 5.1. Aggregation is allowed only if either: 5.1.1. One plaintiff has {{c10::joint liability claims}} against multiple defendants—use the total value of the jointly liable claim; and/or 5.1.2. Multiple plaintiffs seek to enforce a {{c11::single title or right}} in which they have a {{c12::common, undivided interest}} (rare), such as several plaintiffs jointly owning real estate and suing the defendant to quiet title.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. {{c1::Secrecy}} 1.1 Grand jury proceedings are conducted in {{c2::secret}}. 2. {{c3::Suspect’s rights}} 2.1 The suspect (target) has **no right** to {{c4::attend}} grand jury proceedings. 2.2 The suspect has **no right** to {{c5::confront or cross-examine witnesses}} before the grand jury. 3. {{c6::Witness rights and limits}} 3.1 Witnesses are **not entitled** to {{c7::Miranda warnings}} because the grand jury is not considered {{c8::custodial interrogation}}. 3.2 Witnesses may **not** {{c9::challenge a subpoena}} to testify before the grand jury on the ground that the government lacks probable cause or is using inadmissible evidence. 3.3 Witnesses do **not** have a {{c10::right to counsel inside the grand jury room}}. 3.4 Witnesses may, however, {{c11::leave the room to consult with counsel outside}} before answering questions.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: Inter vivos and testamentary trusts: Trusts are generally created {{c1::inter vivos}} (during the settlor's life) or as {{c2::testamentary trusts}} (trusts created by will). 1. {{c3::Inter vivos trusts}} 1.1 {{c4::Transfer of property}}: The property owner transfers property to another as trustee. 1.2 {{c5::Declaration of trust}}: The property owner declares himself trustee for another. 1.3 {{c6::Delivery}}: If the property owner names another as trustee (i.e., the settlor is not the trustee), the property must be delivered to the trustee. 1.4 {{c7::Formalities}}: A writing is not required, but an {{c8::oral trust}} and its terms can only be established by {{c9::clear and convincing evidence}}. 1.5 {{c10::Land as trust property}}: A {{c11::writing}} is required under the {{c12::Statute of Frauds}} when {{c13::land}} is trust property. 2. {{c14::Testamentary trusts}} 2.1 A testamentary trust is a trust created by {{c15::will}}. 2.2 Trust intent, essential terms, and identification of beneficiaries must be ascertainable by either: 2.2.1 The terms of the {{c16::will itself}}; 2.2.2 {{c17::Incorporation by reference}} of an existing writing properly incorporated by reference into the will; or 2.2.3 A {{c18::power of appointment}} exercised under the will. 3. {{c19::Pour-over provisions}} 3.1 A pour-over provision is a provision in a will that {{c20::devises property to a previously existing trust}}. 3.2 A pour-over provision {{c21::does not create a trust}}. 3.3 It simply {{c22::transfers property}} to an existing trust.

subject: Real Property
cloze: 1. In general: A {{c1::leasehold tenancy}} is an estate in which the {{c2::tenant}} has a {{c3::present possessory interest}} in the property and the {{c4::landlord}} has a {{c5::future interest (reversion)}}. 2. Four leasehold estates: 2.1 {{c6::Tenancy for years}}: 2.1.1 Lasts for a {{c7::fixed period of time}}. 2.1.2 Requires a {{c8::definite beginning and end date}}. 2.1.3 If the duration is {{c9::longer than one year}}, the lease must be {{c10::in writing under the Statute of Frauds}}. 2.1.4 {{c11::Terminates automatically}} at the end of the fixed period. 2.1.5 {{c12::No notice}} of termination is required. 2.1.6 Also referred to as an {{c13::estate for years}}. 2.2 {{c14::Periodic tenancy}}: A tenancy that repeats for successive periods (for example, month to month) until properly terminated. 2.3 {{c15::Tenancy at will}}: A tenancy with {{c16::no fixed duration}} that either party can terminate at any time (subject to any required reasonable notice or demand to vacate). 2.4 {{c17::Tenancy at sufferance}}: A tenancy that arises when a tenant {{c18::wrongfully holds over}} after termination of a lease ({{c19::holdover tenant}}).

subject: Family Law
cloze: Premarital agreements ({{c1::prenups}}) are {{c2::contracts}} between {{c3::prospective spouses}} that alter {{c4::default state law rules}} governing {{c5::property and support}} at {{c6::divorce or death}}. The {{c7::marriage itself}} is considered sufficient {{c8::consideration}} to support the agreement. Many states follow the {{c9::Uniform Premarital Agreement Act (UPAA)}}, which sets out {{c10::what may be included}} in a premarital contract and the {{c11::framework for validity and enforcement}}.

subject: Trusts And Estates
cloze: A gift provided in a will {{c1::lapses}} where the beneficiary {{c2::predeceases the testator}}. Absent application of an {{c3::anti-lapse statute}}, the gift will go back into the {{c4::residue}} of the testator's estate. 1. {{c5::Anti-lapse statutes}}: a gift that would otherwise lapse vests in the predeceased beneficiary's {{c6::descendants}}, who become substitutes. 1.1 Application: the lapsed gift will be saved if the predeceased beneficiary was: 1.1.1 A {{c7::relative of the testator}} (usually descendants only). 1.1.2 And {{c8::had descendants}}. 1.2 Who may be substituted: some states allow only the testator's {{c9::descendants}}, while others (and the {{c10::UPC}}) allow any of the testator's {{c11::relatives}}. 2. {{c12::Lapse in the residue}}: this can arise where a bequest is made to a person who predeceases the testator and the anti-lapse statute does not apply (e.g., the predeceased beneficiary was not the testator's relative). 2.1 {{c13::Common law}}: the lapsed gift passes to the testator's heirs via {{c14::intestacy}}. 2.2 {{c15::Modern view}}: {{c16::residuary beneficiaries}} who survive the testator and the deceased beneficiary take the deceased beneficiary's share. 3. {{c17::Class gifts}}: 3.1 If a will makes a gift to a class of people and a class member predeceases the testator, {{c18::surviving class members}} take the predeceased member's gift absent an alternative provision in the testator's will. 3.2 Exception: if an anti-lapse statute applies to the predeceasing class member (e.g., the predeceased was the testator's relative and has surviving descendants), the gift vests in the {{c19::predeceased member's descendants}}, not the class.

subject: Real Property
cloze: Special RAP considerations often arise with: (1) contingent interests like {{c1::options and rights of first refusal}}, (2) {{c2::class gifts}} (including the {{c3::Rule of Convenience}}), and (3) classic hypotheticals such as {{c4::age contingencies beyond 21}}, the {{c5::fertile octogenarian}}, and the {{c6::charity-to-charity exception}}.

subject: Con Law
cloze: The {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}} (or {{c2::negative Commerce Clause}}) is an {{c3::implied limit on state power}} derived from the {{c4::Commerce Clause}}. 1. Even when {{c5::Congress has not acted}}, state laws may not {{c6::unduly burden interstate commerce}}. 2. The Dormant Commerce Clause limits {{c7::state laws that burden interstate commerce}} by {{c8::interfering with Congress’s commerce power}}.

subject: Evidence
cloze: A {{c1::hearsay}} statement is admissible if, at the time it was made, it was against the {{c2::pecuniary, proprietary, penal, or legal interests}} of the declarant. 1. Requirements for {{c3::statement against interest}} (statement is admissible if): 1.1 Declarant is currently {{c4::unavailable}}. 1.2 The statement was contrary to the declarant's {{c5::pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest}} when made. 1.3 A {{c6::reasonable person}} would not have made the statement unless he believed it to be true. 1.4 In {{c7::criminal cases}}, there must also be {{c8::corroborating circumstances}} indicating the {{c9::trustworthiness}} of the statement. 2. Distinguish from {{c10::party-opponent admissions}}: 2.1 A party-opponent admission is a statement of a {{c11::party}} or a {{c12::vicarious statement attributable to that party}}. 2.2 There is {{c13::no requirement that the statement is against the declarant's interest}}. 2.3 A statement against interest is any statement against the {{c14::declarant's interest at the time it was made}}. 2.4 There is {{c15::no requirement that the declarant is a party}} in the proceeding.

subject: Criminal Procedure
cloze: 1. The {{c1::Fourth Amendment}} only applies if a person has a {{c2::reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP)}} in the place or thing searched and/or the items seized. 2. {{c3::Standing}} to challenge a government search requires a REOP, determined by the {{c4::totality of the circumstances}}. 3. REOP is limited: there is {{c5::no REOP in inherently public information or in areas outside the home’s curtilage}}, but REOP is {{c6::automatically recognized in certain strong home-related situations}} (ownership/possession/residence/overnight guest).

subject: Real Property
cloze: Upon a mortgagor's default, the {{c1::mortgagee}} may: (1) {{c2::foreclose and have the property sold}}, potentially seeking a {{c3::deficiency judgment}} or distributing any {{c4::surplus}} to {{c5::junior lienholders}}; (2) respect the mortgagor’s {{c6::equitable right of redemption}} before sale and, in some jurisdictions, a {{c7::statutory right of redemption}} after sale; (3) accept a {{c8::deed in lieu of foreclosure}} if the arrangement is {{c9::fair and reasonable}}; and (4) seek {{c10::possession}} depending on whether the jurisdiction follows {{c11::lien}}, {{c12::title}}, or {{c13::intermediate}} theory, or by {{c14::consent}} or {{c15::abandonment}}, while bearing duties to {{c16::account for rents}}, {{c17::manage the property}}, and potential {{c18::tort liability}}.
